title: A Historic Transition in Mexico
description: The inauguration of Vicente Fox Quesada as Mexico's president today is a hopeful watershed in that nation's history, one that may someday be deemed as significant as Mexico's early-19th-century independence from Spain or its early-20th-century revolution. It marks the first peaceful transfer of power from one political faction to another in modern Mexican history, as the Institutional Revolutionary Party ends its 71-year rule. Mexico's 100 million people have reclaimed their government, and now look to Mr. Fox to consolidate their democracy.

title: Metro Business Briefing; COMPANY TO CUT JOBS
description: A Long Island video-game software company, Acclaim Entertainment Inc., said yesterday that it lost $131.7 million in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, from delays in introducing new products, and that it would cut costs through measures including staff reductions. The company, based in Glen Cove, said its losses compared with net income of $36 million in fiscal year 1999. Revenue fell 56 percent to $188.6 million, compared with $431 million in 1999. The company said cost cutting should reduce operating expenses by 30 percent, or $130 million, in fiscal 2001.

title: GENERIC DRUG MAKERS SUE OVER BRISTOL-MYERS PATENT
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals and Mylan Laboratories filed separate lawsuits yesterday to block a new patent on a Bristol-Myers Squibb anxiety drug. The patent would delay introduction of generic versions of the drug, buspirone, sold under the trade name BuSpar. Watson and Mylan had expected the Food and Drug Administration to approve different dosages of generic buspirone last week. Instead, Bristol-Myers announced on Nov. 21 that it had received a patent that would extend its exclusive right to sell the treatment.

title: DELL TO OFFER A LINUX SYSTEM
description: Dell Computer plans to make an investment in a small Silicon Valley developer of Linux software. The company, Eazel Inc., which was founded by three of the original members of the Apple Macintosh design team, has developed a program called Nautilus that is intended to make the Linux operating system more accessible to nonspecialist computer users. Besides the Nautilus software, Eazel has developed several commercial services, including a software catalog and an online data storage system. The company said it intended to simplify greatly the task of installing Linux and other open source software. Dell will include Eazel software and services with computers that it ships with the Linux operating system. Terms of the investment were not disclosed, but Eazel executives said the computer maker had made ''a significant investment'' in the company, based in Mountain View, Calif. It now has 70 employees and had previously raised $14 million. John Markoff (NYT)

Because the baby girl is remarkably happy and outgoing for an infant who was left abandoned in the woods, she melts the hearts of everyone who comes in contact with her.

The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, abandoned its claim that an air traffic controller was partly responsible for the crash of Flight 1420 at the Little Rock airport in a heavy thunderstorm on June 1, 1999. American has settled more than 50 lawsuits related to the crash and has been ordered by federal juries to pay $17.5 million to two passengers who survived it.

title: C.I.A. Shuts Down Chat Room
description: WASHINGTON -- The CIA has fired four employees and reprimanded dozens of others for participating in a secret chat room hidden in the agency's computer system, The Washington Post reported Friday. The newspaper said the disciplinary action was described as the largest in the agency's history, and followed a seven-month investigation that involved 160 employees and delved into activities going back 15 years. The CIA issued a statement that said the investigation found no ``unauthorized disclosure of classified information.'' A memo to all employees said investigators uncovered ``a concerted and sustained effort on the part of a group of individuals to create, maintain and hide databases on the agency's computer systems.'' The agency's statement said four employees were stripped of security clearances, ``rendering them ineligible for continued CIA employment,'' the Post reported. Eighteen others received letters of reprimand. ``Most of them will be suspended without pay for periods ranging from five to 45 days,'' the agency said. Nine contractors also were stripped of security clearances, which means they cannot work on CIA contracts, the statement said. Seventy-nine other CIA employees with ``minimal involvement'' in the computer scheme received either warning letters or security briefings. But former CIA employees with firsthand knowledge of the secret chat rooms told the newspaper that the disciplinary actions were an overreaction by CIA management. Ross Stapleton-Gray, a former CIA analyst who participated in the covert communications channels when he worked at the agency from 1988 to 1994, said those involved were primarily computer-savvy employees who enjoyed a sense of community with other ``techies.'' The agency said the first secret chat room was created as an ``unofficial user's group'' on the CIA's mainframe computer in the mid-1980s. ``Over the years, as the agency migrated to new information systems, the hidden databases were moved to take advantage of these new systems,'' the statement said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVAL, APEL, DR. NAOMI MILLER
description: COVAL-APEL-Dr. Naomi Miller. A noted New York dentist who did pioneering work on tempro-mandibular joint dysfunction and later specialized in orthodontics, died November 24 after a long illness at her home in Glen Cove, Long Island. She was surrounded by her husband, Robert Apel, and her three children Ilya, Payson and Larry. Dr. Coval-Apel's dental practice spanned 47 years. She received her BA from the University of Chicago in 1939 and her DDS from Columbia University in 1943. In order to encourage women to have a career in dentistry, she lectured frequently to many professional organizations around the world. She received numerous awards, including one from the Oral Hygiene Committee of Greater New York and also from the British Society for the Study of Orthodontics. She was past-president of the Five Towns Auxiliary of Peninsula General Hospital; Vice President of Five Town B'nai Brith; President of Five Towns American Jewish Congress and many other organizations. Dr. Coval-Apel was also an accomplished sculptor, jeweler, and poet. All the vicissitudes of youth, all the stresses of building a career, all the agonies of rearing children are worth the journey, when one sails towards the finishing line with a magnificent spouse who is one's best friend.

description: HADDEN-Samuel T. Of Simsbury, Connecticut, died on November 29, 2000.He was 11 years old and had faced innumerable physical challenges with heroism, humor, grace and dignity. Without words he spoke his truth eloquently. He personified the finest elements of the human spirit and inspired others to reach for his example. Sam is survived by his parents Sara and David Hadden, his brother Jamie and his sister Liza. He was beloved by his grandparents Sarah R. and the late Hamilton Hadden, Jr., and Jeanne C. and John R. H. Blum. He had 27 cousins and 16 aunts and uncles. A lover of music, Sammy, lived with his brother Jamie at a group home in Bloomfield, CT. run by the Greater Hartford Association for Retarded Citizens. He touched the lives of all who knew him, especially the wonderful caregivers at his HARC home, as well as his teachers and friends at school in Simsbury. Calling hours will be from 5-7PM at the Taylor and Modeen Funeral Home, 136 So. Main St., W. Hartford, CT. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, December 2, 10AM at the Universalist Church of West Hartford, 433 Fern St., W. Hartford, Ct. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Greater Hartford Association for Retarded Citizens, 900 Asylum Av, Hartford, CT. 06105 in memory of Sam and in honor of his extraordinary and devoted caregivers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, MARTIN MCGREGOR
description: HORNER-Martin McGregor. Of Orient, New York and Riviera Beach, Florida died suddenly at home in Florida on November 25, 2000. He was born February 25, 1924 in Newark, New Jersey and was a graduate of Phillips Academy Andover (1942) and Princeton University (1946). He served as an ensign in the U.S. Navy in World War II. He is survived by his brother Stephen Horner, his daughter Petria Fossel, his sons J.W. Maitland Horner and Martin Horner, his stepdaughter Linda Jesel, his stepson Alan Tramposch, nine grandchildren and five step-grandchildren. His daughter Sylvia Baker and his wife Dorothy Horner predeceased him. Funeral services will be private. Memorial services will be held at a later date in both Florida and Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Martin's name to Princeton University, Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543 or The American Cancer Society, 2200 Lake Boulevard, Atlanta, GA. 30319.

title: MACFARLANE RAISES OFFER FOR BRITISH POLYTHENE BY 24%
description: The Macfarlane Group, a British packaging maker, increased its hostile offer for British Polythene Industries yesterday by 24 percent to $:196 million (pounds) ($278.8 million), the equivalent of 310 pence ($4.42) a share. Macfarlane would also assume $:79 million in debt and pay British Polythene's shareholders a scheduled first-half dividend of 7 pence a share. Last week, British Polythene had offered to buy back 30 percent of its shares at 320 pence. It declined to comment on Macfarlane's sweetened offer.

title: John Lennon, a Lad; Paul McCartney, a Grown-Up
description: On the NBC Web site for ''In His Life: The John Lennon Story,'' it is possible to enter an auction bid for a brick from Lennon's boyhood home, where some of the film was shot. Each brick, the site promises, will come with a certificate of authenticity, and a portion of the income will go to the Strawberry Field Children's Home in Liverpool, an orphanage whose name existed long before the song.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the jazz musician Chick Corea misspelled the name of the club in Buffalo where he performed on Monday. It is Tralfamadore, not Tralfamador.

title: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AGREES TO ACQUIRE OXFORD FUND
description: Apartment Investment and Management, the second-largest owner of apartments in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $206 million in securities for the Oxford Tax-Exempt Fund, which owns bonds and other debt secured by apartments. Apartment Investment will pay $28.20 in preferred and common stock for each unit of Oxford. Two months ago, Apartment Investment, based in Denver, bought a controlling stake in the Oxford Realty Financial Group, which among other things manages Oxford's day-to-day operations, for $856 million. Oxford is based in Bethesda, Md.

title: Looking at Higher Education, Report Finds Vast Differences Among States
description: High school students in Nebraska are twice as likely as those in Alabama to take mathematics courses designed to prepare them for college. Young people in North Dakota are twice as likely as those in Nevada to enroll in college. And because of differences in state tuition, Vermont families must spend nearly 40 percent of their annual income to send a child to a state university, compared with families in Utah, where the figure is 17 percent.

title: As the Battle Between the Tabloids Intensifies, So Do The Post's Labor Woes
description: Executives at The Daily News say they will continue to publish their free afternoon newspaper into next year in an effort to keep pressure on The New York Post. The Post, meanwhile, has had its circulation jump by 50,000 on weekdays after halving its newsstand price in response to the free paper.

title: A Sense of Justice Emerges From a Rapper's Mayhem
description: ''Let the man who's free from sin cast the first stone,'' Everlast sang during his genial performance on Tuesday at the Bowery Ballroom. Like any child who grew up dreading the darkness of a confessional, this Irish-American hip-hop star has an acute sense of justice. It surfaced in the songs from his two most recent albums, which have made him a noble figure on the hip-hop scene. And it marked his stage patter, which reflected a current feud and a long-lost love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIN, GLADYS TALMAGE
description: PERKIN-Gladys Talmage. On Tuesday, November 28, 2000, at home in New Canaan, Conn. Age 93. Beloved wife of the late Richard Scott Perkin, a founder of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. Born Gladys Frelinghuysen Talmage on May 13, 1907, she was the daughter of Mr & Mrs John Frelinghuysen Talmage, of Brooklyn Heights and East Hampton, Long Island. She was a descendant of Captain Thomas Talmage, a founder of East Hampton in 1648, and Philip Rhinelander, 18th Century New York Merchant. She attended Pine Manor College and Pratt Institute and, in 1930, married investment banker, Richard S. Perkin. In 1937, she assisted him in the formation of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, which became a leading manufacturer of optical systems and scientific instruments. Following Mr Perkin's death in 1969, Gladys Perkin devoted her life to philanthropy. As Chairman of The Perkin Fund, she supported the American Museum of Natural History, The Boston Academy of Music, Harvard's Center for Blood Research, The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, The Juilliard School, The New England Conservatory, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Norwalk Hospital, Rockefeller University, The Waveny Care Center and The Wildlife Conservation Society. In 1980, Pratt Institute awarded her the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. A long time member of the New Canaan Garden Club, Mrs Perkin also served for many years on the Visiting Committee of Harvard's Department of Astronomy and as a member of the Rockefeller University Council. Gladys Perkin is survived by three of her children, Richard T. Perkin of New York, Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, Mass., and Robert S. Perkin of Darien, Conn. Her son, John T. Perkin, died in 1997. She also leaves nine grandchildren, two great grandchildren and her brother, Theodore Frelinghuysen Talmage of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Funeral services will be held at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge(Route 124), New Canaan, Conn at 11:00AM, on Monday, December 4. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to St Mark's Episcopal Church or Waveny Care Center, both in New Canaan.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Monday about conservative Anglican archbishops from around the world who gathered in Pennsylvania to express disagreement on social issues with liberals in the denomination's American branch, the Episcopal Church, misstated its position on homosexuality. Last July the American church's policy-making body discussed the ordination of gay men and women and the blessing of same-sex unions, but it did not decide to permit them. The national body has taken no action against bishops or local clergy members who carry them out.

title: Council Readies Unique Sex Bias Measure
description: New York City would become the first jurisdiction in the country to grant victims of rape, domestic violence and other crimes ''motivated by gender'' a broad civil right to sue their attackers under a bill unanimously passed by a City Council committee yesterday.

title: Nasdaq's Big Drop
description: The Nasdaq composite index plunged again, finishing its worst month since the market crashed in 1987. The technology-heavy index is down nearly 50 percent from the peak it reached in March. Those numbers help to explain why this holiday will not be nearly as joyful for shoppers and retailers as might be expected. But the broader question is whether the Nasdaq collapse portends bad economic times.

title: County Approves Garbage Station in Linden
description: In a unanimous vote, the Union County Board of Freeholders approved a proposed barge-to-rail garbage transfer station in Linden tonight despite objections from opponents who spoke at a public hearing here earlier in the evening.

title: Seoul Journal; It's Korean Reunion No. 2, With a Few Sour Notes
description: After waiting for half a century, when Ra To So finally got a glimpse of his older sister today, his first reaction was confusion imposed by the fog of decades of separation.

title: CHRYSLER EXPECTED TO CLOSE MORE PLANTS TEMPORARILY
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. is expected to announce this morning the temporary closing of a series of factories, some for more than a week. As the economy slows, Chrysler has huge inventories of unsold Jeeps and minivans, and the unit's new German management has been reluctant to continue offering costly rebates to increase sales and keep factories operating. DaimlerChrysler plants in Detroit; Brampton, Ontario; and Toledo, Ohio, are already closed this week, affecting about 13,600 workers. Keith Bradsher

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; When Air Bags Help, and Harm
description: AIR bags improve people's chances of surviving crashes, on average, but it is now sadly clear that the bags are deadly to some children and small adults. Two new studies help to show who benefits and who does not.

description: For the second time in five months, the Pentagon is scaling back its troubled plan to inoculate all military personnel against anthrax because of dwindling supplies of the vaccine, senior military officials said today.

title: King Closure
description: The suspension of ''The Plant'' -- Stephen King's online serial novel -- after the fifth monthly installment gives rise to all kinds of horticultural metaphors. But the one that matters is that the soil was simply not rich enough. Some 120,000 paying readers downloaded the first installment of ''The Plant.'' By this week's fifth installment that number had dwindled to 40,000, many of them no longer paying. That is a respectable number of downloads by most other measures, but not quite King-like. Some readers complained that the price of the installments had jumped from $1 to $2, though on his Web site's FAQ -- frequently asked questions -- page Mr. King explained that the price of the whole work would not exceed $13. ''One thing I almost forgot,'' he said on the FAQ page, ''and that is the issue of pricing'' -- the one thing publishers never make the mistake of discussing with readers.

title: CANADA KEEPS ROARING
description: Canada's economy grew by 1.2 percent in the third quarter, equivalent to a 4.8 percent annual rate, stronger than many economists had been expecting. Increases in capital investment, business inventories and consumer spending all contributed to the increase. But exports slipped for the first time in three and a half years. On average, economists now expect growth of 5 percent for all of 2000 and 3 to 3.5 percent in 2001.

title: Residential Real Estate; Lower-Rate Mortgage Is Returning to the Market
description: A mortgage type that offers borrowers lower rates in return for sharing any profits with the lender on the eventual sale of the home is reappearing around the country.

title: Behind Europe's Frenzy: A Disease That Affects the Brain
description: Mad cow disease, known to scientists as bovine spongiform encephalopathy, is believed to be caused by aberrant proteins called infectious prions, which affect the brain, leaving it with spongelike holes.

title: When and How AIDS Activism Finally Found Its Voice and Power
description: It is a common assumption in these comfortable times that the primary role played by politically activist art in the United States tends to be neurotic, self-dramatizing personal venting. According to this smug, rose-colored view, such art may rarely accomplish anything concrete, but at least it releases the rage of malcontents who make it while validating everyone's personal freedom of expression. In other words, it's a necessary irritant.

title: SNAG IN THAI BANKRUPTCY
description: A court in Thailand delayed approval of a plan to restructure $3.8 billion of Thai Petrochemical Industry's debt, saying it needs time to review objections to the plan. About 150 creditors of Thai Petro, the country's largest bankruptcy case, endorsed the plan Monday after rejecting 20 amendments requested by the company's chief executive. The case is seen as a crucial test for the country's year-old bankruptcy courts.

title: Mussina's Top Attribute Is His Head, Not His Arm

They anticipate a fastball, and he buckles their knees with a knuckle-curve. They look for a split-finger fastball low, and he fools them with a high fastball.

That will bring the total to 300 in the Chicago area and elsewhere in the Midwest. The news prompted a sharp rise in EarthShell's stock, which closed at $3.13, up 38 cents, or 13.8 percent.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LENDING PROGRAM EXPANDS

The seven-year-old program has granted more than 350 loans totaling more than $18 million to companies with about 4,000 employees, according to the city's Economic Development Corporation, the program's sponsor. The credit unions -- Bethex in the Bronx and Homesteaders, Lower East Side People's and Union Settlement in Manhattan -- join the three banks in the program: Chase Manhattan, EAB and Sterling National. Joseph P. Fried

title: Album of the Week
description: THE OFFSPRING: ''Conspiracy of One'' (Columbia). Commercial fortunes aside, Southern California punk-pop hasn't changed much since the early 1980's. That was when the Descendents bonded the catchiness and the momentum of the Ramones to the complaints of bored, restless, misunderstood suburban teenagers. The Offspring keep cranking out snappy three-minute songs that ricochet amid resentment, pep talks and sarcastic humor: this time 12 of them fit on a 37-minute album. ''Conspiracy of One'' slightly varies the formula by tilting toward hard rock in a few songs and shamelessly aping Nirvana in another; it also tosses some Latin percussion into ''Original Prankster.'' The power chords signal that the songs are less flippant than before; Dexter Holland sings about unfocused rage, romantic misfires and his own unpredictable mood swings. For comic relief, there are songs about a riot as a boys' day out, about stalking and about wishing a too nice girlfriend would develop a bad attitude and get some tattoos. The fast tempos and brash guitars go a long way toward dissolving the Offspring's growing biliousness. JON PARELES

title: Colleague Changed Story On Beating, Officer Says
description: A lieutenant in the Orange Police Department testified today that a fellow lieutenant, who is among the five officers accused of beating and pepper-spraying a suspect who died in custody, admitted at first to being present at the suspect's arrest but then denied it once a grand jury began investigating the incident.

title: Giants' Brown Sees Familiar Face on Horizon
description: Last winter, Bruce Smith and Lomas Brown, two savvy 36-year-old veterans, were looking for jobs. Brown, a left tackle, signed with the Giants hoping for his fifth, and most likely last, shot at making the National Football League playoffs.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in Weekend yesterday with a dance review of Eiko and Koma's ''When Nights Were Dark,'' was reproduced upside down. Eiko's head should have appeared at the top of the frame.

title: California Governor Offers Steps on State Energy Policy
description: Gov. Gray Davis outlined his initial steps today to deal with California's energy problems, but consumer advocates said he did little to provide a reasonable solution for them.

title: A Transcript of Arguments in the Supreme Court Over the Florida Recount
description: Following is a transcript of the Supreme Court arguments yesterday about the Florida recount, as recorded by the Federal New Services, a private transcription service. The lawyers questioned were Theodore B. Olson, for Gov. George W. Bush; Joseph P. Klock Jr., for the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris; Paul F. Hancock, the deputy attorney general of Florida; and Laurence H. Tribe, for Vice President Al Gore.

title: RAYTHEON EARNINGS EXPECTED TO BE BELOW FORECAST
description: The Raytheon Company, the military aerospace contractor, told analysts yesterday that its 2001 earnings would be in a range of 5 to 10 cents a share lower than previously forecast. Analysts attributed the shortfall to a delay in selling Raytheon's aircraft business, but the company declined to comment on such a sale. The earnings warning caused Raytheon stock to tumble. Shares fell $4.63, or 14.3 percent, to $27.75.

description: JONES-Philip. Yesterday would have been our 50th. Love Beatric

title: Protesting Sanctions, Iraq Stops Oil Flow
description: As part of its attempt to chip away at decade-old United Nations sanctions, Iraq has abruptly stopped exporting oil. Iraq cut off exports after failing to win authorization to divert some of its oil profits to accounts not controlled by the United Nations. Oil markets were calm in response to the action by Saddam Hussein.

title: Proposing A Messiah Before Jesus
description: Fifty-three years after the first Dead Sea scrolls were discovered in caves in the Judean desert and eight years after they became widely available, bitter arguments are still flaring over these inscriptions on animal skins that are believed to be the oldest existing records of the Judeo-Christian heritage.

title: The Supreme Court Arguments
description: Americans got a vivid picture yesterday of the chaotic search to resolve the outcome of the lingering presidential election. In Washington, noisy demonstrators rallied outside the United States Supreme Court while inside the justices wrestled thoughtfully with Florida's election laws, the Constitution and an obscure federal statute enacted in 1887. In Tallahassee, more truckloads of disputed ballots arrived from South Florida as lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore prepared for a hearing today on whether they should be counted by hand. Americans, meanwhile, seemed increasingly weary of the arguments but willing to let the impasse play out a bit more.

description: Kendall Gill held the ball on the wrong end of the court, helpless, out of timeouts and out of time, waiting the final 1.3 seconds until the buzzer sounded in anguish again for the Nets.

title: A Sampling Of Works In Progress; Silver and World Trade
description: From the most raked-over history to the latest technology, scholars continually manage to ask new questions, rethink old verities and produce fresh insights. Arts & Ideas takes an occasional look at what some of today's thinkers -- the established as well as those who yearn to be -- are working on. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs and others may turn out to be dead ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here are three works in progress.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ADVANCED NEUROMODULATION SYSTEMS INC., Plano, Tex., a maker of products used to manage chronic pain and other disorders of the central nervous system, has agreed to buy closely held Hi-tronics Designs Inc., Budd Lake, N.J., which develops and makes electro-mechanical devices for cardiology, neurology and orthopedic clinical applications, for $25.3 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANREEPINGHEN, FRANCOIS C.

Visiting at Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown La., East Hampton, L.I., N.Y. today 79PM, service Saturday, 12 Noon at Most Holy Trinity Church. title: U.S. Supreme Court Presses 2 Sides on Vote Case
description: Appearing as divided as the rest of the country over Florida's disputed presidential votes, the United States Supreme Court grilled the lawyers for both sides today in an intense argument session that ended in uncertainty over how -- or whether -- the justices would decide Gov. George W. Bush's appeal of the Florida Supreme Court's extension of the state's vote-counting deadline.

title: Without Pictures, TV Networks Were Scrambling
description: The historic hearing was not even half over yesterday morning when Roger Cossack, a lawyer and co-host of a legal issues program on CNN, bounded out of the United States Supreme Court to deliver a major scoop for the network: the first on-air report of what was transpiring inside the courtroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, ANN F.
description: AMES-Ann F. Of New York, NY. Died on November 23, 2000 at the age of 96. Mrs. Ames was the wife of the late Irving M. Ames. She is survived by her daughter Susan Ames. Mrs. Ames was awarded a Juris Doctor degree from Cleveland-Marshall College of Law at Cleveland State University, a member of the Class of 1928, where contributions in the memory of Mrs. Ames will be accepted. Funeral services will be private.

title: Trinidad Breaks a Sweat (and It's Just a Weigh-In)
description: The weigh-in for Saturday night's fight between Felix Trinidad and Fernando Vargas took longer than Trinidad had hoped.

title: Newark Group Seeks Housing Body's Ouster
description: A housing advocacy group has asked a federal court to remove a local housing authority overseeing the construction of replacement public housing and substitute it with a court-appointed consultant, saying the agency has been inadequate in its efforts to come up with liveable alternatives to decaying and demolished high rises.

title: For Prey of a Different Feather, Give Birds of Clay a Shot
description: oint at the bird," he said. "Kill the bird." If only it were that simple, I remember thinking. I stood behind the trap, my right arm shaking from the weight of a shotgun that was bigger and heavier in real life than in my imagination.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dec. 2nd Also Lives In Infamy
description: MOST of us have freeze-frame memories of truly awful moments when the world seemed to turn upside down.

title: Micron Earnings Warning
description: Shares of Micron Electronics fell more than 25 percent after the company, a direct seller of personal computers, said earnings for the fiscal first quarter would be far below analysts' estimates because of falling computer chip prices at its SpecTek unit. Micron based in Nampa, expects to report revenue of $385 million to $400 million and earnings of 1 cent to 4 cents a share for the quarter ended Nov. 30, the company said in a statement. A spokeswoman declined to elaborate. Analysts had forecast earnings of 11 cents a share. The company's stock fell $1.25, to close at $4.06 Friday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: GAS PRICES TO BE FREED
description: Deeming the British natural gas market sufficiently competitive, regulators are proposing that price controls on Centrica P.L.C., the country's largest supplier, be lifted in April. The government said that six million customers had switched gas suppliers since Centrica's monopoly ended in 1998 and that 60,000 are switching weekly. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Group to Buy Controlling Interest in Datek Online for $700 Million
description: Datek Online, one of the nation's fastest-growing online brokers, said yesterday that a group of private investors had agreed to pay $700 million to acquire a controlling stake in the company.

title: REPURCHASE OF UP TO $1 BILLION OF STOCK PLANNED
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation will repurchase up to $1 billion of its common stock, depending on market conditions, the company said, and it will suspend a systematic repurchase program it began in 1998 while the $1 billion open-market buyback is going on. At current prices, the $1 billion would buy about 2.6 percent of Compaq's outstanding shares.

title: For the Spice of Life, Literally
description: ''Frank Herbert's 'Dune' '' is a gamble.

title: Army to Detonate Old Bombs Found at Former Weapons Plant in Colorado
description: State officials agreed today to allow the Army to detonate small bombs filled with a toxic liquid that were recently discovered on the grounds of a defunct weapons plant north of Denver.

title: Automakers Are Facing a Sales Slowdown
description: Through most of the 1990's, automakers avoided building new assembly plants, convinced that the good times would not last. They have finally committed themselves in the last two years to a string of new factories, only to find their timing is as poor as ever: sales have begun to slow, particularly for Detroit's manufacturers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I will share the power, and also the responsibilities. I am the guardian of power, not its owner.''

title: SECRETS
description: An American missing for 20 years turns up alive. A Japanese man pretends to have a job. Watergate's 18 1/2 minutes may yet be recovered. A special issue of The Times Magazine explores why, in an age of transparency, the allure of the hidden remains stronger than ever, and how even a powerful figure like John M. Deutch, the former director of central intelligence (profiled by Thomas Powers), can be undone by a classified culture.

title: INSIDE
description: Schools Drop Scout Events

title: Columbia Revels in Success Of Fund-Raising Campaign
description: Nearing the end of a decadelong fund-raising campaign, Columbia University announced yesterday that it had raised $2.74 billion -- more than double the initial goal in 1990.

title: Diners Journal: District
description: As the name suggests, District knows exactly where it is. And if anyone was in doubt, the design at this theater district newcomer makes things perfectly clear.

title: Court Says No to a New Palm Beach Vote
description: Vice President Al Gore suffered a setback today when the State Supreme Court rejected an appeal seeking a revote in Palm Beach County, where many voters said they were confused by the so-called ''butterfly'' ballot.

title: White House Arranging F.B.I. Checks on Both Sides' Cabinet Picks
description: The White House is working on arrangements with the Bush and Gore camps to allow the Federal Bureau of Investigation to begin reviewing the backgrounds of both candidates' cabinet picks as early as next week.

title: In Consumer Electronics, Shoppers Seem to Be Thinking Downscale
description: Even before holiday shopping begins each year, magazines and newspapers publish technology guides offering suggestions for expensive gizmos and gadgets to give.

title: Toward Solvency for Nassau County
description: A last-minute bipartisan budget accord in Nassau County has averted the embarrassment of a New York State takeover of county finances. The agreement in the normally fractious County Legislature on Wednesday night was approved when Democrats and Republicans compromised and unanimously accepted a mix of tax increases and spending cuts designed to get the county out of its nearly bankrupt status. The accord is a step forward, but it is not without flaws. It relies on overly optimistic tax revenue estimates and unidentified savings in the years ahead. As a result, state monitors who pressed for this new agreement will have to keep a careful watch in coming months.

title: A Lesser-Known Successor Is Making His Voice Heard
description: THREE months ago, South Africa's Anglican bishops decided that they should take the blood test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and that they should be public about it. Among the first to go was the church's head, Archbishop Njongonkulu Ndungane of Cape Town, who had his blood drawn before a crowd of journalists.

title: Court Ends Its Oversight of a Restaurant Union
description: A federal judge in Trenton ended five years of court supervision of the nation's largest hotel and restaurant workers' union yesterday after Justice Department prosecutors said the monitoring had substantially erased mob influence and corruption from the union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DAVID
description: SCHWARTZ-David. Died on November 29th at Beth Israel Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. David is survived by a loving family: wife Grace; children Barbara Onish, Steven Schwartz and Sanford Schwartz; grandchildren Russell Onish, Alison Onish, Robert Schwartz, Jonathan Schwartz, Megan Schwartz and Joshua Schwartz. David lived an active, full, rewarding and charitable life for 93 years. David will be remembered for his devotion to Temple Beth El of Manhattan Beach, his love of the outdoor and his tenacity in all he pursued. The funeral will be held Sunday, December 3rd at 11:00AM at Garlick's funeral parlor at 1153 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn. Donations in honor of David Schwartz should be made to Temple Beth El of Manhattan Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDWICK, AMBROSE H., JR.
description: HARDWICK-Ambrose H., Jr. Age 73 of Bay Head, NJ on November 29th. Beloved husband of Dora. Father of Cynthia and Robin. Memorial service, Tuesday, December 5th, 11:00 AM at All Saints Episcopal Church, Bay Head, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to either Save Barnegat Bay, 906-B Grand Central Avenue, Lavallette, NJ 08735 or The YWCA of Essex and W. Hudson Counties in Orange, New Jersey.

title: SEIZURE IN BELGIUM
description: Global TeleSystems Inc., a European phone company whose original investors included George Soros, left, said a Brussels court seized control of its Belgian unit after an employee said he thought it was going bankrupt. The company, based in London, said that the employee was wrong and that the seizure would be contested. Global TeleSystems stock has fallen 96 percent this year as cash dwindled and operating losses persisted. Its chief executive resigned in September, and it said in November that it would sell two divisions to raise cash and that it might default on some debts.

title: Journal; Happy Anniversary, Mr. Presidents!
description: Who says we still don't have a president-elect? We have not one, but two pseudo-presidents-elect. Next week brings the election's one-month anniversary, which means it is not too early to judge each of their pseudo-presidencies, one of which, like it or not, is going to become real by the time the Groundhog Days of November give way to the official one on the calendar.

title: Gwen Grant Mellon, 89, Dies; Founder of a Haitian Hospital
description: Gwen Grant Mellon, who with her husband Dr. William Larimer Mellon Jr. founded a modern hospital in Haiti that served an area with few medical facilities of any kind, died on Wednesday in Miami. She was 89.

title: Welser-Most Conducts the Philharmonic
description: Even though he had worked in the United States often, the Austrian conductor Franz Welser-Most had yet to establish a strong musical profile here when the Cleveland Orchestra appointed him as its new music director, effective 2002. According to a newly published history of the orchestra by Donald Rosenberg, critics and concertgoers in Cleveland were as surprised by the choice as everyone else.

title: Andrew Stone, 96, Director, Writer and Producer of Films
description: Andrew L. Stone, a prolific film director who won praise for his 1943 movie ''Stormy Weather,'' starring Lena Horne, died in June 1999. He was 96.

title: Goaltending Silences Islanders and Devils
description: The Devils and the Islanders have developed contrasting patterns in the third period and overtime this season. The Devils have generally found ways to win and the Islanders have found ways to lose. Tonight, neither finished in typical fashion as the teams played to a scoreless tie before a crowd of 17,002 at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEPPEL, RUTH S.
description: KOEPPEL-Ruth S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Ruth S. Koeppel. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Susana Rotker-Martinez, 46, Language Professor at Rutgers
description: Dr. Susana Rotker-Martinez, director of the Rutgers Center for Hemispheric Studies, was hit by a truck and fatally injured Monday while crossing a road in Piscataway, N.J. She was 46 and lived in Highland Park.

title: Bernard Vorhaus, 95, Prolific American Director in England
description: Bernard Vorhaus, an American-born film director who made his name in England during the 1930's and who became a victim of the Hollywood blacklist in the 1950's, died on Nov. 23 in London. He was 95.

description: From the United States Supreme Court in Washington to the Florida Supreme Court in Tallahassee, these were the main events yesterday in the battle for the presidency.

description: Mike Jarvis entertained the thought just once, he said, when he was a high school coach at the Cambridge Rindge and Latin School and attended a Celtics game at the Boston Garden.

title: Prayers in Jerusalem, Fatal Clashes Elsewhere
description: As tens of thousands of worshipers gathered for prayers, the first Friday of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan passed without serious violence in East Jerusalem today as both Palestinians and Israeli security forces showed restraint.

title: Travels With an Aunt: New York for Children
description: Bless the family symmetry that gave my son, Edward, a first cousin who shares not only his age (almost 12) but also similar passions for general science and general mischief. Unfortunately, they live three hours apart, which limits all but their online time together.

title: China's Top Justice Official Ousted, Some Say for Corruption
description: China's minister of justice was removed from office this week, officials acknowledged today, and according to some accounts he is under investigation for corruption.

description: Mayor Bill Clinton?

title: 2 Insurers Raising Liability Coverage On Bigger Vehicles
description: With evidence growing that sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and large vans are causing disproportionate harm to cars and their occupants in collisions, two insurers that together cover nearly 25 million vehicles have quietly begun making drivers of the bigger vehicles pay more for liability insurance.

title: Red Cross Requests Mediation In Rift on Safety of Blood Supply
description: The American Red Cross is asking a federal court to appoint a mediator in its long-running dispute with the Food and Drug Administration over how best to monitor the safety of blood supplied by the Red Cross.

title: With Passion and Valor
description: Almost half a century ago, when football at Army and Navy was more successful and prestigious than it is now, an Army assistant coach named Vince Lombardi would drive to Long Island to get game film developed. Before returning to West Point, Lombardi would stop in Manhattan to visit Gen. Douglas MacArthur, then living in the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Republicans Bear Down On Absentee Ballot Suits
description: Compared with the challenge filed by Vice President Al Gore, or the case before the United States Supreme Court, the cases filed here in Leon County Circuit Court seeking to throw out absentee ballots from several Florida counties may seem like small blips on the radar screen of Florida elections lawsuits.

title: Schiano Hopes to Inject New Life Into Rutgers
description: On the first day of his new job, Greg Schiano did not waste any time to start pitching his program.

title: PINOCHET'S ARREST ORDERED BY JUDGE
description: A Chilean judge formally charged Gen. Augusto Pinochet today in the kidnappings of opponents after he overthrew the Socialist government of Dr. Salvador Allende in 1973, and ordered him placed under house arrest.

title: Proposed Line Would Lighten Subway Crush
description: In an effort to ease severe congestion on two of the main subway lines that run between Manhattan and Queens, New York City Transit is proposing to add a subway line, the V train, and to make major routing changes on the F line, one of the most heavily used in the system, officials said yesterday.

title: Sampras Routs Safin With Surprising Ease
description: Marat Safin walked onto the court today with No. 1 on his mind. Pete Sampras walked onto the court with New York on his.

title: William B. Furlong, Sports Columnist And Author, 73
description: William Barry Furlong, a widely read sports columnist, magazine writer and author, died last Saturday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 73.

title: No Apologies From Stuttgart; DaimlerChrysler's Chief Defends His Strategy
description: Jurgen E. Schrempp, chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, was not about to make apologies.

title: A Plan to Appoint Electors With No Jeb Bush Signature
description: Saving Gov. Jeb Bush from the prospect of signing a bill to deliver Florida's 25 electors to his brother, leaders of the Florida Legislature said today that they could select electors with a resolution that would not require any action by the governor.

title: Europeans Challenge U.S. Limits on Steel Imports
description: The European Union filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization today, challenging United States import restrictions on two steel products.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about the emergence of the century-old philosophy of pragmatism as the latest trend in architecture misidentified the poet to whom the neo-pragmatist philosopher Richard Rorty referred. Saying that regardless of what inspires the work, the end result is what matters, Mr. Rorty compared an architect's work to that of Yeats, not Keats.

title: Imported Pest Raises Fears for Forests
description: SINCE it was first spotted in Brooklyn in 1996, the Asian long-horned beetle has caused the destruction of 5,100 trees in New York and 1,400 in Chicago. Infested trees are cut down, chipped and burned because there is no other way to kill the pest, which has come dangerously close to Central Park in New York and Lincoln Park in Chicago.

title: Turning Fidgets Into Karate Kicks; Some Find That Martial Arts Ease Attention Disorders
description: The karate class that Daniel Povzhitkov attends begins in meditative silence, then explodes into the kata, a choreographed sequence of blocking, kicking and punching. The 10 children then glide into a series of jumping front kicks and back elbow strikes in their little white gis, all solemn-faced and graceful. The only noise is an occasional grunt, or a command muttered in Japanese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, WILLIAM A.
description: WEXLER-William A. B'nai B'rith International mourns the death of Dr. William A. Wexler, international president from 1965-1971 in Israel-where he had lived for many years-on November 30. A past chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish American Organizations, member of the United Jewish Appeal National campaign cabinet, former Savannah, GA alderman and civil rights activist, Bill Wexler's example will continue to inspire us all. We extend our condolences to his family and friends. May his memory be a blessing always. Richard D. Heideman, Int'l President of B'nai B'rith Daniel S. Mariaschin Executive Vice President Arie Bar Zion, President of B'nai B'rith Israel Pnina Bor, International Vice President Naor Yerushalmi, Chairman B'nai B'rith World Cntr-Jerusalem Alan Schneider, Director B'nai B'rith World Cntr-Jerusalem

title: Unlocking Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Cape Town Journal; District Six Still Is Where the Heart Is
description: William Bailey and a few hundred of his long-lost neighbors came home this week to the place they knew as District Six, but he was worried that none of them would remember his face. After all, it has been more than 30 years since he and thousands of others were expelled from the neighborhood, separated and scattered by South Africa's apartheid government in its effort to turn the district into a whites-only community.

title: ARC, A CANADIAN FUND, TO PURCHASE STARTECH ENERGY
description: ARC Energy Trust, a Canadian closed-end energy fund, agreed yesterday to buy Startech Energy Inc., an oil and gas producer, for 332 million Canadian dollars ($216 million) in stock, or 0.96 of a unit worth 10.75 Canadian dollars ($7) for each share of Startech. It will also assume 145 million Canadian dollars ($94.6 million) in Startech's debt. Both companies are based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: MILLER IS SET TO SELL ITS CELIS BREWERY BUSINESS
description: The Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it planned to sell its Celis Brewery business, and that it would shut down the unit's plant in Austin, Tex., later this month. Celis made 15,000 barrels of beer last year, a tiny share of Miller's total output; Celis is sold mostly in Texas. The Milwaukee-based Miller, which made 43.3 million barrels of beer and had sales of $4.34 billion last year, bought the remaining interest of Celis from the Celis family in April after buying a majority interest in 1995. Miller also owns two other regional specialty beer brands, Leinenkugel in the Midwest and Henry Weinhard in the Northwest.

title: Inquiry Uncovers School Bus Drivers' Pasts
description: Dozens of school bus drivers in Connecticut have criminal backgrounds that include convictions for possession of narcotics, assault, risk of injury to a minor and illegal weapons possession, state officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVITT, LAURENCE G.
description: LEAVITT-Laurence G., 97. Of Norwich, Vermont, survived by a daughter Sally Cheney Bell, a son Richard Hall Leavitt, six grandchildren, 11 great grandchildren. Services December 9th at 11:AM, Rollins Chapel, Hanover, N.H. Donations to Laurence and Dorothy Leavitt Scholarship Fund, Vermont Academy, Saxtons River, Vermont 05154.

title: A Stunning Guggenheim, but in the Wrong Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Holiday Calendar column in House & Home on Thursday about a tour of antiques shops today from 5 to 8 p.m. in Hudson, N.Y., sponsored by the Hudson Opera House, misstated the telephone number for information. It is (518) 822-1438.

title: Escort of Voyeur Bus Suspended by Police
description: A police officer was suspended without pay yesterday after he used his marked patrol car with its dome lights flashing to escort a glass-enclosed bus through Midtown Manhattan as naked women danced inside and blew kisses at passers-by, the police said.

title: Window on the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Are Planning for Life Without Nelson
description: They completed their primary objective in signing Mike Mussina, but the Yankees have a couple more holes to fill, including the job that is about to be vacated by reliever Jeff Nelson, who is expected to sign a three-year contract for slightly under $11 million with the Seattle Mariners on Monday.

title: South Africa to Distribute $50 Million in Donated AIDS Drugs
description: After months of official indecision over how to confront the epidemic ravaging South Africa, the government announced today that it would make critical drugs available to people who have H.I.V. or AIDS.

title: Nine Men Amid Gothic Strangeness
description: So much is fascinating about Lar Lubovitch's new dance piece, ''Men's Stories,'' that its enigmatic quality becomes a natural part of the entire experience offered to the viewer.

title: Army Orders Peacekeepers To Sessions On Rights
description: The Army has ordered that all fighting units based in the United States undergo specialized training intended to prevent the possibility of human rights abuses by soldiers sent overseas on peacekeeping missions, Pentagon officials announced today.

title: And in Florida, Justices Refuse Bid for Recount
description: The Florida Supreme Court rejected an appeal today by Vice President Al Gore that it begin the immediate manual recount of 14,000 disputed ballots from South Florida, forcing Mr. Gore's contest of the presidential election into a lower-court trial that begins Saturday morning.

title: Now We Know That Not All Votes Count
description: The United States exists today because our forefathers fought and died for the right to vote. One hundred years later, women took to the streets to win it. And two generations ago, hundreds of thousands of Americans risked their lives fighting to ensure that blacks had this right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, LESLIE M.
description: STOCK-Leslie M. On December 1, 2000. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Loving father of Roger and Elyse. Dear brother of Albert. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Alexandra, Samuel and Robin. Devoted father-in-law of Steven and Marissa. Service Sunday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the UJA Federation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONE, IRENE (NEE BECKMANN)
description: KRONE-Irene (nee Beckmann). Beloved mother of Kathryn and wife of the late Helmut Krone. Died suddenly in a traffic accident in Martinique, Wednesday, November 29, 2000. A memorial service will be announced. Please make donations to the Helmut Krone Scholarship Fund of the One Club.

title: Coke Forms Alliance With Interpublic
description: One of the world's largest advertisers, the Coca-Cola Company, is hiring one of the world's largest advertising agency companies, the Interpublic Group of Companies, to coordinate the marketing for its flagship soft-drink brand. The company spends an estimated $1 billion annually on all forms of advertising and marketing for the brand, called Coca-Cola Classic in North America and Coca-Cola or Coke elsewhere around the world.

title: A World That at First Howled in Derision Grows Somewhat Anxious, and Also Admiring
description: As the election drama unfolds in the United States, attitudes abroad have moved from surprise and ridicule to growing concern over global consequences and grudging admiration for the sturdiness of the country's institutions.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Al Gore's reliance on a small inner circle omitted the word ''no'' in a quotation from a former consultant who said Mr. Gore was unwilling to listen to other points of view. The comment was, ''There is no Plan B and there is no talk of 2004.''

title: PRICE LOWERED ON TELENOR OFFER
description: The Norwegian telephone company Telenor A.S. lowered the price range for its initial public offering because of soft demand. The new range for the offering, set for Monday, is $13.57 to $14.86 a share, to raise $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion, for 21 percent of the company's shares; the company had originally hoped to raise $2.7 billion. Similarly, Telefonica of Spain and France Telecom have scaled back offerings for their mobile phone arms, and Royal KPN of the Netherlands postponed an offering until next year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; Using Principles of Zen In Fight Against AIDS

title: GOLDMAN FUND IN BID FOR REAL ESTATE OF ENI OF ITALY

As the authors note, Americans ''pioneered the measurement of facets of American life that had never been systematically counted before such as crime, love, food, fun, religion and work. . . . title: DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE TO CUT MORE THAN 1,700 JOBS
description: Delphi Automotive Systems Inc., the world's largest auto parts maker, said yesterday that it would furlough more than 1,700 workers in plants in Michigan, Ohio and New York because production of cars and light trucks in North America is slowing. The workers will be laid off indefinitely starting in the next three weeks, Delphi said, and will draw 95 percent of their regular pay; all will eventually be rehired. Delphi employs about 54,000 hourly workers. The move comes after Delphi, which is based in Troy, Mich., dismissed 100 workers on Nov. 9 at a Michigan plant because of production cutbacks by automakers. General Motors, Delphi's former parent and largest customer, cut fourth-quarter production 5.2 percent, to 1.38 million vehicles from the year earlier, while Ford Motor lowered output 3.4 percent.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: Essay; Sieve City
description: Elsewhere in the country, spilling secrets may be a pastime; in Washington, it's a profession. And there is no one who has done the job more zealously than Bill Gertz. Few outside the Beltway, and to be honest, few who live inside it, have heard of the middle-aged suburban family man who writes about national security issues for The Washington Times, the capital's unabashedly conservative newspaper. But within the tight circle of experts who follow state secrets, Gertz has become well known. In the past decade he has probably ferreted out and published more classified information than anyone else in America. His string of politically slanted yet often authentically embarrassing scoops about the inner workings of the Clinton administration's foreign policy have frequently driven those in power to distraction. Indeed, as Gertz acknowledges, he is widely believed to be the primary target of recent legislation, passed by both houses of Congress but vetoed by the president, that would have made it a felony to leak classified information to the press. Next year, the national security community is expected to request similar legislation from the new Congress.

title: Bulk Hogan
description: Think American status sneakers, and Nike comes to mind. But for Europeans, Hogan, created by the designer Diego Della Valle, of Tod's, has long been the brand that says street style. Now, Hogan, a logo-free line of shoes and bags, is the new kid on the accessories block in the United States. Though Hogan's high-end leather sneakers, from $245 to $565, were introduced in select department stores like Neiman Marcus and Saks two years ago, the label started causing a stir last month when its first American boutique opened on Spring Street in SoHo. A flashy party attracted the actresses Minnie Driver, at left carrying Hogan's PanAm bag, and Julianne Margulies, along with the fashion-forward style tribe. The big attraction was a new line of handbags: boxy, retro shapes in leather and canvas jazzed up with sturdy handles, buckles, zippers and pockets. Why the big deal? ''Hogan is like all-terrain,'' said Mary Alice Stephenson, the fashion director of Marie Claire. ''If you leave in the morning with tons of stuff and then have an event at night, you can fill a Hogan bag with everything.'' ELIZABETH HAYT

End-of-year dream excursions include yachts cruising the Greek islands in search of mountain greens and barley biscuits, and long-tailed boats navigating Mekong Delta canals seeking fragrant rice. Forget what you thought you knew about choosing and cooking perfect rice. And buy a sack of bread flour and look for a non-Zone New Year's diet: meat is prominent on the curriculum, but so are carbohydrates -- lovingly shaped by hand, of course.

description: KOEPPEL-Ruth S. Age 91, died peacefully on Thanksgiving, November 23, 2000 at home with her daughter Nancy and grandsons David & Steven in Stuart, Florida. Loving wife of the late Harry Koeppel. Adored mother of Nancy S. Koeppel and the late Robert A. Koeppel. Cherished grandmother of David and Steven Koeppel and Elizabeth Lingle and William, Alexandra and Caroline Koeppel. Loving great grandmother of Benjamin and Alexander Lingle and Harrison Koeppel. She will always be remembered for her beautiful smile and her joy of living which she maintained with graciousness and charm. Most of her life she lived in NYC, which was her favorite place to be. She lived her last years with her daughter and grandsons in Florida, where hopefully she made a difference in the recent Presidential elections. She had an avid interest in politics. title: A Double Life; A Life of Fiction
description: Charles Dickens was traveling home from France on June 10, 1865, when the train he was riding in went off the tracks while crossing a bridge. Seven first-class carriages dropped into the river below. The eighth, Dickens's own, dangled off the bridge, hanging from its coupling and throwing the Dickens party into the lower corner of the carriage. Dickens calmed his companions and then clambered onto the bridge. He found a conductor, obtained a key to the carriage and freed his friends. Then he filled his top hat with water, took out his brandy flask and went about succoring, and in at least one case, rescuing, those trapped in the wrecked cars below. Men and women died in front of him. He helped others find their own dead loved ones. He was, to use a possibly Dickensian word, indefatigable.

title: Essay; The Voice of Small-Town America
description: James Thurber wrote ''The Years With Ross'' in 1958, toward the end of his most productive and original period, and he managed to make both less and more of his subject than he intended. More, because he turned Harold Ross, the creator and first editor of The New Yorker, into a legend, the Casey Stengel of American letters, the guy who wanted to know if Moby Dick was the whale or the man and who scribbled ''Who he?'' all over his writers' copy. And this, in turn, made less of Ross -- in the eyes of many New Yorker veterans, painfully less -- because it turned him from the great and farseeing editor they knew into a kind of hapless Thurber husband who lucked out by hiring Thurber. For those who think that Ross really was like Stengel -- a superb manager of talents who skillfully hid his shrewd judgment behind an assumed mask of colorfulness -- it is easy to see Thurber's Ross as a caricature, or even a betrayal.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: If the pattern of the past two years holds, we may be seeing a law developing: authors and publishers fare better in years when the editors of the Book Review are least contented by them. The editors compete in the hunt for books to nominate for the list of the year's best, and 2000 started slow and lost speed right down to the end. Grouch carpeted the office like crab grass. When it came time for everyone to read everyone else's nominees and make choices, there were only 20 titles in contention, the smallest number in more than 20 years. The number of nominees, in fact, has been declining two per year for three years running.

title: A Beef Place at Home on the Mid-Range
description: LAST summer the unheralded Dodge City Steak House in Westhampton moseyed into the vast price gulch between Bryant & Cooper and Boulder Creek. Until then the steakhouse revival on Long Island had been largely confined to expense-account, high-roller venues and a few low-end emporiums that stressed quantity more than quality. There's a lot of room between the big beef palaces, with their $15 shrimp cocktails and $38 steaks, and the $12.95 economy steak spots. The commendable Dodge City Steak House, at 62 Montauk Highway (631-288-0500), has pulled its rig dead center between the two.

Judge Sauls also questioned Judge Burton.

title: Reading, Writing and . . . Work? Not Always

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00; I Was a Teenage Pornographer
description: When I finished high school, my family returned to Los Angeles after six years abroad. We spent that summer, the oddest of my life, at a raffish residential hotel for show-business transients. During the time I'd been away, my friends all seemed to have adopted the same hobby: taking drugs. Their voices had changed; they'd started shaving. Worse, I may have been the only adolescent in Los Angeles history without a driver's license. So much decadence, and I was stuck with my nose pressed against the glass, stranded in Gomorrah. And then my parents insisted I find a job.

title: Behind Closed Doors; The Last Taboo
description: Ours is the Age of Un-innocence. We live in a period that is unparalleled for its steamy atmosphere of exposure, its insistence that there is nothing to be ashamed of and hence nothing to hide. Delighting as we do in disrobing even the most exalted of public figures, we have conspired to make the once walled-off realm of private life into a collective spectatorial drama. These days, the classic codes of social behavior no longer apply: we are all living in glass houses, and we are all throwing stones.

title: American West Masters On Exhibit in Denver
description: A new exhibition at the Denver Art Museum shows how some of the country's best-known artists depicted the American West between 1832 and 1979. ''Painters and the American West,'' on display through Jan. 21, features more than 100 works. Highlights include Albert Bierstadt's ''Wind River, Wyoming,'' circa 1870; Frederic Remington's ''Return of a Blackfoot War Party,'' 1887; and Charles M. Russell's ''Scouts,'' 1902.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE TRUMPET OF THE SWAN. By E. B. White. Illustrated by Fred Marcellino. HarperCollins. $16.95. (All ages) The story of Louis, the silent trumpeter swan with a large heart; of Sam Beaver, the boy who befriends him and takes him to school; and of how a horn helps love along, has never had the same standing as ''Stuart Little'' or ''Charlotte's Web.'' This handsome new edition with eloquent illustrations may bring another generation of readers to this 1970 novel.

title: Doggerel for the Barking Set
description: The holiday season brings a litter of books for dog lovers. The 500 or so dog pictures in ''A Thousand Hounds'' by Raymond Merritt & Miles Barth (Taschen, $39.99) relate canine and human history through images, from Picasso's to William Wegman's. The humorist Roy Blount Jr. and Valerie Shaff, a photographer, collaborate on ''I Am Puppy, Hear Me Yap: The Ages of Dog'' (HarperCollins, $20), a collection of cute sepia-tone prints and even cuter musings. A baby basset hound admits, ''I've got something on my mind and something in my mouth/ And I don't know what either one is.''

title: GARDENING
description: One gardening book after another this season explains the ancient uses of the word ''paradise,'' leading us back to the walled gardens of the Persians, to the Virgin's enclosed bower in medieval paintings, to the earthly roots of what has become a theological rather than a horticultural concept. But the definition of paradise, to my mind, depends as much on the kind of gardener to be found there as it does on the kind of garden. In Milton's version of Eden, Eve says to Adam, ''what we by day / Lop overgrown, or prune, or prop, or bind, / One night or two with wanton growth derides, / Tending to wild.'' Gardens do by nature tend to wild, of course. But can paradise really require the meticulous labor so obvious in the images of enclosed Persian gardens and the Virgin's hortus conclusus?
