description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: On Language; Netspionage
description: E-fraud solicitor is how Steven Philippsohn, a lawyer in London, describes his line of work. In a recent article in Communications World, he used a word that fills a void (once pronounced in Brooklyn as ''a woid that fills a verd''): ''Netspionage is already affecting computer contractors.''

title: Fixing Your Stained-Glass Windows
description: MANY homes built between 1880 and 1930 have sashes over doors or in-window frames with stained glass. These attractive windows add a striking decorative accent to any interior. A large number of these still survive today but over time, they can sag and deteriorate. Homeowners often wonder how the windows can be restored and whether repair techniques can be performed by the average do-it-yourselfer or if they should be done by professional restorers.

title: Lindsey Davison, Blakely Page
description: Lindsey Cox Davison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Davison Jr., of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Blakely Chapman Page, the son of Brittain Bardes Cudlip of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jay Jarvis Page of Manhattan. The Rev. Joel W. Pugh, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel in Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: For Jets, No Doubt About Key To Defense
description: The talk is of gaps and stacks, nickels and dimes. But it takes Marvin Jones, with a wry smile, dry wit and a team-leading 102 tackles, to boil the guts of the Jets defense down to its essence.

title: Six Characters Look for Meaning
description: KARL SMITH is an undercover policeman. James Joyce Milliken (what's in a name?) is a human rights lawyer, but don't worry, they call him Jimmy.

title: A Guide to the Cork Trail
description: Kevin M. Atticks, a Baltimorean, has written guidebooks to the wineries in Maryland and around Lake Erie. The informative ''Discovering New Jersey Wineries'' (Resonant Publishing, Baltimore, $9.95) was inevitable.

title: In a Gay World, Without the Usual Guides
description: SHOWTIME'S made-to-shock series ''Queer as Folk'' begins with this voiceover from Michael, who has the innocent look of a teddy bear: ''The thing you need to know is, it's all about sex.'' As he speaks, he and his friends are in a gay disco called Babylon, where one dancing man wears only a silver-spangled thong, chains hang from the ceiling, drugs are common and everyone ignores the signs that read, ''No sex in the bathrooms, that's what the couches are for.''

title: HIGH SCHOOL SCIENCE STARS
description: A joint research project exploring what happens when stars known as white dwarfs die earned honors for two high school seniors -- Jacqueline Gordon, who attends Mamaroneck High School, and Megan Hall, who attends John Jay High School in the Katonah-Lewisboro district. As regional finalists in the Siemens Westinghouse Science and Technology Competition, they shared a $1,000 prize. They worked with a Columbia University astronomy professor, Joseph Patterson, under a program that teams students with professional scientists. Merri Rosenberg

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 19 about the growth of high technology industries in New Jersey referred incorrectly to technologically related companies in the state. The figure used, 13,415, was an estimate by the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, not a count.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, FRANCES A.
description: WOLF-Frances A. On December 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Dr. Dorothy Cantor and mother-in-law of Gerry. Proud grandmother of Joshua Cantor and Laura and David Cramer. Adoring great-grandmother of Brad, Scott, Andrew, Alex and Molly. Dear sister of Hy Alter, Gladys Silverman and the late Syd Goldberg. Service private.

title: Marguerite Cyprus and Michael Loucas
description: THE first person to greet customers at the Burger Heaven restaurant on East 53rd Street near Fifth Avenue is Marguerite Eleanor Cyprus, who welcomes people in an old New York way: with a huge but not too long-lasting smile, quick jokes and her eye on the clock. She grew up working in her family's four Burger Heavens, all in Manhattan, and now at 36 she deals out the menus as quickly as a card shark.

title: A Resort Asks, Seconds Anyone?
description: HEY, Esther!'' my son Sam, and his Israeli cousin, Avishai, yelled down the hall on the way to lunch. A moment later, a dozen coiffed heads turned, and Sam and Avishai, both 11 years old and whooping like hyenas, darted into the men's room.

title: Dining Out; Healthful Creations That Also Taste Good
description: FOR vegetarians, vegans and other diners who appreciate healthful dishes that are also tasty and interesting, Green Symphony is a find. The restaurant puts a contemporary spin on food based on Buddhist culinary tradition, updating the principles set down in the kitchens of early temples and monasteries; and diners here won't find better fare of this kind anywhere else in Westchester or in the entire New York area.

title: THEATER; We're All Trapped, But Let's Laugh
description: YOU know what I think? I think that we're all in our private traps. Clamped in them, and none of us can ever get out. We scratch and claw, but only at the air. Only at each other. And for all of it, we never budge an inch.'' Thus spake Norman Bates.

title: A Renovation Causes Trouble in Paradise
description: ON the morning of Oct. 7, George Kimmerle of Mendham, N.J., decided he was fed up.

title: Intimidating Result
description: To the Editor:

title: MANZIE PAROLE
description: A state appeals court ruled last week that Samuel A. Manzie, the teenager who confessed to killing an 11-year-old boy in 1997, could be paroled after 30 years in prison. A three-judge panel found that the sentencing judge improperly applied a state law requiring that convicts serve at least 85 percent of their prison time. Mr. Manzie, now 19, would have had to spend 59 1/2 years of his 70-year sentence before being eligible for parole. Mr. Manzie strangled Eddie Werner as the boy was making door-to-door fund-raisingsales in Jackson Township.

title: The Nation; Transition: The Changing of the (786) Guards
description: VERY little in this city of power and ego is uglier than a presidential transition. Except, perhaps, a failed transition that condemns a new president to an even uglier first year in office.

title: Location, Location, Click, Click
description: APARTMENTVIEW.COM

title: A Journey Is Completed
description: Hilda and Samuel Tavarez moved from the Dominican Republic into a home for the city's working poor in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The building, once a parochial school, was revived by Catholic Charities, one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Coldwell Banker Brokerage Expands in Westchester
description: Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage has associated with McMillan Severin Mitchell & Constabile, a 45-agent office in Larchmont. The association of the two companies, now known as Coldwell Banker McMillan Severin Mitchell & Constabile, took effect Nov. 8..

title: You Jane?
description: Jane Austen's ''Charlotte''

title: Conflicting Rulings On Co-ops
description: A NEW YORK appeals court issued a ruling last month that complicated an already confusing legal situation regarding the rights of tenants who rent vacant co-op or condominium apartments from an original sponsor after the conversion.

title: No One Is Too Young or Too Old
description: Students and senior citizens play side by side in the New Jersey Intergenerational Orchestra of Cranford, one of the few orchestras of its kind in the country that includes young people, some players with several years' experience, and people their 70's and 80's, some of whom are playing music for the first time in their lives.

title: A Student Union Built by Students
description: ONE hundred and sixty-five boys and girls, wards of the state, live perched above the Hudson here at the Graham School, where there was once a big, vacant room.

title: Francine Weinberg, Jonathan Graff
description: Francine Susan Weinberg, the daughter of State Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg of Teaneck, N.J., and the late Irwin Weinberg, is to be married today to Jonathan Alan Graff, a son of Ellen Graff of Los Angeles and the late Edward Graff. Rabbi Mordecai Finley will officiate at the Victorian at Heritage Square, a historic house in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Swiss Cling to Their Army
description: If Switzerland clings to its fabled neutrality, some Swiss ask, why on earth does it need a $3 billion military budget -- why can't some of that be shifted to, say, aid for the needy or promoting global peace? Their fellow citizens didn't agree, though, voting nearly 2 to 1 not to trim one-third of that budget, just as they voted down a related proposal a decade ago. The world's hot spots, the government noted in fighting the cutbacks, include some perilously close to the peaceful Swiss hearth -- like Kosovo. Hubert B. Herring

title: James Jones, 86, Who Walked With the Hounds, Dies
description: James S. Jones, an architect whose passion was following packs of basset hounds on foot in pursuit of elusive hares, died Nov. 13 at a nursing home in Chester, N.J. He was 86.

title: At Some Hotels, It's Adults Only
description: NO national law bars a hotel from refusing to take children as guests. According to Kara Peterman, a spokes woman at the Department of Justice, Title II of the 1964 Civil Rights Act says hotels may not discriminate on the basis of race, religion, ethnicity or national origin, but makes no mention of family status or age. And hotels are not covered under the Fair Housing Act of 1968.

title: Considering Approaches To Lowering Property Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Chartered Train Carrying Giants Kills Man
description: A chartered train taking the New York Giants to Washington for their game with the Redskins today hit and killed a man yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J., in what the police said appeared to have been a suicide.

title: Lives; Lies I Lived
description: My brother attended Soviet schools in the late 1940's, when the Americans were our enemies. No one had ever seen them, of course. This made them even more terrifying for simple people because, who knows, they might be anywhere, disguised as Soviet citizens in regular clothes. They would reveal all our mysteries, steal the secrets of our might and, God forbid, become just as strong and unconquerable as we were. That's what my brother was told in school. Above all, it was strictly, strictly forbidden to let anyone know what went on in gym classes. The enemy could not be allowed to find out how many situps and push-ups Soviet schoolchildren could do in a row, how fast they could climb up a rope and whether or not they could do handstands.

title: Sports of The Times; Making the Grade With Kent State Through Values, Not Victories
description: ON the night Laing Kennedy gathered the Kent State University football team to announce that the school was extending the coach's contract, Dean Pees's players stood and cheered as if he were Lombardi. Then they went out the next day and lost to Akron, 34-6, finishing their season at 1-10.

title: A Ford Executive Puts It in Park
description: After only three and a half years on the job, Bobbie Gaunt, 54, the highest-ranking woman at the Ford Motor Company, announced last week that she would quit at year-end as president and chief executive of its Canadian subsidiary and return to Michigan to spend more time with her family and work for nonprofit and small-business groups.

title: In a Leftist's Lens, The 'Common Man' Of a Dark Decade
description: THERE is a photograph of a despairing man, his face buried in his hands, sitting beside a poster for Charlie Chaplin's ''Modern Times.'' There is another of a woman standing glumly beside the empty window of a kosher poultry shop. Others: a man talks to a woman who has nervously raised the gloves in her hand to her mouth. Artists march with placards. Men sit around on benches, next to one another but effectively alone. A heavy woman and a thin one seriously, worriedly, study the signs in a travel bureau. This is how the streets of New York looked to Ben Shahn in the 1930's.

title: The Secret Pan
description: MAURICE RAVEL

title: Light of Foot, They Perform And Move On
description: ON a late November day, David Dorfman walked down Broadway in SoHo on his way to a rehearsal. The dance bag hanging from his shoulders, and the suitcase on wheels he trailed behind him, appeared to be packed with enough gear to rival the peddlers who had set up tables along the sidewalk where he passed.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: Chart; Top Secrets
description: Secret: What is the ''secret formula'' for Coca-Cola?Description: Concocted in 1886 by John Pemberton (and sold in 1888 to Asa Candler), the recipe for the world's most popular soft drink remains one of the best-kept secrets in American commerce. It's clear that the drink no longer contains one original ingredient, cocaine, but after that little is known.Party Line: The company says the key to the formula is the ''mystery ingredient'' known as Merchandise 7X, identified on Coca Cola's label only as ''natural flavorings.''Best Guess: Various researchers have speculated that 7X is a combination of oils derived from lemon, orange, coriander, nutmeg and cinnamon.

title: Audio Archaeology; Eavesdropping On History
description: The National Archives in Washington recently received an extraordinary request from Stephen St.Croix, who is the president of a company called Intelligent Devices. St.Croix is an expert in the esoteric field of sound extraction, and he proposes to solve one of Washington's most enduring mysteries: what was on the 18 1/2-minute gap on the Watergate tape? He believes he can retrieve the sound from a tape that may have been erased as many as five times more than 25 years ago.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: A year ago, demonstraters in Seattle ransacked a Starbucks Coffee store, venting their rage on that very visible symbol of globalization. Today, there are 566 Starbucks outlets in 18 foreign countries. There are also 15,751 McDonaldses in 119 foreign lands, as well innumerable Pizza Huts, KFC's, Dominoes, Burger Kings and other American fast food brands blanketing the globe. Surely, in an age when everybody eats and runs, this a wonderful thing?

title: Full of Himself
description: The Elvis-talking, bicep-bulging Johnny Bravo appears in viewers' favorites on ''The Best of Johnny Bravo Marathon,'' Saturday and next Sunday from noon to 8 p.m. on the Cartoon Network.

title: When Builders Are Inspectors
description: THERE are about 900,000 buildings in the five boroughs. And in the last year alone, the New York City Department of Buildings issued 68,702 construction permits -- 4,825 of them for entirely new buildings and 63,877 for alterations on existing structures, not infrequently to convert a century-old factory into residences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONE, IRENE (NEE BECKMANN)
description: KRONE-Irene (nee Beckmann). Beloved mother of Kathryn and wife of the late Helmut Krone. Died suddenly in a traffic accident in Martinique, Wednesday, November 29, 2000. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 7, 2000 at 1pm at The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd St. Donations in her memory may be made to the Helmut Krone Scholarship Fund at The One Club, 32 East 21 St., New York, NY, 10010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, REITER, JERILYN
description: HAYES-REITER-Jerilyn. On Nov. 30, Jeri died. She will be sadly missed by her family, Jonathan and daughters Mariel and Sophie, mother-in-law Shirley, and sisterin-law Fran, and relatives and friends. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 3rd, at 11:00 AM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue.

title: Where Chickens Don't Perch in the Meat Cooler
description: THERE are thousands of places in New York where you can buy a dead chicken. But until recently, there were just a few where you could get a live one.

title: Unfortunate Timing, No Matter Who Wins
description: IF a bad economy can break a president, then this is not the moment to become president of the United States. The economy is clearly faltering, on all fronts. What we are experiencing is no brief dip, to be followed soon by a fresh surge of activity. America faces a dry period -- long enough, perhaps, to taint the next chief of state, whether he is Al Gore or George W. Bush.

title: Consumer Magazine Coming To Rate Local Businesses
description: A nonprofit consumer group plans to start a local version of its Consumers' Checkbook magazine for the Westchester and Fairfield markets next fall. The Washington-based group, the Center for the Study of Services, has been publishing magazines for the Washington area since 1976 and for the San Francisco area since 1981.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-31

title: What's Doing in San Diego
description: San Diego's downtown has been promised a renaissance for decades, and despite a financing mixup that has stopped construction of a downtown park for the Padres baseball team, revitalization seems well under way.

title: Over 60: Fashion's Lost Generation
description: DOROTHY GRAY has spent a lifetime swimming upstream. An arbitrator at the New York Stock Exchange, she pursued her law career in the days when most women her age were chasing mates, and dressed with a fearless flair at a time when her peers at work were uniformly clad in meek gray suits. At 72, Ms. Gray, attired in sheared green mink, has by no means changed her ways. She still works. And she continues to dress with an elan that a much younger woman might envy.

title: Rappers Who Definitely Know How to Rock
description: WHEN Run-DMC and Aerosmith teamed up for ''Walk This Way'' in 1986, the result was a culture clash -- and a huge success. Critics and fans alike were captivated by the spectacle of upstart black rappers alongside veteran white rockers, and the music video played up the contrast: Run-DMC, clad in its trademark black jeans and sweatshirts, greeted the long-haired Aerosmith first with anger, then with enthusiasm. The song established Run-DMC as crossover pop stars and revivified Aerosmith's stagnant career. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s integrationist dream had returned as a brilliant marketing scheme.

title: Lively Puppets In a Dark World
description: THE primary work of Timothy and Stephen Quay -- the obscure, identical-twin siblings known to the world of cinema as the Brothers Quay -- is the arcane and highly specialized art of puppet animation. Yet what they accomplish in the nightmarish shorts for which they are best known -- and which have been released on DVD from Kino as ''The Brothers Quay Collection'' -- is closer to the medieval practice of alchemy than to any identifiable modern pursuit.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Malian guitarist Habib Koite misspelled the names of three musicians and a composer. The American guitarist who influenced Mr. Koite was Jimi Hendrix (not Hendricks). Two of Mr. Koite's Malian contemporaries are Salif Keita (not Kieta) and Oumou Sangare (not Omou). The American minimalist composer to whose work Mr. Koite's has been compared is Philip Glass (not Phillip).

title: Sharply Split Congress Grapples With How to Keep Things Going
description: With the newly elected Congress more closely divided than at any time since Dwight D. Eisenhower was president, members of both parties are wrestling with how to run a branch of government where any question -- from the confirmation of cabinet members to assigning committee office space -- could create deadlock.

title: ART REVIEWS
description: 'Aaron Copland's America'

title: Brookhaven Approves Construction Near Preserve
description: Stony Brook residents are crying foul over recent approval by the Brookhaven Town Planning Board of a proposal to expand construction on land bordering Forsythe Meadows, a Suffolk County nature preserve.

title: If Walls Could Talk, Here's What They'd Say
description: ONE afternoon last week Randy O'Neill, the customer-service director for Lancer Insurance in Long Beach, was getting ready to drive out to Farmingdale to visit Paul Gatto's studio. Mr. Gatto was putting the finishing touches on an oil painting that Lancer had commissioned of an antique Mack bus. Mr. O'Neill wanted to take a look, because if the painting passed muster (and it did), Mr. Gatto would strike a limited series of 2,000 lithographs for Lancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, ROYAL
description: FRIEDLANDER-Royal. On October 30, 2000, at Northwest Hospital, Seattle. Husband of the late Mary. Survived by sons Bernard and Joel, daughter-in-law, Jill, and grandson, Max. Recepient of the Bronze Star in WWII. Longtime resident of Westchester County. A printer, teacher of printing, volunteer, storyteller. Spent the last five years of his life as a resident of Seattle. Everyones ''Favorite Uncle''. He is dearly missed by many. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings, NY.

title: Mr. Humanismus
description: Leon Battista Alberti

title: Cities Need Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Microsoft Strikes Back
description: After a string of devastating rulings by a federal district court in the government's landmark antitrust lawsuit, the Microsoft Corporation struck back. In its opening brief with the Court of Appeals, the company accused Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of committing a host of procedural and substantive errors. The company also claimed that Judge Jackson was biased and had violated ethics rules by speaking publicly about the case.

title: Future Myths, Adrift in the Sands of Time
description: If you were a television producer with a $20 million property in your care, would you hand it over to a guy who had played a zombie in a George Romero movie? You would, if you were Richard P. Rubinstein, who figured that John Harrison -- who got a screwdriver in the ear in the legendary horror movie ''Dawn of the Dead'' -- was just the person to write and direct ''Frank Herbert's Dune,'' an epic-scaled, six-hour mini-series that is the Sci Fi channel's most ambitious project to date.

title: Silent, Holy, Calm, Bright, Etc.
description: MERRY CHRISTMAS!

title: From 'The Perfect Storm,' A Passage to Financial Freedom
description: THE winters of 1992, '93 and '94 here on Cape Cod were some of the coldest on record. Temperatures hovered in the 20's and low 30's, winds cut to the bone and local residents bundled in.

title: Coming to a Cabinet Near You: Jackie Chan As Defense Secretary
description: IN a brash, 11th-hour attempt to advance his cause, Democratic candidate Vice President Al Gore today announced ''my transition phase is over,'' and released a full list of Gore administration cabinet members.

title: Tuscaloosa Journal; A Meeting of Campuses Bridges a Cultural Gap
description: On the first day of class in Ethical and Effective Problem-Solving, Tamara Nix stood up when she introduced herself as a sophomore marketing major from Birmingham. Kathy Rogers sat as she shared her vitals: senior, creative writing, Starkville, Miss.

title: An Oriole Fan's Lament
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nixoniana
description: To the Editor:

title: Year-Old Ballet New York Spreads Its Wings
description: BALLET NEW YORK'S curtain raiser at Old Westbury next Sunday is not the customary elegant dance. Instead, the performance begins with an unstaged fragment of Rachmaninoff's soaring ''Vocalise,'' to which the audience just listens. Before a toe shoe is even pointed, the troupe's director and choreographer, Konstantin Uralsky, creates musical focus, reference to his native Russia, and a prologue to his new one-act ballet, ''Wanderers in the Light.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNIGAN, MABEL B.
description: FINNIGAN-Mabel B. November 27, 2000, at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Frederick. Sister of the late Edmund Burke. Funeral mass at Ascension R.C. Church, 221 West 107th St., Saturday, December 16th, 10:30 AM.

title: Gina Imperato, Charles Oestreicher
description: Gina Lynn Imperato and Charles Gary Oestreicher were married last evening by Rabbi Michael White at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, LISA LENTNEK
description: WHITNEY-Lisa Lentnek. Of Dobbs Ferry, NY, at age 35. Beloved wife of Klaus and loving mother of Matthew, age seven, and Steven, age five. Lisa was the daughter of Donald and Ruth Lentnek of Woodmere, NY, and sister of David and Marci Klein and their daughter Ayana. Lisa was a graduate of Lawrence High School 1983, and the University of Pennsylvania in 1987. Lisa and Klaus were married September, 1991, in NYC. She will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral today, 1:30 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY. Memorial contributions to Extended Health Care Fund at Woodlands Community Temple, 50 Worthington Rd., White Plains, NY 10607.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKENS LEVEY, EMILY
description: WILKENS LEVEY-Emily. On December 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Judge Irving L. Levey. Loving mother of Hugh W. Levey and Jane W. Michael. Adoring grandmother of Alex, Evan, Philip, Elise and Mariel. Loving sister to Janet Manus. Service will be private. Contributions may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave., Bronx, NY 10471. For information contact Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, Bronx.

title: POSTINGS: Public Meetings This Week; The Next Phase For Ellis Island
description: Ten years after transforming the Main Building on Ellis Island into an immigration museum, the National Parks Service is preparing the next phase of its work, to save and rehabilitate 30 other historic structures on the island that have fallen into disrepair since being abandoned by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the 1950's. They include the vast Baggage and Dormitory Building, the New Ferry Building (a 1930's replacement, hence its designation as new) and the 28-building hospital complex.

title: Children's Books
description: MOISHE'S MIRACLE

title: Copy Shop
description: THE FORGER

title: Paths for Our Warming Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel Daly, John Knox
description: Rachel Kristin Daly, a daughter of Margaret Daly of Wantagh, N.Y., and the late Thomas P. Daly, was married last evening to John Joseph Knox, the son of Farideh Knox of New York and James Knox of Sarasota, Fla. Msgr. Edward Mitty performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Princeton Combos Mix It Up
description: A familiar quip about changeable weather is, ''If you don't like it, wait a few minutes.'' The same might be said of a Princeton University event that pushes the 20th-century concert envelope so far that it can't be given a name. Works by Stravinsky and Ravel fit into the envelope neatly. A concerto by a graduate student, informed by the resonances of the Norwegian folk fiddle, stretches the envelope some, but universities often give exposure to campus composers. The big rarity in Thursday's concert, to be repeated in Richardson Auditorium on Saturday, joins the Princeton University Orchestra and its Concert Jazz Ensemble in Duke Ellington's ''Tone Parallel to Harlem.'' It's academe meets mondo classico meets jazz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYLVAN, SEYMOUR
description: SYLVAN-Seymour. Of Oradell, NJ on Nov. 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Sarah (nee Greenspan). Devoted father of Larry and Ken. Dear brother of Elliott. Loving grandfather of Adam, Zachary, & Jennifer. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner of Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ, Sunday, at 11:30 AM.

title: Sky Watch: A Most Fascinating Body
description: For those with binoculars and telescopes the next few nights will offer the best views for observing the Moon, one of the most fascinating of celestial bodies. In fact, even with just small optical power, a wealth of detail on its surface can be seen. Around those times when the Moon is half-lit or in gibbous phase, those features lying close to the terminator  that variable line between the illuminated portion and the part of the Moon in shadow  stand out in sharp, clear relief.

title: Talk of Midweek Legislative Session to Pick Bush Electors, but Senate Leader Hesitates
description: Late this afternoon, it looked as if Republican leaders of the Florida Legislature were making plans to call a special session beginning midweek to award Florida's 25 electors to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

title: Miss Kitty Sashays Into Times Square
description: When Sanrio, a gift and accessory chain known for its oh-so-cute character Hello Kitty, opened in Times Square last month, it introduced a New York line of Hello Kitty products exclusive to the store.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFFMAN, PAT
description: KAUFFMAN-Pat. November 24. Founder and President of Entertainment for the Blind, a non-profit organization that integrates the sightless into the world of arts and culture. Beloved mother of Dorothy, Sherry and Debby. A force on Broadway and Lincoln Center. An exceptional woman who made a difference in the lives of many. Memorial Service at Riverside Memorial Chapel on December 11 at 6 PM.

title: The Sort of Affair to Make a Girl Feel Shabby
description: I'VE had my fair share of one-night stands.

title: Miami: A new Marriott sheds its traditional image in South Beach
description: My overnight stay at the new Marriott at South Beach in Miami began on a warm note. As my taxi pulled up at the entrance, two young men in crisp white shirts and blue shorts bounded forward to open the door, welcomed me effusively and escorted my luggage up the stairs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 19 about votes on environmental issues misstated the name of a park in Port Washington, a candidate for enlargement with money from a new conservation fund. It is the Barbara Johnson Memorial Park, not Barbara John.

title: Michelle Connolly, Jeffrey Roberts
description: Michelle Louise Connolly, a daughter of Rosemary Coyne of Doylestown, Pa., and Kevin Connolly of Annandale, Va., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Michael Roberts, a son of Nancy and Michael Roberts of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. John R. Gilchrist performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield.

title: An Opening Created by a Cloud
description: The opportunity for Tim Legler to take the Middle Township High School girls' basketball coaching job came under unfortunate circumstances.

title: Imported Pest Raises Fears For Forests
description: SINCE it was first spotted in Brooklyn in 1996, the Asian long-horned beetle has caused the destruction of 5,100 trees in New York and 1,400 in Chicago. Infested trees are cut down, chipped and burned because there is no other way to kill the pest, which has come dangerously close to Central Park in New York and Lincoln Park in Chicago.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Drug Roadblocks Barred
description: In the drug wars, police officers on traffic duty have been ground troops, stopping and searching cars. The United States Supreme Court drew some limits, ruling that stopping traffic at checkpoints to interdict drugs is going too far. The offender was Indianapolis, where officers at roadblocks checked drivers' licenses and registrations and had dogs sniff for drugs. The court's 6-to-3 decision said the city's general interest in reducing crime could not override the general rule that a police search requires some ground for suspicion. Laura Mansnerus

title: Where They Can Do Something About the Weather: Predict It
description: Since 1993, the National Weather Service office that makes forecasts for the southern and central part of the state plus southeastern Pennsylvania, northeastern Maryland and all of Delaware has been in Mount Holly. Recently, the Weather Service started providing more detailed forecasts. Gary Szatkowski, the meteorologist in charge of the Mount Holly office, talked about weather forecasting.

title: Bookend; Where's the Beef?
Porcini, Even a Little, Goes Far Mixed With Something Else
description: BOLETUS EDULIS, perhaps the greatest mushroom of all, is now in season. More commonly known as porcini or cepes, the crop now showing up in food markets and restaurants is from Oregon. But these mushrooms are not cheap -- they cost around $40 a pound. If you have plenty of porcini, slice them and grill or saute them in butter and olive oil. But just $10 worth goes a long way, however, when the mushrooms are combined with something else.

title: A Never-Say-Old Generation Can't Outrace the Clock Forever
description: THE 70 million or so baby boomers, by virtue of their numbers, have changed just about everything they've touched as they have moved through and dominated the demographic pipeline.

title: Death, and Life, in a Medical School in Yemen

title: Hotel With a Chilly Reception, by Design

Modeled on the igloolike Icehotel Sweden in Jukkasjarvi, Sweden, the Ice Hotel in Quebec will be built this month from 2,500 tons of ice and 4,500 tons of snow.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Yes to Doctor-Aided Suicide
description: Dutch lawmakers approved a bill allowing doctors to assist seriously ill and suffering patients in their wish to die. The law, which is expected to go into effect next year, will make the Netherlands the first country to legalize doctor-assisted suicide, a practice that was widely tolerated but technically remained a crime. The Royal Dutch Medical Association has drawn up a series of strict conditions, now embedded in the law, that doctors must meet before proceeding. The law applies to physicians only, not to others who want to help someone die or commit suicide. Marlise Simons

He said his Delaware football team had pounded previously unbeaten Lehigh today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA quarterfinals, 47-22, because the Blue Hens had been conditioned for a run deep into the playoffs. Then I touched a match to the two incense-like sticks and pushed them into the soft bare earth, waiting to make sure they would remain lit before I placed a perforated bucket over them.

title: Add Up the Losers, and You Get a Multimillionaire
description: EVERYBODY'S inner adolescent acts up now and then. Maybe you're half-awake in a hotel room and overhear someone you're traveling with making fun of the fact that you snore or talk in your sleep, and you just want to die. Or disappear. Maybe you have a conversation with a colleague in which he mentions Plato's cave (a space where innocents mistook shadows for reality), but when you refer to it you inexplicably say Plato's Retreat (a space where 1970's swingers met for group sex). Suddenly you've time-warped back to seventh grade, with all the attendant insecurity and potential for humiliation. At times like these you can understand Adam Sandler's success.

title: The Nation: Altered States; A Shift in the U.S.-Cuba Time Warp
description: IN an era when an American president beguiles crowds in Vietnam, and China is a key trading partner, U.S. policymakers still need to be reminded of their victory over communism when talk turns to Cuba.

Andrea Bocelli, the megastar tenor and crossover champion, has made his first complete opera recording, singing the role of Rodolfo in a new version of ''La Boheme'' from Decca. The conductor is Zubin Mehta, who has never worried about sullying his artistic reputation with commercial ventures when a fat fee is involved. To the bargain, Mr. Mehta brought the Israel Philharmonic, a distinguished orchestra that can no doubt use the cash.

In my play ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' I first imagined a woman making a speech at a ladies' luncheon and breaking down in the middle of it. I set out to write a play that would ultimately lead to that event. The inspiration for ''The Sisters Rosensweig'' was far less circuitous. I was the youngest of three sisters, and three sisters has proved itself not a bad idea for a play. If your sister's nickname is Gorgeous, moreover, how could you not take advantage of it?

But these mushrooms are not cheap -- they cost around $40 a pound. If you have plenty of porcini, slice them and grill or saute them in butter and olive oil. But just $10 worth goes a long way, however, when the mushrooms are combined with something else.

title: Invisible Man; The Pretenders
description: Walking down a crowded street in Tokyo, it is impossible to know if that well-dressed man you just passed actually has a job or is just pretending to go to work. When Japan's economy collapsed in 1989, unemployment, unheard of in the country's postwar boom, hit hard, jumping from 1 percent then to 5 percent today. Though the saddest effect of the cataclysm is Japan's rising suicide rate, its strangest is the number of former salarymen who haunt the business districts of downtown Tokyo, unable to stay home or in their neighborhoods between the morning and evening rush hours. These men -- and they are all men -- are the newly unemployed. They are as elusive as body snatchers, rising early every day, donning white shirts and knotting their ties before setting out for jobs they no longer have. Some have not yet found a way to tell their wives and families the bad news. Others are afraid their neighbors will find out. Nearly all have given up hope of a better future: they are middle-aged in a country that hires young and, until recently, for life. This is not the land of second chances.

By informing the film's thrilling displays of physical prowess with psychological insight and choreographic sophistication, Mr. Lee touches the heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIN, GLADYS TALMAGE
description: PERKIN-Gladys Talmage. On Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2000, at home in New Canaan, CT. Age 93. Beloved wife of the late Richard Scott Perkin, a founder of the PerkinElmer Corporation. Born Gladys Frelinghuysen Talmage on May 13, 1907, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frelinghuysen Talmage, of Brooklyn Heights and East Hampton, Long Island. She was a descendant of Captain Thomas Talmage, a founder of East Hampton in 1648, and Philip Rhinelander, 18th Century New York Merchant. She attended Pine Manor College and Pratt Institute and, in 1930, married investment banker, Richard S. Perkin. In 1937, she assisted him in the formation of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, which became a leading manufacturer of optical systems and scientific instruments. Following Mr. Perkin's death in 1969, Gladys Perkin devoted her life to philanthropy. As Chairman of The Perkin Fund, she supported the American Museum of Natural History, The Boston Academy of Music, Harvard's Center for Blood Research, The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, The Juilliard School, The New England Conservatory, New York Presbyterian Hospital, Norwalk Hospital, Rockefeller University, The Waveny Care Center and The Wildlife Conservation Society. In 1980, Pratt Institute awarded her the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. A longtime member of the New Canaan Garden Club, Mrs. Perkin also served for many years on the Visiting Committee of Harvard's Department of Astronomy and as a member of the Rockefeller University Council. Gladys Perkin is survived by three of her children, Richard T. Perkin of New York, Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, Mass., and Robert S. Perkin of Darien, Conn. Her son, John T. Perkin, died in 1997. She also leaves nine grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and her brother, Theodore Frelinghuysen Talmage of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Funeral services will be held at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge (Route 124), New Canaan, Conn., at 11:00AM, Monday, December 4. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to St. Mark's Episcopal Church or Waveny Care Center, both in New Canaan.

title: High-Tech Smuggling; The Submarine Next Door
description: Last July, eavesdroppers for the Colombian national police intercepted a series of radio conversations that Col. Jaime Enrique Bonilla describes as ''very strange.'' ''They were saying things like, 'Bring the flour for the party tonight,' and 'The foreigners are ready,''' recalls Bonilla, who oversees the division of the police force that operates in the mountainous central state of Cundinamarca, which includes Bogota. ''They didn't use names. Lots of farmers communicate with one another using radios, but they always use names. When people don't use names, that concerns us.'' Fourteen leftist rebel groups are based in Cundinamarca, and investigators suspected they were overhearing coded conversations about arms trafficking, cocaine processing or preparations to attack a village.

description: THE windows at Feinsod hardware store on Purchase Street here look much as they have for many Christmas seasons. A mechanized Santa waves a gloved hand; an intricately wrought miniature carousel rotates and plays carols; deer made of white lights and wire stand on cotton snow. This year, however, it is all partially obscured by something new: big signs in bright colors bearing the words ''sale,'' ''store closing'' and ''everything must go.''

You take a step back and look again, with wonder. There it all is: roofless rooms, passages twisting into forgetfulness, an altar . . . painted? Blood-stained? What?

Ben Affleck, who was not such a huge star three and a half years ago, is the charming, boyish hero of CHASING AMY (1997), and Joey Lauren Adams is the sexy-voiced blonde of his dreams. The film is a smart, spare, quick-witted comedy that treats sexual orientation as just one more complication in the course of modern true love. Kevin Smith wrote and directed, so there are a number of conversational riffs that are thoroughly unrelated to the plot and highly entertaining - Friday at 10:05 p.m. on Starz.

The new hall will be housed at the Armory Track and Field Center at 168th Street and Broadway, it was announced yesterday. The Armory in upper Manhattan has become a beacon for the sport, and this season will be the site for more than 80 track meets and will serve as a training site for more than 40,000 athletes.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Barak Agrees to Elections
description: In the midst of continued violence, Israel plunged into a politically turbulent period. Unofficially, campaign season began when Prime Minister Ehud Barak, wresting the initiative from his rivals, said he would not fight the lawmakers' hunger for new general elections. Sometime next spring -- the date has not been set -- Mr. Barak is expected to face Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister, in a rematch of their 1999 race. But Mr. Barak has to win internal Labor Party primaries, and Mr. Netanyahu has not made clear if he will throw his hat in the ring and fight Ariel Sharon for the Likud Party leadership. Deborah Sontag

title: Woman's Pottery Collection Becomes Store's Inventory
description: For years, Barbara Ross has been collecting pottery made by a company named Red Wing from a Minnesota town of the same name. Her collection of 3,500 pieces has now become the initial inventory for the Red Wing Gallery on Main Street in Tarrytown. The store, which opened in October, also sells paintings, jewelry, antiques and handmade furniture.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; 427 Rental Units for Active-Adult Retirement Market
description: A DEVELOPER known for rental properties has broadened his offerings in the active-adult retirement market with a 427-apartment development that will differ from most such communities by allowing residents to lease, rather than purchase, their apartments. The development, Woodbridge Hills, will offer people 55 and over housing as well as social and recreational activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVNI, MOSHE
description: AVNI-Moshe. On Thursday, November 30, Moshe Avni, age 70, of LaGrangeville, NY, died while visiting his family in Tel Aviv. He is survived by his sister, Lenka Juster, and brother, Zalman Rubinstein, both of Israel; his daughters Ravit Avni-Singer, of New Haven, CT and Michal Avni, of Washington, DC; and his three grandchildren, Nathan and Lital Avni-Singer and Eitan Avni-Heller. A funeral service was held Sunday December 3 at Rishon L'etzion, Israel. A memorial service in New York will be announced soon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Avni Foundation, a fund established by Mr. Avni to promote the teaching of ethics in schools (c/o 132 Todd Hill Rd., LaGrangeville, NY 12540).

title: Replacing Wall Tiles In Shower
description: Q. I have a new house. My contractor installed the wrong color wall tile in the shower stall of one of the bathrooms. I'd like to have him replace it with the color I like, but my mother-in-law is concerned that removing the old tile and retiling will damage the wall. What do you think? . . . Eileen Russ Heltzer, Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Learning With a Difference, One Step at a Time
description: Sarah, a fifth grander, remembers watching her classmates learn to read and spell while she was left behind. ''It's like trying to climb a mountain,'' she says. ''I had all the equipment I needed, but I couldn't get over the mountain without help.''

title: Changing Ownership For Women in Football
description: The Women's Professional Football League, which made its Long Island debut last year, has grown to 11 teams playing a 10-game schedule. One of the notable games of the season was played yesterday in an intracity rivalry pitting the New York Sharks against a team from the Women's Continental Football League, the New York Gems.

title: Presidents in Waiting
description: Now that we have all been beaten silly by legal and political oratory, perhaps it is time to ask what the proverbial visitor from Mars would make of all this. On first arriving, he or she might think that a tirelessly explanatory fellow named David Boies and a stern woman named Karen Hughes had been put in charge of arguing out some arcane tribal dispute. Somewhat later the visitor would conclude that the respective sides looked to mournful, world-weary sachems called Lieberman and Cheney for spiritual guidance. That would lead eventually to the core anthropological problem of figuring out the parts of two iconic figures who appeared sporadically to great fanfare but little visible progress -- first Al Gore, who presented himself as the victim of cosmic injustice, and then George W. Bush, who promised that many questions would someday be answered by a potent but elusive character known as Jim Baker. To the visitor, this Baker's main trait would seem to be skill in scaring the beautifully costumed Warren Christopher away from a place called Tallahassee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORITZKY, HAROLD
description: PORITZKY-Harold. Age 82, of Yorktown Heights, NY, passed on November 27, 2000. Survived by loving wife Helen, daughters Pamela and Robin, granddaughters Tanyth and Eleanor, brothers Bernard, Herman and Alan Sander Poritzky. Beloved teacher and mentor to thousands of students and colleagues. Memorial gathering will be held Sunday, December 10, 2000, 2-5 PM, at Eagle Bay Clubhouse, Rt. 9, North Ossining, NY. Donations to MS Society, 2 Gannett Dr., Suite LC, White Plains, NY 10604; 914-694-1655.

title: Restoring Your Stained-Glass Windows
description: MANY homes built between 1880 and 1930 have sashes over doors or in-window frames with stained glass. These attractive windows add a striking decorative accent to any interior. A large number of these still survive today but over time, they can sag and deteriorate. Homeowners often wonder how the windows can be restored and whether repair techniques can be performed by the average do-it-yourselfer or if they should be done by professional restorers.

title: INVESTING WITH: Anthony R. Manno Jr., Kevin W. Bedell And Kenneth D. Statz; Security Capital U.S. Real Estate Shares Fund

Manno Jr., who worked for a bank that made loans to real estate owners and developers through the 1970's bear market, brings extensive experience in real estate financing. Kevin W. Bedell offers skills gained at a private real estate investment adviser. Kenneth D. Statz has Wall Street perspective as a former real estate investment trust analyst at Goldman Sachs.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2  This multicultural city of four million people recently celebrated ethnic diversity and harmony at the 2000 Olympic Games, but local Jews and Muslims are now worried by more than 100 physical and verbal attacks on Jews since the Games finished on Oct. 1.

title: Food; The Clandestine Chef
description: Roxy Beowulf Kazar (not her real name) is an acquaintance who may or may not have gone to China in the not so distant past. If she did, she may or may not have befriended Whua Tre Karvalho (not remotely her real name), a native of the Xinjiang Autonomous Region and a wonderful cook. Karvalho told Roxy that if either of their names wound up in print, Karvalho would be tracked down and arrested. ''For revealing a recipe?'' asked a stunned Roxy. Karvalho replied, ''Just because I'm paranoid doesn't mean the Chinese didn't get Hong Kong back.''

A Berkeley Carroll parent and member of the faculty since 1984, he leaves a legacy of passion for our school, its students, academic excellence, and a zeal for athletics, especially soccer. Our love and deepest sympathy go to his son, Larry, Class of 1999, his daughter, Jordan, Class of 2001, their mother, Helen Chan, his sisters, Valerie Lynch and Rosalind Inglis, and his fiancee, Antoinette Duncan. To honor and celebrate Peter's life, the School will hold a memorial service on Monday, December 4, 3:30 PM, at Old First Church, 7th Avenue and Carroll Street, in Park Slope. title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Mexico Gets a New President
description: Vicente Fox Quesada, wearing cowboy boots and promising change, became the president of Mexico. His swearing-in marked the end of seven decades of one-party rule and the start of a newly democratic era in the nation. The day was marked by a mild earthquake, a puff of smoke from an 18,000-foot volcano outside Mexico City, and a surge of hope among many Mexicans who voted in July to wrest the presidency from the Institutional Revolution Party, which had run the country since 1929. title: ARCHITECTURE
description: THE ATHENIAN ACROPOLIS: History, Mythology, and Archaeology From the Neolithic Era to the Present. By Jeffrey M. Hurwit. (Cambridge University, cloth, $79.95; paper, $27.95.) The limestone outcropping on which the world's most celebrated civic center is built forms such a natural site for a citadel and sanctuary that it is not surprising to learn that the Acropolis of Athens was held sacred some 5,000 years before the Periclean Age and its Parthenon. In this magisterial study of the ''high city'' sacred to the Greek city's goddess, Athena, Jeffrey M. Hurwit, a professor of art history and classics at the University of Oregon, displays immense erudition and command of the scholarly literature. Yet, far from producing a dryly academic treatise, Hurwit constructs a vivid picture of this multipurpose hub of ancient urban life and details just how the Acropolis was used, when and by whom.

title: This Web Site Rocks! (It's Turning a Profit.)

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: The Ethicist; Husbands and Lies
description: I am a police officer, and I sometimes handle phone inquiries from family members about persons just arrested. When a wife asks about charges, and her husband has been arrested for soliciting a prostitute, I can withhold the information in the hope that he has learned his lesson, sparing her pain and humiliation, and perhaps preserving a marriage. But is a husband who violates the law and his vows entitled to my protection? And worse, withholding the truth could put the wife at risk of contracting a sexually transmitted disease. Should I tell or not? -- Anonymous, N. Y.

title: BUSINESS DESIGNATION SOUGHT

It is the city's third attempt for such a designation, which will enable it to extend tax breaks and other incentives to new businesses. Gerrie Post, the city's commissioner of planning and community development, said Mount Vernon was previously turned down for the designation because the city did not meet state specifications for vacant land. Mount Vernon, which encompasses 4.2 square miles, is 99 percent developed. This year, Ms. Post said, the state is being ''more flexible'' about that requirement. Elsa Brenner

The L.I.R.R. is in fact a giant economic experiment. The goal of the experiment is now clear: To discover the equilibrium point at which the least possible competence may be obtained at the highest possible price.

title: Big Ambitions on a Tiny Irish Stage
description: THE road from Dublin to the deep southeast of Ireland runs straight but slow between the Wicklow Mountains and the sea, and at the far end of it stands Wexford: an unprepossessing, huddled coastal town that looks across the mud flats -- slobs, locals call them -- that frame the estuary to the River Slaney. Signs on the approach roads tell you Wexford is Historic, which is true in that the English King Henry II supposedly spent 40 nights on his knees in its now ruined abbey, doing penance for the murder of Thomas a Becket in 1170. But otherwise, like most small towns in Ireland, Wexford isn't much more than a couple of churches, a couple of hotels and a parade of shops alternately called Doyle or Murphy: somewhere you might easily not know about except that -- unlike most small towns in Ireland, or anywhere else -- it happens to have an annual opera festival of international significance.

title: Expanding the Hedge Fund Tent
description: HEDGE funds have long been regarded as investments for the wealthy, and justifiably so. Getting in can run to much more than $1 million at the best funds, and only recently did initial investments at others begin to fall as low as $100,000. And that does not take into account the usual high management fees, or an incentive fee for the fund manager that is generally a hefty 20 percent of annual profits.

title: What Secrets Tell
description: Once, it was believed that a wholesale revelation of secrets would not occur until the Day of Judgment, when graves would be opened and the tongues of the dead at last loosened. Nowadays you might almost get the impression that the time had arrived, so profuse has been the unsealing of lips, the unlocking of vaults, the uncovering of caches. Secrets, some of them moss-covered with age, have one after another been stripped naked in public. There are two major catalysts for this phenomenon. The dissolution of the Soviet empire, first of all, opened a tremendous number of lead-lined rooms. We now know where various bodies are buried, who spied and for whom and what they transmitted. Because to Westerners the U.S.S.R. was for more than 70 years the No. 1 sphinx, the serial release of K.G.B. documents over the past decade has solved whole shelves' worth of longstanding mysteries and promoted an atmosphere of real or imaginary worldwide openness.

title: Children's Books; Peace Among the Animals
description: Here is BEAR NOEL, written and illustrated by Olivier Dunrea (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 4 to 8), a calming book for a season that is anything but calm. A huge and jovial Bear Noel tromps through the north woods, bringing Christmas to the animals -- Hare and Wolf, Fox and Boar, Hedgehog and Possum. A refrain, repeated on each page as each new animal is alerted, is perfect for read-aloud merriment: ''He is getting nearer. . . . He is laughing. . . . He is coming (whispered). . . . Who is coming? . . . Bear Noel!'' (shouted). The full beauty of Olivier Dunrea's book, however, is in the details. Snow falls from the top of every page into the oblivion of the snow-white bottom, sometimes gently yet other times so briskly we can see the eyes and face of Fox braced against the cold. The snow is thick and seemingly untouched, covering every branch and rock, but there is still a hint of green moss on the side of a tree and evergreens darkly etched against the night sky. The snow ''shimmers and sparkles'' on the trees but lies ''hushed and silent'' on the frozen ground. Dunrea matches word to image as each sensuous illustration expands across the page. For a brief moment, the snow stops as the animals feast at the small tree Bear Noel has decorated with berries and nuts and seed balls. For a brief moment, says Bear Noel, ''All creatures may come together without fear.'' It is Christmas Eve. Hare stands on the back of Wolf. Fox protects Hedgehog. Bear Noel jingles his bells. Here is the message of peace the season is meant to convey. On the last page, we see only Bear Noel silently disappearing into the snow. Does the peace among the animals last? Could it? There is an unspoken invitation for the child to wonder. Bear Noel is as simple, complex and elegant a story as each single snowflake. Karen Leggett

description: Back when Jimmy Carter was president, his anti-inflation czar, Alfred Kahn, was chastised for his excessive frankness when he spoke about a possible recession. So in subsequent speeches he referred to the threatened event as a ''banana.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLAN, ELI
description: BALLAN-Eli. 71 on November 19, 2000 in Boca Raton, FL. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, friend. An exceptional man in every respect. He will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, BENITA
description: RICH-Benita. Died peacefully on December 1, 2000 after a long battle against breast cancer. Beloved mother of Jeffrey (Olivia), Marc (Debra), and Lisa Singer (Richard). Adoring grandmother of Wyatt, Blake, Mackenzie, Jackson, Alec and Kelly. Cherished sister of Barbara Levine (Richard) and daughter of the late Samuel and Kate Moskowitz. Funeral services will be private. She will be sadly missed. Her memory will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Reading Into the Navajos' Rugs
description: MUCH can be -- and has been -- read into the rugs of the Navajos. But in doing so, many scholars say, it is easy to confuse fact and fantasy. That's the theme explored in ''The Navajo Weaving Tradition,'' an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich that parades two dozen blankets and rugs, ablaze in color and design.

title: An Ailing Russia Lives a Tough Life That's Getting Shorter
description: When the chest pains first gripped him that February day in 1998, Anatoly Iverianov was driving a tractor through one of the birch-and-pine forests that carpet Russia's border with Finland, dragging fresh-cut logs to a wood lot.

title: Duke Bombards Temple With Its 3-Point Prowess
description: For all of its disruptive reputation, Temple's matchup zone defense can be pulled out of shape like an old sweater by crisp passing on the perimeter and the dispiriting accuracy of 3-point shooting.

title: Memo to Art Museums: Don't Give Up on Art
description: WHAT do art museums want? The question is a recurring one, raised at different times for different reasons. But lately it has acquired a particular urgency because the answer, it increasingly seems, is that they want to be anything but art museums.

title: CLARIDGE REORGANIZATION
description: The Claridge Corporation said it would sell the Claridge Hotel in Altantic City to Park Place Entertainment under a bankruptcy plan was filed last week in federal bankruptcy court in Camden. The Claridge Hotel has been in bankruptcy protection since filing for Chapter 11 in August 1999. The plan calls selling the hotel for about $65 million and paying its creditors $83 million: $79.1 million in stock and $6.7 million in cash. The Claridge, shown here, which opened in 1981, is next to Bally's Park Place Hotel, which is owned by Park Place Entertainment. Abhi Raghunathan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BONASORTE, GARY
description: BONASORTE-Gary. Friends of this beloved man will gather on Thursday, Dec 7, at 1PM at St. Marks Church In-the-Bowery, 2nd Ave and 10th St, to celebrate his memory. At 8PM the same day his last play ''Big Hearts'' will be performed at Rattlestick Theater, 224 Waverly Pl. All are welcomed.

title: Gov. Taft Praises Bush Move in Preparing for Presidency
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2  Gov. George W. Bush is "rightfully our president-elect" and should not be faulted for beginning a transition to the presidency, picking a cabinet and setting the tone for his administration, Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio said today in the Republicans' weekly radio address.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Holiday Books issue of December 1999. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction and poetry, nonfiction, children's books, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings. The complete reviews of these books may be found at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.

title: True Romance
description: SIDETRACKS

title: Rock 'n' Roll With a Mission
description: A group of New Jersey rock 'n' roll musicians, mostly from the shore area, got together seven years ago with the idea of playing a few concerts for needy people at places like soup kitchens or homeless shelters.

title: TRAVEL
description: Has daily life in the industrialized world become too comfortable, too predictable, too safe? Is it necessary nowadays to put oneself at great physical risk in hostile climes in order to have anything worth calling an adventure? The short answer to these questions would seem to be yes -- at least if this season's bounty of far-flung and hairy-chested travel narratives is any indication. But there's also a long answer, reminding us that the right kind of traveler can experience as much exhilaration bumming around Saskatchewan in a rusty Citron as joy-riding through the minefields of Cambodia on a dirt bike. After all, you don't have to read Milton to know that the mind is its own place, and that the mind of the traveler can make, say, an Akron of Aqaba, an Aqaba of Akron.

title: Old McDonald Had a Wedding
description: Hayrides. Hot apple pie. Bins filled with home-grown produce. These are some ways to try save New Jersey's dwindling number of family farms.

title: London: 2 Tones of Luxury
description: BY the time I got to the Halkin Hotel, a three-minute walk from Hyde Park Corner, it was midafternoon and I was wilting after a flurry of work earlier in the day. Tucked away on a quiet, pretty street feeding off a noisy, unpretty street, the 41-room hotel is unassuming and discreet. Look down to answer your cell phone, and you might miss it. But as the taxi pulled up, a smooth young man in a chic black suit suddenly materialized from inside the automatic glass doors to whisk my suitcase away and usher me inside.

title: The Original Spin Doctor
description: Niccol's Smile

title: Let Them Eat Cake, and Visit Long Island
description: DISCOVER the undiscovered Island. That's the old slogan of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau. And that's what a group of French travel agents recently did.

title: Site R; Bunker? What Bunker?
description: The man switches off his leaf blower and turns to regard the mountain rising behind his yellow-sided Cape house with its split-rail fence and immaculate yard. He has lived here more than 50 years, and in all that time, he swears, he has never learned what goes on inside the mountain, what lies behind the Warning: Restricted Area signs and the heavily guarded gates and the tall fence topped with barbed wire. Never wondered about the two obvious tunnel entrances across the valley from his front porch. Or about the helicopters thundering in and out of the area at all hours. Or about the elaborate antennas on the mountaintop. Sorry, he shakes his head. He can't help.

title: Playing Your Career Against the Market
description: IN choosing their investments, most people regard balance and diversification as a matter of choosing the right mix of stocks, bonds and mutual funds to match their goals. But a growing number of economists say investors are overlooking one of the most important elements of their financial portfolios: their jobs.

title: At Cooper Square, a New Player Takes the Stage
description: TWENTY years ago -- or 30 or 40 for that matter -- the Cooper Square Committee would have scorned the redevelopment plan for three acres of urban renewal land off East Houston Street that a community task force worked out with the Giuliani administration a year ago. The committee is a nonprofit community development organization that formed four decades ago to resist the redevelopment plans of Robert Moses in the neighborhood.

title: A River Rises
description: WHEN Majora Carter was growing up in Hunts Point, the Bronx River was a nasty rumor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, MARGOT
description: STEWART-Margot, on November 27, 2000, in NYC. Loving mother of Brandon, dearest sister of Gerda Loffler and Gunther Endres. Born June 24, 1927, in Nuremberg, Germany. Painter, mosaic muralist and charter student of the Norfolk School of Art of Yale University. She had numerous shows, including solo exhibits at the John B. Myers Gallery. Known for her kindness to her fellow artists, she was an assistant to Charles Egan when his gallery showed artists who became the forefront of Abstract Expressionism. Her love of nature and animals inspired her to create beautiful visions for those she touched. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Port Offers Shippers A Siberian Shortcut
description: ONLY five years ago, Vostochny International Container Services -- a port terminal in a city of rat-infested apartment blocks and above-ground hot water pipes -- did not even own a fax machine.

title: U.S. Is Easing Close Scrutiny Of Hotel Union
description: The Justice Department has signed an agreement to end five years of intensive oversight of the nation's largest union of hotel workers.

title: Guts on Sticks
description: LONG DISTANCE

title: Tara Nowick, Jeffrey Stein
description: Tara Julie Nowick, the daughter of Ilana and Neil A. Nowick of White Plains, was married there last evening to Jeffrey Alan Stein, a son of Joanne and Joseph Stein Jr. of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Ridgeway Country Club.

title: The Election: When First Impressions Count; Florida Face-Off
description: AMONG the myriad facts the presidential election drama has brought home, from obscure points of constitutional law to the categorization of chads, one truth about human nature stands out: No matter how far Americans think they have come in the ways they size people up, they still judge a book by its cover -- and a woman by her foundation.

title: Special Toys by One-of-a-Kind Makers
description: IN a time when many toys are made of molded plastic, drawing their power from batteries and their inspiration from movies or television, the search for simple wooden or fabric toys can be a real challenge. The goal is to find something safe -- no button eyes that pull off, no wires or nails -- and something that a child will find intriguing enough to play with over and over. A big bonus, though hard to find, is a toy that is handcrafted by an artisan, someone who can customize it and add special touches, and who will be there to do repairs or supply additional toys as gifts.

title: Tradition (and a $6 Haircut) Dies After a Building Is Sold
description: Edward I. Koch has sat in his chair. So have Mario M. Cuomo, Abraham D. Beame and legions of other civil servants. They all came to sit for Frank Lagana, known as the unofficial barber of City Hall.

title: The Screech of Brakes, and a Call for a Crackdown
description: The two accidents occurred on the same day.

title: Cry of 'Buses Are Coming!' Echoes on a Quiet Street
description: The flier, passed out to residents of the quiet, tree-lined streets, prophesied gloom and doom.

title: Corrections
description: An interview transcript in The Times Magazine last Sunday about Bernard Shaw, the CNN anchor, misspelled the brand name of the gin in a martini he savored the day after the election. It is Bombay Sapphire, named for the gemstone. (Safire, also a refreshing spirit, was the author of the column five pages later.)

title: AIRPORT CURFEW
description: Panorama Flight Services, whose clients include light general aviation users and operators, has agreed not to work on aircraft at the Westchester County Airport in Harrison overnight, when a voluntary flying curfew is in effect. Under terms of a proposed revision of its lease with the county, Panorama will not service aircraft before 6 a.m. -- and even then only to serve aircraft that will depart after 6:30 a.m. Panorama is the second airport tenant to agree to the curfew in its lease. Elsa Brenner

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Grand Caravan and Chrysler Town & Country; It's Time for a Recount In a Tight Minivan Race
description: TWO years ago, when two of us set out to drive the leading minivans and rank them for this page, we came away dizzy with details. Were there eight cup holders or nine? Two power sliding doors or one? Six headrests or seven? But we had no trouble coming up with a unanimous No. 1.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: Salient Facts: Freedom of Information; The Paper Chase
description: Thirty-four years after the Freedom of Information Act became law, its admirers tout it as one of the most powerful tools of government accountability in American history. That said, those who would force the government to divulge its secrets had better have ''the patience of saints and the endurance of marathon runners,'' as one judge put it last year in reference to the case of Carl Oglesby, a political writer. In December 1987, Oglesby sued the United States for documents he had requested two years earlier, as part of his research into the government's relationship with Reinhard Gehlen, a Nazi general who under U.S. supervision established West Germany's espionage service. Here are the highlights in Oglesby's 15-year effort, which continues to this day.

title: From an Election, Lessons Learned
description: To the Editor:

title: After Fire, Costume Shop Picks Brewster
description: THE new Phoenix Theatrical Costumes shop here came by its name naturally.

title: Light of Day for an Old Stop on the Underground Railroad
description: An 1890 house, pockmarked and nibbled by vines, slumps on the side of an ample lot at 113-115 Davis Avenue. Even its ghosts seem to have fled. But if they were still around, they could tell stories about the Gay and Wilcox families, significant contributors to the American abolitionist movement, who owned the now-abandoned piece of property from about the 1830's to the 1940's.

title: Sailing From Newport, Conner Begins Pursuit
description: The four-lane thoroughfare skirting the docks in downtown Newport, R.I., is called America's Cup Avenue. It's a reminder of a glorious era, when the world's finest sailors regularly jousted for the cup in the nearby waters. Traffic along the road, a bumper-to-bumper crawl on a busy summer weekend, is literally going nowhere fast.

title: The World: Democracy in Haiti; Where Votes Are Just a Start
description: EVEN before Jean-Bertrand Aristide was declared the winner of last Sunday's presidential election, his exultant supporters danced in the streets proclaiming his victory. So what if the vote tallies had yet to be compiled or that the country's major opposition parties had boycotted the elections? Democracy in Haiti these days seems to be more anticipatory than participatory.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-03-00: Questions for William Bastone and Daniel Green; Paper Trailblazers
description: Q: For those who haven't seen it, what's the goal of your Web site?

title: DROP IN SPENDING BY U.S. CONSUMERS SIGNALS SLOWDOWN
description: Americans are buying less jewelry and fewer homes than they did a year ago. Personal computers are gathering dust on warehouse shelves. Sales of airplane tickets and minivans have flattened in recent weeks.

title: To Count or Not to Count? A Judge Ponders Competing Legal Standards
description: The Tallahassee trial that could determine who won the presidency began with the lawyers outlining sharply different versions of the legal question before the court.

title: PASSAIC RIVER STUDY
description: The Passaic River will undergo a cleanup study in a step toward restoring its commercial and recreational value, federal officials announced last week. The $100,000 study by the United States Army Corps of Engineers will collect data on the lower 17 miles of the river from the Dundee Dam on the border of Passaic and Bergen Counties to Newark Bay. Officials said the Passaic's water is polluted and its riverbed is clogged with dioxin-tainted silt. Steve Strunsky

title: Vintage Cole Porter, Played to Giddy Effect
description: EVEN though Lark's Nest Prison is home to everyone doing time there, home was never like this, certainly not to Policy Pinkle, who doesn't remember ever having lived anyplace else, not unless you count the state juvenile detention center.

title: An Actor Awash in Ambition and Merlot
description: He stood in the portico awash in light cast by a flickering gas lamp. It was raining, and his jacket did not quite fit. He had come from an audition. He had already had a few glasses of wine and apologized for it.

title: HANDICAPPED PARKING
description: The New Jersey Developmental Disabilities Council says the state's doctors are too free in issuing handicapped-parking permits. . In a report issued last week, the council said too many permits -- about 300,000 this year as against 7,000 in 1981 -- means that those who really need spaces cannot find them. The council called on the Division of Motor Vehicles to crack down on enforcement and to educate doctors. Anne Ruderman

title: Mortgage Limit Is Raised
description: More home buyers will be able to secure cheaper loans next year because Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the federally sponsored mortgage agencies, are raising the limit on the size of home mortgages they buy from banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, ALVIN
description: SILVERSTEIN-Alvin, 83 of Boynton Beach, Fl, formerly of Woodmere, L. I., NY died Wednesday November 22nd at home. He is survived by wife Evelyn, son Bert and wife Debbi Silverstein, daughter Laura and husband Steven Bedford. Grandchildren Adam and Rebecca Silverstein and Emma and Nathaniel Bedford. Also survived by his brother Raymond.

title: Front and Center on the Sidelines; Lone Boy on Long Beach High School Cheerleading Squad Hears Jeers, Too
description: SCOT HOROWITZ is one of the best-known students at Long Beach High School.

title: Brooklyn's Prized Wollman Rink Is Feeling Its Age
description: If ice-skating rinks could have strokes, Prospect Park's 40-year-old Wollman Memorial Rink recently suffered a massive one, inching it closer to what many see as its inevitable demise and replacement.

title: Strong Statements In a Serene Setting
description: THE austere cement block that is the Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery at Wesleyan University in Middletown is an almost ideal venue for the exhibition ''Black and Blue: Examining Police Violence.'' The art matches it in austerity.

title: A Playful Geometer Makes the Complex Seem So Simple
description: IT'S a sparkling autumn afternoon, and Sol LeWitt has made the journey from one of his favorite places -- his home and studio in rural Connecticut -- to one of his least favorite: across a table from a journalist with a tape recorder.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Vote Count
description: It was the hottest ticket in town, the 90-minute Supreme Court argument Friday on whether the Florida Supreme Court overstepped its authority when it extended the certification deadline for the state's presidential vote count. The court appeared as divided as the rest of the country.

title: A Childhood Lesson Relearned
description: AS our family prepares for the holidays, I have been thinking of a timeless lesson learned at my father's knee. Long ago, I accompanied my father to the rug stores of Boston, musty and mysterious caverns where men joked and haggled in snatches of English, French, Arabic and Armenian as they maneuvered among mounds of rugs and gestured toward other enormous rugs hung from the walls.

title: A Believer in Decency, a Wringer of Tears
description: IN movies by the Swedish director Lasse Hallstrom, there are no bad people. Just a lot of mildly flawed good ones. From Ingemar, the young hero of ''My Life as a Dog'' (1985), who despite the best intentions in the world can't seem to stop annoying his dying mother, to Gilbert, the teenage protagonist of ''What's Eating Gilbert Grape'' (1993), who is saddled with caring for his dysfunctional family, to Dr. Larch, the ether-addled orphanage director in last year's ''Cider House Rules,'' Mr. Hallstrom has never turned his camera on a character whose foibles, however large, didn't coexist with a generous dose of human decency.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Great Neck author Helaine Helmreich misstated the year her novel ''The Chimney Tree'' was accepted by the University Press of Colorado. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the .50-caliber rifle misstated the name of the Congressional agency that investigated the public availability of armor-piercing ammunition. It is the General Accounting Office, not the Government Accounting Office.

title: One Step Forward, After Four Steps Back
description: For the second consecutive Friday, investors hunting for bargains among technology stocks drove up the Nasdaq composite index after it had sunk all week.

title: A Leica Wrapped in Silk
description: Hunters of luxury goods think of Hermes for $200 neckties or sumptuous silk scarves. Soon they may associate it with cameras. Hermes plans to take a big stake in Leica Camera A.G., for $15 million; the move will offer a lifeline to ailing Leica, maker of the renowned M6.

title: Rockefeller Center: Oases for Shoppers
description: MARITIME

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Curbing Illicit Diamonds
description: South Africa, with the backing of dozens of nations, won approval in the United Nations General Assembly for an international certification system for diamonds that will help buyers of rough stones try to sort out the gems from legitimate mining operations and reject ''conflict diamonds'' -- those smuggled to raise money for rebel armies. The Namibians have offered to set up a technical committee to draw up certification guidelines. The experts are to report back within a year. Barbara Crossette

description: DIGIOVANNI-Constance. 6/7/60-12/3/94. Missing my beautiful little sister, my forever friend.

description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Is Setting Its Sights on Downtown
description: The city government here is embarking on a major effort to revitalize the downtown area, trying to draw people to the heart of the city with new housing, more shopping and a broader cultural life.

description: To the Editor:
