description: HAUSER-Elizabeth Hoppin, Ph.D. Died at home on November 30, 2000, at age 65. Beloved mother of Mary Eliza Engelbrecht, devoted grandmother of John William Engelbrecht. Having earned her doctorate from Columbia University, Dr. Hauser was a psychotherapist in private practice in NYC for over 30 years. A dedicated volunteer in many programs, she was a founder and leader for more than a decade of Cub Scout Pack #

title: Killing Him Softly, And Other Funny Stuff
description: I don't normally follow murder cases closely, but the trial of a North Dakota plastic surgeon, Robert Bierenbaum, was hard to miss. That's because my friend Sue went to high school with him in West Orange in 1970's.

title: Development in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: No Need to Hide Styx Albums Now
description: IN popular culture, as elsewhere in life, the most shameful secrets are often the last to be told. So maybe it shouldn't come as a shock that after the revivals of William Shatner and "Charlie's Angels," some bona fide trendsetters are resurrecting one of the more embarrassing acts of recent decades, Styx.

title: Once Again, Frogs Land in Willimantic
description: A QUARTET of giant bluish-green frog sculptures has taken up residence on the massive cement thread spools mounted on Willimantic's new bridge across the Willimantic River. Thread City Crossing, as the graceful arched bridge is known, combines the city's two enduring symbols: thread and bullfrogs.

title: ART
description: If you are looking at the pictures, the best art books are likely to be the newest. The quality of color reproduction just keeps getting better. But if you're also reading the words, all bets are off. The best art criticism, in every age, tells us something about the art under consideration and something about the critic. Rilke on Rodin, Baudelaire on Delacroix, Meyer Schapiro on Cezanne -- once you have read these writers, the works of art are never quite the same again. And yet, art keeps asking something new from us, what Robert Frost called ''counterlove, original response.'' Word and picture, image and text -- the terms kept shifting in my mind, like yin wrestling with yang, as I meandered among the harvest of this year's art books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRY, THEA
description: BRY-Thea. Beloved wife of the late Gerhard Bry, mother of Ava Bry Penman (of Brookline, Mass.) and the late Peter Bry, grandmother of Deborah Bry, David Bry and Joshua Penman, motherin-law of Brenna Bry and Lewis Lockwood. Died November 29, 2000 at age 89, of cancer. Devoted clinical psychologist: over 60 years of private practice in New Jersey; former Chief Psychologist of Newark's Head Start Program; cofounder of Institute for Training in Infant and Preschool Mental Health of the Youth Consultation Service, Montclair, N.J. Her enthusiasm for life will be dearly missed by family and colleagues.

title: Jack Hemingway Dies at 77; Embraced Father's Legacy
description: Jack Hemingway, whose achievements as a conservationist and proficiency as a fisherman were nearly overshadowed by his role as the son of a celebrated father and the father of famous children, died Friday night at Weill Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Cyber scout column on Nov. 12, about the expanded offerings of map sites on the Web, referred incorrectly to the ability of randmcnally .com to handle hotel reservations. The site does give users the option to link to another site to make hotel reservations; but reservations cannot be made on randmcnally .com itself.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Week in Review on Aug. 20 about public relations efforts to exploit the West Nile virus outbreak referred incorrectly to a letter about the availability of Dr. James J. Rahal, head of infectious diseases at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, to chat with reporters about the disease. He did not send the letter himself, though he says he was consulted; it was sent by a public relations firm representing the hospital.

title: Crafts Centers Near and Far Show Their Seasonal Best
description: WHILE there is no one road leading to Connecticut's five craft centers, there is an organized craft trail and a map, and each center gladly charts trips to the next. It's a diverting way to see the state while shopping, particularly at this season, with its special holiday shows.

title: Nov. 26 - Dec. 2; Russia Answers a Question About Wallenberg's Death
description: What everyone thought they knew is now, at long last, officially admitted: Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who helped thousands of Jews escape the Nazis at the end of World War II, was executed in 1947 in the K.G.B.'s Lubyanka Prison in Moscow. Aleksandr Yakovlev, who heads a Russian panel rehabilitating victims of Stalin's political terror, said he has asked the Kremlin to certify that Mr. Wallenberg was such a victim. Mr. Wallenberg was last seen in January 1945, on the way to a meeting with Soviet Army commanders in Budapest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITER, JERILYN
description: REITER-Jerilyn. We mourn the loss of Jeri Reiter, wife of Jonathan Reiter, our esteemed colleague and First Vice Chairman, to whom we extend our deepest condolences. Liberal Party of New York State Martin S. Begun, Chairman Raymond B. Harding, Vice Chair

description: To the Editor:

title: Aquarium On Verge Of Change
description: Strictly speaking, the $59 million New Jersey State Aquarium, a state-financed tourist attraction on the waterfront that draws about 500,000 visitors a year, is not for sale.

description: A PIG IS BIG Written and illustrated by Douglas Florian. Greenwillow/HarperCollins, $15.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title: Bus Boycotters Are Celebrated in Montgomery
description: Most people know that Rosa Parks fired up a movement 45 years ago by refusing to surrender her bus seat to a white man in Montgomery, Ala. But few people know that Claudette Colvin and Mary Louise Smith did the same thing.

title: Leslie Effron, Jason Levin
description: Leslie Ann Effron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Effron of White Plains, was married last night to Jason Ari Levin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Levin of Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi Alfredo Borodowski performed the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLEN, JOHN C.
description: CULLEN-John C. Of Clearwater Florida, a retired Auditor for the New York Times, died Thursday, November 30th, 2000, at his daughter's home in Barryville. He was 101. The son of the late James and Mary Ellen Barron Cullen, he was born October 1, 1899, in New York City. He was the widower of Grace Matheson Cullen. A former City Clerk for Pinellas Park, Fla., he was a 50+ year member of the Masonic Lodge; and a member of Good Samaritan Church, Pinellas Park, Fla. Survivors include two sons, John Cullen Jr. of Indonesia and William M. Cullen of East Liverpool, Ohio; one daughter, Grace Forsythe of Barryville; and several grandchildren, greatgrandchildren, nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Cremation will be in Cedar Hill Crematory, Newburgh. Memorial contributions may be sent to Hospice of Sullivan County, 800 Stony Brook Court, Newburgh, NY 12550. For further funeral service information, the VanInwegen-Kenny, Inc. Funeral Home, 195 Broadway, Monticello.

title: Chinese Find Power Abuse Isn't Limited To the Cities
description: Three young officials in a town in central China figured out an easy way to supplement their modest salaries: They took over an abandoned police station and turned it into a private prison, arresting more than 200 people and demanding money for their release.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: OFF TO THE COOKS: Islands in the Sun has five-night packages to the Cook Islands starting at $999 a person, including air fare from Los Angeles, based on double occupancy ($1,089 in January). The lowest price is for five nights at the 36-room Club Raro Resort on Rarotonga, and includes daily breakfast. Five nights at the 182-room Edgewater Resort, with breakfast, a picnic lunch and an island show, is $1,129 ($1,189 in January). Six-night packages with a choice of nine resorts throughout the Cooks begin at $1,179. And a seven-night plan that combines three nights in the Edgewater with four nights at Aitutaki Lagoon Resort on the island of Aitutaki starts at $1,529, with interisland air fare. Rates are valid through March 25, and there are seasonal supplements. Contact Islands in the Sun at (800) 828-6877 or see www.islandsinthesun.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE HAVENON, ANDRE VICTOR
description: de HAVENON-Andre Victor. 58, on November 20 in New York City. Mr de Havenon, a clinical psychologist, was the son of the late Gaston de Havenon and Carol Brewster of Baltimore. Mr. de Havenon graduated from Yale in 1964 and obtained a Master's Degree from New York University. He lived in Europe for many years where he was a writer for Radio Luxembourg. He then returned to New York, married Susan Beeson, a photo stylist and interior designer. They had one child, Victor. They resided in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan and spent their summers in East Hampton where they were members of the Devon Yacht Club. He was an avid golfer and a superb angler whose knowledge of sports was encyclopedic. He is survived by his wife Susan Beeson de Havenon, their son Victor William Helme de Havenon, his mother Carol Brewster, his sisters: Rebecca Kapell Leigh and Sarah de Havenon Fowler; his brothers Michael de Havenon, Alex de Havenon, Daniel Brewster, Gerry Brewster and David Kapell. Mr de Havenon was a brilliant and compassionate man who lived an interesting life. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A Memorial Service will be held at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South at noon, Saturday, December 16. Memorial contributions to the American Heart Association, 122 East 42 St, NYC 10168, would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 19 about the conductor Kent Nagano referred incorrectly to his experience with the New York Philharmonic. He has indeed conducted the orchestra; they gave four performances together in November 1987.

title: Menus to Match Shanghai's Vitality
description: SHANGHAI, historically one of China's most intriguing cities, has been undergoing a cultural renaissance as well as an extraordinary physical transformation. The city now boasts a gleaming skyline, especially in Pudong, the thriving economic zone across the Huangpu River, and the culinary landscape is equally compelling.

title: Paths for Our Warming Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Conspiracy; Chelsea Under Wraps
description: The worst way for a famous person to retain her privacy is to demand it. A celebrated recluse will never be left alone in a celebrity culture; her silence is an irresistible challenge and her secrets will eventually be prized from her. Is it any coincidence that J. D. Salinger has attracted two of the most loquacious memoirists in decades? No, the business of being a public private person is subtle and tricky. Retreat and refusal are not enough. Bargains must be struck.

title: BACKTALK; North Carolina Is Part of the Roots and Growth of Women's Soccer
description: Anson Dorrance, the women's soccer coach at the University of North Carolina, remembers exactly what he and the University of Colorado Coach Chris Lidstone told a room of intercollegiate officials two decades ago in their bid for a women's championship tournament. Although the sport did not nearly meet the criteria for having a national championship -- like a required number of colleges with women's soccer programs -- the two young advocates were passionate in their rhetoric.

title: In Time for Holidays, Saks Opens Discount Outlet

The store, which is being operated for Saks by the Ozer Group, a Boston-based liquidation company, opened Nov. 22 and will close in mid-January, Dennis Williams, the store manager, said. Merri Rosenberg

description: Exactly 70 days ago the Giants were trying to prove something against the Washington Redskins. The Giants were undefeated, a dreamy time when they wondered if they could keep the good times rolling, with a highly ranked defense and an improved offense.

title: A Down-Home Opus By Philharmonic Leader
description: THE music at Saturday's concert by the New Philharmonic of New Jersey is American, but no one would expect a reference to New Jersey. Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' and Ellington's ''Nutcracker Suite'' are American-jazz-inflected, Copland's ''Appalachian Spring'' is about someplace south of here, Bernstein's ''Prelude, Fugue and Riffs'' is Broadway. But wait: John Sichel's ''The Turnpike at East Rutherford''? Aha.

title: Patient Confidentiality; The Cop and the Therapist
description: In August 1995, Jack Garner decided that he needed to see a therapist. He was a police officer with 31 years' experience, and he had won more than a dozen commendations. For the past nine years, he had served in Gwinnett County, Ga., which is northeast of Atlanta. Gwinnett had long been, as one of Garner's future lawyers would describe it, ''a redneck speed trap'' on the way to Athens; but now it was a high-tech suburb filling up with wealthy professionals. As a consequence, the stop-and-frisk era of policing was over. Garner was an old-school cop who had trained in Atlanta. He wasn't adjusting well. ''I wouldn't say Jack was a friendly-type person,'' one of his supervisors at the time, Gene Knight, remembered. ''He was pretty direct.'' The department was unhappy with him.

title: As Cable Rates Rise, So Do Complaints
description: FOR almost 20 years, Allen Fritz of Dix Hills has watched in frustration as his Cablevision bill has increased. He has toyed with the idea of switching to a satellite television system before, but on Nov. 21, when Cablevision announced that it would raise its rates again in January, he decided to consider such a move more seriously.

title: Hawaii Cruises: Growth Ahead
description: WHEN Norwegian Cruise Line's 1,960-passenger ship, Superstar Leo, moves to Honolulu from Singapore at the end of next year, to begin weekly year-round cruises, it will become the only foreign-registered cruise ship to make its year-round home in Hawaii. And soon to begin year-round cruises around Hawaii is the 1,214-passenger Patriot, formerly Holland America Line's Nieuw Amsterdam, recently bought by United States Lines and scheduled to enter service on Saturday. The two ships are expected to help boost the number of cruise passengers in Hawaii from this year's estimated 200,000 to about 400,000 in 2005, according to a report prepared for the state's Department of Transportation.

title: POSTINGS: Going Up in Chelsea; 210 Rentals On W. 21st St.
description: Twenty months after the City Planning Commission passed an amendment to the zoning code that permits new housing in Chelsea between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue from 16th to 23rd Streets, several new buildings have been completed or are under construction.

title: 'Sleigh Ride' and More: Leroy Anderson's Life
description: IN a mid-summer heat wave in 1946 in Woodbury, the composer Leroy Anderson began what would become his most famous piece: ''Sleigh Ride.'' Complete with jingling bells, clip-clops and a whinny from Dobbin, ''Sleigh Ride'' was ranked No. 6 last year on a list of the most performed Christmas standards, according to Eleanor Anderson, the composer's widow.

title: Upshaw Deplores the Plight of Black Assistants
description: As a Hall of Fame guard for the Oakland Raiders, Gene Upshaw was one of the toughest men to play pro football. As executive director of the National Football League Players Association, he has been equally brave over the years, confronting ownership on a variety of issues. That boldness was on display at the owners' meetings in late October, when Upshaw, with the consent of Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, addressed the paucity of black head coaches in professional football.

title: Chicago: Lots of marble, glass and a window seat with a view
description: A waiter who saw me struggling with a pepper grinder at the restaurant in Chicago's new Park Hyatt Hotel smiled in sympathy. ''Those grinders are very pretty,'' he said confidentially, ''but they aren't very functional.''

title: For Holidays, Reading And Then Drinking
description: THE holiday season always brings a cache of wine books, many of them primarily shoppers' service manuals, others of deeper interest to aficionados. I acquired a cross-section in order to sample how Long Island was presented this year.

title: Blooms for the Winter: Botanical Prints
description: ALL the garden and shelter magazines tell you that winter is the time to look out the window and enjoy the bones of your garden. If you are an especially fortunate gardener, you can peer at your well-clipped boxwood balls or your expensive armillary sundial. Even if you don't have those things, you can try to spot glimpses of color: the last few barberries hanging on the bush, a stray rose hip or two, or even a flash of scarlet as a cardinal flies by.

title: Steinbrenner's Quirks Worth the Wait
description: The man who spends more money on players than anyone in baseball history has a quirky economic personality. George Steinbrenner finances the first payroll that soars beyond $100 million, but he holds the line at giving Mike Mussina $15 million a year, approving $14.75 million instead. He outspends every other team taking risks in signing Cuban defectors and other Latin players, but he doesn't sign Derek Jeter to a multiyear contract because he is waiting for some other team to establish a new salary plateau.

title: Mideast Violence Hurts Egypt's Tourism Boom
description: EGYPT'S tourism boom is on the verge of going bust, a victim of the Palestinian-Israeli violence that broke out in late September and fears of terrorism in the region. After a dazzling recovery over the past three years and huge investment in new Red Sea and North Sinai hotels and resorts, the country's hotel and tour operators are facing a bleak winter season, and many have already slashed prices.

title: Crime-Scene Forensics; Dead Men Talking
description: The nameless teenage Mexican immigrant killed in a drug skirmish could hardly have imagined that this would be his final resting place. His knees are drawn up into the fetal position; his body appears almost mummified, the skin a leathery brown merging with the fall leaves underneath. The sloped woods around him hum with cicadas. All is deathly peace in this hillside spot. A few feet away, a leg lies perfectly camouflaged in the brush, given away only by crimson strips of flesh still clinging to it. Under a row of trees nearby, a woman lies on her back, half rotted away, her arms outstretched in a frozen gesture and her hair lying in a molted mat around her skull. Three yards further on, a raw foot protrudes from a body bag. As it is lifted, a mass of maggots is suddenly scattered by the sunlight. The body is pale gray-green, quivering with the larvae feeding on its back, which has melted into a liquefied surface as soggy as a bar of soap. The sugary porcine smell in the air is unmistakable. Under spice bushes and saplings, little piles of bones lie quietly decomposing. The setting all looks rather pastoral, except for the two rusting cars and cases of scientific instruments nearby. Cemetery it may be, but conventional it is not.

title: Liberties; High and Low
description: Everyone is counting on the Supreme Court to bring civility, integrity and sanity to our election collision.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Avis Chief's Parachute Could Be Solid Gold

title: TEACHING WITH ARCHIVES
description: The Board of Regents and State Archives has given Westchester an award for excellence in the educational use of local government records. State educators made special mention of a project focusing on Lewis Brady, a runaway slave who eventually became a property owner in Ossining. Through the archive program, children learned about Mr. Brady through historical documents like maps, deeds, census records and an obituary. Elsa Brenner

title: Venetian Hotels of the Moment
description: THOUGH it plays host to the Biennale exhibitions of avant-garde art and architecture and to festivals of modern music, dance and film, Venice is not exactly the first place you go to experience the shock of the new. Indeed, the day before my husband, Howie, and I arrived there, we watched a brief documentary about the great modern architect Carlo Scarpa, whose early career in Venice was frustrated by the city fathers. Cannily gauging the intimate connection between the picturesquely antique and the tourist lire, they balked at letting him alter so much as the position of one window in his restorations.

title: Graves Along the Border; The Disappeared
description: Deserts everywhere are mysterious, daunting landscapes. But in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, it is not just nature that holds the most vexing secrets. Those involve the fate of hundreds of people who have vanished. No one knows where their bodies are buried. Some of their relatives cling to fantasies that the missing are still alive. But most believe that the remains of los desaparecidos are out there, somewhere, in the barren sea of sand that surrounds this industrial city and stretches along the United States border.

title: Laptops by the Pool in Silicon Valley
description: In the past two years the W hotel chain has become synonymous with the ultrahip of the New Economy, the perfect place to make the scene -- whether in New York, San Francisco or Los Angeles. But the newest California property in the chain -- a five-story stucco and tile building with a mansard roof -- sits next to a huge Sun Micro systems campus in Newark. The hotel is 10 minutes (when it's not rush hour) from downtown Palo Alto, the heart of Silicon Valley. Its presence is proof that Silicon Valley spills over its borders, north to San Francisco and east across the bay into both East Bay cities, Newark and Fremont.

title: Defending the Fourth Amendment
description: The Supreme Court, in an important case last week, reaffirmed the fundamental Fourth Amendment principle that searches and seizures must be based on suspicion that a particular individual is engaged in wrongdoing. The case involved roadblocks set up by the Indianapolis Police Department to stop and check passing cars for illegal narcotics with drug-sniffing dogs.

Sure, there was Babe -- the one in the children's movie -- and the precocious Arnold Ziffel of ''Green Acres,'' the old television series. But that was about it until the Federal Aviation Administration ruled that a 300-pound pig named Charlotte had every right to be on a US Airways passenger flight from Philadelphia to Seattle, and in first class.

title: Computer Security; The Whiz Kid Vs. the Old Boys
description: One of these days -- perhaps this year, perhaps next -- John M. Deutch is going to get a call from his lawyer. If he is lucky, he will learn that his ''case'' has been resolved. Of course, it may not be a ''case'' in the formal sense; he has not been charged with any criminal offense nor has he been informed by the Justice Department that he is the target of a criminal investigation. But ''case'' is probably still the best word to describe the slowly unwinding chain of events that began with the discovery in late 1996 that Deutch -- then the outgoing director of central intelligence, as the C.I.A.'s chief is formally known -- had placed classified files on an unclassified Apple computer provided to him by the agency for his use at home.

title: MARSHLANDS STUDY PLANNED
description: As part of the county's efforts to protect the historic features of Marshlands Conservancy in Rye and to maintain its natural characteristics as a preserve and wildlife sanctuary, a comprehensive study of the 136-acre property will be conducted. The study will provide the county with a benchmark for preservation planning and maintenance of the property. The study will also encompass the adjacent Jay Property, which was acquired by the county in 1992 and was the boyhood home of John Jay, the first chief justice of the United States. Elsa Brenner

title: MORE MILLIONAIRES
description: The number of millionaires in New Jersey nearly tripled between 1993 and 1998, rising from 3,000 to 8,310, according to the Statistics of Income report issued by the state Division of Taxation last week. Based on a review of 1998 income tax filings, the report found that incomes in the state's wealthiest counties, Morris, Hunterdon and Somerset, grew by about 60 percent over that period, while incomes in the poorest counties, Hudson, Cumberland and Atlantic, grew by 30 percent. The number of people or families making less than $10,000 a year decreased from 1,020,964 to 718,748. The millionaires make up 0.2 percent of the population and account for nearly 12 percent of the state's income, while the bottom 10 percent of earners make 1.7 percent of the income. Karen DeMasters

title: Chewing Over Chads And Choices
description: TO chefs, the most disturbing accusation to emerge from the voting morass in Florida is that of a Republican recount monitor in Broward County, who claims he saw a Democratic observer eat chads off a table. Chad, distressed cooks say, should never be eaten unaccompanied.

title: This Isn't a Civics Lesson -- It's a Brawl

It would be nice to think that this episode had reconnected Americans to politics, but the reality is likely to be just the opposite. The candidates' positions on dimpled chads and absentee ballots are more compelling than were their positions during the election campaign on education and Social Security because the contest for power is now so raw. When it's over, it may only have served to deepen the public's cynicism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, JOHN S.
description: McSHERRY-John S. Age 59. An advertising executive and media research expert, died December 1, 2000 in New York City, of cancer. Mr. McSherry was the Senior Partner and Media Research Director of TN Media, a division of True North Communications, Inc. He had over 30 years of advertising experience at major agencies. Prior to joining TN Media in June 1988, he was associated with the interpublic group of companies as Vice President of Media Research at both McCann-Erickson and Campbell-Ewald. Earlier positions in media research included Ted Bates and J. Walter Thompson. Mr. McSherry wrote research articles for numerous industry publications, and received recognition from the Association of National Advertisers for innovative contributions to media. He was elected Adweek's Media Research All Star in 1996. Among Mr. McSherry's notable contributions to TN Media, were the development of several proprietary reach and frequency models. Industry participation included the AAAA Media Research Committee, Radio and Television Research Council, EMRC Television Measurement Committee, and the International Advertising Association. Mr. McSherry was a graduate of Dartmouth College and served as an officer in the U.S. Army. He is survived by his partner Carl Koivuniemi, his mother Marion Miles of Albany, N.Y. and his sister Marion Minahan of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, December 6th, 2-4PM with funeral service to follow.

title: Containing the Ebola Virus

Because patients die rapidly and dramatically, from shock and massive bleeding, Ebola has been the stuff of movie treatments and nightmare scenarios in the West. The West's concern about Ebola can be useful if it spurs help for Africa's dismal health care system.

You think, 'This is it,' but it doesn't last." The freelance editor with reddish-brown hair and a penchant for red lipstick and nail polish, among other red things (see below) was wistful after reflecting for a few hours on her imminently former home, her nostalgia stoked by a reading of the opening paragraph of E. B. White's "Here is New York." title: A Delirium of Gypsy Music Barrels Along in Overdrive
description: Django Reinhardt enthusiasts are a peculiar subspecies: no excuses are offered for fealty to a single artistic source. True Djangophilia -- whose standard is set by Sinti Gypsy guitar players, like Reinhardt himself -- doesn't really mean building on Reinhardt's language. It means trying to sound as much like him as one can. Within the context of the jazz world, Djangophilia is an honorable pursuit; but to see it in action is a bit like watching a bunch of talented actors standing around in fedoras and doing Bogey for an hour.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TAX DEAL OVER NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Officials of a town and school district in Westchester County said yesterday that they had reached a tentative tax-stabilization agreement with Entergy Nuclear. The company has bought the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Cortlandt, N.Y., from the New York Power Authority and has an agreement to buy Indian Point 2 and the defunct Indian Point 1 from Consolidated Edison. Officials of Cortlandt, and of the Hendrick Hudson School District, said that under the agreement, Indian Point 3 would be kept off the tax rolls and Entergy would pay the town and district a total of up to $9 million a year in lieu of taxes. The payments will be made over the next 14 years if the state approves legislation to keep Indian Point 3 off the tax rolls. If not, Entergy will be assessed a possible $9 million or more a year in taxes for four years. Mike Kansler, chief operating officer for Entergy Nuclear Northeast, said the company was willing to enter into the agreement to be ''a good corporate neighbor.'' The agreement is subject to approval by the Cortlandt town board and the district's school board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUNGREISZ, REBBETZIN MIRIAM
description: JUNGREISZ-Rebbetzin Miriam. Revered mother of esteemed Rebbetzin Esther Jungries, founder of Hineni organization. Known to all as ''Mama'', her smile, her love, and great caring acts of chesed will be missed not only by her beloved children, grandchildren and great grandchildren but by thousands of people whose lives she has touched. The Jewish community has lost a true tzaddekes. Our families are honored to have known and been loved by her. May she find eternal rest in the Garden of Eden among the righteous of Zion and Jerusalem. Levine, Pilevsky and Leifer Family.

title: Hamburger Safety May Be Partly in the Flip
description: The safest hamburger may be a well-flipped hamburger, a new study from the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California suggests.

title: A Violinist Is Enhanced By a Violin With a History
description: Miriam Kramer, a gifted young violinist born in Meriden, Conn., and now living in London, gave some sort of debut on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall. A United States debut, the advance publicity said, but the program called the recital, coming at the end of an American tour, merely a Lincoln Center debut.

title: DoubleClick in Layoffs as Online Advertising Slackens
description: Cutbacks in the Internet advertising industry have reached DoubleClick, which laid off more than 150 employees, or about 7 percent of its work force, yesterday.

title: ONLINE HOLIDAY ADS START LATE
description: Holiday-related online advertising is starting later this year, according to a report released yesterday by AdRelevance, part of Jupiter Media Metrix, even though the number of online advertisers this season is four times what it was last year. The report also found that the number of holiday-themed ads in October 2000 was less than half of what it was in October 1999. Similarly, according to another survey released yesterday by Jupiter Research, also part of Jupiter Media Metrix, only 11 percent of online retailers said they planned to spend more than 50 percent of their budgets this holiday season, compared with 29 percent last year. Allison Fass

title: MICROSOFT JOINS IN CINEMANOW FINANCNG
description: CinemaNow, a leading distributor of independent feature films on demand over the Internet, announced today that it had closed another round of financing during which it had gained Microsoft as an investor, joining the original investors Blockbuster and Kipco. CinemaNow's majority owner is Lions Gate Entertainment through its recent acquisition of Trimark Pictures. Judith Berck

title: Metro Business Briefing; LOTTERY AT LA GUARDIA
description: The Federal Aviation Administration conducted a lottery yesterday to distribute La Guardia Airport landing slots among new airlines and those with only a small presence there, using a fishbowl and capsules once used by the Commission on Selective Service to determine the order in which men would be drafted. Thirteen airlines participated in the lottery, which was held in Washington. The first one picked was the commuter affiliate of Delta Air Lines, but the F.A.A. structured the lottery to allow only smaller airlines in the first round, giving Midwest Express the first choice of landing times. The commuter affiliate of US Airways was the last chosen. Among the others were Legend Airlines, which ceased flying over the weekend because of financial trouble; the F.A.A. held an extra ''contingency'' round in the lottery, to distribute Legend's slots if the airline, based at Love Field in Dallas, does not resume service. Landing slots between 3 p.m. and 7 p.m. were the first chosen. The new assignments are to take effect on Jan. 31. The capsules, each containing an airline's name, were borrowed from the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Film Institute Plans to Offer an Annual Top 10
description: The movie awards season, which begins this month with critics' prizes and culminates with the Oscars in late March, has become even more crowded with the announcement today that the American Film Institute intends to name the top 10 films of 2000 on Jan. 9 and plans to do it each year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRY, HENRY AVERELL
description: GERRY-Henry Averell. Of Locust Valley and Fishers Island, New York, and Boca Grande, Florida, died on December 2, 2000, at the age of 86, at Bon Secours Venice Hospital, Venice, Florida. Beloved husband of Nancy and father of Averell, Sheldon, Ann, Nancy and Richard. Grandfather of seven grandchildren. Memorial service to be held Thursday, December 7, at St. Andrews Church, Boca Grande, FL, at 11:30 AM. Another memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Foxcroft School, P.O. Box 5555, Middleburg, VA. 20118, Boca Grande Health Clinic, P.O. Box 517, Boca Grande, FL 33921, or Fishers Island Health Project, P.O Box 344, Fishers Island, New York 06390.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICKONA, EDWARD J.
description: LICKONA-Edward J. Died peacefully on November 29, 2000, at the age of 86. A native of Poughkeepsie, NY, he and his wife spent their retirement years in Port Orange, FL, before moving to McGraw, NY in 1999 to be closer to family. A quiet man of tender heart and wry humor, he will be forever missed in a million ways by his sweetheart and wife of 60 years, Winnie, his son Tom and his wife Judy of Cortland, NY, his son Terry of Austin, TX, & his daughter Cheryl Lickona-Weckler and her husband Chad, his two grandsons and his five great-grandchildren. Arriverderci, Daddy. We love you...

title: For Monkeys, a Millipede a Day Keeps Mosquitoes Away
description: Upcoming titles from that little-known publishing house, Capuchin Press: ''Don't Swat the Small Stuff,'' ''Who Moved My Millipede?'' and ''Bananas from Heaven: A True Story of Monkeys, Mosquitoes and Miracles.''

title: Chief Inauguration Planner Tries to Beat the Clock
description: It was all going so smoothly. Like any talented party planner, Tamara Somerville had the invitations designed and off to the printers with weeks to spare. The location was settled on long ago. Many of the capital's best caterers were eager to bid on the sit-down lunch to follow the ceremony.

title: Computer Security Experts Question Internet Wiretaps
description: Despite winning a favorable review by an outside group, the F.B.I.'s Carnivore Internet wiretap system continues to raise strong concerns about privacy and the legal limits of government surveillance, a prominent panel of computer security experts said yesterday.

title: Suspense Doesn't Sell at E-Speed
description: In the long gone days of my childhood in Buenos Aires, Sunday was movie day. The neighborhood theater showed triple and sometimes quadruple features, introduced by live acts (elderly pianists or melancholy clowns) that we would loudly boo and by ongoing serials (space adventures or Wild West sagas) that we would faithfully follow. Ostensibly, we came for the features, but in truth, we loved the serials. ''This suspense is terrible,'' says Gwendolen in Oscar Wilde's ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' ''I hope it will last.'' We, too, hoped it would last, well beyond the next Sunday, because we knew in our bones that there was nothing better than a never-ending story, dished out in miserly, tempting segments.

title: Moynihan Name Lives On At the Newest Courthouse
description: United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan may be on his way out of public office, but several hundred of his admirers gathered in Lower Manhattan yesterday for a ceremony that will ensure his name remains part of New York City's landscape.

title: Absentee Ballot Rules Under Scrutiny in State Senate Race
description: The fierce election dispute over State Senator Roy M. Goodman's seat yesterday entered a stage resembling the presidential battle being waged in the Florida courts, as five appellate judges questioned whether some rules had been shifted midstream while absentee ballots were being counted.

title: Gene Altered Foods: A Case Against Panic
description: Ask American consumers whether they support the use of biotechnology in food and agriculture and nearly 70 percent say they do. But ask the question another way, ''Do you approve of genetically engineered (or genetically modified) foods?'' and two-thirds say they do not.

title: The Justices Speak, and the Networks Scramble to Understand What They Said
description: To Frank Sesno, CNN's Washington bureau chief, it was ''the ultimate challenge.''

title: Real Detectives. Real Crimes. Real Voyeurism.
description: In a Brooklyn neighborhood the police hover around the body of a murdered man lying on the ground; his hands and feet stick out from under a sheet tossed over him, and blood streams onto the sidewalk.

title: Concern Rising Over Use of Juvenile Prisons to 'Warehouse' the Mentally Ill
description: Sheila M. just turned 16. She suffers from both mental retardation and manic depression. In the last four years, after her mother died of a heart attack during a family quarrel and her father was arrested for beating her, she has been transferred more than 65 times between children's shelters, group homes, psychiatric hospitals and juvenile jails, many of them rushing to unload her on another agency, court records show.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; To Curb Flu at Sea, Treat the Staff
description: Investigators from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who tracked an outbreak of respiratory infections that persisted through three voyages of a cruise liner have recommended that crew members be given flu vaccine shots.

title: Ems-Chemie Bids To Buy Axantis
description: Ems-Chemie Holding, a Swiss chemical maker, offered today to buy the three-quarters of the cellulose maker Axantis Holding that it did not own for about $252 million. The move came after a rival bidder, Daniel Model, sold his stake to Ems and withdrew his offer for Axantis.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO BUY SIMPLEX TIME RECORDER
description: Tyco International, a conglomerate whose holdings include ADT security systems, agreed to buy Simplex Time Recorder, which installs, monitors and services fire alarm and security systems, for $1.15 billion. Simplex is closely held. Tyco, which is based in Bermuda and run from offices in Exeter, N.H., has made more than $40 billion in acquisitions in the last four years. Its stock rose 63 cents, to $54.94.

title: Televising the Highest Court
description: Rarely is history as palpable in the making as it was last Friday when the Supreme Court interceded for the first time in a presidential election. The encounter between the justices and attorneys for Al Gore and George W. Bush was a riveting, intellectually rigorous 90-minute skirmish. By taking the unprecedented step of releasing an audio recording of the argument as soon as it ended, the court provided Americans with an invaluable civics lesson. But the lesson would have been greatly enhanced if the event had also been shown on television. The court missed an opportunity when it failed to allow the millions following the case to be eyewitnesses to history, instead of mere eavesdroppers.

title: Pirates Win, but Griffin Sprains His Knee
description: Ty Shine, grimly running a brush through his hair in a corner of a somber Seton Hall locker room late tonight, said softly that he would have taken that one bad pass back if he could. But he knew there was no way to get it back, and now Seton Hall might have to play its biggest game of a promising young season without its best player.

title: BP and Partners to Seek Gas in Vietnam
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., Statoil A.S. of Norway and their partners will sign agreements on Wednesday for a $1.5 billion plan to explore for natural gas in Vietnam.

title: Democrats Keep Silver In Speakership
description: Sheldon Silver received an overwhelming embrace of his leadership in the New York State Assembly tonight, locking up votes to hold onto his job as speaker, just a few months after facing down a coup attempt that was staged by his fellow Democrats.

title: The Big City; Substitute for a Subway on Second Avenue: Free Enterprise
description: THE Second Avenue subway is dead! Long live the Second Avenue Free Way!

title: Bush Takes Restrained Tone On Day That Goes His Way
description: Publicly, advisers to Gov. George W. Bush spoke in muted tones, with measured words, about what happened in Florida today, portraying it not as a victory for Mr. Bush but as a matter of justice.

title: The Grand Canyon of the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: In This Case, the Patient Had a Secret Service Escort
description: When Dr. Jonathan S. Reiner began examining Dick Cheney in a coronary care unit here early in the morning of Nov. 22, he told the Republican vice-presidential candidate that he would treat him like a regular patient.

title: Supreme Court Acts in Harbor-Tax Case
description: Exporters can pursue their claims for $500 million in refunds of a federal harbor tax that was struck down as unconstitutional in 1998 unhindered by a time limit the Justice Department tried to impose.

title: SUN TO ACQUIRE HIGHGROUND SYSTEMS
description: Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held HighGround Systems, a developer of data storage management software, for $400 million in stock. Sun, best known for its servers and workstations, is also active in the storage equipment market, which is expanding rapidly because of the large amounts of data created by use of the Internet. HighGround is based in Marlborough, Mass.

title: Mighty Moon Suits Are Falling Apart
description: For people awake and aware during the Apollo Moon landings, the most unforgettable images sent to Earth were of astronauts in their ghostly white spacesuits framed by the gray landscape of another world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, BERTHA
description: BLANK-Bertha. Dr. Peter Gorevic and all in the Division of Rheumatology at Mt. Sinai Medical Center express their deep regret at the passing of Mrs. Bertha Blank, beloved mother of Dr. Howard Blank. All our prayers and best wishes to Dr. Blank and his family during this most difficult time.

title: Japan Shows Little Growth In Economy
description: The Economic Planning Agency of Japan said today that the economy grew 0.2 percent in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, continuing to teeter between growth and recession.

title: Gore Huddles With Family on a Bad Day
description: With the calendar flipping to a full four weeks since Election Day, Vice President Al Gore was, still, digging in as he received more bad news today.

title: Plans for Golf Course Draw Opposition
description: Two environmental groups and neighbors of the run-down Ferry Point Park in the Bronx have gone to court to stop the construction of a golf course on the site of a former landfill within the park, saying the city is ignoring threats to the health of people living nearby.

title: Early Intervention Dentistry: Going to Work on Baby Teeth
description: William Morrison is only 8 years old and still has most of his baby teeth, but he is already a veteran of the orthodontist's office. He recently completed a six-month course of treatment with a metal device glued to his upper teeth designed to improve his jaw alignment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATHROP, GRAYSON F.
description: LATHROP-Grayson F. Former chairman of the board of Al Paul Lefton Company, Inc., a New York and Philadephia advertising agency, died November 28, 2000 in a New York. He was 83 and lived in Greenwich Village. ''He died after a long illness'', his son Tad said. Mr. Lathrop began his advertising career with Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc. in 1940 where he was vice president, account supervisor and in 1958, moved to Lefton Company as vice president, management supervisor. In 1962, Mr. Lathrop was named general manager of Lefton's New York office and three years later was elected a director and secretary of the agency. In 1967, he was elected to the newly created post of executive vice president and, in 1972 was named chairman of the board. He retired in 1987. Mr. Lathrop was born in Springfield, OH., and was educated at Phillips Exeter Academy and Harvard Unversity. He served as 1st Lieutenant with the 106th Infantry Division in WWII, and saw combat service in the Battle of the Bulge, during which he was awarded a Bronze Star. He is survived by his wife, Roswita Kluge-Lathrop, and by his sons, Grayson (Tad) and Kevin of New York and Gavin, of San Diego, and by three grandchildren. His former wife Muriel died in 1980.

title: A Holiday Toy That's Intended to Be Dubious
description: Oh, my. A. A. Milne's Gloomy Gus, Eeyore, is new on the holiday market as a plush and (appropriately) blue talking toy, just in time to teach children the power of saying, ''I can't.''

title: EXCITE DROPS PLAN TO JOIN WITH CHELLO
description: Excite At Home, a provider of fast Internet service, said it had called off a plan to combine its international assets with Chello Broadband. UnitedGlobalCom, majority owner of Chello, told Excite At Home that it was unable to complete the transaction because of market conditions. Excite At Home said in July it would create Excite Chello, which was expected to have 300,000 subscribers and operations in 15 countries.

title: A Stealth Substitute for Braces, Designed Only for Adults
description: Many adults with crooked teeth are reluctant to undergo orthodontic treatment because of the embarrassment of wearing a mouthful of metal braces. Now, a new orthodontic device promises to straighten mild cases of overcrowding or improperly spaced teeth almost invisibly.

title: State Department Disciplines Six in Laptop Case
description: In the continuing quest of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to clamp down on security breaches even as she prepares to leave, the State Department said today that disciplinary action was being taken against six employees who it said were involved in the disappearance of a laptop computer nearly a year ago.

title: N.Y.U. Women Are Poised To Make a Run at the Title
description: Janice Quinn, coach of New York University's women's basketball team, says she has not felt this good about a team since she became a college coach.

title: A Sandwich of Virtuoso Works Between Ovations
description: Marc-Andre Hamelin has been appearing regularly in New York since he imposingly won the 1985 Carnegie Hall Competition, and his recordings have also kept up his reputation as an exploratory virtuoso pianist. Only a steep one-price ticket, therefore, can account for the modest audience that went to hear him at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Evening Hours column of Sunday Styles this week with a report about the holiday benefit at the American Museum of Natural History was published in error. It showed Crown Prince Pavlos of Greece (who did not attend the event), not Gordon Davis, chairman of Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: Using M.R.I., Researchers Explore the Brain in Search of the Funny Bone
description: Two cannibals sat beside a large fire, after eating the best meal they'd had in ages. ''Your wife sure makes a good roast,'' commented the first cannibal.

title: Q & A
description: Stroller Potatoes

title: Atoning for Earlier Loss, Knicks Rout the Clippers
description: It was certainly not like paying back Shaquille O'Neal and the Los Angeles Lakers or even Patrick Ewing and the Seattle SuperSonics, but at least give the Knicks credit for backing up their bravado. Feeling good about themselves after handling the talented Minnesota Timberwolves last Saturday, the Knicks talked about getting revenge and making amends for last month's embarrassing loss to the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: TALKS TO RESUME IN BERLIN UTILITY FIGHT
description: The Southern Company, the largest power producer in the United States, said it would resume negotiations over control of Bewag, a Berlin electric utility, after a court upheld an injunction blocking E.ON A.G., a major German utility group, from selling its stake in Bewag to a rival, HEW A.G. Southern acquired 26 percent of Bewag in 1997 and wants to buy the rest. E.ON is obliged to sell its stake because of antitrust concerns about the merger that created E.ON.

title: Beth Israel to Pay $1.2 Million for False Medicare Claims
description: Beth Israel Medical Center has agreed to pay $1.2 million to the federal government to settle civil charges that the hospital improperly billed the Medicare program during the early 1990's.

title: Groh Tries to Have Jets Take It Game at a Time
description: The National Football League distributed a piece of paper today, ''N.F.L. Playoff Scenarios.'' But Jets Coach Al Groh had beaten them to it.

title: Cablevision Postponement
description: Cablevision Systems, the largest cable-television provider in the New York metropolitan area, postponed for a second time a shareholder meeting to vote on the creation of a tracking stock for its programming holdings, known as Rainbow Media Group. The meeting was to have been held Friday; the new date is Jan. 5. The proposed stock would track investments in cable networks like American Movie Classics and Bravo. Rainbow is partly owned by General Electric's NBC subsidiary and is valued by analysts at $3 billion to $4 billion.

title: New Layers of Evidence Suggest Mars Had Water
description: A new analysis of spacecraft photography of Mars appears to show that in its earliest history, much of the planet was a land of lakes and shallow seas and that this left distinct layers of sedimentary rock where a fossil record of Martian life, if it ever existed, is most likely to be preserved.

title: S.& P. Eliminates 4 Old-Line Stocks From Its 500 Index
description: Four venerable old-economy industrial warhorses, Bethlehem Steel, W. R. Grace, Crown Cork and Seal and Owens-Illinois, were designated for deletion from the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks yesterday. They are to be replaced by two prominent technology companies, Intuit and Symbol Technologies, plus a utility company, Allegheny Energy, and a financial services company, the Ambac Financial Group.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEIL, BARBARA
description: BEIL-Barbara My cherished and beloved wife. Your first birthday in heaven. Time has passed but my love will always remain. Love, Shelly

title: Spiced With Imports but Malian at Heart
description: Oumou Sangare and Habib Koite, the two musicians from Mali who led their bands on Thursday night at the B. B. King Blues Club, share a wise stubborn streak. They are willing to use electric guitars, trap drums, microphones and other imported technology. But they seem unimpressed by the music that usually arrives with them. Instead, they hold on to Malian rhythms and melodies, and their songs maintain African music's age-old role as the community's memory and conscience. It's not provincialism or purism; they are playing what they want to hear.

title: Astronauts Finish Adding Solar Wing To Station
description: Working with deliberate starts and stops, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour today completed the addition of a major upgrade in power for the International Space Station by extending a second solar power wing over the spacecraft.

title: Sports of The Times; Spanning Dynasties With Yogi
description: ABOARD the Metroliner Sunday morning, somewhere between Newark and Trenton, Yogi Berra leaned into the aisle and said: ''Do you know what I told Mike Mussina the other day? I said, 'You just joined a really good group. They're like the guys I played with. They don't fight. They just want to win.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, ESTELLE
description: RAPOPORT-Estelle. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Marian. Loving sister of Milton and Arnold Fuchs. Service Wednesday 10:00 AM at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; Padded Underwear for Saving Frail Hips
description: Researchers hope that the findings from a large study in Finland published last month in The New England Journal of Medicine will help convince frail elderly patients that they can cut their risk of a serious fracture by wearing hip protectors.

title: Infectious Diseases Rising Again in Russia
description: Russia's political turmoil, its economic crisis and its new freedoms have been accompanied by a surge in infectious diseases. Tuberculosis is flooding the country, producing what some authorities are calling the largest outbreak in the world of one of medicine's most ominous problems, drug-resistant TB. Rates of other infections, including hepatitis, syphilis and AIDS, are skyrocketing. Health experts worry that if the rising rates of infectious diseases continue unabated, Russia itself may turn into an epidemiologic pump, sending infectious diseases into the rest of the world. Freedom's Toll:

title: UNITED REFINING RAISES BID FOR GETTY PETROLEUM
description: The United Refining Company said it would raise its bid for Getty Petroleum Marketing by 4.3 percent, to $84 million in cash, or $6 a share, after Getty, which has agreed to be acquired by Lukoil Holding of Russia, said it would not hold further talks with United until it had put its bid in writing. Getty owns 1,300 gas stations in 12 states. Getty's agreement with Lukoil becomes final today unless Getty accepts United's bid. United owns a refinery in Warren, Pa. Getty is based in Jericho, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, SYBIL P.
description: WOLFE-Sybil P., 57, of Pomona, NY, passed away on November 29. Beloved by all, ''Tibby'' is survived by husband Herb Wolfe, sons Alden and George Wolfe, brother Stephen Teitler and sister Rosalyn Radin. An immensely talented sculptor and designer, Sybil eagerly shared her artistic gifts with the community. She was a consummate hostess and decorated her homes in Pomona, Boca Raton and the Berkshires with style and warmth. She loved horses, dancing, antiquing and traveling to exotic locales. A period of shiva will be observed through December 5 at 11 Beaver Dam Road, Pomona. The family has requested that donations be made to The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 560 Sylvan Avenue, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey 07632.

title: Baby's Death Is Declared A Homicide, Officials Say
description: A 15-month-old Brooklyn boy who died on Sunday was beaten to death, and the case has been ruled a homicide, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATHGEB, MARLENE MASINI
description: RATHGEB-Marlene Masini. On Dec. 4, 2000. Beloved companion of Robert E. Bochat. Devoted mother of Lisa A. and Amy C. Rathgeb. Beloved sister of Ernest and Ronald Masini. Visiting at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 St., NYC, on Thursday 4:00-9:00 PM. Funeral service Friday 11:00 AM at St. Bernard's Church. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the American Cancer Society or to North Shore Animal League.

title: Dow Surges 186.56 Points As Nasdaq Stumbles Again
description: Blue-chip stocks sprinted to one of their best gains in five weeks yesterday, while the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index failed in its attempt to recover from an early decline and finished with its 10th loss in the last 12 sessions.

title: QUALCOMM WINS CHINA BACKING ON WIRELESS
description: Qualcomm received official backing from the Chinese government yesterday for the use of its wireless technology by the country's second-largest wireless carrier, China Unicom Ltd. The approval from the Ministry of Information will probably ensure that Qualcomm's code division multiple access technology, known as CDMA, will be widely used in China. Separately yesterday, Qualcomm reached a cross-licensing agreement with Texas Instruments that allows each company to supply circuits for several wireless technologies. Shares in Qualcomm climbed 8.4 percent, to $90, their highest level in 7 months. Simon Romero

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about a request by Republican officials in New Mexico for a hand recount of the presidential voting in Roosevelt County referred incorrectly to Al Gore's lead in the popular vote nationwide. He received a plurality, not a majority.

title: U.S. Justices Agree on Need To Clarify Case
description: The United States Supreme Court avoided a definitive ruling in the Florida election case today by stepping back from the brink of disunity and asking the Florida Supreme Court to clarify the basis of its Nov. 21 ruling that permitted recounts to continue past a statutory deadline.

description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuelan Voters Approve Removal of Labor Leaders
description: Voters in Venezuela have decisively approved a referendum that ousts the leaders of the country's labor unions, who are sympathetic to opposition parties, and paves the way for creating a single new government-dominated workers' federation.

title: Two forecasters say the growth in industry revenue will slow moderately in the year to come.
description: ADVERTISING spending in America in 2001 will not grow as fast as had been anticipated as recently as this summer, two leading industry forecasters predicted yesterday.

title: Tunnel Vision; New Orleans Has 'Desire'; in New York, It's the 'W'
description: The news that the letters W and V may be joining the 15-letter team that forms the names for New York City subway lines raises all kinds of questions. There are the obvious ones, like ''Why?'' and ''Where, exactly, will these lines be going?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPERMAN, ABRAHAM S., MD.
description: KUPERMAN-Abraham S., MD. Age 66 of Manhattan, died December 4, 2000, in Boston after a short illness. Pulmonologist on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, affiliated with Westchester Square Hospital, who had an active clinical practice in the Bronx for 27 years. Born in Capetown, South Africa, in 1934 he made Aliyah to Israel in 1955 and moved to the United States in 1963. He is survived by his sons, Gilad and Alan, both of Boston, his exwife Carmel Kuperman of Manhattan, his brother Israel of Capetown, his sister Miriam Rosenberg of Sydney, Australia, and his friend Anita Notrica of Manhattan. Funeral at the Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (Exit 17 Sawmill), Dobbs Ferry, New York, December 5, at 1 PM. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, Shiva TuesdayThursday 6-9PM at 40 E. 84th St, Apt 14A and Sunday 2-5PM at 303 West 66th Street, Apt 5AE.

title: Four Virgins and Their Leader on a Road to Armageddon
description: It's highly unusual television fare: a four-part mini-series about an obscure 19th-century British zealot and his influence on the seven young women who take care of his household. While there is sexual scandal (that's familiar), the drama focuses on more challenging concerns, like the meaning of existence, female self-determination, faith and humanism.

title: The Neediest Cases; Family Back on Its Feet After Series of Setbacks
description: Rainelle Henderson mopped the floor of her empty kitchen one day last August as she prepared for movers from a storage company to arrive with her furniture, clothing, certification papers that allowed her to work as a home health aide, and most of her personal photographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHM, MILFORD MILES
description: BOHM-Milford Miles. The American Technion Society (ATS) expresses profound sorrow at the passing of Milford Bohm of St. Louis, a charter member of the St. Louis Chapter and a moving force in the ATS for more than 30 years. Mr. Bohm and his wife, Lee, established an exchange program for students and faculty between the Technion and the Washington University School of Business. Mr. Bohm also supported the Technion Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, the St. Louis Chapter audio-visual library, the Irving A. Shepard Chair in Finance, and faculty recruitment efforts. A Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents and an alternate member of Technion's International Board of Governors, Mr. Bohm was honored with a Technion Honorary Fellowship in 1999. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lee Bohm and the entire Bohm family. Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President John S. Wallach, President, St. Louis Chapter Alvin A. Wolff, Jr S.t Louis Chapter

title: Metro Business Briefing; DONATIONS TO CLUB TECH
description: As part of an initiative to help end the so-called digital divide, Microsoft Corporation will give $88 million in software and $12.3 million in cash to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America over the next five years, William H. Gates, the company's chairman, and a phalanx of politicians announced in Harlem yesterday. The initiative, Club Tech, an expansion of a pilot begun in 1999, will establish or augment computer facilities and instruction at the more than 2,600 clubs worldwide. The computers and Internet connections are supplied by PowerUP, a nonprofit organization founded last year that works with companies like America Online, Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. Speaking to more than 100 children at the Dunlevy Milbank Boys and Girls Club yesterday, Mr. Gates said the gift would help the clubs expand on ''neat new things.'' He added, ''In fact, I'm envious that you have something far better than what I had as a kid,'' He was speaking of the club's technology room, which he toured earlier in the day.

title: Hamburger Safety May Be Partly in the Flip
description: The safest hamburger may be a well- flipped hamburger, a new study from the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California suggests.

title: Natural Gas and Heating Oil, in Short Supply, Gain in Price
description: Natural gas prices soared to a record yesterday, and heating oil also surged on forecasts for frigid weather at a time of low inventories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HAROLD, D.D.S.
description: SCHWARTZ-Harold, D.D.S. Oldest surviving member of Class of 1921 School of Dentistry, Columbia University, died on November 28, 2000. Loving husband of Pauline. Brother-in-law of Gail Gold. Uncle to Richard and Carolyn Gold, Nancy and James Shapiro, Pat and Howard Cohen, Robert and Toby Cohen, Steven and Janet Cohen, Paul and Jane Cohen, Charles and Edna Schwartz. Dr. Schwartz practiced in Brooklyn and Manhattan until retiring to Florida in 1973. He will remain forever in our hearts.

title: A 'Steeper Mountain'
description: It was not the end, not yet, but today's ruling in a tiny, crowded Tallahassee courtroom may have marked the beginning of the end of the nation's long, long millennial electoral melodrama.

title: Rightist Squads in Colombia Beating the Rebels
description: They began as a gang of thugs backed by the once-powerful Columbian drug cartels. But when the guerrilla war intensified, they evolved into quasi-independent right-wing paramilitary squads that killed peasants suspected of supporting Colombia's leftist rebels.

title: Review Set on Reasonableness of Arrest for Small Offense
description: The lawyer for a Texas mother who was ordered from her pickup truck by a police officer for not using seat belts, placed in handcuffs and taken to jail in front of her crying children had the ideal Supreme Court case today -- perhaps a bit too ideal.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE TO SELL CUSTOM COFFEE ON THE WEB
description: As part of a strategy to offer consumers more personalized products over the Internet, Procter & Gamble said it had begun selling custom blends of its Millstone gourmet coffee through a new Web site. Consumers are asked 12 questions about their preferences, and the answers are used to determine which of 50 varieties of beans is used in the final product, which will cost about $10 for a 12-ounce bag, about 20 percent more than specialty blends generally cost in supermarkets. The company used a similar approach in September 1999 when it started Reflect.com, which sells cosmetics tailored to customers' physical characteristics.

title: Executive Resignations at ING
description: Two executives of the corporate and investment banking arm of the Dutch financial services firm ING Group resigned today after ING said it was scaling back operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONVISSOR, CAROLE
description: CONVISSOR-Carole. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of Carole Convissor, one of the most respected and cherished members of our community. A member of the School's administrative staff since 1982, as Director of Special Projects, she lovingly developed numerous special events that had an enormously positive impact on all who experienced them. With care and sensitivity in all that she touched, she was a special friend to Juilliard's trustees, students, faculty, administrators and alumni. Our condolences are extended to her beloved husband, Sam, and her children and grandchildren. She will be deeply missed by us all. Her legacy will continue to live at Juilliard for many years to come. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman of the Board Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CHINADOTCOM CORP., New York, named Daniel Widdicombe chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer at I-Quest Corp.

title: Russia Has Few Weapons As Infectious Diseases Surge
description: Natalia Kostina lay flat on her back on a metal examining table in this city's tuberculosis hospital, staring impassively at the ceiling. In an instant, a doctor jabbed into her abdomen a thick needle attached to a syringe and pushed in a few cubic inches of air.

title: Dr. Cyril Clarke, 93, British Rh Disease Geneticist, Dies
description: Dr. Cyril Clarke, a British physician and professor of medicine whose fascination with butterfly wings led him to pursue research that helped end infant deaths from a blood disease caused by incompatible Rh factors, died on Nov. 21 in Hoylake, Cheshire, England. He was 93.

title: Eloise McGraw, Children's Author, 84
description: Eloise Jarvis McGraw, author of ''The Moorchild,'' a 1996 Newbery Honor book, and other novels for children, died on Thursday in Portland, Ore. She was 84 and lived in Oswego Lake, Ore.

title: UNITED AIRLINES WINS DISPUTE WITH REGIONAL CARRIER
description: The UAL Corporation's United Airlines unit won the final round in a legal dispute with a regional airline that accused United of reneging on an agreement to coordinate services. The United States Supreme Court refused to consider Mesa Air Group's appeal of a federal appeals court's conclusion that Mesa's claims were barred by the 1978 law that deregulated the airline industry. The dispute centers on an agreement that let Mesa use the United name and logo for certain flights. The airlines coordinated schedules and shared revenue from the flights. United in 1997 replaced Mesa with SkyWest on eight routes out of Los Angeles and terminated the agreement entirely in 1998 after Mesa eliminated service on routes it said were unprofitable.

description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPER, JULIUS D., M.D.
description: JASPER-Julius D., M.D. Suddenly on December 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Lois (nee Guterman), devoted father to Steven and Nancy, Richard and Millie, and Barbara and Stuart Aferiat. Loving grandpa to Robert, Lily, Kyle, Ben, Alex and Corey. Caring brother to Gabriel. Dr. Jasper graduated from the University of Tennessee with an M.D. degree in 1948. He practiced internal medicine in Mount Vernon for 48 years, retiring in 1998. Prior to that, he served as physician in combat with the 3rd Infantry Division during the Korean Conflict. Funeral arrangements are at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon at 12:00 noon, Wednesday, December 6, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, WILLIAM M.
description: MORRISON-William M. 74. Born Abbington, Pa. With great affection, he will be remembered for adventuring in to many kinds of different worlds, for extreme courage while battling years of cancer and the beautiful quality of making all he came in contact with feel special. May he be as free as the hawks he loved so much.

description: With two favorable court rulings behind them, Congressional Republicans escalated their call today for Vice President Al Gore to concede, while their Democratic counterparts largely heeded his calls to stick with him for a few more days of legal maneuvering.

description: Moving to calm growing fears over mad cow disease, the European Union today voted its most drastic measures yet to try to control the spread of the fatal illness.

description: Foods rich in soy do less than estrogen and little more than placebos to reduce hot flashes in women going through menopause, according to a new Mayo Clinic study that reviewed research on soy's health effects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, LISA LENTNEK
description: WHITNEY-Lisa Lentnek. The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of NY mourn the untimely passing of Lisa Lentnek Whitney whose parents, Donald and Ruth Lentnek, have been our dedicated supporters for many years. Her commitment to those in need was as passionate as her devotion to her family, and she will be missed by so many. Our deepest sympathies go to her parents; her husband, Klaus; her children, Matthew and Steven; her sister, Marci; and the entire family. May all who benefited from Lisa's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

The story, ''Prince Rooster,'' is an old Hasidic tale; Mr. Spiegelman did not create it.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: A Burst of Energy in the Regional Theater; Spiffy New Homes and Riskier Productions Expand the Art and the Audience
description: This fall a new musical, ''The Ballad of Little Jo,'' had its world premiere at the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago. A historical tale thematically about gender issues, set in the late 19th century in an Idaho mining town, it was based on the life of a real woman, Josephine Monaghan, who, until she died, was thought by her neighbors to have been a man.

title: An Octogenarian's Recital Presents Youth as Encore
description: The pianist Earl Wild recently celebrated his 85th birthday, but he put off the party until Wednesday evening, when he played a recital at Carnegie Hall. One would not take Mr. Wild for an octogenarian. Although his hair is white, as it has been for decades, he is robust and agile, and he offered a program that made no concessions to age.

title: Irene Krone, 60, Design Consultant And Safety Advocate
description: Irene Krone, who founded I. Krone Associates, a product-consulting firm, and co-founded Stop Traffic Offenses Program, or STOP, a traffic-safety advocacy group, died on Wednesday in a car crash while vacationing on Martinique. She was 60 and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: STREAMLINING AT DEUTSCHE BANK
description: At a weekend board meeting, Deutsche Bank decided to reorganize its five divisions into two, with business banking, investment banking and real estate activities in a new corporate and institutional customer group, and securities, cash management and trade finance in a new asset management and private banking group. Analysts said that in addition to promised efficiencies the move seemed to set up visible springboards for two key lieutenants of Josef Ackermann, who will succeed the current chairman, Rolf-Ernst Breuer, in 2002.

Cherished brother and brother-in-law of Mitchell and Denise, Steven and Tracy, Dona and Michael. Dedicated uncle to all his nieces and nephews. title: The Met Orchestra Leaves Its Founding Father, Only Temporarily
description: Much has been made, and for good reason, of the degree to which James Levine has transformed the Met Orchestra from an accompanying ensemble into a virtuoso instrument worth hearing on its own. The orchestra has been making recordings, and in recent years it has had a series of its own at Carnegie Hall, where it has strayed far from operatic fare. Still, for concert performances, Mr. Levine has always been at the orchestra's helm, and although one assumed that the ensemble would shine just as brightly in other hands, there was no way to know for sure.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about remarks by the president of the New Jersey state troopers' union in defense of aggressive traffic stops misidentified the highway where he said such stops had yielded large seizures of illegal drugs. It was Interstate 295, just north of the Delaware Bay Bridge and south of the turnpike -- not Interstate 95.

title: Chirac Is Pressed for Explanation of Former Aide's Arrest
description: President Jacques Chirac is facing increasing calls to reply to accusations that when he was mayor of Paris he was at the center of a well-organized corruption scheme that netted millions of dollars for his party, the Rally for the Republic.

title: On EU Table:More Power For Germany?
description: BRUSSELS  Whatever arrangement is found at the European Union summit in Nice this week to respond to Germany's attempt to win preeminent voting rights within the EU's policy-making council, this much is inevitable: The Germans are moving toward a palpably dominant position in the EU.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, REVEREND KENNETH
description: MURPHY-Reverend Kenneth, Order of Carmelites, unexpectedly on December 3, 2000. Member of The Order of Carmelites and The American Province of St. Elias. Loving son of the late Thomas and Virginia (nee Mackey). Cherished brother of Thomas (deceased) and Patricia Nerad (Patrick). Devoted uncle of Amanda. Fr. Murphy earned his Bachelors Degree in Economics and Finance at Catholic University and his Masters of Divinity Degree at The Washington Theological Union, Washington, D.C. Following his ordination Fr. Murphy was assigned to Our Lady of the Scapular Church where he served as Associate Pastor and House Procurator from 1981-1985. In 1985, Fr. Murphy served as Pre-Novice Director and Provincial Procurator in Purchase, NY. In 1990 Fr. Murphy returned to Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens Church were he served as Pastor until 1997. In 1997 Fr. Murphy was assigned to St. Elias Priory in Boca Raton, FL were he served as Campus Minister at Pope John Paul II High School. In June of 1998, Fr. Kenneth was reassigned to Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens where he served as Chaplain at Bellevue Hospital. A wake will be held at Our Lady of the Scapular-St. Stephens Church, 142 East 29th Street, NYC on Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Evening prayer will be celebrated on Wednesday at 8:00 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, December 7 at 10:30 AM. Burial will be at Carmelite Cemetery, Carmelite Drive, Middletown, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Carmelite Education, P.O. Box 868, Carmelite Drive, Middletown, NY 10940.

title: Tallahassee in the Big Leagues
description: How much longer will it last? With Al Gore's defeat yesterday in the Leon County Circuit Court, we may soon be coming to an end of Tallahassee's reign as center of the universe. But for now, our hotels and restaurants are still full and our cellular phone links are still maxed out.

title: A Gene Detective on the Trail of Alzheimer's
description: On a recent frozen afternoon, Dr. Rudolph Emile Tanzi, a 42-year-old neurogeneticist, was lounging at his beachfront home here near Boston, fingering the new book ''Decoding Darkness: The Search for the Genetic Causes of Alzheimer's Disease,'' which he wrote with Ann B. Parson, a journalist.

title: Mets Lose Out on Neagle But Say It's Not Personal
description: The Mets reached the World Series last season and they have money to spend. They have showered some of it on their own relief pitchers, but no free agents from outside the organization have decided to sign on.

But lawyers on both sides have been reluctant to talk about their progress.

description: The government concluded its five-stage sale of Portugal Telecom, with the last 111.3 million shares, or 11 percent of the company, pulling in $630 million in a heavily oversubscribed offering. The government retains 500 shares with special voting rights. Benjamin Jones
