title: No More Football, Lots of Questions
description: Pete Alvanos won four football games this season as coach of Swarthmore College. That is four times as many games as the Garnet Tide won in three previous seasons combined. Alvanos revived a moribund team that once lost 28 games in succession, and the message boards in his office are cluttered with the geometric scrawl of plays that produced the first 1,000-yard season by a running back in the 122 years that football has been played at one of the country's premier liberal arts colleges.

title: CARDINAL HEALTH TO BUY BINDLEY WESTERN
description: Cardinal Health, one of the largest drug wholesalers in the country, agreed to buy a rival, Bindley Western Industries, for $1.67 billion in stock. Cardinal will also assume $430 million in debt. Bindley shareholders will receive 0.4275 share of Cardinal for each Bindley share, equivalent to a 29 percent premium, based on Friday's closing prices. The deal gives Cardinal a position in the fast-growing business of selling radioactive diagnostic and treatment materials to hospitals and clinics. Shares of Cardinal fell $5.50, to $94; Bindley rose $5.88, to $38.88.

title: From Gore Lawyer's Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday by Vice President Al Gore's main lawyer in the Florida contest lawsuit, David Boies, after the ruling by Judge N. Sanders Sauls rejecting the suit, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Mexico Moves to Bar Televisa's Radio Deal
description: Mexican antitrust authorities said today that they would prohibit the world's largest Spanish-language broadcasting company, Televisa, from completing a planned merger to create Mexico's largest radio company.

title: Nelson Moves to Seattle; Yankees Focus on Jeter
description: On the day the Yankees lost Jeff Nelson to the Seattle Mariners after offering him $9 million for three years, they began preparations to keep Derek Jeter for several more years.

title: 8th Graders See Success Fall Off From 4th Grade
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  Four years after American fourth-grade students scored high on an international test of science and math, their performance declined markedly when they reached the eighth grade, a second survey shows.

title: Cowgirls Get the Blues And Then Move On
description: K. D. Lang may no longer be the white-hot show business phenomenon she was several years ago when Vanity Fair photographed her being shaved by Cindy Crawford. But Ms. Lang, who appeared at the Beacon Theater on Saturday evening, has built-in career insurance that fluctuations of mass taste can never take away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, MATHILDA
description: FURMAN-Mathilda, 84, on December 3, 2000. Loving wife of the late William and mother of Roger. A biochemist and, upon retirement, founder of the KRMH Food and Hunger Project. She was a fighter until the end. Services at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, December 6 at 12 noon.

title: VITAL SIGNS: FERTILITY; If You've Got Rhythm, You've Got Trouble
description: Traditional guidelines about when during the menstrual cycle a woman can get pregnant are unreliable, a study by scientists from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences has concluded.

title: G.M. SAYS IT WILL NOT COMPLETE HUGHES DEAL THIS YEAR
description: General Motors said it would not complete a transaction involving its Hughes Electronics subsidiary before the end of this year. GM said that it was making progress on a possible sale or spinoff and that there were several interested parties with different ideas of what to do with the unit, which owns the DirecTV satellite-television service, among other businesses. G.M. owns 100 percent of Hughes's assets and 32 percent of its tracking stock, which trades separately from ordinary G.M. shares. G.M. shares, which have fallen 29 percent this year, rose $1.25, to $51.56. The Hughes tracking stock, which rose 79 cents, to $22.99, has declined 28 percent this year.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET RAISES NUMBER OF JOB CUTS TO 1,300
description: Dun & Bradstreet, a provider of credit reports and other business information, said its cost-cutting program, begun in October, would eliminate 1,300 jobs, 1,000 more than previously announced. Of the 1,300 positions, 42 percent are in North America, 52 percent are in Europe and 6 percent are elsewhere, the company said in a statement. About 400 of the 1,300 positions are vacant. Shares of the company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., rose 69 cents, to $24.13.

title: In Subway Changes, W Follows V, but for Riders It's Not So Simple
description: After announcing a new V train last week, New York City Transit confirmed plans yesterday for yet another subway line -- the W -- which will begin service next summer. The line will be part of a realignment of rails and service to accommodate repairs on the Manhattan Bridge.

title: Old Clothing Never Dies, It Just Fades Far, Far Away
description: A twister sweeps through Macy's. All the clothes are vacuumed up and set aswirl. They settle at last like soft shrapnel across a vast field. Picture this space as an area the size of several football fields: a warehouse, actually, filled with garments from many periods, all seasons, in every permutation of style.

description: The Israeli Army confronted angry Jewish settlers in Gaza today and fired rockets at a refugee camp near Bethlehem in a resurgence of violence, but most of official Israel was preoccupied with the coming electoral battle here.

title: Gwendolyn Brooks, 83, Passionate Poet, Dies
description: Gwendolyn Brooks, who illuminated the black experience in America in poems that spanned most of the 20th century, winning the Pulitzer Prize in 1950, died on Sunday at her home in Chicago. She was 83.

Whitman and Ransom (Whitman Breed Abbott and Morgan 1959-1995), partner 1965-1995. Chairman tax department 1968-1995; managing general partner 1972-1995; George J. Noumair, PC, 1996-present. Beloved husband of Kathryn. Loving father of Kathryn Cotter, Robert G., Claire Smith and James J. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Dear brother of Edward G. and Margaret Farr. Visiting private. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY 11375, Tuesday, December 5, at 10:15 AM. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Catholic University of America, Columbus School of Law, Columbus Law Fund, Washington, DC 20064, would be appreciated.

Mac Schwebel, Chairman Board of Trustees James M. Dubin, Vice Chairman Dr. Elliot Spiegel, Headmaster

title: A Bankruptcy Filing
description: Gorges/Quik-to-Fix Foods Inc., a meat processor that was spun off from Tyson Foods in a leveraged buyout, filed for protections from creditors under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today after determining it was unable to pay debts related to the spinoff. Gorges, based in Dallas, reported $140.9 million in assets and $121.1 million in debts. Principal unsecured creditors include holders of $54.9 million in 11.5 percent notes due in 2006, and CIT Financial, with which it has a $50 million credit line. Tyson sold the company, which supplies the food service industry with cooked and ready-to-cook meats and partly prepared foods like meatballs and taco filling, to its managers for $184.5 million in 1996.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bork, Bush and Bubba
description: I felt sorry for Al Gore last night. It appears increasingly likely that he will lose the presidency by some 500 votes. But I also find myself relieved that slowly but surely, in their own ways, the different courts seem to be building a foundation of legitimacy for Gov. George W. Bush's narrow victory. That is hugely important. Our democracy has taken a hit here, and both Democrats and Republicans need to think about how they can start shoring it up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NEALE D.
description: KATZ-Neale D. We mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Neale D. Katz. Neale served faithfully as Israel Representative & Director General of the United Israel Appeal from September 1984-1996. Operation Moses, the initial movement of Ethiopian Jews to Israel, was successful, in part, due to Neale's lead role. Neale was tenacious in his pursuit of justice for those he served. His UIA responsibilities, on behalf of the American Jewish Federation system, included a close monitoring of and working with the Jewish Agency for Israel. He championed programs of Immigration and Absorption of new immigrants to Israel, Public housing (AMIGOUR), neighborhood redevelopment (Project Renewal) and the Israel Education Fund. Neale made Aliyah with his wife, Sandy, and their four children in August 1972, leaving a successful law practice in Chicago, Illinois. He served as an active member, officer and awardee of the Jewish United Fund of Metropolitan Chicago Young People's Division, as well as the National United Jewish Appeal Young Leadership Cabinet. He was indefatigable in his travels to explain the work of the Jewish Agency for Israel. He was an Associate Member of its Executive. He also served as the Treasurer of the World Conference of Jewish Communal Service. Neale will be missed by his many friends and colleagues. He was a member of the ''best and the brightest''. Neale is survived by his wife, Sandy, his children, Richie & Vicki Katz, Amy Katz, David and Karijna Katz, and Nancy & Allan Myburgh and two grandchildren, Billy & Iris. Burial in Jerusalem, December 5, 2000. Condolences may be sent to: Katz Family Shai Agnon 16, Apt 5, Jerusalem, Israel. Baruch Dayan Emet United Jewish Communities and United Israel Appeal Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman UJC Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman UJC Executive Committee Bennett L. Aaron, Chairman UIA Board Stephen D. Solender President UJC

title: MCM, MARKET NEWS PROVIDER, SAID TO SEEK BUYER
description: MCM Inc., a privately held provider of financial market analysis and news, is offering itself for sale, said people at several firms that have been approached as potential buyers. MCM, which sells data on global fixed-income, currency and equities markets, especially coming securities offerings, was said to be asking $55 million to $60 million. An MCM spokesman declined to comment. MCM's customers include banks, mutual funds and financial firms; it also supplies some data to news organizations and to subscribers to its Web site. Its products include MoneyWatch, CurrencyWatch and EquityWatch.

description: Two months ago, when Roger A. Enrico announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive of PepsiCo, he tried to allay concerns that his departure would change the company he had worked so hard to piece back together.

description: The signing of Mike Mussina, a star pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, by the Yankees to a six-year, $88.5 million contract greatly increases George Steinbrenner's prospects for another World Series victory next year. That is great news for Yankee fans. But it reinforces a trend that plagues baseball.

title: Bacardi USA Names Agency for Gin Account
description: Bacardi USA in Miami said yesterday that it had named Margeotes/ Fertitta & Partners in New York, majority-owned by the Maxxcom unit of the MDC Corporation, to handle brand advertising for Bombay Sapphire gin. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Minor Planet Found in Obscure Corner of Northern Milky Way
description: PHOENIX - A University of Arizona astronomer has found an object in the outer reaches of the solar system that could be the second brightest and largest so-called ``minor planet'' in space, researchers said on Monday.

title: Ivory Gets Payton Award
description: At 5-feet 8-inches tall, Louis Ivory has been told countless times that he is too short to play football. Yesterday, Ivory, a running back from Furman, stood as tall as one could in Division I-AA after he received the Walter Payton Award as player of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an ethics class that brings together students from historically black Stillman College and the University of Alabama, which excluded blacks until 1963, misidentified the governor who resisted desegregation at the university. He was George C. Wallace. (Ross Barnett was the governor of Mississippi; he made a similar stand at the University of Mississippi a year earlier, in 1962.)

title: A Sleepless Scott Plans Shake-Up For Nets
description: Byron Scott woke up at 4 o'clock this morning, suffering from the same sort of insomnia that has probably plagued his predecessors as coach of the Nets. A seven-game losing streak just 17 games into his head-coaching career had already made his sleep fitful. He was wondering how he could: a) get back to sleep or b) solve the Nets' problems when morning came.

title: A Boy's Death Shocks the British And Touches Off Soul-Searching
description: The stabbing by teenage gang members of a 10-year-old Nigerian boy, who was then left by passers-by to die in an open stairwell of a rundown London housing project, has caused widespread alarm in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, REV. THOMAS GERARD
description: CONNOLLY-Rev. Thomas Gerard, S.J. Reposing at Loyola Hall Chapel, Fordham University, Bronx, NY, Tuesday 3:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday 11:00 AM at Loyola Hall Chapel. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITHEIMER, AARON
description: SMITHEIMER-Aaron. The Chai Club of The Community Synagogue, Port Washington, New York, expresses its deepest sorrow on the passing of its founding President, Aaron Smitheimer. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Louella his wife; Roy, Don and Eileen his children, Karen and Cathy, daughters-in-law and grandson Adam Gabriel. Stanley L. Ronell, President.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about Mary Cassatt's work on view through Dec. 22 at Adelson Galleries in Manhattan misspelled the surname of an organizer. She is Susan Pinsky, not Pinksy.

title: Delta, in Court, Says Pilots Are in a Slowdown
description: Delta Air Lines plans to ask a federal judge on Tuesday to order its pilots to end a slowdown that has inconvenienced 40,000 passengers between Friday and Sunday, the airline said today.

title: CHINA CLOSES TROUBLED TRUSTS
description: The central bank of China closed three state-run investment trusts that it said were insolvent. Ningbo International Trust and Investment, Ningbo Donghai Trust and Investment and Citic Ningbo were closed on Thursday, officials said, giving no details about the trusts' debts beyond saying that they could not pay them. Craig Smith

title: Passaic County Republican Chairman Is Indicted on U.S. Bribery and Fraud Charges
description: The chairman of the Passaic County Republican Party was indicted today on federal bribery and mail fraud charges in a continuing investigation of the Republican-dominated county government that has already resulted in guilty pleas by two other officials.

title: Juggling Buckyballs Raises Hope of Warmer Superconductors
description: Add a layer of aluminum oxide to a crystal made of neatly stacked soccer-ball shaped carbon molecules known as buckyballs, and the result is a superconductor that effortlessly carries electricity at relatively warm temperatures.

title: Aura of Pessimism Pervades the Vice President's Team
description: Several of Vice President Al Gore's legal and political advisers and leading Democrats expressed little hope tonight that the Florida Supreme Court would overturn a Leon County Circuit Court ruling, leaving Mr. Gore with no more options in his quest for the White House.

title: INQUIRY ASKED ON AMAZON PRIVACY CHANGES
description: Privacy groups in the United States and Europe called on government agencies yesterday to investigate Amazon.com, saying the Internet retailer had violated laws on both sides of the Atlantic when it changed its privacy policy last summer. In a letter to the Federal Trade Commission, the two groups, the Electronic Privacy Information Center and a company called Junkbusters, asked the F.T.C. to determine if Amazon had engaged in deceptive trade practices by collecting personal information on its customers then changing its privacy policy to permit the sale of that information. Susan Stellin

title: UBS AUDITED AGAIN IN TOKYO
description: The Japanese investment banking unit of UBS of Switzerland had its second surprise regulatory inspection in three months, this time by government agents whose usual assignment is to look for evidence of specific infractions. Japanese securities regulators started an investigation of UBS Warburg on Nov. 21, government officials said, joining a team from the country's Financial Services Agency, which has been examining UBS since late August as part of a two-year sweep of the industry. The investigations are expected to take several months, and analysts said they were very likely to end in a finding of violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AFROMOWITZ, MAX
description: AFROMOWITZ-Max. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Max Afromowitz. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President

title: A Martian Lands, And Doesn't Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: Leveraged Buyout Specialist Resigns His Job at First Union
description: David Knowlton, an investment banker at the First Union Corporation who was co-manager of the bank's effort to finance leveraged buyouts and other private equity investments, is resigning, a spokeswoman for First Union confirmed yesterday.

title: 3Com Says Its Losses Will Exceed Expectations; Shares Drop
description: Asserting it had been battered by turmoil among the telephone companies it supplies, 3Com, a maker of telecommunications and data network equipment, said today that its per-share loss for the second quarter would be greater than expected.

title: Tyson Enters Bidding War for the Nation's Largest Meatpacker
description: Tyson Foods, the nation's largest poultry company, jumped into the bidding war yesterday for IBP Inc., the nation's biggest meatpacker, offering a package of cash and stock valued at $4.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, HAL
description: ROSENTHAL-Hal Dear Mucka, 7 years gone from my sight, but never my memories; gone from my touch, but never my heart. Lovingly, Your wife, Jo

title: The Heroine Is Unhappy, but It Doesn't Matter Because She's Dead
description: The experimental choreographer Doug Varone keeps his audience on the move on two floors (and the staircase in between) at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, where his hourlong piece ''Neither'' had its premiere on Sunday night.

title: Columbia Gives Awards For Journalism Done Online
description: Salon, the Internet magazine, and MSNBC.com, the World Wide Web site of the cable channel, have been honored for general excellence in Columbia University's first Online Journalism Awards.

title: Clinton Seeks Budget Accord With Leaders
description: President Clinton met today with Congressional leaders of both parties to seek agreement on spending bills that Congress needs to pass before adjourning for the year.

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column on Friday about a type of mortgage that offers a lower rate in return for a share of profits in the eventual sale of the property misstated the name of a lender that will soon be offering such loans in New York. The company is IPI Skyscraper, not ISI Skyscraper.

title: Woman Charged With Abandoning Newborn
description: Hours after giving birth yesterday morning, a Union City, N.J., woman placed her newborn in a plastic shopping bag and abandoned her outside an apartment building in near-freezing weather, the police said.

title: A Day of Rulings From the Supreme Court and a Trial Court
description: Yesterday was Day 27 of the 2000 presidential election. Here is a summary of the day's events.

title: Riyadh Journal; Saudi Mall-Crawlers Shop Till Their Veils Drop
description: When night falls, softening the concrete contours of the city and lighting its highways with an electric glow, young Saudis head for the mall.

title: Summerall Goes Back Into the Booth, Feeling Like Superman
description: ''That time, Johnson threw a slant,'' John Madden said during Sunday's Giants-Redskins game on Fox, ''and the receiver ran an out.''

title: New-Home Sales Declined 2.6% in October
description: Sales of new homes fell 2.6 percent in October but were still on pace for the second-best year on record, the Commerce Department reported today. A separate report showed a decline in the index of leading economic indicators.

title: Army Will Give National Guard The Entire U.S. Role in Bosnia
description: The Army announced today that it would effectively turn over its mission in Bosnia to part-time National Guard soldiers, including troops from Kansas, Minnesota, Indiana and New York, over the next two years.

title: Safety: Padded Underwear for Saving Frail Hips
description: Researchers hope that the findings from a large study in Finland published last month in The New England Journal of Medicine will help convince frail elderly patients that they can cut their risk of a serious fracture by wearing hip protectors.

title: Warning by U.N. Kosovo Envoy
description: A United Nations envoy urged the Serbian government and the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Kosovo today to act fast to prevent tensions from worsening on the border.

title: Indiana and UConn Return to Semifinals
description: Indiana and Connecticut are returning to the national semifinals, where they will meet Creighton and Southern Methodist on Friday night at Ericsson Field in Charlotte, N.C. Indiana will be seeking its third consecutive title, while Connecticut will try to reach Sunday's championship game after losing to Santa Clara in four overtimes in last year's semifinals.

title: Fassel Talks in Slogans, but Thinks in Victories
description: His team might make his brash playoff prediction come true this weekend, but Giants Coach Jim Fassel refuses to enjoy the moment even in the wake of his biggest victory in three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT M.
description: FELDMAN-Robert M. Suddenly, of a heart attack, Sunday, December 3, of Newton, Massachusetts, formerly of New York City. Beloved husband of Nancy (Edman) Feldman. Devoted father of Adam Feldman, M.D. of Boston, MA., and Lisa and her husband Aaron Rosenberg of Manhattan Beach, CA. Loving grandfather of Zachary Rosenberg. Dear son of Belle (Kiviat) Feldman of NYC and the late Fred Feldman. Son-in-law of Priscilla Edman and the late Dr. Emmanuel Edman. Dear brother of Martin Mann & his wife Lorena of NYC. Services at Temple Shalom of Newton, 175 Temple Street, Newton, MA, on Tuesday, December 5, 11:00 A.M. Memorial observance at his late residence immediately following the service and continuing Wednesday and Thursday, 6-9 P.M. Remembrances may be made to the Robert M. and Nancy E. Feldman Fund for Medical Research, Office of the Chancellor, University of Massachusetts Medical School, 55 Lake Avenue North, Worcester, MA 01655. Bob Feldman contributed warmth, optimism, and determination in a truly humanistic way. As a husband, father, and new grandfather, he was unequalled in his love, generosity and leadership. As a businessman and entrepreneur he was thoughtful, intellectual, persistent, and one who made things happen. He will always serve as a role model for us all and will be forever in our hearts. For information Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: White House Memo; With Hint of Nostalgia, Clinton Savors Rituals Of a Waning Presidency
description: President Clinton and his aides have a running joke in these waning days of his administration.

title: BLUELIGHT.COM TO BUY SPINWAY ASSETS
description: BlueLight.com, the year-old electronic commerce company whose majority owner is Kmart, announced yesterday that it had acquired the core assets of Spinway, an Internet service company. Spinway provides technical access for BlueLight's free Internet service, used by more than five million people, as well as 3,600 electronic shopping kiosks in more than a thousand Kmart stores. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. BlueLight said it would retain some Spinway employees. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Halls of Justice Going Up All Over; New York City Nears a Peak In Its Courthouse Building Boom
description: In Hearing Room 387 at Queens Family Court, lawyers who jam into the closet-sized chamber have had to settle for a not-so-judicial-sounding seat assignment: the windowsill. At Brooklyn Family Court, defendants awaiting their turn overflow into equally grand accommodations: the stairwell. And at Manhattan's 111 Centre Street courthouse, where suspects and the families of victims sometimes have to assemble in the same room before trials because of cramped conditions, scuffles on occasion break out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, JEAN
description: WOLF-Jean. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extend their heartfelt sympathy to Cary Wolf, Vice President of the Board of Directors on the passing of his beloved mother Jean Wolf. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy, Chairman Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: A Stealth Substitute for Braces, Designed Only for Adults
description: Many adults with crooked teeth are reluctant to undergo orthodontic treatment because of the embarrassment of wearing a mouthful of metal braces. Now, a new orthodontic device promises to straighten mild cases of overcrowding or improperly spaced teeth almost invisibly.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MOVE TO TIMES SQUARE IS PLANNED
description: Arthur Andersen, the world's largest accounting and consulting firm, completed a deal last Friday to move its headquarters to a new skyscraper to be built in Times Square. The company would take about half the space in the 47-story, 1.2-million-square-foot tower that will be built on the block bounded by Seventh Avenue and Broadway, between 42nd and 41st Streets. Arthur Anderson plans to move about 3,000 employees from its current home on Avenue of the Americas when the $600 million skyscraper is completed in 2004. ''It's the center of the business services and entertainment world,'' said Louis Salvatore, the company's interim worldwide managing partner. ''I think we'll feel right at home there.'' The developer, Boston Properties, bought the site from Prudential Insurance Company for $164 million on Friday. And last month, Arthur Andersen got a $4.5 million incentive package from the city for what has become one of the most sought-after corporate locations in New York City, Times Square. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose on signs that economic growth is slowing more in the United States than it is in the 11-nation euro region. In New York, the euro settled at 88.79 cents, up from 87.90 cents on Friday.

title: New Jersey Senate Votes to Raise Prescription Drug Aid for Elderly and Disabled
description: The New Jersey Senate approved a stack of health care bills today, the most far-reaching of them a measure that would expand the state's prescription drug subsidy program for the elderly and disabled to an estimated 100,000 middle-class residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, DON
description: WIENER-Don, whose business career as a finance and administrative executive spanned a period of over 30 years, died November 30 at home in New York City. With him was Gloria, his wife of 47 years, who was also his ''best friend'', and their cat, Hrothgar. Prior to retirement, he was Director of Administration with the law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed for 15 years. He began his career with Ford Motor Company in the 1950's in Detroit and subsequently entered the advertising agency business, concentrating his talents in administrative operations, including earnings policies, employee benefit programs and cost-effective billing and purchasing procedures. As Vice President of Administration and Finance with a major agency in New York, he authored articles and spoke on the subject of agency profit plans. During World War II, he was in Army Intelligence and Operations in the European Theatre, landing in Normandy on D Day plus 6. He held an M.A. from Stanford University, a BA from UCLA and a Rockefeller Fellowship at Kenyon College. He was an avid birder and a lover of nature, literature and the arts. He especially enjoyed cross-country skiing and being a ''part-time Catskill beekeeper'' at his upstate New York country home. His favorite ''toy'' there is a 1942 Allis Chalmers tractor which he used to mow the fields and keep the road to the house clear of snow in the winter. Besides his wife, he is survived by his sister, Faye Subrin, his brother, Jack Wiener, four nieces and two nephews, all California residents, and a multitude of friends. No service is planned. Contributions may be made to his Memorial Fund (please specify 10081540) at the Nature Conservancy, 4245 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 100, Arlington, VA 22203 or to the Beaverkill Valley Fire Department, HCR 1, Lew Beach, NY 12758

title: GORE LOSES FLORIDA RECOUNT CASE; PUTS LAST HOPE IN STATE HIGH COURT
description: Sweeping away every legal argument presented by Vice President Al Gore, a Florida circuit judge today refused to overturn Gov. George W. Bush's victory in the state's presidential election. The decision promised to make Mr. Gore's quest for the presidency more difficult than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWER, HOWARD
description: ROWER-Howard. Died on November 30 in New York City surrounded by his family. He can be remembered by New Yorkers as the soul behind Club Vinyl. He was early to develop Tribeca from warehouses to what it is today. Howard was the pioneer of organic food distribution. His Infinity Food Co. blazed the trail for wholesome, beneficial foods at a time when to do so was a rebel cause. Howard was a friend of international circus performers and provided aid to those injured in their profession. He traveled with Dr. Patch Adams, clowning in orphanages in Russia, was a member of the Board of Coney Island USA Foundation, and an annual judge of their Mermaid Parade, the Chairman of the Board of the Alexander and Louisa Calder Foundation, on the Board of Threshold Foundation, the Painter Hill Foundation, and a member of the Social Venture Network, but proudest of his membership in the Turtle and Tortoise Society of New York. Howard's connection with Circus Oz (Australia's national circus), lead to his deep devotion to the Aboriginal culture and its art and his formal adoption into a family of Aboriginal people.

description: What, one might wonder, did Palm Beach County do to deserve this?

description: To the Editor:

title: The Election Road Narrows
description: The courts were not kind to Vice President Al Gore yesterday, especially that of Judge N. Sanders Sauls of Florida, who peremptorily rejected Mr. Gore's reasonable request to review ballots that have yet to be counted. But the rulings of Judge Sauls and the United States Supreme Court pushed the election a step or two closer to resolution. Barring reckless actions by the Florida Legislature, definitive decisions on the state's vote -- and the outcome of the presidential election -- now rest primarily with the Florida Supreme Court, the institution best suited by law and temperament to resolve the ballot battle. Both Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush should make clear to the nation that they will be guided by the decisions of the state Supreme Court.

title: Complaints Are Welcome. Perkiness Is Not.
description: SHE could at least pretend to be harried and harassed, show some battle scars, look less like a television anchor and more like the enforcer who played office ''bad cop'' in her deputy days. But Jane S. Hoffman, the commissioner of consumer affairs, one of the most visible commissioners in the Giuliani administration these days, exudes capability as if it were mandated. ''Come in, come in,'' invites Ms. Hoffman, ear to the phone, eyes on the door. She is taking a call, but ready to receive visitors at 42 Broadway.

title: MP3.com to Restart Its Music Service, for Those Willing to Pay
description: MP3.com plans today to reactivate the online music service that became the subject of a losing battle with the record industry. This time, instead of testing the legal limits of digital music distribution, it will test the willingness of fans to pay for what they want to hear.

title: An Office Tour for Mom and Dad
description: THERE were graying heads and relaxed-fit jeans in the conference room at Vault.com's downtown Manhattan office one chilly afternoon last week, in numbers that have never been seen there before. There were cookies and milk, too, and a PowerPoint video demonstration that began with the basics and gets simpler. ''What is the Internet?'' the first slide asks. Answer: ''A bunch of computers that are connected together.''

description: Elmo, Big Bird and the rest of the Sesame Street Muppets are coming back to New York, financially speaking.

Ringel and loyal brother-in-law of William Ringel of Kew Gardens, N.Y. Loving stepfather of Jorge Santiago, Ivan & Wilson Gutierrez & their family of San Juan, Puerto Rico. title: Metro Business Briefing; A RULING IN CRAZY EDDIE CASE
description: A federal judge in New Jersey ordered the wife of a former executive of Crazy Eddie, the failed discount electronics chain, to surrender about $5 million in real estate yesterday, in what could be the last chapter in an enforcement saga involving Eddie Antar, the chain's owner and founder. The judge, Harold A. Ackerman, of United States District Court in Newark, ordered Rose Antar, the wife of Sam M. Antar, the father and former business partner of Eddie Antar, to turn over several family residences and vacation condominiums that her husband had transferred to her, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced. In April, the court ordered Sam Antar to return $57.5 million in principal and interest to regulators to help reimburse Crazy Eddie shareholders, who lost about $120 million, the S.E.C. said. He did not turn over the funds. At its peak, Crazy Eddie operated 40 stores in the metropolitan area.

title: Home Depot Names Officer From G.E. As President
description: Moving quickly to sign up the remaining also-ran in the race to succeed John F. Welch Jr. at General Electric, Home Depot Inc. announced yesterday that it had named Robert L. Nardelli as president and chief executive.

title: Amended Set of Absentee Ballots Is Ruled Valid in Senate Contest
description: In the closely contested race for the State Senate seat held by Roy M. Goodman, a panel of five appellate judges ruled yesterday that a corrected absentee ballot, the second of two filled out by some voters, should be considered valid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAULAY, JOHN PAUL.
description: MACAULAY-John Paul. Born February 2, 1922 in Manhattan, New York. Died on November 28, 2000 at Good Samaritan Hospital. A graduate of Marietta College in Ohio, John served as an officer of the O.S.S. during World War II. He was a retired corporate executive of Atlantic Richfield, where he served many years as a negotiator in Labor Relations. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 45 years, Rosemay Macaulay. A memorial service will be held in the chapel of St. Vincent Medical Center, 2131 W. 3rd Street in Los Angeles on December 7, 2000 at 4 PM.

description: President Vicente Fox's newly appointed national security chief said today that he would try to unravel a rat's nest of illegal government wiretaps that politicians and the police had used ''not to fight crime, but to fight criticism.''

title: New Reds Around Naples
description: FOR centuries, southern Italy has been a vast reservoir of rustic red wines, produced for a market bounded by the seas and the rugged inland hills. But in the last 25 years, several winemakers began adopting modern methods of viticulture, and their wines started to pique the interest of collectors and bargain hunters around the world.

title: DELL ADDS TO SERVER LINE
description: Continuing to push into the server market as its core business of selling personal computers matures, Dell Computer said yesterday that it would begin selling four new server computers and related services in the first two months of next year. Two new general-purpose servers, the PowerEdge 1550 and PowerEdge 350, will carry base prices of $2,599 and $1,499. Two new appliance servers, the PowerApp.web 110 and PowerApp.web 120, will be $1,499 and $2,599, respectively, and will be aimed at Internet service providers, managed host companies and other businesses. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., says it is now the No. 2 worldwide seller of Intel-based server computers.

They would have won 13 of 17 games, the third-best record in the modern era of the franchise. Only the two Super Bowl teams won more games.

title: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL TO SELL THREE UNITS TO INEOS
description: Imperial Chemical Industries agreed to sell three units to a rival, the Ineos Group, for $:325 million ($470 million), bringing Imperial Chemical's staged exit from its original business, bulk chemicals, near completion. The deal covers Crosfield, which makes silica additives used in toothpaste, and Klea, its refrigerants unit, which will be sold to Ineos, and establishes a joint venture with Ineos that will buy Imperial's Chlor-Chemicals unit, a spokesman said. To complete the deal, Imperial will buy out a Japanese joint-venture partner in Crosfield and Klea and absorb $:250 million in costs, mostly related to the cleanup of chemical sites in the chlorine-related chemicals business. This will leave Imperial with $:100 million more debt immediately, but without the burden of the units' future losses, the company said.

title: EMC TO OFFER SMALLER SERVER

It is SRI International, not Stanford Research International. The article also misstated the date of the most recent significant structural change to the Internet. It was 1984, when the domain naming system was created, not in the late 1980's.

title: In Short, Still a French Classic
description: WHEN I was first learning to be a serious cook, no task was more daunting than making demi-glace. It was a two- to three-day process that began with roasting and simmering beef and veal bones to obtain a rich stock. The stock was thickened with roux and seasoned with additional meats and vegetables. The final step was the painfully slow reduction of the broth to a gelatinous essence.

You might expect a billboard or a colorful sign advertising France's last remaining traditional vinegar-maker, but there isn't one. Instead, a sharp, unmistakable aroma, powerful enough to penetrate a rolled-up car window, broadcasts the Martin-Pouret address. It sits, as it has for more than two centuries, on Faubourg Bannier, a busy commercial street on the northern fringes of this ancient city on the Loire, although now it is surrounded by auto dealerships, warehouses and railroad tracks.

But the argument against throwing out a total of 25,000 votes in the two counties does not depend on the fact that discarding them would be politically disruptive. It would be a gross distortion of Florida election law and basic fairness to dismiss so many votes that were cast in good faith by Florida citizens on the grounds that county officials used bad judgment in letting party workers fill out some absentee application forms.

For the Whitney Museum of American Art, where a full-scale retrospective of this conceptual artist's work opens on Thursday, the correct answer is 30, most of them artists themselves. Their job was to sand, tape and paint surfaces as high as 17 feet, applying as many as seven layers of paint and penciling in tens of thousands of lines as they reproduced Mr. LeWitt's diagrams directly on the gallery walls.

On a recent night, the crowd at the bar swelled 8 and 10 deep, carrying pagers to alert them when their tables were ready. As the noise and sartorial energies rose to near-nightclub levels, a woman seated near the Buddha was moved to go way off the menu. Reaching over the water's edge, she gazed imploringly upward, then placed a palm on the statue's behind.

Century shares, which jumped 10 percent on Monday ahead of the announcement, gained $6.25 to close at $30.56 yesterday. The deal, the 11th announced this year by BB&T, gives it a stronger presence in metropolitan Atlanta, Savannah and Macon, Ga., and in areas of Tennessee and Alabama. BB&T is based in Winston-Salem, N.C.; Century South in Alpharetta, Ga.

title: Time Out or Burn Out for the Next Generation
description: College admissions officers, especially those who admitted the parents of todays applicants, have an unusual vantage point from which to observe changes from one generation to the next. Many of us are concerned that the pressures on todays students seem far more intense than those placed on previous generations. College admissionthe chance to position oneself for "success" through the acquisition of the "right" college degreelooms large for increasing numbers of students. Particularly because selective colleges are perceived to be part of the problem, we want to do everything possible to help the students we enroll make the most of their opportunities, avoiding the much-reported "burnout" phenomenon that can keep them from reaching their full potential. Of course, the quest for college admission is only one aspect of a much larger syndrome driving many students today. Stories about the latest twenty-something ".com" multimillionaires, the astronomical salaries for athletes and pop-music stars, and the often staggering compensation packages for CEOs only stimulate the frenzied search for the brass ring. More than ever, students (and their parents) seek to emulate those who win the "top prizes" and the accompanying disproportionate rewards. From the Cradle On...

The threat of a regional war seems to be growing, with potentially ruinous consequences.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC DOUBLES BONUS PAID TO ITS CHAIRMAN
description: The Emerson Electric Company doubled to $6 million the bonus it paid its chairman, Charles F. Knight, who relinquished the chief executive title this year after running the company since 1973. Mr. Knight's cash pay increased to $10.8 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, from $6.8 million the prior year, mostly because of the bigger bonus. The company, which is based in St. Louis and first gained fame for developing the electric fan around 1900, now makes telecommunications and electronic equipment and components. The company's proxy filing that details executive compensation states that Emerson has increased earnings for 43 consecutive years.

title: Security Council Lets Iraq Spend Oil Fund
description: After a day of hard bargaining, a divided Security Council agreed tonight to give Iraq new leeway in spending the billions of dollars in oil proceeds accumulating in this period of high oil prices.

description: Adapted from "The Taste of China" by Ken Hom (Simon & Schuster, 1990)

title: U.S. Decides '94 Attack On Hasidim Was Lone Act
description: After a second investigation, federal investigators have determined that a man who was convicted of firing shot after shot into a van full of Hasidic students on the Brooklyn Bridge in 1994 was not acting in concert with any terrorist organization. The attack injured three students, one severely, and killed a fourth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHERN, MARY ELIZABETH
description: MULHERN-Mary Elizabeth Furer. Died on December 5, 2000. Mary was born and raised in Brooklyn, married in 1966, had a daughter Gannon in 1976 and became a Senior Vice President of First Union Corp., in 1996. She was diagnosed with stage four ovarian cancer in December 1993. Mary was a woman of striking beauty and vibrant personality who played many roles in her life and was an inspiration to her colleagues, friends and family. She leaves her mother, Mary Furer, her husband Tom, her daughter Gannon, sister Penny, Karen and Sheila, and brothers Bill, Tom, Mike and Joe. A memorial service will be held in mid-January, place and time to be announced. Contributions in her memory can be made to Dr. Dan Smith, The Spirit of Care Foundation, NY Presbyterian Hospital, 161 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. The dollar advanced after remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chief, prompted a rally in stocks and bonds. In New York, the euro settled at 88.09 cents, down from 88.79 cents on Monday.

description: ''Frank Herbert's 'Dune' '' is to the Sci Fi channel what the Super Bowl is to CBS: the big game.

title: C & N TO ACQUIRE CONTROL OF THOMAS COOK
description: The German tour operator C & N Touristic, jointly owned by Lufthansa and Karstadt Quelle, a German retailer, is expected to announce this week that it has acquired control of the Thomas Cook Group by buying a 22 percent stake from the Carlson Companies for $:550 million ($799.7 million) in cash. Included in the deal is Carlson's right of first refusal on the remaining 78 percent of the company's stock, which is jointly held by Preussag and Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale; Preussag must sell its interest to satisfy regulators after it bought another British tour operator. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

This may be unfair -- or it may be wishful thinking. But in any case it was Mr. Cheney, speaking last weekend, who gave us our first post-election hints about Mr. Bush's economic policy. And the news is not good.

title: Corrections

title: MAKER OF CON-TACT STICKY PAPER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Decora Industries, an adhesives maker known for its sticky Con-Tact shelf paper, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors. The company, based in Fort Edward, N.Y., and its Decora Inc. unit listed $123.2 million in assets and more than $224.9 million in debts. The company, which failed to make a Nov. 1 interest payment on $112.7 million in 11 percent notes due in 2005, said it had reached agreement with about 70 percent of its noteholders to exchange the notes for stock in the reorganized company. Decora developed Con-Tact paper in 1952 and manufactured it under an agreement with Rubbermaid for many years; it bought the brand from Rubbermaid in 1998 for $52.5 million in cash.

He also described himself as optimistic about his chances of prevailing in his month-old political and legal struggle -- even after suffering a sweeping defeat in a Florida court on Monday.

description: The relationship of Mayor John O. Norquist of Milwaukee with a former aide has been catapulted into the public spotlight, with the aide filing a sexual harassment complaint against the city and the mayor saying they had a consensual extramarital affair.

title: A Pocket-Size Opera From a Harrowing Kafka Story
description: In the age of the Khmer Rouge and Rwanda, of Bosnia and Kosovo and Sierra Leone, it seems unlikely that Franz Kafka will ever go out of fashion. No 20th-century writer tells more about that awful zone where the absurd becomes tragic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Iraq's suspension of oil exports omitted a word in summarizing a view of independent arms experts on terms for getting weapons inspectors back into Iraq. They said that to avoid letting Iraq do only the minimal accounting required, international authorities should ''not'' give the country a list of tasks that must be done to close the book on its biological, chemical, nuclear and missile programs.

description: Four years after American fourth-grade students scored high on an international test of science and math, their performance declined markedly when they reached the eighth grade, a second survey shows.

description: MOSCOW, Dec. 6  A Moscow court gave the maximum sentence of 20 years at hard labor today to Edmond Pope, an American former naval intelligence officer accused of trying to acquire technology for a rocket-propelled torpedo.

description: On the ice, he won more games than any other goalie, but his life was not always happy at home. Sometimes he argued with his wife and frightened their children. ''We would keep the door to the kitchen closed,'' the goalie's wife said. ''He'd be in the living room.'' One night, after an argument, the goalie locked his wife out of the house without a coat in winter weather. ''Don't you dare open that door,'' the goalie shouted to his children. ''Got it?''

description: If the United States men's soccer team is to succeed at the world's game, it has to learn to play games with the world.

description: Only days after Chancellor Harold O. Levy barred the school system from supporting the Boy Scouts because of their policy against gay troop leaders, school board members in a Queens district are staging something of a rebellion. This is the same district that helped oust a previous chancellor over issues involving gay men and lesbians.

description: The Emerson Electric Company in St. Louis said yesterday that it would change its name to Emerson and change its logo for the first time since 1967 as part of a rebranding strategy meant to convince consumers that the company is as focused on technology as on engineering.

description: Manager Joe Torre was the first to call Mike Mussina on behalf of the Yankees, and then the general manager, Brian Cashman, called. But when Mussina picked up the phone last month and was asked by a secretary if he had a minute to speak to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, he was not sure what to think. ''Are you calling on behalf of the Yankees or the Mets?'' Mussina asked.

title: BRAZIL AUCTION POSTPONED
description: The government of Sao Paulo state put off its planned auction of a controlling interest in Energetica de Sao Paulo, a leading power generator, after the last of six prospective bidders withdrew, citing unresolved concerns about the company's debt. The state had hoped to raise 1.74 billion reais ($880 million).

title: PETSMART.COM BUYS PETS.COM NAME
description: Pets.com, the online pet store that announced last month it would shut down, has sold the Pets.com domain name to its old rival Petsmart.com. The price of the deal was not disclosed. As part of the arrangement, Petsmart also acquired the name Petstore.com, which Pets.com obtained in June along with Hamster.com when it purchased the assets of a rival online pet supply store. The companies said they hoped to complete the deal within a month. Petsmart of Pasadena, Calif., purchased the domain names the same week it announced it would delay its planned initial share offering. Pets.com, based in San Francisco and backed by Amazon.com, announced on Nov. 7 that it would end operations and lay off most of its 320 employees.

description: Is New York finally ready to receive Alice? The first time this spiritual temptress hit town, 36 years ago, she was greeted with rancor, ridicule, irritation and some unpleasant personal name-calling.

description: After Vice President Al Gore lost his challenge to the Florida vote count in a Tallahassee trial court on Monday, it seemed that an appeal to the Florida Supreme Court could bring the litigation battle for the presidency to an end within days.

description: Dick Cheney took to Capitol Hill today to reassure restive Republicans that the transition to a Bush administration was under way, and to gingerly embrace the role he expects to play as the equivalent of a 51st Republican senator.

title: LUCENT PICKS NAME FOR SPINOFF
description: Lucent Technologies renamed the microelectronics unit it plans to spin off Agere Systems Inc., taking the name of a company it acquired earlier this year. Lucent plans to sell 20 percent of Agere in the first quarter of 2001 in an offering that analysts say could raise $8 billion or more. It will distribute the remaining 80 percent to Lucent shareholders by the middle of the year. Lucent bought Agere Inc. in April for $377 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUVALL, MAX
description: SUVALL-Max.The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Max Suvall whose family has embraced his legacy of righteous deeds and Jewish community leadership. His son, Marc, is a former chair of our Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal. Marc's wife, Harriet, a guiding light on our Women's Campaign Executive Board, created a teen center at our affiliated JCC of MidWestchester, and started Operation Mitzvah in Westchester. Our deepest sympathies go to them; his other children, Michael and Susan, and their spouses; his grandchildren, David and Cara; his beloved friend, Jesse; and the entire family. May all who benefited from Max's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: CISCO HIRES AT&T EXECUTIVE
description: Cisco Systems, which controls more than three-quarters of the market for products that link communications networks and power the Internet, has lured a key executive from AT&T, hiring Hossein Eslambolchi as its vice president in charge of service provider businesses. Mr. Eslambolchi, a 15-year AT&T executive, was a senior vice president in charge of the company's development of Internet-based communications systems that focus on data as well as voice traffic. At Cisco Systems, he will work on building sales of optical networking services and products. ''Cisco understands the direction where tornado-market opportunities like optical networking technology are heading,'' he said. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing; KOZMO.COM ADDS DELIVERY FEE
description: Kozmo.com, the one-hour online delivery service, has begun charging a $1.99 fee for orders of less than $30, retreating from an earlier promise of no delivery fees. In recent months, several online delivery companies have added or increased delivery fees. Joseph Park, the co-founder and chairman of Kozmo, who served as its chief executive until last summer, made the promise that it would not charge extra for delivery. But company officials said Kozmo's new chief executive, Gerry Burdo, was testing the waters for a permanent delivery fee last month when the company added extra charges for some holiday gift orders. Kozmo, a privately held Silicon Alley company that delivers in 11 cities, is trying to increase its average order price, and has had some success selling some more expensive items since its chief rival, Urbanfetch, shut down its Web site in October. Jayson Blair

title: Nokia Offers Upbeat View Through '03
description: During a gathering of analysts and investors here today, Nokia, the Finnish mobile phone maker, painted an upbeat picture for revenue and subscriber growth, helping to set off a broad rally in technology stocks.

title: Two Dozen More Bankers Leave Credit Suisse for UBS
description: In a talent raid that either failed or was quite successful depending on which side is telling the story, Credit Suisse First Boston lost about two dozen more investment bankers to the United States investment banking unit of a rival Swiss bank, UBS.

title: TECHNICOLOR ON THE BLOCK
description: Carlton Communications said it was in talks to sell its Technicolor film-processing unit in the next few weeks and that its profit fell 44 percent in fiscal 2000, mainly because of widening losses on investments in digital TV. Net income from continuing operations, excluding one-time items, fell to $:70.2 million ($101 million), or 8.8 pence (12.8 cents) a share, from $:124.3 million ($180.7 million) a year earlier. It first said it wanted to sell Technicolor a year ago, but analysts were skeptical that a buyer could be found. Technicolor's main competitor, Deluxe, is also being offered for sale by its parent, the Rank Group. Rank and Carlton are both based in Britain.

title: Sports of The Times; New Champ Learned Patience
description: AUTO racing is not football, even though they share some of the same constituency.

title: Independent Counsel Seeks To Interview Lewinsky Again
description: Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, has asked a handful of witnesses, including Monica Lewinsky, Linda R. Tripp and Betty Currie, to be reinterviewed by his prosecutors as he winds up deliberations about whether to indict President Clinton after he leaves office, lawyers involved in the case said today.

title: BOTH CHIEFS QUIT AT CORUS
description: The Corus Group, a giant British-Dutch steel maker, said both its two chief executives, J. F. van Duyne and J. M. Bryant, resigned after the company's recent poor performance. ''The carbon steel business continues to struggle,'' Corus said in a statement that warned of ''further major restructuring'' in light of the weak market outlook and adverse currency movements. Both resignations were immediate.

title: Debate After Football Injury: Aggressive Play vs. Assault
description: In football, a game of organized, even ritualized, aggression, it can sometimes be hard to tell where a good play ends and an assault begins. Now, an unusual case in the Nassau County courts will try to draw that fine line, after a high school football game that left a Long Island teenager with a dislocated and broken elbow.

title: Fall From Subway Train Kills 3-Year-Old Boy
description: The Q train from Brooklyn to Manhattan was crowded yesterday morning, but Xing Ling Mei managed to get a seat at the end of a car with her son Austin, 3. The boy sat on his mother's lap at first, then stood up. Ms. Mei ordered him to sit back down as the train left the DeKalb Avenue station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLER, CONRAD, M.D.
description: MEHLER-Conrad, M.D. Of New York, NY on December 4, 2000 at the age of 85. Beloved husband of Tuci for 51 years, loving father of Rya and Charles Rosenzweig, and proud grandfather of Jessica and Erica. Resident of Czernowitz, he attended medical school in Bologna before making Aliyah to Israel during th Holocaust. In his new homeland, he fought bravely in the Israeli army and delivered thousands of babies at Degainia Hospital in Jaffa. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1957, he became a psychiatrist and eventually the medical director of Bronx Psychiatric and a member of the faculty of Metropolitan Hospital. A gentle and caring man and a wonderful listener, he will be missed by his family, friends, and patients.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: New Health Czar at Columbia

title: Western Conference A Test for a Hot Team
description: Last month, the Knicks left for a Western Conference road trip on a high after winning three of four games impressively, only to return humbled after losing two of three. Now, the Knicks are rolling -- 3-0 since Latrell Sprewell challenged them with a heartfelt locker-room speech -- and it's time to go west again.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE PLANS LAYOFFS OF 14 PERCENT OF STAFF
description: The Outboard Marine unit of Greenmarine Holdings said it would lay off 14 percent of its work force, involving about 1,000 jobs, to cut costs because demand for marine recreational vehicles had slowed. Outboard, based in Waukegan, Ill., said problems with the supply of engine materials also hurt its operating performance, and that further cutbacks could be necessary if demand for its products continues to weaken. Outboard makes boats under the Chris-Craft, Four Winns and Stratos brands. It and its parent are closely held.

title: An American Sound That's Both Spruce and Brash
description: The Chamber Music Society's concert on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall paid homage to two American composers: David Diamond, who celebrated his 85th birthday in the summer, and Lucia Dlugoszewski, who died in April. Two artists of the same era could hardly have been more different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURMAN, MARTIN, MD.
description: KURMAN-Martin, MD. title: 'My Fake Job' A Bit Too Fake For New Yorker
description: In his first article for The New Yorker magazine, Rodney Rothman, a freelance writer and television producer, wrote a humorous personal essay titled ''My Fake Job.'' In the article, which The New Yorker published in the Nov. 27 issue, Mr. Rothman described two weeks during which he masqueraded as an employee at an Internet company, working under the assumed name Randy Ronfman.

title: A Man Who Likes His Quiet Comes to the Big, Noisy City
description: Stepping between the 40-foot pines surrounding his house, Mike Mussina is 15 minutes from Divine Providence. That's the hospital where he was born, and the Little League field on which he played is even closer, 10 minutes if you obey the speed limit. It takes eight minutes to get to the house where his parents live, where he sought isolation as a child, in this isolated town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEMSON, ROBERT B.
description: GEMSON-Robert B. Died peacefully at home on December 4, 2000, at age 83. Beloved husband of Miriam (nee Solender), loving father of Constance and Donald, dear father-in-law of Lesley, cherished grandfather of Edward and Maya. Born in NYC, graduated from Boys HS, received a BA from LIU, JD from Fordham Law School and MS from Hofstra. He was an English teacher at East Meadow HS for over 20 years, and Director and co-owner of Camp Berkshire in Winsted, CT for over 30 years. Following retirement from teaching, he initiated ''Have Cast Will Travel'', a musical variety show that performed 355 shows at senior centers. He also wrote a newspaper column entitled ''On My Mind'' for a variety of community newspapers on LI for over 20 years. He won numerous awards for ''Have Cast'' show, including Jefferson Award for Public Service, Boys HS Alumni of Year, and Newsday Award for Community Service. His humor, friendliness, warmth and kindness will be missed. Services today at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 12:30PM. Contributions to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Melville, NY.

title: BRIDGESTONE SHARES FALL
description: A report in USA Today that lawyers suing Firestone over tire failures want to add Firestone's Japanese parent, Bridgestone, as a defendant in the case knocked Bridgestone's share price down the maximum allowed for stocks in its price range, 14 percent. Yoichiro Kaizaki, president of Bridgestone, said the company expected claims and replacement costs related to faulty tires to total $900 million, while plaintiffs' lawyers were said in the newspaper report to be hoping for $50 billion in damages. Bridgestone executives said the company was not considering a bankruptcy filing. Its shares closed at 1,252 yen ($11.29). Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Corrections

description: Safeway Inc., one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, agreed today to buy the closely held Genuardi's Family Markets Inc. to strengthen its foothold on the East Coast.

title: Griffin's Injury Is Not Severe
description: Eddie Griffin, Seton Hall's standout freshman forward, strained a tendon in his right knee in Monday night's victory over Norfolk State, but did not sustain any damage to his ligaments or cartilage, the school said today. He will undergo treatment and has not been ruled out of playing in the Pirates' game Saturday at Illinois.

title: Fox for Streisand
description: Barbra Streisand's audience does not seem to fit the profile of the Fox network, which for some time has tilted toward young men, but Ms. Streisand will be seen in her swan song concert film on the Fox network on Feb. 14. ''Barbra Streisand: Timeless,'' will be a compilation of songs from the concert she performed last New Year's Eve at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas. These are not selections from this year's farewell concert tour, which was not filmed.

title: Nasdaq Sets Record In Broad Rally Amid Hope On Rates
description: Stocks soared yesterday, propelled by what investors took as a clear sign of impending cuts in interest rates and by optimism that the presidential election stalemate may be nearing an end.

title: Speaker Tempers Call for Session on Electors
description: Tom Feeney, speaker of the Florida House, said again today that he believed a special session of the Florida Legislature might be needed to appoint the state's 25 presidential electors. But this time his remarks reflected less of the sense of urgency of days past as he declared that Vice President Al Gore appeared to be running out of options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LISA C.
description: MILLER-Lisa C. Age 32. Died December 1 at her home in NYC. She was as Associate with Jerusalem Venture Partners, a venture capital firm specializing in high technology. She earned a Masters Degree in Public Policy from Columbia University in 1995 after receiving her BA with honors in Political Science from Barnard College in 1990. She is survived by her parents, Susan and Bruce Miller of Wisconsin as well as her younger brother, B.J. Miller of San Francisco. She was actively involved with the organizations Step-Up and Veritas, and was a great friend of Barnard. She changed the lives of the people who knew her and will be missed immeasurably. Visitation will begin at 8:30AM at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University at 116th and Broadway on December 7. The memorial service will begin at 9:45am. A reception will follow at the Faculty House of Columbia University. A memorial fund in her name is being established at Barnard College.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''American children continue to learn, but their peers in other countries are learning at a higher rate.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, REVEREND KENNETH,
description: MURPHY-Reverend Kenneth, Order of Carmelites, unexpectedly on December 3, 2000. Member of The Order of Carmelites and The American Province of St. Elias. Loving son of the late Thomas and Virginia (nee Mackey). Cherished brother of Thomas (deceased) and Patricia Nerad (Patrick). Devoted uncle of Amanda. Fr. Murphy earned his Bachelors Degree in Economics and Finance at Catholic University and his Masters of Divinity Degree at The Washington Theological Union, Washington, D.C. Following his ordination Fr. Murphy was assigned to Our Lady of the Scapular Church where he served as Associate Pastor and House Procurator from 1981-1985. In 1985, Fr. Murphy served as Pre-Novice Director and Provincial Procurator in Purchase, NY. In 1990 Fr. Murphy returned to Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens Church were he served as Pastor until 1997. In 1997 Fr. Murphy was assigned to St. Elias Priory in Boca Raton, FL were he served as Campus Minister at Pope John Paul II High School. In June of 1998, Fr. Kenneth was reassigned to Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens where he served as Chaplain at Bellevue Hospital. A wake will be held at Our Lady of the Scapular-St. Stephens Church, 142 East 29th Street, NYC on Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Evening prayer will be celebrated on Wednesday at 8:00 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, December 7 at 10:30 AM. Burial will be at Carmelite Cemetery, Carmelite Drive, Middletown, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Carmelite Education, P.O. Box 868, Carmelite Drive, Middletown, NY 10940.

description: Russia's biggest aluminum producer, flush with cash and seeking new investments in Russia's reviving manufacturing sector, has increased its management role in the country's second-largest carmaker, reflecting a broader trend among the highly profitable commodities companies.

title: Cutting Flights at La Guardia May Not Mean Fewer Delays
description: Despite a lottery held on Monday that will essentially reduce the number of flights at La Guardia Airport, there is no guarantee that travelers will see an end to the overcrowding and delays that have become common there, industry officials said yesterday.

title: F.D.A. WARNS ALCON LABORATORIES ON QUALITY AND SAFETY
description: The Alcon Laboratories unit of Nestle S.A., which makes eye drugs and medical devices, failed to follow federal quality and safety regulations, the Food and Drug Administration warned the company in a letter dated Nov. 17. The letter, released by the agency yesterday, was based on an inspection of an Alcon plant in Fort Worth in October. Among the lapses cited were a lack of written procedures to assure that drug-making equipment would prevent microbial contamination of drugs and improper testing of some equipment. A spokeswoman for Alcon said it had addressed the problems and notified the agency.

description: I COULD give you the easy description of my job. I am a chef and pastry chef for Petrossian restaurants in New York and Paris. But my palate lies somewhere between the worlds of savory and sweet. I've never quite been able to separate the two.

title: Gore Awaits 'Final Arbiter' In Long Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Stung by a strongly worded state court ruling and without a hoped-for lifeline from the U.S. Supreme Court, Vice President Al Gore turned to the Florida Supreme Court on Tuesday as probably his last resort. A final resolution in the election appeared to be only days away.

title: Opening Albany's Secret Doors
description: By an overwhelming 95-to-1 vote, Democrats in the New York State Assembly agreed this week that Speaker Sheldon Silver could keep his leadership position, at least for awhile. The one vote against Mr. Silver came from Michael Bragman, who launched a failed rebellion against the speaker earlier this year. But the dwindling of resistance should not be read as a sign that Albany and its leaders can now slip back into their stale and secretive ways.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HIGH PAY FOR A HIGH-TECH HUB
description: Central New Jersey has some of the highest-paid technology workers in the country, according to a study released yesterday by the American Electronics Association. Using data from 1998, the group found that the high-tech industry in Hunterdon, Middlesex and Somerset Counties pays workers an average of $78,835 a year. That figure is surpassed only in Seattle ($129,259) and San Jose, Calif. ($85,149). Central New Jersey has become a high-tech hub, ranked 25th in high-tech employment in the study; the area is home to large telecommunications outfits as well as small software and computer firms. Leslie Eaton

She received a notice of suspension, which she has the right to appeal; she did not receive a letter of separation, the bureaucratic equivalent of dismissal.

title: HEWLETT AFFIRMS GROWTH TARGETS
description: Seeking to restore investor trust after an unexpectedly poor quarter, Hewlett-Packard reiterated that revenue growth in the 2001 fiscal year would meet analysts' expectations of 15 to 17 percent, but that most of the growth would come in the second half. In a conference with analysts, who are still smarting after the company missed expectations by 10 cents a share last month, Carleton S. Fiorina, the Hewlett chief executive, acknowledged that investor confidence was clearly shaken and outlined plans to improve performance. She said last quarter's unanticipated earnings shortfall was galvanizing; she and several other executives did not receive bonuses for the second half of the year, and the retirements of several managers were accelerated. The company had anticipated a major slowdown in personal computer sales and focused in higher-margin products, including network servers and storage machines. The guidance is based on a predictions of a soft landing, or gradual slowing of the economy, she said. A major recession would probably force Hewlett-Packard to revise its guidance. Chris Gaither

title: BANKS ACT ON TAIWAN ASSETS
description: A group representing large commercial lenders in Taiwan said its members would pitch in to help ease the country's credit problems by financing new asset-management companies that would buy banks' troubled loans. Plunging stock and property markets have eroded the value of banks' collateral, while borrowers struggle to make payments in a slowing economy. The government has asked the banks to help solve the problem of bad loans, whose total the government puts at $10.9 billion; private estimates are higher.

title: RETAILER NAMES CHAIRMAN

Jiro Amagai, who oversaw retail policy at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, replaces Isao Nakauchi, Daiei's founder, who resigned in October over the company's problems. Daiei has the backing of its banks for now, but may need government help if the banks grow wary. Stephanie Strom

description: MARCUS-Leonard. Yeshiva University and its Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology are saddened by the passing of a dear friend, beloved husband of Adele. An eminent entrepreneur and highly respected leader of the Jewish community, he was a founding member of the FGS Board of Governors and-with his late first wife, Murial-a YU Guardian and Fellow of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. They established FGS' Leonard and Murial Marcus Family Project for the Study of the Disturbed Adolescent, which has supported the fellowships of hundreds of students and advanced research in a vital area. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Adele; children, Peter and John; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Dr. Jayne G. Beker, Chair FGS Board of Governors
