description: O.K., so you might not be ready for (or able to afford) a fancy wireless Internet connection for your laptop computer. But you still want to be able to read what you find on the Net while you're on the go. Or perhaps you just don't want to tie up your telephone line while reading Web items on your desktop computer.

title: Florida Lawmakers to Convene Special Session Tomorrow
description: After hemming and hawing for more than a week about the need to convene a special session of the State Legislature immediately, Florida's Republican Senate president and speaker of the House said today that the sound of the ticking clock had simply grown too loud, forcing them to act.

title: As If an Umbrella and Hat Conspired to Defeat a Man
description: Gregg Goldston, a lanky mime with nimble limbs and an expressive face, presented his ''One Man Mime Show'' on Monday night at the Theater at Raw Space. His seven solos, directed by Victoria Labalme, displayed Mr. Goldston's gestural abilities. His agility was often more impressive than his dramatic conceptions.

title: A Game Too Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Hide the Facts About Air Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: High Profits Open Way to Black Market In Animal Feed
description: BRUSSELS  European Union farm ministers have decreed a temporary ban on meat and bone meal in an effort to halt "mad cow" disease, but experience in Belgium with illegal hormones indicates that the policy is unlikely to work consistently.

title: Restoring Swirling Cloaks And Passion to 'Il Trovatore'
description: Two of the Metropolitan Opera's strongest productions of recent years, Shostakovich's ''Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District'' and Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron,'' were staged by Graham Vick, whose reward, if it can be called that, was to be given the task of directing one of the most notoriously awkward operas in the standard repertory, Verdi's ''Trovatore,'' in a new production that opens tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A letter yesterday about the 1960 presidential election misstated the number of Illinois electoral votes that year. It was 27, not 22 (the current number).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, DICK
description: HALPERN-Dick. To a wonderful man, companion and lover of all things. May he decorate the heavens the way he decorated our lives. We will all miss him. Steve, Lynne and Lillian

title: Hallway Land Grab
description: WHEN Kent Oz, an investment banker, and Lisa Krasnowski, a flight attendant, built a second floor in their double-height studio in a fancy condominium building in Midtown Manhattan, they had room for their bed and bureau, but they were without a closet up there -- or a bathroom.

title: Netscape's New Browser
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD SEEKS CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: The Armstrong World Industries unit of Armstrong Holdings has filed in bankruptcy court for Chapter 11 protection from creditors. The unit said it had become financially overwhelmed by asbestos-related personal injury claims that might reach $1.36 billion by 2006, according to regulatory filings. The parent company and other subsidiaries, including Triangle Pacific and operations outside the United States, were not included in the filing. Armstrong officials said they had tried to settle asbestos lawsuits but could not resolve enough to avoid the Chapter 11 filing for the unit, based in Lancaster, Pa., which makes flooring products. Armstrong Holdings stock closed yesterday at 94 cents a share, down 13 cents.

title: Bishop George W. Barrett, 92; Fostered Women's Ordination
description: Bishop George West Barrett, a former leader of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester, who ordained four women as Episcopal ministers in 1975, before the Episcopal Church had approved ordaining women, died on Sunday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 92.

title: The Fine Art Of the Menorah
description: Tradition! Tradition! The form of a Hanukkah menorah has its own tradition -- of being open to design interpretation, as long it can hold nine lights. Otherwise, anything goes. This year, a New York veterinarian made a Southwest-style menorah of elk horns. For the more conservative, there is a miniature sterling menorah from Israel, compact enough to be used for traveling; it can also be turned upside down and used as Sabbath candlesticks. The seven models shown here are all from museum shops. Hanukkah begins at sundown on Dec. 21.

title: Accounts
description: * Ladies Professional Golf Association, Daytona Beach, Fla., to T. G. Madison, Atlanta, to handle its account, which had been at the Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at less than $5 million.

title: Buoyed by Aid Offers, Turk Is Off to European Meeting
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit flew today to a summit meeting of European leaders in France flush with news of a pledge of $10 billion in international aid to avert a financial crisis and with signs of progress in Turkey's effort to join the European Union.

title: Profit Warning by Bank of America Sets Off Big Retreat
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday after an explosive rally on Tuesday that propelled the Nasdaq composite index to its biggest one-day gain ever.

title: Broadway Meat, Cut for a Skewer
description: Some ghosts get attention by rattling chains or causing small objects to fly. But the phantom haunting the Stardust Theater has only to open her mouth to make walls shake and hearts flutter. After all, she was a Broadway star before the days of miking, and her voice comes at you like a Mack truck down an Alpine road. ''Listen to me!'' says Ethel Merman, as she lectures a wimpy-looking Elton John on Broadway style. ''I've been dead for a long time. I know about these things.''

title: Free Press Is Battered in Post-Soviet Central Asia
description: Across the former Soviet lands of Central Asia, repression of news media is increasing and indiscriminate, say Western diplomats, local journalists and representatives of foreign and domestic private groups monitoring the region's progress -- or lack of it -- in building democracy.

title: Building the Latin American Internet
description: A little more than a year ago, Rance Hesketh was doing business on a cell phone from his car. Mr. Hesketh, a 36-year-old Canadian executive, had signed on to be the manager in Brazil for OptiGlobe, an Internet infrastructure company that existed, at the time, only in the minds of its founders in Bethesda, Md.

title: TEXTRON TO BUY TELECOMMUNICATIONS MANUFACTURER
description: Textron, a conglomerate whose businesses include helicopters and financing, agreed yesterday to buy the Tempo Research Corporation, a maker of testing equipment for the telecommunications industry. Terms were not disclosed. Tempo, closely held and based in Vista, Calif., is expected to have $55 million in sales this year. Textron is based in Providence, R.I. Shares of Textron, down 37 percent this year, fell $1.31, to $47.31.

title: Divinely and Romantically, Embracing a Higher Love
description: U2 is stripping away its facades. On Tuesday night, when it played at Irving Plaza for a nationwide radio broadcast, U2 was just a four-man band on a plain club stage. The concert was, pragmatically, part of a promotional effort for the band's new album, ''All That You Can't Leave Behind'' (Interscope). But it was also a signal that U2 had decided to reclaim an identity that it struggled against for a decade: unguarded, anthemic and openly spiritual.

title: ERICSSON CUTS JUNIPER STAKE
description: Ericsson A.B., the largest supplier of wireless-network equipment, indicated it had made almost $1.62 billion by selling half its stake in Juniper Networks Inc. Ericsson will use the proceeds to develop gear that lets mobile phone users download video and surf the Internet. Shares of Juniper, which makes equipment used to direct data traffic in computer networks, fell $15.70, to $140.30. Ericsson's stake, which it acquired before Juniper's June 1999 initial offering, was reduced to 2 percent from 5 percent, a spokeswoman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUCY, DONALD G.
description: SOUCY-Donald G. On December 5, 2000, passed at his residence in Glen Oaks Queens at the age of 82. He was the founder and Principal of Don Soucy Photo Association in New York City, NY. Beloved husband of the late Josephine Brennan Soucy. Loving father of Ali, Donna and Michele. Cherished grandfather of Arielle, Joshua and Cadence. A memorial service will be held at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York. Today 7-9:30PM. Cremation service private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAZQUEZ, GAIL A.
description: VAZQUEZ-Gail A., age 57, of Jupiter, FL and formerly of Island Park, NY, went to her heavenly rest on Tuesday, December 5th. Gail is survived and will be lovingly remembered by her husband, William, daughter Andrea, stepsons William M. and Jeffrey, sister Linda, and brothers John and Lawrence. A memorial service will be celebrated in NY at The Community Presbyterian Church of Malverne at 5PM on December 17th. Memorial contributions in memory of Gail may be made to: Community Presbyterian Church of Malverne, 12 Nottingham Rd, Malverne, NY 11565, or to: Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Motorola Deal With Canadian Supplier
description: In its latest move to streamline operations, Motorola has agreed to sell two plants to Celestica Inc. of Toronto for $70 million and to buy more than $1 billion worth of cellular phones and other products from Celestica over the next three years.

title: Delay of Federal Inmate's Execution Is Debated
description: In a series of private meetings today, Attorney General Janet Reno and her advisers forcefully debated whether President Clinton should grant a reprieve to Juan Raul Garza, a federal inmate who is scheduled to die next Tuesday by lethal injection.

title: WITH COURT SET TO HEAR APPEAL, LEGISLATORS MOVE ON ELECTORS
description: Hours after Vice President Al Gore's lawyers filed what they said was his final appeal in his quest for the presidency, the Republican leaders of the Florida Legislature called a special session for Friday to appoint a set of presidential electors who would support Gov. George W. Bush.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: EBay, a Site for the Lost and Found
description: PLEASE do not buy me a used hockey jersey that Wayne Gretzky may or may not have worn when the Rangers played away.

title: Shopping Outlook; Try, Try, Again
description: WHEN online shoppers click on the Buy button this holiday season, they may be crossing their fingers at the same time. Last year, some Web-based retailers delivered a relatively disastrous shopping experience -- many online orders did not arrive before Christmas, if they arrived at all. This year, several analysts say, the majority of last year's online shoppers are willing to give the Web another try.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN TO ACQUIRE STAKES IN 2 MINING RIVALS
description: Anglo American, one of the world's largest mining companies, has agreed to trade $863 million in nonmining assets for minority stakes in two competitors. Anglo will turn over three-quarters of its 20 percent stake in FirstRand, a major South African financial services company, to Remgro, a holding company for mining, financial and industrial interests. In exchange, it will get 7.1 percent of Billiton and 11.3 percent of Gold Fields. Anglo has shed assets worth about $1.6 billion this year to concentrate on mining and processing ore.

title: Wireless Technology for Offline Shoppers
description: THE Genuardi's Family Markets store that opened yesterday in King of Prussia, Pa., may not seem like the most likely place to look for the future. But it does offer a glimpse of a possible outcome for in-store shopping.

title: JUDGE IN MOSCOW CONVICTS AMERICAN ON SPYING CHARGES
description: A Moscow judge today handed down the maximum sentence of 20 years at hard labor against a former American naval intelligence officer, Edmond Pope, after a seven-week espionage trial behind closed doors.

title: A Rock Machine With Creaks
description: Perhaps one day the late 1980's to early 90's will be recalled as watershed years for rock 'n' roll, as a time as nostalgically redolent of greatness to future generations as the late 60's is now.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The end of Diller's elusive dream for USA Networks.
description: AFTER two years of trying to program its 12 television stations with distinctively local formats, USA Networks Inc. said this week that it was putting the stations up for sale or seeking a joint venture for them.

title: Big Merger In Net Access For Europe
description: With Europe's many Internet service providers scrambling to consolidate, the Wanadoo unit of France Telecom said today that it had agreed to acquire Britain's largest provider, Freeserve, in an all-stock deal valued at $2.37 billion.

title: Sorry for Your Loss, But Not That Sorry
description: AFTER Annie Scully's husband died of a heart attack last January, she received hundreds of sympathy cards and notes in the mail -- and three sympathy cards via e-mail.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Lawmakers to Try Philippine President on Impeachment Charges
description: After two months of sensational accusations, seamy disclosures and steadfast denials, President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines is finally getting his day in court.

title: NORDSTROM LAYING OFF 35 PEOPLE AND CUTTING 2 CATALOGS
description: Nordstrom, the operator of department stores, said yesterday that its Nordstrom.com unit was laying off 35 people in Seattle as it reduces the number of catalogs it publishes to two from four. The Internet unit has 1,000 employees, a company spokeswoman said. Nordstrom and Nordstrom.com are based in Seattle. Nordstrom.com said it would continue to publish only the ''Lifestyle'' and ''Clothes for Life'' catalogs. ''We were mailing our customers too many catalogs,'' Nordstrom.com's chief executive, Dan Nordstrom, said in a statement.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 21 about repairing ruptured membranes in pregnancy misspelled the given name of a patient treated at New York University Medical Center. She is Lori Melzak-Klein, not Laurie.

title: Fearing Bush Will Win, Groups Plan Pollution Suits
description: Saying it was increasingly likely that Gov. George W. Bush would be the next president, a number of leading environmentalists have enlisted trial lawyers in a strategy to circumvent what they predicted would be the antienvironmental spirit of a new Bush administration.

title: Low Turnout Kills Proposal For Strong Mayor in Hartford
description: In the end, Tuesday's citywide referendum on whether to change Hartford's government to a strong-mayor system did not fail for lack of a winning margin. It died of an overdose of political apathy.

title: When the Losers Go Away, It Can Make a Player's Day
description: Bridge is thriving in the New York metropolitan region. District 24, which is New York City and Long Island, had a bigger original entry in the North American Open Pairs than any other district. This was significant in the final played on Sunday at the Vanderbilt Club in Lake Success on Long Island, because the numbers determined that the top three qualifiers in Flight A, rather than the usual two, earned an expense-paid trip to the national finals in Kansas City, Mo., in March.

title: Difficult Job For Jury: Ignore Fact Victim Died
description: From the start, the trial of five Orange, N.J., police officers has hinged on a fine legal distinction: the defendants are charged with beating and pepper spraying a suspect who later died in custody, but not with the death itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, BENJAMIN
description: WEXLER - Benjamin. Beloved husband for sixty-three years of Ruth, devoted father of Janet, Ted and Sara, adored grandfather of Evan, Melissa, Lauren and Ari, precious great-grandfather of Melanie & Jordan. Service, Parkside, Kings Plaza, Brooklyn, 12/8, 10AM.

title: 2 Pro-Democracy Party Leaders Given Prison Sentences in China
description: Two years after a crackdown began on a short-lived pro-democracy party, two more of its leaders were sentenced to prison today, bringing the number of party members imprisoned to at least 30.

title: A Determined Rocker Takes On Broadway
description: STRIPPED down to the bare essentials -- tattoos and a tiger-stripe bikini thong -- between costume changes for a publicity shoot at the Circle in the Square Theater, Joan M. Jett seems less formidable than the sneering, snarling bad-girl-of-rock reputation that preceded her to Broadway. Her speaking voice is a tired contralto, and beneath a rainbow of lid-to-brow stage makeup, her left eye is flecked with blood: she spent the morning at the hospital having a piece of theater grit extracted by her favorite physician, the one she entrusts with her vocal cords.

title: AMAZON TO OFFER CONSUMER REPORTS
description: Amazon.com Inc. said it had reached an agreement with Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, to distribute product reports and advice to Amazon.com customers. Terms were not disclosed. Amazon.com will offer free product summaries in relevant areas throughout its Web site, with full information to be available early next year on a pay-per-view basis, the companies said.

title: 101 Rabbis Call for Sharing Temple Mount
description: More than 100 American rabbis have issued a statement saying that there is no religious reason to require exclusive Jewish sovereignty over the Temple Mount, the massive stone plateau in Jerusalem, considered holy by both Jews and Muslims, that has been at the center of the recent violence in the Middle East.

title: CHINA TO PERMIT BANK AUDITS
description: Reversing past policy, the Chinese government said it would allow the Big Five international accounting firms to audit its state-owned banks. Arthur Andersen, PricewaterhouseCoopers, KPMG International, Ernst & Young and Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu are on a new list of 68 firms permitted to audit institutions like the Bank of China, which are preparing to list their shares overseas early in 2001. Craig Smith

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSEL, ROSA
description: PRESSEL - Rosa. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: One for Road: Fassel Creates An Away Mood
description: Jim Fassel has muzzled his assistant coaches, bridled his players and brazenly made predictions. Next up for the Giants' coach: weekend getaway consultant.

title: I.B.M. IN ALLIANCE WITH INFINEON
description: I.B.M. and Infineon, the former semiconductor division of Siemens of Germany, plan to announce today a partnership to hasten development and commercial production of magnetic random access memory chips. Such magnetic devices, known as MRAM, have a potential combination of speed, low cost and power efficiency far superior to current memory chip designs. I.B.M. said its new goal for commercialization was 2004. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Essay; Al Gore Agonistes
description: In ''vacating'' nullifying -- the Florida Supreme Court's decision to change election law by extending the recount deadline, the U.S. Supreme Court followed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's advice to tell the state jurists to ''clarify'' their reasoning.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about proposed remedies for California's energy problems referred incorrectly to a 1988 action by the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, a group that is now drafting an initiative on electricity. The 1988 effort, a voter initiative to reduce automobile insurance rates, was approved, not rejected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANSOHOFF, BABETTE
description: RANSOHOFF-Babette, Age 96 in Stamford, CT. on November 25, 2000. Former Republican National Committeewoman, she was active in Republican politics for over 60 years, having managed numerous congressional, senatorial and gubernatorial campaigns as well as chairing President Eisenhower's campaigns in Fairfield County. Widow of Arthur Ransohoff, sister of Henry Strauss of Noroton, CT., mother of Martin, a motion picture producer, and Jack, a nuclear engineer, 10 grandchildren and 22 great grandchildren. Her daughter, Barbara Burnett, who predeceased her, was wife of the former president of Washington and Jefferson University in Pennsylvania. Active in golf Mrs. Ransohoff won the New Orleans Women's championship in her thirties and the Stamford, CT. women's championship when she was in her late sixties.

title: SWISS LICENSE AUCTION COMPLETED
description: After a three-week delay, the Swiss government permitted its auction of four high-speed mobile phone licenses to proceed with only four bidders, under rules essentially ensuring that each would win one license. Swisscom; Team 3G, a group led by Telefonica of Spain; and dSpeed, a pair of companies controlled by Tele Danmark, will pay the minimum bid amount, and Orange Communications will pay slightly more. The auction raised only 205 million francs ($120 million); the government had hoped to reap 15 to 30 times that.

title: IBP to Discuss Takeover With Tyson
description: IBP Inc., the nation's biggest meatpacker, said yesterday that it would begin talks with Tyson Foods on its $2.8 billion cash-and-stock takeover offer.

title: Why Jazz Books Never Die
description: Being popular is not always really important, nor does not being popular really count very much a lot of the time. It's simply that some things inspire such passions among their followers, no matter how relatively small their number, that publishers become caught up in the subject and inundate the marketplace with books about it. And even make money. Jazz is such a delicacy.

title: Nelson Stays Upbeat In the Face of Cancer
description: One day after learning that he had prostate cancer, an upbeat Don Nelson stood oncourt tonight, directing his Mavericks through a pregame shoot-around without a hint of anxiety.

title: Exploring the Depths That Will Live in Infamy
description: The waters around Pearl Harbor are littered with ships and planes that were destroyed during the Japanese attack on the Hawaiian island of Oahu on Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORIN, ROSE
description: GORIN-Rose. Deceased December 7, 1961. In loving memory forever. Devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Margaret, Irene, Leo, Mark, Kathy, Alex, Destiny Rose.

title: CALENDAR
description: Historic New York

title: Tales With Rivers of Blood and Freshets of Freud
description: DR. DEATH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, FELICE (NEE REICH)
description: LERNER-Felice (nee Reich), on December 6, 2000. Beloved mother of Harvey (Aileen) and Maggie Lerner. Cherished daughter of Adeline and the late Meyer Reich. Devoted and beloved sister of Dorothy (David) Goldberg. Adored grandmother of Zachary, Margot and Jordan. Loving aunt. Services Friday, December 8th, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKENS, EMILY
description: WILKENS-Emily. The Trustees, administration, faculty and staff of the Fashion Institute of Technology acknowledge with sadness the death of Emily Wilkens, Trustee Emerita of FIT's board. Her contributions to the growth and development of FIT will always be appreciated. We extend sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Dr. Joyce F. Brown, President Edwin Goodman, Chairman

title: Snapshots On Your Television
description: THE week before we were married, my fiancee and I had what sounded like a great idea: After scanning photos from every phase of our lives, we would use the computer to create a slide show. We'd play it on a TV at the wedding reception so our guests would have something to watch as they munched carrot sticks and waited for the real party to begin.

title: West Wayne Is Named Lead Agency of Saks
description: Saks Inc. said yesterday that it had named West Wayne in Atlanta as agency of record, effective on Jan. 1, for its department store group, which includes 253 stores in 24 states operating under names like Carson Pirie Scott, Herberger's, Parisian, Proffitt's and Younkers. Billings were estimated at $35 million.

title: Bush's View Shifting To Prospect of Leading
description: He lost the popular vote, and if he assumes the presidency, he will do so with the thinnest of edges in the Electoral College.

title: U.S. Accord Being Sought On U.N. Dues And on Court
description: With less than two days to go at a meeting to put finishing touches on the International Criminal Court, a group of nations friendly to the United States is scrambling, with diminishing confidence, to strike a deal that would let the Clinton administration sign on to the tribunal.

title: CIRCUIT CITY SAYS QUARTERLY LOSS WILL BE LARGER
description: The Circuit City Group, the electronics retailer, said yesterday that it expected to report a loss for the quarter that ended Nov. 30 that will be about four times what analysts had forecast. Stiff price competition and costs and lost sales related to store remodeling caused the change, the company said. The company's stock slumped $3, or 24 percent, to close at $9.75. Circuit City said it expected a loss of 31 cents to 33 cents for the quarter, the third of its fiscal year; analysts had forecast a loss of 8 cents a share. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 10 percent in the quarter, while those of the company's main competitor, Best Buy, posted a 5.9 percent increase.

title: U.S. Looking at SmithKline Effort to Block Generic Drug
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether SmithKline Beecham, the British drug company, has engaged in illegal trade practices by keeping competitors from selling generic, lower-cost versions of Paxil, its popular antidepressant, according to court papers.

title: Glamour Was a Way Of Life
description: A DRINK, a cigarette and a well-mannered dog seem to be the only props required for the society portraits in the photographer Slim Aarons's 1974 book, ''A Wonderful Time: An Intimate Portrait of the Good Life.'' The private islands in the Bahamas, the Newport manses, the Palm Beach polo ponies and Gob elin tapestries are taken for granted by photographer and subject alike.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EMELOCK, HERMAN
description: EMELOCK-Herman. December 7, 1998. I miss you daily. Your care, your love and our wonderful life together. You were absolutely remarkable and unique, the way you conducted your life, until the very last day. Your loving wife, Ana.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about Mario Giacomelli, an Italian photographer, misstated his age. As the article said, he was 75, not 91.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: The Greenspan Effect
description: Since he started boosting interest rates in May 1999, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has singlehandedly tried to cool off an economy and stock market that he viewed as overheated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULHERN, MARY ELIZABETH FURER
description: MULHERN-Mary Elizabeth Furer. Died on December 5, 2000. Mary was born and raised in Brooklyn, married in 1966, had a daughter Gannon in 1976 and became a Senior Vice President of First Union Corp., in 1996. She was diagnosed with stage four ovarian cancer in December 1993. Mary was a woman of striking beauty and vibrant personality who played many roles in her life and was an inspiration to her colleagues, friends and family. She leaves her mother, Mary Furer, her husband Tom, her daughter Gannon, sister Penny, Karen and Sheila, and brothers Bill, Tom, Mike and Joe. A memorial service will be held in mid-January, place and time to be announced. Contributions in her memory can be made to Dr. Dan Smith, The Spirit of Care Foundation, NY Presbyterian Hospital, 161 Fort Washington Ave., New York, NY 10032.

title: Economic Scene; A study shows committees can be more than the sum of their members.
description: WHEN Alan Blinder returned to academia from his post as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, he was convinced that the committee nature of the Fed made it slow to recognize and respond to changes in the economy. There was no research on the topic. So he and a Princeton University colleague, John Morgan, conducted an experiment to test whether committees performed worse than individuals.

title: Leetch's Assists Lift Rangers To Victory
description: During the Rangers' recent three-game losing streak, Brian Leetch seemed to go into a brief slump, too. The attacking defenseman, off to a dynamic start this season, had only one point in that span and had a plus-minus ratio of minus 3.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NATURAL GAS BILL DECREASE
description: With sharp increases expected this winter in the cost of natural gas, Consolidated Edison will reduce its delivery charge from this month until the end of March, the New York State Public Service Commission said. The reductions are prescribed in an interim rate plan that the commission adopted last week. Con Ed said that the delivery charges would be 16 percent lower for a typical residential customer and 19 percent lower for a typical commercial customer. Joseph P. Fried

title: Football at Swarthmore
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Finds Police Abuse Unpunished
description: More than 80 substantiated complaints of police abuse were lost and dozens of officers went unpunished because of serious mismanagement at the Civilian Complaint Review Board, according to a city report released yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Sunday about a vote by the Charlotte-Mecklenburg County school board in North Carolina to continue considering race in assigning students referred incorrectly to a court ruling. A federal appeals court overturned a district court ruling that would have ended desegregation on the ground that the district had achieved integration. The lower court did not find that segregation continued in student assignments, school locations and transportation policies.

title: Because the Operative Word Is Opulent, a Designer Reaches for Red
description: For some people, there is no such thing as too much. They simply must perch on red velvet stools while they sip brandy and rub their pointy Prada-clad toes against a red leather bar, or drink tea from the safe confines of a red velvet chair while a chandelier twinkles overhead. For them, the Villard Bar and Lounge at the New York Palace Hotel at 455 Madison Avenue (51st Street) will be just right. When the bar, below left, and tea lounge, below right, open in February, opulence will be everything, said Pierre Court of Manhattan, who designed the two rooms and a second lounge, the lavender Empire Room. The mahogany bar will be wrapped in red leather and studded with brass lions' heads. Upstairs, the tea lounge will have burgundy velvet walls and armchairs. ''It is Victorian or Napoleon III, depending on which side of the channel you're on,'' Mr. Court said.

title: A Phone for the Age Of Illumination
description: For the over-40 set (you know who you are, the ones who can't read a menu in dim light), here comes the Panasonic Big Buttons cordless phone, left. It has buttons that light up and are considerably bigger than those on a standard cordless phone. And if your memory is going as well, this new version of the Panasonic Big Buttons has a handset locator. It's $99.95 at Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, (212) 821-9200, or www.thelighthousecatalog.com.

title: The New Nordics: Burning the Forest and Breaking the Ice
description: SARI ANTTONEN, 34, a striking brunette from Finland, was sitting onstage at the new Scandinavia House in New York last month, as part of a panel on Nordic design, complaining about Alvar Aalto: Finland's most famous export.

title: In America; Keep Them Out!
description: The tactics have changed, but the goal remains depressingly the same: Keep the coloreds, the blacks, the African-Americans -- whatever they're called in the particular instance -- keep them out of the voting booths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRAY, PORTER
description: McCRAY-Porter. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and members of its International Council are deeply saddened by the passing of Porter McCray, at age 92, founding director of the Museum's International Program and an honorary member of the International Council. During Porter's distinguished career, he was the Museum's director of circulating exhibitions in the United States from 1947-50 and director of circulating exhibitions for both international and domestic programs from 1952-61. He became director of the JDR 3rd Fund, where he remained until his retirement in 1975. Porter's contributions to the field of international culture and exchange were legendary and strongly felt throughout the world. His numerous involvements included such organizations as the Japan Society, the Asian Cultural Council, the Byrd Hoffman Foundation, the Archives of American Art, the International Council of Museums, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Museum of African Art in Washington D.C., and the U.S. Department of State, all of which were deeply affected by his abiding commitment to them. We send our profound sympathy to his sister, Frances Jacob, and to his grandniece, Frances Blades. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Ringling Brothers, What's Old Is New Again
description: From 1919 until 1956, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus performed primarily in tents. Then the tents were deemed too expensive to maintain, raise and move, and the circus began performing only in arenas. In the 70's, the Big Apple Circus proved tents were viable, even in New York City, and along came other one-ring tent shows (Cirque du Soleil, Zingaro) to prove it. So it seemed time for Ringling Brothers, too, to get back under canvas. This year it has raised a new circus tent in Bryant Park. Todd Dalland, a founder of FTL Happold of Manhattan, the tent's designers, said his company ''eliminated the side poles, the guy ropes and the stakes.'' Instead, the tent, filled with red plush velvet seats, is supported by a metal scaffolding system. The show, ''Barnum's Kaleidoscape,'' runs through Dec. 31.

Wife of the late Henry, cherished mother of Marcia Frifield & Sylvia Sapir, beloved mother-inlaw of Don Frifield and Dr. Paul E. title: Settlement In Works For Wolves Executives
description: A decision is expected this week that will end one of the most embarrassing and costly incidents in National Basketball Association history. Glen Taylor, the owner of the Minnesota Timberwolves, has acknowledged that he expects to be suspended by the league for his role in a deal with then-Minnesota forward Joe Smith that violated salary-cap rules.

description: A City Council committee considering a bill that would prohibit banks from charging noncustomers for using their automated teller machines heard testimony yesterday from residents who called the fees an unfair burden on people in poor neighborhoods.

title: Corrections

The sound of my father's drill in the basement, a signal that my brother's hand-me-down bindings were being transferred to my first pair of skis. The smell of P-tex, the waxy, candle-like stick used to patch gouged ski bottoms. And then, after rubbing my eyes from a nap on the drive of that first ski trip, seeing -- for the first time -- that there was no horizon in the sky.

description: Senior commanders at the Army Corps of Engineers manipulated an economic analysis to justify the proposed construction of a $1 billion system of locks along the Mississippi and Illinois Rivers, according to a sharply critical report released today.

description: THERE are places, like Europe and Japan, where short text messages sent by cell phone are as common as e-mail. Students use them to send notes in class. Business people zap messages back and forth during meetings. The unattached use them to scout for dates.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DOUBLECLICK EXECUTIVE LEAVES
description: A key executive at DoubleClick, Wenda Harris Millard, has left the company to head Ziff-Davis Media's Internet subsidiary. Ms. Millard was the executive vice president at DoubleClick, which is based in New York. She oversaw its 400-person advertising sales operation and managed strategic relationships with Web publishers. In her new post, she will serve as the president of Ziff-Davis Internet, and will serve as the chief Internet officer of Ziff-Davis, a publishing company. Ms. Millard was lured to Ziff-Davis by James D. Dunning Jr., its chairman and chief executive officer, with whom she worked when she was the president and group publisher at SRDS, a leading provider of media and marketing information. Jayson Blair

description: There would seem to be every reason for the marriage between David Cone and the Yankees to continue. They need another starter to complete their five-man rotation, the coaching staff knows him, and Cone has been a respected member of the team for six years.

title: Children Are Off but Their Teachers Are at School, Training
description: Sheila Rothenberg will be checking up on her friend's children today. They will be locked in their apartment from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. playing video games and watching television. It's not that her friend is a bad mother. It's just that she cannot take her children to work and students don't have school today, even though their teachers do.

title: Who Decides? The Question Is Bedeviling Europe Again
description: The last time European Union leaders met to discuss how to restructure the union's decision-making institutions, a furious dinner table quarrel broke out. In the end, President Jacques Chirac played down the problems, saying ''real progress'' had been made toward agreement.

title: Dow Jones Lowers Its Forecast For Earnings in This Quarter
description: A fourth-quarter dip in financial advertising, which ebbed along with the market for initial public offerings, has cut into expected revenue at Dow Jones & Company's flagship newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, prompting the company to lower its fourth-quarter earnings forecast by 6 percent to nearly 10 percent.

title: Metro Business Briefing; UTILITY MERGER APPROVED
description: Consolidated Edison won conditional approval from New Hampshire regulators yesterday for the $7.49 billion purchase of Northeast Utilities, New England's largest utility. Among the requirements that the regulators placed on Con Ed were that the buyout would save consumers at least $74.8 million and that $12.5 million in severance packages would not be charged to consumers. Connecticut regulators have approved the merger but have ordered conditions that Con Ed has said could prevent it from being completed. The Connecticut attorney general and consumer counsel are suing to block the merger. New York regulators have approved it.

title: Plastics Company to Pay $782,000 in Sex Discrimination Case
description: A Syracuse-area plastics manufacturer has agreed to pay current and former female workers $782,000 to settle sex discrimination charges, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said yesterday.

title: DEL WEBB TO USE JOINT VENTURES TO REDUCE BORROWING
description: Fresh from fending off dissident shareholders and an attempted hostile takeover, the Del Webb Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its indebtedness by forming joint ventures with partners like home builders. The company, based in Phoenix, builds retirement communities. It has been criticized for borrowing too much to finance land purchases. It said it would bring in partners to buy land and build future projects, concentrate more on smaller ''country club'' projects where margins are highest, and consider nonretirement developments on parcels next to its communities. The company's shares rose 31 cents, to $26.50.

title: Gary Bonasorte Memorial

The speakers are to include the playwright Terrence McNally, the actress Marin Mazzie and the actor Jason Danieley.

title: Provenance and Curatorial Conscience
description: The details of an old painting's provenance -- the history of its ownership -- can often look like a verbal maze, a shorthand catalogue of terse allusions to auctions, exhibitions, reproductions and the lives of former owners. Provenance is just the kind of thing that only museum curators and art historians concern themselves with, because only they are interested in the minutiae of receipts and sales records that make up the economic background of the history of art. For the most part, the details of the provenance of the works in museum collections have remained invisible to the public just as the administrative records of the museum remain invisible.

title: The Last Act Begins
description: With today's arguments before the Florida Supreme Court, the battle of the Florida ballots is headed for a denouement, and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush ought to prepare themselves and the nation for the belated identification of the next president. Though the legal and political hourglass appears to be running out for Mr. Gore, there is still a possibility for yet another reversal of fortune. Whatever the result of the final flurry of court decisions, both candidates should accept the rulings of the Florida Supreme Court as the last word on the election.

description: Despite flagging support for his peace efforts, President Andres Pastrana opted today to give the nation's largest rebel group an eight-week extension on the demilitarized zone that the government ceded to the rebels two years ago.

description: Just as winter tightens an icy grip on much of the United States, the federal government warned yesterday that consumers can expect to pay about 50 percent more than a year ago to heat their homes with natural gas.

title: INQUIRY ON DAIMLER RAIL SALE
description: The European Commission has begun an antitrust investigation of the proposed sale of DaimlerChrysler's Adtranz railroad equipment unit to Bombardier, the Canadian transportation equipment conglomerate. The commission said the deal raised serious competition concerns in the markets for regional trains, trolleys and trams in Germany, Austria, France and Sweden. A final ruling is expected in April. Paul Meller

title: A Judicial Test of Press Freedoms
description: In a string of decisions protecting freedom of the press, the United States Supreme Court has often stepped in to block government efforts to punish disclosure of truthful, lawfully obtained information of public significance. A major case heard this week by the court challenges the justices not to let a legitimate concern for privacy rights override the threat to First Amendment freedoms posed by an overreaching federal wiretap law.

Jason Ferguson recalls the time he extended his hand to shake a child's hand, only to see the youngster yank his away. Al Groh says playing in Oakland is like encountering Halloween every day.

title: In Ruined Liberia, Its Despoiler Sits Pretty
description: Soon after the sun sets, the road into this capital, which has had no electricity in nearly a decade, disappears into the dark night. The glimmer from candles and oil lamps casts faint shadows of pedestrians moving about in the very center of town, where the few clusters of light come from private generators. There are no traffic lights.

title: HASBRO ISSUES 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS WARNING
description: Hasbro warned yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter would be far below expectations, and that it would break even or lose money for fiscal 2000, because of sluggish sales, especially of trading card products. Analysts had forecast a profit of 23 cents a share. The company, which makes toys and games under brands that include Hasbro, Playskool and Tonka, said it would sell its Hasbro Interactive and Games.com units to Infogrames Entertainment of France for $100 million, almost all in stock.

title: On Union Square, a Sweeping Staircase With a Ballroom to Match
description: ''I'm developing a staircase fetish,'' said David Rockwell, an architect who likes designing high-drama staircases like the one above. It's at the W New York Union Square hotel, which opened last week. (Other slightly vertiginous stairs by Mr. Rockwell are at Ruby Foo's and Rosa Mexicano, both on the Upper West Side.) His firm, the Rockwell Group, worked with the architects Brennan Beer Gorman in renovating the former Guardian Life Building, a 1911 landmark, into the W. The hotel's mahogany and steel staircase is bordered by patches of wheat grass, above right, a nod to nearby Union Square Park. The ballroom's coffered ceilings, top right, are echoed by the carpet's pattern. Olives, the hotel's restaurant, has gossamer lace patchwork curtains. The hotel is at 201 Park Avenue South (17th Street); rooms start at $319. Phone: (212) 253-9119.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNEN, BRUCE P.
description: DENNEN-Bruce P. Beloved father, died suddenly December 3. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and former Trustee, Mr. Dennen earned a BA/Yale and a MBA/NYU. He served as a Director of The Susan Fund, an organization assisting youth diagnosed with cancer to pursue higher education. Mr. Dennen was also a Member of the Education and Public Relations Committee of the Dept. of Social Services of Greenwich, CT and a member of Christ Church. He was predeceased by his twin brother Robert and is survived by his two children, Ivey and Scott, and four nieces. A service will be held at 2:30PM, Saturday, December 9, at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the memory of Bruce Dennen to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 381 Park Avenue South, New York NY 10016; The Susan Fund, 8 Hilly Field Lane, Westport, CT. 06880; or Alumni Office-Memorial Donations, Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N.H. 03833.

title: Critic's Notebook: Looking for the Real John Lennon; 20 Years Later, Both the Man and the Myth Remain Vulnerable
description: As they have done with ritual devotion every Dec. 8 for 20 years, admirers of John Lennon will find ways to pass by the Dakota tomorrow and perhaps linger for a moment. Lennon lived in that stately building at the corner of 72nd Street and Central Park West (his widow, Yoko Ono, still does), and it was in its entranceway that he was shot to death on Dec. 8, 1980, as he returned from a recording session at nearly 11 p.m.

title: BABYGEAR CLOSES ITS DOORS
description: Babygear.com, an Internet retailer of discount baby products, has closed. The company, which said it had filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy protection, becomes one of the latest additions to a growing list of electronic retailers that have foundered. A message on its Web site early yesterday said Babygear was ''unable to take orders, ship orders or issue credits'' and added, ''Any further matters will be handled by the court.'' Babygear raised more than $30 million of initial funding, and hired the singer Marie Osmond as a spokeswoman. IVillage, the media Web site for women, sold its e-commerce division, iBaby, to Babygear in July; iVillage took an equity stake in the company. Babygear, which had developed a reputation for poor customer service, posted this message on its site: ''For credit on items that you did not receive, please contact your credit card company directly to dispute any charges.''

title: The Neediest Cases; Holidays Come to an End, But Needs of Poor Stay On
description: After last year's Neediest Cases annual appeal ended in March, gifts to the fund tapered off, as they do every year.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS RETRENCHES
description: In an effort to reverse annual losses of $:100 million ($143 million) in its operations at Gatwick Airport, southeast of London, British Airways said it would scrap half the long-distance flights it operates there, move 10 international routes to its main hub at Heathrow Airport and concentrate its remaining Gatwick operations in a single structure. About 1,000 jobs will be eliminated. The airline said it would use Gatwick only for short-distance flights to European cities. Suzanne Kapner

He is mourned by his many friends on both sides of the Atlantic and by his associates and students at Columbia University, Graduate Center CUNY, Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, University of California at Berkeley, and the Montefiore Hospital. Memorial services will be held at a later date.

title: Microsoft Media Player Even Throws In a Snowman
description: Microsoft released a mini-upgrade of its Windows Media Player 7 this week that includes some holiday-theme material. The most practical inclusion is a software tool for converting MP3 audio files to Windows Media Audio format. Because the Windows Media music format is much more compact than MP3, Microsoft says, the conversion can allows users to double the amount of music stored on their hard drives. But not all portable music players support Microsoft's format.

title: RIVAL TAKES ON NETSCAPE AND EXPLORER
description: In a move to grab market share from Microsoft's Internet Explorer and America Online's Netscape, the two leading Internet browsers, Opera Software has released a free version of its latest browser, Opera 5.0. About 1.5 million users have paid $39.95 for the Opera browser, known for its speed and full array of features despite its small two-megabyte size. The free version will carry banner advertising. Jon von Tetzchner, chief executive of Opera Software, which is based in Oslo, said the company would work with smaller Internet service providers who view themselves as competing with the Microsoft Network and America Online. ''Releasing a free version of Opera is opening doors for us to get distribution deals with smaller I.S.P.'s and portals,'' he said. Mr. Von Tetzchner said Opera Software was working with wireless manufacturers to offer a version of the free browser on hand-held devices. Catherine Greenman

description: Colin Cowdrey, one of the greatest batsmen in the history of cricket and an important administrator of the sport, died Tuesday at his home in Angmering, West Sussex, England.

title: A Well-Bred Lounger for Reading or Lolling About
description: Twenty years after he introduced the multicolored Wink chair, a reclining lounger that has become a 20th-century design classic, Toshiyuki Kita has returned with a recliner called Dodo. Even though Dodo has more bells and whistles than its predecessor, its mechanism is still only two simple levers. One operates a pneumatic spring that easily adjusts the chair's tilt. The other adjusts the footrest. Completely reclined, the chair feels like a first-class airplane seat (not bad if you are used to sitting in economy). Upright, it is supportive and comfortable for reading. The chair is available in fabric (starting at $2,245) and in leather (from $3,090). It swivels, perhaps a bit too easily, on a nickle-plated base. Dodo and other new chair designs from Mr. Kita are at Cassina, 155 East 56th Street (closed Saturday and Sunday), (212) 245-2121. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MELISSA HUNT CLARK
description: FREEMAN-Melissa Hunt Clark. Age 55, of 215 East Orange Street, Lancaster, formerly of Manhasset, NY, died Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital after a lengthy illness. She was the former wife of James L. Freeman. Born in Schenectady, NY to the late Jack Andrew Clark and Justine Hunt Clark of Sarasota, FL. Mrs. Freeman was a homemaker, mother, and wife. Mrs. Freeman was an artist, enjoyed needlepoint, reading, gardening, and was a magic maker. Throughout her life she traveled extensively worldwide. She served on the Board of Directors & head of the Annual Giving for Greenvale School in Glen Head, New York. Survivors include two daughters, Rebecca Hunt Freeman of Lancaster, and Hadley Colburn, wife of Gary Lehrman of New York City, son, James Van Rensselaer Hunt Freeman of Baltimore, MD., brother, Peter C. husband of Carol L. Clark of Lancaster. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service from St. James Episcopal Church, corner of N. Duke and Orange Streets, Lancaster on Saturday at 2:00 PM with Rev. Canon Peter Eaton officiating. Friends may call at the church, Saturday at 1:00 PM until the time of the service. If desired memorials may be sent to the Lancaster Museum of Art, 135 N. Lime Street, Lancaster, PA. 17602 or to the University of PA. Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, C/O Melissa Freeman Memorial Fund, Office of the Director, 33rd & Spruce St., Philadelphia, PA. 19104-6324. Condolences and Correspondences may be directed to the family at 215 E. Orange St., Lancaster, PA. 17602.

Memorial service at the Brick Church Chapel, 91st and Park, NYC on Friday, December 8 at 3PM. We, your family and friends will love you and miss you, but will always remember YOU.

title: No Mistaking This Firehouse For a Supermarket
description: The new Morris Heights firehouse in the Bronx, above, dresses the part. Glass bricks in the shape of a 55-foot-long hook and ladder truck, outlined in red and buff concrete blocks, allow a glimpse inside at a real fire truck. At night, the glass bricks glow from within. The firehouse, for Engine Company 75, Ladder Company 33, Battalion 19, is the first built in the city since 1984. ''It had to be community-friendly, because firehouses are one of the great things for neighborhood kids, when the fire truck goes clanging out,'' said Richard Dattner of Manhattan, the building's architect. The corner tower is a reference to the towers where fire-spotters were stationed before the invention of the telephone and electric fire alarms.

title: Sports of The Times; A Fullback,But Much, Much More
description: BEFORE the Jets went out for practice yesterday, Richie Anderson sat on a stool in front of his locker and went over all the duties he was required to perform as a Jets running back. First and foremost, he said, he lined up in the backfield and played the traditional role, providing lead blocks for Curtis Martin. He also lined up in the slot and ran pass routes, or split out like a flanker and took defensive backs deep, often making a catch in traffic to keep drives alive.

title: 29 More U.S. Deaths Linked to Firestone Tires
description: Government investigators have received complaints linking 29 more deaths to the failures of Firestone tires, including 4 people killed since the company announced a huge recall four months ago, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: MUSICIANS' LAWSUIT DISMISSED
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit filed against MP3.com and several major record labels by oldies music performers who claimed their recordings could not be distributed over the Internet without their permission. The Coasters, the Original Drifters, the Main Ingredient and the Chambers Brothers, who made recordings mostly in the 1950's and 60's, claimed their contracts with the labels only covered rights to vinyl records and tapes. They sought court-ordered control over digitization of their recordings. In dismissing the case, a federal judge in Manhattan found that the musicians had given up rights when they signed contracts with the labels.

title: Researchers Trying to Find Ways to Turn Microchips Into Lasers
description: WHATEVER their many talents, silicon microchips aren't very bright. That is, they can't produce significant amounts of light, certainly not enough to act as tiny lasers. But because photons -- the basic units of light -- make electrons seem relatively sluggish, a silicon chip that could spit out laser light is the stuff of dreams for engineers looking for ever faster computer chips.

description: President Clinton, in an interview to be published today in Rolling Stone magazine, speaks of two failures by his administration -- its policy on gays in the military and efforts to end disparities in drug sentences.

title: Have My Answering Machine Call Your Answering Machine
description: People have so many phone numbers these days that it's more likely that you'll get voice mail when you call someone rather than an actual person. Now a new service called SoundBite, which lets you record voice messages to be sent to other people, is creating new possibilities for people who want to communicate via phone without ever speaking to one another.

title: POLYCOM BUYS ISRAELI EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Polycom Inc., a California-based audio and video-conferencing equipment manufacturer, said it had agreed to acquire Accord Networks Ltd., an Israel-based maker of Internet networking products, for about $339 million in stock. The deal will allow Polycom to develop video conferencing systems that take advantage of the Internet and faster bandwidth. Under the terms of the deal, Polycom will pay Accord shareholders 0.3065 share -- worth $14.25 -- an Accord share. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: NEWSLETTER SAYS BAYER HAS HIRED STRATEGIC ADVISERS
description: A German investment newsletter, Platow Brief, reported yesterday that Bayer A.G., fearing that it may soon be confronted with a hostile takeover bid, has hired Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Bank to devise defense strategies. The newsletter did not cite any source for its report, and Bayer, Germany's biggest drug maker, declined to comment on it. Bayer stock closed down 0.20 euro at 53.85 euros in Frankfurt. Bayer's American depository receipts rose $2.25, to $48.50, in New York. Credit Suisse First Boston has advised Bayer on several large acquisitions this year.

title: What Can Be Done to Unify The Nation?
CUTBACKS AT ANOTHER CONSULTANT
description: The Viant Corporation became the latest e-commerce consulting company to announce it would revamp its business and eliminate jobs. Viant said it would lay off 125 employees -- 17 percent of its work force -- and close its Dallas office. The company, based in Boston, said the transition would cost $5 million to $7 million, but said the cuts would save $18 million in 2001. In recent weeks, at least five other e-commerce consulting companies have announced layoffs and restructurings in light of the sharp pullback in spending for Internet consulting services by start-up companies and corporations. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: A Spy Conviction in Moscow
description: The conviction in Moscow of an American businessman on espionage charges and the severe sentence imposed on him raise troubling questions about the quality of justice in Russian courts. The secrecy of the proceedings against the American, Edmond Pope, a former naval intelligence officer, makes it impossible to evaluate the evidence against him. But there are ample grounds for concern, and Mr. Pope's deteriorating health makes it imperative that a means be quickly found to secure his release on humanitarian grounds.

title: Holiday Albums; Albums Wishing You a Merry With a Ha-Ha and a Ho-Ho-Ho
description: THE annual flood of holiday albums has poured onto record-store shelves. Stars are ready to personalize the old songs or put a wintertime twist on their usual styles; unknowns hope familiar material will help them find new listeners. Pious or raunchy, ethnic or homogenized, blue or sentimental, unabashedly corny or determinedly hip, they all try to pack holiday feelings into cozy commodities. At the same time the holidays also bring out music packages that won't be obsolete on Dec. 26: compilations, greatest-hits albums and reissued albums. Below, the rock and jazz critics of The Times survey the seasonal bounty. (Individual CD's range from $11.97 to $28.97; two-CD sets range from $19.97 to $31.97.)

title: Europeans, and Protesters, Meet on the Riviera
description: As protesters clashed violently with the police in the streets, European Union leaders began a crucial three-day summit meeting today by promising to come up with a new decision-making structure that would allow them to accept new countries as members.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: If Pipa was intended to mop up the overflow from Chicama, the plan isn't working. Instead of one packed restaurant, ABC Carpet and Home now has two. Blame Douglas Rodriguez. When he cooks, a crowd gathers. Pipa, a Spanish word meaning ''great time,'' has modest ambitions. It's a tapas bar with little tables, little portions and a big wine list. The idea is to stop in and grab a seat and a snack. The problem, after 7:30 p.m., is finding a seat. You're more likely to add your name to the waiting list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, ROBERT S.
description: CARR-Robert S., 57, of Stamford, CT, an executive of Citigroup for 19 years, passed away suddenly on December 5. Beloved husband and best friend of Joan. Loving and devoted son of Elsie Peterson Carr and Harry F. Carr of Wilmington, DE. Brother of the late Thomas Carr. Bob was an exceptional man who made a difference in the lives of many. He was quiet, unselfish and faced life with humor and a loving heart which will live on in us forever. Bob really loved his family, his friends, his home, his job and his life with Joan. As a managing director of Citigroup's Audit and Risk Review he was thoughtful, supportive, and one who made things happen. He is a shining example to us all of leadership and in caring for his staff and others. A memorial service will be held at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT Saturday, December 9, at 1:00PM. The family will receive guests at the funeral home on Saturday from 11:30 AM until the time of service. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to The University of New Mexico-Anderson School, Albuquerque, NM 87131 or Stamford Hospital, Shelburne Road, Stamford, CT 06902.

title: Plausible Plan for the Hudson
description: The 10-year battle between the federal government and the General Electric Company over cleaning up the Hudson River reached a major turning point Wednesday when the Environmental Protection Agency ordered the company to spend a half-billion dollars over five years to dredge toxic PCB's embedded in the river bottom north of Albany. The company will fight the plan during the mandatory 60-day comment period that lies ahead, and it is theoretically possible that a new administration in Washington could amend or delay it. But as G.E. must now realize, the dynamics of this long and complicated struggle have now shifted dramatically against it.

title: Rules Sought for Analysts on TV
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is forming rules to require television analysts and money managers to disclose possible conflicts of interest when they recommend stocks on the air.

description: Lou Carnesecca, the former coach at St. John's, will become the first college athlete or coach to have a banner hung in his honor at Madison Square Garden, officials at the arena announced yesterday.

title: Conceptualism, by the Gallon, Covers the Walls
description: I DON'T know what to tell you if you fail to get some kick out of the Sol LeWitt retrospective at the Whitney. Hands down it is the most beautiful exhibition by a living artist in a New York museum in a long time, an antidote to the nonsense on view in several other museums around town, a rebuttal to soreheads saying there's never serious contemporary art around anymore, and also a digestible, brightly colored package just in time for the holidays. The perfect gift for the city that has everything except enough shows like this one.

title: Into the Blur Of Meanings Love Creates

title: DAEWOO OVERSEAS OPTIONS
description: Daewoo Motor is considering selling some overseas assets to its South Korean rival, Hyundai Motor, if General Motors chooses not to acquire them, according to Lee Jong Dae, chairman of Daewoo. Creditors of Daewoo, whose application for bankruptcy protection was approved last week, have been talking with G.M. and Fiat about an acquisition of the entire company, but Mr. Lee said the creditors and the company would consider other approaches if G.M. and Fiat walked away from takeover talks, as Ford Motor did in September.

title: New Serbian Coalition Reaches Agreement on Sharing Power
description: Anticipating a sweeping victory in Serbian parliamentary elections in two weeks, the leaders of an 18-party coalition that toppled Slobodan Milosevic in October have agreed on how they plan to share power in a new government.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Big City column on Tuesday, about proposals to increase competition in Manhattan transit, misstated the name of the university where Daniel B. Klein, an economist who advocates a competitive system, is a professor. It is Santa Clara University. (The University of California at Santa Clara is nonexistent.)

title: Foreign Affairs; The Last Green Mile
description: With the odds increasing every day that George W. Bush will be declared the 43rd president, a couple of things are becoming clear: Bush voters are the likely winners. Gore voters are the likely losers. And all those people who voted for Ralph Nader and the Green Party are the likely really big losers.

title: People
description: Andrew Delbridge was named senior vice president and executive director for account planning at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C., part of MarchFirst, suceeding Leslie Murray, who left. Mr. Delbridge had been chief executive at Publicis Communication, Auckland, New Zealand, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: A New Division At Initiative Media
description: Initiative Media Worldwide in Los Angeles, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is forming a division, Initiative Partners, that will handle media planning and buying services for agencies that want to contract out those functions.

title: Colombian's Peace Pursuit: Part Carrot, Part Stick
description: His peace efforts faltered. Guerrillas stepped up their attacks. A greater number of Colombians clamored for a harder line against rebels, who have waged war for 36 years.

title: BALTIC FERRY BIDS REJECTED
description: Deutsche Bahn, the state-owned railway company, which has been trying to sell assets to stem losses forecast at $2 billion or more annually through 2005, nonetheless rejected offers from two bidders for Scandlines, a ferry company it has owned jointly with the Danish government since 1998. Neither the bidders' names nor other details were announced. Scandlines routes link north Germany with countries around the Baltic.

title: Man vs. Mountain, the Nth Round
description: The director Martin Campbell knows what his competition is for ''Vertical Limit,'' a shallow yet empty action extravaganza set on the notorious Himalayan peak K2. It's the ''Cliffhanger'' trailer, which neatly jettisoned the (heh, heh) plot and shoehorned in every heart-stopping leap and explosion that took place in the blissful, snowcapped setting, where even sub-arctic temperatures couldn't keep Sylvester Stallone from wearing T-shirts. (The trailer is the best picture Renny Harlin ever made.)

title: Mismatched in Every Way but One
description: Sanaa Lathan and Wesley Snipes make one hot couple. She's gorgeous, he's buff, and when the sparks fly between them in ''Disappearing Acts,'' don't be surprised if smoke starts seeping from your television. If this movie, on HBO tomorrow night, could sustain some of those therms when its sultry stars are not in the clinch, it would be remarkable. But it can't, and it isn't. When the hot stuff stops, the film cools down faster than this attenuated metaphor. Brrrrr.

title: SWEDEN TIGHTENS RATES
description: The Riksbank, Sweden's central monetary authority, raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter point, to 4 percent, to keep inflation at bay in anticipation of tax cuts promised for 2001. The move was the first since February and was not likely to be repeated before June, analysts said. As expected, the Bank of England said it would leave interest rates in Britain unchanged, and the Swiss central bank was expected to do the same tomorrow.

His friendship and his wisdom will be sorely missed by countless congregants and the community at large. Funeral services will take place on Friday, December 8 at 10:00 AM at the Westchester Jewish Center. May the Almighty comfort his wife Marly, his dear children Neil, Kenneth, Mark and Shari, and his beloved grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Randy Heller, President Jeffrey Segelman, Rabbi

title: Two Primary Figures Emerge in Bombing of the Cole
description: Yemeni officials have told the Clinton administration that they have identified two key figures in the October bombing of the destroyer Cole, and intelligence officials say they believe that at least one of them is associated with the organization controlled by Osama bin Laden.

title: N.F.L. BIDS SAID TO HEAT UP
description: The National Football League may attract bids that include a record $10 million a year for the rights to become the new producer of its Internet site, the fourth-most- popular among American sports fans, people close to the negotiations said. The league said ESPN.com, America Online, SportsLine, Yahoo and at least three other companies are vying for the rights, more than twice the number of companies that bid for the site in 1998. The three-year, $10 million N.F.L. Internet agreement, under which Walt Disney's ESPN.com splits Web advertising revenue with the league, expires in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRAY, PORTER A.
description: MCCRAY-Porter A. The trustees, staff, fellows, and extended family of the Asian Cultural Council are deeply saddened by the loss of Porter McCray, who for so many years was such an extraordinary colleague, mentor, and friend. Porter was a cultural advisor to members of several generations of the Rockefeller family, and between 1947 and 1961 he developed and directed the domestic and international circulating exhibition programs at The Museum of Modern Art. In 1963 he was appointed founding director of The JDR 3rd Fund (now the Asian Cultural Council), a foundation which was created by John D. Rockefeller 3rd to promote cultural exchanges in the visual and performing arts between Asia and the United States and which Porter led with remarkable vision, dedication, and care. The uniquely effective model of grantmaking that Porter established nearly forty years ago continues to form the basis of our work at the Asian Cultural Council today. Throughout a brilliant professional career in the cultural and philanthropic worlds that spanned more than six decades, Porter was a tireless and enthusiastic champion of many of the most talented artists and arts specialists of our time, and the lives of countless individuals here and abroad have been profoundly touched by his great generosity, encouragement, and advice. An inveterate international traveler and superb connoisseur, Porter will also always be remembered as a true gentleman whose impeccable manners and unfailing good taste set a wonderful example for all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sister Frances Jacob and his grandniece Frances Blades. A memorial service will be held at 4:00 PM on January 23, 2001, at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, NY, NY 10017. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Porter's memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, (1800-ACS-2345). Elizabeth J. McCormack Chairman Richard S. Lanier, President Ralph Samuelson, Director

title: Brazil Still Optimistic on Phone Auctions

description: A volunteer Republican fund-raiser convicted of covering up his role in an alleged campaign corruption plot was sentenced yesterday to five months in prison and five months of home arrest.

title: After D and D, You May Need R and R
description: Before there was the Internet, with its multi-user dungeons (like chat rooms) and virtual identities, there was Dungeons and Dragons, a fantasy role-playing game that first became popular in the mid-1970's among young men who owned every album Yes had ever made and who used sci-fi jargon like ''grok'' in conversation. The game, in which players, led by a designated dungeon master, assume the personas of wizards and warriors, has proved durably popular. And why not? How better to escape the safe tedium of contemporary American youth than to pretend to fight monsters, weave spells, rescue maidens and hunt for treasure?

title: BRAZIL TO HALT LOAN AID
description: Responding to threats of $1.4 billion in trade sanctions from Canada, the Brazilian government said its development bank would stop subsidizing interest rates on loans to Embraer, the aircraft manufacturer. But Canada said Brazil's move was insufficiently different from proposals it rejected before publicly threatening to impose sanctions. The two countries have been at odds since 1996 when the World Trade Organization found that both were illegally subsidizing their aircraft makers in the regional jet market. Canada changed its policies to comply with the organization's orders, but Brazil has not yet done so.

title: AT&T Weighs Selling an Asset
description: The AT&T Corporation is in preliminary talks about selling its 10 percent stake in the Japan Telecom Company to British Telecommunications P.L.C., executives close to the companies said yesterday. All three companies are planning to meet in the next few weeks to discuss a possible deal, the executives said.

title: Encounters, Brief but Fateful

description: Agilent Technologies, a testing and measuring equipment maker that was spun off from Hewlett-Packard in June, agreed yesterday to sell its automation software business to Verano, a closely held software company. Most terms were not disclosed, but the companies said Agilent would take an equity position in Verano in partial payment for the automation unit. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLORY, CLIFFORD DAY, JR.
description: MALLORY-Clifford Day, Jr. The Trustees and Staff of Mystic Seaport, The Museum of America and the Sea, are deeply saddened by the passing of Clifford Mallory. Cliff served the Museum during virtually his entire adult life, becoming a Trustee in 1940 and continually serving until his death on December 7, 2000. During his sixty years on the Board, Cliff held numerous committee and officer positions and served as President from 1976 to 1984 and Chairman of the Board from 1984 to 1988. More important, however, than the positions he held was the impact he had on the Museum and all associated with it through his extraordinary personality. People were naturally drawn to Cliff and his enthusiasm for life and his interests was contagious. For all of us at Mystic Seaport, Cliff was our last link with the earliest days of the Museum which was founded in 1929. Cliff knew the three founders and all those who have led and shaped the Museum through the years. His father and uncle preceded him as President and his son and son-in-law currently serve as Trustees, continuing the family tradition. This involvement in preserving America's maritime history is logical because of the remarkable role the Mallorys have played in that history. The family has been continuously involved in the maritime industry in America since 1816 as sail makers, ship builders, ship owners and shipping brokers. This nearly 200 years of contributions to our maritime heritage was a point of real pride to Cliff who made his impact as head of C.D. Mallory and Company and through his work on behalf of Mystic Seaport. We send our most sincere sympathies to his wife Pauline Cropper Mallory, his daughters Diana Gros Louis and Veronica Stubbs, his son Charles Mallory, his seven grandchildren and his sister Barbara Hathaway and her family. William E. Cook, Chairman J. Revell Carr, President Mystic Seaport, Mystic, CT

title: HONDA SAYS IT WILL REPLACE ACURA INTEGRA NEXT YEAR

If Hollywood were to remake ''Casablanca'' (and let's fervently hope it has no such plans), Russell Crowe should be on the short list of candidates to play Rick. Although the new movie borrows elements (including a dramatic airport finale) from that World War II classic, it is more like a distant (and hollow) echo than a contemporary remake of the original.

title: Primer on Printmaking That Stresses Innovation

They are brought together in a smashing (but all-too-cutely titled) show, ''Hard Pressed: 600 Years of Prints and Process,'' which amounts to a thumbnail history of exploration in the field of fine-art prints, from earliest woodcuts to the latest in digital technology.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MEDICAID FRAUD CONVICTION
description: A top official of one of the nonprofit organizations being investigated on suspicion of defrauding a federal home mortgage program has been convicted of Medicaid fraud in an unrelated case, the New York State attorney general's office said yesterday. Family Preservation Center of Bohemia, N.Y., had a state contract to coordinate Medicaid services for the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities. Its executive director, Alfreda Taylor-Langhorne, 34, of Mastic, N.Y., was accused of billing the state more than $500,000 for nonreimbursable expenses, including tutoring, baby-sitting and trips to the circus. A Suffolk County jury found her guilty on Wednesday of grand larceny and falsifying documents. The Family Preservation Center, which lost its state contract in April 1998, subsequently bought 47 brownstones in Harlem under a program intended to increase homeownership in poor neighborhoods, and later defaulted on the loans, according to officials of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. Terry Pristin

The deal would give Shaw almost total control of Canadian cable television markets west of Ontario, plus some cable properties in Texas. title: IRIDIUM SATELLITE WINS PENTAGON CONTRACT
description: Iridium Satellite said yesterday that it had moved one step closer to taking over the assets of Iridium, a satellite telephone company that filed last year for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. On Wednesday, the Pentagon agreed to spend $72 million for two years of satellite service from Iridium Satellite. That fulfilled one of the conditions Iridium Satellite set when it persuaded a judge in New York to approve its bid to buy Iridium's assets for $25 million last month. Motorola, which built and ran the satellite systems and made many of the handsets, has agreed to make or license the production of handsets and perhaps sell up to five satellites to the new company. Boeing is expected to operate the satellite system under contract. Iridium filed for Chapter 11 after failing to sign up enough subscribers for a telephone satellite system that cost more than $5 billion. David Barboza (NYT)
