In this comedy of platinum-plated manners in ever-acquisitive Manhattan, people are given to saying things like ''I just put Barry and Diane in their car.'' And ''I gave my statue to Martha Stewart.'' And ''Guess what? Madeleine Albright just offered us a ride home.'' And all within a mere two minutes of dialogue.

It would be convenient to dismiss the disparities -- after all, the United States wouldn't trade economies with any of the 14 countries -- from small ones like the Slovak Republic and Slovenia to larger and more populous ones, like Japan and Canada -- whose eighth graders topped ours. But what's at stake is tomorrow's economy, not today's.

title: MORE CUTBACKS AT NORTHPOINT
description: NorthPoint Communications Group, a provider of high-speed Internet services, dismissed 248 employees, or nearly one-fifth of its work force, to cut costs. NorthPoint, based in San Francisco, made the move a week after Verizon Communications pulled out of an agreement to acquire the company. Like other providers of Internet access over digital subscriber lines, NorthPoint has been squeezed by the high costs of building a network and signs that consumer demand is not as strong as projected. ''This is a very difficult time at NorthPoint,'' said Elizabeth Fetter, the company's chief executive. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Making the Spirit Go A-Leaping
description: IT is holiday time. The fateful call has been placed, too late as usual in all likelihood, to purchase tickets to a weekend performance of "The Nutcracker." There is a moment's silence, then the operator returns. "Sold out," she says, her voice as thoughtfully brisk as that of an emergency- room nurse. Or, even worse in its tantalizing near-possibilities, "Partial view only."

title: NOKIA BUYING SECURITY PROVIDER
description: The Finnish company, Nokia, agreed to acquire Ramp Networks, a provider of Internet security services, for $126 million. Nokia, the world's largest maker of mobile phones, said Ramp, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., would help it increase sales to companies seeking ways to conduct secure transactions over the Internet. Nokia, which will pay $5.80 for each Ramp share, or a premium of 17 percent over the closing price on Wednesday, expects the transaction to be concluded in the first quarter of 2001. T. Kent Elliott, a senior vice president at Nokia, said the acquisition was a result of ''the increasing use of the Internet and the ever-increasing risk of network security threats.'' Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Buddies Who Share Second Chances
description: ''Spring Forward'' presents an unusual and welcome spectacle: two very fine actors, Ned Beatty and Liev Schreiber, engaged in an intense contest to see who can give the more understated performance. This may sound less than thrilling -- and it's true that the movie's slow, easy hush sometimes tends toward somnolence -- but there is real satisfaction in watching such exact and unpretentious applications of craft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDGWICK, MARIAN PARKER
description: SEDGWICK-Marian Parker of Suffern, New York, died on Friday, December 1st, after a short illness. Ms. Sedgwick, nee Parker, was born in Charleston, West Virginia, on July 4th, 1920. She grew up in Roanoke, Virginia, and attended Swarthmore College, from which she graduated in 1941. For many years she was a teacher of English in the New York City schools. After retirement, she travelled widely, volunteered at Skylands Botanical Garden, and was active in charities for the protection of animals. She is survived by three daughters, Anne Parker Mills and Dr. Evelyn Moore Mills of New York City, and Catherine Stiller of Amherst, New York. A memorial service will be held at noon on Saturday, December 9th, at the Wanamaker Carlough Funeral Home in Suffern, NY.

He would probably never have been in that position again if he had re-signed with the Yankees, and so Cone is moving on. The Yankees and the pitcher agreed to sever their relationship yesterday, after six seasons that included four World Series championships.

title: GETTY REBUFFS THIRD OFFER BY UNITED REFINING
description: Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc. dismissed a third offer by the United Refining Company yesterday and urged shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding of Russia. Getty also said it would fight a New York lawsuit filed by United to block Lukoil's purchase. Getty, which has 1,300 gasoline stations in 13 Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, agreed last month to be acquired by Lukoil for $5 a share, or about $71 million. United's latest offer was for $6 a share, plus absorption of the $5 million breakup fee Getty would owe Lukoil for backing out of their agreement. United owns 303 Kwik Fill and Red Apple filling stations, mostly in New York and Pennsylvania, and a refinery in Warren, Pa., where it is based. Getty is based in Jericho, N.Y.

title: Ruling Fuels G.O.P. Resolve to Appoint Electors and Democrats' Will to Fight

title: ALLIANZ, EUROPE INSURER, TRIMS SOUTH AFRICA BUSINESS
description: Allianz A.G., Europe's second-biggest insurer, said it would scale back its business in South Africa to about a fifth of its current size and lay off ''a large number'' of its 283 workers in the country to stem losses. Allianz said it would stop offering conventional insurance to all but its biggest international clients in South Africa beginning in March, but would continue to sell a specialized form of insurance called alternative risk transfer, custom-written policies for specialized risks like a manufacturer's warranty liability. Allianz generated about $865 million in premiums in South Africa last year.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''We now have the legal authority to count the vote.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Celera Genomics' plan to make its genome data freely available to researchers while charging companies for access omitted part of a quotation by Dr. David Baltimore, a molecular biologist, in some editions. While he characterized some critics of the plan as saying ''that if the need for commercialization is so important, then don't publish,'' he also added: ''It's a reasonable point of view. But I think it's a point of view that's shortsighted. It does not provide the scientific community with access to the Celera data. It is basically cutting off your nose to spite your face.''

title: AFRICAN CEMENT MERGER TALKS
description: Pretoria Portland Cement, South Africa's biggest cement maker, is in talks with Portland Holding of Zimbabwe, and analysts said the discussions were likely to lead to a takeover of the Zimbabwean company, now 44 percent owned by Anglo American P.L.C. Buying Portland Holding would add about 750,000 tons of annual capacity to Pretoria Portland's 5.1 million tons.

title: Big Board Tries to Move the Battle Lines in Its Fight With Nasdaq
description: Opening a new front in its unceasing battle with the Nasdaq stock market, the New York Stock Exchange outlined plans yesterday to offer investors new index funds and said it would begin an aggressive new advertising campaign.

title: Knicks Turn to Longley For Big Lift Off Bench
description: For a couple of weeks, it was as if the 7-foot-2 Luc Longley had been stamped with a bulk rate and shipped to the end of the bench upon his return from injury.

title: If It's Funny, You Laugh, But Why?
description: Plato wanted it tightly regulated in his Republic. Socrates thought it should be used sparingly -- like salt. Pythagoras swore off it entirely and forbid his followers to indulge.

title: Pataki Signs Law Enabling City to Finance Tower for Stock Exchange
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation yesterday enabling the city to finance a long-stalled plan to build a major 50-story trading complex and office tower for the New York Stock Exchange in the city's financial district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSTOCK, DAVID
description: WACHSTOCK-David. The Board of The Metropolitan Institute for Training in Psychoanalytical Psychotherapy is saddened by the untimely death of David Wachstock, candidate, representative and fellowship holder. We extend condolences to his family.

title: Yikes! There's a Baby in the Workplace!
description: To the Editor:

title: Jim Lansing, 81, Fordham Athlete and Coach
description: Jim Lansing, an all-American end at Fordham University and a former varsity and club football coach there, died in his sleep last Saturday night at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 81.

title: A Big Ruling From Florida
description: Yesterday was the 32nd day of indecision in the presidential election and these were the main events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXMAN, ELSIE
description: WAXMAN-Elsie. We are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Elsie Waxman, beloved mother of our dear friend Joan Telley, Executive Director of the CCFA NY Chapter. Our heartfelt sympathy to Joan, her sister Susan and the entire family. The Modell Family Shelby and Bill, Leslie Michael and Abby Mitchell and Robin

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgian Court Rejects Lernout & Hauspie Bankruptcy Petition
description: A Belgian court denied a request for bankruptcy protection today from Lernout & Hauspie N.V., the maker of speech-recognition software.

title: Inquiry Faults the Cole's Captain and Crew
description: A Navy inquiry has found that the captain and crew of the American destroyer Cole failed to follow strict security procedures before a skiff packed with explosives attacked it in Yemen in October, killing 17 sailors, senior officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMMEL, VICTOR E.
description: SCHIMMEL-Victor E. Suddenly on December 7. Beloved son of Gertrude and Alfred; brother of Edward; husband of Sydney Firestone; father of Amelia Anne and Joanna Sarah. Burial Oakland, CA.

title: The Neediest Cases; Finding a Guide Through Bureaucracy
description: Ivy C. limped with small, halting steps because of the pain her right foot caused her. The smallest two toes had been amputated. Diabetes had caused her to lose much of her circulation to them. The wound left by the operation refused to heal for several weeks.

title: See Spot Run, Or Is That Spot's Clone?; Owners Look to Science To Resurrect Family Pet
description: Zack Roseman, an affectionate and gregarious Manhattan resident, was so adored by his family that when he died unexpectedly in April at age 14, his grieving relatives decided to freeze some of his flesh for future cloning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JUDITH
description: ABRAMS-Judith. Loving mother of Baruch Spier. Dear sister of Matthew Abrams. Cherished friend to so many who will greatly miss her. Service Sunday, 10 AM, ''Plaza Memorial Chapel,'' 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about avoiding gift shipping delays misstated the order deadlines for eToys. The company will guarantee express delivery by Dec. 24 if orders are placed before midnight, Pacific time, on Dec. 20, not Dec. 23.

title: The Plot Thickens, and a Crowd Expecting the End of the Story Roils in Disbelief
description: The protesters were back at the State Supreme Courthouse yet again this afternoon, this time joining activists from both parties and reporters waiting for the state's highest court to announce its decision in the disputed Florida presidential contest.

title: Saluting the Ailey Junior Troupe
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater likes to celebrate ''family.'' On Tuesday night it paid tribute to Sylvia Waters on her 25th anniversary as head of Ailey II, the junior troupe. It was a night of good dance, performed to music played live, and it suggested Ms. Waters's importance to the Ailey establishment.

title: For Gays, Tolerance Is a Prime-Time Fantasy
description: To some, Showtime's new series ''Queer as Folk,'' a drama about gay and lesbian life, signals that on TV at least, gays have been accepted. The show, which includes vivid scenes of gay intimate life, is at the R-rated edge of a more mainstream trend that has produced at least a dozen gay characters on network TV shows this year. But while open-mindedness spreads into prime-time and major network entertainment, it seems that when it comes to real life, the American people are not so accepting.

title: A Victory for Mr. Gore
description: A lightning bolt yesterday from a divided Florida Supreme Court gave Vice President Al Gore one last chance to come up with the votes that could make him president, and once again threw the election into unfamiliar territory. But in acting boldly, the court also acted wisely. The carefully reasoned majority opinion issued by four of the court's seven justices affirmed the core principle that must guide the candidates and the nation in bringing the election to a fair and legitimate resolution. As the court itself said, ''This election should be determined by a careful examination of the votes of Florida's citizens and not by strategies extraneous to the voting process.''

title: Woman Gets $120,000 in False Arrest for Theft
description: Celeste Goring-Johnson got $120,000 from the city and a Brooklyn jewelry store yesterday. The money put to rest a federal lawsuit in which she claimed she was falsely arrested for stealing a diamond ring.

title: Foot Traffic Blocked By the Box
description: STROLLED down the block to send off a letter, and almost walked right past the mailbox. It was hard to see, obscured as it was by half a dozen garish distribution boxes for local newspapers and catalogs from the Learning Annex, the Seminar Center and the Gotham Writers' Workshop.

title: BAIN CAPITAL BUYS TOYS UNIT OF CONSOLIDATED STORES
description: Bain Capital Inc., a major leveraged buyout firm, said yesterday that it had purchased the KB Toys unit of the Consolidated Stores Corporation for $305 million in cash and securities. Bain said KB, the second-largest toy retailer after Toys 'R' Us, would be run by its current management. Consolidated said last month that it would sell KB to concentrate on its closeout clothing and housewares chains, Pic 'N' Save and Big Lots. Bain, which has spent $17 billion buying companies since 1984, will pay $258 million in cash and give Consolidated a note for $45 million and warrants valued at $2 million.

title: A Setup for a Seminole Surprise
description: NEW HAVEN -- Two Florida judges refused yesterday to disqualify absentee votes in Martin and Seminole Counties, despite technical violations of state law. They made good, sound decisions, comporting with common sense and Florida case law. There's just one little problem  a problem that Florida's State Supreme Court will have to deal with if and when it hears an appeal. The two circuit judges committed the very same error that caused the United States Supreme Court last Monday to vacate the Florida Supreme Court's decision, on Nov. 21, extending a deadline for manual recounts.

title: A Vintage Yzerman Leads Detroit
description: Steve Yzerman scored his first goal of the season and added two assists to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-1 victory last night over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: U.S. to Look At Complaints Of Black Voters
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights voted today to begin a ''systematic investigation'' into complaints about voting irregularities in Florida, and perhaps other states, to determine whether the rights of minority voters were violated on Election Day.

title: Nets Stun Suns And End Skid At Nine Games
description: Appropriately, Sherman Douglas, the crafty 34-year-old understudy who led the Nets all night, began the game-winning play tonight. With 6.7 seconds left in a game the Nets could not afford to lose, locked in an 84-84 tie with the Phoenix Suns, Douglas inbounded the ball to Aaron Williams, who slid the ball on a back-door play to Douglas.

title: Florida Lawmakers Galvanized by Ruling
description: Republican legislators in Florida said the ruling by the state Supreme Court made them even more resolved to push forward with a special session to appoint presidential electors for Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday about public anxiety over genetic modification of foods referred incorrectly to nuclear magnetic resonance, another technology that faced resistance fed by its name. That term -- later changed to magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., when used in medicine -- referred to the nucleus of an atom, not the nucleus of a cell.

title: Space Station Crew Greets First Visitors
description: Ringing a ship's bell in the naval tradition, the three residents of the International Space Station greeted their first visitors today, the shuttle astronauts who have been working on the station's exterior for almost a week.

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Lights Go Out Across City for a Few Seconds; Subways Are Halted During Evening Rush
description: For just a few seconds, the lights went out in New York City yesterday.

title: Abroad at Home; Fair And Square
description: It is feeling more and more like a play by Luigi Pirandello, a tormenting drama in which the audience keeps thinking it will know the answer to the riddle and never quite does. But no playwright could have imagined the scenario of this election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATALAN, ROBERT
description: KATALAN-Robert. Beloved husband of Aline. Beloved father of Ilana Katalan and Jak Katalan. Died December 5, 2000. Private funeral held in Hallandale, FL.

title: Mark Tucker, 46, Jazz Scholar and Musician
description: Mark Tucker, a professor, musician and jazz scholar who specialized in Duke Ellington, died on Wednesday at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 46.

title: After Summer of Power Woes, California Is Hurting Again
description: It was not supposed to be like this.

title: Giants Break Tradition With Indoor Practices
description: Because his team is 6-1 on the road and only 3-3 at home, Giants Coach Jim Fassel has tried to treat aspects of Sunday's game against the visiting Pittsburgh Steelers like an away game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBLATT, MILDRED (RUBIN)
description: SILBERBLATT-Mildred (Rubin). On Thursday, December 7, of Canton, MA, formerly of NY. Beloved wife of the late W. Beryl Silberblatt. Loving mother of Katherine S. Wolfthal of Weston, MA., and Steven William Silberblatt of NYC. Dear sister of David Rubin of Florida, and the late Ida Lasker, Betty Stone, and Manny Rubin. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Services at the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA, on Sunday December 10 at 1:00 PM. Memorial observance through Sunday evening at the home of Katherine S. Wolfthal. Remembrances may be made to the Orchard Cove Scholarship Fund, One Del Pond Drive, Canton, MA 02021. For information call 617-277-8300.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHOE, LEO J.
description: DONOHOE-Leo J. On December 8, 2000 of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Jeannette Wicklow Donohoe. Loving brother of Mary Anna Donohoe of Bethesda, MD., and Margaret Jordan of Weston, CT. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, cousins and dear friends. Associated with Southern Progress, a division of Time Warner for many years. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Sat 7-9 and Sunday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Kessel St., Forest Hills, Monday, December 11 at 9:45 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, STANLEY
description: SCHWARTZ-Stanley, of Lawrence, NY, and Boca Raton, Fla. On December 7, 2000. He was a longtime executive of Friendship Dairies, an avid golfer, and dedicated philanthropist, serving on the Board of Directors of Temple Beth-El of Long Beach, the Peninsula Counseling Center, and the Long Beach Medical Center. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Lawrence (Lois) Schwartz, Judy (David) Feldman and Gail (Robert) Lutolf. Devoted grandfather of Jenny and Joshua Schwartz and Pamela Lutolf. Dear brother of Phyllis Farber. His family and friends will miss him every day, every way. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 11:30 AM, Sunday.

title: Broad Recount Presents Risks For Both Sides
description: Vice President Al Gore went to court to force manual recounts in three predominantly Democratic counties that were presumed to hold a big advantage for him. But the Florida Supreme Court's order to review at least 45,000 untallied ballots across Florida leaves the outcome far less certain, an analysis of county and precinct data shows.

title: A Sense of Weary Disbelief Envelops the Bush Camp
description: They knew that the ruling might not go their way, because they saw the Florida Supreme Court as a wild card that had thwarted them before. They were braced for any and every possibility, because the winding, wacky road since Nov. 7 had taught them not to predict the next turn.

title: U.S. Jobs Report Is Another Indication of a Slowing Economy
description: American businesses continued to increase their work forces last month, but at a slower rate than in the first half of the year, offering another sign that the United States economy has cooled yet is not approaching a recession.

title: Together, the Rational and the Spontaneous Can Make Sweet Illogic
description: Consider this triangular set of passions: An eccentric, slightly mad genius who, in his youth, produced groundbreaking scientific work, has an only daughter who may be as much of an eccentric and slightly mad genius as he. The two form an oddly close bond; the thoughts of one seem to begin where the other's trail off. But then a third pole emerges: a young man, a disciple of the father, who begins to fall in love with the daughter. The father's devotions are both erotic and pedagogic; the student's attractions are both submissive and domineering; the daughter's attitudes are both servile and rebellious. A nearly incestuous ribbon seems pulled between all vertices, spurring jealousies, rivalries, uncertainties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUJOL, ODETTE
description: PUJOL-Odette. Beloved mother of Jean-Claude. Loving grandmother of Bianca and Sandrine. Viewing on Sunday, December 10th, at Barretts Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass on Monday at 10:30 AM at The Church of St. Vincent De Paul, 23rd St between 6th & 7th Ave. Interment following the service at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings, NY.

title: Cutting Luna
description: Sometime late last month, someone with a chain saw hiked into a small private redwood preserve in Northern California and made a 19-foot gash in the tree that the conservationist Julia Hill, known as Butterfly, had lived in for two years. It is a 300-foot, 1,300-year-old redwood that Ms. Hill calls Luna. The wound is not likely to kill the tree, but arborists have bridged the cut with metal tensioning rods mounted in heavy steel brackets to keep Luna from being felled by high winds.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRW INC., Cleveland, an aerospace and automotive products manufacturer, has sold the Marc products and services unit to an investment management group led by Washington Investment Partners L.L.C., a privately held merchant bank, for an undisclosed sum.

title: In Twin Lawsuits Over Ballots, Twin Rulings Against Gore
description: When the Florida Supreme Court salvaged Vice President Al Gore's hopes this afternoon with its ruling to begin recounting votes, he already had two strikes against him.

title: Iraq Tests America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Setup for a Seminole Surprise
description: Two Florida judges refused yesterday to disqualify absentee votes in Martin and Seminole Counties, despite technical violations of state law. They made good, sound decisions, comporting with common sense and Florida case law. There's just one little problem -- a problem that Florida's State Supreme Court will have to deal with if and when it hears an appeal. The two circuit judges committed the very same error that caused the United States Supreme Court last Monday to vacate the Florida Supreme Court's decision, on Nov. 21, extending a deadline for manual recounts.

title: E-ZPass System Faces $65 Million Deficit, and Its Success Is Partly to Blame
description: The E-ZPass automatic toll collection system will have to pay off a deficit of nearly $65 million in 2008, the year it was expected to break even, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday. And part of the reason is the system's popularity.

title: Spotlight Again Shifts To Justices In Washington
description: As Gov. George W. Bush's lawyers raced back to the United States Supreme Court tonight, the contours of the final legal battle of this tortuous presidential election were fairly clear.

title: Little Progress Reported in Budget Agreement
description: After the House and the Senate approved temporary spending measures today to keep parts of the federal government running for another three days, Congressional leaders reported little progress in reaching agreement with the White House on a budget for the current fiscal year, now more than 10 weeks old.

title: Record Labels Win Internet Ruling
description: Radio stations that make their broadcasts available on the Internet must pay fees to record companies, the United States Copyright Office has ruled, in a decision the radio stations assert conflicts with federal law.

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, PETER
description: SCHNEIDER-Peter. Of Scarsdale, NY and Waquoit, MA on December 7, 2000 in his 88th year following a life of accomplishment; first in his class at St. John's Law School; first of 30,000 on the list for appointment to the NYC Police Department ''Super-Class'' of 1940; and first in the hearts of his family-his late wife Ruth Levy Schneider, and daughters Lois B. Schneider of Sarasota, FL and Judith A. Cion of New Orleans, LA. Founding partner of the law firm of Schneider, Kaufman and Sherman; founder and president of Citizens Crusade Against Crime. Service Sunday 9:45AM at ''the Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Shomrim Society Scholarship Fund, 1, Police Plaza, Rm 306, NY, NY 10038.

title: Public Transit Is Essential For Stadium, Mayor Says
description: Responding to a proposal from the New York Jets for a domed 75,000-seat stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that a critical element of any such project would be the expansion of public transportation to the site.

title: Daley Comment on Ruling
description: Following is a transcript of a statement yesterday by William M. Daley, campaign manager for Vice President Al Gore, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Analysts Turn to P.R. To Market Themselves
description: When nearly 1,000 psychoanalysts gather here next week for the fall meeting of the American Psychoanalytic Association, they will find topics on the agenda that would have been unthinkable 10 years ago. Panels on psychoanalysis by e-mail and videophone, on corporate consulting and on marketing and media training, things that other mental health professionals have been doing for years, are just a few signs that this most reserved of professions is reinventing itself.

title: The Florida Supreme Court's Decision on Hand Recounts of Ballots
description: Following is the ruling yesterday by the Florida Supreme Court ordering a recount in the state's presidential election. The vote in Gore vs. Harris was 4 to 3. Justices Harry Lee Anstead, Barbara J. Pariente, R. Fred Lewis and Peggy A. Quince concurred in the majority opinion; Chief Justice Charles T. Wells and Justice Major B. Harding wrote dissents, with Justice Leander B. Shaw joining in the latter. Italizicized portions show emphasis in the original.

title: Lawyers for the Poor Cite Low Pay In Threat to Refuse New Cases
description: Lawyers who represent poor people in New York's increasingly desperate family court system are vowing to refuse new cases in Manhattan and Brooklyn if they do not get a raise in the rates they have been paid since 1986.

title: Mets Turning Attention To the Power of Ramirez
description: The Mets co-owner Fred Wilpon had a strong feeling early yesterday that the Mets would lose Mike Hampton. But Wilpon promised that the Mets had other plans, and those plans could include a strong pursuit of another free agent: the slugging outfielder Manny Ramirez.

title: Judge Sets Sunday Deadline for Counts
description: A Florida circuit court judge tonight set a deadline of 2 p.m. on Sunday for completing manual recounts of uncounted ballots ordered earlier in the day by the State Supreme Court and gave county elections officials broad discretion over which ballots would be counted as legitimate.

title: F.T.C. Nears A Decision On AOL Case
description: After nearly a year of reviewing the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, the Federal Trade Commission is on the verge of taking a final vote that seems as predictable as the outcome of the presidential contest in Florida.

title: 'Big Three' Lead the Resurgence in Distance Running
description: Distance running, which has been sagging badly in the United States for more than a decade, is getting a strong boost from three teenagers who train harder and think tougher than their predecessors.

title: ASK JEEVES SAYS LOSS IS WIDER THAN EXPECTED
description: The online question-and-answer service Ask Jeeves Inc. said late Thursday that its chief executive, Rob Wrubel, would resign and that its fourth-quarter loss will be wider than analysts expected. In response, the company's stock fell $5.88, to close at $3.81. Before yesterday's trading the shares had lost 91 percent of their value this year. The company said its fourth-quarter loss from operations, excluding amortization, would be about $18 million, or 50 cents a share; analysts had forecast a 33-cent loss.

title: Unarmed Suspect Killed by New Jersey Officers, Police Say
description: A man wanted in the slaying of a woman in her Fort Lee apartment was killed in a barrage of 27 shots Thursday night by a group of New Jersey officers who faced him in the dim hallway of an East Windsor motel and opened fire when he brandished what turned out to be a TV remote control and shouted threats, the police said.

title: From the Crib to Awestruck Shepherds
description: Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio'' is not a blueprint for a single public performance; it surveys an entire season in the church's year. Its six cantatas depict in serial form the liturgical events that reach from Christmas Day to Epiphany. Bach clearly had a self-contained musical book in mind. The mood, the key relationships and the forces called for make this clear. We are invited to sample the ''Christmas Oratorio'' piecemeal but always with an eye to its completeness.

title: H. C. Artmann, Austrian Poet, Author and Literary Rebel, 79
description: H. C. Artmann, an author, poet and leader among Austria's avant-garde, died on Monday at his home in the Josefstadt quarter of Vienna. He was 79.

title: York Helps Rangers End a Long Drought
description: Mike York, at 5 feet 10 inches and 185 pounds, is not very big for a hockey player, and he is painfully quiet. And that makes it easy to lose York, the Rangers' 22-year-old forward, on and off the ice.

title: Lemieux a Ranger Killer
description: Nearly everyone involved in the game agrees that Mario Lemieux's return can only be good for hockey. The question on Broadway, however, is whether the third coming of Lemieux can be any good at all for the Rangers.

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, BARBARA
description: HERMAN-Barbara. On December 7, 2000. Beloved wife of Jerome, loving mother of Stephanie, dear sister of Leonard, adoring grandmother of Kera. She is profoundly missed. Service Monday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEDEO, JOSEPH E.
description: DeDEO-Joseph E. Of Palm Beach, FL and Southampton, NY on December 8, 2000 at age 63. Husband for 32 years of Esther Dadigan DeDeo, father of Simon Joseph DeDeo, son of Clara DeDeo, brother of Marguerite Caggiano. Reposing Monday December 11, 7-9PM at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc, 203 Hampton Rd., Southampton, NY. Funeral mass Tuesday 10AM at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary R.C. Church, Hill St, Southampton. Interment Sacred Hearts Cemetery.

title: Supreme Court of Florida; 'The Recount Shall Commence
description: ''By a vote of 4-3, the majority of the court has reversed the decision of the trial court in part. It has further ordered that the Circuit Court of the Second Judicial Circuit here in Tallahassee shall immediately begin a manual recount of the approximately 9,000 Miami-Dade ballots that registered undervotes.

title: BEAR STEARNS AND HICKS HALT MANVILLE BUYOUT
description: The Bear Stearns Companies and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. abandoned a proposed buyout of the Johns Manville Corporation yesterday after Manville, the second-largest American maker of construction materials, said it would not accept a bid below the $3 billion the prospective buyers initially offered in June. Manville, based in Denver, is 76 percent owned by a trust set up to benefit victims of asbestos-related illness and their heirs, whose lawsuits drove Manville into Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection in 1982. Manville had expressed skepticism in October that the deal could be completed on the original terms because of difficulties arranging financing.

title: Nassau Averts Takeover, But Not Close Oversight
description: In the end, the convoluted machinations of Nassau County's finances were resolved -- at least temporarily -- with a whimper instead of a bang. There were no officials racing to get their budget stamped at 11:58 p.m., no 10-hour delays while one last tax rate was crunched to perfection. There was a meeting that started at 4 and ended before 5, a unanimous vote, a few moments of relatively amicable commentary, and then everyone could go home.

title: Florida Court Used a Classic Tool of Judicial Review
description: After Vice President Al Gore's sweeping defeat at the hands of a Tallahassee trial judge last Monday, it was clear that his lawyers would have an uphill battle overturning the ruling.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Anti-Clinton Are Pleased to Denounce . . .
description: FOR all his argumentative powers, Theodore B. Olson, the reigning constitutional litigator for this city's conservative Republican establishment, falls quiet and openly admiring as his wife, Barbara K. Olson, combative partisan on the shouting-heads television circuit, cuts loose with some updated odium toward her favorite target, the Clintons, president and senator-elect.

title: 10 Die as Violence Surges on Palestinian 'Day of Rage'
description: Ten people were killed today in the West Bank and East Jerusalem in one of the deadliest days of violence since the outbreak of the current Palestinian uprising more than two months ago.

title: Stanton Says He Is Ready To Answer Manager's Call
description: The bullpen phone rang in the seventh or eighth inning when the Yankees had a lead over the last four years, and Mike Stanton never knew whether the call was coming for him or Jeff Nelson. But Nelson has signed with Seattle, so more of the late-inning burden will shift to Stanton.

title: Morningstar Demotes Its Chief Executive
description: Morningstar Inc., the mutual fund research company, demoted its chief executive, Don Phillips, to be one of three executives with the new title of managing director. The company's chairman, Joe Mansueto, assumed the title of chief executive.

title: Honoring Two Who Went Their Own Way
description: Sarah Cahill, a pianist who specializes in American music, devoted her recital at the Miller Theater last Saturday evening to two 20th-century iconoclasts, George Antheil, as a celebration of his centenary, and Leo Ornstein, who celebrated his 108th birthday at a nursing home in Wisconsin that same day.

title: Stunned Republicans Vow Fight to End
description: Prominent Republicans, stunned and infuriated by the Florida Supreme Court decision, vowed tonight to mount an intense battle over the presidency and take it to Congress if necessary. But a handful acknowledged for the first time that Vice President Al Gore might end up in the White House.

title: BOUYGUES TALKS OFF
description: Bouygues, the French construction and communications group, said its negotiations with Telecom Italia Mobile had ended and no new talks were planned. Bouygues said earlier this week that it was looking for a new strategic shareholder to help it bid for one of France's four telecommunications licenses, but a spokeswoman would not comment on reports that the talks concerned an offer by the Italian company to increase its stake in the Bouygues telecommunications subsidiary.

title: Rockies Show Hampton How High Is Up
description: Shunning the Mets and their belated $100 million-plus offer, Mike Hampton reached agreement today with the Colorado Rockies on an eight-year contract for $123 million. The contract is baseball's longest for a pitcher in nearly a quarter-century, and it is the largest in terms of total dollars a baseball player has ever had.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a change in accounting rules for writing off ''good will'' defined the expression incorrectly. It is the difference between what one company pays for another and the fair market value of the acquired company's assets -- not the book value of those assets, which is the value on the company's balance sheet.

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nader Factor, a Month Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Marymount in Westchester to Become Part of Fordham
description: Ending 93 years as an independent Roman Catholic women's college, Marymount College has agreed to become a campus of Fordham University in a consolidation that will be completed by July 2002, the two colleges announced today.

title: New Governor of Chiapas Promises, 'No More Bloodshed'
description: Mexico's southernmost state, Chiapas, joined the country's transition to its first real democracy today when it inaugurated an opposition politician as governor, ending the Institutional Revolutionary Party's long control over this impoverished and troubled region.

title: BIDS FOR SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Merant P.L.C. of Britain said more than one company had signaled an interest in buying it, but it did not name the bidders. The news caused Merant shares to shoot up by a third, to 110.5 pence ($1.60). Merant has eliminated jobs and cut expectations for earnings and sales three times this year as it struggles to remake itself into an Internet business. Its main business had been software services for mainframe computers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about avoiding gift shipping delays misstated the order deadlines for eToys. The company will guarantee express delivery by Dec. 24 if orders are placed before midnight, Pacific time, on Dec. 20, not Dec. 23.

title: Groh Looks to Johnson To Help Return Kicks
description: The Jets desperately need help in returning punts, a category in which they rank 27th in the National Football League. You can practically see the grimace on Dedric Ward's face every time the ball sails toward him.

title: New Plan Would Scale Back Quota for Electric Cars in California
description: California air regulators are moving to relax a controversial and closely watched program that would force automobile manufacturers to sell electric cars starting in 2003.

title: BAYER CONSIDERS REVAMPING

The company, which makes drugs and specialty chemicals and is best known for developing aspirin, said it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Bank to help it explore strategic options. The company did not elaborate, but analysts said sales of business lines or a more aggressive pursuit of mergers and acquisitions were probably on the table. In the past, Bayer has been reluctant to surrender control of its units in joint ventures, and it has lately been a subject of takeover speculation. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Renewed Hope on Chiapas
description: President Vicente Fox has wasted no time in addressing one of Mexico's most serious political problems, the seven-year-old stalemate between federal troops and Zapatista rebels in the southern state of Chiapas. Within hours of his inauguration last week, Mr. Fox lifted military roadblocks in the region and expressed a willingness to negotiate with the rebels. His interior minister offered an amnesty. This week the administration presented Congress with a bill granting Mexico's indigenous people limited autonomy. These are important and welcome steps by a government trying to reverse the legacies of the Institutional Revolutionary Party's seven-decade rule. Under the PRI, Mexico glorified its Indian past but neglected its contemporary indigenous communities.

title: SUNOCO AGREES TO PURCHASE OF COASTAL STATIONS
description: Sunoco Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 103 gasoline stations from the Coastal Corporation and to supply another 150 Coastal stations with fuel. Most of the stations are in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Virginia or Tennessee. Financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Sunoco also announced that it expected to earn $90 million to $110 million, or $1.05 to $1.30 a share, in the fourth quarter, mainly because of strength in its refining operations; analysts had forecast 87 cents a share. Sunoco's stock price rose 44 cents to close at $29.44. Coastal, which is being acquired by the El Paso Energy Corporation, fell 94 cents, to $78.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESSEL, ROSA (NEE HIMMELBLAU)
description: PRESSEL-Rosa (nee Himmelblau). Passed away Wednesday, December 6, 2000 at the age of 101. Rosa, devoted wife of the late Adolphe Pressel, was born in Belgium & came to the United States in 1939 where she settled in New York City and became an active supporter of several community and charitable organizations. She was a longtime, active member of Congregation Shearith Israel and its Sisterhood. Her work for the Dalton Community in Israel helped to establish an industry for the Moshav. More recently, her pet project has been Dorot, a local charity which provides food for the homebound. Mrs. Pressel was also an avid bridge master. Rosa has been a tremendous inspiration to both family and friends. She is survived by two sons, Paul and Raymond, five grandchildren, seven great grandchildren and one great, great grandson. Memorial contributions to the Sisterhood of Congregation Shearith Israel, or to Dorot would be greatly appreciated.

Naval historians say the ship Dmitri Donskoi, scuttled in 1905, which Dong Ah had agreed to salvage, could not have been carrying more than a few tons of cargo and certainly not the 15,400 tons of gold mentioned in the rumor.

title: OPINION; When Presidents Were Worthies
description: THE recent presidential election has been a dismal affair, no matter who takes the oath on Inauguration Day. Yes, the system did work, after a fashion, and the republic continues to be strong. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERGH, CARIBEL FINGER
description: STERNBERGH-Caribel Finger, 89, of Washington, DC, passed away at Arleigh Burke Pavilion, McLean, VA, Dec. 1, 2000. Born in Gainesville, GA, she earned B.S.C. and L.L.B. degrees from the Univ. of Georgia. One of the first women attorneys in Georgia, she served on the Governor's staff before moving to New York, where she practiced criminal law. She was a member of the Federal Bar, and the U.S. Supreme Court Bar. She was a parishioner at All Saints Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, MD. for over 50 years. She was an accomplished cellist, actress, rifle woman, and horsewoman. She helped establish educational and vocational Programs for women, helped set up libraries in the public schools in Washington, DC, and tutored many immigrants for naturalization court. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, Daughters of Colonial Wars, the Daughters of 1812, and the Military Order of World Wars. She was an active member of the Washington Club, Delta Zeta Sorority, Twentieth Century Club, Capital Speakers Club, Women's Bar Association, The Salvation ArmyWomen's Auxiliary, Women's Assn. for the National Symphony Orchestra, Washington Opera Scholarship Society, the Sovereign Military Order of the Temple of Jerusalem, and was a sponsor of the National Debutante Cotillion. Wife of the late Col. VanRensselaer H. Sternbergh, USA, she is survived by a son, VanRensselaer H. Sternbergh, Jr., of Greenwich, CT., a daughter, Caribel S. Fitch, of Bethesda, MD, three grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. A funeral service will be held at the Fort Myer Chapel, December 11, 2000, at 10:00 AM, with interment at Arlington National Cemetery.

Porto, she bequeaths a legacy of a passionate love of life and a commitment never to acknowledge the threat of defeat. To the treasures of her life, grandsons Brad and Ryan O'Sullivan and Joseph and Brian Porto, she imparts endless love and affection. The boys will always cherish her stirring example of courage that belied her petite stature. It is a very difficult void to fill, but her show of consistent strength and grace in the face of great adversity will give them an abundance of enduring and inspirational memories. She leaves behind a sister, Gloria Bianchi, her daughter-in-law Jean Anne Celebrezze Porto and her grandson Joseph's wife, Annie Thompson Porto. As a family we find consolation in her reunion with her beloved husband, Joe. She will now realize all the happiness she gave to so many others. Under the watchful eye of Dr. Mark Kris, her life was extended with quality. Please make contributions in her memory to Lung Cancer Research Fund, #

title: Displaying the Waters of Life
description: IN 1911, in response to high death rates among infants, the Health Department began the Little Mothers League to educate mothers in tenements and girls who had to care for younger siblings. The picture above, of a bathing lesson from the league, is part of an exhibit titled ''Healing Waters: Utopian Responses to Dirt, Disease and Disorder, 1890-1940.'' The show focuses on ways Progressive and New Deal reformers used water, providing indoor plumbing, public baths, fire protection and recreational facilities to the growing city. It is a collaboration between the South Street Seaport Museum and the New York City Municipal Archives. Social problems like dirty streets, the spread of disease, inadequate sanitation and overcrowding that were brought on by mass immigration and rapid industrialization are examined. The exhibit is intended to demonstrate that technology and social engineering allowed reformers to mold a modern city. Photographs, written documents, drawings and maps are on view.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Code of the Slammer
description: Edward Bunker's gritty prison novel, THE ANIMAL FACTORY (St. Martin's Minotaur, paper, $11.95), originally published in 1977, rings with an unsurprising authenticity. The author was in and out of the California penal system for 18 years and spent time in San Quentin, where he was first incarcerated as a baby-faced 17-year-old. Now the former bank robber and forger has become a cult icon of sorts, championed by filmmakers like Quentin Tarantino, who cast him in ''Reservoir Dogs,'' and Steve Buscemi, who adapted this book for a recent movie. Bunker's criminal past is embroidered into this melodrama about a handsome young middle-class cocaine dealer, Ronald Decker, who is sent to San Quentin for 10 years to life. Immediately beset by menacing suitors, Ron finds protection through a vaguely homoerotic father-son relationship with Earl Copen, a hard-timer who knows as much about Celine and Dostoyevsky as he does about scams and shivs. Both men are caught in prison's classic double bind: to get parole they have to play by the rules, but to stay alive they ''must follow the codes of the underworld.'' Of course, after a dehumanizing year of witnessing race wars, casual murder and sexual slavery, Ron is an animal who violently determines his chances, and Earl's, with the inevitability of Greek tragedy -- It had never been a matter of real choice,'' Earl says. Bunker, who is also the author of a memoir titled ''Education of a Felon,'' writes in plain, sometimes clumsy prose, yet his oddly honorable bad guys have a rich emotional complexity. His digressions on penal reform are impassioned, if redundant. What armchair gangsters will most enjoy are the details about prison culture -- from the price of a life in cigarettes to how inmates communicate through the toilet ''telephone'' system. Sia Michel

title: Bookend; The Rising Sun Sets on Japanese Publishing
description: Japan's popular love affair with books, though it began only in the 1880's, once more than made up in intensity whatever it lacked in longevity. A century ago, during the Meiji Restoration, a national drive to catch up to the West, literacy in Japan became universal and parents came to see producing well-schooled children as their duty to the state. Publishing for the masses took off. Japan's second great drive to excel began after the devastation of World War II, and once again book learning was at its center. Public libraries became common for the first time after the war, and during the rise to economic power the whole nation seemed to live by the maxim: save money, go to sleep early and read plenty.

title: Lonely Gay Teen Seeking Same
description: In the summer of 1999, when he was 15, a youth I will refer to by only his first name, Jeffrey, finally admitted to himself that he was gay. This discovery had been coming on for some time; he had noticed that he felt no attraction to girls and that he became aroused when showering with other boys after physical education class. But Jeffrey is a devout Southern Baptist, attending church several times each week, where, he says, the pastor seems to make a point of condemning homosexuality. Jeffrey knew of no homosexuals in his high school or in his small town in the heart of the South. (He asked that I withhold not only his last name but also any other aspects of his life that might reveal his identity.) He prayed that his errant feelings were a phase. But as the truth gradually settled over him, he told me last summer during a phone conversation punctuated by nervous visits to his bedroom door to make sure no family member was listening in, he became suicidal.

title: PULSE; I'll Have a Large Shampoo With Collagen Cream
description: Cafeterias are the latest in Manhattan dining chic. Ian Schrager's Hudson Cafeteria and Frank Gehry's lunchtime spot for Conde Nast employees made waves this fall. Now the fad has spread to the trend-driven beauty industry. At 598 Madison Avenue (57th Street), just around the corner from the Midtown Bliss day spa, are a few hundred feet of retail space called Quick Blisscertificates, where shoppers grab a tray and slide it past a buffet selection of Bliss beauty products with perky names like High Thighs, Glamour Gloves and Rosy Toes. The self-serve spateria is an attempt to accommodate the frenzied clients who swarm the halls of the two Manhattan Bliss spas at holiday time. In the past, they served Champagne to keep the customers in line calm. This year, shoppers will be directed to QuickBliss, which is open seven days a week and offers free shipping. DANA DICKEY

title: Transforming Notes From the Underground Into a Map of a Cave
description: Leigh Cave was discovered in 1960 by two state geologists preparing for the creation of the Round Valley Reservoir in Hunterdon County. The contours of its interior are still being discovered. The cave is now the property of the New Jersey Water Supply Authority, which does not permit the public inside. But since 1985, members of the Northern New Jersey Grotto and the Central New Jersey Grotto, the local chapters of the National Speleogical Society, have been allowed. The only map ever made of Leigh Cave was made back in 1960. Three months ago a new effort to map it was begun by John Tudek, a member of the Central New Jersey Grotto. He expects to finish in the summer. In the meantime, he is also teaching other cavers how to map a cave. He recently talked about the process.

After all, there are only two flights a week out of Brisbane, Australia, that will even take you here -- here being the nation of Nauru, a tiny island 1,200 miles east of New Guinea in the Pacific Ocean, just south of the Equator. It may be about as far away from everywhere as you can get and still be somewhere.

title: Crime

''You're always trying to dig up the corpses,'' a wise and subtle villain tells Rebus in SET IN DARKNESS (St. Martin's Minotaur, $24.95). ''One foot in the past and one in the grave.'' If awkward, the stance is right for a city like Edinburgh, so proud of its violent history, and for a case like this one, which digs up a 20-year-old crime to cast a dark cloud on the future of the new Scottish Parliament.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Shinier Than Now
description: Long after the heyday of Hollywood portrait photographers like George Hurrell, and long before the tyranny of paparazzi who stalk stars like bloodhounds, there was Murray Garrett. Garrett was barely 20 years old when he moved from New York to Hollywood, camera in hand, and established himself as a photojournalist for publications like Time, Life and Look. HOLLYWOOD CANDID: A Photographer Remembers (Abrams, $35) consists of 150 of his favorite black-and-white images. Never are they as studied or opulent as Hurrell's and rarely as hurried or invasive as the paparazzi's; they are congenial, a pleasant time tunnel back to the 50's, when stars still welcomed ''at-home'' photo shoots. Often the shots are humorous, luminous and, at best, revealing. Joan Crawford is depicted, without makeup and looking strangely sweet, on a radio sound stage; Jane Wyman is shown radiant at hearing raves for her performance in ''Johnny Belinda''; Ava Gardner is photographed laughing with the kind of naturalness she never showed on screen. Garrett's accompanying remarks provide the book's real snap. True, you must wade through a river of celebrity pap to find the sharp and juicy, but then you discover a cutting anecdote about Shelley Winters (''Anyone meeting Shelley for the first time will find her very funny, but as many directors and actors could tell you, the amusement doesn't last long'') or a nasty remark from Bob Hope, whispered to Garrett during a break in a television program (''Five minutes away from Milton Berle is like a month in the country''). In the end, Garrett and his subjects share something important in common: they are most compelling when they are most candid. Marjorie Rosen

title: A Time for Patience
description: Never in living memory has there been a political contest like that now being waged between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Prior to Friday's ruling from the Florida Supreme Court, public opinion was running strongly in a direction that would have made it necessary for Mr. Gore to concede. We now expect that tide to pause, and for a new mood of watchful waiting to emerge in the public opinion polls based on the simple, powerful principles at the heart of the Florida court's opinion. As we said when the decision was announced, the key principle is simply that elections should be decided by the votes actually cast. Moreover, the court reasoned that since the physical evidence of the ballots themselves is still available to Florida's officials and courts, everyone should get on with the fundamental democratic activity of counting them. Once those votes are completely counted, the totals will exert a gravitational pull on the public and the candidates that will, in our view, move the country away from the constitutional crisis forecast by some.

title: On Rocky Road to Reform, Europeans Advance, but Not Far
description: European Union leaders, struggling to reform their cumbersome bureaucracy so that they can begin admitting new members to the 15-nation group, reached agreement on one of the three major areas under negotiation today. But that provisional accord left smaller nations vowing a fight to the finish to keep their clout.

title: A BUDGET BONUS
description: Westchester County legislators working on next year's budget have found what could be a bonus: additional sales tax revenues. A preliminary analysis by auditors reviewing the proposed $1.2 billion budget for 2001 said the initial $261.9 million sales tax projection may be too conservative; that figure could actually be as much as $4.7 million higher. They based their estimates on this year's sales tax collections, which so far are about 12 percent ahead of last year's through October 1999. With the economy showing signs of slowing, however, Kathleen M. Tooher, the budget director, is recommending that the county plan conservatively and only count on the lower projection.

title: Amy Foote and Matthew McCooe
description: MANY people describe Amy Wendling Foote as a true Texan. She grew up in Dallas, where her father was for years the headmaster of the Greenhill School, and she is so friendly she practically lassos strangers at parties. She loves margaritas and doesn't wince when eating hot chili peppers.

title: Italian Fare in a Cozy Redo in Port Chester
description: RESTAURANTS will frequently repaint their dining rooms or change tired draperies or the color of the linens. Keeping a clean, spiffy look is part of the maintenance every restaurant must undertake. But the original decorative concept is usually unchanged, only refreshed. Alba's, however, has undergone not only redecoration but also total renovation, turning a pleasant but characterless space into a dining room with all the charm of a cozy New England inn.

title: Pulling the Plug
description: WHO OWNS DEATH?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAINE, HERMAN J.
description: SHAINE-Herman J. Of Clifton, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Rhoda Friedman Shaine. Devoted father of sons Dr. Bruce and Lewis Shaine and daughter Susan Shaine Kaye. Dear grandfather of Rachel and Ilana Kaye and loving brother of sister Rhoda (Bobby) Shaine. Died November 30, 2000 at age 76. A graduate of New York University (Class of 1947), he was employed by The New York Times for forty-four years, latterly as Payroll Supervisor for the Circulation Department. Herman was a World War II Army veteran (Medic-ETO) and served for many years as the Quartermaster, Floyd Gibbons Post (500), Veterans of Foreign Wars, in addition to being a member of the (New York) Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union. He was also a member of the Clifton (New Jersey) Jewish Center, to which contributions may be made (Shaine Memorial Book Fund). A man of integrity, stature and ability, he will be dearly missed.

title: Boating Into History
description: Imagine the history of the Hudson from the perspective of the boats that have navigated it. Roger Panetta, a local historian, has taken just such a boat's-eye view in an exhibition he co-curated at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title: Professor Scarry Has a Theory
description: As members of Families of EgyptAir 990 Inc., we were reassured to read that, for now, Elaine Scarry, a Harvard English professor, ''is through with'' electromagnetic interference (Emily Eakin, Nov. 19). Frankly, we wish she had turned to other pursuits before tackling EgyptAir 990, the disaster that claimed our parents and 213 others a year ago.

title: Admiring Houston's Creative Bent
description: MY first trip to Houston, about 20 years ago, was on assignment for Rolling Stone. There I interviewed a rock musician with a 10-gallon hat and a foot-long beard who, as it happened, also sat on the board of the city's Museum of Contemporary Arts. I was impressed by this, because it suggested that Houston was a city that embraced, even encouraged, eccentricity.

title: Cold Remedies
description: With the first cold weather of the season, children didn't have to be told to wear gloves last week. They pulled them on of their own free will. Family pets reluctantly wore sweaters or coats. After years of protests, fur was back with a vengeance, in ranch-bred skins. The shearling coat was a star, in earth tones, black and vibrant fuchsia. Cloth coats with lavish fur trimming and all qualities of sable coats were popular. An opulent red fox coat, above left, and a whimsical cloth coat with trompe l'oeil foxes and trimmed in fox, top far left, were standouts.

title: At Age 28, Weinke Is the Oldest Heisman Winner
description: The quarterbacks Chris Weinke of Florida State and Josh Heupel of Oklahoma will meet again on Jan. 3 in the Orange Bowl in Miami in a game that may decide the national championship. That will be a team honor in a team sport.

description: Dorian Drees, a daughter of Susan Drees Sugarman of Palm City, Fla., and the late John M. Drees, was married yesterday to Reed Stuyvesant Kean, a son of Thomas H. Kean, the former governor of New Jersey, and Deborah Bye Kean of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Joseph G. Farias, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

Wearing a waistcoat, a high collar and spats, he brandishes a cane and a tall silk hat. Topping it off is his remarkable head. It is absolutely smooth, no wayward wisps in sight.

A Mercedes S-class for $100,000-plus or a rare, late-model Aston Martin at $300,000? A brand-new Rolls-Royce at $350,000 or maybe one of those new Bugattis that Volkswagen is planning to sell in the region of $750,000?

title: LEAF RECYCLING
description: Through an expanded program this fall, the county's recycling of leaves is expected to double to 20,000 tons this year over last. Leaves are being recycled at commercial composting sites, where they are turned into topsoil, potting soil and other natural reusable gardening products. So far, 12 municipalities have chosen to participate in the county's organic waste recycling program -- five more than last year. Municipalities load the leaves left at neighborhood curbsides into large transport trailers for delivery to composting centers outside the county. To date, 400 truckloads, or approximately 8,000 tons of fall leaves, have been transferred. ELSA BRENNER

title: Sleeping With the Fish
description: What to do on New Year's Eve is always problematic, especially for families. First Nights, parties with baby sitters in the basement, functions at houses of worship all try to meet the need. This year, there is a new option in Camden, an overnight at the New Jersey State Aquarium in an event called Deep Sleep. Families and groups can arrive as early as 7:30 p.m. on Dec. 31. Then they will get special tours, eat snacks, listen to songs, watch a dive show in the big tank and get to chat with staff members. At midnight, there will be a ginger ale toast and a view of fireworks over the Benjamin Franklin Bridge on the Delaware. Participants should take along sleeping bags and whatever else they'd take to a sleepover. The event is over after breakfast on Jan. 1, 2001, at 9 a.m. The cost is $40 a person. Registration is required, at (865) 365-3300, extension 330, and scout troops and other groups are invited.

title: SUPREME COURT, SPLIT 5-4, HALTS FLORIDA COUNT IN BLOW TO GORE
description: As abruptly as the world seemed to change at 4 p.m. on Friday, it did so again at 2:45 p.m. today when the United States Supreme Court halted the hand count that the Florida Supreme Court had ordered. Judges and election officials, who had begun counting ballots shortly after dawn today across Florida, started packing them up and waiting to see if the ground would shake once more.

title: Food; Grecian Formula
description: Coming and going is what Greeks have always done best. Beginning with Odysseus, the ur-tourist, Greeks have defined themselves by adventure, says Aglaia Kremezi, a food historian and photojournalist who, for more than a decade, has trained her sights on her nation's cooking. But, she adds, they are also known for their accommodation.

title: Political Briefing; Elections Are Over; Let the Race Begin
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana, a moderate Democrat, won election in 1996 by just 5,788 votes. And though she will not face re-election for two more years, her first opponent is already out beating the bushes and bayous.

title: Frame by Frame, an Action Film Dripping With Art
description: ED HARRIS'S ''Pollock,'' opening in New York on Friday, sits atop the category of biopic that includes Charlton Heston as the tormented Michelangelo, Jose Ferrer as the tormented Toulouse-Lautrec and Kirk Douglas as the tormented Vincent van Gogh. Now Mr. Harris, as the tormented Jackson Pollock, does his part for the tradition, upending tables, urinating into a fireplace and, at his drunkest, becoming a fluorescent shade of orange that makes him look even more like a pumpkin than Al Gore did during the first presidential debate.

title: Tinker, Tailor, American . . .
description: The cold war made a brief comeback in a trial that seemed intended to show that Russia still has secrets worth stealing, to wit: a rocket-propelled torpedo system called the Squall that Russia would like to sell to foreign navies. The case was that of a former naval intelligence officer, Edmond Pope, who was convicted of espionage and sentenced to 20 years for acquiring allegedly secret information about the Squall. President Vladimir V. Putin took the role of a leader, and former spy, who backs his intelli gence chiefs. But after a clemency-board recommendation, it seems that Mr. Putin may send the American home for Christmas as a gift to a new president-elect. Patrick E. Tyler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELOTTA, THOMAS A.
description: VELOTTA-Thomas A. Mr. Velotta passed away November 30 at the age of 89 in Portland, Oregon and is survived by his daughter Virginia Velotta Bell of Portland, his son Thomas, Jr. of Brooklyn, his stepson Rick Dufay of Los Angeles, and his sister Helen and brother Nunzio of Manhattan. Born in Calabria, Italy and raised in New York City, Mr. Velotta began his career in January, 1928 as a page for NBC radio, eventually rising to Vice President of News, Special Events, and Sports for ABC Television. During his career in radio and television, Mr. Velotta helped assemble and supervised some of the industry's most illustrious on-air commentators including Walter Winchell, Drew Pearson, Louella Parsons, and Paul Harvey to name but a few. While with ABC, Mr. Velotta also produced coverage of the national political conventions for 1948, 1952, 1956, and 1960.

description: JUST out of prison after five years, Percy Talbot, a young woman in need of healing, is ready to start her life afresh in Gilead, a mythical town in rural Wisconsin.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: IN OUR TIME: Memoir of a Revolution, by Susan Brownmiller. (Delta, $14.95.) More history than memoir, this reserved chronicle of the women's liberation movement in the late 1960's and 70's, written by the author of ''Against Our Will: Men, Women and Rape,'' is crammed with names, dates and facts. ''Brownmiller notes with well-earned satisfaction'' that ''the gains won by her generation of feminists were real and substantial,'' Laura Miller wrote in the Book Review in 1999.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-10-00: Time Line; Sour Grapes
description: Two days before Thanksgiving, the United Farm Workers union called off its 16-year boycott of California table grapes. To many supporters, it had been a touchstone of liberal politics, a cause with powerful symbolic value that had also achieved some practical results: winning better conditions for vineyard workers and putting pesticide hazards on the national agenda. Yet its passing, after all this time, went almost unnoticed. And growers say they barely felt the pinch.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-10-00: The Ethicist; Rolling in Dough
description: I found a roll of money in a restaurant restroom, presumably lost by another patron. I could (1) keep it, (2) ask the restaurant to return it if the owner comes looking or (3) leave it in place, figuring that the restaurant could not be trusted and that the restroom is where the rightful owner would look. I chose Option 3. Which would you choose? -- Michael Lewyn, Atlanta

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you didn't get your fill of giant killer worms in last week's Sci Fi production of ''Dune,'' try TREMORS (1990), a daringly deadpan sendup of the beastie genre. Kevin Bacon and other residents of a desolate Western town don't go for broad satire or even the reference-dropping of the ''Scream'' movies. They play it straight, 50's-style, making for a lot of sublimely silly moments. ''Is it a snake?'' one character says upon seeing what turns out to be a small piece of a mega-worm. ''Looks more like an eel,'' says another. And then they start bidding on it. EBay users, takenot.e The worms track the humans via vibrations in the ground, so walk softly and carry a big stick - Sunday at 6:30 p.m. on USA.

title: Barbara Brown, Jonathan Moss
description: Barbara Ann Brown and Jonathan Jed Moss are to be married today in Pearl River, N.Y., by Angelo J. Ingrassia, a retired State Supreme Court justice, at the Pearl River Hilton.

title: The Ins and Outs of Solid Counter Tops
description: IN the late 1960's, DuPont revolutionized the counter top when it introduced Corian. This was a different type of material because it was not made up of layers bonded together like the ubiquitous plastic laminate used for most counter tops. Corian was solid throughout, and for this reason manufacturers, dealers and installers referred to counters made from it as solid-surface. Soon other manufacturers like Avonite, Formica and Swan introduced their own versions.

title: A Show Born on the Road
description: FOR one brief, delirious moment, ''Barry Manilow's Copacabana: The Musical'' -- who could ask for a more elucidative title? -- is imaginable on Broadway. If the so-called legitimate theater can accommodate ''Aida,'' ''Footloose'' and ''Saturday Night Fever,'' why not the current stopover at the Shubert Theater in New Haven?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON IMBERT, ENRIQUE
description: ANDERSON IMBERT-Enrique, distinguished Argentine author and scholar, died in Buenos Aires, on December 6, 2000. Born February 12, 1910 in Cordoba, Arg., he immigrated to the US in 1947 as a result of the Peron regime with his wife, Margarita (Margot), and their two children. Prolific author of many collections of short stories, several novels and numerous essays and scholarly papers, he led a life dedicated to art and culture. Anderson was also Professor of Latin American Literature for many years at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor and the Victor Thomas Professor of Latin American Literature at Harvard University from 1965 until his retirement in 1980. He was a member of the Argentine Academy of Letters and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the recipient of many awards, most recently the honoree of the Dia de los Mayores Notables Argentinos on August 18, 2000. Anderson is survived by a daughter, Dr. Anabel Anderson Imbert of Oakland, CA, a son, Carlos Anderson of Meredith, NH, three grandchildren, Robert, Vanessa and Enrique, and two great-grandchildren, Alexandra and Christopher.

title: The Rewards And the Risks Of Playing an Icon
description: THE scene is a harrowing one. Judy Garland is sitting in a conference room in the early 1960's. Her television variety show is on the ropes. A smarmy CBS executive tells her that compared with other stars on the network, she makes the audience uncomfortable. ''Who makes them comfortable?'' she asks. The executive solemnly replies, ''Lassie.'' Garland says, wanly, ''I'm not Lassie.''

title: Word for Word/Dennis Miller Decoded; Veni, Vidi, Vici, Babe: Football for Eggheads
description: WHO says football fans have to be beer-swilling vidiots and layabouts? When the comedian Dennis Miller joined the broadcast team on ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' this season, he embarked on a crusade to inject a little high-brow into the no-brow, peppering his analysis with allusions to obscure actors, historical events and arcana like cosmic wormholes and the Italian-made bolt-action Mannlicher-Carcano rifle.

title: DOUGLAS GIVES NETS A LIFT
description: Earlier this season, Sherman Douglas arrived at the arena, slipped into his uniform and got taped and ready for that night's game, the same as he has for 12 National Basketball Association seasons. And for seven games this season, he sat, waiting and watching as Nets Coach Byron Scott looked to the bench for help and plucked someone else.

title: Building Atmosphere
description: THE Huntley Taverne has worked hard to earn that E at the end of its name. In French, ''taverne'' translates to something like ''wine bar,'' but the long and beautifully chosen wine list isn't the only impressive feature of this nine-month-old restaurant.

description: Rather than searching for what passes for suburbia's Holy Grail a parking space at the train station -- as she normally does, Ivy Schmerken followed the directions of the man in the red parka and left her car in the middle of the parking lot.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES LAWSUIT AGAINST IONA
description: Justice Muriel Hubsher of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday dismissed a $21 million suit brought against Iona College by a woman who claimed the school's negligence caused her son's alcohol overdose last year. The son, Kevin Lawless, 18, died last December after drinking at two bars while pledging a fraternity that had been banned. An autopsy revealed that he died from a combination of alcohol and a heart defect. Justice Hubsher said a college is not legally bound to guarantee the well-being of its students. The family is seeking $8 million in damages from each of the two pubs, Molly's Bar and Ketch 22 North in New Rochelle, where Mr. Lawless was drinking.

title: New Music Director for Boychoir
description: It is no small thing to find a music director for a concertizing group as important as the American Boychoir. Especially since James Litton, the sixth director, is such a tough act to follow. For 16 years, his young Princeton-based ensemble has been singing with orchestras, like the New York Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony. Even more numerous are its non-orchestral concerts in sacred and secular locales around the country, and it maintains a vigorous recording schedule, mainly for Angel.

title: The Neediest Cases; In a Confusing City, Providing Lifelines And Lessons for the Visually Impaired
description: Charlotte Buskey walks to the door of her apartment and calls to her dog, Tag. He obediently comes, eyebrows raised in expectation. Tag, a 2-year-old black Labrador retriever, is her guide dog. She straps a leather harness around his chest.

title: Lust for Life Thrives On a Shadowy Stage
description: IMAGINE some favorite puppet characters, like Kermit the Frog, Big Bird and Ms. Piggy, are captured by an invading nation and used to voice competing theologies and political policies. Sound a tad farfetched? Something similar actually happened on the island of Java 55 years ago when the ''Wayang Revolusie'' came to be.

description: Antawn Jamison was well on his way to Sam Bowie Infamy, forever to be known as the guy drafted before you-know-who.

title: Stretching Aloft
description: To the Editor: Congratulations to Betsy Wade for clarifying the facts about travel and congestion in ''Stretching for Safety Aloft'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 26). As a frequent long-distance traveler (I teach shiatsu internationally), I use a series of simple in-flight stretches to boost circulation and reduce jet lag.

title: Bowling, the Sport People Love to Hate
description: PARKER BOHN III may not be as familiar an athlete as, say, Tiger Woods, but he still gets recognized in restaurants and airports. Nowhere is he more revered, however, than at Howell Lanes, the local alley where the left-hander learned to bowl at the age of 8.

title: Waves of Low-Flying Planes Send Morale Even Lower
description: Residents of Park Slope say that low-flying jets approaching La Guardia Airport are an increasingly annoying problem and that they want aviation officials to reroute some planes. Officials, meanwhile, say that they want to address the situation but that a permanent answer could take years.

title: This Campus Is Being Simulated
description: A troubling aspect of online classes is that the full-time and tenured professors who give American universities their scholarly reputations, stability and character may largely be replaced with a few superstars and cadres of slave labor -- specifically, teaching assistants ''drawn from the vast pool of unemployed and underemployed graduate students and bearers of graduate degrees.'' Now, part-time teachers, who have doctoral or master's degrees and constitute much of the faculty, earn about $2,000 per course, for an annual income of $12,000 to $16,000. They have no benefits, no job security and no chance of promotion. Few possess the energy, funds or institutional support to develop scholarly reputations in their fields. The virtual university would exacerbate rather than correct this exploitative system. Let's hope that in the brave new world of online learning, the workers will turn to the old-fashioned tactic of union organization.

title: Temple Plan Raises Issue For Coalition In New Delhi
description: Eight years ago this week, Hindu militants tore down a 16th-century mosque with sledgehammers and crowbars. That act of aggression against a Muslim place of worship set off deadly riots in predominantly Hindu India -- and it continued to resonate ominously here in the capital this week.

description: A FAST-GROWING concept that its advocates say could change the face of housing on Long Island has attracted enthusiastic attention from planners and builders. The aim of the nationwide community-planning movement is to retain open space while allowing for population growth.

description: Following is the text of the ruling yesterday by the United States Supreme Court to halt the hand recount in Florida and set Monday morning for arguments. The vote in George W. Bush v. title: The Mighty, Blighted Hudson
description: Two-and-a-half million cubic yards of PCB-laden Hudson River mud is one mighty load of yuck. But that's what General Electric will face, along with a nearly $500 million pricetag, if an Environmental Protection Agency plan becomes final next year. The company, which owned factories in upstate New York that polluted the river, says that dredging up PCB's -- linked to cancer in humans -- would poison the Hudson all over again. The E.P.A. says that only removal will heal the river and its fish, which are still too laden with chemicals to be safely eaten. Kirk Johnson
