title: QUICK BITE/Princeton; Along with Sushi, Free Nicknames
description: ''Hey Squash Roll,'' Andrew Co, an owner of Sakura Express, calls when I enter his sushi restaurant. I'm Squash Roll because I harbor an antipathy toward anything raw and so opt for squash inside my sushi. I'm Squash Roll because Andrew and his brother and business partner, Albert, have nicknames for everyone. The sushi-making experience of Albert and Andrew Co is apparent; they have worked as sushi chefs since their first week in America nine years ago and they have owned Sakura Express for the last four years. Their humor -- tagging my always turned-out roommate High Maintenance or a Russian physicist the Russian Spy -- is equally apparent. Begun as an offshoot of Sakura House, a sit-down restaurant in Princeton Shopping Center that was owned by the Cos' aunt, Sakura Express is now an independent enterprise with a loyal following of its own. It's not big, with seating for 25 on stools at a few tables or along a windowsill counter. Andrew estimates that he knows 60 to 70 percent of the people who walk through the door. And a lot of people walk through the door; the brothers roll 900 pieces of sushi a day, spooning out 250 pounds of rice a week. Favorites include California rolls ($3.50 for six), salmon ($1.50 each) and yellowtail tuna ($1.75 each). For people squeamish about sushi (and for whom even squash won't do) there is chicken teriyaki ($4.95) and shrimp tempura ($5.95). Miso soup, salad and rice are available as sides. The brothers have a way of occasionally making the cost of a soup or salad disappear from the tab of one of their regular customers, the ones with nicknames. Anne Ruderman

title: Comverse's Earnings Set Record for Quarter
description: Comverse Technology Inc. (Nasdaq: CMVT) has announced that its third quarter net income grew 52 percent to a record $68.4 million, compared with $45 million in the third quarter last year. The Woodbury company, which manufactures wireless network products, also reported record sales for the quarter of $318 million.

title: CONFIRMED
description: Mario A. Paparozzi, who teaches criminal justice at the College of New Jersey, will get a chance to put his academic theories into practice. The senate last week confirmed his appointment by Governor Whitman as the new chief of the embattled state parole board. Dr. Paparozzi has been an advocate of tougher standards for parolees and for systematizing the state's often chaotic parole review process. One of the tasks awaiting Dr. Paparozzi will be to deal with a prisoner advocacy group, which last week urged inmates and families to object to a tentative agreement intended to reduce a backlog of prisoners waiting for parole hearings. The parole board was criticized this year when the state attorney general's office determined thousands of prisoners were waiting months past their eligibility dates before receiving hearings. Karen DeMasters

title: First, Job and Family, Then a Rock Band
description: CONVENTION has it that it takes a rebellious streak to start a band and put up with the long hours in the studio and the late nights on the road. But Peter Spink took on the rigors of a musician's life only after meeting the right woman, getting married, starting a family and taking on a mortgage.

description: EMPLOYEES at the Sony store here say they are shocked and angered by the recent brutal murder of a beloved companion. But it is of some consolation that the victim's camera can be replaced and its neck rebuilt with glue.

description: THE Ladies Village Improvement Society is probably the most venerable civic group in East Hampton. The organization was founded 105 years ago to ensure that Main Street, then a dirt road, was sprinkled to keep down the dust. The society's headquarters, the restored Gardiner Brown House, is a village landmark on Main Street.

As Director of Special Projects at The Juilliard School, she was a good friend to us, assisting in immeasurable ways in our collaboration with the School. Our condolences to her family and to all of her friends and colleagues whose lives were touched by her thoughtful and nurturing spirit. Marilyn Horne

title: Coming to America to Learn a Secret: Boldness

And that is exactly what is worrying the Swiss government, which has watched in dismay as America's brash young executives spawn the hot companies and vast wealth of the new economy.

description: The Senate Environment Committee passed and sent to the Budget and Appropriations Committee a bill last week that would require drinking water supplied to a home from a private well to be subject to a quality test before the home was sold. From 300,000 to 400,000 homes in the state get water from private wells. Anne Ruderman

title: Black and White And Loved All Over
description: Of all the attempts of the Chinese Communist government to win over Washington, none has attracted so much advance good will as the delivery of two sad-eyed giant pandas named Mei Xiang and Tian Tian. China will receive $1 million a year from the National Zoo, where officials expect the pair will become an instant star attraction and hope they will relax enough to produce the viable offspring that eluded their predecessors, the late Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing. Francis X. Clines

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, CAROL J.
description: STEVENS-Carol J. Of New York City and East Hampton. Died on December 5 in New York-Cornell Hospital of ALS. Carol was a warm, insightful, giving person and a source of strength and support to her many friends. These traits also pervaded her professional life. After receiving an M.A. in education from the University of Massachusetts, she briefly taught school; but soon turned to social work as her career. She received an MSW from Fordham University and spent 25 years at St. Vincent's Services in Brooklyn, working first on the development of their Foster Boarding Program, and from 1980 to 1992, serving as Director of the Agency's Foster Care and Adoption Services. As the number of children served by St. Vincent's Services grew, she never lost sight of the individual entrusted to her care. Her Director's door was always open to those children and families in need of her counsel or intervention. Her friends will miss her caring nature, her ready response to their needs, her wise counsel and her fun-loving sense of humor. A gifted communicator and speaker, she was cruelly deprived of speech by her illness, but she adapted to the Internet to maintain contact with her friends and family, which was so important to her and to them. She showed immense bravery in the long course of her rare, incurable illness, fighting each day to maintain dignity and mastery of herself. She bore her illness without complaint or self-pity. Her caring extended to the plight of animals. She was an advocate for the protection of Carriage Horses in New York City. In her honor, donations may be made to the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 Twenty-Fourth St., NW, Washington, DC 20037. Carol leaves a brother, Dr. William Schwartz of Los Angeles; a niece, Laurie Schwartz, and nephew, Dr. Eric Schwartz of Boston; and dear friends Helen Morris, Ann Davis and Josh of New York City. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Life After Death Row
description: It has been 20 months since Ronald Keith Williamson was exonerated and freed from death row in Oklahoma, where he spent the better part of nine years pacing back and forth in his 9-by-11-foot cell, screaming that he did not rape and kill a young woman in a town called Ada. Ravaged by mental illness and the anguish of his time in prison, he is unable to hold a job and lives in a group home in Oklahoma City.

Stricter gun laws may have prevented Eddie Vaughn from amassing his arsenal. However, the death toll might have been higher had Fred Capps not had a loaded and (I'm sure) licensed gun nearby. His wife and children would certainly not be alive today.

description: NORV TURNER, his job as the Washington Redskins' head coach hanging by a chin strap last month, called Eddie Murray, the former field-goal kicker, to help save his job. Murray, 44, came out of retirement and, it turned out, was unintentionally instrumental in getting Turner fired. The dismissal occurred last Monday.

title: Corrections

title: Running With the Herd: Kenya on Horseback

Behind me lay a long, broad, grassy plain reminiscent of Anywhere, U.S.A. -- western Kansas or Nebraska, central Nevada, even West Texas. Yet bordering the edge of this plain stood clumps of thorny acacia trees, and behind that the shadowy Loita Hills of Kenya, their contours increasingly revealed as the sun rose.

title: Sleep, The Final Luxury
description: SHERWIN HARRIS, a New York art director, has turned his bedroom into a kind of twilight zone, a blue-lighted decompression chamber filled with sleep-inducing props. They include a feather bed, indigo sheets and slate blue walls, a collection of silk brocade eye masks and even a hand-held computer that reminds him when it's time to hit the sack. ''I've created this cloud to fall into, the right environment for sleep,'' Mr. Harris said, adding wearily, ''The twist is that I never actually get there.''

Then a 10-year battle with esophageal cancer left him too weak to talk. At 61, after multiple surgeries and countless hospital stays, he was determined to spend his final days in the five-room converted trailer that he had built himself. Around-the-clock support from his wife, Lillian, and Kim Boyce, then a nurse from the Hospice Care Corporation of Kingwood, W. Va., made his last wish possible.

description: IF the International Monetary Fund gave grades to its major borrower nations, Turkey and Argentina probably would have received mostly A's this year.

description: FRIDAY is a big day for Brad Glick. Dec. 15 is the date when he and thousands more Long Island high school seniors expect a letter telling them whether they were accepted to the colleges of their choice under the ''early decision'' plan.

She signed the document as she sat in the waiting room of the hospital, and then handed it back to the messenger who had brought it from the lawyer's office. Somone has to sift through miles of old tapes, track down information and assemble scattered photographs and memorabilia and anecdotes. They've been busy again this year, culling material from the few name-brand groups that haven't already been anthologized and coming up with compilation concepts that are studiously historical or downright whimsical.

title: HELP WITH HEATING BILLS
description: Applications for the county-administered Home Energy Assistance Program are being accepted to help eligible individuals and families pay their home-heating bills. Last winter, 11,035 Westchester households were helped by the federal program, receiving almost $1 million in aid. Public assistance recipients and food stamp recipients should contact their Social Services District Office. Others can call Westchester Community Opportunities Program at (914) 592-5600. The elderly, disabled and Social Security recipients should call the Westchester County Office for the Aging at (914) 665-5900. Households not receiving public assistance may be eligible for home-heating assistance if their gross monthly income for a family of four, for example, falls at or below $2,857.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-10-00; Mascaragate 2000
description: What with the fate of the union hanging in the balance, you could be forgiven for missing one of the stranger sideshows of Election 2000: the catty contretemps over Katherine Harris's makeup. There is nothing in Mascaragate that casts any light whatsoever on the status of the Electoral College or even of the dimpled chad. But in a funny kind of way it does reveal something surprising about America -- and how certain feminist arguments, once extreme, have wound their way into the most unlikely corners of our culture.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-10-00: Economics of: Fuel-Cell Cars; Ulterior Motors
description: The collapse of the climate talks in the Netherlands last month isn't likely to impede the development of easy-on-the-environment cars in this country. California is still requiring that 10 percent of the cars sold there be emission free by 2003, and Massachusetts and New York are adopting similar laws. All the big automakers are promising to sell so-called fuel-cell cars by 2004, but should we have to wait even that long? After all, fuel-cell technology -- which harnesses the energy released when hydrogen is combined with oxygen from the air (water instead of carbon dioxide is the byproduct) -- has been around for more than 150 years. Last month, both Ford and DaimlerChrysler showed off prototype cars powered by environment-friendly hydrogen. We could use those now: Americans are responsible for the release of more than two tons of vehicle-produced greenhouse gases a year per person. Bringing cleaner cars to the marketplace, however, has been fraught with obstacles.

title: Back to the Supreme Court
description: The United States Supreme Court did a disservice to the nation's tradition of fair elections by calling a halt to the recount of disputed ballots in Florida. The manual recount was progressing smoothly and swiftly Saturday in most parts of the state, with new votes being recorded for both Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. Indeed, the entire exercise was serving the core democratic principle that every legal vote should be counted and was also on the verge of solving the monthlong issue of which man actually got the greater number of valid votes. The stay abruptly imposed by five justices at midafternoon was an unwarranted intervention that could well deny the country its last chance to determine which candidate has the stronger title to the state's decisive 25 electors. The ruling, which looked highly political on its surface, could also damage the reputation of the Supreme Court for years to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THON, WILLIAM E.
description: THON-William E., 94, noted artist, died at his home in Port Clyde, ME, Wednesday after a brief illness. Born in New York City, August 8, 1906, Mr. Thon was a World War II veteran. He has resided in Port Clyde since the 1940's. For several years, Mr. Thon worked with Consolidated Edison Electric Company in New York City, where he met the love of his life Helen Elizabeth whom he married June 3, 1929 in New York City. Mrs. Thon died November 20, 1999. Having previously purchased land in Port Clyde, in 1946, the Thon's built their home in which Mr. Thon still resided. He enjoyed the closeknit community and considered his neighbors family. In 1947, Mr. Thon traveled to Rome, where he had been honored with Membership in the American Academy of Arts. While living in Rome, he traveled with his wife to Greece, Spain, Portugal, and Rhodes. With gradual loss of sight due to Macular Degeneration, Mr. Thon stated at the time of his wife's death that, ''In recent years, she became my eyes and during her illness, I became her strength.'' He found satisfaction in sharing his art with others, painting what he saw through his own eyes. Mr. Thon received the Prix de Rome in 1947 and in 1948 a Fellowship from The American Academy of Arts and Letters. Among his numerous awards are First Prize from the Brooklyn Museum in 1941 and 1944, distinctions from The National Academy of Design, Gold Medals from the American Watercolor Society in 1970 and 1978, State of Maine Award and Citation from Governor Kenneth Curtis in 1970, and a Silver Medal from The Audobon Society in 1986. Mr. Thon's paintings are represented in many public and private collections including The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Brooklyn Museum, The Hirshhorn Museum, The High Museum, The Whitney Museum, The Butler Art Institute and The Columbus Museum of Art. His work has been featured in solo exhibitions at The Smith College Museum of Art, The Fort Wayne Museum, Bates College, The Farnsworth Art Museum and in many group exhibitions throughout the United States. Described by his primary caregiver Ms. Heidi Stevens, as a true gentleman, Mr. Thon enjoyed sailing his friendship sloop ''Echo'', with his neighbor Harriet Dennon. Several nieces and nephews survive Mr. Thon. Funeral services were held in Maine. Call Burpee-Strong Funeral Home, Rockland, for more information. Memorial donations may be made in his name to Maine College of Arts, 97 Spring Street, Portland, ME 04101.

title: AMERICAN SKIING SET TO ACQUIRE MERISTAR HOTELS
description: The American Skiing Company, an owner and operator of ski resorts based in Newry, Me., said it had agreed to acquire MeriStar Hotels and Resorts and rename the combined company Doral International. Shareholders of MeriStar Hotels will receive 1.88 American Skiing shares for each share of MeriStar they own, a ratio that, at the time the deal was announced, valued MeriStar shares at $5.17 a share, or $185.5 million, more than double its market value at Friday's closing price of $2.25. But word of the deal changed the valuations sharply: American Skiing shares fell 75 cents yesterday to close at $2 a share, cutting the value of the deal to $3.76 a share, or $135 million. MeriStar Hotels, which gained 44 cents to close at $2.69, runs 106 hotels owned by a real estate investment trust, MeriStar Hospitality. American Skiing will also assume $95.2 million in debt.

title: Nine Votes for History
description: All but lost in the pinched legalisms dwelled on by the Supreme Court in yesterday's oral arguments was any sign that the court has its eye on the lodestar that should guide the resolution of the presidential election. Now, as in the beginning of this matter, every ballot in which the intent of the voter can be determined should be counted. On earlier occasions when equally momentous national issues came before the Supreme Court, the sort of detailed legal and constitutional debate that unfolded yesterday over the Florida vote might merely have been the prologue to a landmark ruling that guided American society to higher ground, like the 1954 school desegregation decision. That can still be the case here, if the justices have the wisdom and vision to look beyond the tangled circumstances in Florida and shape a decision about extracting the people's verdict from the nearly six million votes cast in Florida.

In return, Peregrine will take on more than 1,000 customers of Tivoli, which I.B.M. bought in 1996 for $743 million, and enter a sales partnership with I.B.M. Global Services. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Federal Jury in Antitrust Suit Says M.L.S. Is Not a Monopoly
description: A federal jury in Boston found yesterday that Major League Soccer is not an illegal monopoly that has conspired for five years to restrain player salaries.

title: Delta Is Turned Down on Restraining Order
description: A federal judge declined today to grant a temporary restraining order to Delta Air Lines against its pilots' union, saying the link between the union and a possible work slowdown by pilots was too weak.

title: BRITISH AIR TRAVEL INCREASES
description: With Britain's rail services in disarray because of accidents, track repairs, delays and flooding, BAA P.L.C., the operator of Heathrow, Gatwick and five other British airports, said passenger traffic at its airports rose by 5.6 percent last month to 9.1 million, mainly reflecting a rise in domestic air travel. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Deregulation Called Blow To Minorities
description: The 1996 landmark law that was warmly embraced by the Clinton administration and many Republicans as a way to begin deregulating the nation's telecommunications industry has had the unintended effect of raising substantial new barriers for companies controlled by minorities and women, new independent studies commissioned by the federal government have found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, BETTY
description: GORDON-Betty. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. mourns the passing of our beloved member Betty Gordon. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband Herman and family. Rabbi Alan Lucas Rose Schecter, President

title: Marvin Leath, 69, Ex-Congressman
description: Marvin Leath, a conservative Democrat with an interest in military affairs who served six terms as a congressman from Central Texas, died on Friday at a hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 69 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Purchase Nearly Completes Land Acquisition for 2-State Park
description: A 15-year effort by environmental groups and government agencies to create Sterling Forest State Park from vast tracts of woodlands, trails, streams and lakes 40 miles northwest of New York City was all but completed yesterday with the acquisition of one of the last parcels of coveted private land.

title: A Slugging Shortstop To Get $252 Million
description: Alex Rodriguez, the slugging free-agent shortstop, was signed by the Texas Rangers yesterday to a 10-year contract worth $252 million. The deal doubles the previous richest pact for a professional athlete, the six-year, $126 million deal that Kevin Garnett received from the Minnesota Timberwolves of the National Basketball Association.

title: Excerpts From Arguments Before Supreme Court on the Florida Recount
description: Following are excerpts from oral arguments before the Supreme Court yesterday on the Florida vote recount, as recorded by The New York Times. The lawyers questioned were Theodore B. Olson, for the Bush campaign; Joseph P. Klock Jr., for Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris; and David Boies, for the Gore campaign.

title: Bishop of Long Island, James T. McHugh, Is Dead at 68
description: Less than a year after becoming the spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.4 million Roman Catholics, Bishop James Thomas McHugh, an anti-abortion leader, died Sunday at his residence in Rockville Centre. He was 68.

title: Lycee Francais Will Build a School on a Site in the 70's East of York Avenue
description: The Lycee Francais of New York has found the site for a new home on the Upper East Side, allowing the French primary and secondary school to move eventually from the six old houses it currently occupies in the neighborhood to a modern school building near the East River.

title: Late Start for Arnott Doesn't Slow Him Down
description: Jason Arnott, whose face is locked in a perpetual scowl and whose voice never rises above a subway grumble, went to his linemates a month ago and quietly asked for a favor. He asked them to be patient with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLARD, KATHARINE T.
description: VILLARD-Katharine T. On December 6th, 2000, of New York City, N.Y. Mrs. Villard was born at Seagate, N.Y. on August 18, 1904. She was preceded in death by her husband the late Vincent Serrano Villard, Sr., and a son Vincent Serrano Villard, Jr. She was the daughter of Calvin Tomkins, former N.Y.C. Dock Commissioner and Kittie Neilley Tomkins. She graduated from the Ethel Walker School, and Bryn Mawr College, 1926. A member the Cosmopolitan Club since 1931, she lived in Manhattan all her life, and for many years maintained a country home in Tomkins Cove, N.Y. Survivors include two daughters Mariquita Villard Vitzthum, of Putney, Vermont, Katharine Neilley Villard, of New Hampton, NH; and four grandchildren: Catherine LeGouis, Jeanne Baufils, Louise LeGouis, and Stephen Villard Seckinger. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the charity of your choice.

description: All roads, they said, lead to Rome, and so they did. The proof is right there on the map, one of 99 representations of the landscape of antiquity in a new atlas of the Greek and Roman world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, STANLEY
description: SCHECHTER-Stanley. Jeffrey Citron, Pres. Marvin Leffler, Secretary

description: Morgan Stanley Capital International has announced changes in the way it calculates its widely watched worldwide stock indexes, a move that could cause billions of dollars in investments to shift.

title: RENONG-UNITED DEAL TO BE REVERSED
description: Halim Saad, the chairman of one of Malaysia's most indebted companies, Renong Bhd., said he would honor a promise made to irate minority shareholders in Renong's toll-road-operating unit, United Engineers Malaysia Bhd., by buying back 31 percent of the parent company's stock from the subsidiary for 3.16 billion ringgit ($833 million). To quell an outcry over the deal that placed the Renong shares in United's hands in 1997, Mr. Saad gave United a put option for three and a half years to unwind the deal; his offer would liquidate it in stages through 2002.

title: 2 Agencies Make High-Level Changes
description: Two agencies are making high-level personnel changes.

description: In one of the largest takeovers of a biotechnology company, Shire Pharmaceuticals of Britain agreed yesterday to pay $4 billion in stock to acquire BioChem Pharma, maker of the AIDS drug 3TC.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: John Reed; Running Hot in Pursuit of Cancer Treatment
description: It is not easy keeping up with Dr. John C. Reed. For two years running, Dr. Reed, the scientific director of the Burnham Institute, a cancer research center here, has been No. 1 on a list of scientists ranked by the number of ''hot papers'' they have published.

description: There were funerals here this weekend for a Protestant taxi driver and a Catholic construction worker killed in tit-for-tat sectarian murders, grim evidence on the eve of President Clinton's return to the province that the promise of the peace settlement he helped broker is still far from fulfilled.

title: Pinochet Wins Round in Court But More Hurdles Lie Ahead
description: A Chilean Appeals Court today dismissed kidnapping and murder charges filed against the former dictator Augusto Pinochet and reversed an order placing him under house arrest. But an appeal was immediately filed in Supreme Court, which will decide on the matter in the next few weeks.

title: Talks by Irish Executive to Buy Stake in Eircom Break Down
description: Talks have broken down between Eircom P.L.C., Ireland's former state telecommunications company, and the Irish businessman Paul Coulson, who had been negotiating with the company and KPN of the Netherlands about acquiring KPN's 21 percent stake in Eircom.

description: Thomson Multimedia of France confirmed that it had agreed to acquire the Technicolor film processing unit of Carlton Communications P.L.C. of Britain for $2.07 billion in cash and stock, at the high end of analysts' expectations. Thomson S.A., the state-owned electronics conglomerate, owns slightly more than half of Thomson Multimedia, which makes consumer electronics under the RCA and other brands. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Tale of Piracy: How the Chinese Stole the Grinch
description: The Grinch may be stealing Christmas on movie screens across America, but Chinese copyright pirates have already done him one better: they've stolen the Grinch here.

title: When Stress Erodes Vaccine Benefits
description: Adding new evidence that stress can be a wide-ranging threat to human health, researchers have found that elderly people under emotional pressure when they receive pneumonia vaccinations seem to reap less benefit from the shots.

title: FRANCE MAY TRIM AIRLINE STAKE
description: The French government is considering giving up majority control of Air France, a step it vowed never to take, to help the airline forge a link with Alitalia, Bloomberg News reported, citing an unidentified source. The report said the government was seeking advice on whether to reduce its 56 percent stake because the Italian government, which intends to sell its 53 percent stake in Alitalia, resists alliances between Alitalia and state-controlled companies. Analysts said that such an alliance was vital to either carrier's ability to compete with the Lufthansa-led Star Alliance and that Alitalia's talks with Swissair were faltering.

title: HARTZ MOUNTAIN NEGOTIATING WITH POTENTIAL BUYER
description: J.W. Childs Associates, a buyout group that owns consumer products brands like Mr. Bubble, NutraSweet and Personna razor blades, is negotiating to buy Hartz Mountain Industries, the marketer of pet supplies, according to federal filings. Hartz is closely held; its chairman, Leonard Stern, put the company up for sale in July, and the proposed merger received clearance from the Federal Trade Commission last week. Financial terms were not disclosed. Hartz Mountain's sales are about $300 million, analysts say.

title: Committees Approve Resolutions Allowing Florida Lawmakers to Name Electors
description: One day before federal law calls for each state to settle its presidential contest, Florida's Republican-controlled Legislature moved a step closer to appointing its own slate of electors for George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIWEL, HENRY
description: FEIWEL-Henry. Husband of the late Maria Feiwel. Father of Patricia, Jean and Larry. Uncle of Ren, Robert, Toni and Ray. Art lover, art maker, businessman, passed away peacefully on December 11. Services Friday, 3:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison.

title: Shining Through the Veils and Mist of 'Pelleas'
description: ''Pelleas et Melisande'' as a symphonic concert follows Debussy's only opera to its logical conclusion. The Cleveland Orchestra had this in mind on Saturday night at Severance Hall here when it placed squarely before us the piece's most important element, the orchestra itself.

description: METTER-Rose M. Beloved wife of Harold. Devoted mother of Andrew and Joel and mother-in-law of Wendy and Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Jordan and Daniel. title: Arts Abroad; Have You Seen This Woman?
description: Museums rarely lose works of art, particularly nine-foot-high sculptures. But that, says the French-American artist Niki de Saint Phalle, is precisely what the Pompidou Center in Paris has done with one of her famous Nanas. And thereby hangs a Hanover tale.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; Haiti's Battles Idle an Army of Tourist Guides
description: A teenager scrambled into the street near a downtown hotel, waving his slender arms at an oncoming car as if he were guiding an airplane to the gate. As the driver, a foreigner, parked and stepped from the car, the young man trotted out about all the English he knows.

title: To Cuban Roots Add Modern, Making It Look Easy
description: Ballet Hispanico has found a very promising new choreographer in Pedro Ruiz, whose new ''Club Havana'' was performed by the company on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater. Mr. Ruiz is a 15-year member of the troupe, and ''Club Havana,'' only his second major piece, is imbued with the company's personality and history. But what gives one such hope for Mr. Ruiz's future as a choreographer is his ease and lack of assumption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRATCH, ROSE
description: DRATCH-Rose. On December 9th. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Dear mother of Barbara and Stephen. Loving grandmother of Cary, Samantha, Brian, Adam and Lindsay and great-grandmother of Lindsey. Graveside service was held on Monday, December 11th at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: PITNEY BOWES TO SPIN OFF COPY AND FAX MACHINES
description: Pitney Bowes, known for postage meters, said yesterday that it would spin off its copier and fax machine business, which has annual sales of $700 million, to shareholders. With slow growth and shrinking profit margins in a competitive field, the unit's operating profit fell about 30 percent in the third quarter. Pitney Bowes shares fell 44 cents, to $29.94. The new company will continue using the Pitney Bowes trademark and will be based in Trumbull, Conn.; the parent is based in Stamford, Conn.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PAY RAISE AT THE APOLLO
description: A month after winning the right to union representation as regular performers at the weekly ''Amateur Night at the Apollo,'' four musicians have received salary increases in a contract agreement between the union and the Harlem theater's management. Under the agreement, signed last week to cover Ray Chew and the Crew, Mr. Chew's pay is to rise to $650 a week from $450, said Heather Beaudoin, a spokeswoman for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. She said the increase would be in two stages, on Jan. 1, 2001 and Jan. 1, 2002. Pay for his three sidemen will similarly increase to $400 from $250, she said. They had had no raises in eight years with the show, she said. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Campaign Touts the Benefits of Folic Acid
description: In the 1980's, federal health officials published a map of sorts that set off alarm bells in South Carolina.

title: SHELL SAYS HOSTILE BID IN AUSTRALIA FARING WELL
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that investors were responding favorably to its hostile bid for Woodside Petroleum, an Australian oil company. The offer, for 14.8 Australian dollars ($8.07) a share or 6.5 billion dollars ($3.5 billion) for the shares it does not already own, is the first part of a two-stage proposal by Shell to raise its stake in Woodside from 34 percent to 56 percent. Woodside has been campaigning against the bid, which is Shell's second. An earlier bid was rejected by Woodside's non-Shell directors.

title: As Florida Goes . . .
description: While the Supreme Court may ultimately determine the fate of this election, Florida's Legislature is determining the destiny of future presidential contests.

title: Moynihan to Take a Post at Syracuse School of Public Affairs
description: When he leaves the Senate early next month, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will join the faculty of the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, John L. Palmer, the school's dean, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTO, DAISY M.
description: PORTO-Daisy M. Our mother's valiant struggle against lung cancer came to a peaceful end on November 29, 2000. To her children Emilie O'Sullivan and Ben E. Porto, she bequeaths a legacy of a passionate love of life and a commitment never to acknowledge the threat of defeat. To the treasures of her life, grandsons Brad and Ryan O'Sullivan and Joseph and Brian Porto, she imparts endless love and affection. The boys will always cherish her stirring example of courage that belied her petite stature. It is a very difficult void to fill, but her show of consistent strength and grace in the face of great adversity will give them an abundance of enduring and inspirational memories. She leaves behind a sister, Gloria Bianchi, her daughter-in-law Jean Anne Celebrezze Porto and her grandson Joseph's wife, Annie Thompson Porto. As a family we find consolation in her reunion with her beloved husband, Joe. She will now realize all the happiness she gave to so many others. Under the watchful eye of Dr. Mark Kris, her life was extended with quality. Please make contributions in her memory to Lung Cancer Research Fund, #

title: NEWSPRINT COMPANY REJECTS DEMAND TO REPLACE CHIEF
description: Abitibi-Consolidated, a newsprint maker, said yesterday that a panel of its directors rejected as unacceptable a demand by a major shareholder, Quebecor, that the company's chief executive, John Weaver, be dismissed. Quebecor, which owns 11 percent of Abitibi, has been calling for the replacement of Mr. Weaver by a former chairman of Abitibi, Michel Desbiens, since late October. Quebecor says Abitibi has failed to take full advantage of rising newsprint prices.

title: Jets Try to Forget Rout And Focus on the Lions
description: Al Groh persuaded himself this morning not to dwell on the Jets' 31-7 debacle in Oakland, and then turned his attention to Sunday's game against the Detroit Lions.

title: Old Evidence Resurfaces, Unsettling '82 Murder Case
description: A grisly crime shocked this small town nearly 19 years ago. A 75-year-old widow, Dorothy Ely Edwards, who grew up riding horses, studied music in college and took up painting in her 50's, was raped and murdered, stabbed 52 times, her body, clothed only in her robe, dumped in her bedroom closet.

title: Official Bowing Out Of Governor's Race
description: Buster Soaries will not be running for governor after all.

title: Partner Said to Seek Buyout From News Corp.
description: Rupert Murdoch's partner in a family entertainment cable channel is expected to ask Mr. Murdoch's company, the News Corporation, to buy him out later this month.

title: QUALCOMM TAKING $80 MILLION CHARGE
description: Qualcomm said yesterday that it would take an $80 million charge after losing an arbitration ruling by the International Chamber of Commerce in favor of the Korean Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute. The chamber ruled that Qualcomm must share royalties, in addition to interest and costs from the arbitration, related to a technological development agreement reached with the South Korean institute in 1992. The ruling is a setback for Qualcomm in South Korea, the largest market abroad for its code division multiple access wireless technology. Qualcomm's shares fell $3.75, to $99.50. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Marbury To Return To Lineup Tonight
description: The gym walls were already decked with holiday cheer for the Nets' annual Boys and Girls Club party this evening.

title: Taking a Beach House? Check Out the Neighbors
description: The setting of ''Icarus'' is an affluent beach neighborhood, ostensibly in Los Angeles, but it might as well be the bleak and empty landscape occupied by Lucky and Pozzo. It is, after all, a kind of limbo in which the characters, a sampling of unfortunate souls, wait for something to happen so that life can be different and meaningful. The play, by Edwin Sanchez, is a tender comic fable that draws its humor from tying the flailing existential optimism of Samuel Beckett's most famous creations to tinsel-thin celebrity dreams; there's a ''Waiting for Spielberg'' quality that carries with it a societal lament.

title: A Practical Tool, but Puzzling Too
description: What is the greatest mystery in physics today? Different physicists have different answers. My candidate for greatest mystery is a question now a century old, "How come the quantum?"

title: U.S. Envoy Tackles Objections To Tribunal on War Crimes
description: When the Clinton administration's special envoy on war crimes wrapped up his last negotiating session on the formation of an International Criminal Court last week, he left on the table a new proposal intended to assuage fears of Americans opposed to the court.

title: Accounts
description: National Association for Variable Annuities, Ralston, Va., to Avrett, Free Ginsberg, New York, part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, to handle creative duties for a national campaign to build awareness of variable annuity retirement plans. Spending for the account, which had been handled in-house, was estimated at $12 million to $13 million.

title: Rodriguez Strikes It Rich in Texas
description: When Tom Hicks, the owner of the Texas Rangers, met with the free-agent shortstop Alex Rodriguez two weeks ago, a baseball official said recently, he ''fell in love'' with Rodriguez and told Rodriguez's agent that he would do whatever was necessary to sign him. Today, Hicks did as he vowed, giving Rodriguez the most lucrative contract ever for a professional athlete -- a 10-year deal for $252 million.

title: Hershey Names Dieste For Hispanic Ads
description: Hershey Foods in Hershey, Pa., said yesterday that it had named Dieste & Partners in Dallas, an affiliate of the Omnicom Group, as its first agency of record to create ads for its candy, confections and grocery brands aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers.

Over five hours, the Mets announced four moves that were completed over the last three days. TYLER KEPNER

title: Black Robes With Humans Inside Them
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  If there was any good humor left in the nation after five weeks of enormous dispute and doubt about its next leader, the Supreme Court was quick to mine that possibility when one of the day's anxious appellants made a factual error and, with all due deference, began misidentifying judges as he pleaded for their sympathy.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SUPERMARKET SALE APPROVED
description: The sale of 185 of 197 Grand Union Company supermarkets to C&S Wholesale Grocers has been approved by a federal bankruptcy judge in Newark. Bankruptcy Judge Novalyn L. Winfield last week authorized the sale of Grand Union of Wayne, N.J., to C&S of Brattleboro, Vt., for $301.8 million. C&S bid jointly with six supermarket chains at a Nov. 16 auction. The chains are: Stop & Shop Supermarket Company and Tops Market, both units of Koninklijke Ahold; Shaw's Supermarket, a unit of J Sainsbury; Pathmark Stores; Price Chopper, a Pathmark unit; and Hannaford Brothers Company, a unit of Delhaize America. Grand Union has stores in Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the summit meeting of the European Union compared the Netherlands and Belgian populations incorrectly in some copies. The Netherlands, with about 16 million, has about 60 percent more people than Belgium. (Belgium does not exceed the Netherlands by 50 percent.)

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile yesterday about Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, who is reviewing the merger of America Online and Time Warner, misstated the middle initial of the former New York governor who was a co-counsel on Mr. Pitofsky's first antitrust case as a lawyer. He was Thomas E. Dewey, not D.

title: NO BIDDING WAR FOR ABBEY

title: AMD WARNS OF WEAKER SALES
description: As further evidence of an all-around bad quarter for computer-related companies, Advanced Micro Devices said yesterday that fourth-quarter sales and profit would miss forecasts because of weak demand for personal computers. AMD said profit would be 50 cents to 60 cents a share, missing the 68-cent average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Sales will show little change from the October quarter, the company said. After AMD's main rival in PC chip making, Intel, said last week that fourth-quarter sales would change little from the previous period, some analysts expected AMD to be next.

Grandmother of Nathan, Misha, and Raphael. Also leaves behind daughters-inlaw Emily and Liza and son-in-law Jed. Susan was a teacher of English and mentor to a generation of students at Jamaica High School, and an advocate for Soviet Jewry. title: General Motors to Announce Plans for Oldsmobile's Future
description: With sales at its Oldsmobile division crumbling despite major discounts, General Motors scheduled a satellite broadcast by its chairman to its dealers on Tuesday morning to announce G.M.'s plans for the division, prompting speculation that the automaker might reorganize or even gradually eliminate the division.

title: Global Effort to Make Machines That Make Chips
description: A decade ago, when a Japanese company sought to acquire a Silicon Valley operation making crucial equipment for semiconductor manufacturing, the prospect was treated in this country as a threat to national security. Chip industry executives and politicians feared that the sale would touch off a chain of events ending an era of American technological supremacy.

title: Vodafone Said to Seek Japan Deal
description: The Vodafone Group is in talks to buy 15 percent of Japan Telecom for about $2.5 billion in a move that would give it an edge over its rival British Telecommunications as the two maneuver for greater control of the company, Japan's third-largest telecommunications operator, people involved in the discussions said today.

title: Death Penalty Doubts
description: President Clinton's decision last week to delay the execution of Juan Raul Garza for six months pending further study of troubling racial and geographic disparities in the federal death penalty system was a small but significant act of conscience. Mr. Garza, a confessed murderer who had been scheduled to die by lethal injection this morning, would have been the first federal prisoner put to death in 37 years.

title: ORACLE OFFERING SOFTWARE TOOLS ONLINE
description: Oracle continued its charge into the Web-based services arena by announcing that it will make two of its popular programs for Internet developers available online. Oracle said the two free programs, which allow companies to create and maintain Internet portals and wireless applications, would give customers access to Oracle's services from any computer without having to download the software onto specific machines. Mark Verbeck, a senior research analyst with Epoch Partners, an investment firm in San Francisco, said the shift to free services would encourage developers to create programs for Oracle's platform. In its announcement, Oracle challenged Microsoft directly, saying it planned to use the new programs to outpace Microsoft as the company developers would turn to. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Ford Issues Recall Over Speed Controls
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today the recall of 110,633 Ford Explorer and Mercury Mountaineer sport utility vehicles because a poorly programmed computer chip in the engines fails to limit the vehicles' top speed. The automaker also said that the vehicles' top speed is higher than previously disclosed even when the chip is working.

title: The Giants Lose Jurevicius for at Least a Month

title: Peace in the Horn of Africa

Horrific trench combat reminiscent of World War I has claimed the lives of between 75,000 and 100,000 conscripts. The two countries, among the poorest on earth, have squandered more than $1 billion on arms, enriching profiteers from Russia and Bulgaria to China and North Korea while impoverishing their own people.

description: At 85 and in poor health, Augusto Pinochet probably faces a future of endless courtroom battles. His lawyers can very likely delay a trial for months, if not years, and human rights activists concede that their dream of seeing the former dictator behind bars will probably never come true.

title: Part of Drug Battle: Keeping It in Stores
description: Critics of the Food and Drug Administration have argued that the agency has been allowing drugs to be rushed into use since a 1992 law enabled speedier reviews. A case in point is that of Odell Buggs, a 28-year-old counselor who suffered a stroke that her doctors attributed to an ingredient in her over-the-counter decongestant, Tavist-D. She sued the manufacturer, the pharmaceutical giant Novartis A.G., saying its cold pills had left her with brain damage. Novartis, based in Switzerland, had a strong defense: the ingredient, phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, was in dozens of cold remedies, as well as appetite suppressants, and had been taken in billions of doses with no ill effects. The Buggs case offers a glimpse into how companies marketing PPA worked aggressively to assuage concerns about the safety of a drug that for six decades was a staple in American medicine cabinets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, SUSAN G.

Levy intends to propose a major change next week in the programs offered to students in bilingual education, allowing some to take intensive classes in English that would put them into mainstream classes more rapidly, school officials familiar with the plan said yesterday.

title: SOUTHWEST AIR TO REDUCE TRAVEL AGENT COMMISSIONS
description: Citing pressures to restrain costs, the Southwest Airlines Company said it would join the rest of the industry and reduce the commission it pays travel agents to 5 percent, from 10 percent for paper tickets and 8 percent for electronic tickets, as soon as a 1995 agreement with the American Society of Travel Agents expires Dec. 31. Most other airlines trimmed commissions to 5 percent last year, and many imposed caps of $50 on domestic round trips and $100 on international round trips. Southwest's new commission rates include a $30 cap on one-way fares and $60 on round trips.

title: This Year The Thought Does Count; It's Not Just a Doll, It's Sort of a, Well, Philanthropic Concept

This year, in an unusual move, the store based its window story on a new book, ''One Enchanted Christmas,'' put out by a doll company called Little Souls Inc.

description: My day begins when the alarm goes off at 3:30 a.m. I once found myself showering with my socks on. I catch a ride at 4:15, stop for a cup of coffee and a bagel and am at my desk by 4:30 when I skim through six newspapers and log onto the Internet. As I ate, she told tales of her own childhood at the turn of the century in Augsburg, Germany. My favorite described how her mother -- my grandmother Lina Bernheim Nathan -- taught her and her older sister, Trudel, to bake cookies, kuchen and gugelhupf in an electric toy stove with miniature cooking molds.

The Officers, staff and members of the Newspaper Guild of New York mourn the passing of Tom Keenan, who served as a champion of working people during his many years of involvement in our Union. In addition to working as a Local Representative, Tom served seven terms as Guild Chairperson at The New York Times Unit with great determination and integrity. His wide smile and friendly handshake will be terribly missed by all those who were honored to know him. Barry F. Lipton, President William J. O'Meara, Secy/Treas. Peter Szekely, Local Chairperson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAINMAN, ANNE
description: STAINMAN-Anne. Beloved wife of Sam, mother of Arthur & Lois Stainman, and Terrie Bendorf. Grandmother of Evan, Susan, Robin, Mindy and Jesse. Friends may call in New York on Friday, 6:00-8:00 PM.

title: Argentina Picks Up Where France Left Off
description: NOT that long ago, the malbec grape seemed destined for history's scrap heap. Once, it was a staple of Bordeaux. Though never achieving the importance of cabernet sauvignon or merlot, it had a clear role to play in the annual blending of grapes.

title: Actor's Goal: To Make Kabuki Nothing to Snooze at
description: The average Kabuki performance is punctuated by the sounds of snores emanating from the audience. Highly mannered and slow-moving, with confusing plot twists laid out in archaic language, an afternoon or evening of Kabuki -- or, for that matter, its cousins Noh and bunraku, Japan's traditional puppet theater -- can be more akin to a session with a chiropractor than to entertainment.

title: Testifying in Killing Plot Trial, Judge Describes Other Threats
description: A state judge, taking the stand yesterday at the trial of a stockbroker charged with plotting to kill her, calmly testified that many defendants wanted her dead.

title: Plummeting, Then Soaring Up To Put Her Agony on Paper
description: ''Excuse me Miss, excuse me, can I walk you? Excuse me, excuse me Miss. . . .'' In ''Glory Goes and Gets Some,'' Emily Carter's new book of semi-autobiographical short stories, she describes her heroine, Glory, stumbling along East Houston Street high as a kite on drugs, as a descant of male voices calls after her: ''They honked and squealed, barked, drawled, groaned, purred, hissed, whispered and raggedly begged at me as I twitched down the street in a borrowed dress that was as red as the stoplights.''

title: No Field? Grow It In a Sunny Window
description: LEMON grass picked young, when it is dewy fresh and tender, is unlike anything you can buy in an American supermarket. It is much more intense, fragrant and flavorful. But as exotic as lemon grass may be to American gardens, it turns out to be as easy to grow as a weed.

title: For a Cold Winter Night, When They'd Rather Eat In
description: Peter Luger, the steakhouse in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn that has been in business since 1887, is just now getting around to selling steaks retail. But the steak lover on your gift list would probably consider the wait well worth it.

title: Sharp Elbows In Israel, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Hofstra Will Switch Conferences in 2003
description: Proclaiming that Hofstra could no longer ''sit and wonder'' about its future, Athletic Director Harry Royle said yesterday that the school -- led by its flagship men's basketball team -- will join the Colonial Athletic Association in the fall of 2003.

title: A Storied Nameplate Relegated to the Museum
description: If anyone might be expected to mourn the impending demise of the General Motors Oldsmobile division, it would be Peter Berusch, who not only owns 13 Olds cars, mostly convertibles, but also restores pre-1973 models at his shop in Lawrenceville, Ga. Still, the announcement left him unmoved.

description: Adapted from Sirichalerm Svasti

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS PLUNGES. Natural gas fell as forecasts called for milder Midwest weather than previously expected. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell $1.268, or 13.5 percent, to $8.145 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, JACK (JACOB)
description: LIEBOWITZ-Jack (Jacob) S. Of Old Westbury, L.I. and New York City. Died on December 11, 2000 at the age of 100. He was the adored and adoring husband of Shirley. He is survived by his devoted daughters, Joan Levy (George), Linda Stillman (Ronald), and stepson, Robert Schwartz (Jody). He was the grandfather of Richard (deceased), David (Jennie), Michael, Rosie (Rick), Robin (Richard), Jonathan (Denise), and Emily. Great grandfather of Joshua, Alex, Benjamin, Eliana, Leo, Ariana, and Harry. Services will be held at Temple Beth-el at 5 Old Mill Rd, in Great Neck, 11 AM, Wednesday, December 13.

description: BERKMAN-Alice Barrasch. On Dec. 11, 2000, in her 90th year. Beloved wife of the late I. George Berkman. Survived by her children Barry, Andrew and Deborah and their life partner and spouses Tina Kazan, Kathy Berkman and Joel Levine. Also survived by her six grandchildren Tony, Elise, Emily and her husband David Harris, Ben, Joseph Bacal and Gabrielle Berkman-Levine. Funeral was held December 12th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, DAVID JOSEPH.
description: BELL-David Joseph. Loved by all who knew him. He will be lovingly remembered by Arline, his wife of 50 years, by his children and their spouses, Roberta and Daniel BellKligler, Evan and Barbara Bell, Cynthia and Eric Bell-Kamen, Marilyn and Jeffrey Klein, his grandchildren Eitan, Talia, Nati and Sefi living in Israel, Elie and Cara, Monica & Maxine. He is survived by his siblings, Bernard, Miriam and Martin. David was born on August 22, 1922 in Brooklyn, son of Russian immigrants, Max & Ceila Belofsky. He was a former resident of Scarsdale, Sagaponack and New York City. He graduated from CCNY with an Accounting degree and went on to establish a successful accounting practice, Cogan, Bell & Co. David died peacefully on Tuesday, December 12, 2000 surrounded by his loving family, after a long life of accomplishments, purpose and loving commitment to family, friends, community, synagogue and the State of Israel. He loved life. Services will be held 11:00AM Thursday at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to ''Moshav Tzippori'', for a memorial synagogue fund.

title: State Tournament Going to Newark
description: Recalling the town's heyday in boxing, which turned out fighters like the former middleweight world champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler, officials announced yesterday that Newark would become the regular home of the New Jersey state amateur boxing championships.

title: The Modern Master In the Art Of the Deal
description: In the long unwinding of Scott Boras's life, from California farm boy to the most successful player agent in sports history, one constant has been his deep yearning to play an important role in professional baseball, the world that obsessed him as a young man and later eluded him as a player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNS, SUZANNE MARIE.
description: BERNS-Suzanne Marie. December 12, 2000. Wife of H. Jerome (Jerry) Berns, (Associate of the 21 Club New York City). Stepmother of Cecily Rosenthal. Sister of Hansi Karacz and Francis Tanzer. Step-grandmother and step-great grandmother. She will be deeply missed by her family and numerous friends. Funeral private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Suzanne Berns Scholarship Fund at the Culinary Institute of America, Hyde Park, NY.

title: He Knows If You've Been Naughty, But You Can Still Send Him E-Mail
description: IN a wired world, an old-fashioned letter to Santa Claus can seem sadly, well, old-fashioned. First-class mail can take days, and paper-and-envelope communiques can be mangled or lost. But e-mail goes through in a twinkle, faster than Dasher, Dancer, Donder and Blitzen on a long winter's night of rooftop hopscotching.

title: Cutbacks at Wheel Maker
description: The largest manufacturer of wheels for the automobile industry, Hayes Lemmerz International, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,200 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force, because of production cutbacks that are being made by its customers. The company, based in Northville, Mich., said that the jobs would be eliminated in the United States, Europe and Brazil, and that it would take a pretax charge of $8 million in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31 for costs associated with the move, as part of a program to cut costs and dispose of surplus assets.

title: Legislators Adopt Budget With Bigger Cut in Tax Rate
description: Westchester County legislators have adopted a $1.2 billion budget that is even more generous to property owners and low-income families than one proposed last month by the county executive.

title: House Adopts Bush Electors, But Act May Be Moot
description: Hours before the United States Supreme Court issued a ruling that cleared the way for Gov. George W. Bush to become president, Florida's House today took what it expected might be its own decisive step by voting for a slate of electors who could put Gov. George W. Bush in the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABNEY, STEPHEN F.
description: DABNEY-Stephen F. Of Smithtown, L.I., in NYC, Dec. 10, 2000. Survived by his brother, sister and several nieces & nephews. Services will be private. Memorial gifts may be sent to the Phippsburg Land Trust, P.O. Box 123, Phippsburg, ME 04562.

title: A Momentous Night of Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Shares Retreat, Moving Nasdaq 2.8% Lower
description: Technology stocks fell yesterday while some old-line consumer stocks had a modest day in the plus column.

title: A Day in Limbo Ends in Anger and Relief After the Supreme Court Rules
description: For the corps of Florida election officials, politicians, lawyers and others who endured an agonizing wait to see what the United States Supreme Court would do, tonight's ruling that apparently put an end to the election lawsuits brought a mixture of anger, elation and relief.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The yen fell on concern that a Bank of Japan survey of business confidence would reinforce expectations for slower growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 111.52 yen, up from 110.71 yen on Monday.

description: GREGORY-Dorothy. 79, Chappaqua, N.Y. A memorial gathering is being planned for February.

Herbert Rubin Herzfeld & Rubin, PC

title: Changes of Scenery Taken to the Ninth Degree
description: Rick Lukianuk loves watching the surprise on people's faces as he describes his journey from the upper echelons of corporate America to small-town academia -- or, put another way, from coping with stress to having a ball. ''I can see it in their eyes,'' he said. ''They say, 'Wait a minute, you can actually do what you want to do?' ''

title: The Internet Gives Corporate Banking a Do-It-Yourself Look
description: ANYONE can be a travel agent, stock trader or retailer, thanks to the Internet. Now companies are becoming their own bankers as well, turning to online transactions or Web marketplaces that limit, or even eliminate, a traditional banker's role between buyer and seller. That can cut into the services that have defined corporate banking for generations.

Camp Loyaltown mourns the loss of Jane, beautiful and beloved wife of our President, Ephraim. Our heartfelt condolences to the family.

title: CUTBACKS AT BOTTLER
description: Panamerican Beverages Inc. said it would reorganize its operations in Venezuela, Colombia and Mexico, cut about 3,300 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force, and take charges totaling $431 million in an effort to cut costs and return to profitability. Panamerican, based in Mexico City, is a major Coca-Cola bottler and the largest soft-drink bottler in Latin America. Excluding the charges, the company said, it will lose $12 million to $14 million this year.

title: Rodriguez Throws $252 Million Bat at the Mets
description: Now that Alex Rodriguez has his $252 million contract, his fondest wish might be to have his new team, the Texas Rangers, play the Mets in the World Series.

title: An Ex-Governor to Join Equity Firm
description: William F. Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, will become a general partner of Leeds Equity Partners, a private equity firm based in New York.

title: British Drug Makers See F.T.C. Approval of Merger
description: The British companies Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said today that they had received initial clearance from United States regulators for a long-delayed $68 billion merger to create the world's second-biggest drug maker after Pfizer Inc.

title: PALM REACHES LICENSING DEAL
description: Samsung Electronics has licensed the Palm operating system for its next family of smart phones, devices that combine the wireless telephone with the hand-held computer. The first product should hit the North American market in the second quarter of 2001, Samsung said. The announcement came at PalmSource, a conference in Santa Clara, Calif., attended by more than 3,000 developers who create software for the Palm operating system. Palm hailed Samsung's decision as a victory in its war against Microsoft over the market for hand-held operating systems. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHTIO, AUGUST G., MD
description: KOHTIO-August G., MD The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary notes with sorrow the passing of a well respected member of its medical staff. Affiliated with the hospital as an Ophthalmologist and Ophthalmic Pathologist since 1958, Dr. Kohtio was a stalwart supporter of the Infirmary and the Ophthalmology Education Program. He will long be remembered by those who profited from his devotion. Our sincerest condolences to his wife Vita and their entire family. Robert C. Della Rocca, MD Chairman, Medical Board Joseph B. Walsh, MD Chairman Dept of Ophthalmology KOHTIO-August, M.D. The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary Alumni Association regrets to announce the recent passing of our respected & esteemed colleague, Dr. August Kohtio. He will be remembered fondly for his generous contributions to the Infirmary family. Members of the administration, hospital staff, friends and colleagues extend their deepest sympathies to his family. Jeanne Rosenthal, M.D. Douglas Buxton, M.D. Melissa Paschow, M.D,

title: Betty Crocker: Can She Cook in Cyberspace?
description: TRADITIONAL marketers are eager, if not anxious, to capitalize on the Internet to broaden and deepen the ties they have built with shoppers through familiar media like television, radio, newspapers, magazines and billboards, and promotions in stores. But the 264-megabyte question remains: How best to enter the confusing, constantly changing cyberrealm?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLL, MAXWELL
description: SOLL-Maxwell. The Faculty of the NYU (Medical Center) Psychoanalytic Institute and the members of The Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the untimely passing in mid November of Maxwell Soll, M.D., our esteemed colleague. After graduating from the institute in 1972, and moving to Dallas in 1978, he had a creative and distinguished career. Our condolences to the family. Michael Singer, D.O., Director NYU Psychoanalytic Institute Leonard Barkin, M.D. President, PANY

title: Denver Journal; In '99, World Celebrated; Now It's Denver's Turn
description: As the new year passed through various time zones last Dec. 31, television cameras captured the glow and dazzle of one millennium celebration after another: jubilant, confetti-covered masses in rolling moments of shared euphoria.

title: An Unfair Bankruptcy Bill
description: The Senate passed the same distorted bankruptcy bill last week that the House had passed earlier this year. The bill amounts to a handout to the credit card industry, whose heavy lobbying and huge campaign contributions guaranteed big victories in both houses. President Clinton has promised to veto the bill, in part because it hits hard at poor debtors and leaves loopholes for sophisticated ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZZARI, GERTRUDE B.
description: LAZZARI-Gertrude B. Of Bronxville, New York, on December 10, 2000. Wife of the late John B. Lazzari, Jr., mother of John B. Lazzari, Mary Regina Niehaus, & Ann Marie Beccue, grandmother of four, great grandmother of two. Calling hours are at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. on Tuesday and Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial at Annunciation Church, Crestwood, is on Thursday, December 14th at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: VIRGIN EXPRESS UNIT IN JEOPARDY
description: Virgin Express Holdings, the Brussels-based discount airline, said it would close its Irish unit next month if no buyer could be found. Problems at the two-year-old unit, which flies between Shannon in western Ireland and London, Brussels and other cities, have dragged the parent into the red and prompted so much executive turnover that Belgian regulators threatened to suspend its license. Virgin Express and the long-haul carrier Virgin Atlantic share trademarks and are both controlled by Richard Branson, but are otherwise unconnected, a spokeswoman for Virgin Atlantic said.

title: The $252 Million Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Sites Aren't Closing the Sale
description: EVEN if insurance sites do not sell many policies on the Web, and so far they haven't, they appear to have accomplished one thing: making insurance agents look good.

title: Case Against Camden Mayor Was Not Proved, Lawyer Says
description: The lead defense lawyer in the extortion and racketeering trial of Mayor Milton Milan used his closing arguments here today to rebut the arguments presented by federal prosecutors, saying that the government's witnesses had lied and that prosecutors had failed to prove their case.

title: In a Poor and Violent Land, a Tenuous Link to the World
description: FRANCOIS BENOIT climbs into his Mitsubishi four-wheel-drive vehicle each day and heads down a winding road from his home in the cool, green hills overlooking this city to a sweltering commercial district where Alpha Communications Network, Haiti's main Internet service provider, is based.

title: GAME MAKER JOINS XBOX EFFORT
description: Ending several months of speculation in the video game industry, Electronic Arts said it planned to make titles available for the forthcoming Microsoft game console, the xBox. Microsoft hopes the xBox, scheduled for a fall 2001 introduction, will provide competition to the Sony Playstation and other leading consoles, for which Electronic Arts already makes titles. Robbie Bach, chief xBox officer for Microsoft, said that the decision by Electronic Arts, the largest independent game maker, to also support xBox ''raises the profile'' of the game system. Electronic Arts said it would make 10 unspecified titles available within six months after xBox appears. Electronic Arts shares rose $1.94, or 4.9 percent, to $41.69. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Yep, You Can Sing That In X, Y and Z
description: Over the last few years playwrights increasingly have drawn inspiration from the worlds of science and mathematics. Tom Stoppard's ''Hapgood'' and ''Arcadia'' were among the first plays to explore the mystery, romance, humor and even poetry of particle physics and chaos theory. Michael Frayn's ''Copenhagen'' and David Auburn's ''Proof'' provide further evidence of the dramatic viability of theoretical debate. Is the time then ripe for a musical comedy about mathematics? If ''Fermat's Last Tango'' is anything to go by, the answer is not quite.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Compaq Issues a Warning On Its Sales and Earnings

title: Bombing Suspect Threatened His Interrogators, They Testify
description: A suspect in the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya pointed his finger at his American interrogators, blamed the United States and Israel for the attack and said that if he was going to be held responsible, ''his tribe would take revenge,'' an F.B.I. agent testified yesterday.

title: Monsignor Is Chosen To Run L.I. Diocese
description: Moving quickly to assure leadership for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre after the death of Bishop James T. McHugh, a group of 12 priests elected Msgr. John A. Alesandro yesterday to serve as diocesan administrator. He will remain in the post until the Vatican names a successor to Bishop McHugh.

title: Wharton School to Start Program in San Francisco
description: In an effort to reach the fast-growing pool of executives on the West Coast, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania is setting up a program in San Francisco that will offer a master's degree for business professionals, the school announced yesterday.

title: Beethoven the Engineer, Barenboim the Conductor
description: Not too much in music is more exciting than a Beethoven symphony in full working order -- the kind of performance that Daniel Barenboim and his Berlin orchestra, the Staatskapelle, gave on Monday night, when they opened a weeklong Beethoven festival with the ''Eroica'' at Carnegie Hall.

title: MORE DELAYS IN THAI PETRO CASE
description: A bankruptcy court delayed approval of a $3.8 billion debt-restructuring plan for Thai Petrochemical Industry after the company's chief executive, Prachai Leophairatana, asked the Supreme Court to change the team of judges. Mr. Prachai, formerly a member of Thailand's Senate, had clashed with the judge now overseeing the case, Kraisorn Barameeauychai, during the drafting of the 1999 Bankruptcy Law; and the Thai Petro case is seen as the law's first major test. Creditors have controlled the company since it was ruled insolvent in May.

title: The Kiosk, Where Brick Meets Click
description: AMABEL AMARANTO is the picture of a helpful Gap employee, pleasant, smiling and eager. With her headset, a high-tech device that makes selling jeans and T-shirts seem as urgent and life-dependent as air traffic control, she looks as modern as can be. But when I ask to see the store's Web kiosk, she says, ''What's a kiosk?''

title: No Ads, but Strong Sales For Electric Toothbrushes
description: Create a need and fill it. If anyone truly understands that old maxim, surely it is John Osher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNING, DR. EDWARD F.,
description: DOWNING-Dr. Edward F., neurological surgeon of Savannah, Georgia, died on December 10, 2000. A loyal alumnus and friend of the Neurological Institute of New York, Columbia University, he was revered in his community and respected nationally as an elegant and gifted neurosurgeon. Our sympathy is extended to his wife Helen and daughter Callie. He was a dear friend and will be sorely missed. The Department of Neurological Surgery, The Neurological Institute of New York, Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GANS, JEROME
description: GANS-Jerome. Nine years has passed. Our thoughts of you have not diminished. You are always remembered, always loved. Mona, Andy, Larry, Helene Jamie, Kyle, Casey

He was loved and respected.

title: The Red Sox Spice Up Baseball's Best Rivalry
description: The first time Manny Ramirez ever played a major league game at Yankee Stadium, he pounded two homers and a double and delighted the fans who stood along the left-field line waving Dominican flags and chanting ''Man-ny, Man-ny.'' The baseball-crazed fans from Washington Heights love the Yankees, but they love Ramirez more, so they rooted for him and the Cleveland Indians on that occasion, and a handful of times every season.

title: Sports of The Times; A-Rod Chose Big Bucks, Small Setting
description: ALEX RODRIGUEZ is rich enough to shrug off the perception in Seattle that he is disloyal for taking $252 million from the Texas Rangers, out in the middle of nowhere, when he could have remained in haughty Dot-Com City.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: After 25 Years, a Symmetry of Soul
description: There can be satisfaction when a concert that makes business sense first and foremost ends up working well in other quarters as well. Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax, cellist and pianist, are distinguished artists with big reputations. Avery Fisher Hall is a symphony-size space that will accommodate a large number of ticket buyers. Art may argue that the intimacy of a duo recital deserves a smaller place to hear it in, but the prospect of leaving an overflow of frustrated customers on the sidewalk was unacceptable merchandising. The music on Monday night was by Beethoven, Mendelssohn, Brahms and John Corigliano. The audience numbered well over 2,000.

title: Bush Prevails; G.O.P. Is Cautious
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12  Exactly five weeks after one of the most unsettled presidential elections in American history, George Walker Bush appeared tonight to have swept away any lingering legal obstacles, gaining the right, at long last, to consider himself president-elect.

title: Day-to-Day Duels on Political Issues Have Grown Increasingly Personal
description: Someone in the Gore campaign directed reporters to a federal judge who was willing to talk about a potential conflict of interest involving Justice Clarence Thomas. A spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, denounced the Florida Supreme Court as ''a bunch of partisan hacks.''

Stein, President Allan S. Sexter, Secretary

title: Germans Seeking to Mediate Israel-Lebanon Prisoner Trade
description: German mediators are trying to arrange a prisoner exchange that could soon free four Israelis held prisoner by the Hezbollah militia and two senior Lebanese Muslim militants abducted years ago by Israel, officials from Hezbollah and Israel said today.

title: Nation's Toughest Smoking Ban Is Adopted
description: County legislators approved a smoking ban today for this affluent suburban village near Washington, a measure that antismoking advocates described as the most extensive in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, MARIE,

Memorial contributions to Mid-Fairfield Hospice, 180 School Road, Wilton, CT. Services will be held Wednesday, December 13 from the Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, Connecticut, 203-255-8993.

title: Baseball, by the Millions
description: Alex Rodriguez, the former Seattle shortstop, has signed a contract with the Texas Rangers that averages out to $25 million a year -- some $9 million a year more than the highest-paid player in baseball this past season, the Los Angeles pitcher Kevin Brown. The numbers on Rodriguez's $252 million, 10-year contract are stratospheric, as were the ones on the $160 million, eight-year contract between Manny Ramirez and the Red Sox. But what seems even more shocking is the price being paid for more or less ordinary players, like Kevin Appier, a 15-11 pitcher with a 4.55 earned run average, whom the Mets signed for $10 million a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISANO, RONALD G.
description: PISANO-Ronald G. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Heckscher Museum of Art are deeply saddened at the loss of our longtime friend, supporter, and colleague, Ronald G. Pisano. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. The art world has lost a brilliant scholar, author, curator and advocate. The definitive authority on the work of William Merritt Chase, Ronald Pisano curated numerous exhibitions and authored several books focussing attention on the artist, his followers and Long Island landscape. Ronald's contributions to the Heckscher Museum of Art have been vital to our growth. His talent, generosity and knowledge have benefited the Museum in innumerable ways. From co-authoring the Catalogue of the Collection to curating exhibitions, to personally contributing to the richness of the collection. Above all, he was a valued friend, gentle soul and a colleague who will be greatly missed.

title: ACQUISITION WILL CREATE LARGEST TRUCKER IN N. AMERICA

M.S., based in Memphis, operates mainly in the East and in Mexico; Swift, based in Phoenix, operates mainly in the West. Swift shares fell $3.06 yesterday, to close at $17.13, while M.S. shares rose $6, to close at $28.50.

title: WILLAMETTE ASKS STOCKHOLDERS TO REJECT TAKEOVER BID

The offer, which expires Jan. 4, was a 38 percent premium to Willamette's share price at the time. Shares of Willamette, based in Portland, Ore., fell 38 cents, to $48.63. Weyerhaeuser, based in Federal Way, Wash., fell 50 cents, to $45.75.

title: SALE OF IDENTITY SOFTWARE HALTED
description: An Internet business that offered software used to produce false identity documents like drivers licenses and birth certificates has been ordered to halt sales by a federal district judge in Los Angeles, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. The F.T.C. said that Jeremy Martinez of Tarzana, Calif., operated a business called Info World that maintained Web sites offering 45 days of access to fake identification templates for $29.99. The commission said Mr. Martinez customized his sites to attract consumers who were surfing the Internet to find fake identification. Web sites use hidden words, called meta-tags, that help search engines identify and index Web site content. Some of Mr. Martinez's meta-tags were ''illegal id,'' ''fake id fraud'' and ''forging documents,'' the F.T.C. said.
