Covad, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., expects to have sales of $390 million and installations of 460,000 digital subscriber lines at the end of next year, down from previous estimates of $550 million and 650,000 lines.

title: It Takes a Bidding War: Vying for the First Lady's Memoirs
description: The bidding for Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton's proposed book about her life in the White House exceeded $7.5 million yesterday afternoon, even though she is making the extraordinary request that publishers pay her nearly the entire sum by the end of this year.

title: G.E. TO TAKE $4 BILLION CHARGE FOR HONEYWELL
description: General Electric said yesterday that it would take $4 billion in pretax charges for the purchase of Honeywell International and raised its estimated annual savings from the acquisition by two-thirds, to $2.5 billion. Honeywell also reiterated that its fourth-quarter profit would be below forecasts. The company said it would take as much as $425 million in pretax charges in the period, partly because of a decision to cancel the sale of some units after the $45 billion deal with G.E. was made. The revisions come less than two months after John F. Welch Jr., the chief executive of G.E., broke up a merger between Honeywell and the United Technologies Corporation. Mr. Welch said at the time that the addition of Honeywell would be too good to pass up, and he forecast $1.5 billion in annual savings. The purchase will add 11 cents a share to profit in the first year, and 17 cents in the third year after the acquisition is completed, even if there is no growth at the Honeywell businesses, Mr. Welch said on a conference call. Shares of G.E. fell after Honeywell's warning, closing at $52.81, down $2.50.

title: From a Rude Bump, a Lift for a School
description: About seven years ago, Sara Koffman was walking east on 57th Street toward her apartment as school was letting out. As she recalls it, a teenage boy, a student at the High School of Art and Design, pushed her to the ground. And there began one of the city's odder tales of educational philanthropy.

title: Jack Liebowitz, Comics Publisher, Dies at 100
description: Jack S. Liebowitz, the comic-book publisher whose business acumen helped turn Superman, the creation of two teenage cartoonists, into the most recognizable superhero in the world, died on Monday in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 100 and had homes in Old Westbury, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Business Travel; Clinton Sees His Future: Long Lines In Airports
description: Like most executives who are contemplating retirement and about to lose that prized access to the private jet, Bill Clinton sounded a little pained last week discussing his imminent return to the joys of commercial business travel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCTAGUE, MARY ''MOLLIE''
description: McTAGUE-Mary ''Mollie'' (nee Turbett). Native of County Leitrim-Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Devoted mother of Maureen Hayden, Roseleen McTague & Frances Roth. Loving sister of Elizabeth Molloy & John James Turbett. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Reposing Lincoln Park Funeral Home, 625 McLean Avenue, Yonkers. Mass Thursday 11 AM St. Paul the Apostle Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Reaching for Less Than the Sky; As Boldest Fall, Modest Dreamers Fly On
description: THEY said the Internet would change everything. That there were new rules for a new economy. That a generation of nimble revolutionaries would topple the old guard of the Fortune 500.

title: Moves at ABC
description: Accurate or not, there is a definite perception in television that men enjoy shows about crime and women like programs about relationships (Court TV, the cable channel that has a sizable female audience, begs to differ with this perspective).

title: Commercial Real Estate; Project Picks Up Where It Left Off a Decade Ago
description: Soon after architectural plans were drawn up a decade ago for a 55-story limestone tower at 745 Seventh Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, the economy went into a tailspin. The owners of the site eventually had to settle for a parking lot instead of a skyscraper.

title: Keeping La Guardia Flying, if Anyone Can
description: WILLIAM R. DECOTA is abashed that he doesn't have a better La Guardia Airport nightmare story. A couple of years ago, he was on a canceled flight. Once he sat through a two-hour snow delay. He racks his brain but can't come up with something more dramatic. Maybe, he says, it's because he flies only a few times a year.

title: Crunch, Crunch: The Holiday Approaches
description: THE Victorians may have been famously narrow-minded in their views, strait-laced in their manners and strictly dullsville in their dress, but when it came to candy, they must have been a wild and crazy bunch. There is no other way to explain their affection for one of the world's most indulgent sweets, English toffee.

title: Or You Could Call It Schadenfreude.com
description: PHILIP KAPLAN is another of those annoyingly young dot-com successes that no one with a real job wants to hear another word about. Except that his Web site is so perversely satisfying.

title: Medical Journal Bars Authors' Prepublication Comments
description: In a move that renews debate about when new research findings should be disclosed to the public, The Journal of the American Medical Association has tightened its rules about what scientists and research institutions can say before their results are published.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBLER, JOHN
description: KOBLER-John. Died December 11, 2000 in New York City, age 90. Beloved husband of Rita Stein Kobler. Loving father of Jay Kobler, Lynn Hannon, Karen Reiser and Andrea Bagg. Grandfather of Lisa, James, Jennifer and Adam. Great grandfather of Caitlin and Samuel. Journalist and author of ''The Reluctant Surgeon: A Biography of John Hunter'', ''Capone'', ''Ardent Spirits'', ''Damned in Paradise: The Life of John Barrymore'', and numerous other books and articles. He will be missed by all who loved him.

title: Scarce Slots? Hold an Auction
description: In April, Congress passed a law intended to stimulate competition at La Guardia Airport and increase service to small communities. In response, the Federal Aviation Administration substantially increased the number of flights allowed to operate at La Guardia, already one of the nation's busiest airports.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law.''

title: GM Will Drop Oldsmobile and Cut Jobs by 10%
description: LONDON  In a dramatic restructuring that highlighted the pressures slowing the U.S. economy, General Motors Corp. announced plans Tuesday to phase out its Oldsmobile division and slash its salaried work force by 10 percent, or 6,600 jobs, in North America and Europe.

title: Lemon Grass On Native Ground
description: IT was a breezy late November morning, just after the rainy season, and as traffic-clogged Bangkok receded, the countryside looked as fresh as spring. Our destination was two hours north, a women's farm cooperative where lemon grass is a cash crop. Along the four-lane highway, whole chickens were being turned over open fires. Prized roosters pecked away under the confines of straw cloches. Gas stations were festooned with fresh flowers, and rice paddies sported an occasional scarecrow. Route 66 it was not.

title: Research on Educational Technology
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics is teaming up with an organization known for its skepticism of technology use in the classroom to fund new research into how computers and software impact the development of children from birth though age 11.

title: McVeigh Ends Appeal of His Death Sentence
description: Timothy J. McVeigh has decided to end the appeal of his death sentence for the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing and has asked a federal judge to have him executed within four months.

description: Luongo's Reach

title: Temp Workers At Microsoft Win Lawsuit
description: Microsoft agreed to pay $97 million yesterday to settle an eight-year-old class-action lawsuit in which thousands of temporary employees accused the company of improperly denying them benefits.

title: Redskins' Sims Has Surgery
description: The Washington Redskins placed Keith Sims on injured reserve today after the offensive lineman had surgery on his left Achilles' tendon, the team said.

title: Spain Holds News Magnate as Russia Sought
description: Acting on a request from Moscow, Spanish authorities arrested the embattled Russian news media magnate Vladimir V. Gusinsky at his house in southern Spain late Monday.

title: Clinton Rouses the Irish With a Plea to Cherish the Peace
description: Tens of thousands of people crowded into the central square of this small border town halfway between Dublin and Belfast tonight to hear President Clinton make the final pitch of his presidency for continued peace in the land of his ancestors.

title: Compaq Sees Weak Results This Quarter
description: In another sign of weakness in the personal computer business, Compaq Computer said today that its sales and profits in the fourth quarter would be lower than expected.

title: The Court Rules for Mr. Bush
description: The United States Supreme Court has brought the presidential election to a conclusion in favor of Gov. George W. Bush, but its decision to bar a recount in Florida comes at considerable cost to the public trust and the tradition of fair elections. Our national history bears the comforting lesson that the American people's confidence in the rule of law and the stability of their institutions will not be damaged in the long run. It is incumbent on citizens and elected officials alike to respect the authority of the ruling and the legitimacy of the new presidency whether or not they agree with the court's legal reasoning. In the short term, Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore bear great responsibility for bringing the nation together in spirit if not in immediate political agreement. Mr. Bush needs to be gracious and unifying in victory, and Vice President Gore must master the difficult task of placing the national need for continuity ahead of any bitterness he may feel.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''Icarus,'' at the Bank Street Theater, misidentified the central characters in a Samuel Beckett play to which the setting was compared. Beckett's characters, in ''Waiting for Godot,'' are Vladimir and Estragon, not Lucky and Pozzo.

title: AMAZON LEADS IN HOLIDAY ADVERTISING
description: Amazon.com is the top online advertiser so far this holiday season, according to a report that is to be released today by AdRelevance in New York, part of Jupiter Media Metrix, which reported that Amazon had occupied the No. 1 overall online advertiser spot in eight of the last nine weeks and had attracted more than a half-billion impressions on online holiday-themed ads each week since October. In addition, the AdRelevance report found that Amazon had been devoting much of its online advertising to direct marketing; 70 percent of the retailer's top 10 online ads offer free shipping. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTO, DAISY M.
description: PORTO-Daisy M. Our mother's valiant struggle against lung cancer came to a peaceful end on November 29, 2000. To her children Emilie O'Sullivan and Ben E. Porto, she bequeaths a legacy of a passionate love of life and a commitment never to acknowledge the threat of defeat. To the treasures of her life, grandsons Brad and Ryan O'Sullivan and Joseph and Brian Porto, she imparts endless love and affection. The boys will always cherish her stirring example of courage that belied her petite stature. It is a very difficult void to fill, but her show of consistent strength and grace in the face of great adversity will give them an abundance of enduring and inspirational memories. She leaves behind a sister, Gloria Bianchi, her daughter-in-law Jean Anne Celebrezze Porto and her grandson Joseph's wife, Annie Thompson Porto. As a family we find consolation in her reunion with her beloved husband, Joe. She will now realize all the happiness she gave to so many others. Under the watchful eye of Dr. Mark Kris, her life was extended with quality. Please make contributions in her memory to Lung Cancer Research Fund, #

title: If Statistics Don't Lie, Don't Let Johnson Know
description: Larry Johnson's statistics are not impressive at all. Among the league's 29 starting power forwards, he ranks near the bottom third in every category. He is averaging 10.7 points and 6.5 rebounds with a .415 field-goal percentage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, MORTON
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Morton. On December 11, 2000 (formerly of Englewood). Beloved wife of Evelyn. Devoted father of Sue, (Alan) and Beth (George). Dear grandfather of Jonathan, Neil, Marc, & Rachel. Graveside services were held at Beth El Cemetery Washington Township, N.J.

title: Directors Who Owed Millions Depart From Troubled Insurer
description: Conseco, the troubled insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that its board had voted to oust two directors because they owed millions of dollars on loans guaranteed by the company. It added that three other directors who owed money had resigned from the board.

description: THE COMPLETE LETTERS OF OSCAR WILDE

title: Gore's Failure to Ask for Manual Statewide Recount May Have Been Critical Mistake
description: In the inevitable second-guessing that followed today's defeat at the hands of the United States Supreme Court, Vice President Al Gore's failure to ask the Florida courts for a manual statewide recount has emerged as one in a series of pivotal legal miscalculations that may have doomed his 35-day battle to wrest Florida's 25 electors from George W. Bush, legal experts said today.

title: Canada Gets Approval to Impose Trade Sanctions Against Brazil
description: Canada won approval today from the World Trade Organization to impose $233.5 million annually in sanctions against Brazil in a dispute over aircraft export subsidies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZMAN, MINNIE
description: SALZMAN-Minnie. On December 9, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Phyllis Smith, Maxine Young and Stephen Salzman. Dear sister of Mildred Kleinhandler and David Rose. Cherished grandmother. Services were held on Tuesday at Congregation B'nai Israel, 2 Banksville Road, Armonk, NY.

title: EARNINGS NEWS LIFTS NET2PHONE
description: Shares of Net2Phone rose nearly 20 percent yesterday after the company reported first-quarter revenue that beat analysts' estimates. On Tuesday, Net2Phone, based in Hackensack, N.J., reported $30.8 million in revenue for its first quarter ended Oct. 31, surpassing analysts' estimates of $30 million, and up from $13.1 million a year earlier. The Internet telephony services provider's per-share loss narrowed to 9 cents from 17 cents, and its shares rose $1.94, to $11.69.

title: Don't Know What People Think About You? Soon, You Will
description: If you have ever wondered what other people are saying about you (and who hasn't?), a new online database is prepared to slake that masochistic need to know.

title: First Complete Plant Genetic Sequence Is Determined
description: Scientists from the United States, Europe and Japan have determined the first complete genetic sequence of a plant, an accomplishment that should deepen understanding of plant biology and provide new ways to genetically engineer crops to increase food production and improve nutrition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, FLORENCE BRILL.
description: MANDELL-Florence Brill. Age 75. Of Paramus, NJ. Wife of Paul, mother of Margery Libin, and Robert. Beloved grandmother of Daniel, Alexander, Matthew, Devora and Diana. Services 10AM Friday, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, (East) Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Toward Structurally Sound Sand Castles
description: Architecture for children -- why not? It's never too early to teach children the difference between a joist and an obelisk. ''Arches to Zigzags: An Architecture ABC'' (Harry N. Abrams, $18.95) is the fifth architecture book for children by Michael J. Crosbie and the photographer Steve Rosenthal, joined this time by Kit Rosenthal. Vivid photographs illustrate the letter E with the gigantic eaves of a Frank Lloyd Wright house; N stands for neon, illustrated with the facade of a 1930's Art Deco hotel in Miami.

title: 'Traffic' Captures Awards From New York Film Critics
description: Steven Soderbergh's film ''Traffic,'' a somber investigation of the drug trade, was voted best film of the year by the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday at Sardi's.

title: Irish Peat Company Adapts to Change
description: Of all the economic changes taking place in Ireland, few are as dramatic as the ones occurring at the national institution known for supplying peat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMS, MAURICE
description: ABRAHAMS-Maurice. Of New City, N.Y. Died December 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Sandy. Loving and devoted father of Seth and Felicia, father-in-law to Yosef Emuna and Sari, dear son of Edythe and Lewis (deceased) and brother of Robert and Jonathan, loving uncle and great uncle. In his memory the family requests that contributions be made to Congregation Sons of Israel in Upper Nyack, New York.

title: CARLSBERG MAKES COKE CONCESSIONS TO SECURE ORKLA
description: Carlsberg, the large brewer, agreed to stop selling Coca-Cola products in Sweden to win antitrust approval for its purchase of Orkla's breweries, Swedish regulators said. Carlsberg and Orkla will also sell seven of their beer brands -- Three Towns, Fat, Arboga, Eagle, Bayerbrau, Starkbock and Sailor -- and give up rights to five imported beers. The divestitures will trim the companies' combined share of the Swedish market to 45 percent from 56 percent. Orkla is based in Oslo and Carlsberg in Stockholm.

title: The View Through Polyester and Steel
description: MARY BRIGHT, a New York curtain maker, often works with techno-fabrics. ''Some drape beautifully, and most are durable,'' she said. But metallic fabrics can also cause headaches, because they wrinkle and the wrinkles last forever. ''If you want a funky rumpled look, they are great,'' she said. Ms. Bright advises asking about lining and cleaning techno-fabrics before purchasing them. Some fabrics are available only from decorator showrooms; most curtain makers and upholsterers can order them for you.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW JERSEY ECONOMIC FORECAST
description: New Jersey's economy will be moderate through 2005 without a serious threat of recession, according to an economic forecast released yesterday by the director of the Rutgers Economic Advisory Service. Nancy H. Mantell, the director, said she expected the average growth rate for personal income to remain about double the growth of consumer prices throughout the forecast period. For example, the report said, personal income in New Jersey increased by 5.4 percent this year, with consumer prices increasing about 3 percent. The report predicted a personal income growth rate average of 5.1 percent from 2002 to 2005, with consumer prices increasing on average by 2.6 percent. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Project Uses Simulations To Research Flu Vaccines
description: If you have not already enlisted your computer to help in the search for signs of extraterrestrial life, here's another worthy endeavor for your underused machine: Help conduct research on flu vaccines.

title: Armthorpe Journal; Illness That Haunts Europe: One Family's Story
description: It was bad enough when the two consulting neurologists began arguing, right in front of John Middleton, about how to tell him that the mysterious ailment afflicting his 19-year-old son, Matthew, was the always fatal human form of mad cow disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNICK, SAMUEL
description: VERNICK-Samuel, 95. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL. A strong man with a heart of pure gold. Survived by his beloved wife Miriam, four sons Irving, Shelly, Marty and Bob, their spouses, eight grandchildren and six great grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Irving Vernick

title: Sports of The Times; The Cowboys Can Rely On an Enduring Helper
description: As soon as Troy Aikman wobbled to the sideline with another concussion, the relatively unknown Anthony Wright was suddenly the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback Sunday against the Washington Redskins. He knew he was on the spot. He also knew who to turn to.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS. The yen fell against the dollar after a survey by the Bank of Japan showed business confidence was stalling. In New York, the dollar settled at 112.44 yen, up from 111.52 on Tuesday.

title: Getting Under the Skin of a Fish That Can Get Under Yours
description: WHEN Ed Caldwell, an engineer, saw a Big Mouth Billy Bass at his father's house recently, he got an idea. He borrowed the fake fish and took it to his office at Cymbolic Sciences in Bellingham, Wash. ''I put it on my co-workers' desks early in the morning,'' he said. ''When they came in it would start singing and wiggling around -- it scared them to death, but they thought it was hysterical.''

title: Art Is Forever, While Light Is Fleeting
description: In the notoriously cloudy Pacific Northwest, sunlight is as precious as art. Or so one might assume from the $15 million Bellevue Art Museum, above, which opens Jan. 31 in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue. Museums tend to skimp on windows because natural light can damage artworks, but the Bellevue museum has no permanent collection to protect, emphasizing instead ceramics studios, classrooms and other hands-on facilities.

title: CHINA CRITICIZES QUOTA CUTS
description: China's trade ministry attacked a United States decision to reduce quotas for imports of its textiles and threatened retaliation. About $9 million in Chinese exports are affected. The United States cut the quotas because, it says, Chinese goods are falsely labeled as made in Hong Kong or Macao, which have their own quotas. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Congress Revives Bill On Investment In Poor Areas
description: Congressional Republicans and White House officials, locked in a bitter political standoff for much of the year, said today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement reviving legislation to provide tax credits and other incentives for investment in economically depressed areas.

title: As Charges Mount, Heat Increases For Chirac
description: President Jacques Chirac's political troubles continue to mount. As he pursues the uphill task of selling the Nice summit meeting on the remaking of the European Union as a success, he faces new accusations that he was at the center of a corruption scheme when he was mayor of Paris.

title: Union Rebuts Claim That Teachers Aided Cheating
description: It was a year ago that Edward F. Stancik, the special New York City schools investigator, issued the finding that dozens of teachers and 2 principals in 32 schools had helped students cheat on standardized reading and math tests used to rank schools and promote students.

title: Czechs Agree to Let Outside Experts Inspect Atomic Power Plant
description: Austria and the Czech Republic, with the mediation of the European Union, signed an agreement today to resolve their dispute over a new Czech nuclear power plant 30 miles from the Austrian border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, JACK
description: LIEBOWITZ-Jack. The officers and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jack Liebowitz, whose life embodied the world of our values and the compassion of our mission. As the comic-book publisher who turned Superman and Batman into household names, Mr. Liebowitz was a superhero himself. He was a board member of one of our predecessor organizations, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, & a founding trustee and president of our beneficiary, Long Island Jewish Hospital, now North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. For 50 years, he gave of himself unstintingly and unselfishly to the Long Island community and to communities worldwide. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Shirley; his daughters, Joan Levy and Linda Stillman; his stepson, Robert Schwartz; his many grandchildren & great-grandchildren; and the entire family. May all who benefited from Jack's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO LIEBOWITZ-Jack. It is with the deepest sorrow that we mourn the passing of Jack Liebowitz, a Founding Trustee, a past President of the Board of Trustees of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and a Trustee and Honorary Chairman of the Board of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. For fifty years, he unselfishly gave of himself for the benefit of the community and the hospital he loved. Without his guidance, generosity and inspiration, LIJ would not have developed into one of the pre-eminent medical centers in this region. Our most sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. John S.T. Gallagher, CEO Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Discarded Tapes Checked for Link to Los Alamos Lab Scientist
description: Federal officials said yesterday that investigators had found several tapes in a landfill outside Los Alamos, N.M., and were analyzing them to see if any had been discarded by Dr. Wen Ho Lee, the former Los Alamos National Laboratory scientist who told of filling computer tapes with nuclear secrets and then throwing them in the trash.

title: Appeals Court Declines Suit Over Ballots For Senator
description: The state's highest court refused today to hear an absentee-ballot case in the race for the Manhattan seat held by State Senator Roy M. Goodman, clearing the way for the counting of votes to continue in the contest.

title: Port Authority Set To Vote on Hearings For Fare Increases
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to move closer to increasing PATH fares and tolls on Hudson River crossings when it votes today on whether to hold public hearings on the proposal.

title: Economic Scene: Technology Rise and Fall Is as American as the Model T
description: The Nasdaq has lost nearly 45 percent of its value since reaching a high in March, with many dot-coms now selling at 90 percent off their top prices. The technology boom and bust we have lived through the last few years has been a breathtaking ride, but it is hardly unprecedented.

description: Three private foundations have pledged $30 million to help redesign some of New York City's largest, lowest-performing high schools, breaking them into smaller schools with unconventional curriculums.

description: Palm Inc., whose hand-held computers became an icon for the popular- technology boom, is gradually retooling its business model to counter competition fashioned primarily by its own success.

description: Following is the text of the Supreme Court's decision Tuesday night that there could be no further counting of Florida's disputed presidential ballot. The vote in Bush v. Gore was 5 to 4. It is not clear who wrote the majority opinion, but Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote a concurring opinion in which Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas joined. Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer wrote dissents in which various justices joined. Italicized portions show where emphasis was added in the original. The text is reprinted from yesterday's final editions.

title: Beyond the Election; Mr. Gore's Farewell, Mr. Bush's Task
description: In a gracious exchange of televised speeches, the president-elect, George W. Bush, and Vice President Al Gore moved last night to unify the nation and heal the wounds of their bitter struggle for the White House. Mr. Bush pledged a presidency of ''common sense, common courtesy and common goals'' built around a new spirit of bipartisanship. Mr. Gore abandoned his quest for the presidency with a deeply personal concession, invoking his faith, his father and his dedication to social justice.

title: Study Finds That Caching by Browsers Creates a Threat to Surfers' Privacy
description: NORMALLY, Web browsers quietly mind their own business, speeding through Web pages at their masters' whim. Now a study from Princeton University has found that one part of Web browsers -- the caches -- might also allow nosey or unscrupulous Web site operators to spy on their visitors' browsing habits. Edward W. Felten, co-director of Princeton's Secure Internet Programming Laboratory and co-author of the paper with Michael Schneider, said he was not aware of any actual snooping using a technique he has discovered. Nevertheless, he said that this potential intrusion poses a significant threat to privacy. The study concludes that there is no practical way to prevent it.

title: CIRIO OF ITALY SEEKS REST OF DEL MONTE ROYAL SHARES
description: Cirio, Italy's largest canned foods company, said yesterday that it made an unsolicited offer of about $150 million for the shares it does not already own in Del Monte Royal Foods Ltd., based in Kempton Park, South Africa, which sells canned foods under the Del Monte label in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. Other than sharing the trademark, Del Monte Royal is unrelated to Del Monte Foods, the American food processing company. Cirio said it offered 5.25 South African rand (68 cents) a share for Del Monte Royal Foods and for the companies that controlled it, Royal Holdings and the Del Monte Royal Corporation. Cirio controls 11 percent of Del Monte Royal Foods directly and another 25 percent through holdings in Royal Holdings and Del Monte Royal Holdings, which it wants to disband.

description: A month after pitching camp here, the warring factions are demobilizing, leaving behind rear guards in case the battle somehow flares again. The arbiters, too, are standing down from their state of high alert, cautiously optimistic that their lives can return to normal.

title: Phillips Won't Respond To Rodriguez's Remarks
description: Yesterday marked a month since the Mets publicly backed out of negotiations for Alex Rodriguez, the star free-agent shortstop. On Monday, Rodriguez signed a record 10-year, $252 million contract with the Texas Rangers. On Tuesday, he had harsh words for Mets General Manager Steve Phillips.

title: Innovative Theater Space Is Planning An Expansion
description: Symphony Space, the Upper West Side bastion of unconventional programming, plans to announce a $24 million campaign today to raise money for its endowment and to unite its 22-year-old stage with the vintage Thalia movie theater around the corner.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 27 about the Romanian presidential election misstated a position held by one candidate, Corneliu Vadim Tudor, on a territorial issue. In the past, he called for Romania to take back part of Moldova, not all of it. The article also referred incorrectly to the content of his two weekly magazines. They continue to use anti-Semitic and anti-Hungarian language; they have not stopped recently.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Syria's release of about 50 Lebanese prisoners misstated the title of Adnan Addoum, the Lebanese official who said his government would interview all prisoners before deciding who could go home. He is the prosecutor general, not a prosecutor who is a military general.

title: DAEWOO LABOR DEAL UNRAVELS
description: Union officials said they were withdrawing support for a plan to revamp Daewoo Motor, which is insolvent, because creditors pushed for cost-cutting measures without consulting workers. The company wants to shed 7,000 jobs, or two-fifths of its work force, to return to profitability in 2001 under a plan developed by consultants from Arthur Andersen. Union support is seen as crucial to keeping Daewoo in operation long enough for creditors to sell it, possibly to General Motors and Fiat.

title: Perelman Said to Buy Back Bonds in Big Bet on Revlon
description: Ronald O. Perelman has made a large, contrarian bet on Revlon, the ailing cosmetics company he controls, spending perhaps as much as $250 million to buy back zero-coupon junk bonds secured by nearly half of his 83.5 percent stake in Revlon, according to an executive briefed on Mr. Perelman's plans.

title: UTILICORP'S PLANS TO SPIN OFF TRADING UNIT ARE DETAILED
description: UtiliCorp United Inc., a utility company, announced details of a two-stage plan to spin off its natural gas and electricity trading unit, Aquila Energy. The first step will be an initial public offering that the company expects to yield $425 million; afterward, UtiliCorp would distribute its remaining controlling interest in Aquila to its shareholders within a year, according to regulatory filings. Part of the proceeds from the initial offering will be used to pay the parent a $125 million cash dividend, a technique that the company believes will preserve the tax-free status of its later distribution of shares to shareholders. UtiliCorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., announced in August that it would divest itself of Aquila.

title: Aliases Subject of Internet Libel Case
description: Last week Judge Richard L. Williams of the federal district court in Richmond, Va., rejected a series of motions and gave his seal of approval to a jury's verdict that awarded $675,000 in compensatory and punitive damages to Dr. Sam D. Graham Jr., a urologist in private practice in Virginia and former head of the department of urology at Emory University School of Medicine.

title: Affirmative Action Plan Is Upheld at Michigan
description: A federal judge upheld the University of Michigan's affirmative action program yesterday, ruling that diversity is a critical component of higher education and that colleges and universities can continue to consider race and ethnicity in admissions decisions.

description: GORTCHACOW - Princess Con stantin nee Marie Wyrouboff. On December 8, in Paris, France in her 89th year.

It read: ''Hi Slatalla, A Half.com buyer has contacted us in regard to an item purchased from you that has not been received. Please inform us of the status of this order (reply with history).''

description: TRAU-Charles. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary are saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Antwerp, Belgium, Jewish community, beloved husband of Toni, and father of Dr. Rene Trau. He is the brother of Rabbi Solomon Trau, Board treasurer of RIETS and, with his wife, Beryl, a RIETS Fellow. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to his grandson and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

description: The Florida Senate ''dodged a bullet'' today, as one lawmaker put it, when it halted a special session that had been convened to appoint a slate of electors pledged to put George W. Bush in the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IREYS, ALICE RECKNAGEL.
description: IREYS-Alice Recknagel. On December 12 in her 90th year. Wife of the late Henry Ireys. Survived by her sister Catherine Ropes, her children Cathie, Anne and Henry and five grandsons. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Memorial service on December 21, at 2 PM, at Grace Church, Brooklyn, 254 Hicks Street. IREYS-Alice Recknagel. The Brooklyn Botanic Garden has lost a dear friend and colleague, the renowned landscape architect, Alice Recknagel Ireys. For more than 70 years the Garden has been enriched by her talents as a student, designer, most notably for the creation of the Fragrance and Garden, as a teacher, as a member of the Auxiliary, and as a Distinguished Advisor to the Board of Trustees. Her creativity, forthrightness and indefatigable spirit will be deeply missed. We express our condolences to her children Anne, Catherine and Henry and their families. Earl D. Weiner, Board Chairman Judith D. Zuk, President Joanne Woodfin, Auxiliary Pres

title: Metro Business Briefing; TELEMARKETING REGISTRY
description: Connecticut will use a trade group, the Direct Marketing Association, to distribute to telemarketers a list of state residents who do not want to receive unsolicited sales calls. The Department of Consumer Protection said about 200,000 people have signed up. Under a state law that takes effect Jan. 1, businesses across the country are prohibited from calling people. There are exemptions, like companies that start doing business in the state after Jan. 1 or businesses placing calls to current customers, the department said. The Direct Marketing Association is to charge telemarketers $400 a year for the list, which will be updated quarterly. Residents can sign up on the Web, at www.state.ct.us/dcp, or by calling (800) 842-2649 from within the state. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: MAN IN THE NEWS; The 43rd President -- George Walker Bush
description: Gov. George W. Bush cast his quest for the presidency as a stand against poisonous Washington -- its gridlock, its scandals, its bruising partisanship -- and in the very last week of his campaign he was barnstorming under bright banners that promised, ''Bringing America Together.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, ROSE TRILLING.
description: GOLDNER-Rose Trilling. Of Ardsley, NY. Died on December 12, 2000. Beloved wife of Sig; mother of Nancy and David Goldner and mother-in-law of Jules Cohn; grandmother of Paul and Daniel Goldner; Sister of Charlotte Trilling; cherished member of the entire Goldner family. A memorial will be held at a future date.

title: WIRELESS COMPANIES TO MERGE
description: Aether Systems agreed to acquire RTS Wireless for $111.5 million in stock and cash in a deal that is expected to broaden the array of mobile Internet services Aether offers to large wireless carriers. The deal will advance Aether's plans to sell software that enables carriers to provide services like instant messaging on cell phones. The deal is another in a string among small wireless Internet companies that have had difficulty raising funds through the sale of stock or debt. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Fighting the Battle of (and for) Her Life, With Help
description: Four decades ago, Alice Ellen Litwin would stand on Brighton Beach in the afternoon and serenade her aunt's friends with a cheery soprano voice and a few of her favorite songs.

description: As the longtime owner of the local barbershop, Hank Mascolo keeps his finger on the pulse of the political sentiments here.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE JUSTICE; Justice Thomas Speaks Out on a Timely Topic, Several of Them, in Fact
description: A day after the Supreme Court ensured that George W. Bush would be the next president, Justice Clarence Thomas told a group of high school students that it was a mistake for anyone to believe that politics played a role in any of the court's deliberations and decisions.

title: Metro Business Briefing; YESHIVA BUYS HOTEL
description: Yeshiva University agreed yesterday to buy one of Manhattan's last residential hotels for young women from the Ladies Christian Union for $7.25 million. The university plans to use the building, called Roberts House, as a dorm for its Stern College for Women, according to Roberto Ortiz, director of Eastern Consolidated, which brokered the deal. The university has been interested in the building, at 151 East 36th Street, since it went up for sale in June because it is within walking distance of Stern College, on 35th Street and Lexington Avenue, Mr. Ortiz said. Yeshiva plans to rewire the building for Internet access and to install new air-conditioners, Mr. Ortiz said. The school hopes to have the dormitory ready by next August, he said. Eun Lee Koh (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSON, DONALD P.
description: DICKSON-Donald P. Of Pomfret Center, CT. Died of a heart attack on December 12, 2000. He was a member of the class of ''49'' Princeton University. After 77 good and happy years of life and 53-1/2 years of a sensational marriage. Survived by wife and lover Georganna; by sons, David, Peter, John and Andrew; their wives, Paula, Janet, Mary and Lur; ten wonderful grandchildren. Predeceased by a daughter, Ann, and brother, Bob, who was a true brother in every sense of the word. If remembrances are desired, please consider The Don & Georganna Book Fund at Princeton University Library; Christ Church, Pomfret; The Bob Glenn Scholarship Fund, Pomfret School.

title: ORACLE TO GET STAKE IN EXCHANGE
description: The big software maker Oracle will take an undisclosed stake in Covisint as part of an agreement to provide software to the new auto-industry online trade exchange. Though financial terms were not released, a spokesman for Covisint said that Oracle was likely to have a stake similar to that of Commerce One, another business software maker, which said on Tuesday that it would receive a 2 percent share of Covisint. The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler announced plans for the exchange in February, and it officially opened for business on Monday.

title: A Web Site That Came in From the Cold to Unveil Russian Secrets
description: ANDREI SOLDATOV sits down in the lobby of the Hotel Rossija in Moscow, orders tea, flips open his Sony Vaio laptop and logs on to the Internet to demonstrate his Web site via his wireless modem. A Vaio may not be an exploding pen or an umbrella that doubles as a machine gun, but in modern Russia, a high-tech laptop and wireless modem are about as James Bond as gadgets get. This is appropriate, given that his Mr. Soldatov's Web site, www.agentura.ru, is about Russian espionage.

title: In Crisis, California to Force Big Utilities to Supply Power
description: California's power crisis deepened today as some big electricity generating companies refused to sell power to the state's financially ailing utilities, prompting Energy Secretary Bill Richardson to say that he would invoke rarely used emergency powers and force them to ship the desperately needed power.

title: Young & Rubicam Closing Trend Unit
description: Young & Rubicam in New York is closing its trend-watching and brand-consulting unit, the Intelligence Factory, at the end of the month. Ira Matathia and Marian Salzman have led the unit since it was formed in November 1997 under the name Brand Futures Group.

title: Costly Contracts Make Insurance Costs Rise
description: During the Texas Rangers' pursuit of Alex Rodriguez, the team knew that in addition to paying the former Seattle shortstop $252 million over 10 years, it would also need to pay millions to insure him against a disabling injury.

title: Honey, They Blew Up The Housewares
description: AS Edwin Perez described it, he might have been helping an untrained rider onto a stamping horse.

title: Man Convicted of Midtown Brick Attack Gets Maximum Sentence of 25 Years
description: A drug peddler was sentenced to the maximum term of 25 years in prison yesterday for a brick attack on a Manhattan street corner that shattered a woman's skull and left the city stunned by the outburst of random violence.

title: MUSICBANK IN DEAL WITH EMI
description: The start-up online music company MusicBank said it had reached a licensing agreement with the EMI Group. MusicBank plans to introduce its service later this month; the service will allow consumers who own CD's to listen to them online without having to upload the recordings manually. The company already has agreements with Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment, Vivendi Universal's Universal Music Group, Time Warner's Warner Music Group and Sony Music Entertainment. A similar service that MP3.com offered, without first getting licenses, attracted lawsuits by major record companies. MP3.com later settled for about $170 million.

Visitation Wednesday and Thursday, 4-9pm, Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., NY, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 10am, December 15th, St. Bernard's Church 330 W. 14th St. In lieu of flowers donations in her name may be sent to the National Arts Club, Music Scholarship Fund, 15 Gramercy Park South, N.Y.C. or the New York Youth Symphony, 850 7th Ave, NYC.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cries of Alarm as Nasdaq Adds Details to Its New Trading Plan
description: After more than a year and a ton of tinkering, executives at the Nasdaq stock market are confident that their plan for a new, comprehensive stock trading system will soon be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But with each additional detail that Nasdaq has provided about the plan, the more devilish some investors think it has become.

title: Clinton, in Ulster, Confronts Warring Passions Head-On
description: President Clinton received a blunt reminder of the heated passions that remain in Northern Ireland today as he visited the National Assembly and found himself caught up in a spirited debate with a small group of hard-line lawmakers who oppose a peace accord that he helped forge.

title: Selling Mutual Funds With Beauty, Not Numbers
description: Mutual funds, especially in the United States, have tended to rely on masculine images, heavy on performance-driven themes, to get their message across. Now, two European asset managers are getting in touch with their softer side.

title: LLOYDS TSB PURSUES ABBEY
description: In an effort to win over shareholders without making a hostile bid, Lloyds TSB defended its latest offer of $:13.37 ($19.37) for each share of Abbey National in a filing with the London Stock Exchange. Abbey National had been in talks with the Bank of Scotland about a merger when Lloyds intervened with a bid, which it later sweetened to be worth about 40 percent more per share than the Bank of Scotland offer. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Yanks Ponder Deal With Jeter
description: The Yankees have had not had any discussions with Derek Jeter's agent since Alex Rodriguez signed his 10-year, $252 million contract with the Texas Rangers on Monday, but they are hopeful about signing him to a multiyear contract soon.

title: Alternative Rap Gains Steam
description: Two styles of music dominated the pop charts this year: preening teeny-bopper pop and street-themed rap. Waiting on the sidelines, however, are the antitheses to these two genres. New metal bands like Slipknot, Papa Roach, the Deftones and System of a Down have been picking up steam for some time, selling more than 500,000 copies of their albums and providing an antidote for teenagers whose sense of rebellion is not quite being fulfilled by 'N Sync.

Jerome Berns. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Jerry and all of their friends, family, and colleagues. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Suzanne Berns Memorial Scholarship Fund at the CIA. BERNS-Suzie. Our lives were blessed when we met Suzie, a woman of extraordinary grace, elegance, humor, generosity, and charm. We will never forget her. Love, Ellen Rooney, Michael Krumholz, Joey, and Kathryn. BERNS-Suzanne. The ''21'' family sends Mr. Jerry deepest sympathy and much love on the loss of his beloved wife, Suzanne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SYLVIA
description: SIEGEL-Sylvia, 82. Of Lawrence, N.Y. and Del Ray Beach, Fla. Born in Brooklyn, daughter of Morris and Sadie Horowitz. Married for nearly 60 years to Jacob H. Siegel. Mother of Judge Marsha S. Berzon (& Stephen) of Berkeley, CA; Arthur (& Carol) of Riverdale, N.Y.; Beth (& David Kornetsky) of Newton, Mass; Marion (& Peter Ide) of Falls Church, VA. description: Art in the Round

title: Artists vs. Dot-Coms: Fighting San Francisco's Gold Rush
description: ON the evening of Dec. 2, AK Press, an anarchist book publisher, held an eviction party, an increasingly common occasion here. Four years after moving into an unheated warehouse in the Mission District, it had fallen victim to spiraling rents. ''Dress warm,'' the invitation warned. A few blocks away, on newly fashionable Valencia Street, restaurants offered valet parking. But AK Press's guests -- a mix of graying bohemians and magenta-haired young activists -- arrived mostly by bike or by bus.

title: AFTER BUYING CIGNA UNITS, ACE SUES FOR CONTRACT BREACH
description: ACE Ltd., which paid $3.45 billion in cash last year for the Cigna Corporation's property and casualty insurance units, sued Cigna for breach of contract in federal court yesterday, accusing it of misrepresenting the value of the businesses. ACE, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, asserted that after the deal closed, it found over $170 million in ''clear accounting and bookkeeping errors'' in financial statements prepared by Cigna and that Cigna had improperly kept $48 million that should have been refunded to the property and casualty units. A Cigna spokesman did not immediately return a call seeking comment. Cigna, now mainly a health insurer, is based in Philadelphia.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE HISTORY LESSON; Breyer, in Dissent, Sees Repeat of Tarnished Past
description: In his dissent from the majority opinion in the Supreme Court's ruling on the Florida recount, Justice Stephen G. Breyer explained his convictions in part by reciting a history lesson he saw in the elongated and topsy-turvy presidential election of 1876.

description: A little more than two months into their season, the Rangers are still a work in progress. At 15-16 after Tuesday night's 3-2 loss in San Jose, they are again in danger of not making the playoffs.

title: A Pen-Size Web Camera For the Well-Connected Spy
description: A new digital camera called the Pencam Trio looks and feels like something that Q might have designed for James Bond, that is if Bond wanted to send a low-resolution image of Dr. No's hideout to Miss Moneypenny's corporate e-mail account.

title: MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY 18.5% STAKE IN ARGENTINE BANK
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that its international division would acquire an 18.5 percent stake in Banco Rio de la Plata, a private bank based in Buenos Aires, for $261 million. Merrill Lynch agreed to buy a 7.21 percent stake owned by the Fundacion Perez Companc and an 11.33 percent stake owned by the Perez Companc family. Banco Santander Central Hispano owns 79.15 percent of Banco Rio, which has $13.6 billion in assets.

title: McBride Is Ready For Return to Action
description: Brian McBride is committed to making 2001 a happy, but more important, a healthy new year.

title: The Court in the Crossfire
description: For the first time in its history, the Supreme Court has declared the winner of an election. And not just any election. For an institution that must conserve its moral capital, the immediate effect of the split decision threatens to harm the public's confidence, a confidence that Justice Stephen Breyer has called "a public treasure." The deeply fractured opinions in Bush v. Gore will never fully set to rest charges that the court has compromised its integrity.

title: Bridgestone Cuts Earnings Forecast 81%
description: The Bridgestone Corporation cut its earnings forecast 81 percent today and said it would take a $750 million charge to cover a tire recall and possible legal action against its United States unit, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc.

title: A Tale of Two Germanys; Gunter Grass on His New Book and His 'Strenuous Homeland'
description: As a late autumn sun warms the red tiles of Gunter Grass's getaway here, northern Germany could not seem farther away. Yet even in this isolated corner of southern Portugal, where the author escaped a year ago to prepare his Nobel address to the Swedish Academy, where he vacations every summer with his grandchildren, where he now fills his afternoons painting watercolors, Mr. Grass never quite leaves Germany.

description: After nearly a year of review, the Federal Trade Commission has set a meeting for Thursday to decide whether to approve the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, taking a vote that officials said today remained too difficult to call.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE LEGAL ISSUES; Concession on 'Deadline' Helped Seal Gore's Defeat
description: Back on Nov. 20, during what would be the first of a series of historic oral arguments, the chief justice of the Florida Supreme Court turned to David Boies, the chief lawyer for Vice President Al Gore, and asked a question.

title: Transcript Tells of Alaska Airlines Pilots' Efforts Before Crash
description: Five miles above the Pacific Ocean, alone with a mechanical problem they could not counter or even completely diagnose, the crew of Alaska Airlines Flight 261 seemed to try everything to save their plane, even as it rolled upside down and rocked back and forth in the last moments of flight.

title: Self-Advertising On the Web
description: It is fitting that since book publishing has become so driven by marketing, more and more authors of popular works are turning to Web sites to give us what could be called the equipages of their lives. Which is to say they want to bind us as readers by making us their friends. Usually, there's little elegance to the material on the sites of most best-selling authors, but nonetheless -- perhaps even because of that -- there's certainly an hour or two of great entertainment to be had in scrolling through them. On the other hand, the sites for the more literary writers demand understanding, not familiarity.

title: Hard Hat, Lunch Bucket, Keyboard
description: IT was a damp, chilly and overcast day in Toronto, but Chris Holm-Laursen, a field technician for Bell Canada who spends most of his time outdoors, barely felt the cold. title: DOW CHEMICAL WILL NOT BID FOR BRAZILIAN PLANT
description: Dow Chemical surprised analysts by announcing yesterday that it would not bid for control of Brazil's largest petrochemicals plant, Petroquimica do Nordeste, known as Copene, at an auction that might be held this week. The auction of a state-owned 77 percent stake in the plant, expected to bring $600 million to $1.6 billion, was postponed by a Brazilian court last Thursday because the bidding rules were not clear enough. Two bidders remain in the hunt, Grupo Ultra of Brazil and Perez Companc of Argentina. Dow said it pulled out for strategic reasons and to avoid complicating regulatory approval of its pending merger with Union Carbide.

Mr. Sahin, left, who became a large Lucent shareholder after his company, Kenan Systems, was acquired by the big telephone equipment maker in a $1.5 billion stock deal in 1999, left the company after disagreeing with a plan to dismember the software development unit into several separate divisions. Mr. Sahin's departure follows that of John Hughes, the head of wireless equipment for European networks, who resigned earlier this month. Lucent is revamping to counter a slowdown in sales growth.

Each comes with a notecard and two easy-to-peel stickers -- one for the address and one to seal the flap. The envelopes, 4 1/2 by 5 3/4 inches, offer a festive way to send a holiday gift check or a New Year's Eve invitation. They also make a nice wallet for carrying photographs. title: REGULATORS ALLOW EXELON TO BUY POWER PLANTS' STAKES
description: The Exelon Corporation won approval from regulators to buy stakes in power plants that are part of its purchase of a 49.9 percent interest in the Sithe Energies unit of Vivendi of France for $680 million. In allowing the transfer, the regulators rejected concerns expressed by a Boston-based utility, NStar, that the transfer would give Exelon control of 60 percent of electric generation for northeastern Massachusetts during peak power periods. Exelon was formed in October by the merger of Peco Energy in Philadelphia and Unicom in Chicago. The sale will leave Vivendi with 33 percent of Sithe's North American business; Marubeni of Japan owns 15 percent and Sithe's managers, 2 percent.

title: Mets Make Roster Moves
description: The Mets have not gone to an arbitration hearing in nine years, and they avoided two potential cases yesterday by designating for assignment infielder Matt Franco and pitcher Pat Mahomes, removing both from the 40-man roster. That means Franco and Mahomes will probably be traded or given free agency within a week. The Class AAA right-hander Lariel Gonzalez was also designated for assignment.

title: Furby Hacker Tinkers, Then He Simplifies

title: In Downturn, An Overhaul For Whirlpool

The solemnity of last night's prime-time speeches by Al Gore and George W. And even as this bizarre election ended, neither man could entirely escape the media images he had created over the past year.

title: Metro Business Briefing; INSIDE TRADER SENTENCED

Pomponio, a North Caldwell, N.J., businessman who made $31,000 by trading on secret stock tips leaked by the former chairman of the Manhattan investment bank Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., was sentenced yesterday to 21 months in prison. The former chairman, James J. McDermott Jr., is now serving eight months for revealing inside information to a Miami sex film actress, Kathryn B. Gannon. Prosecutors say Ms. Gannon passed the tips on to Mr. Pomponio. Judge Kimba M. Wood of United States District Court in Manhattan rejected Mr. Pomponio's plea for leniency, a lawyer said. Ms. Gannon is fighting extradition from Vancouver, British Columbia.

The Advance will go on sale in the United States and Europe next July. Nintendo has sold more than 100 million Game Boys since 1989.

title: WITH SALES SHRINKING, MAYTAG WARNS ABOUT PROFITS
description: The Maytag Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would fall by about half because sales of washers, ovens and other appliances were shrinking. The announcement is the third profit warning this year from the company, and follows by a day a similar warning from its rival, Whirlpool. The company's interim chief executive, Leonard Hadley, said the company would respond by giving more emphasis to its less expensive Magic Chef and Admiral brands and less to its flagship brand. Maytag also said it would take a charge of $55 million to $65 million for various belt-tightening costs. Shares of Maytag, based in Newton, Iowa, fell $2.50, or 8.4 percent, to $27.19.

title: What Mr. Bush Can Do
description: One of the more poignant moments in Vice President Al Gore's memorable concession speech was his expression of regret that he would not be able to stay and fight for people ''who need burdens lifted and barriers removed.'' Mr. Gore's dedication to social justice and his commitment on issues such as health care were the noblest part of his campaign. We were struck therefore by the intersecting sentiments in President-elect George W. Bush's speech. He spoke of improving health care and retirement security and a determination to ''address some of society's deepest problems one person at a time.'' Republicans and Democrats can use the same words to mean different things, of course. But in using the word ''bipartisan'' three times and ''together'' 12 times, Mr. Bush seemed determined to reintroduce himself as someone who would come up with social and economic policies that draw support from both sides of the Capitol.

title: Is There Any Hope for a Dyslexic Mind Reader?

Mel Gibson plays Nick Marshall, a cool-cat Chicago advertising executive with the Strip in his blood. His mother was a showgirl and raised him like a Vegas princeling. Now he prowls the streets of Chicago with a sexist joke at the ready, just like the cigarette that perches in the corner of his mouth. Nick is an unrepentant chauvinist: ''a man's man who doesn't get what women are all about,'' sighs his ex-wife, Gigi (Lauren Holly). His teenage daughter, Alex (well played by Ashley Johnson), thinks he's a jerk.

(''Realm,'' for that matter, is another bit of fudging.)

title: PLUS: BASEBALL

description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that an embattled New York tour company's buses should be temporarily banned from city streets. The ban will last until a judge decides whether to permanently revoke the company's license.

title: Home Video: Talking About a Conversation
description: Could a film like "The Conversation" be made now? "Tougher now," Francis Ford Coppola said the other day about his movie, released in 1974. "But I'm not sure that kind of film could be made then, either, which is to say it always takes some other kind of leverage, here being that you made `The Godfather' so they'll let you go and make a cheap little movie you want to make."

title: AOL SECURITY FLAW DISCOVERED
description: Some versions of America Online's popular Instant Messenger software have a security flaw that could allow a malicious hacker to take control of the user's machine. The flaw in the World Wide Web-based version of the software was brought to light by the Internet security firm @Stake. The attack is possible even if the Instant Messenger software, which is included with every copy of the Netscape Web browser, is not used. ''We recently discovered a potential issue with the Web-based A.I.M. program and immediately fixed it,'' an AOL spokesman said, adding that no breaches based on the flaw had been reported. AOL has published an updated version of the software that blocks the attack at http://www.aol.com/aim/home.html. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Overcoming Bitterness On the Way to Redemption
description: In ''The Visit,'' a young man named Alex Waters (Hill Harper), dying of AIDS while in prison for a rape he may not have committed, must struggle to overcome his own bitterness and to repair his relationships with his family. The film, directed with fluidity and restraint by Jordan Walker-Pearlman, is also about that family -- about the effect Alex's predicament, as his father delicately calls it, has on his parents (Billy Dee Williams and Marla Gibbs) and his elder brother, Tony (Obba Babatunde).

description: Cisco Systems agreed to acquire ExiO Communications for about $155 million in stock in a deal that will enhance Cisco's ability to offer its customers access to corporate and public networks using a single wireless device. The acquisition of ExiO, a company with operations in South Korea that develops technology under the code division multiple access wireless standard, comes after Cisco's purchase earlier this year of JetCell Inc., a similar company that uses the competing global system for mobile communications wireless standard. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAILMOR, ELAINE
description: GAILMOR-Elaine, 84. Of Westport, Connecticut, died December 2, in Florida. An Honors graduate in sociology at NYU she served many years as the Administrator of the Miquon School, an innovative, progressive private elementary school in Miquon, PA. A tireless crusader for peace and human rights, she thrived on lively political dialogue, peppered with humor. She was predeceased by her husband, William S. Gailmor, a journalist and popular news commentator in New York whose radio career was aburptly ended by the Blacklist in the late 1940's, and a brother Robert E. Pantell. She is survived by her daughter and sonin-law Wendy and David Newton of Weston, Connecticut; her son Jon Gailmor, daughter-in-law Cathy Murphy, and grandchildren Aaron, Maya and Micaela, of Lake Elmore, Vermont; and her companion of many years Richard Temko. Characteristically, a few days before her death, she commented on the post-election Florida fiasco: ''If I'd been up and around, none of this would have happened.'' She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRICK, HELEN (CASEY) ISAACS
description: HERRICK-Helen (Casey) Isaacs, 87, daughter of Stanley Myron Isaacs and Edith Somborn, and wife of Snowden Terhune Herrick. Descendant of Myron Samuel Isaacs, founding Rabbi of Temple Sha'aray Tefila. Stanley M. Isaacs was former Borough President of Manhattan. Edith Somborn was the author of his biography ''Love Affair with a City''. Husband Snowden T. Herrick was former Deputy Director of Public Relations for the United Nations Center for Social and Economic Information (CESI). Mrs. Herrick founded and was Editor and Publisher of ''The Weekly Tribune'', the only English language newspaper in Switzerland, was a civil rights advocate and patron of theater and the arts. She was the co-founder and director of Population Communications International, and served on the Board of the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center. Mrs. Herrick is survived by: son, Michael M. Herrick, Executive Chef, Royal Amsterdam Hotel, Pella, Iowa; granddaughter, Sanne Herrick; surrogate daughter Ava Stern, Managing Director, BSMG Worldwide in NYC; nephews John Isaacs, President, Council for a Livable World, Washington, D.C., and Stanley Isaacs, Palo Alto, California; and niece Jane Isaacs Toussaint, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Service to be held at Temple Sha'aray Tefila Sunday, December 17, reception to follow at the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center. Further details, phone 917-856-3486.

title: HARVEYS CASINO IS DELAYING ITS TAKEOVER OF PINNACLE
description: Harveys Casino Resorts, a casino operator based in Lake Tahoe, Nev., is delaying its takeover of a rival, Pinnacle Entertainment, the two companies said in separate statements. Neither company gave a reason. In April, Harveys, which is closely held, agreed to buy Pinnacle for $578 million in cash, or $24 a share, and to assume about $650 million in debt. The deal, which Harveys said had not been called off, would combine Pinnacle casinos in Mississippi, Louisiana, Nevada and Argentina with Harveys casinos in Nevada, Iowa and Colorado. Shares of Pinnacle, based in Glendale, Calif., fell $6.06, or 28 percent, to $15.31.

title: A Russian Return to Havana
description: President Vladimir Putin is in Cuba this week, on a visit rich in symbolism. But Mr. Putin, the first Russian leader to visit Havana since the disintegration of the Soviet Union, brings a substantive agenda as well. He seeks to repair political and economic ties that have frayed in recent years. The days are past when Moscow's relations with Havana threatened American security. But Mr. Putin should not provoke Washington by expanding Russian arms sales to Cuba or helping Havana complete an unfinished civilian nuclear reactor.

title: The Sympathetic Eye On a Metropolitan Beat
description: Just 100 years ago a 23-year-old painter called Everett Shinn made a considerable splash with his first exhibition in New York. It was in a very good gallery on Fifth Avenue. title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW BANK BRANCHES
description: Commerce Bancorp Inc., which owns banks in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, said it would open 10 to 15 new branches in Essex County, N.J., over the next three years. The first two branches, which will be open seven days a week, are scheduled to open in the spring in Bloomfield and Fairfield, the company said in a news release. Company officials could not be immediately reached for comment. Commerce Bancorp, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., plans to add 30 locations in eastern New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware next year. The bank says it is New Jersey's largest local bank, with about $8 billion in assets and 150 branches. It had 1999 revenue of $386.5 million.

title: JUDGE RAISES CONCERNS ABOUT WORLDCOM ACQUISITION
description: A Delaware Chancery Court judge, while refusing yesterday to block WorldCom's planned acquisition of Intermedia Communications, said that actions by some Intermedia executives might expose WorldCom to $2.5 billion in damage claims if the deal was completed. The judge said Intermedia executives serving on the board of Digex, a company that Intermedia controls, might have violated their legal duties to Digex shareholders by waiving anti-takeover defenses to smooth the path for WorldCom's acquisition of Intermedia. His ruling led investors to doubt that the deal would go through, causing Intermedia's stock to fall $5.25, or 43 percent, closing at $7. Shares of Digex rose $2.19, to $31.44.

title: Ndabaningi Sithole, 80, Fighter for Zimbabwe
description: The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, a black nationalist who rose to prominence championing the downfall of Rhodesia's white-minority government and then fell from official favor for denouncing the ruling party he helped to install in what is now Zimbabwe, died on Tuesday.

title: Highland Highlights: Scottish Master Drawings

It's at the Frick Collection, and the pleasure is all ours.

Beloved wife of Sig; mother of Nancy and David Goldner and mother-in-law of Jules Cohn; grandmother of Paul and Daniel Goldner; Sister of Charlotte Trilling; cherished member of the entire Goldner family. A memorial will be held at a future date.

title: Yesterday's Heroes, Up on Pedestals
description: ''You must think you belong in the Hall of Fame.'' That was my mother's put-down when anyone exhibited what she called delusions of grandeur. Growing up in the 1930's, when the Hall of Fame was famous, I wasn't sure of its appearance and exact location; but I never doubted its existence, as each year four or five inductees were announced with much fanfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, JUSTIN SABLE
description: OPPENHEIM-Justin Sable, age 77. Died peacefully on December 14, 2000. Devoted husband of Joyce. Adored father of Janet Wexler, Judith Darrah and Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather of Abigail and Jill Wexler; Samuel, Gabrielle and Julius Oppenheim. Caring brother of Mona. Services 10 AM Sunday, December 17, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Chase and Morgan Say Earnings Will Fall Short
description: The deep slump in stock and bond markets, combined with a slowing economy, is exacting a heavy toll on Wall Street.

description: CALLAGHAN-Theresa M. (nee Rothwell) on Wednesday, December 13, 2000 of Wayne, NJ. Beloved wife of the late John E. (1981). Beloved mother of Edward, Eugene and John Callaghan and Theresa Lamberski. She filled the lives of her family and friends with joy. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 AM, Holy Cross. Visiting Friday 2-4, 7-9 PM at the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, Wayne, NJ.

title: Campaign-Finance Bill Poses Problems for Candidates in New Jersey Governor's Race
description: As two prominent New Jersey Republicans prepare for what is likely to be an expensive and contentious primary battle for governor, a single piece of campaign-finance reform legislation is suddenly taking on heightened significance.

title: Agency Finds Many Health Plans Should Cover Contraceptive Costs
description: Millions of American women who have been paying for birth-control pills out of their own pockets may have a claim for insurance coverage, under a ruling by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that employers are discriminating against women when they offer insurance coverage for preventive health care like drugs to lower blood pressure, but exclude prescription contraceptives.

title: Tooning In to Morals
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Yemeni on Delicate Path in bin Laden Hunt
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said today that he would support American efforts to seize Osama bin Laden, the F.B.I's most wanted terrorism suspect, if Mr. bin Laden is found to have inspired or directed the Oct. 12 bombing of the destroyer Cole, which killed 17 American sailors, wounded 39 others and heavily damaged the ship.

description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Tough On Gangsters, High Tech And Global
description: The Clinton administration says that sophisticated, well-connected networks of international criminals are a real and growing national security threat, and plans Friday to issue a study that documents the rise of transnational criminal syndicates that know no boundaries to their illicit activities.

title: Rutgers Outlasts Princeton
description: Rutgers trailed for most of tonight's game, but the Scarlet Knights led when it mattered most.

title: In Utah, an Old-School Coach With Tenure
description: Long before John Stockton and Karl Malone policed his locker room, Jerry Sloan's players once turned on him. It happened in 1982, only days before the Chicago Bulls fired him. He did not work as a head coach again for six years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECKEWELL, CARL A.
description: RECKEWELL-Carl A., 65. On December 9, 2000, after a long illness. Loving husband of Joyce, beloved son of Dorothy, and brother of Elsa Gibbons. Services were held.

Cherished grandmother of Claire Ellison, Matthew Dowell, Eric Lewenstein and Scott Stevens. She was the first model of the Ford Model Agency and one of the 12 most photographed women of the 1940s. A noted photographer and recipient of several awards. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Monday, December 18, 2000, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: American Jailed as Spy in Moscow Is Freed on Putin's Orders; U.S. Welcomes Gesture
description: Edmond Pope, an American businessman and retired naval intelligence officer who had been convicted of espionage by a Russian court and sentenced to 20 years in prison, was pardoned today by President Vladimir V. Putin and was immediately flown out of Russia.

title: Sports of The Times; LaFontaine Savors Life After Hockey
description: PAT LaFONTAINE has been to that murky corner of the universe where Troy Aikman seems to be spending more of his time.

title: Princeton Video To Buy Mexican Unit
description: Princeton Video Image in Lawrenceville, N.J., a company that inserts virtual advertising images, like signs and logos, into television programs, is expanding by buying Publicidad Virtual de CV in Mexico City. Financial terms of the deal, to be announced formally today, were not disclosed.

title: PSEG GLOBAL IS ACQUIRING 90% OF ARGENTINE COMPANY
description: PSEG Global, the international unit of Public Service Enterprise Group, a Newark utility holding company, said it had agreed to acquire a 90 percent stake in Empresa Distribuidora de Electricidad de Entre Rios S.A., an electricity distributor in Argentina, for $200 million, plus the assumption of $80 million of debt. Empresa has 230,000 customers in the Argentine province of Entre Rios. PSEG Global owns power plants and utilities on several continents.

title: Candy Power Comes to Town
description: ''Chocolat'' poses a less-than-penetrating question: Can the liberating virtues of pleasure -- here embodied by the warm, inviting power of chocolate -- triumph over well-meaning but closed-minded small-town zealots?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURZ, ARNOLD WOLFGANG
description: KURZ-Arnold Wolfgang. My darling Arnie. Ten years ago today. 12/15/90. Always in my heart, always in my soul. I steer by your star. Your Donna

title: As Museum Move Evokes Tweed, City Hall Is Criticized
description: Officials for the Museum of the City of New York yesterday defended their sudden decision this week to move the institution from a city-owned building in Upper Manhattan to a city-owned building in Lower Manhattan, amid criticism that the Giuliani administration had engineered the move in secrecy and with arrogance.

title: Favorable Lease Deals May Be Fading Fast
description: THE boom in leasing that propelled the auto market to sales records shows signs of fizzling out, as auto companies' finance subsidiaries and other lenders confront some discouraging financial facts.

title: As the President-Elect Takes Center Stage; With an Asterisk
description: To the Editor:

title: Classrooms Still Overflowing, Study Finds
description: New York City's public schools are less crowded than they were a year ago, but more than half of all city elementary schools still operate at or above capacity, according to a study released yesterday by Public Advocate Mark Green.

title: 'Tibor de Nagy Gallery: The First 50 Years'
description: Tibor de Nagy
