description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Yankees Bringing Boehringer Back
description: The Yankees signed Brian Boehringer, one of their former pitchers, to a minor league contract yesterday and will give him the opportunity to win a spot in their bullpen in spring training.

title: George Montgomery, Dashing Cowboy, Is Dead at 84
description: George Montgomery, a Westerner to the core, who went from prizefighter to stuntman to cowboy star before turning his energies to sculpture, furniture-making and painting, died on Tuesday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 84.

title: Firestone and Ford Make Progress on Tire Inquiries
description: Firestone and Ford Motor have made considerable progress in their investigations into the tire-related crashes that have killed more than 100 Americans, mostly in Ford Explorers, but they remained divided on some basic issues as they presented their results to regulators this week, people close to the inquiries said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: More Bad Earnings News Pulls Stock Prices Lower

title: Hermanson And Wells Lost to Mets
description: After falling short in their effort to sign Mike Hampton, the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday switched to the trade market for a pitcher, acquiring Dustin Hermanson. The Mets failed to re-sign Hampton, who went to Colorado, but they will not be replacing him with David Wells any time soon.

title: Some Tangled Issues Kept F.T.C. on Edge During Negotiations
description: As he sat in his office earlier this fall, Mozelle W. Thompson, the member of the Federal Trade Commission most skeptical about the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner, described to the companies' top executives how his TV screen went blue when Time Warner abruptly pulled ABC from its cable systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, MARGARETTA P. (NEE EGAN)
description: COLLINS-Margaretta P. (nee Egan), native of County Roscommon, Ireland. Devoted wife of the late Michael F. Beloved mother of Michael, Mary Teresa Macchiarola, Martin and Rev. James P. (Chaplain of Bishop Kearney H.S.). Loving mother-in-law of Patricia and Frank. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Joseph, Michael and Frank Macchiarola. Funeral Saturday, 8:45AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass St. Francis de Sales RC Church, at 9:45AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Francis College Scholarship Fund, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Ellis to Make First Jets Start
description: Shaun Ellis likes to say he has played in big games before. After all, he went to Tennessee, where a ferocious Southeastern Conference schedule prepared the Volunteers for annual runs at the national championship. But even Ellis admits that no game will be bigger than this Sunday's against Detroit, with a playoff berth on the line. Ellis, a first-round draft pick, will make his first professional start at defensive end, in place of the injured Rick Lyle, who is out for the season with a broken leg.

title: 'Something Happened'
description: Apex Art Curatorial Program

title: Changes at the Top At Post & Partners
description: Principals of Post & Partners in New York and its predecessor agency, Emmerling Post, have new duties.

title: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: AFTER THE VOTE -- A special report.; In Desperate Florida Fight, Gore's Hard Strategic Calls
description: Clearly it was going to be an important meeting, important enough that Vice President Al Gore thought his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, should breach the Sabbath to be there.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DUKE ENERGY, Houston, an energy-trading company, said it had sold a 23 percent stake in a 500-megawatt gas-fueled power plant it is building in Newcastle, Okla., to the Oklahoma Municipal Power Authority. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Officers
description: Five angry and distraught police officers in Orange, N.J., turned a deserted police headquarters hallway into ''a stairwell of torture,'' as they beat and sprayed with pepper spray an unarmed man they mistakenly thought had killed a fellow officer, a prosecutor charged as closing arguments in the case began today.

title: Regents Back 6 Charter Schools; Total Is Now 33
description: The New York State Board of Regents approved six new charter schools yesterday in New York City suburbs and upstate areas, bringing the number of the publicly financed, privately managed schools in the state to 33.

title: Anderson Has New Role: Starting in Pro Bowl
description: There was a time not long ago when Richie Anderson entered the Jets' training camp and wondered if he would outlast it. He wondered if the bubble on which he seemed to perpetually teeter would finally burst beneath him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSELLE, JANE GARTMAN
description: HERSELLE - Jane Gartman. March 12, 1903-December 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David, adored mother of Carol Krinsky and husband Robert D. Krinsky, dearest grandmother to Alice, John, and Keren Osman, greatgrandmother to Maya OsmanKrinsky. Mourned also by brotherin-law, Martin Cherry. Funeral private. Memorial gathering to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to Planned Parenthood or the National Dance Institute.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, BETTY (SUSSKIND)
description: WEISS-Betty (Susskind). After 10 years, you are still with us. Len, Jeff and Bil

title: Blake and Kings Tie Up Rangers
description: Rangers Coach Ron Low told the Czechs: Shoot the puck, shoot the puck.

title: I'm Not Dead Yet: Genetic Mutation That Lives Up to Its Name Is Found
description: By slightly disabling a single gene, researchers report that they have doubled the life span of fruit flies. Scientists said the discovery opens a new arena in the fast-developing field that studies life extension.

title: In Gaza Strip, The Israelis And Arafat Get Together
description: Senior Israeli officials began meetings with the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat tonight in an effort to revive the peace talks, part of a sudden burst of diplomatic activity seeking to break the hostile stalemate between the two sides.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Workers Get Greater Drug Test Protection
description: The Transportation Department announced new rules yesterday to protect the rights of 8.5 million workers who undergo drug testing that the government makes mandatory as a safety measure. But critics, while welcoming the changes, said they did not go far enough.

title: HONG KONG BANKS TO MERGE
description: The Bank of China said it planned to merge its Hong Kong operations with 10 sister banks to create a single entity that would be the second-largest bank in the territory after HSBC Holdings. The Bank of China is one of China's four major state-owned commercial banks and is responsible for all foreign exchange transactions. The new entity is expected to list its shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Glut of Used S.U.V.'s Will Cost New Buyers
description: SPORT utilities have suffered the most from a decline in the residual values of leased vehicles. Now lenders are waiting to see what happens when a redesigned version of the Ford Explorer, the nation's most popular S.U.V., goes on sale in February.

title: AOL AND TIME WARNER GAIN APPROVAL FOR HUGE MERGER, BUT WITH STRICT CONDITIONS
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner today, clearing the way for the creation of the world's biggest media business. The agency's approval came after the two companies agreed to stringent conditions meant to ensure competition in providing Internet services and the interactive television systems of the future.

title: The Devils Are Given Their Rings
description: The Devils' captain, Scott Stevens, walked around the dressing room after today's practice displaying his Stanley Cup ring with as much pride on his face as he did last June in Dallas, when he carried the Stanley Cup and the Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the playoffs.

title: Beyond Dickens and the Land of Sweets
description: A sampling of holiday celebrations in New York City. More holiday events are listed on Page 46. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, STANLEY
description: SCHECHTER-Stanley. Longtime member of Jewelry and Watch Industry Executive Committee. Recipient Humanitarian Award. Stanley's dedication to NCCJ's battle against bias and bigotry has been an inspiration. We will miss Stanley and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Mort Weisenfeld, Board Member Maryann B. Coffey, Exec Dir Greater New York Region The National Conference for Community and Justice

title: HSBC HOLDINGS OF LONDON IS IN TALKS TO BUY TURKISH BANK
description: HSBC Holdings of London is in talks to acquire Demirbank, a Turkish bank seized last week by regulators, a government official said yesterday. Before the seizure, HSBC had offered $1 billion for a 50 percent stake in Demirbank; now it is said to be offering that figure for all of it. The government is under pressure to sell 11 seized banks to keep its losses, which now total $7 billion, from mounting much higher. Officials said an announcement about eligible bidders for all 11 seized banks could be expected today.

title: A Salute To Satchmo
description: It's hard to find a child over 5 who can't deliver a spirited rendition of ''When the Saints Go Marching In.'' But ask the same youngster to name the jazz musician most associated with that tune, and you're likely to get a blank stare.

title: Broker Blames Stress of Jail In Plot to Have Judge Killed
description: Testifying for a second day, a jailed stockbroker acknowledged yesterday that he had ordered the murder of a state judge, but attributed his actions to the psychological pressures of imprisonment.

title: CHIP MAKER IS BUYING OUT THREE WAFERTECH PARTNERS
description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing agreed yesterday to buy out some of its partners in WaferTech, a joint venture that operates a wafer plant in Camas, Wash. It will pay $350 million for a 23 percent stake belonging to the Altera Corporation, $60 million for a 4 percent stake belonging to Analog Devices and $40 million for a 2.7 percent stake belonging to Integrated Silicon Solutions. All three transactions should close this month, Taiwan Semiconductor said, giving it about 97 percent ownership of WaferTech.

title: In Policy Switch, City Eases Stance On Water Meters
description: Fourteen years ago, New York City began an ambitious plan to install water meters in every residential building, hoping that charging building owners according to the water used would encourage conservation and prepare the city for the next inevitable drought.

title: Richard Anuszkiewicz
description: Mitchell Algus Gallery

title: Putin Feels Whiff of Soviet Era in Cuba
description: Russia and Cuba, two battered allies who fell out a decade ago when the Soviet Union fell apart, officially got back together today when President Vladimir V. Putin and President Fidel Castro pledged to reinvent the relationship based on a modest agenda of trade and commerce and an equally modest smattering of ideological alignment.

title: Workers Bid Ill-Fated Chernobyl a Bitter Farewell
description: Fourteen years and seven months after an experiment here went unimaginably awry, spewing the radiation of dozens of Hiroshimas across Europe, workers at the Chernobyl nuclear complex gathered today to bid the site's last working nuclear reactor -- and many of their jobs -- a bitter goodbye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUEHLING, GEORGE
description: FRUEHLING-George. Born Fort Madison, Iowa, died November 7, at home in NYC. He is survived by his sister Doris Stigall of Fort Madison, one niece and four nephews. He was predeceased by his companion Joseph Pinto. Donations may be made to the Guild for Exceptional Children, 260 68 Street, Brooklyn, NY 11220.

title: The Big City; Hallowed Be the Name On the Label
description: IF you're tired of sermons denouncing the commercialization of Christmas, you might enjoy a stroll down Fifth Avenue with James B. Twitchell. You will not hear him condemning the crass materialism of the throngs buying $600 purses at Gucci, Fendi and Louis Vuitton. He would rather point out the similarities between those emporiums and St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: U.P.S. and FedEx Cut Their Forecasts on Profits
description: United Parcel Service and the FedEx Corporation both said today that they had cut their profit forecasts because of softness in consumers' holiday spending and a reduction in shipment volume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, ALICE D'O
description: BERGEN-Alice D'O. On December 12 at 94. Beloved wife of the late Robert Bergen. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Robert Jr., Betsy, Frederick and Margaret Ann. In addition, survived by eight grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Memorial service Friday, December 15 at East Hill Woods, Southbury, CT. Contributions to East Hill Woods Memorial Fund, 611 East Hill Rd., Southbury, CT 06488.

title: NATO Won't Allow Serbian Use of Force in Three-Mile Buffer
description: International peacekeepers and administrators here said today that they would not tolerate Serbian police or army use of force to reassert control of a three-mile-wide buffer zone along Kosovo's eastern border that ethnic Albanian rebels control.

title: . . . BUT LOSES AN EXECUTIVE
description: Cisco Systems said its executive vice president, Gary Daichendt, quit, becoming the second of the chief executive John Chambers's top two deputies to leave the maker of networking equipment in the last four months.

title: 2 FRENCH FILM COMPANIES TO COMBINE THEATER NETWORKS
description: Gaumont S.A., a French film producer, distributor and theater owner, and a rival, Pathe S.A., said they would combine their movie theater networks into a single company called EuroPalaces. Pathe, owned by Jerome Seydoux, will control 66 percent of EuroPalaces, while Gaumont, whose chairman is Nicolas Seydoux, Jerome's brother, will own the rest. EuroPalaces will have 700 screens in four countries and annual sales of about 2 billion French francs ($270 million), the companies said.

title: With Eye On Return, Gill Tests Sore Knee
description: As the Nets approached the end of practice today, the team lined up along the baseline and began running a series of sprints and suicide drills. Kendall Gill, with his knee wrapped in a brace, took his place at the end of the court and joined the team for every painful, tiring lap up the floor.

title: In Need of Cash Soon, Xerox Sells China Operations to Fuji
description: Making good on a promise in October to start selling assets before the end of the year, the Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its operations in Hong Kong and mainland China to Fuji Xerox for $550 million in cash.

title: A Dark Lesson In Trust
description: CURTIS HANSON said he wanted to make two points to the actors Russell Crowe and Guy Pearce before they started filming ''L.A. Confidential'' back in 1996. He wanted them to understand how people really looked and moved and talked back in the early 1950's in Southern California, where the story was set. But just as important, he wanted them to see the kind of naked, emotion-driven acting that he thought the complex, hard-boiled story required.

title: 'Collector's Choice'
description: Exit Art

title: Thomas Babe, 59, Playwright For Papp's Public Theater
description: Thomas Babe, the author of ''Kid Champion,'' ''A Prayer for My Daughter'' and other plays, and one of Joseph Papp's most prolific resident playwrights at the New York Shakespeare Festival, died on Dec. 6 in a hospice in Stamford, Conn. He was 59 and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Levy Enraged Over Aid Plan For Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy angrily denounced a $14.5 billion school aid proposal put forth by the State Board of Regents yesterday, calling it ''grossly unjust'' because other cities in the state would receive more per pupil than New York City.

title: Joy of Junk: Bonds Are So Cheap That They Look Good
description: WHAT can explain the carnage in the junk bond market this year? Either investors have panicked or the market is warning of dire problems ahead.

title: Into Alien Territory
description: Audiences will be seeing a different Gillian Anderson in ''The House of Mirth,'' an adaptation of the Edith Wharton novel from the British filmmaker Terence Davies that opens next Friday in New York and Los Angeles. Unlike Dana Scully, the alien-chasing F.B.I. agent she plays on ''The X-Files,'' her character in Mr. Davies's film actually has emotions and is able to express them, albeit in delicate, Whartonesque ways.

title: Oracle Says Earnings Exceed Expectations
description: The Oracle Corporation announced earnings today that modestly exceeded expectations, and company officials said that barring a broad recession, they did not anticipate hitting the kind of obstacles that led to disappointing returns for a number of big-name technology companies in recent weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HARRIET
description: WEISS-Harriet. On Dec. 14, 2000. Beloved wife of Harry. Devoted mother of Susan and Dr. Norman Sonnenklar and Bette and Dr. Richard Weledniger. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Eric, Risa and Leslie and great grandmother of Jacob and Adam. We love you and thank you for all of our shared memories. Services on Friday, 11:30 AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMURA, GERTRUDE TRAIL
description: LaMURA-Gertrude Trail. December 12, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Frank P. LaMura. Dearly loved mother of Gertrude Steinhauser, Cortland, N.Y., Sandra Trail Bruggemann, Waitsfield, VT., Linda Ann McFadden, Tucson, AZ., Edward Locke LaMura, Staten Island, N.Y. Grandmother and great grandmother, whose 100 years and nine months of life will never be forgotten. Services and interment to be announced.

title: ABBOTT IS SAID TO BE BUYING BASF DRUG BUSINESS
description: Abbott Laboratories has agreed to buy Knoll, the pharmaceutical unit of BASF A.G. of Germany, in a transaction worth about 13 billion marks ($6 billion), according to reports in German newspapers, which cited unidentified sources. BASF declined to comment on the report, while Abbott did not return calls seeking comment. Abbott, which bought Knoll's urology drug business earlier in the year, was said especially to covet a Knoll rheumatoid arthritis drug, D2E7, which is thought to have potential for $850 million or more in sales. Eli Lilly & Company and Sanofi-Synthelabo of France were previously reported to be bidders for Knoll.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Talking About A 'Conversation'
description: Could a film like ''The Conversation'' be made now? ''Tougher now,'' Francis Ford Coppola said the other day about his movie, released in 1974. ''But I'm not sure that kind of film could be made then, either, which is to say it always takes some other kind of leverage, here being that you made 'The Godfather' so they'll let you go and make a cheap little movie you want to make.''

title: Gucci Posts Strong Growth, But Share Price Declines
description: The Gucci Group N.V., the luxury goods giant that has been on an aggressive acquisition spree, reported strong revenue and profit growth in the third quarter, largely thanks to the performance of its flagship Gucci division.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 26 about Romania's presidential election referred incorrectly to the country's currency. It is the leu; lei is the plural form.

title: Jarvis and St. John's Plan to Start Over With Clean Slate
description: As his St. John's players gathered around him yesterday at Alumni Hall, Coach Mike Jarvis asked them to start anew.

title: A Hero of the Celtic Renaissance
description: From the cottage I keep in West Clare, I sometimes look across the Shannon Estuary to the Kerry Hills. From the end of the peninsula, I can make out Ballybunion, where Bill Clinton golfed in September 1998, in the midst of the Monica Lewinsky imbroglio. Back in Washington, Senator Joseph Lieberman was calling Mr. Clinton's behavior ''immoral,'' which, of course, it was. But in Ireland a beauty parlor named Monica's on the road to the famous golf course had its sign removed lest it embarrass the motorcadians. The Irish know what's in a name. They also know that words can hurt or heal old wounds.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL IN BELGIUM
description: The mobile telephone subsidiary of Royal KPN will buy out France Telecom's half-interest in their jointly owned mobile company, KPN Orange Belgium, for 500 million euros ($438 million), and will assume 250 million euros ($219 million) in debt, Royal KPN said. France Telecom, which got the stake when it bought Orange from Vodafone earlier this year, had to sell it to satisfy antitrust regulators. KPN Mobile will have the right to use the Orange trademark in Belgium until Oct. 1, 2002. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: DIAMOND MINERS IN TALKS
description: A major South African diamond miner, Trans Hex Group, says it is talking with Mvelaphanda Diamonds, the country's largest black-owned mining company, but did not announce the purpose of the talks. Last year, Trans Hex acquired the Gem Diamond Mining Corporation in a transaction that effectively gave Mvelaphanda about a 9 percent stake in Trans Hex. Mvelaphanda executives have said they want to increase their stake.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It takes perseverance to reach the dining room at Olives. Young merry-makers have colonized the lounge of the W Union Square Hotel, but the clusters of sofas and settees are only the outer perimeter. Next the bar must be negotiated. It's an open question whether the lounge mops up the overflow from the bar, or vice versa. Either way, intrepid diners have every right to feel a sense of accomplishment when they reach their tables.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLAY, ELIZABETH ANNE
description: MALLAY-Elizabeth Anne. On December 13th, 2000. She is survived by Mary Katherine Hawryluk (Richard) and her two children, David and Kevin. Funeral will be held Monday, December 18th at Cathedral of St. Peter and Paul, 18th and The Parkway, Philadelphia. Viewing 9-10 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at 10 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY. Dinan Funeral Home, 215-563-3655.

title: WORKERS HALT KOREAN BANK MERGER
description: Bowing to protests by union workers over threatened job cuts, Kookmin Bank suspended its merger talks with the Housing and Commercial Bank. Kookmin's president, Kim Sang Hoon, who had been trapped in his office for 36 hours by hundreds of protesters, agreed to call off the talks minutes after seeing one worker douse himself with linseed oil and threaten to set himself on fire. The South Korean government, which has been pressing its troubled banking industry to merge, cut costs and restructure, said it expected the talks to resume eventually.

title: A Ruler, Something of a Snake, Becomes a Llama
description: ''The Emperor's New Groove'' is a timely reminder that animated films don't have to be grandiose visual circuses with full Broadway scores to entertain.

title: Plan Would Put Extra Trains On Busy Lines
description: Transit planners say they intend to add more buses and subway trains next year to lines that are straining under the load of millions of new passengers, from the Lexington line's overflowing platforms to the packed E and F trains of Queens.

title: Launching That Small Steel Missile, Hoping Not to Hit the Bar Stool
description: How I wasn't getting slaughtered in the first darts competition of my life, I still can't explain.

title: POLISH EXECUTIVE FIRED
description: The Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa unit of Elektrim, Eastern Europe's largest mobile phone company, said it had fired its chief financial officer, Stanislaw Majewski, because of his unsatisfactory performance. The company did not provide specifics. Its chief executive, Boguslaw Kulakowski, will assume Mr. Majewski's duties until a replacement is found. Elektrim shares, which had plunged before the announcement on a market rumor that the company was far behind in tax payments, rose 2.8 percent to close at 47 zlotys ($10.77) The company denied the tax rumor and asked securities regulators to investigate.

title: Former Head of Rockland Democrats Is Indicted
description: The former chairman of the Rockland County Democratic Party was indicted today on federal corruption charges stemming from a series of real estate transactions, including the development of the Palisades Center Mall in West Nyack.

title: Our System Leaves the Loser Standing
description: Can the process that resolved Bush v. Gore possibly have been good, even if the result may seem to many to be unfair? We have to conclude that it was, even if we may think the supreme court judges of state and nation had their minds clouded by partisan devotions and debts.

title: King and Queen of Kitsch (Ta-daaa!)
description: ''Pete 'n' Keely,'' a campy minimusical by James Hindman, is precisely as funny as a pair of bell-bottom tuxedo pants. They are worn by George Dvorsky, half of a Vegas-y pair of entertainers serving as the hosts and stars of a live television special in 1968. He has the manner and the mustache, not to mention the formalwear, of Robert Goulet on a visit to Ed Sullivan, and the pants are perhaps the subtlest reminder of the show-biz era being sent up, with loopy and overbearing affection, at the John Houseman Theater.

title: Prices Paid to Producers Go Up Slightly as Business Inventories Rise
description: Prices paid to producers in November showed the smallest gain in three months and business inventories rose in October, government figures showed today, indicating that companies have little latitude to raise prices.

title: A Poignant Slice of Lives Restarted
description: Rich theater, capable of touching the heart, tickling the funny bone and tapping wells of recognition, sympathy and suspense while its music sets feet to tapping and hands to clapping, is attesting to the vitality of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater as it begins its 85th season.

title: MITEL TO SELL EQUIPMENT UNIT
description: The Mitel Corporation agreed to sell most of its struggling office phone-equipment business for about 350 million Canadian dollars ($230.8 million) in cash and notes to companies controlled by Terry Matthews, one of Mitel's co-founders. Selling the unit, which provides half of Mitel's revenue, will allow the company to concentrate on its more profitable semiconductor business. Under the deal, Mr. Matthews will also become the nonexecutive chairman of Mitel, but he will not be involved in the day-to-day running of the company, he said.

description: Last week, Russia decided to bring back the old Soviet national anthem, which was first broadcast nationally on Jan. 1, 1944. The melody, by court composer Aleksander Aleksandrov, was chosen personally by Joseph Stalin.

description: EToys, an online toy retailer in desperate need of a blockbuster holiday season, said yesterday that its sales were substantially lower than expected, and that if it failed to attract additional investment, it was on a course that would cause it to run out of money at the end of March.

description: A federal judge in the embassy bombings case in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a defendant whose lawyers had suggested he was suffering from mental illness was competent to stand trial.

description: An oddity in computer programming delayed a clue that could have warned Alaska Airlines about a problem with a part that brought down one of its flights in January, killing 88 people off California, company officials said today.

description: LifeScan, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, pleaded guilty to criminal charges yesterday and agreed to pay $60 million in fines for selling defective blood glucose monitoring devices to diabetics and submitting false information about the problems to federal regulators.

title: NISSAN EYES MINICAR MARKET
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation is considering various ways to participate in Japan's thriving minicar market, among them a proposal to market Nissan minicars through the Suzuki Motors Corporation. Minicars, with engine displacements smaller than 660 cubic centimeters, now account for one-third of all cars sold in recession-plagued Japan, but Nissan and its rival, the Toyota Motor Corporation, have both largely missed the trend so far, in part because they regarded profit margins on minicars as too small. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

description: In a move that could significantly reduce enrollment in New York City's bilingual education program, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy will propose that the Board of Education end the automatic assignment of students with limited English skills to such classes and have parents choose whether they want their children in programs where English is emphasized, school officials say.

description: Ruth Martin, a writer whose English translations of both popular and obscure operas were widely used in American opera houses, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

title: U.N. Economic Panel to Study Ways to Help World's Have-Nots
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan named a high-level advisory panel of international financial experts today and gave them five months to come up with concrete ideas to help poor countries that are falling farther and farther behind a global economic boom.

title: BRADLEES SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING LIQUIDATING ITSELF
description: Bradlees Inc., the discount retailer that emerged from Chapter 11 protection in February 1999, said yesterday that it was considering liquidating itself and that it was negotiating with lenders to ease the terms of its revolving credit agreement and head off a default. In a regulatory filing, Bradlees said it might not be able to comply with terms of the $290 million credit line, which requires the company to have at least $50 million on hand from Dec. 15 through Jan. 15. The company, based in Braintree, Mass., lost $18.3 million, or $1.83 a share, on sales of $346.1 million in the quarter ended Oct. 28.

title: New Europe's Changing Landscape Strains French-German Ties
description: France and Germany have scheduled a summit meeting next month in an attempt to resolve sharp differences over the special relationship between them that has been central to the development of the European Union, officials announced here today.

title: BLACK & DECKER SAYS QUARTERLY EARNINGS WILL DECLINE
description: The Black & Decker Corporation, the world's largest maker of power tools, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit would fall as much as 27 percent because of slowing sales, price competition and weakness in the euro. Two power tool plants in the United States and one in Britain will close by the end of the year, furloughing 2,000 workers, the company said. Profit from operations will be 95 cents to $1.05 a share, the company said, down from $1.31 a share in the period a year earlier.

title: F.B.I. Agents Rally Against Possible Clemency
description: About 500 active and retired F.B.I. agents and employees marched to the White House today in a highly unusual protest, angered that President Clinton might commute the life sentence of an American Indian activist convicted of killing two F.B.I. agents 25 years ago.

It was the 15th Infantry Regiment of the Third Infantry Division, not the 15th Infantry Division.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply on Record Volume
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday on record trading volume, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a new closing low for the year. Only a late-day rebound kept the Nasdaq composite index from ending just a few points from its low.

title: Oil Patch Is Coming Back to Life As Natural Gas Prices Set Record
description: No Lear jets are parked at the local airstrip anymore. The toys of the oil boom days disappeared when prices collapsed nearly two decades ago. Only the wild memories remain, like the time one oilman flew his friends to New Orleans for lunch because he wanted fresh oysters.

title: MediaNews Allowed to Buy Utah Paper from AT&T
description: A federal district judge in Salt Lake City rejected a request yesterday to block the MediaNews Group in its $200 million acquisition of The Salt Lake Tribune. The ruling allows AT&T to sell a newspaper it never wanted and allows the chief executive of MediaNews, W. Dean Singleton, to buy one he had long coveted.

title: DEAL FOR BRAZIL DATA NETWORKS
description: Portugal Telecom has agreed to buy the telecommunications networks of two Brazilian banks, Unibanco and Banco Bradesco, for $281 million. The banks will transfer their networks and related licenses to a new company, which will then be acquired by PT Prime, Portugal Telecom's data transmission unit. The company expects Brazil's data transmission industry to grow by 30 percent over the next three years. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Another Setback for Vouchers
description: The school voucher movement suffered a major legal setback this week when a federal appeals court in Ohio struck down Cleveland's school voucher program for fostering a level of government entanglement in religion impermissible under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause. The sound 2-to-1 decision seems a likely candidate for review by the U.S. Supreme Court.

title: KOREAN WIRELESS LICENSES AWARDED
description: Groups led by the Korea Telecom Company and the SK Telecom Company will pay $1.1 billion each for advanced mobile telephone licenses that will allow them to offer mobile Internet service, the South Korean government said, but bids by groups led by the LG Group and Hanaro Telecom Inc. have been rejected. By fixing the cost of the licenses and using performance as the criteria for awarding them, the government has avoided the chaos that attended the auctions for similar licenses in Europe, and may have helped consumers obtain better service, analysts said. The government will hold a competition for a third license next year.

title: Corrections

title: Tasteless At Times, But Where's The Yuck?
description: ''Dude, Where's My Car?'' is a surprisingly sweet, mild-mannered movie for a teenage comedy spoof, and that's not a good thing. Yes, the film, which opened yesterday, has its gross-out moments (urination in a fish tank), its adolescent sexual obsessiveness (the same old breast fetish) and its druggy humor (a dog gets stoned on pot). But the mad excesses and gleeful tastelessness of a genre that calls to what remains of the dirty-minded brat in all of us are largely missing from this cheery post-''Wayne's World'' stew of teenage buddy jokes and low-rent sci-fi nonsense.

title: CISCO SETS ASIDE $275 MILLION TO COVER LOSSES
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the bellwether manufacturer of networking equipment, set aside $275 million during its first fiscal quarter to cover losses from unpaid customer bills and other items, more than tripling the amount earmarked a year earlier, according to a regulatory filing. The move reinforced analysts' concerns that cash shortages at telecommunications companies were beginning to crimp the results of companies like Cisco that supply them with equipment. Cisco has been pushing to sell more to telecommunications carriers as a way of sustaining its annual sales growth of 50 percent or more, one of its chief attractions to investors.

There was no applause between segments, just a stunned, intent silence as Ms. Blackman filled the room with portents of mortality.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO PAY $324.4 MILLION IN PATENT CASE
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation must pay the Cordis unit of Johnson & Johnson $324.4 million in damages for infringing a patent, a jury decided. The patent concerned stents, surgical devices used to hold formerly clogged blood vessels open after heart surgery, and the jury said it based the damages on royalties and profits forgone by Cordis because Boston Scientific sold a competing stent. The figure was about two-thirds what Cordis had asked in the suit.

title: Guiding the Battles of the Women's Rights Movement

Back in the early 1970's, the headiest days of the women's movement, the secretaries at the Center for Law and Social Policy went to the male lawyers who founded the group and presented a list of demands: They did not want to serve coffee anymore. They wanted raises. They wanted the center to start a women's rights project. And they wanted a female lawyer hired for it.

title: An Unlikely Policeman for Mergers
description: After years of costly lobbying, legal wrangling and political maneuvering, it turns out that a small group of antitrust officials here in Washington will be the new Internet regulators. They will police a marketplace and force competition in markets that thousands of local governments, lawmakers in Congress, the White House, the courts and the Federal Communications Commission had refused to touch.

title: The George Bush I Knew
description: I remember the moment well: About 33 years ago, George Bush (we never used the ''W'' back then) was sitting among a group of us in a college common room at Yale, engaged in one of our late-night comment-on-everyone sessions. Someone made an acerbic comment about a fellow student who was considered one of the biggest nerds on campus. There was laughter. Then George said: ''Hey, it's not so easy for him. He's a good guy -- leave him alone.'' We all quieted down.

The transaction puts the value of a seat back to what it was from April to June; the most ever paid for a seat was $2.65 million, in August. The exchange has 1,366 seats, which convey the right to trade at the exchange. Names of buyers and sellers of seats are never disclosed.

The deal leaves AtomFilms shareholders with 30 percent of the new company, and Macromedia, the San Francisco-based company that owned a majority of Shockwave, with a minority stake. Both Shockwave and AtomFilms have been losing money, and many other companies aimed at producing and distributing entertainment on the Web have closed because scant advertising revenue failed to cover production costs. But Ron Burgess, chairman of Shockwave and of the unnamed new company, said that by consolidating the Web sites, adding Shockwave's technology expertise and its library of interactive animations and games to Atom's film library, and cutting about 100 of their 300 employees, the combined operation could be profitable next year. Western Areas has been expected to sell its stake since a plan to merge with six other gold mining companies fell apart earlier this year. A Canadian rival of Barrick, Placer Dome Inc., bought the other half of the deposit from Western Areas last year for $235 million, and Placer has the right to match any offers Western gets for the remainder.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Freedom and Poetry
description: For more than 40 years, Carolyn Kizer has used poetry as an outlet for her humanistic, liberal ethos. She was a feminist practically before the term existed, and she has consistently spoken out against injustice both in her work and in her life. As a result, COOL, CALM & COLLECTED: Poems 1960-2000 (Copper Canyon, $30) provides an opportunity to look back not only at her career, but at the recent social and political history of America. She covers civil rights, women's rights and almost everything in between, but even when she's writing about more intimate matters, her underlying concern is freedom. One of the earliest poems in the book, ''The Worms,'' is about a child walking over the worm-strewn ground after a rainstorm, viscerally aware of ''Trying not to wound / anything alive; / Most especially / Not to maim the self / By any kind of death.'' It's an innocent desire that can't last, of course, a bitter truth Kizer gets to in her long poem from the 1960's, ''Pro Femina.'' ''I take as my theme 'The Independent Woman,' ''she writes. And then she adds, pointedly, ''Independent but maimed.'' Despite her constant railing against the machine, however, Kizer's poetry remains fundamentally optimistic, perhaps because she seems to love existence almost in spite of herself. ''Observe the world with desperate affection,'' she wrote in the 70's. This collection, which includes translations from a dizzying number of foreign poets, is ample proof that she's spent a lifetime taking her own good advice. Melanie Rehak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, G. MYRON
description: HAMMOND-G. Myron, Major died December 7, 2000 in Manhattan at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was formerly of Essex, Connecticut. He was a retired grain broker. He was a major in the US Army in the Second World War and acted as a liaison officer to the British Embarkation Commandant. For this work he was decorated as a ''Member of the British Empire'' by the British Government. As an Assistant Director of Operations for the British Channel he received a Bronze Star. He was a member of the Essex Yacht Club in CT. He leaves his beloved wife of 52 years, Daisy Strom Hammond and two stepdaughters, Yvonne and Suzanne, and a granddaughter Viveka, and one sister Eleanor Franklin and her family. A private service will be held. Contributions in his memory may be made to Dr. Jeffrey Matos, Electro-Physiology Fund at Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, NY, NY 10021, C/O Mary Anne McKenzie.

title: How Do You Cure A Sex Addict?
description: In the Middle Ages, melancholy and rage and other extremes of temperament (as well as mental illness in general) were ascribed to a deficiency or excess of one of four humors (Lauren Slater, Nov. 19). These were black bile, yellow bile, choler and phlegm. Substitute serotonin for these, and it is possible to conclude that our understanding of human behavior has not gotten far beyond this primitive level of reductionism. S.S.R.I.'s (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) reduce sex drive in many patients. The notion that they normalize sex drive needs to be subjected to scientific scrutiny, otherwise medieval impressionistic and anecdotal judgments will still prevail.

Afterward, I learned, with little surprise, that Hugh Johnson, the nonpareil British critic, had listed it as his white port recommendation for 2000.

title: Lives; Evening the Score

I had always imagined that someday, in the privacy of our own home, I would feel good coming clean about that 1,000. I would confess and feel a huge weight lifted, knowing that he would not understand what that score really meant. (''It's like 100 with a bonus zero,'' I would say.)

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE COLLECTED SHORT FICTION OF BRUCE JAY FRIEDMAN. (Grove, $14.) These humorous tales, published between 1953 and 1995, feature dizzying flights of fancy and whammo endings, taking on subjects as varied as psychiatrists, Hollywood, cocaine, guilt, sex and Jewish mothers. ''Friedman has been likened to everyone from J. D. Salinger to Woody Allen,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here in 1995. ''This collection should finally establish him for what he is: Bruce Jay Friedman, sui generis and no mean thing.'' Speaking of Jewish mothers, Friedman's 1964 novel, A Mother's Kisses (University of Chicago, $14), describes the efforts of a 17-year-old Brooklyn boy to break free from the gravitational field of ''the most unforgettable mother since Medea,'' according to our reviewer, Haskel Frankel. She is ''heaven and hell jammed into a hammock-sized bra and a too-tight girdle. She is a Bensonhurst Mae West.''

title: WORKING DEATH ROW: A special report.; In the Busiest Death Chamber, Duty Carries Its Own Burdens

description: VIRTUALLY all financial planners say asset allocation is the most important determinant of wealth in retirement. It is far more important, they say, how you divide your portfolio among stocks, bonds and other categories than how you invest within them.

title: December 10 - 16; Olds Lives Down to Its Name
description: General Motors' fatal mistake was to let Oldsmobiles get a reputation as old people's cars. Burdened with a geriatric name because it was founded by Ransom E. Olds, Oldsmobile nonetheless thrived for decades with cars that offered power and smooth performance for prosperous families in early middle age. But the bland Cutlasses that G.M. cranked out in huge numbers in the late 1980's and early 1990's excited no one except rental fleet managers, who could buy them cheaply. G.M., which tried over the last five years to revive the brand, says it will phase it out over the next few years. Keith Bradsher

But aloha-style warmth (above and beyond what the music generates, of course) will have to be coaxed from four rented propane heating units, which will be turned on a day in advance to raise the temperature in the cavernous wooden hall to a pleasant 65 degrees.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DUSTIN HOFFMAN was touching in ''Tootsie'' and Robin Williams had some wonderful comic moments in ''Mrs. Doubtfire,'' but when it comes to movie actors in drag, give me Terence Stamp as Bernadette, the sardonic, grieving transsexual of a certain age in THE ADVENTURES OF PRISCILLA, QUEEN OF THE DESERT (1994). It's a comedy - as buoyant as it is flamboyant - about three Australian drag queens on a bus tour in the provinces, but Mr. Stamp gives the story a soul. Hugo Weaving and Guy Pearce are his traveling campanions. Stephan Elliott directed - Sunday at 6 p.m. on Channel 9.

title: Sentenced to Nature
description: We'd been hiking all morning with full packs, up and down the rough hills of the Escalante Desert in southwestern Utah. It was mid-May, and yet the noontime temperature had already reached into the 90's, the heat driving each of us further into our own thoughts and walking rhythms, a ragged, single-file brigade of capped heads bowed to the rugged terrain, the bright red bloom of an occasional springtime cactus flower only pointing up the otherwise hard-bitten cast of the flora around us: juniper, sagebrush, tamarisk and pinyon.

title: Can-Do Attitude at Japanese Restaurant
description: ADVERSITY brings out the best and worst in restaurants just as it does in people. The five-month-old Koiso Japanese Restaurant in Carle Place came through nobly on a recent Saturday, the busiest, most hectic night of the week, when first its phones and then its ability to process credit cards failed. Koiso was unable to take reservations or cancellations and many of the patrons who depend on plastic rather than cash were unable to pay their bills. It was a mini-crisis that would have panicked many a veteran restaurateur into pressuring people for personal checks or credit card imprints. But the smiling staff and cordial owners of the spotless storefront at 540 Westbury Avenue (516-333-3434) simply asked diners to please return at another time to pay their bills if they didn't have enough money on hand.

title: Are Biotech Stocks Worth a New Look?
description: EVEN after their pullback last month, biotechnology stocks are trading at an average of 61 times the earnings that Joel Sendek, an analyst at Lazard Freres, projects for next year. More traditional drug makers are trading at just 27 times earnings. But some of the biotechs are starting to look like fair values to investors who note that these companies are, after all, growing far faster than other drug businesses.

The Koran, he says, is more powerful than tanks.

The funeral mass will be celebrated at the Church of St. Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street, New York at 10:30 AM on Monday, December 18th.

title: Emergency Crews Worry as Hospitals Say, 'No Vacancy'
description: Michael Mc Namara's ambulance took the call: an 89-year-old woman with cancer, abdominal pain, possibly a broken hip after a fall. Normally, Mr. McNamara, an emergency medical technician, would have taken her to Massachusetts General Hospital, to the doctors who care for her. But, he had to tell her, the hospital was turning down ambulances at the moment.

title: An Apocalyptic Attitude Gripped the TV Commentators, Not Their Viewers
description: For the last five weeks, Ted Koppel began ''Nightline'' by reciting ABC's slogan for the postelection drama; in a solemn cadence suited to imminent nuclear disaster, he declared, ''A Nation Waits.'' On MSNBC, when Brian Williams wondered what to tell the children when they came home from school and asked if our country was O.K., his booming voice carried a hollow echo of Red Scare days. Many civics classes have been taught about this election muddle, but no one was shouting, ''Duck under the desks, kids, they're recounting in Florida!'' And just before George W. Bush's victory speech on Wednesday, Peter Jennings said the president-elect would ''begin to settle the nation down, if he can.'' Settle down? Who was unsettled?

title: DECEPTIVE SALES
description: The state Division of Consumer Affairs announced last week that it was suing a cemetery owner for using what the division characterized as deceptive sales practices in obtaining financial commitments for burial plots, and for failing to return money when New Jersey residents tried to cancel those commitments. According to the division, sales representatives for CMS Mid-Atlantic Inc., a Pittsburgh, Pa.-based company that owns cemeteries in East Hanover, Totowa, Union, Perth Amboy and Trenton, mailed or called elderly New Jersey residents with offers of ''free burial space'' at a CMS cemetery, and then used hard-sell tactics to get them to buy space in a mausoleum. In 1998 CMS, saying it did nothing wrong, nevertheless paid $12,000 in a settlement of a similar DCA lawsuit regarding sales of headstones. CMS could be fined and could lose its license to operate cemeteries in the state if it is found to have violated state consumer-fraud statutes. Bill Kent

title: FILM: The Year in Film: Critics Pick Their Favorites; Point Counterpoint
description: 'YI-YI' ('A ONE AND A TWO') Edward Yang's three-hour study of middle-class domesticity in modern Taipei is less a movie to watch than one to inhabit. As absorbing and replete with character and incident as a 19th-century novel, it also glows with understated visual intensity and moves with the sweep and patience of a symphony. By paying rigorous attention to the small-scale anxieties and catastrophes that beset the Jian family, Mr. Yang gets at the confusion, and the battered promise, of contemporary urban family life better than any other filmmaker working today.

title: In Africa, A Mea Culpa For Apartheid Tests Whites
description: Some of South Africa's leading white intellectuals and civic figures embarked this week on a campaign urging fellow whites to acknowledge that every white South African was, and still is, a beneficiary of the old apartheid system.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Ronnie Cutrone; Another New Thing
description: RONNIE CUTRONE learned a lot about mixing art and money during his decade as Andy Warhol's assistant, but the lesson that seems to have stuck with him most is the one from the shark: keep moving or you die.

title: BRONX RIVER PARKWAY
description: On the 75th anniversary of the Bronx River Parkway, Westchester County and the Department of the Interior are documenting the history of the Bronx River Parkway Reservation, which is adjacent to America's oldest parkway. Graduate students selected by the National Parks Service, which is financing the project, will undertake the $70,000 study, which will become part of the national collection at the Library of Congress. Similar projects have been completed on the Taconic State Parkway and the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut. Elsa Brenner

description: GOT solidarity? It can be useful. For example, you can prepare mailing lists. Meet interesting people. Enjoy scintillating conversations. Go on crusades. Wage wars. Offer hope to the despairing. Leave the world a better place. Build a Golden Age. And you will never feel lonesome again.

Under the solicitous gaze of a star Goldman investment banker, John L. Thornton, the bureaucrats were fed, cosseted, and given a primer on how to privatize their vast state-owned corporations.

The club's tawdry plastic and metal interior is decorated with film stills of Marilyn Monroe in ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' and at the entrance, each of the Russian women accepted a glass of Russian champagne. Some sipped nervously, considering where to sit. Others, who knew the ropes, sat confidently at tables.

title: Children's Books; The Manger Menagerie
description: The Christmas story is something of a minefield for the contemporary picture-book author -- the line between preaching and secular saccharine is as fine as a strand of tinsel. Sharon McGinley has taken a safe approach in pairing her vibrant illustrations with the traditional carol THE FRIENDLY BEASTS (Greenwillow, $15.95; ages 3 to 8), a telling of the Nativity that's sure to interest young children because it gives the animals of the manger star billing. And McGinley's beasts are nothing if not friendly: the donkey that tells us he brought the pregnant Mary ''uphill and down; I carried her safely to Bethlehem town'' has the sloe-eyed gaze and moppet hair of a fifth Beatle, while the stolid cows and smiling sheep cavort with flying fish, striped snakes and even a stray alligator in a checkered collar. McGinley shows far less imagination with her rather bland Holy Family, but by the time magi and angels join the crowded menagerie, there's enough action to keep any child entertained until the pudding is served. The illustrations, with their swirling woodcut-like lines and Caribbean color palate -- sunflower yellow, lime green, deep-ocean purple -- squarely emphasize the joy of the event, leaving it up to parents to explain its significance.

description: DESIRADA

title: FILM: The Year in Film: Critics Pick Their Favorites; Paradise and Politics
description: 'THE DECALOGUE' Krzysztof Kieslowski's 10-part masterwork was first shown on Polish television in 1988-89 and finally released in theaters this year. It is a sweeping meditation on the human condition that ranks beside the greatest works of Ingmar Bergman in its depth and the potency of its layered symbolism. Loosely based on the Ten Commandments, the cycle's 10 fables, set in and around a Warsaw housing development, ponder the meaning of life and death, morality and the existence of God. Kieslowski's skeptical, open-ended vision suggests that the answers can be intuited only from riddles, signs, portents and sudden, odd strokes of fate. For all its somberness, the individual stories are extremely entertaining. And the visionary realism of this Polish filmmaker, who died four years ago, invests the most mundane objects with a luminous metaphysical weight and an awareness of the interconnectedness of things.

title: Beyond the Beer Garden, Munich's Fine Cuisine
description: FOR northern Europeans, Catholic, Baroque, Bavarian Munich is practically Italy, with better beer. For non-Germans, the city embodies the kinder, gentler, gemutlich Germany. Munich takes contagious pleasure in eating and drinking. The most visible side of its gastronomy is represented by breweries and beer gardens, where sausages and sauerbraten are eaten with the world's best beer, sold fresh and unpasteurized. But there is a flourishing Munich of fine eating as well, with toprated elegant restaurants, of both conservative and creative persuasion, as well as a range of ethnic places, bistros and wine bars.

title: Making Flat Statements
description: THE exhibition at Kenise Barnes Fine Art, ''Lucy Fradkin: A Brief History of Fashion and Friendship,'' illustrates the scope of Naive art. The term naive suggests a childlike style in an artist's line, form, perspective and composition. Figures are often rendered head-on or flat, except for an occasional bent elbow or knee. Colors and patterns are bright, and for the most part, the situations alluded to by dress or circumstance speak of common, everyday occurrences.

title: The High Price of Estate-Tax Cheating
description: CHEATING on estate taxes, which are paid by some of the wealthiest Americans -- roughly 2 percent of the population -- has become even more common than cheating on individual income taxes, according to a new study by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, DR. SAMUEL L.
description: SCHER-Dr. Samuel L. passed away at home December 15, 2000 of natural causes at the age of 94. Born June 20, 1906 in Little Rock, Arkansas. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Ella Scher, an attorney, and two children, Dr. Charles Scher, a plastic surgeon in Ocean Township, NJ and daughter Susan Shuster of Bal Harbour, FL and five grandchildren, Dr. Bernard Shuster, a plastic surgeon in New York City, Kenneth Shuster, a rabbi and lawyer in Queens, NY, Shirley Greenbaum of Brooklyn, NY, Libby Scher and Mia Scher of New York City and seven greatgrandchildren. Burial will be private for family. Dr. Sam Scher graduated from Baylor University College of Medicine on May 30, 1932. He interned and and did a surgical residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City and Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Scher was a pioneer and a well-known respected plastic and reconstructive surgeon in New York City for 62 years. He was an innovator of many plastic surgical procedures. Dr. Scher was president of the Rolls Royce Society of America and a collector of many rare automobiles. He traveled extensively around the world and lectured on many different plastic surgical procedures. Donations may be made to the Shul of Bal Harbour 9540 Collins Avenue, Surfside, FL 33154.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALPIN, BERNARD G.
description: WALPIN-Bernard G. Died December 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Loved by nephews and nieces. He was a friend to all who met him, who enjoyed life to the fullest and was always ready to help those in need. Thanks to the generosity of the 34th Street Partnership, which wants to rid the street of what it calls ''a hodgepodge of unsightly structures,'' the newspaper hawkers there have traded their crates for custom-made mobile vending racks. Here's how the old and the new stack up. DENNY LEE

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Redevelopment to Start Near Shore in Long Branch
description: EARLIER this month this old resort city's long-awaited plan to transform 150 acres of its tattered Atlantic Ocean shoreline into a new neighborhood was nudged forward by $11.2 million in loans and grants from the state.

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert T. Gardiner; Wasatch Micro Cap Fund
description: FOR most of the last two years, managers of many small-capitalization growth funds stocked up on highflying technology issues -- the very kind that have plunged this year. But not Robert T. Gardiner, who runs the $220 million Wasatch Micro Cap fund.

description: SAGE, a new restaurant in Fairfield, subtitles itself ''a gourmet restaurant.'' While that may seem a tad presumptuous for a modest place installed in an off-the-beaten-track storefront, it does telegraph the ambitions of Patrick Sinchak, the proprietor.

title: Habitats/St. Johns Place, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; Finding an Apartment That Has Everything
description: ANYONE who looks for an apartment in New York carries around a mental list of what would be nice, as well as the knowledge that something will have to be sacrificed. Maybe there will be a view -- but then surely, there won't be a fireplace. Even places that cost $4 million or $5 million present trade-offs. In New York, that's life.

title: He May Win the Pennant, But Easy on the Champagne
description: It has been a rough year for Thomas O. Hicks, the Dallas financier. Recent investments in telecommunications companies have soured, a deal to buy the building materials maker Johns Manville collapsed, and his Texas Rangers baseball team, which he took off the hands of George W. Bush and others in 1998 for $250 million, finished in the cellar of the American League West.

title: McCarter 'Carol' An Eyeful
description: MAYBE the people at the McCarter Theater knew they would be vying with a big-budget Grinch this year for the attention of the family audience. Maybe they were just bored and had a lot of money lying around. In any case, they have mounted an all-new production of ''A Christmas Carol'' that makes a lasting impression on the visual cortex, if not the heart.

title: The Election; Clarence Thomas Speaks Out
description: DURING the two lengthy sessions in which the United States Supreme Court dealt with the momentous presidential election case, eight of the nine justices bombarded the lawyers with questions. But, as is usually the case, Justice Clarence Thomas sat silently during the oral arguments.

title: Early Alert on Workplace Rage
description: Hostile employees who lose their cool on the job are not only a threat to other workers; they can also affect their companies' bottom lines. There are ways, however, for employers to see the potential for workplace rage before it starts. One is to weed out job applicants with aggressive tendencies.

description: When East Is West

title: Giving Advice Through Rose-Colored Stock Options
description: AS dot-com companies hurried onto the public markets during the Internet stock run-up of the late 1990's, everyone wanted a piece of the action. Not only were the companies' founders sitting on a potential pot of gold in their equity, employees also got in on the possible upside by holding stock options. And the options booty was also extended to outsiders, like lawyers and consultants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNEMAN, ESTHER GRACIE
description: HENNEMAN-Esther Gracie. Of Buckingham County, Virginia and formerly of New York City, died December 14, 2000 at age 93. The widow of John B. Henneman and mother of the late John B. She served on the Board of Counselors of Smith College and the National Board of the YWCA and was a trustee of the Blue Ridge School and St. Anne'sBelfield School. Contributions in her memory may be made to Smith College, Northampton, MA.

title: Finding A Niche as High Tech's Back Office
description: FOR about three decades, this blue-collar city of 23,000, about 100 miles north of Manhattan, was at the epicenter of the technological revolution. Since the early 1990's, though, when I.B.M. shut down its mainframe-testing operation and offices here, idling 7,000 workers, the city has languished.

title: Causing Spirits to Lift and Toes to Tap
description: TO describe Holiday Express as a group of rock musicians who play charity holiday shows for the needy is to underrate this group of musicians who give up vast amounts of their time between Thanksgiving and Christmas to entertain adults and children in all types of poverty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASH, N. RICHARD
description: NASH-N. Richard. On December 11. Distinguished playwright, novelist, screenwriter, beloved teacher, and one of the pioneers of the renowned Golden Age of television drama. His works have received numerous international awards and been translated in 40 languages, including an African tongue which has no written form. He recently completed a new novel, ''The Wildwood'', and new dramas appear in his ''Selected Plays''. He leaves Christopher, his son by Helena Taylor Nash, and Jennifer and Amanda, his daughters by Katherine Copeland Nash. A memorial service is planned for early Spring.

description: To the Editor:

description: THE HUNTER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATIL, JACQUELINE
description: LATIL-Jacqueline. Died peacefully on December 7, 2000, in Kew Gardens, New York. Survived by her beloved husband, Jean Paul, to whom she was married for 67 years, her sister, Lise Blum Elson, and her sister-in-law Genevieve Blum-Gayet, of Corenc, France. She also leaves her three children, Martine, Catherine, and Bertrand, six grandchildren, Lisa, Anne, Alex, Alice, Ellie, and Francine, one great grandchild, Brooke, two nephews, Richard, and David, her niece, Becky, and other family and friends. Jacqueline was born in 1913 in Paris, France, and moved to the United States sixty years ago. Her interests included birding, mushrooming, origami, and knitting. The lives of many have been touched by her thoughtful and nurturing spirit. She will live on in our hearts, our memories, and our actions forever.

title: FILM: The Year in Film: Critics Pick Their Favorites; Peeling Back Layers
description: 'HAMLET' In his updating of Shakespeare, the director Michael Almereyda does something few other film versions of ''Hamlet'' have ever bothered to attempt, and makes this melancholy-Dane story a singular achievement in the bargain. He roots ''Hamlet'' in an actual place -- Manhattan -- and employs the dramatic contradictions of contemporary New York City for all of their tremendous possibilities. What better headquarters for rampant paranoia and epic depression is there? The visual strategies he brings to bear are matched by his staging of the actors; the soliloquies of Hamlet (Ethan Hawke) are now interior monologues, and characters keep tabs on the world and their feelings through video monitoring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICOSIA, DR. ARNOLD P. (NICK)
description: NICOSIA-Dr. Arnold P. (Nick), age 80, on December 14, 2000 at home in Manhasset, NY, after a brief illness. Predeceased by Jane Gault Nicosia. Beloved husband of Jan Nicosia. Devoted father of Thomas Nicosia of Manhasset, Nancy Moore of Heightstown, NJ, Robert Nicosia of Midlothian, VA, John Nicosia of Dunedin, FL and Susan Bunyon of New Hyde Park, NY. He is survived by thirteen grandchildren. Dr. Nicosia practiced pediatrics in Manhasset for forty years, also serving as the physician for the Manhasset Public Schools and the Police Athletic League. He was a retired Naval Lieutenant Commander serving in both WW II and the Korean War. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Dr. Arnold P. Nicosia Fund C/O Dr. Peter A. Pantina, Manhasset High School, 200 Memorial Place, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: In a First for Swiss, Women in Geneva Gain Maternity Benefits
description: Working women in Geneva canton will be the first in Switzerland to receive mandatory maternity benefits, raising hopes among advocates that Switzerland will not be the only country in Western Europe without such paid leave for much longer.

title: Who Really Brought Down Milosevic?
description: After reading Roger Cohen's article (Nov. 26) on the Serbian students, I wondered how free and fair we would consider our own elections if one party had been bankrolled by a foreign power after it had bombed and blockaded us and watched the elections from nearby gunboats.

title: Beauty, Her Moreau Eyes Say, Isn't Everything
description: IN Giuseppe Tornatore's new film, ''Malena,'' which is set in Sicily during World War II, the Italian actress Monica Bellucci plays a heroine who is every man's dream and every woman's nightmare. The young and gorgeous Malena Scordia, who is marooned in her husband's village when he goes off to war, is an unwitting Circe, driving men to lust and their wives to plot revenge. Walking across the village square, Ms. Bellucci, with her sinuous curves and inimitable hauteur, evokes a grand tradition of Italian screen goddess: part siren, part muse and all trouble.

title: Georgia Church Donates Bulk of $60 Million Bequest
description: ST. MARYS, Ga., Dec. 16  Hundreds of letters fill a small file cabinet. Handwritten requests churn out of the fax machine and curl into a pile. And the office staff members at St. Marys United Methodist Church here have stopped answering the phone, which never stops ringing.

title: Third Moon Of Jupiter May Have Sea Under Its Ice
description: Scientists have found evidence that Ganymede, a moon of Jupiter, has an ocean. That is the third Jupiter moon that shows signs of water sloshing beneath its frozen exterior.

title: A Kit to Pop the Question With
description: It's just the thing for guys taking baby steps toward a marriage proposal -- and the women who love them. A free diamond buying kit is available from Diamond.com, a diamond vendor, via its Web site or by calling (888) diamond. The kit offers a complete education in purchasing an engagement ring. Its CD-size box unfolds to reveal a flap explaining the four C's (cut, color, clarity and carat), and another showing life-size photographs of diamonds, ranging from 1.5 to 4 carats. There's a sample Gemological Institute of America grading report (a certificate of authenticity) and a handy wraparound ring-size measurer. Best of all, the kit comes with a fake gold band with flexible prongs and four different-size rhinestone ''diamonds'' that pop into place.

title: Anna Harvey, Darwin Neher
description: Prof. Anna Lil Harvey and Darwin Victor Neher were married yesterday by the Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian minister, at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison, N.Y.

title: This Maestro Defies Convention Even in Death
description: TEN years have passed since the death of Leonard Bernstein, as the New York Philharmonic has repeatedly reminded listeners this fall, yet his name retains much of its cachet. Such durability cannot be taken for granted. Wisdom in the record business (if that phrase is not yet an oxymoron), for example, holds that a performer's drawing power drops precipitously after his or her death.

description: Bombed by NATO during the Kosovo war and then burned by pro-democracy demonstrators, Serbia's state television and radio network remains an enormous prize for the new authorities as they work toward consolidating power in elections for a new Serbian government on Dec. 23.

title: Four-Wheeled Wallflowers, Waiting for a Dance
description: FORGIVE me if you have heard this before: I love the Acura NSX, an $85,000-and-up supercar that you can take grocery shopping. And I am thoroughly smitten with the Honda S2000 roadster, a $30-something-thousand rocket with a little four-cylinder that has more power, for its size, than any other engine in any other mass-production car in the world.

title: Forced to Strike a Holiday Stage, Man Sees Grinch's Work

But gone is the giant stage that for several years had been host to high school dance groups, eggnog-fueled marriage proposals and assorted live pageantry.

description: A state program that gives tax breaks to New Yorkers saving for college will allow this year's participants to invest more heavily in stocks, according to the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, DOLI
description: COLE-Doli. Of Ridgewood, NJ. Daughter of Mireille Guzelbahar Axelrad of Boca Raton, FL and the late Robert Guzelbahar, wife of Morrill Cole and mother of Amy Ellen Cole of Cliffside Park and Robert Cole of Fort Lee, NJ died on Friday at Sloane Kettering Memorial Hospital in New York City. She is survived, also by her beloved grandchildren, Danielle and Adam, the children of Robert and Ronit Cole and by her sister, Emel Glicksman of New York City and her nieces, Cindy Touma of Tenafly, NJ and Sally Rosen and Nina Rosen both of New York City. A fashion designer and lifelong tennis player, she pioneered in the design of tennis apparel that combined a strong fashion statement with practical, active wearability in the movements of the game. She brought companies into the tennis wear business that had previously had no connection with the tennis world. She designed for Profile Skiwear, Spalding, Champion and other sportswear and hard goods companies. Her business, Lovestitch, printed a classic ALine tennis dress pattern on fabric that permitted the home sewer to cut and sew her own dress. The design and wearability of the dresses were so successful that her customers prevailed on her to go further and manufacture the finished dress for ready to wear sales. She was born in Istanbul, Turkey. In 1954, she participated in a Turkish government assignment as a translator and model on the Turkish good-will ship, the Tarsis, that travelled the Western Hemisphere to introduce modern Westernized Turkish culture and post war economic progress to the American marketplace. Her marriage to New Jersey attorney Morrill Cole followed her disembarkation in New York. Fluent in many languages, she was a graduate of Roberts College in Istanbul and attended the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. She was an active member of the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club until her illness took her from the courts. She was a member of Honors, the bridge club in New York. Her family would appreciate contributions to the Evelyn Lauder Breast Center at Sloane Kettering Memorial Hospital, 205 East 64th Street, NY NY 10021 in honor of the pioneering and humane work of Dr. Larry Norton and his associate Dr. Pamela Munster. Funeral services will be held at Barnert Memorial Temple, Rt. 208 in Franklin Lakes on Monday, December 18 at 12 noon. The family will receive friends at the Cole home, 312 Highland Avenue, Ridgewood until Friday, December 22.

title: When Pet Pigs Become Illegal Livestock
description: DAWN KUSZNIR'S battle with the City of Shelton over her potbellied pigs began with a complaint filed by a next-door neighbor. It led to a Planning and Zoning Commission agenda item that read, ''Vietnamese pigs -- pets or livestock?''

title: Warp and Woof: A Tapestry of Photographic History
description: PHOTOGRAPHY has gone to the dogs. Hundreds of them. With a waggish eye on the dog days of holiday shopping, Taschen has unleashed a book that the press release calls ''a completely original history of photography told through images of canines.''

title: A Glimmer of Satire Amid Freedom's Obscurities
description: IN Prague, the best theater so far this season has not been in a theater, but in a castle. And spectacular theater it was.

title: Irish Vigilant a Year After Their Penalty
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 15  Bob Davie changed as a coach at Notre Dame this season. He is focused more on team chemistry. He is more involved with the defense. And he often warns the Fighting Irish to beware of temptations.

title: Roosevelt Field Named For Son, Not President
description: Contrary to the Dec. 10 opinion essay [''When Presidents Were Worthies''], Roosevelt Field was not named for Teddy Roosevelt, but for his son Quentin, a pilot killed in action in France during World War I. Also Lindbergh did not take off from Roosevelt Field, but from the adjoining Curtiss Field, where the field was longer and less muddy. It was located about where KMart and Target are today, east past Fortunoff's to Merrick Avenue. The third adjoining airfield, Army Airfield No. 2, was renamed for John Purroy Mitchel, a former Mayor of New York City who volunteered for flight training in World War I where he flew a loop, fell out of the plane and was killed. A prime example of the notion that all politicians are worthy.

title: Finally, Nap Time For America
description: AMERICA isn't tired of the election -- America is tired, period. Vice President Al Gore gave an upbeat concession speech in the end, but underneath his bright smile he seemed weary. His lawyers were dead tired too, and some wondered whether they might have made better tactical decisions, like asking for a manual recount for the whole state of Florida, if they had just taken more naps. Gov. George W. Bush's lawyers didn't sleep much either, and even the judges handing down the most important rulings of their lives begged for a few hours of rest.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why A-Rod's Contract Is Good For Baseball
description: THE outcry against baseball's runaway salaries is as old as the game itself. One of the national pastime's earliest champions, Henry Chadwick, an Englishman who aspired to elevate the game to the same status here that cricket enjoyed in his homeland, fumed about ballplayers bouncing from team to team simply to ''advance their fortunes.'' And as far back as 1870, rival owners accused Harry Wright of recruiting high-priced talent from neighboring states for his Cincinnati Red Stockings.

Having spent his entire medical career in Peekskill, he could boast that he had delivered babies of babies he delivered.

We sought and found snow in Dartmouth's Second College Grant during a late-season deer hunt in that remote, rugged and sparsely populated northeastern region of New Hampshire.

title: The Hills Were Alive ...
description: I enjoyed Amy M. Spindler's article on George Cukor's house (Style, Nov. 19) and thought you might be interested in a Cukor anecdote from a noncelebrity. Cukor once boarded a T.W.A. flight on which I was a cabin attendant. At the time, there was much discussion about who the male lead would be when the hugely successful Broadway show ''My Fair Lady'' was made into a film. Cukor had already signed Audrey Hepburn for the Julie Andrews/Eliza Doolittle role, but there was much discussion in the press about whether Rex Harrison would repeat the Professor Higgins role on film.

title: Blobs and Windows That Grab the Emotions
description: A LONG, silvery piece of paper flutters in the air, twisting and turning until it takes on the outlines of a chair and settles gracefully into a circle of light on the darkened stage. Another chair -- well, a bulky thing that sort of looks like a chair -- lumbers toward the paper-turned-chair. Momentarily, they sit contentedly side by side before becoming two ponderous rocks. It's clear that they are rocks because they now look more substantial. Leaning together, trying to touch, they appear to want to know each another, though one rock doesn't give the relationship much of a chance, managing suddenly to become a pair of very luscious lips. That moment doesn't last long, however. They transform themselves into sacks. Not boring sacks, demonstrative sacks. Again, they try to communicate, until one dismissively rolls off, without even a shrug goodbye.

title: What's Tab Turner Got Against Ford?

Brenda Gwin smiled but did not bother to ask what exactly her boss meant by ''later.'' Later could be 3 o'clock that afternoon or later could be one day next week. Even during normal times, Tab Turner is an incredibly busy man, a product-liability lawyer who has grown rich by specializing in sport utility vehicle rollover cases, who files scores of lawsuits each year against auto manufacturers. But lately, with rollover fatalities repeatedly being linked to the Ford Explorer and its recalled Firestone tires, Turner has been rocketing around the nation faster than a car with a sudden acceleration problem.
