title: Bookend; The Ties That Bound in America
description: WHERE have all the good adulterers gone? That was the burden of ''Love and Death in the American Novel,'' the brilliant jeremiad, psychoanalysis and genealogy of the genre by the literary critic Leslie Fiedler. We don't have adultery in America, Fiedler observed -- or not in classic American literature, at any rate. For that matter, we don't have much marriage, either. Among the books canonized as the American Renaissance, only ''The House of the Seven Gables'' ends with a wedding. ''The quest which has distinguished our fiction,'' Fiedler wrote, ''is the search for an innocent substitute for adulterous passion and marriage alike.'' He regretted the absence of heterosexual passion; he thought our tradition was poorer and tamer without it. The classic novels of the United States, he lamented, are ''notoriously at home in the children's section of the library.''

title: Can Bush Mend His Party's Rift With Black America?
description: As president, George W. Bush will have to mend many rifts, but none, perhaps, as wide as the divide between the Republican Party and African-Americans. Nine out of 10 black voters cast ballots for Al Gore. Many living in Florida felt their votes didn't count. The United States Commission on Civil Rights plans to investigate complaints about voting irregularities there, and perhaps in other states, to determine whether rights were violated on Election Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULTE, LILY CARLSON
description: SCHULTE-Lily Carlson. December 14, 2000. Beloved wife of David A. Schulte. Devoted mother of Holly Schulte Ellison, Christina Fleur and William Dowell. Cherished grandmother of Claire Ellison, Matthew Dowell, Eric Lewenstein and Scott Stevens. She was the first model of the Ford Model Agency and one of the 12 most photographed women of the 1940s. A noted photographer and recipient of several awards. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Monday, December 18, 2000, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: A Report Card for 'Boston Public': A's and F's
description: IN the final moments of the second episode of ''Boston Public,'' the Fox series about an urban high school, the camera finds a vice principal named Scott Guber bent over his office desk well into the night. Tie loosened, brow creased, reading glasses perched down his nose, Guber pores over the class rosters and staff lists arrayed in a puddle of lamplight. Only the arrival of the principal, with a gentle order to go home, dispels his concentration.

title: INSIDE
description: Test for Serbian Leaders

title: TOY SELLER AND PRIVACY
description: The online store of Toys ''R'' Us, based in Fort Lee, is being investigated by the state for possible violations of the company's privacy policy. The state consumer affairs office subpoenaed information about the operation of Toysrus.com during the summer, when it had a contract with the Coremetrics research service to gather information about Toysrus.com customers to help the company develop its Web site. Several class-action lawsuits in various parts of the country have asserted that Coremetrics left ''cookies'' in users' computers; cookies are tracers that record information about Internet browsing habits. Toys ''R'' Us's policy states that it will not sell, rent or trade information about customers, and the company denies selling or trading customers' names with any other company, according to Jeanne Meyer, a spokeswoman. But a warning on the Toys ''R'' Us parent company's Web site tells customers who shopped online between April and August that Coremetrics may have left cookies in their computer. Karen DeMasters

title: The Mass Marketing of Venture Capital
description: MARTIN N. GRANT could have bought more shares in America Online. But that would have been Old School. What Mr. Grant, a marketing executive, really wanted was a taste of new-economy high finance. So ignoring the dot-com carnage and general stock market gloom, Mr. Grant put $25,000 into a venture capital fund run by EarlyBirdCapital, a Web-based investment bank. The fund has invested $40 million in some 30 technology start-ups, and hopes to rake in big profits when those companies go public or are sold.

title: December 10 - 16; Hillary Clinton Agrees To $8 Million Book Contract
description: Ending a frantic weeklong bidding war, Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton agreed to sell a memoir of her years as first lady to Simon & Schuster for the near-record advance of about $8 million. The house published her first three books. Two big questions remain: will Senate Republicans question the propriety of the enormous payment? And how will she handle the personal scandals of her husband's administration? David D. Kirkpatrick

title: Schul vs. Broadway, With Sing-Alongs
description: IT was a golden chance to transform an age-old story into a newly resounding one, but it appears that the Forum Theater here didn't care.

title: A Pleasant Alternative To Cable TV
description: With respect to the Dec. 3 article, ''As Cable Rates Rise, So Do Complaints,'' I'm reminded of the pricey restaurant that, after a long wait, produced an entree that would have repulsed a survivor on a life raft who hadn't eaten for a week. With an almost 20 percent rate increase in a year and undoubtably more to follow, the question of costs versus benefits arises. Are frequent, annoying commercials worth the occasional good program? Are service interruptions and dependency on a repairman justified? Are there alternate means of Internet access? Are there other things that can be done with our limited time besides sifting through hundreds of channels?

title: A Stadium, Shops, Condos And Calamari; Development Fantasies For Hell's Kitchen South
description: Acres of open rail yards. Block after block of gridlocked New Jersey-bound traffic. Vast truck depots wrapped in razor wire. Taxi repair shops. Horse stables. Abandoned and crumbling elevated train lines.

description: JUST east of New Milford, alongside scenic Route 67, sits a faded wooden signboard inscribed ''Rock Church.'' What a fitting welcome to Ian Hunter's adopted town.

title: Monthly Surcharge On Rent
description: Q. Does a landlord have the legal right to impose a $20.74 monthly surcharge for an air-conditioner in my apartment? The surcharge is charged for the entire year even though I use the air-conditioner only during the summer months. These charges amount to more than $240 a year. . . . L. Lampkin, Manhattan.

title: Stearns to Return As a Mets Coach
description: John Stearns, the bench coach who was dismissed after the season, will return as the third-base coach when the Mets announce their coaching staff next week, a team official said yesterday.

title: SEX OFFENDERS' WEB SITE
description: The State Assembly unanimously approved a bill last week that would establish a state Internet registry of convicted and released sex offenders. The registry would display the name, address and photograph of sex offenders deemed to pose a moderate to high risk. The bill follows a referendum last month in which voters approved amending the state Constitution to deny sex offenders the right to privacy about suchpersonal information. Those without computer access could request a directory by mail. The bill now moves to the State Senate. Governor Whitman commended the Assembly for passing the bill. Anne Ruderman

title: OUTDOOR SMOKING BAN
description: The Leonia Borough Council voted unanimously last week to ban smoking in the town's nine parks. The ordinance was aimed mainly at groups of teenagers who created litter and the parks and endangered their health, according to Leonia's mayor, Paul Kaufman. Leonia is the third municipality in the state to ban smoking in public parks. Karen DeMasters

title: Where Food Sparkles but Decor Doesn't
description: PERIODIC visits to Cobble Creek Cafe here find that Jose Oliver, the talented chef, keeps the short menu fresh, reinventing his standards and replacing dishes that seem tired. If only such attention were paid to the decor. The chairs' sagging seats have finally been reupholstered, and the handsome bits of stained glass continue to add a bit of glimmer. But, in general, this cube of a dining room has all the appeal of an industrial dining hall, and the unbalanced lighting is to blame. Although the upper portion of the room is illuminated, the dining floor is left in unrelieved gloom.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The East Village; From Mean Streets to Cutting-Edge
description: IN 1967, when Tom Birchard started waiting on tables at Veselka, a Ukrainian diner on Second Avenue at Ninth Street, the East Village was a somewhat battered working-class neighborhood. On summer evenings, children played stickball in the street while adults sat on lawn chairs on the sidewalks or on stoops, chatting with neighbors. There was a club where reputed mobsters met, and there were pawn shops, Italian bakeries, Jewish delicatessens and car mechanics repairing tires and rebuilding motors on the side walk.

title: Fitness Clubs Will Be Sold So a Chain Can Expand
description: In an effort to pay for a nationwide expansion, the upscale Manhattan gym chain Equinox Fitness Clubs has agreed to be acquired by two private investing firms, according to Equinox's chief executive.

title: NEWARK CONTRACT
description: The 5,000 members of the Newark Teachers Union are to vote tomorrow on a three-year contract that will give them a total of 14.67 percent in raises plus some tuition reimbursement. Both sides said the talks went much more smoothly than the yearlong talks in 1997. Steve Strunsky

title: Dog Days
description: What a cold story for this wonderful season of the year: Beginning Crime 101, an education in deviant behavior and a glorification of it.

title: Bewitching Barks, Huggable Trunks
description: I GET the same secret pleasure out of winter walks as I do getting up before anyone else in the morning. No one knows how good this is, I say to myself, and I hope it stays that way. There's an openness to the landscape after the leaves fall and the vines die back. You notice the architecture of the place as a whole: the dark gray outcroppings of schist, for example, as it courses through the woods; the tall mastlike trunks of poplars and oaks; how the land rolls.

title: MUSIC: The Year in Pop and Jazz: the Critics' Choices; Danceable Grooves, Hip-Hop Worldviews
description: D'ANGELO: ''VOODOO'' (Virgin) The groove is everything on ''Voodoo.'' It's a rendezvous for musical impulses from funk, jazz, gospel and rock. It's a playground and a refuge. And it's a place where desire, ambition, intelligence, faith and freedom all swirl together in songs that turn the earthy and the metaphysical into dance partners.

title: A Commanding Virtuoso Avoids the Celebrity Circuit
description: THE pianist Russell Sherman is rather miffed that at this stage of his eminent career he is still considered by some to be an eccentric interpreter. ''I think of myself as a compassionate conservative,'' he said during a recent conversation in New York. ''I respond radically to the score and nothing but the score.''

title: Those Magnificent Jersey Men and Their Flying Machines
description: World War I produced famous flying aces like Eddie Rickenbacker, and others less famous, including some from New Jersey. The New Jersey Aviation Hall of Fame in Teterboro gives seven home-state fighter pilots their due in an exhibition through February entitled ''New Jersey's Aviators of the Great War.'' Their stories are told in one display cases for each pilot, with the help of uniforms, medals, photographs, log books, helmets and other items. An eighth case tells the story of a German pilot who shot down a New Jersey flier in 1918. The hall of fame is at 400 Fred Wehran Drive, open Tuesdays through Sundays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., and admission is $5. Michael O'Neal, an aviation historian and artist and a recreational pilot, recently spoke of the exhibition he organized.

title: A Very Mexican Hideaway
description: TROPICAL night had fallen. We were returning late from a hike on a narrow, unlighted road through the mangroves. Out of the gloom ahead materialized a figure carrying a very large machete.

title: December 10 - 16; Th-th-that's Not All, Folks
description: Thanks to the Federal Trade Commission, Bugs Bunny will now have more Internet outlets. The commission voted to approve the merger of America Online and Time Warner, marrying the world's largest Internet company with the nation's biggest news and entertainment conglomerate. The settlement of antitrust problems followed months of hard negotiations that had threatened to unhinge the deal, which is now expected to be be completed in the next few weeks. Stephen Labaton

title: Back in the U.S.S.R.
description: Outside the Theater of Musical Comedy in the Belarussian capital of Minsk, not too far from the old Valadarka K.G.B. prison, a well-dressed crowd waits in the rain for the theater to open. Tonight's gala performance is the hottest ticket in town, and judging by the fracas at the door, zealous government organizers have invited more people than the auditorium can handle.

title: A Serene Garden in Portland Draws Crowds
description: One of the largest classical Chinese gardens outside China is drawing surprising crowds in downtown Portland, Ore. The garden, Lan Su Yuan, or the Garden of Awakening Orchids, which opened Sept. 14 after 15 years of planning and 9 months of construction, has drawn more than 69,000 visitors through November. About 100,000 had been expected the first full year, according to Gloria Lee, the executive director.

title: That Dazed Feeling on Insurance Prices
description: IS it time to renew your car insurance? Nowadays, the advice to comparison-shop makes more sense than ever.

title: Graven Images From the Past
description: THE mighty Murray Hill distributing reservoir stood at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street when it was depicted in this 1897 engraving by Edwin Davis French. But in a few years it gave way to the New York Public Library. This image survives, thanks to the Society of Iconophiles, which was founded in 1894 and dedicated to preserving in print various monuments and edifices that defined the city. When the society disbanded in 1930, it left a legacy of 119 prints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAILMOR, ELAINE
description: GAILMOR-Elaine, 84. Of Westport, Connecticut, died December 2, in Florida. An Honors graduate in sociology at NYU she served many years as the Administrator of the Miquon School, an innovative, progressive private elementary school in Miquon, PA. A tireless crusader for peace and human rights, she thrived on lively political dialogue, peppered with humor. She was predeceased by her husband, William S. Gailmor, a journalist and popular news commentator in New York whose radio career was aburptly ended by the Blacklist in the late 1940's, and a brother Robert E. Pantell. She is survived by her daughter and sonin-law Wendy and David Newton of Weston, Connecticut; her son Jon Gailmor, daughter-in-law Cathy Murphy, and grandchildren Aaron, Maya and Micaela, of Lake Elmore, Vermont; and her companion of many years Richard Temko. Characteristically, a few days before her death, she commented on the post-election Florida fiasco: ''If I'd been up and around, none of this would have happened.'' She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, PHYLLIS E.
description: LEVINE-Phyllis E. Age 73, of Hallandale, formerly of NYC, passed away Thursday, December 14, 2000. She was the beloved wife of the late Phillip, loving mother of Michael (Harriet) Levine and Karen (Allen) Saperstein. Cherished grandmother of Paige, Lara and Rikki Saperstein. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Leukemia Society. Service will be held December 19, 2000, 10 AM, at Blasberg Rubin Zilbert Memorial Chapels, 720 71st St, Miami Beach, FL 33141; 305-865-2353.

title: A Celebration of Yiddish
description: Ready for some Oy-Robics? Then the place to be at 3 p.m. today is the Kids and Yiddish show at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. It's a celebration of Yiddish culture featuring music and stories -- much of it in English -- produced by the 85-year-old Folksbeine Theater, of New York City, the oldest Yiddish theater in the United States. With the aid of a Klezmer band, the actors and singers perform skits and sing songs (some about Hanukkah with the purpose of passing on the dying Yiddish language to a new generation. The evening is designed for children between 3 and 12. Robbie Woliver

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-17-00: Intimations; A Very Fine Line
description: A young intern in a psychiatric hospital recently told me she was thinking of abandoning the field. She had studied psychiatry to find out how the human mind works, she said, but all she learned was which drug would control which socially incorrect behavior. And who's to say what's incorrect? ''If he showed up here tonight,'' she said, ''I would drug Vincent van Gogh so that he would never paint again.''

title: On Form In Emptiness: A Zen Way
description: I'M trying to make gravel out of Play-Doh,'' explains Tom Friedman helpfully as he notices a visitor puzzling over a pile of odd, dun-colored pebbles in his sun-drenched Massachusetts studio. The kindergarten playtime staple may seem an unlikely medium for an artist whose work is shown at major galleries and museums around the world. But as it turns out, Play-Doh is one of the more conventional art materials you're likely to find in Mr. Friedman's work. This is an artist, after all, who once chewed 1,500 pieces of bubble gum and then painstakingly formed them into a perfect pink sphere meant to be wedged into a corner of an exhibition space, held aloft at eye level solely by its own stickiness.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Hero's Journey
description: A magnificent photo album of a magnificent man in magnificent times, KING: The Photobiography of Martin Luther King, Jr. (Bob Adelman/Viking Studio, $40) uses many archival sources to narrate the life of the leader of the civil rights struggle. Thousands of lenses were trained on King's public journey, which began when the personable young Baptist minister emerged as the charismatic leader of the Montgomery bus boycott in 1955 and reached its apex at the March on Washington in 1963. Short, not handsome, battling a tendency to put on extra pounds, King was physically unimpressive except when he stepped before a microphone and the oratory flowed. The novelist Charles Johnson contributes a masterly elegiac text that does not paper over the philosophical differences between King's sustained vision of peaceful interracial cooperation and the vocal advocates of black power who claimed national attention in his last years. This pictorial history originated with the photographer Bob Adelman, whose own work is well represented. The decision to put the copyright credits on the final page makes it a task to determine which photographer captured which memorable image. Photographers played a significant role in the civil rights struggle. Their names deserved more prominent placement. Susan Brownmiller

The airline had intended to switch to a new kind of grease, but was apparently using new and old, and the two were incompatible; 88 people died. A key document describing who approved the switch is mostly blank. But the mechanism may not have any grease at all. Matthew L. Wald

title: Food; Plaen and Fancy
description: Jack Ty Coch, who looks after my roof, fences, water supply and so forth, still eats brwes menyn, long a favorite of Welsh farmers. It consists of diced bread, a lump of butter, pepper and salt and a little boiling water. The bread, of course, should be homemade. The food writer Countess Morphy remarked regretfully in the 30's that ''the Welsh seem to have been particularly indifferent to the art of cooking. 'Tea and bread and butter' seems to be the national institution, and the amount of both which is consumed is amazing.'' Most of the cooking -- of scones, cakes, crempogau (Welsh pancakes) etc. -- was done on the bakestone, while meat, when the Welsh could afford it, was boiled with vegetables in a caldron over the fire.

title: Boston's Big Dig Joins First Night Festivities
description: First Night Boston this year will include an unusual underground event: brief free tours of the Big Dig, the vast cavity that has wrapped the city in dust and construction barriers through the 90's. Between 11 a.m. and 5 p.m. on Dec. 31, visitors on the 15-minute tours will go down a ramp at Fulton Street, near Quincy Market, to the 10 lanes of Interstate 93 being tunneled under the street and the existing elevated road. Inside the Big Dig, formally the Central Artery-Tunnel Project, the First Nighters will be able to cross future traffic lanes and see a part of the construction that is safe to tour.

title: Style; Another Child's Christmas In Wales
description: People unfamiliar with the Principality who have read Dylan Thomas's ''A Child's Christmas in Wales'' will have formed a rosy, romantic view of the occasion and might take it as typical of the seasonal atmosphere countrywide, but Thomas lived in the south, he did not speak Welsh, and his Christmas was anglicized. Besides, he always did exaggerate. I was brought up in the north, and the whole thing was very different. As one critic writing in the 18th century described it, ''fanatic imposters'' and ''illiterate plebian preachers,'' ''having overrun the country . . . misleading the greater part of the common people from their lawful church,'' were dissuading them ''from their innocent amusements, such as singing, dancing and other rural sports.'' The consequence, he concluded gloomily, was that Wales, ''formerly one of the merriest and happiest countries in the world, is now become one of the dullest.''

title: Chorale Looks Beyond Its Chinese Repertory To Widen Appeal
description: THE choral scene in both New Jersey and New York is busy and competitive. Scores of amateur, collegiate, semiprofessional and professional choruses vie for venues, rehearsal space, audiences and reviews. title: A Haunting Legacy in Provence
description: THE story of Diasporic Jews is a long and poignant one. Here is a people whom history has sent packing from their place of origin. They touch down on unfamiliar soil and quickly arrange their lives with a mixture of the chameleonlike and the steadfast. They speak their host's language, wear his clothes, adapt his cuisine and use his architectural vocabulary to build their houses and their synagogues, yet all the while they nurture and are nurtured by their faith and their identity and their history, and they pass along this heritage to their children, often in the face of considerable persecution and pain.

title: 2 Rookies Say They Understand Why Scott Wants Them In Early
description: When Kenyon Martin heard that the Nets' rookies would report to practice a half-hour early, a policy started this week by Coach Byron Scott, he did not sound concerned. The individualized instruction could only help, and the half-hour would not prove too strenuous for players still adapting to the rigors of the National Basketball Association.

title: Amtrak Offers Rewards For Frequent Riders
description: Airline passengers have been doing it for years, and now Amtrak riders can do it, too. On Nov. 29 the railroad introduced a rewards program that allows frequent travelers to earn points good for rail and plane travel, hotel stays and merchandise.

title: Streetscapes/222 Bowery, Between Spring and Prince Streets; The 1885 Young Men's Institute, Now a Loft Co-op
description: TWO years ago the poet John Giorno succeeded in getting landmark designation for the 1885 brick loft building at 222 Bowery, whose occupants have included the artists Fernand Leger and Mark Rothko and the beat writer William S. Burroughs. Mr. Giorno serves as secretary-treasurer of the co-op board for the building, which was built as the Young Men's Institute by the Y.M.C.A., and this year he had to backtrack on masonry repairs to meet Landmarks Preservation Commission requirements.

title: POWELL TO HEAD STATE DEPT. AS BUSH'S FIRST CABINET PICK

title: Learning to Value Our Own Labor
description: IF only we could be a little more like the six stars of ''Friends,'' the NBC hit comedy. It's not their fame that is so appealing, but rather their all-for-one, one-for-all approach to negotiating. When renewing their contracts early this year, their strategy was that if they didn't make a certain amount per episode -- the same for each star -- they'd all walk. Ultimately, that amount would be $750,000.

title: The Big, Bad, Fun Gun
description: Thank you for Bruce Porter's excellent article (Nov. 26) on the sport of .50-caliber-rifle shooting. I have been a sport and military shooter for most of my 74 years and can find no harm in this endeavor. Long-range shooting has never been used to assassinate anyone here to my knowledge. At the price of these shooting toys and the need for wide-open spaces, I doubt if .50-caliber shooting will ''catch on.'' It is no more dangerous than yacht racing, driving Indy race cars or sky diving. It is one of our freedoms and should be enjoyed not vilified.

title: The Ballot Reform Imperative
description: The margin of error exceeded the margin of victory. That is the shameful post-mortem of the messy 2000 presidential contest in a nation that fancies itself the world's most admired democracy. We point this out not to re-argue a legal decision that we and most Americans accept as final, but rather to emphasize the need for ballot reform in state and national elections. Congress and state governments must now work together vigorously to develop a more accurate and uniform way for Americans to vote. We urged this a few weeks ago when it seemed a political imperative. Now we do so in the belief that it is a constitutional imperative as well.

title: December 10 - 16; All About Sex
description: It was Viagra that made women's groups so mad: if company health plans would pay for a pill to help men's sexual performance, why not women's birth-control pills? Many employers said they would not cover prescription contraceptives for either sex, and it just happened that the five on the market -- the pill, the intrauterine device, the diaphragm, Norplant and Depo-Provera -- are all for women. But the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled that the exclusion of contraception coverage is sex discrimination. But Viagra was not the issue. Rather, the commission said, employers who pay for vaccinations and blood-pressure pills must also cover prescription contraceptives, because under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, preventing pregnancy must be treated like any other preventive care. Tamar Lewin

title: Where a Revolution Was Sparked
description: A FEW days after the Mexican priest had issued his cry for revolt, his swelling band of rebels was facing its first major battle. The revolutionaries of 1810 had swept through a couple of small towns in the mountains north of Mexico City and were descending on Guanajuato, a regional capital rich in silver and Spanish colonial power. The colonists hurriedly hid in a granary on the city's west side, hoping to hold off the rebels and wait for reinforcements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEERY, EVELYN ONKEN
description: BEERY-Evelyn Onken. Of Ridgefield, CT, and formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died on December 13, 2000. The former wife of Dr. Edwin N. Beery, she is survived by sons Edwin N. Berry Jr., of Craftsbury Common, VT, and the Rev. William S. Beery, Ph.D., of Darien, CT; by her daughter Lillian B. Willis, of Ridgefield, CT; by her brother George M. Onken and sister Lillian O. Barnes; and by seven grandchildren and one greatgranddaughter. A graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute, she served on the boards of Brookwood Child Care and the Brooklyn YWCA, and was at one time the Y's Acting Director and one of the first two women elected to the Board of the New York YMCA in 1970. She was a member of the Civitas Club, Mrs. Field's Literary Club, and the Junior League of Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held Friday, December 22, at noon, at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Brooklyn YWCA, Brookwood Child Care, the Packer Collegiate Institute or Grace Church, all of Brooklyn.

As the housing supply shrank and prices rose, they settled in communities up the line, their vehicles flooding the highways, railroad parking lots and Stamford streets.

But an official from Steinberg's office said on Thursday that the firm planned to drop the suit.

description: Judge Edmund G. Fitzgerald Jr. of Yonkers City Court has been disbarred for misusing more than $9,000 in a client's account in 1990, when the judge was practicing law. A panel of five state Appellate Division judges unanimously found that Judge Fitzgerald, who was elected to a 10-year term as city court judge a year ago, violated the Code of Professional Responsibility and must now step down. title: Mara Not Blaming Tagliabue
description: The Giants co-owner Wellington Mara wanted to make it clear he did not think that Commissioner Paul Tagliabue was being too lenient in his punishment of Cleveland General Manager Carmen Policy for salary cap violations. Mara said Tagliabue's hands were tied because of the restraints of the collective bargaining agreement. Tagliabue fined Policy $400,000 for violations when Policy was running the daily operations of the 49ers. . . . Speaking of the Giants, several general managers said last week that the interest levels continue to rise in the assistants Sean Payton and John Fox as head coaching candidates. Some executives also continue pointing to defensive backs coach Johnnie Lynn as a potential defensive coordinator. . . . It's all but official: Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman will most likely retire at the end of this season because of multiple concussions. Meanwhile, the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, has been increasingly visible on the sidelines this season, in player meetings and game-planning sessions with coaches. . . . The consensus around the N.F.L. is that Bill Parcells will remain for at least one more season as general manager of the Jets. Estimates are that he is earning about $1.2 million this year and that he isn't willing to walk away from that kind of cash. Mike Freeman

title: Unlike His Coaches, Clarke Seems Secure
description: With yet another coaching change last week, might the Flyers' chairman, Ed Snider, consider replacing General Manager Bob Clarke? ''No way,'' Snider said, inserting a modifier for emphasis. ''I'm very happy with the direction of the franchise under Bob Clarke.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-17-00: The Ethicist; Where There's Smoke
description: I have a dear 79-year-old friend who lives on a fixed income. A heavy smoker, she is down to one lung and professes no desire to quit. She has no car, so once a month I drive her to the military commissary (her husband was a veteran) in the Presidio to buy cheap cigarettes, which I often pay for. Should I continue to support her deadly habit or cut her off and force her to suffer the withdrawal she says she cannot endure? -- Dave Swanson, San Francisco

title: For a Rookie Soccer Coach, Lessons in What's Important
description: AFTER my son's soccer team went 0 and 8 last spring, draining almost all the fun out of the game for the boys, I signed on to be the team's new coach. My main hope was to make soccer fun again for him and his pals.

title: The Dogs Are Out
description: To the Editor: In reading ''Who Let the Dogs Out? Europeans'' (Nov. 26), I recalled being befriended in 1987 by an aristocratic Milanese family while studying for my degree in veterinary medicine in Italy. Their dachshund Martina regularly attended church, business meetings and all restaurant meals with her family. At restaurants, she ate from the sugar bowls on the table, had veal paillard for her second course and drank espresso (caffeinated, please) from her own silver cup.

title: Excellent Educations Not Confined to Ivy League
description: Your recent article on how difficult it has become for Long Island high school students to gain entrance to an elite college or university because of an increase in applications [''College Hopefuls Face Stronger Competition,'' Dec. 10] prompts this reminder that there is another way to go about it. In the 1980's, my two sons went to Hobart-William Smith in Geneva, N.Y., and got a super education. The campus was beautiful and the facilities excellent. The best part was the faculty. Virtually all the professors had Ph.D.'s; they were excellent teachers. The students could expect to have someone like this for all their classes as well as lectures. At places like Cornell or Penn, on the other hand, the chances are that students will be instructed by overworked graduate students.

title: For Tiger Woods, a 7-Year Pitch
description: More often than not, the number seven is associated with misfortune and danger -- seven years of bad luck, ''The Seven Samurai,'' the Seven Years' War, the seven-year itch. But American Express, which just extended its endorsement contract with the golfer Tiger Woods for seven years, to mid-2007, sees it in a far different way, like the lucky sevens of the Las Vegas slots. Although financial terms of the contract were not disclosed, it is unusually long -- only a handful of other celebrity endorsers, like Michael Jordan and Cindy Crawford, have similar contracts. Mr. Woods, who last month criticized the P.G.A. Tour policy that regulates the use of his image by tournament sponsors, and specifically ads for sponsors that conflict with the companies he endorses, has been a spokesman for American Express since 1997. Allison Fass

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUDESH, STEPHEN BERNARD
description: KUDESH-Stephen Bernard. Age 56. Of Edison. Died Thursday, December 14, 2000, at St. Peter's Medical Center, New Brunswick. Born January 19, 1944, in Queens, NY. Resided in Bayside, Queens, then Kew Gardens, before moving to Edison 25 years ago. Partner at the Cornell Computer Corporation, a computer consulting firm, in Edison for over 10 years, and was also president of its Telecomm Division. Received an M.B.A. in finance from St. John's University, NYC, and did his undergraduate studies at St. Lawrence University, Canton, NY. He is a member of Temple Neve Shalom in Edison, and a member of its choir. He also served as vice president of the J.C.C. of Middlesex County, and is also on the Board of Directors. He also sang in the Big Apple Chorus, NYC, which was invited to sing in Russia in the summer of 2001, and had also sung in Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center with the Big Apple Chorus. Surviving family members: wife Enid (Zucker) Kudesh, daughter Michelle Kudesh, son Jeremy Kudesh. Funeral services Sunday, December 17, 2000, at 9:30 AM, in Temple Neve Shalom, 250 Grove Ave., Edison, NJ, Rabbi Gerald Zelizer officiating. Burial will follow in Beth El Cemetery, Oradell, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the family residence. For information, contact Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, NJ. Condolence messages may be sent to our web address at: www.flynnfuneral.com.

title: OPINION; What We Are About to Receive
description: I WAS recently approached by the nutritionists at Equal, the folks who make those blue packets of tabletop sweeteners, to do some arithmetic in honor of the holidays. They wanted to figure out how many calories Long Island is expected to consume this Christmas holiday and what that all meant in terms of energy. They came to the right place. There is nothing more that a biochemist likes to do on his day off than crunch numbers.

title: Reserving a Stage For Tomorrow's Choreographers
description: ON a recent Friday evening, Charlotte Griffin decided to make a number of changes in her 1997 dance ''Too Much.'' She had originally created this choreographically dense work, which incorporates text and singing, for her senior production at the Juilliard School dance division. In it, dancers grapple with excess; as they shift in complex, constantly evolving patterns on the stage, they speak in cliches and even sing sections of popular songs like ''Que Sera Sera.'' Smart and carefully structured, ''Too Much'' comments subtly on the useless information that surrounds young people as they leave the security of college to face the world.

title: A Long-Dry Pool, With a Famous Past, Faces the Future
description: McCarren Park Pool, on the border between Williamsburg and Greenpoint, has seen better days. Built in 1936, it was one of 11 giant outdoor pools constructed by the Works Progress Administration during Robert Moses' tenure as parks commissioner. Able to hold up to 6,800 swimmers, the pool had a design that was inspired in part by the Baths of Caracalla in Rome.

title: Four-Wheeled Wallflowers, Waiting for a Dance
description: GENERAL MOTORS' decision to pull the plug on Oldsmobile, announced last week, is sad for many reasons. Olds, dating from 1897, is the oldest surviving American auto producer. Its grand engineering tradition brought innovations like the Hydra-Matic transmission, the overhead-valve Rocket V-8 and the front-wheel-drive Toronado. As recently as 1987, it was No. 3 in sales, trailing only Chevrolet and Ford -- but this year, sales of Olds cars fell behind even those of Saturn, the upstart youngster in the G.M. family.

title: Kick Frosty and Win a Tree (A Costly Game for the Seller)

Wife of the late film and stage actor Brian Aherne and sister of producer Alfred de Liagre, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Leonie Labrot Gately of Annapolis, MD. Five grandsons and six greatgrandchildren. An unusual lifetime network of great close and diverse friendships-spanning the early arts colony in Woodstock, NY to Hollywood and from New York City to Europe. She will always be celebrated and loved for her warmth, immense charm, her sense of fun and almost total and complete eccentricity. The laughter and great good nature will live on. Memorial Services will be held in January in Boca Grande, FL.

title: December 10 - 16; Chernobyl Farewell
description: Talk about long goodbyes: nearly 15 years after Earth's worst nuclear accident, workers shut down the last of four reactors at the Chernobyl power station. Ukraine had long resisted the move; it relied on Chernobyl for power and, more important, for 9,000 badly needed jobs. The West pledged huge sums to finish two replacement reactors and safeguard the lethally radioactive wreckage of the Unit Three reactor, where the Chernobyl disaster occurred. Now comes the really long goodbye: the half-life of the melted plutonium in Unit Three is 24,000 years. Michael Wines

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITAKER, ROBERT MARTIN
description: WHITAKER-Robert Martin. Born January 19, 1906 in Gloucester, NJ, died December 1, 2000 in Sarasota, Florida. He was a son of Milton C. and Mabel Martin Whitaker. He had lived in New York City and Westport, CT, and in Putnam Station, NY where there is a family summer home. He was a graduate of Yale College, Class of 1927, and of The Harvard Business School, and was with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co until his retirement in 1961. He was an honorary trustee of The Leopold Schepp Foundation, having been an active trustee until he and his wife moved to Siesta Key nearly forty years ago. He was a member of The Field Club, The Sanderling Club, and The Fishermen, all in Sarasota. He was predeceased by his wife, the former Eleanor Alexander. Survivors include his son, Robert M. Whitaker, Jr. of Saratoga Springs, NY and Riverport, Nova Scotia, two daughters, Anne W. Eaton of Stonington, CT, and Sally W. Freud of Cherry Hill, NJ and Putnam Station, NY, ten grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. He was also prdeceased by his brother, John M. Whitaker. Memorial contributions may be sent to The Marie Selby Botanical Gardens, 811 South Palm Ave., Sarasota, FL 34236 or to The Lake George Associaton, Inc., PO Box 408, Lake George, NY 12845. A service was held at The Sanderling Club, Siesta Key. Burial will be at Bonaventure Cemetery, Savannah, GA at a later date.

This Christmas, however, those volumes may be subject to revision: a debate has broken out over whether Moore was actually the author.

title: Dressed to the Kilt
description: Men today get facials and do yoga, so it shouldn't be so surprising that they're now more comfortable wearing skirts. Or at least kilts. The traditional Scottish wraparound has been discovered by hipsters of Scottish descent and by fashion's forward guard. At the Christian Dior fall show, John Galliano sent a sequined kilt down the runway, and the Burberry designer, Roberto Menichetti, had men in tartan wool kilts in his fall show. The artist Damian Loeb, left, borrowed a kilt from Burberry to wear to an art event this fall. The musician Donovan Leitch has been spotted in one at many a fashion fete. Kyle MacLachlan donned a little plaid number for a recent episode of ''Sex and the City.'' And the director Guy Ritchie is expected to wear a floor-length kilt in the Hunting MacIntosh tartan when he marries Madonna this week. Who knows if kilts will ever replace jeans, but Burberry introduced its line of men's kilts this month, in its signature nova check plaid ($775), and it has already sold out. Anyone who calls to be put on the waiting list (212-371-5010) can order a custom kilt in his family's colors; there's an ancestry directory at the store at 9 East 57th Street. For those in the Stewart clan, which is linked to royalty, the tartan is a mix of green and red, perfect for Christmas. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Ripples From Afghanistan
description: For a small, remote nation of 26 million people that has never had an effective central government, Afghanistan has certainly managed over the decades to be a major source of international instability. In the 1980's, Soviet troops and American-backed Islamic guerrillas fought a brutish war there that helped speed the Soviet Union's demise. Today, in an ironic turnabout, the United States and Russia are united in their opposition to Afghanistan's role as a sanctuary for terrorists and an exporter of Islamic fundamentalist revolt.

title: December 10 - 16; Affirmative Action Upheld

The decision is the second this month to endorse race-conscious admissions decisions, though a federal appellate court struck down a similar program in Texas in 1996. That dispute may well call for a second opinion from the United States Supreme Court. Jodi Wilgoren

title: Three Methods of Removing Wallpaper
description: REMOVING old wallpaper is a messy and tedious job, but it is usually necessary if you want to paint or repaper the walls. Before attacking the wallpaper, take the time to protect the room and its contents. Remove all the furniture and carpets from the room if you can. If not, cover them and the floors with heavy plastic film. Remove the plates from all switches and outlets, then cover them with masking tape. Protect the moldings around the doors, windows and walls with self-stick masking paper.

The amount of available space in Midtown declined by half over the previous year to 6.35 million square feet, or 3.5 percent of the total office space. But asking rents in November averaged $62.24 a square foot, just slightly below the peak of $62.85 recorded in September.

Yet Nelson Rodrigues, once derided as ''a degenerate in suspenders,'' was clearly the progenitor of the modern Brazilian theater, and with the 20th anniversary of his death approaching, his status here is now that of a cultural hero.

Leather suggests armor for a hostile urban environment. All price points are covered, from brand-name jeans worn with down jackets to designer pants worn with a Russian sable coat, top right. Will it be like 45-year-old Gordie Howe's return to hockey in 1973, a seven-year anticlimax? Or will it be like 32-year-old Michael Jordan's return to basketball in 1995: three more league championships and another retirement as the best player, and biggest draw, in his sport? As a controlling partner in the team's ownership, Lemieux has ample motivation. In the post-Wayne Gretzky era, his sport yearns for a charismatic star and a dramatic story line. With a history of Hodgkin's disease, back surgery and two Stanley Cups, the first act of Lemieux's two-act play is prominently in place. Joe Lapointe

title: Javier Bardem Comes Across
description: Javier Bardem is no stranger to fame. The tall, unconventionally handsome actor is already a huge star in his native Spain, where he has made 16 films in the last decade. More important, he has displayed a dazzling range that has made him part of that rare breed of actor: one who is capable of playing any role. Lover, fighter, rascal, brute, con man, gay man, mad Santeria priest on a murderous spree: Bardem has done them all. Now America is starting to pay attention. The reason for all the fuss is Bardem's American debut in Julian Schnabel's ''Before Night Falls,'' a portrait of the Cuban author Reinaldo Arenas, which opens next week. The Film Society of Lincoln Center is also showcasing five of Bardem's recent films.

title: December 10 - 16; Who Has the Energy?

After another crisis week, even some supporters of energy deregulation have given it an F and are seeking government intervention. Gov. Gray Davis went to Washington and Energy Secretary Bill Richardson invoked emergency powers to force generating companies to provide more electricity. With more than 20 states considering deregulation, it is not a promising sign. James Sterngold

title: The Legal Spectacle; Divining the Consequences of a Court Divided
description: SIXTY years ago, Robert H. Jackson, President Franklin D. Roosevelt's attorney general, published a reflection on F.D.R.'s titanic battle with the Supreme Court that had reached its climax in the failed court-packing plan. In 1937, the president, enraged by the court's striking down of the New Deal's economic cornerstones, had proposed to expand its membership to as many as 15 justices by adding a new seat for each member who refused to retire at 70. Born in political desperation, the plan came under withering attack as a threat to the separation of powers and died after the court began to uphold some New Deal programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATIL, JACQUELINE
description: LATIL-Jacqueline. Died peacefully on December 7, 2000, in Kew Gardens, New York. Survived by her beloved husband, Jean Paul, to whom she was married for 67 years, her sister, Lise Blum Elson, and her sister-in-law Genevieve Blum-Gayet, of Corenc, France. She also leaves her three children, Martine, Catherine, and Bertrand, six grandchildren, Lisa, Anne, Alex, Alice, Ellie, and Francine, one great grandchild, Brooke, two nephews, Richard, and David, her niece, Becky, and other family and friends. Jacqueline was born in 1913 in Paris, France, and moved to the United States sixty years ago. Her interests included birding, mushrooming, origami, and knitting. The lives of many have been touched by her thoughtful and nurturing spirit. She will live on in our hearts, our memories, and our actions forever.

title: An Attempt at Harmony
description: On Halloween, Napster, the embattled Internet music upstart, and the recording giant BMG acknowledged they had put a real scare into each other. Napster's service lets users swap music files for free over the Internet, which prompted a lawsuit late last year by BMG and the four other biggest music companies. But on Oct. 31, BMG and Napster announced a deal under which Napster agreed to start charging users and to pay royalties to the recording companies. If that happens, BMG has agreed to drop its portion of the suit, but so far the industry's case against Napster is still pending. At year's end, the labels were scrambling to create their own Internet business models.

title: As Oil Prices Decline, Natural Gas Threatens to Upset the Trend
description: How much longer will this go on? That seemed to be the question for everyone who felt the pinch of oil prices this year, as the cost of a barrel of crude shot past $30 in late winter. The price hit $37 in September, the highest since the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, and gasoline prices in the Midwest climbed to more than $2.50 a gallon, igniting consumer outrage and government inquiries. But the stubbornly high price has begun to slip, falling to less than $30 a barrel earlier this month, even with winter bearing down and stocks of heating oil in the Northeast still sharply below last year's levels.

title: The Uproar Over Altered Corn
description: Government and agricultural industry officials are scrambling to stem a drop in corn exports to Japan and South Korea after the disclosure that some corn grown in the United States has been intermingled with StarLink, a genetically engineered corn approved for use in the United States for animal feed but not for food. The Agriculture Department has agreed with Japan, the largest buyer of American corn, on a protocol for testing for the presence of StarLink in shipments of corn bound for that country. The StarLink incident, which has created disruption in the Farm Belt, is the latest challenge to the agricultural biotechnology industry. While American farmers have embraced genetically engineered crops, some consumers are against them, particularly in Europe. Corn exports to Europe, never high to begin with, have dropped significantly in the last couple of years.

title: DaimlerChrysler at a Juncture
description: Jurgen E. Schrempp, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, may be running out of time. Two years after the trans-Atlantic merger of Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation, the Chrysler operations are hemorrhaging money, and DaimlerChrysler shares have lost more than $60 billion in value since January 1999. Mr. Schrempp installed Dieter Zetsche, a Stuttgart executive, as president of Chrysler and told him to come up with a turnaround plan by the time the company announces year-end financial results on Feb. 28. Cost-cutting is the priority, but it may not be enough if the American car market continues to soften. Industry executives say that Daimler's biggest shareholder, Deutsche Bank, may pull the plug on Mr. Schrempp if he cannot bring about some improvement by summer.

title: Optimism on Global PC Sales

title: Shops vs. Swamps In the Meadowlands; Debate Over a Huge Shopping Mall Marked by Rival Claims and Spin
description: For more than three centuries, man has tried his best to obliterate the watery quilt of marshland and mud flats that sits five miles from the Empire State Building. Long viewed as a mosquito-breeding wasteland, these 32 square miles of salt hay and swamp have been drained, dammed and piled high with mountains of trash, making the Hackensack Meadowlands the nation's most famous garbage dump.

title: For 'New Danes,' Differences Create a Divide
description: This is a love story with its share of pain. It begins in a Turkish village where geese roam the dusty streets and days turn to the rhythm of harvest and prayer. It ends in this bustling Danish port town where passion undid tradition and cultures of East and West clashed.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER; Loyalist Assumes a White House Role
description: When colleagues and acquaintances describe Karen P. Hughes, named today to be White House counselor for President-elect George W. Bush, they use the same words and phrases: tough, no-nonsense, formidable, loyal and utterly devoted.

title: A New Era for U.S. and Vietnam
description: President Clinton opened a new chapter in relations with Vietnam in November by spending three days in the country. It was the first visit by an American president since the end of the war 25 years ago. Mr. Clinton gently but insistently urged Vietnam to set aside its fears and join the global marketplace of trade and ideas, though some Vietnamese leaders did not seem at all sure that they wanted to. Ordinary people were an easier sell: Mr. Clinton was thronged and cheered wherever he went. The president's visit came shortly after the two former adversaries signed a trade agreement that, if carried out, may tear down many of the walls Vietnam has erected around its economy and society. The accord, Mr. Clinton said, will promote ''a more open, sophisticated free market, based on international rules of law.''

title: The Year That European Corporate Acquirers Invaded America
description: The business-class cabin on British Airways' Flight 183 was packed to the last sleeper seat with investment bankers for much of this year. That is the airline's last flight out of Heathrow Airport in London bound for Kennedy International Airport in New York every night. It became so frequently packed with wheeling-and-dealing bankers -- negotiating $263.9 billion worth of trans-Atlantic mergers so far this year -- that it was dubbed the Deal Express by some of the flight's crew members.

title: Mr. Bush's Environmental Choices
description: New presidents who use their cabinet choices to bridge party lines tend to think first of big-ticket posts like Defense, State and Treasury, reserving their more partisan appointments for less visible places like the Interior Department and the regulatory agencies. George W. Bush should think hard before following that course. Ronald Reagan stashed his ideologues at the agencies and Interior with disastrous results, both for the bipartisanship that Mr. Bush professes to hold dear and for the country as a whole. Mr. Reagan was forced to name William Ruckelshaus, a reliable Republican environmentalist, to rebuild the Environmental Protection Agency after two years of mismanagement by Anne Burford and the industry lobbyists she installed in senior positions. Likewise, Mr. Reagan was forced by Congress to accept the resignation of his tragicomic interior secretary, James Watt, who used his office to undermine the statutes he was sworn to uphold.

It then left a rare double rainbow arching, Oz-like, over Midtown Manhattan.

title: Can the New Economy Navigate Rougher Waters?
description: PUFFED up with credit for the prosperity of the 1990's, the new economy is entering its first slowdown, offering numerous efficiencies and injections of wealth to soften the pain. But softening the pain will not be easy. This is the third or fourth new economy since the 19th century -- each one offering a similar promise -- and yet none could stop a persistent downturn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINZ, MARTIN
description: PRINZ-Martin. Curator Emeritus in The Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences at The American Museum of Natural History, died December 16, 2000, after a heroic battle with cancer. Marty was born on September 5, 1931, on the lower east side of Manhattan. He truly cherished his roots. He was proud to follow the tradition of so many other New Yorkers born of eastern European Jewish immigrants who pursued higher education. Marty received his bachelor's degree from City College and his Ph.D. from Columbia University. He will be missed by all who knew him and most especially by his wife Sandy, his children Will, Martha and Michael, their spouses Susan and Mark, his grandchildren Jacob, Henry and Noah, his stepchildren Bonnie and Larry Siegel, his sister and brother-in-law Frances and Bernie Friedman, and his former wife Victoria. Marty was a man who had a great deal of vitality and passion for his work and the people he loved. His goal was always to do the best he could and be honest and ethical in the process. He was a real ''mensch'' who felt at home in the world no matter where he was. Funeral arrangements are private. A memorial event to celebrate his life will be held at a future date. Contributions is his name can be made to Hospice Care Network in Westbury, LI, or The Alumni Association Scholarship Fund of City College.

title: Yerba Buena: A Blend of Jazz, Funk, Cuban and African Music
description: The route of Yoruban culture to the New World from Africa did not go only one way. The Cuban son was popular in the Congo in the 1930's and 40's; the sources of James Brown's and Fela's funk rhythms are impossibly intertwined. And with the rise of cheap recording technology, everyone listens to everything. So why shouldn't it be possible to triply superimpose American funk on Afro-Cuban music on Nigerian Afrobeat and let different kinds of Yoruban-derived music seep into one another?

title: Mayoral Control of the Schools
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani began a major push this month to eliminate New York City's dysfunctional Board of Education. Mr. Giuliani, whose term of office ends in a year, wants the State Legislature to abolish the board so that the next mayor will have full responsibility for the largest school system in the country. That makes sense, given that the school system has been performing poorly and yet no one can be held directly accountable by the voters. The current seven-member board, which is appointed by six different political leaders, diffuses authority and hides the blame for the system's failings. The mayor got it right recently when he said, ''If you were running a business, you would invent this system if you didn't want it to be successful.''

title: Xerox Fumbles in Age of Printer
description: Long before the computer revolutionized the office, the Xerox copier had conquered the workplace. In less than a generation, carbon paper went from ubiquitous to almost unheard of, and Xerox became one of the great success stories of American business. But with computer printers taking over many of the tasks once reserved for copiers, and Xerox stumbling in its efforts to produce competitive products, the company has run into hard times. By this month, the company's bond rating had been cut to junk level, the price of its stock had fallen to a 20-year low and it was scrambling to sell assets in order to raise cash.

title: Hanging Up on Phone Auctions
description: Lured by the hope of huge profits in a wireless world, companies lined up to bid for the rights to European mobile telephone licenses. More than $100 billion was raised by governments selling nothing but the right to be in business, with most of the money going to Germany and Britain. Actually building the systems would cost many billions more before any revenue arrived from the new systems, which would still have to compete with existing mobile phone franchises. Then reality set in. As lenders grew more cautious about financing, some telecommunications companies pulled out of bidding at later auctions, while others formed joint ventures. Italy collected only half the $20 billion it expected, and Switzerland, which hoped to raise $3.5 billion selling four new licenses, had just four bidders, or one for each license. It took in $120 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, VELVERT
description: TURNER-Velvert. A noted musician and former understudy of Jimi Hendrix, passed away on the morning of December 11, 2000, at his home in Brooklyn, New York. Velvert was born October 12, 1951, and is survived by his mother, Helen Harris. Mr. Turner was an accomplished guitarist who crossed paths with Jimi Hendrix as a young teenager growing up in New York City in 1966. He was befriended by Hendrix, who recognized the young scholar's passion for the electric guitar. The legendary guitarist served as a mentor to Mr. Turner, offering both guitar instruction and professional advice to the young musician. Following Hendrix's death in September, 1970, Mr. Turner pursued his own musical career, forming the Velvert Turner Group with Prescott Niles and Tim McGovern. He continued to tour and record for almost two decades. In recent years, Mr. Turner was employed by Samaritan Village in Brooklyn, New York. His efforts on behalf of those struggling with substance abuse made a significant difference in the lives of countless people. A memorial service for Mr. Turner is scheduled for 10 AM, Tuesday, December 19, at Armstrong Funeral Home, 822 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, his family asks that donations be sent to Experience Hendrix, PO Box 58070, Seattle, WA 98138-1070. These donations will be offered to area charities supported by Mr. Turner.

title: The Fed at a Crossroads

Since June 1999, the Fed has raised its benchmark interest rate to 6.5 percent from 4.75 percent. title: PlayStation Shortage Plagues Sony
description: Analysts had forecast that Sony's new PlayStation 2 video game console might be in short supply during the holiday season, even if the Japanese consumer products and entertainment giant met its goal of having one million units ready for the splashy rollout at the end of October. But when production snags forced Sony to enter the market with just half that many machines, many a gamer went home empty-handed. While some enterprising Web surfers were able to profit by finding and then reselling scarce PlayStation 2's online, analysts said the shortfall during the holiday season could lop $200 million off Sony's revenues for the quarter.

title: The Strained European Union
description: The clash of national jealousies the Continent had supposedly overcome may be slowing the process of European integration. That is the one clear fact that emerged from the recent European Union summit at Nice. Absent the forceful leadership and ambitious vision of Helmut Kohl, Francois Mitterrand and some of their other predecessors, Europe's heads of state stumbled away from the negotiating table after five days of talks with a disappointingly modest treaty in hand. The union's failure to undertake ambitious reforms will impede it from fulfilling its aspiration to become an effective diplomatic and economic counterweight to the United States on the global scene.

title: Coping at Coke
description: The swath of changes at the Coca-Cola Company this year has been wide. Stepping in as chief executive in February at a time when soda sales languished and Coke's stock was at its lowest point in more than three years, Douglas N. Daft laid off about 18 percent of the staff. He then named new leaders in nearly all of the company's 26 divisions and pronounced the end of Coke's centralized culture. The changes led to employee defections and sagging investor confidence. Mr. Daft has since worked to restore faith in the company by raising salaries and resolving a racial discrimination lawsuit. At $192 million, the settlement is the largest of its kind. The company also considered buying Quaker Oats, but Coke's board rescinded the offer. Its rival, Pepsico, then struck a Quaker deal.

title: When Roller-Coaster Ride Finally Ends, Knicks Are in the Front Seat
description: The shot would either tie the score and give the Knicks a chance to salvage a terribly inconsistent performance or it would seal a loss that would presumably send Coach Jeff Van Gundy's team reeling into further dysfunction and depression. So Erick Strickland, a reserve guard who had missed all five of his field-goal attempts, was not the man the Knicks wanted their fate resting on.

title: At Firestone, Recall, Then Inquiry
description: When Bridgestone/Firestone announced the recall of 6.5 million tires on Aug. 9, it set off a panic. Most of the tires had been installed as original equipment on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, and Explorer owners mobbed tire dealers across the nation. Firestone, a unit of Bridgestone of Japan, initially said it would take a year to replace the tires. But ample supplies of tires became available by the end of November. By Dec. 6, regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had received complaints of 148 deaths linked to Firestone ATX and Wilderness tires of various sizes. The safety agency said it would try to wrap up its investigation by February or March.

title: No Rest at G.E.
description: Who says that old, big companies are static by definition? General Electric -- around for 120 years, with sales that topped $111 billion last year -- saw as much change in 2000 as any new-economy player. For one thing, it got a whole lot bigger by snatching up Honeywell International out from under United Technologies. And John F. Welch Jr., G.E.'s forceful leader, annointed Jeffrey R. Immelt, the head of GE Medical Systems, his successor, a change expected at the end of 2001. Mr. Immelt declined to say how his reign might differ from Mr. Welch's, but he did say it will be the same in one major way: ''Jack drove change, and I will drive change.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHARD, ROBERT M.
description: BLANCHARD-Robert M. Born June 4, 1924, in Syracuse, NY; son of Isaac Monroe and Frances Snow. Robert graduated from The Taft School and from William College. He served in the United States Marine Corps in World War II. Robert worked on Wall Street as an Analyst for Henderson Harrison. His dream was to fly. Robert earned his Pilot's License and flew all over the country. He flew a Steerman Biplane and later a single engine ''V'' tailed Beach Craft. Robert wintered in Palm Beach, FL, where he passed away on December 16, 2000. He was predeceased by his wife Barbara Gaylord Blanchard. Robert is survived by his wife Maureen Blanchard. A memorial service will be held at a later date at The Royal Poinciana Chapel with Dr. Richard Cromie officiating. Those who wish to make contributions may send them to The Royal Poinciana Chapel, 60 Cocoanut Row, Palm Beach, Florida 33480.

title: The End of the Imperial Presidency
description: Since the moment President-elect Bush finished his acceptance speech in Austin on Wednesday night, his allies and advisers have spoken frankly about the limits that the close election and a divided Congress may impose on the new leader's compassionately conservative agenda.

title: Following Tough Loss, the Jets Take a Hard Look at Unity
description: The startling thing about the Jets' 10-7 loss to the Detroit Lions yesterday was the direction of the discussion afterward, starting at the top with Coach Al Groh, and the feel that filtered throughout the Jets' locker room.

title: A Long Day Of Injuries
description: The most devastating injury to the Jets today was to Bryan Cox, who will have surgery on his broken right leg Monday. He is lost for the season.

title: Unusual Knockout Ending: After the Victory, the Deluge
description: When two strong teams meet in the final of a knockout event, it is rare for one team to gain as many as 30 imps in the final segment of play. The Senior Knockout Teams at the Fall Nationals in Birmingham, Ala., last month, however, produced the bridge equivalent of the Johnstown Flood.

title: The Electors Vote, and the Surprises Are Few
description: As President-elect George W. Bush visited Washington today, he captured a majority of the votes that really count, those of the Electoral College.

title: 40 Miles From Mexico City, Volcano Spews Rocks and Ash
description: A volatile volcano outside this capital of nearly 20 million people erupted with plumes of lava tonight, hours after tens of thousands of people living near the volcano ignored the government's pleas to evacuate.

title: Firestone Engineers Offer a List of Causes for Faulty Tires
description: Offering their explanation for one of the most puzzling auto safety mysteries in decades, Firestone engineers today blamed a unique combination of tire and vehicle design, tire manufacturing and customer abuse for tire failures linked to the deaths of more than 100 Americans, almost all in Ford Explorers.

title: VNU AGREES TO BUY ACNIELSEN FOR $2.3 BILLION
description: VNU N. V. said it had agreed to buy the ACNielsen Corporation, the market research company, for $2.3 billion in cash, or $36.75 a share, a 49 percent premium to ACNielsen's closing price Friday. The move would reunite ACNielsen with its former corporate sibling, Nielsen Media Research Inc., which compiles television and radio ratings; VNU bought the ratings company for $2.7 billion last year. VNU, based in Haarlem, the Netherlands, said it planned to sell its educational and consumer publishing units and issue new stock, and use the proceeds to pay for ACNielsen. VNU also publishes Billboard and other trade publications, and telephone directories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGHEIMER, ALAN J.
description: BURGHEIMER-Alan J. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Alan J. Burgheimer, on November 24 and extend belated condolences to his family. Paul N. Gardner, President

title: Buccaneers Extend Their Season And Push the Rams to the Brink
description: Tampa Bay running back Warrick Dunn did not score four touchdowns tonight, as his St. Louis counterpart, Marshall Faulk, did. But he did something more important: he won the game and put his team into the playoffs.

title: G.M. TO PARE BACK VEHICLE LINES TO REDUCE ITS COSTS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate one-fifth of its car and light-truck models by 2004 to further reduce costs, after announcing last week that it would phase out the Oldsmobile brand and about 15,000 jobs. One of the three G.M. minivans will be among those eliminated, a spokeswoman said. The plan will reduce G.M.'s line to 63 to 67 vehicles; a decade ago the company offered 115.

title: Ohnesorg to Leave Carnegie Hall for Berlin Philharmonic
description: After months of change and turmoil at Carnegie Hall, the institution's executive director, Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, suddenly announced his resignation today to take the top administrative post at the Berlin Philharmonic.

title: Aetna to Shed Customers and Jobs In Effort to Cut Health Care Costs
description: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that it would shed two million of its 19 million customers over the next year as it raises premium charges and struggles to make its troubled managed care business more profitable.

title: NEW CHAIRWOMAN AT LUCENT SPINOFF
description: Avaya, the office-networking unit that Lucent Technologies spun off in September, named Patricia F. Russo chairwoman, replacing Henry Schacht who stepped down in October to become chairman and chief executive of Lucent. Ms. Russo, 47, had been executive vice president and chief executive of Lucent's service-provider networks group.

title: Prelude to a Missile Defense
description: The incoming Bush administration risks making an early mistake if it rushes to build a national missile defense. A hasty move in this area could quickly deplete the good will generally accorded a new president by foreign leaders, especially those of Russia, China and Washington's main European allies. George W. Bush should instead expand research and testing to determine what kind of defensive shield can best meet America's security needs.

description: ISLAND

description: Sluggish sales, price markdowns and the cost of remodeling stores wiped out profits for the Circuit City Group, a major retailer of consumer electronics, in its third fiscal quarter, the company said.

title: Parthenon Next, Watch the Closing Doors
description: Few public works projects have stirred as much anxiety among archaeologists as the ambitious effort to ease traffic congestion by building a subway system in this city where civilizations have been layered upon one another for 3,000 years.

title: Penn Station Needs Millions For Repairs
description: Federal transportation inspectors said yesterday that it would take 30 years to correct fire and safety deficiencies in the tunnels that serve Pennsylvania Station unless $898 million can be found to speed up the work. Even then, the inspectors said, the alterations could not be completed before 2010.

description: With Hanukkah and Christmas lights, fires in the hearth and colorful candles around the house, there are worries that these seasonal delights might also be sources of disaster.

description: MANZELLA-Onofrio H. (Freddie). On December 14, 2000. Predeceased by his first wife, Mary Litrell. Survived by second wife, Christiane, and daughter Lenore and her husband William Frick. description: Cellular telephones may be an increasingly popular convenience in the United States and other prosperous countries. But demand is growing even faster in the world's poor nations, including in Haiti, where wireless phones are considered a necessity for those who can afford them.

description: Does using a hiking pole actually help backpackers, or do they just feel as if it is easier? Both, researchers from the University of Massachusetts say.

title: Metro Business Briefing; M.T.A. SET FOR HYBRID BUS ORDER
description: At a meeting today, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to approve an order for 200 hybrid electric buses that will be used in the five boroughs, Gov. George E. Pataki announced in a written statement yesterday. New York City Transit already operates 10 such buses, the largest fleet of electric buses in the country, said Albert O'Leary, a spokesman for the transit agency. He said 130 others were already scheduled for delivery next year, when the transit agency plans to increase bus service by 5 percent. The 200 new buses, whose electric power is replenished by small diesel motors, would be delivered in 2003. Mr. O'Leary said that the hybrid buses burn at least as cleanly as buses fueled by compressed natural gas, and as new technology is developed, their diesel motors could be replaced by even cleaner fuel cells. The new buses, which will cost $77 million, will be built in New York State by Orion Bus Industries in Oriskany and BAE Systems in Johnson City. ''These buses will pay important health dividends by dramatically reducing bus emissions on the streets of New York, while helping provide good-paying jobs upstate,'' Mr. Pataki said, calling the purchase the largest order of hybrid electric buses in North America. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Europe Panel Plans Accounting Rules
description: The European Commission began debate today on a set of proposed rules to prevent conflicts of interest at firms that offer both accounting and consulting services, an issue that the Securities and Exchange Commission is also wrestling with in the United States.

title: Gillette Plans To Reduce Work Force By 2,700
description: Gillette said yesterday that it would shut down 8 factories and 13 distribution centers and lay off 2,700 employees, about 8 percent of its work force.

title: FILTERING PROGRAMS CONTESTED
description: A little-noted provision in the last-minute spending bill passed last week by Congress would require all schools and libraries that receive federal aid for Internet service to use filtering programs or other technology to protect minors from seeing adult materials online. The American Civil Liberties Union did notice, however, and yesterday said it would file suit to declare the law unconstitutional. The law has become a censorship effort that directly affects adults, said Ann Beeson, a lawyer with the group. John Schwartz

With the dismantling of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the end of the cold war, people predicted that he would have nothing more to write about. description: The shares of OfficeMax Inc., the office-supply retailer that has been retrenching to stem losses, shot up by a third after analysts and a hedge-fund manager said the company's assets are worth more than its market value. Shares of OfficeMax, which had fallen 70 percent in the last year, gained 88 cents, to close at $2.69. OfficeMax has shut down its money-losing computer business and plans to close unprofitable stores.

description: POPPER-Felix. New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of one of its most beloved and august members. Felix has been a member of the company since 1959, as an administrator, conductor, coach and mentor. He was Music Administrator for over thirty years, and a principal part of the team responsible for many of City Opera's major successes. Long before the creation of apprentice programs, Felix was a professional and personal mentor to several generations of young singers at the City Opera and at the many schools in which he worked. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCY, ODETTA (GREER)
description: BUCY-Odetta (Greer), was born on October 25, 1931, on a farm in Grassland, Texas, 11 miles east of Tahoka, to her parents Wesley Robert Greer and Nannie Josephine Bargsley Greer and passed away on December 15, 2000. In addition to helping with the chores on the farm, she also enjoyed athletics, becoming the captain of her high school basketball team. She first caught the eye of her future husband, J. Fred Bucy, Jr., when she was nine years old and he was twelve. He sold her a double dip ice cream cone for half price at a nickel at the drug store where he worked. They married six years later and supported each other by farming before heading off to college at Texas Tech. They then moved to the University of Texas in Austin where he obtained his Master's Degree and she attended college. Upon his graduation, they moved to Dallas to begin her husband's career at Texas Instruments. While raising and nurturing three children, she also supported her husband in his career as he rose to become president and CEO of Texas Instruments. While living in West Texas, Austin, Houston and Dallas, Odetta made lifelong friends that are devoted to her to this day. She traveled around the world many times but was never happier than at home or combing the beach in Port Aransas for shark's teeth with her children and eventually grandchildren. She took the greatest joy in life whether bowling with her girlfriends, sailing through the Bahamas or beating her family in games of Scrabble. Her joy in life was tested when she was struck with cancer at the age of 60. Though her doctors believed she had only six months to live, her spirit and determination and the devotion of her husband, gave the gift of nine beautiful years to her family and friends. She was able to win her battle with cancer, but finally succumbed to a weakened heart. Even during her illness, she lived her life with joy and enthusiasm, never showing a hint of despair or regret. She showed us how to live life to the fullest and how to leave this world with the utmost dignity and grace. She leaves behind her husband of 54 years, J. Fred Bucy, Jr; her son, J. Fred Bucy, III, two daughters, Roxanne Coogan and Diane Gruber; two sons-in-law, Keith Coogan and Mike Gruber; six grandchildren, Joshua Bucy, Patrick Coogan, Michael Gruber, Becky Gruber, and Chris Gruber, a sister, Opal Greer Ray and many nieces and nephews. We will miss her dearly. Services will be 10:30 AM, Wednesday December 20, 2000 in the Main Sanctuary at Lovers Lane United Methodist Church, 9200 Inwood Road, Dallas, Texas, Rev. Ed Robb officiating. Interment to follow at Restland Memorial Park. Donations may be made to The American Lung Association, 8150 Brookriver Drive, Suite S-102 (LB151), Dallas, Texas 75247, The University of Texas Southwestern Medical School Foundation, #

title: The Big City; When Crutch For Education Is an Anchor
