description: In this village tucked away among terraced hills and olive groves, 17-year-old Muhammad Shalash was remembered today as an ace high school student who wanted to earn a college degree and go to America.

title: Bikes, Jeeps and Horses Help to Solve a Mystery of the Amazon
description: The search for the source of the Nile, the world's longest river, inspired heroic explorations into the African interior by the British in the 19th century. They eventually learned that at its most distant reaches, the Nile flows out of Lake Victoria, in what is now Tanzania.

title: From Under His Other Hat, A Conductor's Night of Firsts

title: Sites Suggested for Washington's Next Memorials
description: There are 228 memorials and museums in Washington, roughly one for each year since the federal government moved here in 1800, and a federal panel today came up with the proposed sites for the next 102, which should suffice for the next century.

description: ESPN had a plan: find an agent who would let its cameras record contract negotiations from the inside for the Sunday morning program ''Outside the Lines.''

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY MORGAN KEEGAN
description: The Regions Financial Corporation, a bank holding company based in Birmingham, Ala., agreed to buy Morgan Keegan, a securities brokerage firmbased in Memphis, for $789 million, or $27 a share, in cash or stock at the shareholder's option. At Friday's closing prices, the offer represented a premium of 39 percent. To retain key Morgan Keegan employees, Regions will establish a bonus pool of 5.55 million stock options. Many of Morgan Keegan's 600 retail brokers are in Southeastern states where Regions already has offices. After the merger, which is expected to close in the first three months of 2001, Regions will have 961 brokers in 14 states.

title: The Neediest Cases; Looking For a Home And Feeling At Home

description: RORIMER-Katherine Serrell. 92, died December 17. Widow of James J. Rorimer, Director of The Metropolitan Museum of Art until 1966, she is survived by her children, Anne of Chicago and Louis of Cleveland; and grandchildren, Sarah and Jim. After graduating from Wellesley College and the Institute of Fine Arts, NYU, she worked in the Library at The Metropolitan Museum. She was also a researcher at the Index of Christian Art, Princeton. She was active in cultural and environmental affairs and, at age 90, published her first novel, ''Leave It to Me''. She will be missed for her idealism and humor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art or Scenic Hudson, Inc., 7 Vassar St., Poughkeepsie, NY 12601. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

title: Bank Shares Are Sold
description: The German states of Hesse and Thuringia said they had agreed to buy stakes in a regional savings bank that they had sold a decade ago. Hesse will buy 10 percent of Landesbank Hessen-Thueringen for 600 million marks ($274.8 million) and Thuringia will pay 300 million marks for a stake half that size. The bank, known as Helaba and based in Frankfurt, employs 3,000 and clears the transactions of other banks based in the two states. After years of privatization, the states are looking for ways to benefit from expansion at provincial savings banks. The European Union has criticized German states' continued ownership of stakes in banks.

title: Verizon Opts To Withdraw Application
description: Verizon Communications Inc. withdrew its application to offer long-distance communications services in Massachusetts yesterday, fearful that the petition would be rejected by federal regulators.

title: Jets Have Little to Say and a Lot to Do
description: It was a subdued Al Groh who today sifted through the wreckage of his team's collapse against Detroit, one that could very well cost the Jets a spot in the playoffs. In a virtually deserted locker room, the few players who appeared spoke quietly about how they were not intimidated by playoff-bound Baltimore, next Sunday's opponent, but merely possessed a healthy respect for a Ravens defense that will try to set a league record for fewest points allowed in a regular season.

title: TAX MAGICIANS/A special report.; Sham Shelters for Business Flourish as Scrutiny Fades

title: Growth in Tourism to Slow With Economy, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and tourism officials said yesterday they expected the sharp growth in the number of tourists to New York City to slow next year amid signs of a cooling national economy, but held that tourism remains robust and a driving force in the city's economy.

title: A Judge Who Wears His Heart on His Robe
description: A MAN'S inner life is always betrayed by his bookshelf. On Judge Edward R. Korman's, ''The History of the Supreme Court'' sits next to ''The Power of Nice.''

title: RED HERRING LAYS OFF 32
description: Red Herring Communications said it was cutting 32 jobs, or 9.4 percent of its work force, as it closes an office in Cupertino, Calif., and combines its online and magazine editorial departments. The company, which publishes the business and technology magazine Red Herring, is cutting 7 editorial jobs and 25 engineering and programming jobs, a spokesman, Andy Plesser, said.

title: DEAL FOR SPANISH DIRECTORIES
description: France Telecom's Internet unit, Wanadoo, said it had agreed to buy the Spanish directory publisher Indice Multimedia for up to 360 million euros, or $323 million. Wanadoo, whose share price has fallen by half since it went public in July, will initially pay 80 million euros in cash and issue new stock worth 232 million euros, giving Indice's owners a 2.3 percent stake in Wanadoo; it may pay up to 58 million additional euros later depending on performance. Earlier this month, Wanadoo agreed to acquire Freeserve of Britain for $2.4 billion in stock. Benjamin Jones

title: Budget Bill Jump-Starts Jazz Museum In Harlem
description: Deep in the spending bill passed by Congress last week is a $1 million appropriation for a matching grant that smooths the way for construction of a jazz museum in Harlem, a project that has the support of a variety of musicians, jazz patrons, politicians and community leaders.

title: The Case for the Electoral College
description: As the 538 members of the Electoral College met yesterday to ratify George W. Bush's razor-thin 271-to-266 victory (one Al Gore elector abstained), many Americans continued to question the system that awarded Mr. Bush the White House despite the vice president's 337,000-vote margin in the popular vote. A recent Washington Post/ABC News poll suggested that about 6 in 10 Americans would prefer to abandon the Electoral College and switch to a direct popular vote. Among others, New York's senator-elect, Hillary Rodham Clinton, has condemned the present system and promised to co-sponsor legislation abolishing it and providing for the direct election of the president. That would be a mistake. The Electoral College has enough benefits to justify its survival.

title: Got Game. And Pen. And Mentor.
description: First the good news. ''Finding Forrester,'' the latest in a rising tide of shameless male weepies, does not star that leaky human bucket of crocodile tears, Robin Williams, who helped pioneer the genre. The title role of the cranky but good-hearted mentor to a gifted teenager from the South Bronx is played by Sean Connery, an actor known for keeping an extremely tight lid on his tear ducts.

description: After decades in which researchers concerned about teenage pregnancy focused only on intercourse, a study by the Urban Institute, financed by the federal government, provides the first national data on the sexual practices of 15- to 19-year-old boys.

title: SMITH BARNEY TAKES FULL CONTROL OF KOREAN UNIT
description: The Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup said it took full control of its Seoul-based securities unit, buying the remaining 20 percent held by its partner, Korea Exchange Bank. Financial terms were not disclosed. Korea Exchange Bank controlled 51 percent of the venture, which has more than 100 employees, when it was set up in 1996, but its stake has been trimmed since then. Like most of Korea's banking industry, the bank is struggling with a flood of bad debts, but unlike many competitors, it has won regulatory approval to remain independent.

title: I.M.F. Plans Billions in Aid to Argentina
description: The International Monetary Fund and private banks today promised as much as $39.7 billion to help Argentina reduce its growing debt burden, pep up its economy and stem a crisis of confidence that some economists worry could spread through Latin America.

title: Running Game Is Key for Playoffs
description: The offensive complexion of this season was colored by the St. Louis Rams. Teams asked: Can our offense do anything the way the Rams did when they became Super Bowl champions? Can we go over the top, stretch defenses, emphasize the vertical passing game and back defenses up to open rushing lanes?

title: F.T.C. APPROVES MERGER OF GLAXO AND SMITHKLINE
description: The merger of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. won clearance from the Federal Trade Commission, which required the companies to sell off overlapping product rights in nine drug markets but deferred a decision on a 10th, products to help smokers quit, for up to 30 days. Analysts saw little likelihood that any of the combined company's three quit-smoking products, Nicorette, Nicoderm and Zyban, would ultimately have to be sold. Buyers have already been lined up for other overlapping products, including the antacid Zantac 75. That brand will be sold to Pfizer, which already markets it in the United States.

title: The Accidental Electors
description: It would be comforting, the day after the Electoral College has given us a president who did not win the popular vote, to think that this system of electing presidents was an essential part of the grand design of the United States Constitution. But the Electoral College was cobbled together nearly at the last minute and adopted not because the framers believed it would work, but because it was less objectionable to them than two more obvious alternatives: election of the president by the people or by Congress.

title: Some Graduation Losses, but No Defeats for the Spartans
description: Since his Michigan State basketball team won the national championship last season, Coach Tom Izzo remarked that the demands on him have been greater. Endless interviews. People hanging on his every word. ''I'd sure like to have that problem again,'' Izzo recently said in a conference call.

title: CMGI AND EMC FORM A PACT

title: The Traditionalist's Hit Parade

Like Talbots, which has also shifted its focus, Brooks Brothers now attracts legions of customers who have never used ''summer'' as a verb; it has even gone so far in its efforts at democratization as to issue a CD featuring the music of Santana.

title: In Maya Ruins, Scholars See Evidence of Urban Sprawl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'INZILLO, STEVE
description: D'INZILLO-Steve. We the family, the siblings, of Steve D'Inzillo, mourn the loss of our beloved brother. His sensitivity, caring and love for us have been an abiding source of pride and example. Those same sentiments he dedicated to the larger world of work and country. He entered the work world early, interesting himself in the needs and problems of working people, knowing the necessity and broad social benefit of better working conditions for them and for the country. For the good of the country and the justness of the cause, he joined the Army during World War II, at the age of 37, contributing to the freedom effort as a skilled glider pilot. Upon discharge, he returned both to the movie industry and the union movement that he loved so much. With his protean energy and unique determination, he achieved much in the struggle for dignified wages and working conditions for all workers including women, minorities and the foreign born. In April of 2000, at age 90, he retired as president of local 306 of the International Alliance of Theatrical and State Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators of the United States and Canada (IATSE). For many years, his siblings, friends and union associates have enjoyed his gentle friendship, his great courage, and his extraordinary vision and dedication. He is remembered well and well will he be missed. Steve D Inzillo. July 17, 1910 -October 13, 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELANEY, EDMUND T.
description: DELANEY-Edmund T. Of Gorham Rd, Chester, CT. died Sunday (December 17), was a retired lawyer and an historian, lecturer and author of 5 books on regional history of New York and Connecticut: ''New York's Turtle Bay'' (1965), ''New York's Greenwich Village'', (1968), ''The Connecticut Shore'' (1970), ''A Photographic Guide to Greenwich Village'' (1976) with Charles Lockwood, ''The Connecticut River-New England's Historic Waterway'' (1983) and various articles in newspapers and magazines. He also edited and arranged Life in the Connecticut River Valley 1800-1840 based upon the recollections of John Howard Redfield. Receiving his secondary education in France and England, he graduated from Princeton University in 1933 and Harvard Law School in 1936. Mr. Delaney practiced law for over forty years in New York and Connecticut where he was most recently a partner of the New London and Essex firm of Copp, Kolestsky and Berall from which he retired in 1978. He was a member of the American Bar Assoc. and the Connecticut Bar Assoc. While in New York, he was a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York where he served as Chairman of the Committees on Corporate Law, Law and Medicine and the Committee on Art. He specialized on investment Company Law and served for 39 years as a director of the Oppenheimer Funds. He has been active in civic and community affairs over the past thirty years serving at various times as President of the Chester Historical Society, President of the Chester Rotary Club, trustee of the Connecticut River Watershed Council in Easthampton, Mass., & as a member of the Connecticut Historical Commission in Hartford. He was also a trustee of the Connecticut River Museum in Essex & active in the Rockfall Foundation in Middletown. He was involved in town affairs as Chairman of the Conservation Commission, as a member of the Town Retirement Board and as a Justice of the Peace. He represented Chester at the 3-1/2 Celebration of the Saybrook Colony in 1985 and was Chairman of the Chester Sesquicentennial Committee in 1986. Mr. Delaney was a member of Saint Joseph's Church in Chester, the history of which he wrote in 1991, St. Joseph's Parish-More than a Century of Faith. Long interested in historic preservation and conservation, he was a member of the historical societies of Deep River, Essex, and Lyme, of the Antiques and Landmarks Society and the National and Connecticut Preservation Trusts and Nature Conservancies. After serving in the Squardron A Cavalry of the New York National Guard, he went on active duty in the Field Artillery in 1940, graduating from the Field Artillery School at Fort Sill, OK., and serving as battery commander in the 105th Field Artillery. In 1941, he was transferred to the Military Intelligence Service on the General Staff in Washington where he became a Lieutenant Colonel and Chief on the Western European Branch and French Specialist in G-2 of the War Department General Staff. He accompanied Assistant Secretary of War John J. Mac Eloy on a special mission to North Africa in 1943. In 1945, he became Acting Counsel to the Army-Navy Liquidation Commission in Paris. He received three War Department Citations, the Army Commendation Ribbon and the French Medaille de la Reconnaissance Francaise. He married Barbara Snow in 1965 and has two children from an earlier marriage; Topher Delaney of San Francisco and Nick Delaney of Seattle and five grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother William of Reno, Nevada and a sister, Vivian Perez of Nerja, Spain and six nieces and nephews.

description: The Federal Reserve said today that it was shifting its sights from fighting inflation to steering the economy away from a possible recession, emphasizing in blunt language a number of problems that could derail the decade-long expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, PATRICIA A.
description: HERMANN-Patricia A. New York City School Teacher and Asst Principal for 22 years. Died of lung cancer on December 18, 2000, four days after her 57th birthday in Vieques, Puerto Rico, where she lived for the past seven years. Wife of Lou Yager, Sister of Susan Hermann Ginsberg and Donald Ginsberg; Aunt of Cristopher and Nicholas Goodman, Daughter of the late Sylvia and Dr. Nathaniel R. Hermann. She was a unique and brilliant character whose love of teaching was only surpassed by her love of Puerto Rico and its culture. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., she graduated from the Berkeley Institute, attended Cornell University and graduated cum laude from New York University, where she also attained a Master's degree in English. Her diminutive size did not impede her boundless energy and commitment to working with at risk youths. ''Ms Hermann'' worked at FDR High School in Brooklyn as an English teacher, Asst Principal and Dean of Students. After retiring from teaching in 1987, she pursued a career in fashion as a manufacturer and retailer of Balinese-inspired clothing. She could be seen with her flaming red hair at the street fairs on Columbus Ave and the Jacob Javits Center. Her Bali Llama stores on the Island of Vieques were the first of their kind. Everyone who knew Patricia will remember her for her creative visions, strong individuality and mostly for the love of the people she lived with. She was truly a Puerto Rican at heart, and up until her last days, fought tirelessly for Paz Para Vieques. Descanse En Paz. A celebration of her life will take place at a later date.

Each company will have a 50 percent stake in the venture, which will start production in early 2003.

description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he would soon establish an exploratory committee for a possible campaign for mayor and that he was planning to raise money for a number of candidates running for offices in next year's municipal elections.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Reinventing an Icon of a Grand Old Philadelphia
description: With all the icons at its command, from the Liberty Bell to cheese-steak sandwiches to capering Mummer bands, there reigns at the heart of this city a towering, peerless hulk of a municipal symbol, City Hall, where, after 100 years, the roof leaks, the old grandeur wheezes and self-government has become a cavernous, patchwork thing.

Aventis owns 52 percent of Dade Behring, which is based in Deerfield, Ill.; Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, Bain Capital and executives of Dade Behring own the rest. In November, Dade Behring said it was exploring a possible sale of the company.

His glass bottles designed for major products, including Listerine and Murphy's soap, are utilized today and were featured in an article in Smithsonian Magazine. This beloved, kind, spiritual, gentle man with quiet dignity and special humor will be missed by his many friends and associates. description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate more than 1,300 union jobs, or 5 percent of its hourly work force, and was considering laying off managers for the first time in 15 years. Norfolk Southern has been trying to cut costs in the 18 months since it divided Conrail with the CSX Corporation, leading to traffic snarls and delays. The high cost of fuel and the falling volume of freight made cost-cutting more urgent, the company said. Earlier eliminations of management jobs were carried out through voluntary early-retirement offers. Norfolk Southern shares rose 13 cents, to $13.44.

But her publisher would have to sell the better part of two million copies to make back the advance, and there's a good chance that buyers hungry for a tell-all memoir aren't going to find it in this book.

title: AT&T SPINOFF QUESTIONED
description: The largest cable television provider, AT&T, was asked to clarify how it intends to comply with conditions stemming from its $44 billion purchase of the MediaOne Group. On Friday, AT&T said it would spin off Liberty Media to comply with restrictions on cable ownership, provided it receives a favorable tax ruling on the transaction. The Federal Communications Commission said in a letter to AT&T that ''it is not clear'' if the spinoff was acceptable because it ''is not an irrevocable commitment.'' But the F.C.C. said an alternative plan, to sell or put in trust AT&T's 25.5 percent stake in Time Warner Entertainment if the Liberty spinoff tax ruling was unfavorable, seemed acceptable.

The company's new 20-inch model will go on sale in Japan in January for about $1,960, one-third less than current models, and will be available in other countries beginning in May. Pate a choux is the buttery, eggy dough so familiar when it shows up in the form of eclairs and cream puffs. Otherwise, these days, we hardly ever see it. It seems antique, too traditional. But food trends often run in cycles, and anything this good will get its chance again.

title: EMI BUYS DUTCH LABEL
description: The EMI Group said it had agreed to buy 75 percent of Dino Music, a Dutch independent record label founded by a former pirate radio disk jockey, Tony Berk. Financial details were not disclosed. EMI said it also had an option to acquire the rest of Dino, a leader in a market that is turning increasingly to domestic artists and away from international fare.

description: Five Orange police officers were convicted in federal court here today of beating and pepper-spraying an innocent man who died in police custody during a mistake-riddled investigation into the shooting death of a policewoman.

description: Nobody has ordered a new nuclear plant in this country in more than 20 years, but rising demand for electricity and prices for natural gas are forestalling extinction and giving aging reactors a new lease on life. Consider Vermont Yankee, on the banks of the Connecticut River here.

title: Proceed With Purpose, Scales and Arpeggios Flying

He is by any measure one of the truly extraordinary pianists before the public, although in his case ''before the public'' is a relative term. But there he was on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall playing all 12 of Liszt's ''Transcendental Etudes.'' Then, I suppose it was back to the suburbs of Boston, where he lives and teaches. Who knows when we shall hear him again?

Our deepest sympathies are with her family at this sad time. Carlyle Slade will be remembered by all of us with great affection.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose as cold weather keeps demand high for gas, the leading heating fuel. In New York, natural gas for January delivery rose 57.5 cents, or 6.7 percent, to $9.102 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Of Huge Signs, Lamentations And Rezoning

That's an acronym for Lively Artistic Wall Signs, an association of property owners, graphic designers and printers who make good money from -- what else? -- lively artistic wall signs.

title: In a Nod to Slower Economy, SBC Cuts Earnings Forecast
description: SBC Communications, the nation's second-largest provider of local telephone service, lowered its forecasts yesterday for sales and earnings next year in a sign of how the slowing economy is beginning to affect large telecommunications companies.

Then the outgoing chief executive flies to Andrews Air Force Base for his last ride home on Air Force One, which is redesignated ''Special Air Mission,'' since the president is not on board.

description: BP Amoco and Solvay, the giant Belgian chemical maker, have agreed to exchange plastics businesses with about 2.9 billion euros ($2.6 billion) in sales. BP Amoco will get Solvay's polypropylene unit to add to its petrochemicals business, while Solvay will get BP's engineering polymers business. Under the agreement, the two companies will form American and European joint ventures to make high-density polypropylene. Financial details were not disclosed.

description: Shemsi Salihu, 71, and his wife, Emine, recently came back to their home here after five months spent as refugees, living among their fellow Albanians over the nearby provincial border in Kosovo.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CUOMO DEFENDS HUD
description: Speaking publicly for the first time about the recent schemes that have left hundreds of federally insured buildings in Harlem and other poor New York neighborhoods in default, Andrew M. Cuomo, the secretary of housing and urban development, said yesterday that his agency had acted aggressively to reduce fraud. ''There's always going to be a certain amount of fraud,'' he said. ''What you try to do is reduce it as much as possible.'' Last week, Susan Gaffney, the HUD inspector general, said the agency had cut its staff for single-family home programs in half and could no longer monitor when properties were ''flipped'' -- bought and quickly resold at an inflated price. Responding to the criticism, Mr. Cuomo said: ''I don't believe that this was a staffing issue. This was a fraud issue. We were lied to.''

title: Airbus Clears Plans to Build Long-Range Jumbo Jet
description: Challenging the monopoly of Boeing on planes that can carry more than 400 passengers, the European Airbus group formally gave the green light today for a gigantic double-decker jumbo jet to be known as the A380. It is planned for use on long-distance routes like those between Asia and Europe or the United States.

title: BREAKING UP WITH A BIG GAIN
description: France Telecom sold its 1.8 percent stake in Deutsche Telekom to a bank owned by the German government for 3.1 billion euros ($2.8 billion) or 56.2 euros a share. The price represents a 58 percent premium to the company's closing stock price Monday, and is nearly three times what France Telecom paid for the shares, generating a pretax gain of 1.9 billion euros. France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom agreed to unwind cross-holdings and dissolve a 10-year-old alliance last year over a bid Deutsche Telekom made to acquire Telecom Italia without consulting France Telecom or its chairman, Michel Bon. The bid failed.

description: THE year on Madison Avenue is ending as it began, with a flurry of account activity involving the creative and media accounts of several major marketers.

title: Fiercely Banging the Drum For Those Who Cannot
description: It was an image, said the musician Vernon Reid, that simply would not leave his mind: a picture taken last year by a Human Rights Watch photographer in Sierra Leone of a young man staring at the camera and holding a child in his arms. Both the young man and the child had had their hands amputated.

title: A Stylish, Lusty Widow Shakes Up Gay Paree
description: Franz Lehar's tuneful 1905 operetta ''The Merry Widow'' is so famous that it's easy to forget how wistful and tender it is at heart. But these qualities are only apparent when the operetta is treated seriously.

title: CONTROLLING STAKE IN ENTEL
description: Telecom Italia agreed to pay $820 million to gain control of Entel, the leading wireless and long-distance telephone company in Chile. The deal adds Chilquinta's 25.6 percent stake in Entel to a similar stake Telecom Italia already held, making Telecom Italia the majority stockholder in Entel.

description: Like many boys his age, Juan Esteban Fernandez attended school in the mornings. In the afternoons, he helped his parents plant crops in the rugged mountains outside this city in northeastern Colombia.

title: Keeping Workers Safe, but at What Cost?
description: In November, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration issued a far-reaching, controversial rule intended to protect employees from repetitive stress injuries -- the disabled arms, aching backs and other maladies that each year fell an estimated 600,000 Americans who type, bend, reach and lift objects repeatedly at work.

title: Kirsty MacColl, 41, Pop Singer and Songwriter
description: Kirsty MacColl, a singer and songwriter with a string of hits in Britain, died on Monday in Mexico while vacationing in Cozumel. Reuters reported that her manager, Kevin Nixon, said that she was believed to have been hit by a speedboat in an area reserved for swimmers. She was 41 and lived in London.

title: 30 Punished After a Study Of Ambulances
description: Two city ambulance workers were fired and 28 were suspended yesterday after a Fire Department investigation found that a number of emergency medical teams were extremely sluggish in their response times and that one team had ignored a call for help in favor of a nap.

title: New Regulations for Federal Contractors Will Put an Emphasis on 'Business Ethics'
description: The Clinton administration today will issue new regulations that aim to bar federal agencies from awarding contracts to a company with a record of breaking labor, environmental or other laws, in what business groups called a parting gift to organized labor.

title: Jacques Francois Goddet, 95, Founder and Editor of L'Equipe
description: Jacques Jean Francois Goddet, the founder and for 40 years the editor of the well-known sports newspaper, L'Equipe, and for 40 years the director of the world's most important bicycle race, the Tour de France, died last Friday in Paris. He was 95.

title: Business Travel; Web Sites To Make The Trip Less Work
description: With the holiday season, one of the few slack periods of the year for business travel is approaching. A good time to relax and maybe make a few plans to deal with the rat race more effectively next year. Here, chosen arbitrarily -- but I hope not capriciously -- is a bookmark-list of my picks for the top Web sites to make life a little easier on the road for business travelers:

title: Leverage Aside, Butch Davis Decides to Stay With Miami
description: It appears that Butch Davis will stay at the University of Miami, despite interest from suitors. Still, the sixth-year head coach is finding how wonderful it is to have leverage as he looks to renegotiate his contract.

title: CHEMICAL MAKER ISSUES 2ND WARNING FOR 4TH QUARTER
description: The Rohm & Haas Company, a specialty chemical maker, said yesterday that it would fall short of already reduced fourth-quarter earnings estimates because of slowing sales and rising energy and raw-material costs. The company, based in Philadelphia, said it would earn 29 cents to 34 cents a share in the fourth quarter; analysts forecast 35 cents a share, and before the company's October warning, 47 cents a share, for the quarter. Rohm & Haas's biggest business, acrylic-based materials for making paints and coatings, has proved especially sensitive to the slowing of the economy. Rohm & Haas shares rose $1.81 to close at $31.88.

title: Revisiting Blended Scotch
description: BACK in the 1950's, Scotch meant blended whiskey, the beverage of choice on Madison Avenue and in corporate back rooms, and an emblem of conformity and status in the age of Eisenhower. In the 1970's and 80's, as whiskey lovers began to discover single malt Scotch, blended Scotch came to seem passe.

title: From Australia, the Beauty of Simplicity
description: ONE Friday night I came home late and remembered that I had never had time to cook the beautiful blackfish I had bought at the Greenmarket three days earlier. I was afraid to smell it but hated to waste it, and went looking for camouflage in Donna Hay's new cookbook, ''Flavours'' (Whitecap Books).

title: Teachers Adding an H (for Hygiene) to the 3 R's
description: Joann Sferrazza is in the business of basics. Each week, Ms. Sferrazza introduces the world to a giggly group of 5-going-on-6-year-olds at Public School 14 in Corona, Queens. She teaches the first graders letters and numbers, colors and patterns. She teaches them ''Clifford the Big Red Dog.''

title: Diageo and Pernod Buy and Divide Up Seagram Beverage Assets
description: The balance of power within the global liquor industry shifted further to Diageo P.L.C. of Britain, as the company, which already owns Johnnie Walker whiskey and Smirnoff vodka, and Pernod-Ricard S. A. of France confirmed today that they would pay Vivendi Universal S. A. $8.15 billion for the Seagram beverage assets.

title: CIENA BUYING CYRAS FOR $2 BILLION
description: The Ciena Corporation, a telecommunications equipment manufacturer, agreed yesterday to acquire Cyras Systems Inc. for $2 billion in stock in an effort to bolster its so-called metropolitan optical networks business. Ciena was pummeled by investors worried it had overpaid for the privately held Cyras. Ciena shares fell $23.19, or 24 percent, to $73.19. Cyras's prize product is its K2 fiber optic networking system that can be rapidly deployed in metropolitan areas.

title: GOODYEAR'S NEW-VEHICLE TIRE SALES FELL IN MONTH
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that shipments of tires for new cars and trucks in North America fell in November, mainly because of production cutbacks at DaimlerChrysler, and because higher costs for energy and raw materials, especially oil and rubber, eroded profits. But November shipments of replacement tires in North America ran ''well above'' the 5 percent growth that the industry as a whole experienced, even though the company raised its prices. One-quarter of Goodyear's worldwide tire sales go to automakers, and the rest to the replacement market, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's house-hunting efforts in Washington referred incorrectly to Laughlin and Jennifer Phillips, the owners of one house. Laughlin Phillips is chairman of the Phillips Collection, a Washington art museum, and Jennifer Phillips is a trustee emeritus. (The museum's founder, in 1921, was Laughlin Phillips's father, Duncan.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBUE, VINCENT 43
description: LoBUE-Vincent 43, of Yonkers died December 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Catherine RidgwayLoBue. Cherished son of Ciro and Josephine LoBue. Also survived by his daughters Nicole, Tina, & Veronica and one granddaughter. Brother of the late Grayce LoBueSerowik. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery. Friends who wish may contribute to the Immaculate Conception Church, 53 Winterhill Rd, Tuckahoe, NY 10707 in memory of Vincent LoBue for the restoration of the Outdoor Meditative Garden and Monument of the Blessed Mother.

This bright and appealing restaurant on the Upper East Side follows the decorating scheme of many other Chinese restaurants, but a glance beyond the tanks of fish and the gleaming bar reveals something else: polished wood wine racks stuffed with bottles.

description: Telefonica Datacorp of Spain said it had signed a multiyear, multimillion-dollar agreement to provide dial-up access and network backbone services to America Online units in several important European and Latin American markets. Further financial details of the contract were not disclosed. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

description: The upper house of Parliament censured the Hindu-nationalist-led coalition government today for refusing to dismiss three cabinet ministers who were charged in the demolition of a 16th-century mosque eight years ago. The mosque's destruction ignited ghastly Hindu-Muslim riots.

title: Two Studies Report No Links to Cancer In Cell Phones' Use

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UCHITEL, DAVID, 86
description: UCHITEL-David, 86, of Accord, N.Y., originally a Brooklyn native, passed away on December 19th. As a professional violist, his career was both illustrious and varied. He performed with many of the top big bands, as well as performing with the New York Metropolitan Opera for 37 years. He is survived by his wife Ernestine, son Bruce, daughter Michele, a sister Ruth Shenkman, and 4 grandchildren. He will be missed greatly by all who knew him.

title: The New Boar on the Butchers' Block
description: THE meatpacking district, former frontier territory, looks more and more like a candidate for statehood. Most of the blank spots have been filled in. As a restaurant district, its personality is almost fully formed, and it's probably not too early to label it a chronic underachiever. The area wanted to be another Flatiron district or TriBeCa. It feels more like the South Street Seaport with hip pretensions. The restaurants look good. The people in them look even better, especially the late-night crowd. The food is never quite good enough to be a distraction.

title: U.S. Weather Follows Global Warming Trend
description: Despite a chilly end of the year, temperatures in the United States over all continue to run well above the average of the past century, fitting in with the warming trend of the past decade.

title: FOUNDRY WARNS ON EARNINGS
description: The maker of computer network switches and routers, Foundry Networks Inc., said it expected fourth-quarter profit to be about half of analyst forecasts because of slower sales. Its shares fell $2.38, or 7.2 percent, to $30.63. Foundry forecast profit of 11 cents to 14 cents a share before stock-compensation costs. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected 24 cents a share.

title: LOISLAW TAKES $95 MILLION BID
description: The online legal information service geared to small and midsize law firms, LoisLaw.com, has been acquired for $95 million by Wolters Kluwer, a Dutch publisher of legal, tax and health content for business areas like health care, accounting and the law. LoisLaw, which has 400 employees, will become part of Aspen Publishing, a unit of Wolters Kluwer North America, based in Gaithersburg, Md. Kyle Parker, chief executive of LoisLaw, said he anticipated no staff cuts or relocation of its Van Buren, Ark., headquarters. The deal will enable LoisLaw to tailor products for specific businesses while helping Aspen develop its Internet presence, he said. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Another Fatal Osprey Crash
description: The Marine Corps has wisely grounded its fleet of eight V-22 Ospreys after yet another of these politically resilient but technologically problematic aircraft crashed last week, in North Carolina, killing the four marines aboard. This was the fourth Osprey crash since 1991, and comes just eight months after an Osprey crash in Arizona that killed 19 marines. Defense Secretary William Cohen's plan to appoint a blue-ribbon panel of aviation experts to review the entire Osprey program is long overdue. The Pentagon, which had been expected to approve full production of the Osprey this week, is right to hold off until an investigation of this latest crash is completed and Mr. Cohen's panel has had time to establish whether the aircraft is worth the costs and risks.

Bo Diddley was clever enough to create a few different song archetypes in his early career. Forty-five years down the road, they provide him with some different options for what types of concerts he prefers to deliver.

title: Mexicans Resist Flight From 'Friendly' Volcano
description: Every thousand years or so, the great Popocatepetl explodes with killing force, and as it rumbled and puffed this weekend, government officials monitoring geophysicists' instruments pleaded with thousands of villagers under the volcano to flee.

title: ENERGIS TO BUY ISION
description: Energis, a major Internet communications company in Britain, said it would buy 75 percent of Ision Internet of Germany for 812 million euros ($725 million), mainly in stock, to expand into the business of operating Web sites for corporate clients. Energis will buy the stake from Distefora Holding for 210 million euros ($187 million) in cash and the balance in stock. The price is about seven times Ision's estimated 2001 revenue. Under German law, Energis is required to offer to buy out remaining shareholders after completing the deal.

title: MP3.com Is Confronting Another Copyright Suit
description: A month after MP3.com settled its legal troubles with the major record labels, it has been hit with a new copyright infringement lawsuit, this time filed by EMusic.com and six of its independent partner labels.

title: Metro Business Briefing; POLLUTION CASE SETTLED
description: Phelps Dodge Corporation, which operates a copper-rod manufacturing plant in Norwich, Conn., has agreed to pay a $500,000 civil penalty to settle charges that it violated state air pollution laws, the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, announced yesterday. As part of the settlement, the company has also agreed to spend an additional $500,000 on environmental projects in Connecticut. Clayton D. Allen, a spokesman for Phelps Dodge, said the company disagreed with the state over what the emissions permits required, but decided to settle the suit. He said major improvements were also made to the environmental controls at the copper plant, including a new waste-water treatment system.

title: A TOP EXECUTIVE LEAVING PACIFIC CENTURY CYBERWORKS
description: Pacific Century CyberWorks, Hong Kong's largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that its deputy chief executive, Norman Yuen, would leave at the end of February. He will be the first top official to depart since CyberWorks bought the company in August. Mr. Yuen, who runs the company's main Internet unit and handles its relationships with investors and analysts, could not be reached for comment. The managing director of Citic Pacific, a unit of China's biggest investment company, declined to comment on a report in a local newspaper, The Hong Kong Economic Times, that Mr. Yuen had agreed to join Citic Pacific.

title: A Candidate For Council Cites Pressure Not to Run
description: A college administrator who is planning to run for a City Council seat has accused Democratic Party leaders in Staten Island of pressuring her to back out of the race.

title: Hatcher Comes to Visit, But Devils Play It Cool
description: Derian Hatcher will be at Continental Arena Wednesday night, but throughout the Devils' dressing room after practice today, players played down the notion that they would be out for revenge against the big Dallas Stars defenseman when they meet up with him for the first time since last year's Stanley Cup finals.

title: Belgian Software Company Found to Misstate Revenue
description: The troubled Belgian speech software company Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products misstated up to a third of its total revenue, as much as $277 million in sales, over the last two and a half years, according to a report commissioned by the company's audit committee.

title: Injuries Continue To Nag At the Nets
description: Through the first two months of the season, the goal for the Nets has been a modest one: to survive, finding a way to linger near the .500 mark until Keith Van Horn returns to action sometime near the turn of the new year. But survival always seems more difficult for the Nets than for most other teams, and today the team had another stumble and scare.

title: When the Economy Slows
description: Corporations are finding it a lot harder to make money. Consumer confidence is down. Retailers are experiencing a weak holiday season. Credit is tightening. Layoffs are on the horizon. The Nasdaq index, that once-fearless barometer of the new economy, has lost half its value since the spring. The evidence keeps mounting: America's economy is abruptly slowing down. Reacting to this altered outlook, the Federal Reserve said yesterday that a potential economic downturn had supplanted inflation as the main threat to the economy. Fed watchers interpret this statement as a prelude to interest rate cuts starting in January.

title: Roquefort Cheese Puffs
description: Although not complicated in preparation, the flavoring in this dish is wonderfully sophisticated. We've toned down the Roquefort's power (more often the ratio of Roquefort to cream cheese would be 1 to 1 instead of 2 parts cream cheese to 1 of the Roquefort); the reason for the difference here is that a little less power allows the pistachio and cognac to come through. But play with it if you'd like the cheese to be sharper. The pistachios, by the way, are heated first, to activate their flavorful oils.

title: TRUCK ENGINE COMPANY PROJECTS A LOSS FOR 4TH QUARTER
description: The Cummins Engine Company said yesterday that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss because of declining North American demand for the heavy-duty trucks that use its engines. Excluding one-time charges, the company said, the loss will be 35 cents to 45 cents a share. Analysts had forecast a profit of 66 cents a share for the quarter. Shipments of heavy-duty truck engines are down more than 50 percent from last year, and are running 5 percent to 10 percent below third-quarter levels, Cummins said. Cummins stock fell $2.13 to close at $33.69.

Professor DeFilippis, who runs the foreign languages department at York College in Queens, dreams of a wooden rocker, of singing lullabies in Spanish. So when her oldest son, Joseph, told her 10 years ago that he was gay, she was crestfallen. The first words out of her mouth, she said, were that he would never make her a grandmother.

title: PACIFIC GATEWAY REPORTS TWO TOP-LEVEL RESIGNATIONS

The company in recent months has laid off half its staff, defaulted on a bank loan, received a warning that its stock no longer met Nasdaq listing requirements and said its restatement of 1999 earnings was the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. Its stock, which traded as high as $24 in February, closed yesterday at 3 cents, down from 6 cents on Tuesday.

title: Books That Outshine the Coffee Table
description: How could a Los Angeles design store be complete without these chic seasonal items? Taking the cute out of Christmas decorations is this Sputnik-inspired glass tree ornament (left, $29) designed by Alin Koehler, a recent graduate of the reopened Bauhaus school in Weimar, Germany. Also popular this year are design books as events in themselves (at right). ''Fresh Cream'' (Phaidon Press, $49.95) is a compendium of just-minted contemporary art packaged inside a blow-up pillow (which, alas, must be sacrificed to get at the book). At 15 pounds, ''Neutra: Complete Works'' by Barbara Lamprecht (Taschen; $150) outweighs some coffee tables. The ornaments are at OK, 8303 West Third Street, (323) 653-3501, and at Homework, 1153 North Highland Avenue, (323) 466-1153. ''Fresh Cream'' is at Homework. ''Neutra'' is at OK.

title: CENDANT EXPECTS DROP IN EARNINGS IN 1ST QUARTER
description: The Cendant Corporation, whose businesses range from franchising Coldwell Banker residential brokerages to direct marketing, warned that its earnings in the first quarter of 2001 were likely to fall about 9 percent because of lower income from its diversified services unit and higher interest costs. The company said yesterday that it expected to earn 14 cents a share in the first quarter, down from 22 cents a year earlier. For the year, Cendant said it still expected to meet analysts' earnings estimates of 91 cents a share, including the effects of pending acquisitions of Avis Group Holdings Inc. and Fairfield Communities Inc. but excluding results from its move.com unit, which is being sold to Homestore.com Inc. Cendant's stock price fell 13 cents, to $9.50.

title: BANKRUPTCY FILINGS SET RECORD
description: The shoe retailer Marutomi Group filed for bankruptcy protection, the 12th publicly traded Japanese company to file in 2000 and a record for any year since World War II. Marutomi had been cutting costs since 1998 in an effort to stem losses as its sales declined.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO MISS PROFIT FORECASTS
description: The International Paper Company, the world's biggest paper maker, said yesterday that it was cutting production by 235,000 tons a month as the economy slows and energy costs rise, and that its fourth-quarter profit would be about 30 cents a share; analysts had forecast 44 cents a share. Profit from operations in the period a year earlier was $227 million, or 55 cents a share. International Paper and other forest-products companies have been shutting plants and cutting production to avoid a paper glut that would knock down prices. International Paper's stock fell $1.88, to $37.63.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS ASK COURT TO HALT SMUGGLING CHARGES
description: The two largest cigarette manufacturers, the Philip Morris Companies and R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc., asked a European court to declare that the European Commission lacked authority to sue them in an American court, and by trying to do so had usurped the powers of its 15 member nations. The suit, filed Nov. 6 in United States District Court in Brooklyn, seeks unspecified damages from lost customs duties in connection with a cigarette smuggling operation that began in the late 1970's and that the commission contends was actively abetted by the two tobacco companies.

title: DIMAC WINS APPROVAL FOR REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The Dimac Corporation, a direct marketer that has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection, said yesterday that it won a judge's approval for a reorganization plan that would repay bank lenders 87 cents on the dollar for their claims and give unsecured creditors up to 40 percent of the company's reshuffled common stock, plus some preferred shares. Dimac, based in St. Louis, filed for Chapter 11 protection in April after failing to make interest payments on loans.

title: Chinese-Born Composer Wins $225,000 Ives Prize

description: As Coach Jim Fassel of the Giants said today: ''Hopefully, from now on, we'll have all home games on the away schedule.''

title: An Ad Agency Gives Itself A Little Pow
description: Advertising agencies trade in revamping corporate identities, and the savviest know they must practice what they preach. The venerable agency Ogilvy & Mather now refers to itself by the zippy single name Ogilvy. And its Los Angeles office has traded a Dilbert-style warren of offices in a stodgy building for a flexible, open-plan work space designed by Shubin & Donaldson Architects in the architecturally celebrated development by Eric Owen Moss in Culver City. The goals, said Russell Shubin, included an entrance clients would remember. The solution was a 50-foot-long tube, above right, made of perforated metal panels affixed to a curved steel frame. Other hip features include suspended flat plasma screen televisions and lots of plexiglass, including around library shelves, right. Ogilvy is at 3530 Hayden Avenue.

title: Summer Camp Helps Disabled Girl, 7, to Make Good Friends
description: Laura and Michael Chinnici were expecting to hear one of two phrases shortly after the birth of their first child seven years ago, announcing whether it was a boy or a girl.

title: PRICELINE REJOINS BUSINESS GROUP
description: After a series of setbacks this year, Priceline.com, the ''name your price'' travel service, received a boost yesterday when the Better Business Bureau decided to reinstate the company as a member in good standing. The bureau cited Priceline in September for failing to fully disclose the terms of its travel offers and for customer service problems. ''We had always disclosed the propositions, but we now do it much more up front in the process and we do it multiple times during the process,'' said Daniel Schulman, Priceline's chief executive. Catherine Greenman

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS BUYS BANK OF HAWAII CREDIT CARD UNIT
description: The American Express Company agreed yesterday to buy Bank of Hawaii's credit card business for an undisclosed price. Bank of Hawaii, a unit of the Pacific Century Financial Corporation, has about $226 million in receivables and 148,000 card customers. American Express will issue and advertise Bank of Hawaii-branded American Express cards to the bank's customers. After decades of building its card business on its own, American Express said earlier this year that it would consider buying card portfolios from issuers with longtime cardholders and low charge-off rates; the Bank of Hawaii transaction is its second such purchase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODSIDE, WILLIAM S.

title: HEWLETT-LED GROUP BUYS A MARKETPLACE
description: Converge Inc., an online marketplace founded by a group of 15 technology companies that includes Hewlett-Packard, Compaq Computer, Hitachi and Agilient, said it would buy VerticalNet's components trading exchange, NECX. As part of the deal, VerticalNet will receive $60 million cash and a 19 percent interest in Converge, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., and a seat on the company's board. Exchanges like NECX are intended to help lower component costs for high-technology companies, which already do about $1 billion annually on NECX. The Converge member companies spend about $200 billion annually on components. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Fix the PC, Then Scrape Its Owner Off the Ceiling

The dealer, Heinz Berggruen, who is selling the collection at far below its market value, said yesterday that it was a gesture of reconciliation.

title: Selling the Mom-and-Pop Supermodel Farm
description: SO this breathless exec is M. Katherine Ford, the jet-setting, long-haired ingrate who turned nepotism on its ear last week by flexing her Columbia University M.B.A. and selling the family franchise, a 54-year-old mom-and-pop agency known for its Tiffany cachet and Miss Manners decorum, to an obscure newcomer called Magnum Sports and Entertainment. Think of it as putting the company's pulse ahead of the family's ego. She does.

title: A Camera for Pictures Worth A Thousand Words, With Music
description: Photographers who need music for artistic inspiration might want to consider the Fujifilm FinePix 40i. Most of the time, it's a 2.4 million-pixel digital camera. But when a tiny remote control and headphones are plugged in, it is transformed into an MP3 digital music player.

description: GEVERTZ-Bruce. In our hearts always. We miss you. Judy, Charlie, Emily, Deborah and Jon

The address is www .rdsgrouptrust.com (and not www .htechnology.com, which is the home page of High Technology L.L.C., which designed the RDS Web site but has no other connection to RDS or to the family trust).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHER, LILLIAN
description: FISHER-Lillian. Dear Mom: Wow, a Mei Bear, a Lilly Bear and a Mama Bear. We love and miss you more than ever. Love, Amy, Mort, Susan and all the Girls

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about online custom market-research exchanges, misstated the given name of the chief executive at Marketinginfo.com in New York. He is Brian Weinstein, not Bruce.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Tuesday about plans to build a jazz museum in Harlem misstated the given name of a bandleader with whom Leonard Garment, president of the museum, once played. He is Henry Jerome, not Harry.

title: High Court Voids Charges For Pinochet; Sets New Date
description: The Supreme Court dismissed kidnapping and murder charges today against Gen. Augusto Pinochet. But the court ordered that the general be interrogated in 20 days, so he might be re-arrested and charged again.

title: More Experienced Applicants at Business Schools
description: When Kirsten Muetzel was laid off earlier this month by @TheMoment Inc., an Internet company in California, she was thrilled. Now, she thought, she could focus on getting into business school.

description: ASIA

title: Salon.com Is Cutting Work Force 20%
description: Salon.com, which runs a money-losing Web news magazine, said today that it was cutting 25 jobs, or about 20 percent of its work force, in a bid to cut expenses and speed a plan for the company to earn a profit.

title: Old Story: The Devils Capture A Rematch of the Cup Finals
description: The two finalists in the Stanley Cup championship series last summer met for the first time this season when the Devils took on the Stars at Continental Arena tonight. Dallas was seeking retribution for losing the series in six games and the Devils were mindful of the vicious hit that Derian Hatcher delivered on Petr Sykora in the cup finale.

title: Urban Man, Suburban Man
description: Love and family as a working stiff in Teaneck, N.J., or loveless success and riches in glamorous Manhattan? This is the choice facing Jack Campbell (Nicolas Cage) in the new, slightly surreal movie ''The Family Man.'' The aim, said Kristi Zea, the production designer, was to make Teaneck ''every bit as wonderful and idealistic a world as we could imagine in Manhattan.'' Red-brick homes with snow-covered porches make a nostalgic view of suburbia, bottom. By contrast, her idea of Manhattan is coldly glamorous, below. Definitely surreal for anyone who knows New York is the way Jack leaves his apartment, filmed in the East 50's, and drives his Ferrari through Central Park to his office in the Seagram Building (which is also, as it happens, in the East 50's).

title: ISLES' JONSSON OUT THREE WEEKS
description: If the Islanders are going to continue their success in their lengthy homestand at the Nassau Coliseum, they will have to do it without defenseman Kenny Jonsson.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Selling on the Internet

title: Fatty Diet Could Lead to Thin Bones
description: WASHINGTON - A fat-laden diet could lead not only to obesity and heart disease but to the thinning, fragile bones of osteoporosis, researchers said on Wednesday.

title: Charter School Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro surged on expectations the United States economy will slow and investors will channel more money into Europe. In New York, the euro settled at 90.83 cents, up from 89.34 cents on Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Expects Lower Profit; It Confirms Dividend Cut
description: AT&T confirmed yesterday that it would reduce its dividend -- for the first time since its origin in 1887, the company said -- as it struggles to reduce its debt.

title: What's Better for the Soul, A Sofa or a Coffee Table?
description: Some monks may not agree, but sofas and coffee tables can be good for the soul. Or so claims John Bernard, a fashion designer and owner of the newly opened Los Angeles store Room Service. Its business card promises nothing less than ''home furnishings for the soul.'' In addition to midcentury-modern style furniture, much of which is designed by Mr. Bernard, the store offers amenities meant to make the ''buying experience less stiff and rigid,'' said the manager, Samantha Cruz. These include wine and other drinks for customers and jazz bands on Saturday afternoons (yes, you can lounge on the furniture). The store also rents furniture to movie studios. Shown in the shop window, above, a green Profile sofa designed by Derin Sariyer, for Terminal, $4,700; cushions by Angela Adams, $195 each; a Jesse coffee table, $475. Room Service is at 8115 West Third Street, (323) 653-4242.

title: BRITISH TEST FOR UNAUTHORIZED CORN
description: The British Food Standards Agency said yesterday that contrary to the claims of an environmental group it had found no unauthorized genetically modified ingredients in tortilla chips sold in that country. Friends of the Earth had said in November that tests it commissioned detected Monsanto's Roundup Ready corn, which has been approved in the United States but not in Europe, in four brands of tortilla chips sold in Britain and Denmark. The Food Standards Agency said it had commissioned tests of 11 samples of flour from the same batch used to produce the chips in question and all tested negative. The agency also said in a news release that tests used to determine the presence or absence of a specific variety of corn are not reliable below a concentration of 0.1 percent. Larry Bohlen, director of health and environment programs at Friends of the Earth in Washington, said that while he was not familiar with the British agency's findings, the only way it could have disproved the environmental group's assertion would have been to test the same products that it had. Andrew Pollack

title: Locked Doors and Mystery After a Jazz Resignation
description: Door locks and computer access codes at the offices of the Jazz at Lincoln Center organization were hastily changed on Friday with the abrupt resignation of Rob Gibson, the group's executive producer and director, the chairman of the organization's executive committee confirmed yesterday.

title: Japanese Veteran Testifies in War Atrocity Lawsuit
description: Under the code of his secret wartime army unit, which experimented with chemical weapons on live prisoners and dropped bombs to spread plague bacteria through northern China, Yoshio Shinozuka should not be alive today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a report on poor people charged with crimes in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount spent by the state on poor defendants. It is $4.65 per capita of population, not per defendant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHLER, RICHARD KIRTLAND
description: MICHLER-Richard Kirtland, 70. Died on December 17th, 2000 in Asheville, NC of Parkinson's Disease. Survived by sister Annette Lantzius of Fletcher, NC, and nieces Anne Strauss, Susan Rich, and Renee Lantzius.

title: Devices to Help Museum Pieces Weather the Years
description: ANYONE who has ventured to the attic to retrieve a shoe box of photographic negatives has probably seen what havoc is wreaked by warm temperatures and high humidity. The negatives become warped, waffled and unprintable, and the images are lost.

title: After Recount, Tight Race For Water Board Is Over
description: Trailing by a hair, the incumbent dug in, demanded a recount and threatened to sue. Up by a three-vote margin, the challenger insisted that all the votes had been counted and that he was the winner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKER, SEYMOUR
description: HACKER-Seymour. Died on December 19th, 2000. Dearly beloved husband of Linda Hacker, dearly beloved father of Melissa Hacker & Emily Hacker. Beloved father-in-law of Anne Keating. Dearest grandfather of Olivia Ruth Hacker-Keating. Dearest brother of Laura Lawrence and uncle of James B. Dwyer IV and Maggie Dwyer. He was the last of the great art booksellers. He was friend and father to all who knew him and a great soul. Live in our hearts forever. Service today at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 2 P.M.

title: Democrats Say Goodman Is Stalling the Vote Count
description: Democratic officials charged yesterday that State Senator Roy M. Goodman and his campaign aides were deliberately trying to stall the vote count in his still undecided race on the East Side of Manhattan as a way to keep him in office.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday in the special Outlook issue of Business Day, with an article about Microsoft's business strategy, misspelled the surname of a project developer for the company. He is Burt Keely, not Kealy.

title: AMERICAN TOWER SECURES LEASES
description: The American Tower Corporation said it had acquired leasing rights for 2,193 mobile telephone towers from the Alltel Corporation for about $660 million. The 15-year agreement includes an option for American Tower to buy lease rights to 200 more towers for about $300,000 each, and it gives American Tower the right to build about 500 more towers for Alltel. American Tower expects to sell capacity on the towers to Alltel and other mobile phone companies. Simon Romero

description: NEW YORK

title: Gem Sanctions Sought by U.N. Are Delayed
description: Ukraine, which was barely mentioned in a new report on the illegal diamond trade from Sierra Leone, blocked the report from being introduced today in the Security Council as planned, diplomats said.

title: Digital Reading Activities With a Big Red Dog
description: CLIFFORD READING

title: SOUTH CAROLINA PIPELINE THREATENS TO DROP PROJECT
description: The South Carolina Pipeline unit of the Scana Corporation said yesterday that it might walk away from a $355 million plan to build a power plant and natural gas pipeline to serve Fayetteville, N.C., because the city had withdrawn from negotiations over financing the project. The plant and the 106-mile pipeline that would serve it were to have opened in 2004. The company and the city each said they feared being stuck with liability for the whole cost of the project under the other's financing proposal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, DR. RALPH
description: LEVIN-Dr. Ralph. Loving brother, devoted uncle and good friend to all who knew him. Services Friday, 9:45AM Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Experience the Thrill, the Chill, but Not the Frostbite
description: Brrr. Getting cold again. Let's plan a trip to . . . Florida? What's that, you say? The election is over? Well, if personal finances or political exhaustion dictate a northern chill this winter, here are a few snow-related Web sites to pass the time.

title: Critic's Notebook: Playing in the Key of F, for Fresh; From the Strings and Winds of Babes, a Lesson for Major Orchestras
description: Outside Alice Tully Hall last week people snaked around the block waiting to get into the concert by the Juilliard Orchestra. It was a chance to hear some excellent young musicians playing an appealing program of repertory works: Gluck's Overture to ''Iphigenie en Aulide,'' Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Beethoven's Symphony No. 8. To top it off, the concert was free.

title: Stock Gambling on the Cheap
description: At the eleventh hour last Friday night, Congress passed a measure that will benefit Wall Street at the expense of the average investor. This bill should raise a few eyebrows this holiday season, when investment bankers and brokers are cashing hefty bonus checks just as the holdings of many small investors are entering free fall.

description: To the Editor:

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Jets Take Offense To All the Squawking
description: Tapping into a wellspring of defiance that had seemed dormant while their best chances to secure a playoff berth slipped away in the past two weeks, the Jets hoisted a giant chip onto their shoulders today. It was all in preparation for what Vinny Testaverde said was the most important game of his Jets career, Sunday's matchup against Baltimore that will probably determine the Jets' playoff fate.

title: ROCHE IN TALKS WITH ICN IN BID FOR RIBAVARIN STAKE
description: Roche Holding A.G., the giant Swiss pharmaceutical company, is discussing swapping its stake in ICN Pharmaceuticals for stock in the ICN unit that controls rights to Ribavarin, its blockbuster hepatitis drug, Bloomberg News reported yesterday without identifying its source. The report said Milan Panic, the Serbian-American chairman of ICN who served as president of Yugoslavia before Slobodan Milosevic, had met with Roche officials in Basel to discuss the swap. ICN is preparing to take the unit, known as Ribapharm, public with a stock offering. Roche is working on hepatitis treatments that may work in combination with Ribavarin, which is now sold mainly as part of combinations sold by Schering-Plough.

description: To the Editor:

title: Milt Hinton, Dean of Jazz Bassists, Is Dead at 90
description: Milt Hinton, one of the most recorded musicians of all time and the dean of American bass players, died on Tuesday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 90 and lived in St. Alban's, Queens.

title: BMW THRIVES AGAINST THE TIDE
description: The chief executive of BMW, Joachim Milberg, said that unit sales were 9 percent ahead of last year and that BMW still expected to report a record profit, even though much of the global auto industry has been reporting falling sales. The United States has been especially strong for BMW 3 Series cars and X-5 sport utility vehicles, in part because of currency shifts, he said. He also said BMW's sale of the Rover Cars unit to the Phoenix Group for a nominal price has gone to binding arbitration over the valuation of some assets.

title: The 'What Ifs' That Fascinate
description: Churchill called them ''the terrible ifs.'' He meant those little nudges, those very slight alterations, that might have changed the outcome of a battle, for instance, and in a snowballing process an entire happening of history could have turned out different. Churchill's chilling ifs have become the mind game of a small but cultist book genre called alternative history, or speculative history, or counterfactual history or hypothetical history.

title: USINOR, EUROPEAN STEEL MAKER, EXPECTS DROP IN PRICES
description: Usinor S.A., Europe's largest steel maker, said yesterday that steel prices would face ''strong downward pressure'' in 2001 because of mounting inventories, and that the surge in earnings seen in its third-quarter results would be short-lived. The company's net income rose sevenfold to 220 million euros ($197 million), or 0.94 euros a share, from 31 million euros in the period a year earlier. Usinor's stock fell 0.13 euro, or 1 percent, to 13.06 euros a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, LEON
description: LANE-Leon. The City Athletic Club announces with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed member, Mr. Leon Lane. Michael Todres, President

title: Residents of New London Go to Court, Saying Project Puts Profit Before Homes
description: Efforts to revive the economy of this impoverished old port city are focused on the redevelopment of Fort Trumbull, a ramshackle waterfront neighborhood where Pfizer Inc., the global pharmaceutical giant, is building a new $270 million headquarters for its research and development operations.

title: French Socialists Win Measure To Flip the Order of Elections
description: Legislation that could give the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, a leg up in the 2002 presidential race by reversing the election calendar -- putting the presidential elections before the legislative elections -- passed easily in the National Assembly here today and brought Socialists to their feet to applaud their triumph.

title: National News Briefs; Testimony in Extradition Is Held to Be False
description: A Canadian commission has concluded that an American Indian, Leonard Peltier, was extradited to the United States in 1976 after a witness, Myrtle Poor Bear, gave false testimony.
