Barysh and her husband Steven Swanger of Sudbury, MA. & Alan Barysh of Balitmore, MD. Cherished grandfather of Gabriel & Rebecca Swanger. Dear brother of the late Etta, Frances, Max, Morris & Thomas. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue @ 81st St., New York, on Friday, December 22 at 10:30 AM. Remembrances may be made to Jewish Family and Children's Service, 31 New Chardon St., Boston, MA 02114.

title: Pakistan Ruler Tells Why He Exiled Rival: To Cleanse the Land
description: In a nationally televised address, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, sought tonight to justify his much criticized decision to exile Nawaz Sharif, the prime minister he toppled 14 months ago, to a pleasant life in Saudi Arabia as a guest of the royal family.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks Must Avoid Temptation
description: OH, how tempting it must be about now for the Knicks to take their best shot at the very tall man, loitering in the back of the Atlanta defense while the agent and chess master David Falk plots his next move. Dikembe Mutombo is still a force, even when he's hanging in the weeds, where the Hawks conduct business these days.

title: State Laws Vary, but a Broad Trend Is Clear
description: HAPPY families may all be alike, but they are not all governed by the same laws. When gays and lesbians decide to have children, by whatever means, they enter a web of legal and familial entanglements. Parental nudging is the least of it.

title: Sprewell Brings Back His Scowl
description: Twice on Tuesday night, Latrell Sprewell tried to soar over Dikembe Mutombo, the Atlanta Hawks' All-Star center, for dunks. The hostile attempts seemed to come out of nowhere, as if spurred more by frustration than by confidence. But while neither dunk was made, Sprewell's aggressiveness was good to see.

title: Women Taking Active Role To Study Orthodox Judaism
description: As a girl, Shelly Sher walked with her grandfather to his Orthodox synagogue on the Sabbath but parted from him to climb the staircase to the women's balcony, a cramped, dark space where she remembers it was hard to see the men praying downstairs.

title: White House, Trying Once More for Mideast Peace, Rates the Chances Below 50-50
description: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators met with President Clinton at the White House today, as hopes revived for the possibility of a Middle East settlement before Mr. Clinton leaves office next month.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK GETS STATE DEPOSIT
description: The state deposited $10 million in government funds in a Sunset Park bank yesterday as part of a program to promote economic development in underserved areas. The bank, Community Capital Bank, is based in Brooklyn and opened a branch this month in the Brooklyn Army Terminal. The deposit, made by Comptroller H. Carl McCall, is part of a three-year-old program to deposit interest-earning funds in bank branches in areas that lack extensive banking services. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Arrowhead Stadium To Be Host Qualifier
description: Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City has been selected to host the World Cup qualifier between the United States and either Costa Rica or Guatemala on April 25, the U.S. Soccer Federation said yesterday.

title: In Israel's Election, the First Big Issue Is Divisiveness
description: As of now, Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Ariel Sharon, the Likud Party leader, are the sole contestants for the Feb. 6 elections for prime minister. But this is Israel, land of perpetual political tumult, and there remains an entire day before candidates have to declare.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SLUMPS. Crude oil fell after a report of rising inventories damped concern about low supplies. In New York, crude oil for February delivery fell $2.19, or 7.8 percent, to $25.77 a barrel.

title: Oil and Mining Leaders Agree to Protect Rights in Remote Areas
description: Several big oil and mining companies have agreed to principles meant to safeguard human rights while protecting employees and property in remote parts of the world, the State Department said today.

title: AT HOME WITH/Martha Schwartz; Making Landscapes Pop
description: IN her sprawling office, in a charmless industrial building shoehorned between train tracks and a cemetery, Martha Schwartz explained her proposal for a plaza in Coventry, England. If it is approved, three-foot disco balls will hang from steel cables over a striped stone pavement, turning the plaza into a cross between Studio 54 and the Alhambra.

title: Lindros Suitors Hesitate Because of Concussions
description: The Philadelphia Flyers haven't received any offers for Eric Lindros in the three weeks since he was cleared to play, mostly because no National Hockey League team will be able to insure his contract against another head injury, N.H.L. team and insurance executives said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, LESLIE A.
description: BLOOM-Leslie A. Of Scarsdale, NY, on Dec. 20, 2000. Husband of the late Salka (Lala) Bloom, dear mother of Ann Schaffer, Linda French, Phillip Bloomand David Bloom, and their families. Funeral service Friday 12:30 P.M. at Temple Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ALICE
description: LEVY-Alice. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Randy Shill, Stephen Levy and Lauren Levy. Adored daughter of Henry Besdine. Dear sister of Bonnie Hodes. Cherished grandmother of Jared and Jason Shill. Services are today 10AM, at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shift in Stance by Federal Reserve Deals Blow to Wall Street
description: For years, investors have been trained to believe that whenever the financial markets turn particularly stormy, Alan Greenspan can be counted on to calm the seas. But in their stampede out of stocks yesterday, investors seemed to be awakening to the idea that the chairman of the Federal Reserve may not be quite the guardian angel they thought he was.

title: Seeking Truth About Eminem
description: Last weekend a record executive stood at a party displaying news he had just received on his pager. It said Eminem was going to be named Time magazine's man of the year. The message even included text from the supposed Time article. The next day a report began appearing on music-news Web sites that Eminem had died in a car crash. Both tales, of course, turned out to be false.

title: It's a Free Market, but Who's Fit to Manage?
description: Dmitri Chernov was near despair as he recounted his difficulties making ends meet. ''Russia is a rich country, with tremendous natural and human resources,'' he said. ''But there is no one to manage this wealth properly.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPAPORT, MARSHA
description: RAPAPORT - Marsha. Retired New York City Councilman, Sam Horwitz and wife Estelle and family extend our heartfelt sympathy to husband Jerry, daughter Jennifer, son David and family on the passing of beloved Marsha who was my legislative assistant for 20 years, a great friend and wonderful person. May she rest in peace.

title: Sports of The Times; From Groh, His Best Buster Keaton Act
description: THE coach of the Jets showed up yesterday morning for his daily news conference at the team's Hofstra University training facility with all the exuberance of a flat tire.

title: Man in the News: Donald Louis Evans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Donald L. Evans, a 54-year-old Texas oilman, likes to say that he has been "cycle tested," whipped by the vagaries of commodity markets and, more recently, by the vicissitudes of the prolonged contest that resulted in George W. Bush, his best friend, winning the White House.

title: Chanel uses 'real people,' who are also attractive, accomplished and hold good jobs, to sell scents.
description: USING a group of gorgeous models to promote the Allure fragrances for Chanel just doesn't cut it these days. Now, the stars of ads for both the women's and men's fragrances must not only be attractive ''real people,'' but they must also be accomplished, with interesting professions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBER, EMIL
description: TAUBER-Emil at 88, beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Harvey and Ronald. Adored grandfather of Farrah, Allison, Josh, and Jenna. A true gentleman who was loved and respected by all who knew him; his simple elegance and knowledge distinguished him. Services will be today, 11:30 AM at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills.

title: City Plans to Let Company Run Some Public Schools, in a First
description: In its first effort to turn entire public schools over to private operators, the New York City Board of Education plans to let Edison Schools Inc., a for-profit company that is the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools, run up to five of the city's worst-performing schools beginning next fall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VISTEON CORP., Dearborn, Mich., the auto-parts supplier spun off by the Ford Motor Co. in June, said it had bought closely held LTD Parts Inc., Sparta, Tenn., for an undisclosed price to help supply remanufactured parts to Ford, its largest customer.

title: The Silences Are by Design
description: DAVID BERS, the architect who designed my house in Garrison, N.Y. -- the first I ever built -- recalls that I was very direct when we began discussing the project in the summer of 1997. Yes, I wanted black slate for the kitchen countertops; no, I did not want a front porch.

title: Protests Arise Over Business Aspect of Censoring Web
description: When Congress passed a new bill last week requiring virtually every school and library in the nation to install technology to protect minors from adult materials online, it created a business opportunity for companies that sell Internet filtering systems. But the measure also produced vehement protest from educators and civil liberties groups, who say that the business opportunity is a large part of the problem.

title: Reformers Hope to Win Parliament In Serbia
description: After a short and relatively uneventful political campaign, Serbs are preparing to vote on Saturday for a new government that should remove the last of Slobodan Milosevic's followers from executive power.

title: Manhattan Man Guilty in Rape and Murder Spree
description: A Manhattan man was convicted last night of carrying out one of the most harrowing rape and murder sprees in the city in years: the killing of three young women and the rape of four others. All of the girls attacked by the man, Arohn Kee, were teenagers. Two were 13 years old.

title: Selling on the Internet

title: TERRA LYCOS SLUMP DEEPENS
description: Terra Lycos's shares dropped below their offering price, wiping out all gains since their initial offering last year. Analysts said investor uncertainty about the Spanish Internet company's management, coupled with the flaccid market for technology stocks, contributed to the fall. On the Madrid bolsa, the shares fell to 11.5 euros, below the 11.80 euros at which they were floated in November 1999. On the Nasdaq, Terra Networks sank $1.84, or 16.3 percent, to $9.47. Benjamin Jones

description: For California Republicans, President-elect George W. Bush's selection of Ann M. Veneman to be secretary of agriculture came as little surprise.

title: Nets Fall In Battle Of Teams In Disarray
description: Coach Byron Scott of the Nets was fuming, disgust registering in his clenched jaw and his eyes glowing red. Scott was so volatile after his team's latest abysmal effort that he refused to speak to his players for fear of erupting and telling them exactly how inexcusable their performance was tonight.

title: A Gilman Foundation Chief
description: Arlene Shuler, senior vice president for planning and external affairs at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, has been named executive director of the Howard Gilman Foundation.

title: A New Ballpoint From Cross That Can Read as Well as Write
description: The Cross Convergence pen can be used to keep track of Web addresses but not just with its conventional ballpoint refill. A tiny scanner at the opposite end can read and store up to 300 addresses hidden in bar codes on products, in advertising and in some newspapers and magazines.

title: Metro Matters; Remembering A Mayor, Faults and All
description: THE memories were kind yesterday, as people who knew John V. Lindsay recalled the years when he was the improbably patrician face of New York.

title: A New Web Appliance: No Wires, a Few Strings
description: If you like the idea of an arm-held tablet computer that connects to the Web without wires, but don't like the idea of spending $1,000 for a Honeywell WebPad, NadaPC has what it considers a better deal: An even smaller, lighter Internet appliance that, it says, is absolutely free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CLARA FREEDMAN
description: SOLOMON-Clara Freedman. Devoted wife of Sidney. Loving mother of Raymond. Dearest sister of David and Sigmund. Services Friday 11:15AM Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York. Please omit flowers.

title: Pitino Still Searching for Right Formula
description: The Boston Celtics were run off the floor by the Chicago Bulls last week and the Fleet Center emptied earlier than anyone could remember. Charles Barkley then offered optimism for Celtic legions who have been longing not for a 17th championship banner, but a glimpse -- even a sniff -- of the postseason.

title: AOL Issues Plea for Fast F.C.C. Approval
description: America Online and Time Warner want to close their merger this year and would incur ''substantial burden and expense'' if they are unable to do so, America Online told the Federal Communications Commission today.

title: 2nd Thoughts For News Corp. And WebMD
description: When it comes to the old media's infatuation with new media, what a difference a year makes.

title: Kentucky Insurance Chief Leaves for New York Life and Big Raise
description: The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had hired one of the country's most highly regarded and influential regulators. The move raised concern among some consumer advocates who have long criticized what they call an overly close relationship between the insurance industry and the state officials who oversee it.

title: Gains Reported In Construction Of New Homes
description: Construction of new homes rose in November, led by a surge in apartments, condominiums and townhouses, government figures showed today. The November performance keeps housing construction on track for its third best year of the current economic expansion.

title: Bank of Canada Has a New Chief
description: David A. Dodge has been named governor of the Bank of Canada and will take over the central bank's top job from Gordon G. Thiessen in January.

title: PANEL TO EXAMINE TAX BENEFITS
description: The World Trade Organization agreed to set up a panel to review the United States' revised Foreign Sales Corporation program, which gives up to $4 billion in tax benefits to American companies. It will rule in 90 days on the acceptability of the new law, which is intended to overcome an earlier ruling that such tax benefits violate global trading rules. Separately, the European Union received the organization's approval to impose trade sanctions against the United States; no action is expected before the spring. Elizabeth Olson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARNOGORSKI, BERNICE M.
description: TARNOGORSKI-Bernice M. Beloved mother Paula Axelrod, and beloved grandmother to Samuel Axelrod, passed away Saturday, December 16, 2000. There will be a Memorial Mass on December 30th at Saint Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th St. at 5 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Society of Seamans Children, Staten Island, NY.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEARST, RANDOLPH APPERSON
description: HEARST-Randolph Apperson. On December 18, 2000 at the age of 85. Husband of Veronica, father of Catherine Millicent Hearst, Virginia Anne Hearst Randt and Patricia Campbell Hearst Shaw, Anne Randolph Hearst, and Victoria Veronica Hearst, and four grandchildren. Service private. In lieu of flowers a contribution may be made to Family Connection Literacy Program, C/O Dr. Jean Fuller, Superintendent, Bakersfield City Schools, 1300 Baker Street, Bakersfield, CA. 93305-4399.

title: Hard to Tell When a Virtual Shelf Is Bare
description: IN all fairness, Amazon.com never promised to send me two MP3 players in time to give them to my daughters for the holidays.

title: Rutgers Coach Makes Moves
description: Greg Schiano has been the head football coach at Rutgers for less than three weeks, but he has already made headway in his mission to make the Scarlet Knights a competitive football program. Schiano, a native of Wyckoff, N.J., realizes that the way to turn the program around is by recruiting the top New Jersey prospects who often go out of state to universities like Penn State and Wisconsin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SYLVIA C.
description: SCHWARTZ-Sylvia C. On December 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Marchy. Devoted mother of Judith Duberstein (Dr. Joel) and Dr. Arthur Schwartz (Linda). Cherished grandmother of Laura, Kenneth, Marc (Suzanne) and Amy. Adored great-grandmother of Jack and Matthew. She touched many lives as a devoted early childhood education teacher and administrator. Services 11:30AM Friday, December 22 at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORGES, ANNE MARIE
description: GORGES-Anne Marie. Beloved wife of Gregory. Loving mother of Gregory, Jr. and Richard. Devoted daughter of Margaret Flanagan Bingham and the late George. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Bronx, Thursday, 7PM-9:30PM, Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday at 10 AM Holy Rosary Church.

title: DIAMOND MINE PLAN ADVANCES
description: The Rio Tinto Group and Aber Resources agreed to proceed with an $840 million diamond mining project at Diavik in the Northwest Territories of Canada. The mine is estimated to be capable of producing 6.3 million to 7 million carats a year, or one-sixteenth of world output last year, after it opens in 2003.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ZUCKERMAN TO MAKE DONATION
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher of The Daily News and U.S. News & World Report, has decided to give the net proceeds from the sale of his new-economy magazine, Fast Company, to a charitable educational trust he founded. The magazine was sold to Bertelsmann AG's Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing for $360 million, with a bonus of up to $150 million, depending on ad revenue. Mr. Zuckerman invested $20 million in the magazine when it began about five years ago, and owns about 88 percent. Executives who work for him said part of his profit would be donated to his educational trust, MBZ Charitable Remainder Unitrust, but would not give an amount or say when the trust was established or to whom it has given money. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about renewed interest in old nuclear plants misstated the name of the company that is buying the Nine Mile Point plants. It is Constellation Nuclear, not Entergy. The article also misstated the name of the plant that could be run by the original workers' grandchildren. It is Vermont Yankee, not Yankee Rowe.

title: Nasdaq Tumbles 7.1% as Fed Bias Shift Fails to Halt Skid
description: The slide in stocks picked up speed yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index suffered the biggest of seven consecutive declines and its biggest percentage loss since April. The technology-dominated index has now crumbled 53.8 percent from its peak in March.

title: Accounts
description: * The New Orleans Tourism Marketing Corporation to Peter A. Mayer Advertising, New Orleans, to handle its account, which had been at Montgomery Stire & Partners, New Orleans. Spending was estimated at $5 million. G.Mc & Company Advertising, New Orleans, will handle multicultural advertising.

title: Asking How Sharpton Pays for Those Suits; Case Offers Glimpse of His Finances
description: He says he owns no suits, but has ''access'' to a dozen or so. He says he owns no television set because the one he watches in his home was purchased by a company he runs. He says he has no checking accounts, no savings accounts, no credit cards, no debit cards, no mutual funds, no stocks, no bonds, no paintings, no antiques. The only thing he admits to owning is a $300 wristwatch and a 20-year-old wedding ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANTZ, DR. GEORGE E.
description: WANTZ-Dr. George E. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University are saddened by the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. George E. Wantz. A surgeon at The New York Hospital -Cornell Medical Center since 1949, he gained an international reputation for his innovations in hernia surgery. Incorruptible, affectionate, and generous, he was a model of common sense, intelligence, and simplicity. His inquiring mind and his joy of living were legendary. Dr. Wantz contributed so much to surgical science, especially hernia surgery, and to the lives of generations of surgeons whose paths and careers he guided. We extend our condolences to his family. Memorial contributions may be sent to George E. Wantz Hernia Center Fund, c/o Weill Medical College, Department of Surgery, 525 E. 68th St., Box 561, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORN, PEARL
description: DORN-Pearl. On December 19, 2000, after a long illness. Devoted and loving sister of Sylvia and Anna. Graduate of Cooper Union 1951. Funeral service Thursday at 1:30 PM at ''Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Syringomyelia Association, 300 North Green Street, Longview, TX. 75601.

title: Carnegie Chief Hailed By Supportive Germans
description: Today Germany allowed itself a measure of contempt for New York habits by warmly greeting the return of Franz Xaver Ohnesorg from his bumpy tenure as executive director of Carnegie Hall.

title: Macintosh Fans Can Finally Join The Speech Transcription Game
description: For years, Macintosh fans have stood on the sidelines, looking on as Windows users enjoyed a choice of several speech-transcription programs. Now there are two Mac programs that can transcribe speech that is dictated at conversational speed. But each of the new programs has room for improvement.

title: Vodafone Group Increases Stake in Japan Telecom
description: The Vodafone Group of Britain, the world leader in wireless telecommunications, took another step forward in its global expansion strategy today with the widely expected agreement to increase its stake in the No. 3 telephone company in Japan.

title: Eviction Fears Ease After Inspections in Brooklyn
description: After New York City inspectors checked 29 Brooklyn factory buildings with illegal dwellings, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office said last night that none had safety hazards serious enough to require residents to be evacuated.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RCN CUTS 70 JOBS
description: RCN Corporation, the cable television, Internet and phone service provider based in Princeton, N.J., said yesterday that it had laid off 70 employees from its headquarters staff and that more positions might be eliminated to cut costs. RCN's stock price dropped yesterday to $8.97, a low for the year, from a high this year of $74.87. Nancy Bevac, a spokeswoman for RCN, said executives planned to hold a conference call with investors and analysts today to discuss plans. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Ogilvy & Mather Hires Billing Auditor
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, has hired an accounting firm to review its billing procedures on a federal antidrug assignment and has hired a consultant to help administer the assignment and similar ones after the company was accused of overcharging the government for media buying duties.

title: Taking the Mask Off Pseudoscience
description: ERIK MAX FRANCIS is so passionate about the theory and practice of modern science that in the last year alone he has posted 9,460 messages in scores of online user groups devoted topics like relativity, astronomy and neuroscience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, JOHN V.
description: LINDSAY-John V. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater grieve the death of our former Chairman of The Board, who served the theater with singular dedication from 1984 to 1991. He led the theater with energy and enthusiasm to a previously unknown stability, and the theater's current sixteenth season is a living tribute to John Lindsay and the devoted people he gathered around him to insure that a permanent theater of artistic distinction be securely established at Lincoln Center For The Performing Arts. We extend our love to Mary, Katherine, Margie, Anne, and John, Jr. Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman John Chalsty, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater

title: Fairway Pays $6.5 Million For Properties in Harlem
description: Ever since Fairway opened a large discount market five years ago in a former meatpacking plant on 133rd Street, the no-frills store has been so popular with residents of Harlem and the Upper West Side that shopping there has often been a test of endurance.

title: Russians Send a Message To Georgians: Toe the Line
description: A new requirement that Georgians obtain visas to visit Russia is heightening tensions between the countries and making life harder as well as more expensive for hundreds of thousands of Georgians who travel to Russia for work or to visit family.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TWINLAB TO CUT STAFF
description: Twinlab Corporation, a manufacturer of nutritional products and supplements, said it would cut about 145 jobs to trim costs because of slower sales. The cuts will come through layoffs and attrition, said the company, based in Hauppauge, N.Y. Twinlab stock has fallen 76 percent in the past month.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Crash Course In Southern Speak

title: Up in the Hills, Modernists Just Want to Have Fun
description: Modernism lends itself to constant reinterpretation. Consider, for example, the freshness of a penthouse extension by Lorcan O'Herlihy Architects of Los Angeles in a 1950's house for Dan Nathanson and Chandi Chapman. ''A house has a potential to engage the city,'' said Mr. O'Herlihy (above right). ''There are ways of participating by way of deckings and platforms.'' In this case, Mr. O'Herlihy engaged his Hollywood Hills site by building an 850-square-foot extension on the roof of an existing streamlined modern house with views of Hollywood. His expansion, containing master bedroom, bathroom and lounge area, conforms with California's Modernist tradition of melding inside and outside. The external walls are more glass than solid, with pivoting wood-frame doors, top left. Translucent blue-green channel glass provides privacy while admitting a diffuse light. This glass is a favorite of the architect, who has been experimenting with uses of glass as a skin. Shadows are provided by a slightly undulating trellis of Douglas fir slats, which follows the graceful curve of the building, above left. The lounge area, top, has built-in maple seating.

title: Revolutions Come and Go, but a Porcelain Factory Endures

title: Whitman Stays Silent On E.P.A. Post
description: Neither Gov. Christie Whitman nor the man who would succeed her, State Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, had anything to say today about reports that the governor was on the verge of being appointed the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: It Just Had to Happen: Say Hello to Fusion Architecture
description: When it opened, in 1989, the Patina restaurant, founded by the chef Joachim Splichal, served extraordinary cuisine in ordinary surroundings. Now, those surroundings have stepped up, with a showy renovation by Hagy Belzberg Architects of Los Angeles. The design's combination of rustic and sleek tries to reflect the new menu's mix of California French and heavier game dishes. Rough-hewn cedar planks overhang the reception area, above left. The new patio, above, is built on a former parking lot and has a dry-stacked stone wall that aspires to a Frank Lloyd Wright kind of naturalism. Patina is at 5955 Melrose Avenue, (323) 467-1108).

title: Buffett Buys Company Crippled by Asbestos Suits
description: As a value investor, Warren E. Buffett likes to buy things on the cheap. Yesterday, he found a bargain that could have been marked, ''For Sale: $1 Billion Off.''

title: Jaguars' Taylor Lobs Darts at Giants' Defense
description: Jacksonville running back Fred Taylor has rushed for 100 yards in nine consecutive games. Apparently, he does not want the streak to get to 10 without a fight because Taylor picked one with the Giants' defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDEIROS, FRANK J.
description: MEDEIROS-Frank J. The Directors, Officers and Members of Commercial Finance Association express their profound sorrow at the death of its Past Chairman of the Board, Frank J. Medeiros. Robert S. Sandler, Chairman of the Board Charles G. Johnson, President Leonard Machlis, Executive Director

title: Accounting Board Considers a Change
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which earlier this month endorsed a new way to account for ''goodwill'' resulting from mergers and acquisitions, said yesterday that companies will be able to use the new approach on goodwill already on their books from past deals, as well as any new deals they enter into.

title: I.N.S. Says African Woman Used Fraud in a Bid for Asylum
description: A confidential investigation by the Immigration and Naturalization Service concluded last year that a West African woman obtained political asylum by assuming a false identity and fraudulently claiming she would be punished by genital mutilation if she returned home, immigration agency officials said yesterday.

title: Down a Rabbit Hole to a Dark Wonderland
description: A KNIFE-WIELDING young girl in a blood-splattered apron gazes sullenly from the cover of American McGee's Alice. The illustration seems calculated to shock the viewer; the girl looks like a Victorian child who has been brought via time machine to modern America and given only a knife as protection against her new schoolmates.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY; Whitman Seen as Strong Choice for E.P.A.
description: As Republicans spread the word that she was President-elect George W. Bush's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency, Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey proudly defended her environmental record in interviews this week, refusing to confirm reports that she had been selected while seeming already to be practicing for the national stage.

title: All Soaring Skyward, Except for the Silent One
description: The era of the lip-synching, barely singing pop star may be ending. On Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, WKTU (103.5 FM) had its annual holiday charity concert, ''Miracle on 34th Street,'' a revue of 16 hitmakers (plus two surprise cameos) paying obeisance to the station that helped put them on the charts. And lo and behold, most of them had extraordinary voices.

title: Boston's Digging Produces a Green Jewel
description: Boston's $14 billion Big Dig, the most complex highway construction project in American history, is scheduled to tear down the city's much-maligned expressway and replace it with a high-tech underground highway by 2004. And rising on the site of the former eyesore will be . . . what?

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT; Bush's Announcement of 3 Cabinet Selections
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in Austin, Tex., at which President-elect George W. Bush introduced his choices for three cabinet positions: Ann M. Veneman as secretary of agriculture, Melquiades R. Martinez as secretary of housing and urban development and Donald L. Evans as secretary of commerce. The news conference was recorded by Federal New Service Inc.

description: Following are excerpts from the news conference yesterday in Austin, Tex., at which President-elect George W. Bush announced Paul H. O'Neill, the chairman of Alcoa Inc., as his choice for secretary of the treasury, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: New Privacy Rules Are Challenged
description: Leaders of the health care industry said today that they would immediately ask President-elect George W. Bush to revise new rules issued by President Clinton to protect the privacy of medical records.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Talks in Washington

title: Tea And Transition
description: Given the surreal closeness of Election 2000, and the impeachment of the sitting president less than two years ago, the White House transition from Bill Clinton to George W. Bush has so far been a stroll. In the past few days we've seen Hillary Rodham Clinton having tea with Laura Bush, a jovial Vice President Al Gore swapping niceties with Mr. Bush, and President Clinton behaving like a helpful holiday host to Mr. Bush at a nearly two-hour-long Oval Office meeting. Far from enduring the post-election acrimony most pundits predicted, we appear to be in the midst of one of the smoothest presidential transitions in recent memory. If this seems like an exaggeration, consider some far less cordial transfers of power in the past.

title: College Courses Taught With Tailored Software
description: CHARLES ATWOOD used to hand out a lot of paper. Dr. Atwood, a professor at the University of Georgia, oversees a popular freshman chemistry course that attracts about 1,550 students. Although they don't all meet in one room, the students do work from a common syllabus, which, on paper, amounts to 18 pages. That meant that until a few years ago, Dr. Atwood would kick off the semester by distributing about 28,000 sheets, or more than 50 reams, of paper. But this fall, each student received just one page: an instruction sheet on how to log on to the course's Web site.

title: A Web Site That Came In From the Cold to Unveil Russian Secrets
description: ANDREI SOLDATOV sits down in the lobby of the Hotel Rossija in Moscow, orders tea, flips open his Sony Vaio laptop and logs on to the Internet to demonstrate his Web site via his wireless modem. A Vaio may not be an exploding pen or an umbrella that doubles as a machine gun, but in modern Russia, a high-tech laptop and a wireless modem are about as James Bond as gadgets get. This is appropriate, consid ering that Mr. Soldatov's Web site, www .agentura.ru, is about Russian espionage.

title: Aggrieved in 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lindsay Legacy
description: John V. Lindsay presided with passion, idealism and courage over New York City during one of the most beleaguered periods of its history. In his eight turbulent years as mayor, from 1966 through 1973, New Yorkers endured racial unrest, strikes, economic decline, rising crime rates, antiwar protests, fiscal crises, police scandals and finally a revolt of the white middle class that discouraged him from seeking re-election to a third term. He was a glamorous but divisive figure who battled labor leaders, rival politicians and countless others. Yet his biggest fights were waged against racial hatred and poverty, and he helped awaken all Americans to the cause of the cities.

title: Ardingly Journal; Seeds of Hope, to Keep Mother Earth in Gardening
description: Seeds are world travelers, hitching rides on gusts of wind, cascading rivers or the furry hides of roaming forest creatures. They colonize every corner of the globe, and their travels aren't all easy, with hungry birds and inhospitable landing places often bringing abrupt ends to journeys.

description: Plant Stars of Tomorrow

description: ''To actually read the Torah for the first time, it was awe-inspiring. My hands were shaking. I had been taught I could never touch the Torah, and here I was reading from the Torah.''

title: Decking Out a 'Messiah' But Hewing to Tradition
description: Handel's ''Messiah'' has become such an entrenched Christmas favorite that its genesis as an Easter work is now little more than a historical footnote, something that perhaps only trivia mavens think about when hearing it.

title: Economic Scene; America, don't smirk. The European Union is no joke in any language.
description: THE relentless fall of the euro in 2000 at least until recently -- has lulled Americans into thinking the European Union has lost some credibility as an economic power. Add to this the failure of the recent summit meeting of European leaders in Nice to reach agreement on sharing power, and it is easy to cast aside the ambitions of Europe to form a less fractious and much bigger union. Even the news media in France, which played host to the meeting, were critical of the event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, WILLIAM
description: RAND - William. The Jewish Museum mourns the passing of our Honorary Trustee, William Rand, whose personal passion for art and music inspired an enlightened patronage of New York's cultural institutions. Together with his late wife, Muriel, William Rand took great joy in building an art collection that has immeasurably strengthened the holdings of The Jewish Museum. His deeply held belief that the arts should be accessible to all led him to establish a fund that will perpetuate the Rands' commitment to cultural education. We admired his intelligence and integrity as we enjoyed his charm and style. We extend our sincerest condolences to his daughter, Kathi, and her family. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: A Bright Expanse Of Beauty Underfoot
description: HOME renovators can now choose from a variety of new and durable flooring materials, some originally created for commercial use. Choices range from soft, cushiony industrial-grade rubber -- in many colors -- to tempered glass.

title: SWEDISH INSURANCE DEAL
description: Handelsbanken, a big Swedish bank, said it had agreed to buy the life insurance and mutual fund units of SPP, an insurer owned by the Swedish government, for 7.1 billion kronor ($730 million). The deal would make Handelsbanken the second-largest life insurer in Sweden after Skandia and would increase its assets under management to 250 billion kronor ($26 billion). SPP has been seeking a buyer for the two units all year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPPER, HENRY G.
description: HOPPER-Henry G., 88. Of Indian River Shores, FL, died December 18th, 2000. He was a resident of Monmouth County, NJ for over 60 years before moving to Vero Beach. He was pre-deceased by his wife of 60 years, Wilma Rose Hopper. Mr. Hopper was retired from the U.S. Trust Company of New York City. Survivors include his daughters Lynn Martin of Ormond Beach, FL; Gail (Tim) Wheeler of Jacksonville, FL, four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. For information: Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, FL. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Indian River County, 1111 36 Street, Vero Beach, FL. 32960, or the charity of your choice.

title: FIRST UNION REDUCES ANNUAL DIVIDEND BY 50%
description: The First Union Corporation said yesterday that it had halved its annual dividend from $1.92 to 96 cents to save cash after two years of sliding earnings. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the move would add about $5 billion to capital over the next five years. First Union, the sixth-largest banking company, is six months into an overhaul in which it has shed branches, closed its Money Store unit and taken a $3.8 billion charge.

title: In Orange, Closed Ranks and Relief After Officers' Conviction in Beating
description: Like a family closing ranks around its own, this compact city of 30,000 was all solicitude and wariness a day after a federal jury convicted five local police officers of beating and pepper-spraying an innocent man who died in their custody.

title: Group of Metal Traders Sues Russian Aluminum Producer
description: A Russian corporate battle reached United States courts today when a group of metals trading companies sued Russia's biggest aluminum producer, Russian Aluminum.

title: The New Push for a Missile Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: Negotiating With North Korea
description: President Clinton will decide in the next week or so whether to close out his presidency with a trip to North Korea. Such a visit would be justified if he can come home with a firm, verifiable agreement committing Pyongyang to end the production and export of its missiles in exchange for international help in launching North Korean satellites for civilian uses. Mr. Clinton must also be certain that a visit to North Korea would not interfere with a possible final effort to produce a peace agreement in the Middle East.

title: Ordonez's Backup Will Be Relaford
description: Luis Sojo's single skipped past Kurt Abbott to put the Yankees ahead for good in the final game of this past season's World Series. Abbott was playing shortstop for the Mets in place of Mike Bordick, who was hampered by a broken thumb. Both Abbott and Bordick are now former Mets, with Rey Ordonez and Desi Relaford the shortstop tandem of the moment.

title: In a Garden Of Songs, As Happy As Kings
description: Innocence recalled in the midst of adult struggle is the prevailing spirit of ''A Child's Garden,'' a new musical that has been set on very tentative feet by the Melting Pot Theater Company. The songs, by Louis Rosen, are mostly based on the beloved poems for young children by Robert Louis Stevenson collected in ''A Child's Garden of Verses,'' with lyrics taken directly or adapted from them, and the show, at Theater 3 on West 43rd Street, is about the circumstances under which they were composed.

title: Markets Remain Skittish, but the Dow Gains 168 Points
description: Stocks staged an unimpressive rebound yesterday from their recent pummeling, giving up much of hefty early gains in a session marked by more warnings of profit disappointments, continued forced liquidation of shares bought on credit and year-end maneuvers to cut tax bills.

title: New Arena Plan Shifts Risk, But Still Doesn't Eliminate It
description: The YankeeNets are seeking to advance stalled negotiations aimed at financing a $325 million arena in downtown Newark by offering a revamped plan that they hope will be palatable to government officials and taxpayers.

title: Quicavi Journal; A Rich Life of the Mind Makes a Hard Life Easier
description: The winds are cold and moist in this old fishing village, but they are not as chilling as the stories that the fishermen and potato farmers tell.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARITY, NATALIE
description: GARITY-Natalie, 12/22/89. Dear Mom, you are remembered every day with love by your children, your grandson, and your greatgranddaughter. We miss you.

title: State to Shrink Contested Road Project Near Crucial Reservoir
description: New York State is planning to scale back a highway expansion project adjacent to the Kensico Reservoir under an agreement that addresses concerns about the project's impact on New York City's drinking water, state transportation officials said yesterday.

title: MP3.COM AND WARNER IN PACT
description: Videos and music recordings made by Time Warner's Warner Music Group will be sold on MP3.com's Web site under a two-part nonexclusive agreement with Warner Music, an MP3.com spokesman said. MP3.com will provide various services to Warner Music, including artist pages and e-mail. MP3.com signed a licensing agreement in June for Warner recordings on two of MP3.com's software services after settling claims made in a copyright-infringement lawsuit filed by five major record labels.

title: F.C.C. Orders AT&T to Shed Some Assets
description: Taking a slap at AT&T, the Federal Communications Commission ordered tonight that the telephone and cable giant sell its interest in Time Warner Entertainment, after officials concluded that the company had been trying to wriggle out of an earlier commitment it had made to win the government's approval of its acquisition of MediaOne.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * FABULOUS THUNDERBIRDS, SHEMEKIA COPELAND, G. E. SMITH. B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. The Fabulous Thunderbirds have been playing their Texas blues since 1974. Their founding guitarist, Jimmie Vaughan, has been replaced by Kid Ramos; the band's singer and harmonica player, Kim Wilson, still delivers long-suffering lyrics with suave understatement. Shemekia Copeland got an early start on the blues circuit touring with her father, Johnny Copeland, who died last year. With a gutsy but girlish voice, like those of Etta James or Bonnie Raitt, she sings about men and their many flaws, from indifference to infidelity, and she sounds as if she will get what she wants sooner or later. G. E. Smith, the guitarist from the ''Saturday Night Live'' band, is a connoisseur of American roots music and can make his solos sting even more when they're not interrupted by commercials. title: Gunman Wounds Four People Before Being Fatally Shot by Police

title: Album of the Week
description: ANDY BISKIN: ''Dogmental'' (GM Recordings). It's hard to find gentle humor in jazz -- thanks, perhaps, to the development of harmony over melody and its attendant dangers of bombast and romanticism -- but the clarinetist Andy Biskin has perfect radar for it. ''Dogmental,'' his first album, is full of short pieces that break down into contrapuntal arrangements and short, pungent solos; it's a sweet-tempered album that doesn't take itself too seriously but has a lot of hidden virtues. There are hints of early Ellington (''Little Elsa,'' which develops a strong melody out of six notes, and ''Field Days,'' with Bruce Eidem's growling trombone solo), polka (''Sad Commentary'') and bits of Steve Lacy at his most ruminative and delicate. It would be so easy for an album like this to collapse under the weight of preciousness, but it doesn't. The rhythm section (Ben Allison on bass and Matt Wilson on drums) gives it muscle. You can't say it's indicative of what jazz is up to or where it's going, but it's a little triumph nonetheless. BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTERT, WARREN H.
description: ROTERT-Warren H., counsel to Morgan & Finnegan, LLP, passed away in New Jersey on December 19th at the age of 70. Mr. Rotert was a prominent patent lawyer who specialized in patent and intellectual property litigation and counseling. He joined Morgan & Finnegan, LLP's New York office in 1960. He became a member of the firm in 1965 and retired in 1996 after 36 years of service. He became counsel to the firm in 1997. Mr. Rotert was a member of numerous legal organizations. He graduated with a BS in civil engineering from Lafayette College in 1952, received his law degree from George Washington University in 1959, and served in the US Armed Forces from 1953-1955. Warren Rotert is survived by his wife Jean, son Kevin, daughter Lise Thayer and her husband Brian Thayer, son Kevin, son Todd and his wife Lauren, brother David, and four grandchildren: Alison, Jennifer, Ryan and Mary Beth. His first wife, Mary Jane Rotert, predeceased him. Mr. Rotert will be missed by his partners and friends at Morgan & Finnegan, LLP. Funeral services will take place on Friday morning, December 29 at the Van EmburghSneider Funeral Home in Ramsey, New Jersey. There will be a reception for friends following the funeral service at The Ramsey Golf and Country Club. The family has established the Warren H. Rotert Scholarship Fund and asks that contributions be made to it in lieu of flowers.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Book Deal
description: We are sorry to see Hillary Rodham Clinton start her Senate career by selling a memoir of her years as first lady to Simon & Shuster for a near-record advance of about $8 million. The deal may conceivably conform to the lax Senate rules on book sales, though even that is uncertain. But it would unquestionably violate the tougher, and better, House rules, and it is an affront to common sense. No lawmaker should accept a large, unearned sum from a publisher whose parent company, Viacom, is vitally interested in government policy on issues likely to come before Congress -- for example, copyright or broadcasting legislation.

The stockholders will share in 25 (pounds) million immediately. They will also receive up to $:500 million in 2006 or later from a fund of $:1.45 billion from which reserves will be deducted to pay taxes, smooth out investment returns and sell new policies. The remaining $:225 million will go to policyholders in bonuses. The court found that the plan complied with a rule requiring that 90 percent of surplus distributions go to policyholders and 10 percent to shareholders. AXA is based in Paris.

title: Repairing Bilingual Education
description: Bilingual education in New York City was originally viewed as a transitional program that would teach foreign-born children in their native languages until they were fluent enough in English to enter the educational mainstream. But over the last 25 years, bilingual programs at many schools have become foreign-language ghettos from which many children never escape. The need to expose foreign-born students to more English during the school day -- and to move them as quickly as possible into the mainstream -- was underscored this week in a pair of reports, one from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's task force on bilingual education and one from Schools Chancellor Harold Levy.

title: Scuttle the Everglades Airport
description: President Clinton's efforts to rescue Florida's Everglades will rank among his finest accomplishments in the field of conservation. But there is one more gift he can make to the troubled South Florida ecosystem before he leaves office, and that is to kill a misguided, seven-year-old plan to allow Miami-Dade County to build a major commercial airport on the site of the old Homestead Air Force Base. Such an airport is not only unnecessary but would pose an unacceptable ecological threat to two national parks -- the Everglades, which is a few miles from the base's western edge, and Biscayne National Park, only two miles to the east.

title: Bohemian Chic . . . Until the Moon Hits Your Eye
description: Each Christmas season in the garden of St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church stands a homey Nativity scene whose pastoral presence defies the clamor of traffic on Houston Street. Fresh-cut pine trees rustle beside fiberglass figurines -- shepherds, camels, wise men, and kings -- as if whispering a prayer in the chilled December breeze. In the center, the Holy Family appears before the infant Christ; the creche spans nearly half a block. Shepherds descend hills made from slabs of wood, and to the east a camel boy follows the kings. The creche, which was first erected at St. Anthony's 50 years ago, beckons visitors to what is now the beginning of SoHo, proudly announcing tradition in a neighborhood that worships change.

description: * SUICIDE, PAN SONIC. Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. A singer (Alan Vega), a keyboardist (Martin Rev) and a relentlessly mechanical drum machine made up Suicide, the punk-era band that can now call itself a pioneer of electronica and industrial rock. On its albums, just reissued, Suicide's songs are robotic updates of rockabilly, garage rock and the Doors. It used to play its repetitive riffs until the audience rebelled; now there's more tolerance and humor on both sides. Pan Sonic, sharing the bill, is a deeply minimalistic duo from Finland that layers electronic clicks, whooshes and blips into crisp, slowly evolving mechanized meditations. D.J. Otefsu, better known as the noise-rocker Foetus or Jim Thirwell, plays music between sets. Doors open at 8:30 p.m. Pan Sonic appears at 10, followed by Suicide at 11:15; tickets are $20 in advance, $25 on Dec. 31. JON PARELES

Reggae, jazz, electronica and their hybrids share a quintuple bill at the Cooler's show. The headliner is Dr. Israel (alias Douglas Bennett), a singer who has set out to reunite branches of reggae's family tree, bringing together the deep, leisurely bass lines of dub reggae with the skittering electronic drumbeats of jungle and the uplifting messages of roots reggae, sometimes adding assertive hard-rock guitar. Ari Up, a founding member of the post-punk band the Slits, has lately moved closer to reggae. Harriet Tubman is the jazz-rock power trio of Brandon Ross on guitar, Melvin Gibbs on bass and J. T. Lewis on drums. Liminal -- the trio of D.J. Olive, Loop and Danny Blume -- creates eerie sonic collages, and the Slackers play ebullient ska. At 9 p.m.; admission is $15. JON PARELES

description: * JOHN ZORN'S BAR KOKHBA, MILFORD GRAVES, SEX MOB. Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Tonic Masada is a collection of 205 klezmer-tinged tunes by John Zorn, who oversees various ensembles that play them. Bar Kokhba -- with Marc Ribot on guitar, Mark Feldman on violin, Erik Friedlander on cello, Greg Cohen on bass, Joey Baron on drums, Cyro Baptista on percussion and Mr. Zorn conducting -- pushes the tunes toward chamber music and jazz. Less fragmented and more melodic than most of Mr. Zorn's music, Masada finds connections to Jewish tradition everywhere. Milford Graves, a drummer whose free-jazz playing propels groups like a rushing wind, will play solos. And Sex Mob applies the lessons of avant-gutbucket jazz to radically remake familiar songs. Mr. Graves opens for Bar Kokhba at 8 p.m.; tickets are $40. Bar Kokhba performs again at 11, followed by Sex Mob; tickets are $45. All-night admission is $65. JON PARELES
