description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on concern that cold weather is draining inventories too quickly to avoid interruptions. In New York, natural gas for January delivery rose 50.4 cents, to $9.83 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: The Last Election, and the Next
description: To the Editor:

title: As Consumers Turn Pessimistic, Factory Workers Feel the Chill
description: For much of the last two years, the Frigidaire washer-and-dryer factory in Webster City, Iowa, could barely keep up with demand. The work force in the squat building -- just off the Boone River, close to Iowa's geographical center -- had increased since 1998 by about 700 people, or nearly 50 percent, and the company continued hiring new employees as recently as early in November.

title: With Emotional Farewell, Bush Quits Governorship
description: An emotional George W. Bush quit the only public office he has ever held this morning, thanking Texas legislators and other supporters in a speech in the State Senate here for a ''record of shared success, a true tribute to bipartisan efforts'' during his six years as governor.

title: Recognition By Mail Order
description: '' 'Gladiator' put him over the top,'' Irv Slifkin said of Russell Crowe's standing at Movies Unlimited, one of the largest video mail-order houses in the nation. ''Plus they're finding a lot of his older stuff.'' Together, old and new movies with Mr. Crowe are enough to earn him a new tinted display area all his own in Movies Unlimited's 2001 catalog of 40,000 videos. About 360 actors and directors, from Abbott and Costello to Zhang Yimou, have displays this year. Mr. Slifkin and his colleagues make the designations. ''We vote on it, sort of a committee thing,'' he said.

title: As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: WHEN other people are out for a party, musicians are on the job, and probably no other night offers musical employment like New Year's Eve. Club owners are already laying in the party hats and Champagne glasses, and musicians are ironing their formal wear for next Sunday night. Every club that usually presents live music pours on more of it; restaurants set up impromptu bandstands; dance clubs find divas to belt over their backing tracks, preferably in outfits as memorable as their songs.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: PROJECT OBJECT. Lion's Den, 214 Sullivan Street, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 477-2782. Frank Zappa's music was never easy to play. It called for players who loved both basic three-chord rock and all the whizzing, swerving, whimsical complexities that Zappa could devise. Musicians are still willing to devote themselves to its wayward intricacies, and Project Object has been working its way through the Zappa repertory for years. It will play three sets of Zappa's music, including the complete ''Joe's Garage,'' a rock opera about a time when rock is outlawed. Its guest will be Ike Williams, a longtime member of Zappa's band. Doors open at 9 p.m.; tickets are $30. JON PARELES

title: Black Democrats to Contest Party Leadership
description: Former Mayor Maynard H. Jackson said today that he would challenge the fund-raiser Terry McAuliffe for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee and that his campaign would emphasize the need to reinvigorate the party's grass-roots organizing efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLAN, PENUAL P.
description: ALLAN-Penual P. Recently retired Director of Admission of the Spence School, died on Tuesday, December 19, 2000, at Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Avenue, the Bronx, of cancer. Wife of John H. Allan, mother of David P. Allan, mother-in-law of Catherine Kenworthy Allan, sister of Mary Jane Wallace of Portland, Me., & sister of David S. Palermo, of Larchmont, NY. A memorial service will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, corner of Madison Ave. and 73rd St., in Manhattan, Tuesday, January 9, 2001 at 4 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Penny Allan Fund for Financial Aid at the Spence School, 22 East 91st Street, New York, N.Y. 10128.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: CONNECTICUT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON, ANNE
description: CITRON-Anne. Formerly of New York, died on Wednesday, the thirteenth of December in Charlottesville, Virginia. Mrs. Citron had lived in New York from 1945 until last year, when she moved to Virginia to be closer to family. A native of Pennsylvania, Mrs. Citron served in the American Red Cross in North Africa and Italy during World War II. She was educated at West Chester State College and Temple University in Pennsylvania, and was awarded a Masters Degree from Columbia University. Mrs. Citron wa a published poet and literary scholar. Mrs. Citron was married for 48 years to the late Cecil A. Citron of New York. She leaves her son and daughterin-law, Alex P. Citron and Shelley Citron of Charlottesville, Virginia; and her sister Dorothy Nice of Havertown, Pennsylvania.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about Boston Celtics Coach Rick Pitino misidentified one of the players he drafted in the first round in 1997. Besides Ron Mercer, Pitino drafted Chauncey Billups, not Antoine Walker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, JACOB CARL
description: SEIDEL-Jacob Carl. On December 18 2000 at 87 years old in Deerfield Beach, Florida. Loving husband of Essie for 61 years and beloved father to Andrew and Lauren and her husband John, and cherished grandfather to Rebecca and Ivan. Private ceremony. To life, love and the arts.

title: Mahomes Wants the Chance to Be a Starter Once More
description: Pat Mahomes never complained about the variety of roles the Mets used him in last season. Now that he is a free agent, though, the pitcher wants to find a team that will give him more defined duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINMAN, IRA
description: WEINMAN-Ira. On December 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Barry and Marilyn Daitch. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin and Matthew Daitch. Services today, 10am at Schwarts Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Blvd (76 Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Taylor Stand-In Gives Giants Inviting Target
description: The Giants saw red today. On Wednesday, Fred Taylor, the Jaguars' dangerous runner, set the theme for Saturday's game by conceding that, well, yes, the Giants have a good defense, but not the talent of the league's best.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELBY, YETTA
description: SELBY-Yetta. Of Pembroke Pines, FL passed away December 21, 2000. She is survived by her husband, three children, seven grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. For more information contact Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapels, Fort Lauderdale, FL., 954-434-1531.

title: The Last Election, and the Next
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Martin Wants to Keep This Award
description: Curtis Martin announced at the start of the season that he wanted to be a bigger contributor to the offense so he could help fill the void created by the departure of receiver Keyshawn Johnson. He ran stairs in his condominium building in Florida, and worked hard on his receiving skills. Today, his teammates recognized his efforts, voting him the Jets' most valuable player for the second year in a row.

title: SCHWAB EXECUTIVES TO TAKE PAY CUT IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that it would temporarily cut the salaries of its top executives to conserve cash because of the stock market slump. The co-chief executives, Charles Schwab and David S. Pottruck, will give up half their salaries in the first quarter of 2001, the company said, or about $100,000 over three months, based on their annual salaries of $800,000 apiece. About 750 other officers at vice president level or above will have their January and February paychecks cut by 5 to 20 percent. Lower-ranking employees will keep their current salaries but will be encouraged to take any saved vacation time, plus unpaid leave of up to 20 days. No layoffs are planned, the company said, and employees of U.S. Trust, the private bank Schwab recently acquired, will not be affected.

title: O.K., It's a Wonderful Life. But Where Is It?
description: It seems that every few years the studios release movies that seek to offer Christmas magic but end up feeling forlorn and empty. One was ''Trapped in Paradise'' (1994), which starred Nicolas Cage as a former thief trying to reform who ends up trapped in a winter wonderland of a small town with his no-good brothers. That tradition continues: this year the always hard-working Mr. Cage is marooned in a snow-globe fantasyland in ''The Family Man,'' a piece of moldy wax fruit if ever there was one. A few years ago The New Yorker ran a cartoon with the caption ''Donna Karan's Biggest Nightmare''; the drawing featured someone wearing a sweatshirt with DKNJ scrawled across the chest.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Fed Rejected a Shift in Stance Last Month
description: Federal Reserve policy makers debated in November whether the economy had slowed so much that they should announce that the risk of accelerating inflation no longer was greater than the risk of weaker growth, minutes of their meeting showed.

title: Los Angeles Gains Attention and Money With Its Own Power
description: When city officials decided in 1997 not to participate in the state's plan for power deregulation, there was some concern that the city's financially troubled Department of Water and Power might fail as competition with investor-owned utilities led to lower rates.

title: CELLULAR CONCERN CUTS OUTLOOK
description: United States Cellular said its cash flow in the fourth quarter would fall short of forecasts as the company spends more than expected to upgrade its technology. The company expects cash flow of $102 million in the quarter, down from an earlier estimate of $135 million. United States Cellular also attributed the decrease in cash flow to costs associated with higher-than-expected subscriber growth. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Bush Selects Ashcroft for Attorney General
description: AUSTIN, Texas -- President-elect Bush nominated defeated Missouri Sen. John Ashcroft to be attorney general on Friday, choosing a conservative Republican who lost his re-election bid to a dead man.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Goalies Named Nabokov
description: THE hottest goalie in the National Hockey League is a young Russian named Nabokov. On Wednesday, he spun, he dived, he all but swallowed the puck as he stopped 31 shots for the suddenly successful San Jose Sharks to record his third shutout of the season, 3-0, over Detroit for what was the Sharks' fifth straight victory.

title: INDONESIAN GAS MARKET OPENED
description: Indonesia's minister of mines and energy, Purnomo Yusgiantoro, said the government was planning to open the country's market for liquefied petroleum gas to competition, ending a monopoly held by Pertamina, a state-owned oil company. Prices for the gas are subsidized in Indonesia, and Pertamina loses money selling it. Pertamina has said it will lay off more than 30 percent of its 26,000 workers and sell shares to the public as part of a restructuring effort. Auditors last year said Pertamina had lost about $4 billion between 1996 and 1998 because of inefficiency and corrupt contracts, most involving friends and children of former President Suharto. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: MARC ANTHONY. Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741. Marc Anthony pines for romance with one of the most ardent voices in pop: a tenor that starts out seeming hesitant and rises to pealing, sobbing notes that hold on to their gentleness even at full power. His songs in English tend to be more awkward than his salsa hits in Spanish, but there's no denying his combination of boyish charm and supercharged supplication. At 9 p.m.; tickets are $48 and $60. JON PARELES

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: L.E.S. STITCHES. Continental, 25 Third Avenue, at St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 529-6924. For some preparty moshing, an early-evening show at the Continental features L.E.S. Stitches, a band that carries on the Ramones' tradition of fast, loud, bratty, speed-strumming punk rock. L.E.S. Stitches performs at 8 p.m.; the Krays open at 7. Admission is $10 for the Krays and L.E.S. Stitches; the club will be cleared before the late show by Murphy's Law. (See below.) JON PARELES

title: Student Failure Causes States To Retool Testing Programs
description: Tammy Ho is not used to failing.

title: Seeking a Nest For 'Sea Gull'
description: Next summer's all-star production of ''The Sea Gull,'' directed by Mike Nichols and produced by the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is looking for a home, quite possibly on Broadway.

title: Hail, Ulysses, Escaped Convict
description: The opening credits of Joel and Ethan Coen's new film, ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' announce rather grandly that the picture is ''based upon 'The Odyssey,' by Homer.'' The filmmakers even supply a ritual invocation of the muse, who is asked (via Robert Fitzgerald's translation of Homer's epic) to help them sing of ''the man skilled in all the ways of contending.''

title: U.S. and Europe Trade Proposals to End U.N. Dues Deadlock
description: New proposals from the United States and the European Union failed today to end a deadlock over how to revise the dues for member nations in order to give Washington reductions it is demanding. As midnight approached, diplomats said they expected to be in session until dawn, with no promise of an agreement.

title: The War Within East Jerusalem
description: For the last two months, the white stone apartment buildings of Ha'anafa Street in the neighborhood of Gilo have been targeted by Palestinian gunmen from Beit Jala, the village just across the valley. Until an unofficial cease-fire began a few days ago, Gilo came under sustained attack because it is the only Jewish neighborhood in Jerusalem that borders autonomous Palestinian territory.

title: Brooklyn Man Dies After Being Hit in Head in TriBeCa
description: A Brooklyn man died Wednesday of injuries suffered when a man struck him from behind after he left a topless lounge in TriBeCa, the police said yesterday.

title: Spellbound on the Sidewalk: Is It Art?
description: EVERYONE knows that installation art, or something close to it, is not confined to museums and galleries. Since the 1970's artists have regularly taken over public parks, billboards and even street corners to present works of longer or shorter duration. At the moment the venerable Conceptual artist Lawrence Weiner has peppered Lower Manhattan with 19 functioning yet message-bearing manhole covers, courtesy of the Public Art Fund.

title: U.N. Study of Diamonds-for-Arms Deals Focuses on Shadowy Trader
description: The second of two reports to the Security Council this week on links between illegally sold diamonds and arms for guerrillas in Africa has brought into focus a shadowy trader with many names, nationalities, air companies and bases. The experts call him Victor B.

title: Vodafone Is Buying Mobile Unit Of Eircom
description: After three months of talks, the Vodafone Group agreed today to buy the mobile arm of Ireland's former state telecommunications company, Eircom, for 4.5 billion euros ($4.1 billion) in the largest corporate transaction ever in the country.

title: Helping Hands
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Great Plains Software Purchased by Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation agreed today to buy Great Plains Software Inc. for $1.1 billion in stock in a deal that seeks to improve Microsoft's line of products for small and medium-size companies.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC SAYS EARNINGS WON'T MEET FORECASTS
description: The Georgia-Pacific Group warned yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of forecasts because of increasing energy costs and declining demand for lumber. Profit will be substantially below the 58 cents a share that was the average forecast of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, the company said; it earned $175 million, or $1 a share, in the period a year earlier. The company joins a chorus of forest-products companies issuing warnings about fourth-quarter results, including Mead, Temple-Inland, Boise Cascade and International Paper. Shares of Georgia Pacific gained 25 cents, closing at $28.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have many good citizens who do excellent work in our society that wouldn't be able to pass a college-prep math test, and really don't need to.''

title: A History of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGSAYSAY, TERESITA
description: MAGSAYSAY-Teresita. On behalf of the Teachers College, Columbia University community I want to express my deepest sympathies to the family of Teresita (Tess) Magsaysay and Ken Boxley on the untimely death of our dear friend Tess. She was a graduate of Teachers College and her field of study was applied linguistics. With her husband, Ken, she supported a one-of-a-kind scholarship to attract the best and the brightest to the teaching profession. There are few people so committed to education as Tess, and few so lovely in character and mind. We will miss her. Arthur E. Levine, President Teachers College, Columbia Univ

title: Depths of Suffering to Leaps of Spirit
description: The English soprano Amanda Roocroft began making a name internationally just over a decade ago, when her appearance at European opera festivals excited considerable debate about her prospects as a rising young star. Since then she has pursued a sensible career, singing roles to which she is suited and making a few recital discs for EMI. One thing she had not done until now is sing a recital in this country, but on Sunday afternoon Lincoln Center presented her United States debut recital as part of its Great Performers series.

title: Ikea Moves Account To Carmichael Lynch
description: Ikea, the home furnishings retailer, has chosen Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Excuse Me, but That's Ms. Game Boy to You, Fella
description: Margaret T. Elks has had it with her job. After 30 years as a middle school teacher in Las Vegas, Ms. Elks bemoans eroding discipline, ever-mounting paperwork and declining respect for her profession.

title: Honors
description: Pinnacle Worldwide, Minneapolis, a network of independent public relations agencies, named Henry A. de La Garza, president at de La Garza Public Relations, Houston, as president for a two-year term. He succeeds Jerry Klein, executive vice president at Anne Klein & Associates, Marlton, N.J., who becomes chairman at Pinnacle.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Year in Technology Law
description: Continuing a venerable three-year-old holiday tradition, Cyber Law Journal asked a variety of Internet legal mavens to weigh in with their nominations for the most significant or interesting cyberlaw developments in the year almost past. Here are some of their edited responses.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * JOAN OSBORNE, HOBEX. Village Underground, 130 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 777-7745. Squeeze into this intimate basement room for what promises to be one of this year's steamiest New Year's celebrations. Joan Osborne recently released an adventurous album, ''Righteous Love'' (Interscope) that deserved more attention that it received; here's betting it becomes a cult favorite. Anyway, no matter what her visibility is on VH1, this blues-rock innovator can still walk onto any stage and burn it down with her stellar pipes. Hobex is a soulful party band led by Greg Humphreys, who is turning into the Van Morrison of the college-rock circuit singing his own poignant compositions alongside chestnuts by the likes of Sam Cooke. The grooves will flow. At 7 and 10:30 p.m. For the early show, tickets are $20 for general admission and $30 for reserved seating; for the late show, $30 and $60. ANN POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, STEPHEN, PH.D.
description: MITCHELL-Stephen, Ph.D. On Dec. 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Margaret. Loving father of Caitlin and Samantha. Cherished son of Stanley & the late Lillian. Brother of Richard. Dear nephew of Florence & Leah Lutzky. Service Sunday 10:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date.

title: Group of Countries Protests U.S. Change in Dumping Law
description: A group of countries led by Japan and the European Union filed a joint complaint with the World Trade Organization today against a new American law that would award the proceeds of anti-dumping sanctions to the affected industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, MARK
description: REINER-Mark. On December 21, 2000, succumbed from brain cancer. Beloved companion of Shigeo Haga. Noted casting director for Broadway shows, good friend to all in the industry. He will be missed. ''Break a leg,'' Mark. Service Friday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: As Whitman Goes to Texas, Her Stand-In Becomes Coy
description: The official silence surrounding Gov. Christie Whitman's political future lifted a bit today as the president of New Jersey's Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said she would be in Austin, Tex., on Friday.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially during the holiday season, and should be checked by telephone. Museum hours through New Year's Day may also vary and should be checked before visiting. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, DR. SAMUEL
description: WEBER-Dr. Samuel, passed away Thursday morning, December 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Martha, devoted father of Elizabeth Perlman, and Dr. Ellen Weber Showstack, and the late Richard, loving grandfather of Amy and Jill Perlman, father-in-law of Alvin, and Jon. Contributions to your favoritie charity. Services at ''The Riverside'', Friday, 9:45AM.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Having Style Pays Off for Venus Williams
description: Reebok is in love with Venus Williams, and is utterly certain that being a joyful, powerful tennis player and blossoming fashion symbol makes her worthy of a five-year, $40 million endorsement contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, EDWARD P.
description: COSTELLO-Edward P. A resident of Easthampton, NY died on December 20, 2000. He was 53. Mr. Costello was born on March 20, 1947 in the Bronx to Myrtle (Nelson) and the late Fabian Costello. He served in the US Armed Forces in Viet Nam. He was Senior Vice President at Barney Skanska Construction Company where he worked for the last 12 years. Mr. Costello is survived by his mother Myrtle Costello Hartmayer of the Bronx. He is also survived by a sister Cecilia Orlando and her husband Joseph of New Rochelle, and two brothers Bernard and Lawrence. Also surviving is a newphew Patrick Orlando and a niece Carol Ann Mills. Other survivors include 7 nieces and nephews. Visiting will be Friday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Lloyd Maxcy & Sons, Beauchamp Chapel, 16 Shea Pl, New Rochelle. A funeral mass is scheduled for Saturday at 10:00 AM at Holy Family Church. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Edward Costello Scholarship Fund, Ross School, 18 Goodfriend Drive, Easthampton, NY 11937.

title: Pops Staples, Patriach of the Staple Singers, Dies at 85
description: Roebuck (Pops) Staples, whose family gospel group, the Staple Singers, carried message songs to a huge pop audience, died on Tuesday at his home in Dolton, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He was 85.

title: A Farewell Salute To Mayor Lindsay
description: To the Editor:

title: Pint-Sized Cars Are Becoming Museum Pieces
description: A RECENT television commercial for miniature motorized toy cars asked parents, ''Don't you wish you'd had one as a child?''

title: Bush Is Warned Vouchers Might Hurt School Plans
description: President-elect George W. Bush, in a bipartisan meeting today with Congressional centrists, laid out educational proposals highlighting early literacy and school accountability but heard warnings that waging a legislative battle to funnel taxpayer money to private schools through vouchers could endanger his plans.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Pay-as-You-Go Plan For Car Insurance
description: FOR years, insurance companies have priced auto policies according to the risk factors that they can easily measure: the age, sex and marital status of the driver, the type of car and the owner's neighborhood. But technology has added to the list: companies can now tell how many hours the car is operated, at what times of day and on what kinds of roads.

title: Global Money Launderers
description: America's security is threatened by the spread of international crime cartels -- a dark side of globalization. A valuable new White House report documents how the collapse of the Soviet Union, the lowering of trade barriers and advances in telecommunications have increased the reach of crime syndicates, from Russia and Eastern Europe to Asia, Latin America and the diamond-rich war zones of Africa. The Clinton administration has led an international campaign to crack down on an essential component of the problem, money laundering. But American banks are themselves among the world's leading conduits for laundered funds. Unless America's own laundering laws are strengthened, international efforts to curtail the flow of dirty cash will have limited impact.

title: Devils Get a Chance To Avoid a Letdown
description: Some members of the Devils, including Coach Larry Robinson, said that their victory over Colorado a little more than two weeks ago was the biggest example of how well the Devils can play against a good team. Others said that the victory over Dallas on Wednesday night in the first rematch since the Stanley Cup finals last spring was a better barometer of judging the current status of the Devils.

title: One More Time for Cendant; Despite Sagging Shares, an Executive Plans to Rebuild
description: Can Henry R. Silverman do it all over again?

title: It's a Victory, But Don't Get Too Excited
description: Alumni Hall has served as a sanctuary of sorts for the St. John's basketball team under Mike Jarvis. Benefiting greatly from a carefully crafted schedule, the Red Storm always finds solace in returning to play in its campus gym, where ranked teams are banned and where the host team makes itself at home.

title: Paid Maternity Leave: The Other Gold Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Parisians are used to the idea of the baby bistro. A well-known restaurant achieves popularity, then spins off a smaller, more casual version of itself. Not a twin but a place with recognizable family features. It's taken awhile, but David and Karen Waltuck, the owners of Chanterelle, have brought forth Le Zinc, an unbuttoned, budget-price restaurant just a few blocks from the parent restaurant. It looks like a college hangout with whitewashed walls and a few unframed posters advertising avant-garde films or artists. There's a pounding sound track and, of course, a zinc bar. Le Zinc takes no reservations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOREA, CATHY D. (NEE DU MOULIN)
description: MOREA-Cathy D. (nee du Moulin) on December 20, 2000. Beloved wife of Jerome Morea for twentyfive years. Loving mother of Chris, Doug, and Carrie. Devoted daughter of Edward and Eleanor du Moulin. Wonderful sister to Richard and Ann du Moulin, Doug and Barbara Morea. Adoring aunt to Lora, Edward, Matt, Mark, and Alec. Dear niece of Julia Weisberg and Charles and Edith du Moulin. The famly expreses their deep felt thanks to all Cathy's supportive friends and relatives. Arrangements private. Memorial service December 23, 10:30 AM, United Methodist Church, 1515 Middle Neck Rd., Sands Point, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations to the ''Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation'', 30 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016, would be appreciated.

title: Buying Up The Future
description: The Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and the National Gallery of Art in Washington have acquired substantial holdings of work by Lee Friedlander directly from the artist's collection.

title: A Christmas Cavil
description: Here is a holiday question: When did it become acceptable to send Christmas cards with the name of the sender stamped, not handwritten, beneath the seasonal doggerel? The practice seems about as heartfelt as the ''Happy Holidays'' greetings found these days on the covers of pizza boxes.

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: BERNIE WORRELL. Grange Hall, 50 Commerce Street, at Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-5246. As the keyboardist in Parliament-Funkadelic, Bernie Worrell put the oozing, organic textures in the P-Funk groove machine. He can take credit for the slow-bubbling synthesizer bass lines that are still ubiquitous in hip-hop and rhythm-and-blues. He also has an encompassing knowledge of jazz, funk, gospel and rock that he tosses around lightly. For New Year's Eve, he is playing standards on a Hammond B-3 organ. There are seatings at 10, 10:30 and 11 p.m. Admission, $150, including dinner. JON PARELES

title: Era Closes at Rockefeller Center With $1.85 Billion Deal on Sale
description: A billionaire Chicago family has teamed up with Jerry I. Speyer, the New York developer, in a $1.85 billion deal to purchase Rockefeller Center, the 22-acre complex that stands as an international symbol of commerce and capitalism.

title: DEAL FOR PHONE STAKE
description: The French media and utility conglomerate Vivendi Universal S.A. said it had acquired a 35 percent stake in Maroc Telecom, Morocco's telephone monopoly, from the Moroccan government for 2.3 billion euros ($2.1 billion), and will gain access to the country's two million mobile phone users. Vivendi was said to be the only bidder.

title: YAHOO SEEKS TO BLOCK JUDGMENT
description: Yahoo has asked a federal judge to declare that a French court's recent judgment against the company cannot be enforced in the United States. That judgment, issued in November, ordered Yahoo to block Nazi-related material from appearing on auction sites in France or face daily fines of 100,000 francs, about $13,800. French law prohibits the sale and display of racist material. Yahoo, based in Santa Clara, Calif., filed the request in federal court in San Jose, Calif. The company argued that the order violated the First Amendment and that enforcement was inappropriate because the posted material was not intended for French viewers. Officials for the company have also argued that it is technically impossible to block French citizens from viewing material on Yahoo's United States site, www.yahoo.com. The fines will take effect 180 days after the judgment is served in the United States, which Yahoo officials expect in the next few weeks.

title: Foreign Affairs; Double Duty
description: There was a letter to the editor the other day about a column I wrote on Colin Powell, scolding me for suggesting that Mr. Powell needs to have a concept for how he will approach things like the Clinton team's 1995 bailout of Mexico. The letter writer argued that economics will be the Treasury secretary's responsibility, not the secretary of state's.

title: POWERGEN SAYS IT IS SELLING PLANT TO SCOTTISH POWER
description: PowerGen P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Rye House power station in Hertfordshire, England, to Scottish Power P.L.C. for about $:220 million ($325 million), and to buy back the plant's output until March 2002. The deal completes a program of asset sales PowerGen undertook to reduce debt after it agreed to buy LG&E Energy for $3.2 billion earlier this year.

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * HAMIET BLUIETT GROUP. Sista's Place, 456 Nostrand Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (718) 398-1766. What a sound Mr. Bluiett has on the baritone saxophone, and what ruckus he can kick up when he's stalking a good time. A longtime member of the World Saxophone Quartet, he has been a local favorite since the 70's; he is still hiring good young musicians and creating converts. At 9:30 p.m.; admission is $35 for one person, $50 for two. BEN RATLIFF

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Tuesday about the postponement of action on state legislation expanding access to public records omitted the name of the state. It was New Jersey.

description: RAPAPORT-Marsha. Mentor, colleague, friend. We and the community she served with excellence will remember her always. Senator Seymour Lachman and staff

title: Plan to Privatize 5 Schools Brings Confusion on All Sides
description: Julienne Elesperance was not sure how to interpret the news that Middle School 320, across the street from her apartment complex in Flatbush, Brooklyn, might be turned over to a private company.

title: Manhattan Election Is Finally Over, Too
description: After six weeks of uncertainty, State Senator Roy M. Goodman emerged as the victor in the hotly contested race for the East Side district he has represented in Albany for 32 years. His Democratic opponent, Liz Krueger, conceded that her slim lead had disappeared in a count of absentee ballots.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: 3Com 2nd Quarter Tops Forecast
description: The 3Com Corporation, the maker of computer-networking equipment, reported a fiscal second-quarter loss today that was narrower than the reduced forecast it issued earlier this month.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTDEUTSCHE LANDESBANK GIROZENTRALE, Dusseldorf, Germany, has agreed to buy Boullioun Aviation Services, the United States-based aircraft leasing unit of Deutsche Bank. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * JACKY TERRASSON QUARTET. Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. Influenced by Keith Jarrett and Ahmad Jamal -- from whom he got some of his touch, his socko dynamics and his practice of arranging for his group on the fly -- Mr. Terrasson is a great talent still in development; after his initial splash in the mid-90's, he has been fishing for a new angle. Perhaps his next album of jazzed-up French songs will do the trick, but he is always a satisfying live performer. The concert will be the New York part of a live jazz broadcast on WBGO-FM, ''Toast of the Nation,'' which drops in to sample the parties going on at jazz clubs around the country. The first package, from 8 to 10 p.m., includes one set of music; cover charge is $60 with a $10 minimum. The second runs from 11 p.m. to 2 a.m., including two sets of music, dinner and Champagne, for $95 with a $10 minimum. BEN RATLIFF

title: 255 Licenses Are Awarded For Low-Power FM Radio
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that 255 churches, schools and other local organizations had qualified for licenses to operate low-power FM radio stations. That is fewer than half the number that would have qualified if Congress had not curtailed the program recently at the request of broadcasters.

title: Ultimate Survivor, Man Against Nature
description: WHICH of us, while sitting at the edge of the ocean and gazing toward the horizon, hasn't shivered to imagine being drawn out to sea, getting lost and ending up a tiny forgotten speck in the middle of nowhere, shouting at the sky? As potentially panic-inducing as this vision may be, there's also something alluring about it. It's like standing on the edge of a cliff and imagining that fatal leap into the unknown. And in the heart-stopping ocean and desert-island scenes that constitute the core of ''Cast Away,'' Tom Hanks, in collaboration with the director Robert Zemeckis and the screenwriter William Broyles Jr., bring those visions thrillingly and hauntingly to life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, WILLIAM L.
description: RAND-William L. On December 19, 2000. Loving husband of the late Muriel. Dearest father of Kathleen and Ruben Oliva. Most cherished grandfather of Nicole Valerie. Founder and President of Rand Freres, Paris and William Rand Inc., N.Y. Friend and mentor to all who knew him. Also survived by many beloved nieces, nephews and friends. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday, Dec. 22 at 11:30 AM. Contributions to his Memory may be made to the Jewish Museum 1109 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Israel Acknowledges Hunting Down Arab Militants
description: Senior Israeli officials have acknowledged a new tactic of hunting down and killing individual Palestinian militants whom Israel holds responsible for planning attacks on or attacking its citizens.

title: A Murder in Kenya, Then a Search for the Back Story
description: THE CONSTANT GARDENER

title: New Chief for Canada's Central Bank
description: David A. Dodge, the newly appointed governor of Canada's central bank, says his mandate ''is to keep inflation low and stable,'' the legacy of his predecessor, Gordon A. Thiessen.

title: Informer's Part in Terror Case Is Detailed
description: When four men go on trial in 12 days in New York on charges they conspired with Osama bin Laden in the deadly bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa in 1998, one of the government's central witnesses could be a former American Army sergeant who pleaded guilty in October to assisting in the terrorist conspiracy.

title: Capitalism Comes to Russian Health Care
description: Everything important about Central Clinical Hospital is contained in a single fact: its Granovsky Street address, almost in the shadow of the Kremlin.

title: Investigation Exonerates Principal of Queens School Where Children Were Molested
description: The principal of a Queens elementary school where an intruder molested three pairs of children in a stairwell was cleared of any wrongdoing yesterday by the special investigation commissioner for New York City public schools.

title: Settlement Made by I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. agreed today to pay $300,000 to settle regulatory complaints related to allegations that a unit in Argentina paid a bribe to win contracts, the Securities and Exchange Commission said. The S.E.C. said the company filed misleading financial reports in 1994 and 1995 that failed to reflect the suspected bribe. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing under the settlement.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Rentals at Long-Vacant Westchester Site
description: Vacant for more than a decade, a former Revlon plant straddling the Tuckahoe-Yonkers border has sprung back to life as a luxury rental complex. Its developers say the Westchester project will offer apartments with the same amenities and services as they have developed in Manhattan, but with more space.

title: Ontario Journal; At California 'Swap Meet,' $1 Goes a Long Way
description: Latrice Rocha's eyes seemed to grow as big as grapefruits.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: GROOVE COLLECTIVE. Makor, 35 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 601-1000. There is nothing quite like a party given by this pioneering acid-jazz outfit for getting the unlikeliest people to loosen up and get down together. See how the band's famous vibe takes over this hot new Upper West Side hangout for the first time. Sharing the bill are Rhythmlove D.J.'s Neghino and Osiris, who mix ancient and modern music to form delectable beats. Open bar (wine and beer), hors d'oeuvres and a Champagne toast are included. Doors open at 8:30 p.m; tickets are $100 in advance, $120 at the door. ANN POWERS

title: EL PASO ENERGY TO SELL PIPELINES AS PART OF ACQUISITION
description: The Federal Trade Commission said in a draft consent decree yesterday that El Paso Energy would sell pipelines and other assets to win antitrust clearance for its proposed $840 million acquisition of the PG&E Corporation's gas business in Texas. El Paso Energy is the operator of the largest natural gas pipeline system in the country. Specifically, the commission's draft said that El Paso's interest in the Oasis Pipe Line would be sold to Utilicorp United and Dow Chemical; that PG&E's share of the Teco Pipeline would be sold to Duke Energy; and that PG&E's assets in the Matagorda Island offshore production area would go to Panther Pipeline. The order did not say how much the sales would yield.

title: Italian Politicians Are Squabbling Over TV Exposure
description: Ever since the media and business magnate Silvio Berlusconi entered politics, television -- particularly the three highly successful private networks he owns -- has been the main battleground of Italian political warfare.

title: Absentee Count Gives Goodman Victory in a Contested Election
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman emerged yesterday as the victor in the hotly contested election for the East Side district he has represented in Albany for 32 years, after his Democratic opponent conceded that her slim lead had disappeared in a count of absentee ballots.

title: MORGAN STANLEY AGREES TO BUY BRITISH BROKERAGE FIRM
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Quilter Holdings Ltd., a British brokerage firm, from CGNU P.L.C. and Credit Commercial de France, a unit of HSBC Holdings, for $:172 million ($254 million) in cash. Quilter, with 350 employees and nine offices in London, the Channel Islands and elsewhere in Britain, concentrates on serving affluent investors with 100,000 (pounds) or more to invest, and has 4.9 (pounds) billion under management.

title: Operation Ugly Duckling: Fighting Terrorism in Heels
description: Midway through ''Miss Congeniality,'' Special Agent Gracie Hart of the F.B.I. (Sandra Bullock) baits her co-worker Eric Matthews (Benjamin Bratt) with a sing-song schoolyard taunt: ''You want to kiss me. You want to hug me. You want to love me.''

title: Metro Business Briefing; JOB GROWTH CONTINUES
description: Despite the slowing national economy and the turmoil on Wall Street, New York City employers continued to hire workers at a blistering pace in November, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. Between October and November, the number of new jobs in the city rose by 33,100, or 0.9 percent, far faster than the statewide average increase of 0.4 percent. While some of the job growth came from stores hiring clerks for the holiday shopping season, big gains were also reported in business services, motion pictures and education. The financial sector also showed an increase, despite declining employment at banks as Chase Manhattan began its takeover of J. P. Morgan. The unemployment rate in the city was unchanged, but when adjusted for seasonal factors it edged up to 5.6 percent from 5.4 percent. The unemployment rate in the state also rose slightly, to 4.6 percent from 4.4 percent, as did the national average, to 4 percent from 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton

title: The Big City; Gabby Drivers Have Nothing On Regulators
description: JUST in time for holiday travel, the city's leaders have contemplated a question for drivers with cell phones: When you reach out and touch someone, is your car going to reach out and smash someone else?

title: INSIDE
description: A Gesture of Forgiveness

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: THE NEW DEAL, ULU, UNCLE SAMMY. Wetlands Preserve, 161 Hudson Street, TriBeCa, (212) 386-3600. Get your jam on three different ways at a show that highlights much of what's best about this friendly club. Uncle Sammy, in the lounge, and Ulu, first up on the main stage, offer top-notch takes on the jam-band jambalaya that mixes progressive rock with jazz, funk and whatever else seems interesting at the moment. Heading toward midnight, the New Deal takes over with its live reinvention of cutting-edge drum-and-bass grooves. This will not be an early evening for anyone. At 9 p.m.; tickets are $30. ANN POWERS

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 17
description: TOMORROW 4:15 P.M.

title: NEXTEL DROPS OUT OF FREQUENCY AUCTION
description: Shares of Nextel Communications Inc. rose $1.25, or 5.4 percent, to $24.25, after the nationwide wireless-telephone company controlled by Craig O. McCaw dropped out of bidding for new wireless transmission frequencies. The company dropped out of the auction late Wednesday. Nextel shares had been battered by investors concerned that the company was bidding too much for new wireless licenses, analysts said. The federal government is auctioning 422 licenses for frequencies that can be used to offer voice and data services.

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: STEPS AHEAD. Iridium, 48 West 63rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. Started by the vibraphonist Mike Mainieri in the late 70's, when it was just called Steps, this band was the hard-hitting post-bop fusion band of the 80's; its saxophonist, Michael Brecker, was probably the most influential saxophonist of the period (if we're talking about the number of jazz students who wanted to sound like him). Guest vocalist is Phillip Hamilton of the Pat Metheny Group. There are two sets: 7:30 p.m. (doors open at 6), for $95 a person, including three-course dinner, plus tax and tip, and 10:45 (doors open at 9:45), with four-course meal including Champagne toast, party favors and a jazz CD, for $169 a person. BEN RATLIFF

title: Fanfare for Copland, A Fervent Adventurer
description: To walk through ''Aaron Copland's America'' at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, on Long Island, is a considerable adventure. The exhibition is a biographical study of one of the best-loved American composers of the 20th century. But it is much more: a freewheeling, far-searching trawl through an America that, though vital to Copland, was not his only concern.

title: Movie Folk, It Turns Out, Are Subject to Venality
description: One of the guilty pleasures of David Mamet's Hollywood satire ''State and Main'' is the knowledge that you're being spoon fed the kind of nasty inside dish on movie people you will never find when ''Entertainment Tonight'' and ''Access Hollywood'' go on location. The ruthless prima donnas who scheme, bicker and whine their way through this amusing but brittle comedy emerge as exactly the sorts of connivers and crybabies you always suspected they might be.

title: Lucent Lowers Expectations For 3rd Time
description: In what has become an unwelcome routine, Lucent Technologies warned yesterday that it would lose more money than expected in the current quarter, the third time the company has revised its outlook for the period.

title: Robert Rauschenberg
description: 'Apogamy Pods'

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: THE FLESHTONES. Mercury Lounge, 217 Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Year in and year out, the Fleshtones have held on to the sound of 1960's garage rock, with its distortion-edged guitars and hoarsely exuberant vocals. Once it sounded like punk; now it's starting to sound like die-hard purism. For more back-to-basics rock, the Knoxville Girls and the Broke Revue are also on the bill. D.J. Rigrocker keeps things twanging between sets. At 8:30 p.m.; admission is $20. JON PARELES

title: DNA Fails to Win New Trial for Man on Death Row for Murder
description: New evidence from a DNA test was not enough today for a South Carolina man who has been on death row for 18 years for the murder of a elderly woman.

title: Presidential Real Estate
description: To the Editor:

title: BUCKING TREND, QWEST SAYS IT WILL MEET EARNINGS TARGET
description: At a time when many telecommunications companies are issuing earnings warnings, Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it expected to match or beat analysts' earnings forecasts of 14 cents a share for the fourth quarter. The company, based in Denver, said its newer equipment, lower costs and concentration on high-growth businesses like wireless communications and broadband Internet service spared it from the problems that competitors like SBC Communications and AT&T were experiencing. Qwest's stock gained $5.13, or 16 percent, closing at $37.50; it had fallen $5.25 a share Tuesday on concerns that regulatory delays were hampering its entry into long-distance service.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * BILLY BRAGG. Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. Billy Bragg, the nicest political radical on the rock 'n' roll block, has recently gained attention for his collaborations, both with Wilco on the ''Mermaid Avenue'' albums resurrecting lost Woody Guthrie songs, and with his own cooking band, the Blokes. But those who love Mr. Bragg in his spindly youth remember when he wandered the globe with just his booming voice and an electric guitar, howling out gems like ''The Milkman of Human Kindness.'' This evening harks back to those days, as Mr. Bragg performs solo, takes questions and requests from the audience, and maybe uses his wry British wit to illuminate what exactly happened in the United States this hectic election year. As a special treat, the wonderful young singer and songwriter Sarah Harmer opens the show. Doors open at 8 p.m. for a 9:30 show; tickets are $50. ANN POWERS

title: Latin; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * IBRAHIM FERRER, RUBEN GONZALEZ, OMARA PORTUONDO. Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070. The Buena Vista Social Club brought the classic Cuban son back to the world's attention with an alliance of extraordinary musicians from an older generation. Now, those musicians are headlining on their own. Ibrahim Ferrer is a dapper, old-fashioned crooner who serenely holds his own with a big band. Omara Portuondo is a torchy singer who imbues her songs with an aura of bygone romance. And Ruben Gonzalez is a pianist who can play neatly understated tunes or splash flamboyantly across the keyboard. At 8 p.m.; remaining tickets, $85 and $175. Also Dec. 29 and 30 at 8 p.m.; tickets are $35 to 60. JON PARELES

title: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: RESISTING THE RECOUNT -- A special report.; G.O.P.'s Depth Outdid Gore's Team in Florida
description: If Al Gore wants to appreciate the forces that defeated him in Florida over the last six weeks, he need not look much beyond the scene on Monday morning in the Senate chamber in Tallahassee: Gov. Jeb Bush and the state's entire Republican leadership presiding in triumph as Florida's 25 electoral votes were finally delivered to George W. Bush.

title: Mickey Mantle Jr., 47, Son Of Yankees Hall of Famer
description: Mickey Mantle Jr., who struggled with the expectations accompanying the son of a baseball icon and the travails that afflicted his family far from the public eye, died Wednesday at a hospital in Dallas. He was 47.

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: JAMES SPAULDING. Up Over Jazz Cafe, 351 Flatbush Avenue, near Seventh Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 398-5413. One of the regular figures in the Blue Note Records catalog of the 1960's and later a saxophonist you tended to see in David Murray's orbit, Mr. Spaulding has stayed the course of the experimental bebopper -- a guy who has plenty of use for Charlie Parker and Sun Ra, too, thanks very much. First set, 8:30 to 10 p.m (seating begins at 8), $40, including buffet; second 11:30 p.m. (seating begins at 11), $65, including buffet; both shows, $85. BEN RATLIFF

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: JIMMY SCOTT. Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. The ghostly cracks in Mr. Scott's high voice keep becoming more compelling or disturbing, depending on your sensibility. But he has been an anomalous special interest since the 1950's, and lately he has been stretching the boundaries of the pop songbook, covering music by people like Elvis Costello with as much integrity as he will do a Harold Arlen tune. There's an 8 p.m. show with a $50 cover a person at tables, plus a $20 food or drink minimum, or $30 a person at the bar including one complimentary drink; and an 11 p.m. show, with a $100 charge per person at tables plus a $20 minimum, or $50 a person at the bar with a free drink. BEN RATLIFF

title: POP AND MUSIC GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: KFC and Royal Philips Electronics surprise their longtime agencies with dismissals.
description: TWO big advertisers, KFC and Philips, unexpectedly dismissed longtime agencies yesterday in another sign -- as if one more were needed in this tumultuous year -- of the continuing ferment in competitive consumer product categories.

description: In Calligraphy, Science Versus Art

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: KENNY GARRETT QUARTET. Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, West Village, (212) 242-1785. Musicians hang from the rafters when Mr. Garrett plays here: though his recent records might not indicate it, he's one of the best around, an enormously gifted, communicative and fluent alto saxophonist with some of Coltrane's terrifying energy. At 9 and 11 p.m.; $50 a person cover, plus $25 minimum for the table. BEN RATLIFF

description: Sri Lankan troops opened a new offensive today against Tamil rebels in the northern part of the nation just a day after the rebels had declared a unilateral monthlong cease-fire, voicing the hope that the government would reciprocate and that the peace talks that broke off five years ago could resume.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a meeting between religious leaders and President-elect George W. Bush in which he said he was interested in easing strains with black voters referred incorrectly to one of his appointments. Mr. Bush's choice for national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, would be the second black person in the post, not the first.

title: New York Court Rules for Insurer on Year 2000 Claim
description: In the first major legal ruling on insurance claims for expenses incurred avoiding Year 2000 computer problems, a New York court has come down squarely on the side of the insurance industry.

title: New Partners Hope to Expand Harry Winston
description: Peter Lamm, the chairman and chief executive of Fenway Partners, a private equity company in New York, said he once invested in a family-owned Mexican frozen food business where ''everyone was clawing each other's eyes out.'' That, it seems, is just the way he likes it.

title: David Bowie With a Secret and a Power
description: The boys in ''Mr. Rice's Secret'' belong to a club that awards points to the members who manage the weirdest and riskiest achievements, like secretly videotaping a funeral. Someone deserves the grand prize for persuading David Bowie to participate in this minor drama, in which the adolescent Owen (Bill Switzer) has to deal with his own mortality. Mr. Bowie's presence adds a layer of creepiness to a project that feels like an after-school special from the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation with some youthful swearing thrown in -- a more serious version of ''South Park.''

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * ROSIE FLORES. Rodeo Bar, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-6500. Rosie Flores has situated herself at the junction of Tex-Mex, rockabilly and honky-tonk. That means singing about both broken hearts and the gumption to get over them. She has worked with the West Texas songwriter Butch Hancock and pulled the 1950's rockabilly singer Wanda Jackson out of retirement; with every collaboration, her own music gains depth and feistiness. At 10 p.m.; admission is free. JON PARELES

title: Carnegie Hall, House of Music and Intrigue
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Ball With a Doll, 1800's Style
description: One doesn't often think about America's early settlers at leisure, because so much has been written about their constant struggle to survive the inhospitable New World. But it turns out that the Colonists liked to dress up for parties, too.

title: U.P.S. Sponsorship Won't Be Renewed
description: The United Parcel Service said yesterday that it would not renew its global sponsorship with the International Olympic Committee for the 2002 Winter and 2004 Summer Games.

title: Sharp Production Cutbacks Are Announced by Ford
description: Joining its crosstown rivals in responding to a rapid deterioration in the auto market, the Ford Motor Company announced sharp production cutbacks today -- including the closing of 13 of its 18 North American factories during the third week of January -- and lowered its forecast of fourth-quarter earnings for the second time in three weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLANDER, CANTOR MENACHEM
description: HOLLANDER-Cantor Menachem. Born in Jerusalem, died in New York, buried in Israel. He brought us friendship and laughter and was a devoted, sweet singer of Israel. Cantors Avi Albrecht, Israel Singer and Motti Fuchs Rabbi Myron M. Fenster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINTON, MILT
description: HINTON-Milt. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Milt Hinton, distinguished jazz bassist, who shared his craft with our students for more that two decades as an instructor at Hunter College and Baruch College. Mr. Hinton conducted the Jazz Workshop at Baruch College from 1976 until 1995 and was awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Music in 1996 for his lifetime achievements. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Mona, and his family. Herman Badillo, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Jazz; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * ANDY BEY QUARTET. Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Blessed with a skyscraper of a voice -- it ranges from bass-baritone low notes to an agile falsetto -- Mr. Bey, once a singer with Horace Silver's band, has been making strong records since he emerged from the shadows of obscurity in the mid-90's. His control is awesome, and he's a good piano player, too; in his own self-effacing way, he's an intense performer. At 8 and 11 p.m.; admission is $35 to $175. BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, JOHN V.
description: LINDSAY-John V. Former Mayor of New York City, died Tuesday, December 19th in Hilton Head, SC. Mr. Lindsay was born in New York City on November 24, 1921 and was the son of the late George Nelson and Eleanor Vliet Lindsay. He attended Buckley and St. Paul's schools and was a graduate of Yale University and Yale Law School. During World War II he served on the USS Swanson as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. He was a partner in the law firm of Webster & Sheffield and also served as executive assistant to the Attorney General from 1955 to 1957. A member of the United States Congress from 1958 to 1964, he represented New York City's 17th Congressional District. He served two terms as New York City's Mayor from 1965 to 1973. Prior to retirement in 1995, he was a counsel to the law firm Mudge, Rose, Guthrie. After his time in office, Mr. Lindsay served as Chairman of the Board of Lincoln Center Theater for ten years and then retired as Chairman Emeritus and board member emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Lindsay moved to Hilton Head Island, SC, in November of 1999. He is survived by his wife, Mary; a son, John V. Lindsay, Jr.; three daughters, Katharine Lake, Margaret Picotte, and Anne Lindsay; two sons-in-law, Stephen Lake and Michael Picotte; a brother, Robert V. Lindsay; and grandchildren Jessica and Stephanie Lake and Nicole, Joseph, and Michelle Picotte. Memorial services will be held January 26th at 4 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Memorial contributions may be sent to the John V. Lindsay Fund, Lincoln Center Theater, 150 West 65th Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: 'Gladiator' and 'Traffic' Lead Globe Nominees
description: A studio epic that lavishly recreated ancient Rome and a small-scale independent ensemble drama about the drug trade drew the largest number of Golden Globe nominations today from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association in the awards competition that is the most visible, if not the most predictive, run-up to the Academy Awards.

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: ENON. Brownies, 169 Avenue A, at 11th Street, East Village, (212) 420-8392. Some bands rock; others lurch and sway and crunch. Enon includes Brainiac's guitarist and a rhythm section from Skeleton Key. Paranoia, lovers' quarrels and urban disorder all figure in its polymorphous songs, which veer from clattering minimal syncopations to melodic rock, never shying away from noise. Arab on Radar shares the bill. Tickets are $14 in advance, $16 at the door. Later, the Uniform and guest perform, with punk disc jockeys until dawn; admission is $5 after 1 a.m. Doors open at 10 p.m. JON PARELES

title: Pop, Rock and Blues; As 2001 Beckons, Noisemakers (From Funk to Salsa) Cavort
description: * MARTIN SEXTON. Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. Martin Sexton is a down-home virtuoso with a voice that can groan like an alternative rocker, slide like a soul man or leap up to a pearly falsetto. Singing about restlessness and love while he picks syncopations on his guitar, he can turn an ordinary song into a jazzy showcase, and a good one into a transmission from the heart. At 10:30 p.m., with doors opening at 9; tickets are $35, including buffet and Champagne toast. JON PARELES

title: EATING OUT
description: Warmth and Gusto

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Accused of Discrimination, Clothing Chain Settles Case
description: When she came to work at The Children's Place, a national chain of retail children's clothing stores, Amanda Berube said, her superiors told her that to prevent theft, she should follow black customers as they browsed. They also told her, she said, to withhold large shopping bags from such customers and to refrain from inviting them to apply for store credit cards or telling them about sales.

title: A Gay Pagan Paradise, Snatched Away in Youth
description: ''Before Night Falls'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: The Knicks Are All Talk But Have No Answers
description: The Knicks like to talk about their ability to rally when a situation is at its bleakest. They say that they have resiliency, that they always follow a dreadful loss or a bad stretch of games with an impressive victory. The talk is beginning to sound like the idle chatter of a team without answers.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Too Beautiful to Be a Fight and Much Too Graceful to Be Dangerous
description: Two men, dressed in baggy whites, face each other and crouch in front of a berimbau player, who has begun a rhythmic melody. The men clasp hands and bow their heads as if in prayer, then slowly spin away on their heads and hands, tumbling into the middle of the floor. One arcs into a handstand, the other rolls on his shoulders around and up and over. My husband and I watch from the back of a crowd that claps and sings in accompaniment.

title: OPEL CHIEF SAID TO BE LEAVING
description: Robert Hendry, chief executive of Adam Opel A.G., the German unit of General Motors, will leave the company soon, according to Klaus Franz, one of the 10 employee representatives who sits on Opel's supervisory board. Mr. Franz said he did not know exactly when Mr. Hendry would depart. Mr. Hendry, above, has drawn criticism for Opel's mounting losses and dwindling market share since he took over in 1998. The supervisory boards of German companies are equally divided between company management and workers, and have the power to replace top executives.

description: PATTI SMITH. Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Don't call her the Guy Lombardo of punk rock, but it is becoming clear that this revered poet likes a good tradition. This will be Patti Smith's third consecutive New Year's Eve concert at the Bowery Ballroom. It happens to be her birthday party, too. What might be different this time? Fine new material from ''Gung Ho'' (Arista), her latest album with her hot band; a few brilliant new rants inspired by her favorite radical, Ralph Nader; and the possibility of surprise guests. Michael Stipe has popped the bubbly with Ms. Smith in the past. At 9 p.m.; tickets are $50. Organic Grooves plays at 1:30 a.m.; admission is $20. ANN POWERS

Maceo Parker was the alto saxophonist who drove the horn section in Mr. Brown's groundbreaking J. B.'s; then he went on to do the same job for George Clinton's Parliament-Funkadelic. His group knows the secrets of getting on the good foot. Soulive, a funk-jazz keyboard trio friendly to dancers, is the opening act. At 7 p.m.; tickets are $27.50 until Dec. 30, $30 on New Year's Eve. At 11 p.m., tickets are $57.50 in advance until Dec. 30, $70 on New Year's Eve. Also Dec. 30 at 9 p.m.; tickets are $27.50 in advance, $30 at the door. JON PARELES

title: A Lady Who Turns Heads And Chops Them Off, Too
description: ''Princess Turandot'' begins as a shadow play. The silhouette of the princess appears, holding a little man-doll. Then, with a pair of scissors, she delicately snips off his head. ''Oops!'' she laughs. Part Balinese puppet show, part vaudeville act, part commedia dell'arte, part Chinese opera, part circus and part game show, the Blue Light Theater's production of ''Princess Turandot,'' written and directed by Darko Tresnjak, concerns a princess with a predilection for decapitating men and mounting their skulls on poles.

description: The Florida Supreme Court got in the last judicial word on the recount, ruling 5 to 2 that the State Legislature should develop a standard for counting ballots in order ''to secure the fundamental right to vote.''

description: President-elect George W. Bush, ending a fast-paced week of organizing his cabinet, today selected John Ashcroft, one of the Republican Party's leading social conservatives, as the next attorney general.

title: LUKOIL POSTS PROFIT
description: Russia's biggest oil company, Lukoil Holding, reported financial results using Western accounting standards for the first time, a step long sought by investors. For the first half of 2000, Lukoil said its net profit came to $1.45 billion, or $2 a common share. Lukoil shares rose 6.2 percent on the RTS stock exchange in Russia today to close at 240.46 rubles ($8.60). Last month, Lukoil Holding purchased a chain of 1,300 gas stations in the United States, most of them in the Northeast, in a move analysts said was aimed more at burnishing its image than bolstering profits. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections

While he remains the Clinton administration's ambassador at large for counterterrorism, he is no longer deputy assistant secretary of state in the Bureau of International Organizations.

title: Nasdaq Soars To Finish Off Brutal Week
description: The Nasdaq composite index jumped 7.6 percent yesterday as bargain-hunting investors snapped up technology stocks that had dropped sharply in recent weeks.

description: CHARM CITY is in an uproar: the Baltimore Ravens are in the playoffs.

title: OCTOBER PAYMENTS TO RETIREMENT FUNDS MISSED
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. failed to make some payments to worker retirement funds in October and is trying to refinance a $100 million loan, as it enters the slow winter season with less cash than last year. A spokesman for the airline said that it had missed payments to the funds before and was allowed to do so under its union contracts. Still, the union representing machinists at T.W.A. told its members that it was considering taking legal action against the airline over the payments. T.W.A. had almost $600 million in long-term debt outstanding on Sept. 30, with more than a third of it coming due this year and next, and has not posted an annual profit since 1988. It filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection twice in the 1990's.

title: AFTER LONG FIGHT, U.N. AGREES TO CUT DUES PAID BY U.S.
description: After weeks of bitter negotiations, members of the United Nations agreed in principle today to reduce American dues for the first time in more than a quarter century. If accepted by Congress, the deal will remove the primary irritant between the United Nations and Washington just as a new administration prepares to take over.

title: Two Are Killed in Blaze
description: Two people were killed and two others critically injured after a fire broke out last night in an apartment building in Washington Heights, fire officials said.

title: LEVITZ SET TO EMERGE FROM CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY
description: Levitz Furniture Inc. said yesterday that it expected to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection on Dec. 31 under a plan approved by the court that would effectively combine it with a rival furniture retailer, the Seaman Furniture Company. The two chains will continue to operate separately, though many administrative functions would be shared, and Seaman will manage Levitz's stores on the East Coast as well as its own. Marketing, product selection and inventory for Seaman's 51 stores and some of Levitz's 65 stores will be combined to cut costs, the companies said in court papers. Levitz's principal creditor, Resurgence Asset Management, which also owns Seaman, will be the largest shareholder in a new holding company for the two chains created under the plan.

title: Completing Yugoslavia's Revolution
description: In September, citizens impatient with the misrule of Slobodan Milosevic elected a new president of Yugoslavia, Vojislav Kostunica, and eventually forced Mr. Milosevic to relinquish power. Today many of the same voters have a chance to complete the revolution in Belgrade by electing a new leadership team for the government of Serbia, Yugoslavia's dominant republic and long Mr. Milosevic's primary power base.

title: Bombing at Rome Paper
description: A reported right-wing terrorist set off a bomb outside the office of the left-wing newspaper Il Manifesto in central Rome this afternoon, the police said. The attack, in which the bomber was badly wounded, was carried out four days after the police found a bomb on the roof of the cathedral in Milan.

title: A Hacker May Have Entered Egghead Site
description: Egghead.com Inc., an Internet retailer of computers, electronics and sporting goods, with 3.62 million registered users, said today that customer credit card data might have been stolen by a hacker earlier this week.

title: Rich Nations Will Forgive Debts of 22 Of the Poorest
description: The United States, Japan and European and other industrial powers have agreed to forgive loans to 22 of the world's poorest countries this year, fulfilling a promise to accelerate debt relief and to give a token of the West's unprecedented prosperity to the poor.

title: Delta Petroleum in Deal
description: The Delta Petroleum Corporation, an oil and natural gas exploration company, said yesterday that it had canceled a $49.5 million agreement to buy stakes in about 680 oil and natural gas wells from the Saga Petroleum Corporation. Instead, Delta will buy a single gas property in New Mexico for $2.1 million in cash and $600,000 in stock.

title: JUDGE REJECTS CORAM HEALTHCARE REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: A bankruptcy court judge has rejected the reorganization plan filed by the Coram Healthcare Corporation and a related company, Coram Inc., with the support of lenders holding its principal debt, the company said yesterday. The announcement did not cite a reason for the judge's rejection, and the company said it was not prepared to elaborate. As filed, the plan would have given all of Coram's equity to its debt holders and left nothing for shareholders. Coram said its operating units had continued operating as usual, had maintained positive cash flow and had kept current with trade creditors. Coram sought protection in August because it could not make payments on $251 million in debt due or redeemable in May 2001.

A newspaper, The Australian, said a unit of the Vodafone Group of Britain had offered at least $9.9 billion for Optus; neither company would comment on the report. The Telecom Corporation of New Zealand has also expressed interest. Cable and Wireless of Britain, which owns 52.5 percent of Optus, has said it is willing to sell some holdings.

title: RAISING CASH FOR GROWTH
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc., the Japanese mobile phone giant, has approached bankers about a possible sale of as much as 1 trillion yen ($9 billion) worth of new shares as it seeks ways to finance global expansion. The company is also considering listing its shares in the United States. Speculation about a big NTT DoCoMo offering has helped depress the Japanese stock market because of fears that there is not enough investor appetite to absorb all the new shares.

With $1.7 billion in worldwide sales last year -- $1.1 billion in the United States alone -- the drug is Bristol-Myers Squibb's top-selling product. But it is also a medicine with an inferiority complex.

title: DONNELLEY REDUCES FORECAST FOR 2000 PROFIT AGAIN
description: The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a major commercial printer, reduced its forecast for 2000 profits for the second time yesterday, citing rising costs and lower-than-expected sales at its direct-mail unit. Donnelley said that it would earn $2.15 to $2.20 a share this year, some 10 to 15 cents less than it had previously thought. The company said higher transportation and fuel costs hurt its logistics business, which delivers magazines, catalogs and packages to local post offices to help customers cut costs and delivery times. Donnelley had been counting on that unit to propel its growth but the business has not lived up to expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, JAMES, JR.
description: O'MALLEY-James, Jr., died on December 20, 2000 after a short illness. Born on August 13, 1910 in New York City. Distinguished by his many achievements in the legal profession and public service, and admired for his integrity, high principles and grace. A graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School, he was assistant deputy district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey. A Lt. Comdr. in the Navy during WWII, he became the Officer-in-Charge of the Division of the U.S. Army-Navy War Crimes Office with special executive assignments under Maj. Gen. William Donovan in O.S.S. In 1947, he became a member of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, where he practiced utilities and administrative law as well as leading the firm's representation of LLoyd's of London in the U.S. In addition, he was appointed by Governor Rockefeller to serve a three-year term as Waterfront Commissioner of NY Harbor in 1959; and he was named to the Board of Advisors of the Naval War College in 1982. Devoted husband of the late Marcella Butler for 56 years, he is survived by his son, Malcolm Butler O'Malley, and his daughter, Anne Bigelow O'Malley. Contributions may be made in his name to Interfaith Neighbors, 210 E. 86th St., N.Y., NY 10028. A memorial service will be held on Monday, January 22nd at 10:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave., N.Y., NY at 66th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: NETCREATIONS GETS OFFER THAT TOPS ONE BY DOUBLECLICK
description: NetCreations Inc., a company that manages and markets e-mail address lists, said yesterday that it had received a cash buyout offer of $108.7 million, topping an all-stock bid that DoubleClick Inc. made Oct. 3.
