title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUMMER, HELLEN I.
description: PLUMMER-Hellen I. Mother of Pulitzer Prize winning poet James I. Merrill and former wife of Merrill Lynch founder Charles E. Merrill, died December 18, 2000 in Atlanta, GA., at the age of 102. Born Hellen Ingram in 1898, Mrs. Plummer was raised in Jacksonville, FL. After graduating from high school, she worked as society editor of a Jacksonville newspaper from 1917 until 1922 when, as publisher and editor, she began her own biweekly paper of social happenings in Jacksonville and Miami. In the mid-1920s, she studied at Columbia University in New York and became an almostadopted daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conde Nast of publishing fame. She learned to know many of their celebrated friends, including Charlie Chaplin and Katherine Hepburn. In 1925, she married Charles Merrill and, in the following year, gave birth to James. For some years, they lived in South Hampton. Among her house guests from New York's creative community were such notables as George Gershwin, who, during one summer there, wrote the score for ''Babes in Arms.'' Mrs. Plummer's marriage to Mr. Merrill ended in divorce in 1939. Mr. Merrill died in 1955. During World War II, Mrs. Plummer served as an American Red Cross volunteer in the Pacific Theater. Stationed on Guam, she was in charge of receiving and assigning some 1,200 Red Cross girls who passed through her depot. Mrs. Plummer remarried in 1950. Her second husband Brigadier General William L. Plummer and Mr. Merrill, both U.S. Army Air Corps pilots, had flown together in World War I. In World War II, General Plummer was in command of Orly Field in Paris. After the war, he was assigned to accompany Winston Churchill on his tour of the U.S. General Plummer died in 1969. James Merrill's book of poetry ''Nights and Days'' received the 1967 National Book Award. His 1976 Pulitzer Prize was for ''Divine Comedies.'' He died in 1995. Mrs. Plummer was a charter member of the Junior League of Jacksonville. She was a member of the Piedmont Driving Club in Atlanta and the Everglades Club in Palm Beach. Mrs. Plummer is survived by her step-children Doris Merrill Magowan (Mrs. Robert A.) of San Francisco, Charles E. Merrill, Jr., of Boston and Betty Plummer Potts (Mrs. Thomas B.) of Anniston, AL. A memorial service is scheduled for 11:00AM Saturday, January 20th at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip, 2744 Peachtree Road, N.W., Atlanta, GA. The Rt. Rev. Charles J. Child, Jr., will officiate. Prior to the service, beginning at 10:00 AM, the family will receive friends in the Gould Room. In memory of Mrs. Plummer, contributions may be made to the Memorial Fund, the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip. For information H.M. Patterson & Son, Spring Hill Chapel (404) 876-1022.

title: Stripping Garments but Not the Masks: Sex as the Ultimate Trickery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, MAYOR JOHN V.
description: LINDSAY-Mayor John V. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of John V. Lindsay, Mayor of New York City (1966-1973), member, U.S. Congress (1959-1966) and Director Emeritus of Lincoln Center. As Mayor, John Lindsay served ex officio on the Lincoln Center Board from 1966 to 1974 and he returned to the Board from 1984 to 1991 as the designee of the Lincoln Center Theater which he served as Chairman throughout that time. This beloved man of many achievements and unparalleled style served the people of New York City wisely & well throughout his career. We at Lincoln Center are grateful for his crucial role in ushering in a whole new and vibrant era for Lincoln Center Theater, one that extends to this day. We extend our deep sympathy to his wife, Mary and their children, Katharine L. Lake, Margaret Picotte, Anne R. Lindsay, John V. Lindsay, Jr. and to their grandchildren. description: The right-wingers who were beginning to feel like wallflowers at George W. Bush's cabinet dance can stop complaining. Mr. Bush, who made his earlier selections from his party's ideological center, threw a big bouquet to the ultraconservatives yesterday when he chose John Ashcroft, the recently deposed Republican senator from Missouri, for the post of attorney general. The nomination later in the day of Christie Whitman, the moderate Republican governor of New Jersey, to run the Environmental Protection Agency tilted the overall composition of Mr. Bush's early choices back toward the center. But that could not mute the widespread dismay over Mr. Bush's troubling choice of Mr. Ashcroft.

description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; A community of lay Catholics, working mostly in small groups, seeks to end the death penalty.
description: Mario Marazziti, a 48-year-old Italian journalist, was bustling around Manhattan last weekend amid the throngs of shoppers and wide-eyed tourists. His goal, however, was not to find the perfect gift or to admire the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center or to take in a performance of the ''Messiah'' or even to scout out projects for the official Italian television channel, of which he is a senior manager.

title: The Money to Teach the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAL FOR DUTCH UTILITY
description: In its second expansion move in a month, the Spanish power producer Grupo Endesa agreed to acquire Regionale Energie Maatschappij Utrecht (REMU), a Dutch utility, for 1 billion euros ($1.06 billion) from the local governments that own it. The deal will increase Endesa's share of the Dutch electricity and gas market to 9 percent. REMU serves about 500,000 customers in Utrecht province. In November, Endesa bought 30 percent of SNET, a French electric utility. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UCHIMA, TOSHIKO
description: UCHIMA-Toshiko, age 82, on December 18. Beloved wife of the late Ansei, loving mother of Anju and wife Yoko, proud and adoring grandmother of Maya and Lenn, and dear sister of Teruyuki Aohara and Sachiko Ashihara. The widely esteemed artist of many exquisitely crafted box assemblages exhibited in New York and in Japan over many years, evoking cherished times, places and people, real and imagined, steeped in romance, fancy, love and wit. She was admired for her grace, sincerity and unwavering appreciation of life's beauty and wonder and for her uncommon resolve, courage and dedication. She will be especially missed for her great warmth and devotion to the many whom she held dear.

title: SAINSBURY, BRITISH SUPERMARKET CHAIN, SELLS HOMEBASE
description: J Sainsbury P.L.C., the big British supermarket chain, agreed yesterday to sell control of its Homebase home-improvement chain to two buyers for $:969 million ($1.4 billion). Schroder Ventures, a private equity firm, will pay $:750 million for a majority stake in Homebase, and Kingfisher, a competing retailer, will pay $:219 million. Sainsbury will retain an 18 percent stake in the Homebase chain, and said it planned to sell some of the real estate it leases to Homebase separately. When Sainsbury first sought a buyer for Homebase in August, it said it hoped to get $:1 billion for it. Three other British home-improvement chains, Great Mills, Wickes and Focus Do It All, have changed hands this year.

title: E-Mail Warning About Virus Is Hoax, Health Officials Say
description: The warning leaps out of the in-box like an electronic harbinger of doom. ''Very scary. Be careful,'' reads the e-mail message. ''This is an alert about a virus in the original, one that affects your body, not your hard drive. There have been 23 confirmed cases of people attacked by the Klingerman virus, a virus that arrives in your real mail box, not your e-mail in-box.''

title: Timeless Tale Is Just the Gift For Governor
description: THIS is the season when some newspaper columnists, a breed known for generosity, bestow gifts on public figures who gave the year sizzle and chuckles.

title: Moderates Belong in the Cabinet Room
description: While litmus tests are fine in chemistry, they are not fine for selecting members of a president's cabinet or nominees to the United States Supreme Court.

title: LA-Z-BOY WARNS OF LOWER SALES AND PROFITS IN QUARTER
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., the furniture maker known for its recliners, warned yesterday that sales and profits in the quarter ending Jan. 27 will fall short of analysts' forecasts. The company said that because of sluggish sales, higher interest rates and slower payments from retailers, it would earn 25 cents to 31 cents a share in the quarter, down from 41 cents in the period a year earlier. Analysts had expected 40 cents a share in the current quarter.

description: ''The world of today is in desperate need of a mother,'' whispered Prof. Mark Miravalle as he sat behind his desk at Franciscan University in Steubenville, Ohio, carefully fingering a string of rosary beads.

description: MADSEN-Mary. On December 21, 2000. Survived by four children Joseph Madsen, Rose Marie Walsh, Frank Madsen and Theodore Madsen; grandchildren Kenneth Walsh, Kim; five great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Abroad at Home; A Christmas Carol
description: Not many Americans will recognize the names of Dorothy Gaines and Kemba Smith on the list of people whose federal prison sentences President Clinton has just commuted. But they should be known because their stories challenge our vision of justice.

title: Conflicting Images of Pediatrician in Molestation Case
description: For 35 years, Dr. Stuart Copperman was one of the most prominent and trusted physicians in this tightknit community on Long Island's South Shore. The onetime president of the Nassau Pediatric Society, he was a familiar figure at his temple, a man who saved the lives of neighborhood children, a doctor whom former patients took their children and grandchildren to.

title: Health Club Chain in Move
description: The Cannons Group, the British health club chain best known for having Diana, the late Princess of Wales, as a customer, said today that it had begun a strategic review that might lead to a sale of the company. Its shares rose 13 percent to 128.5 pence, giving the company a market capitalization of $:215.1 million ($316.4 million).

title: News Analysis: A Balancing Act of Sorts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  By selecting Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri and Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey for high-level administration posts, President-elect George W. Bush attempted a careful balancing act today, reaching out to both the conservative and moderate wings of his fractious party.

title: Why Banks Can Avoid A Hard Landing
description: THE volume of problem corporate loans is rising. Individual debt levels are at record highs. And the economy is slowing. So why are investors so sweet on bank stocks?

title: Sheep May Not Safely Graze in Greenlawn
description: MARY had a little lamb, and Maria Hren-Wragge has two. But with the fate of her small flock now in the hands of Huntington town officials, Ms. Hren-Wragge, who lives in Greenlawn, is hoping she can keep them.

title: Chelsea Under Wraps
description: I assumed that an article titled ''Chelsea Under Wraps'' would reflect something of substance, like a conversation with Chelsea. However, the title appears to have been a tease. Furthermore, why on earth would an intelligent woman who does not seem ego-driven want anything to do with the news media, given the pain her family was subjected to. Impeachment may be history, but emotional scars don't heal so quickly. More credit to Chelsea for not behaving like Patti Reagan and others who have publicly berated their families. If and when she has something to say, she will.

title: MUSIC: Listening Across the Generational Divide; A Guilty Mom Confesses A Pleasure
description: FORGIVE me, father, and, while I'm at it, might as well throw in my mother, siblings, daughter and all other relatives, both immediate and those I see only at weddings, bar mitzvahs and unveilings. Forgive me, friends I partied with in college, all of whom will view the transgression I am about to reveal as a result of severe head trauma.

title: TAX DISPARITY
description: New Jerseyans paid $2,342 more per person in federal taxes last year than they got in return, according to a review of state and federal budgets by the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. The state was among 19 that pay more than they get back, with a deficit second only to Connecticut's $2,840 a person. New Mexicans led the nation by getting back $3,994 than they paid. Karen DeMasters

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SHORT STORIES: Five Decades, by Irwin Shaw. (University of Chicago, $20.) These 63 tales by Irwin Shaw (1913-84) cover an impressive amount of narrative and geographic terrain, featuring characters as varied as Brooklyn gangsters, deputy sheriffs in New Mexico, racetrack habitues and bartenders. ''His is a primitive skill possessed by very few sophisticated men,'' William Goldman said here in 1978. ''He asks only that we sit quietly in the cave, and build the fire high to frighten the wild animals outside. And just listen.'' The same publisher has reissued Shaw's first novel, The Young Lions ($18), which tells of the wartime experiences of three soldiers -- an Austrian Nazi and two Americans -- and their climactic meeting in a Bavarian forest. In 1948 our reviewer, Marc Brandel, called this ''an immensely interesting, entertaining and moving book.''

title: Safety First in Sydney-Hobart
description: For many Australian sailors, Christmas Day is a time to relax with their families and perhaps fire up the backyard barbecue. It is also the day to make sure the sea bag is packed and all the sails are aboard. For on Dec. 26 each year -- Boxing Day -- one of the world's great ocean races sets out from Sydney bound for Hobart, Tasmania, some 630 miles to the south. The Sydney-Hobart Race is Australia's premier offshore event.

title: A Little Something for the Teacher
description: WHEN the public schools let out for the holiday break, teachers across Westchester County were dragging shopping bags full of goodies across faculty parking lots. What was in those bags? Certainly, the usual -- mugs, perfumed soaps and any item embossed with an apple. But some teachers bring home more lavish items.

title: Sauteeing the Fruit First, for Remarkable Desserts
description: WHEN I was planning Thanksgiving dinner this year I complied with the family's request for apple pie. But I decided to try something different.

title: From the Page . . .
description: Following is a scene from Edith Wharton's ''House of Mirth'' and, below it, the script's treatment of it for Terence Davies's film.

title: The Nuts and Bolts of Bipartisanship
description: With the election now settled, it is time to turn from the pursuit of power to its constructive use. It is unrealistic to expect a new era of bipartisanship. But is it too much to ask for one good year?

title: From Afar, Christmas Remembered; The Ultimate Test: Go Shopping
description: HONG KONG -- I got to know my future wife, Angela Tung, while Christmas shopping in Manhattan nine years ago. Or, more precisely, she got to know me. The excursion was her idea, a low-pressure way to extend a relationship in its early blush.

title: Let's Hear It For the Year Of the Boob
description: BACK at Thanksgiving, a homemade apple pie we brought to my parents' feast was met with a noticeable lack of enthusiasm. People who tried to eat it immediately began calling for a canine disposal unit -- ''Here, Spot! Here, Fritzi!'' -- even though they knew my parents owned no dog.

title: A Guide to Baltimore Remembers Its Heritage
description: ''Discover Baltimore: A Guide to African American Attractions'' is a new, free 34-page guide from the Baltimore Area Convention and Visitors Association. It includes landmarks, a listing of companies that offer heritage tours, a calendar of events -- including the Juneteenth Jubilee on June 19, commemorating the end of slavery -- and shops, nightclubs and restaurants.

title: Hands Off!
description: CRISTINA NOON of Copiague recently received a gift: an adapter that would allow her to talk hands-free on her cell phone while driving. She returned the item unopened.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Manorhaven; An Affordable Enclave on the Waterfront
description: IN an area on the North Shore of Long Island where expensive owner-occupied single-family houses are the norm, the waterfront village of Manorhaven is a notable exception. In its tightly packed area, covering less than half a mile, the bite-sized village is a domain of one-family and even, very frequently, two-family houses on 40-by-100 foot lots, and rentals are plentiful.

description: IT'S taken 211 years, but Connecticut has finally produced a president of the United States.

title: A World in a Raised Eyebrow, but How to Film It?
description: EDITH WHARTON published her first important novel, ''The House of Mirth,'' in 1905, when the movies were still silent nickelodeon peep shows. She finished her last short story and died in 1937, just two years before the annus mirabilis of ''Gone With the Wind,'' ''The Wizard of Oz,'' ''Beau Geste,'' ''Dark Victory,'' ''Goodbye, Mr. Chips,'' ''Gunga Din,'' ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' ''Ninotchka,'' ''Stagecoach'' and ''Wuthering Heights.'' Yet the advent of film as a rival narrative mode to fiction seems to have left her work absolutely untouched. Thank God. If she had felt honor-bound to observe the quasi-cinematic rule of ''show, don't tell,'' as fiction writers have ever since the movies started taking over, it would have put her out of business.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARKEY, SUSAN
description: SHARKEY-Susan. December 24, 1995 Always in our thoughts. Barnett

title: DELAWARE RIVER AUTHORITY
description: The 2001 budget of Delaware River Port Authority, the joint New Jersey and Pennsylvania government agency responsible for four bridges and a commuter rail line linking Philadelphia with the Camden County suburbs, will be $95.1 million, an 11 percent increase over this year. The authority expects to build a profit-making parking lot under the Philadelphia portion of its Benjamin Franklin Bridge next year. Bill Kent

title: INVESTING WITH: Robert L. Rodriguez; FPA Capital Fund
description: HERE'S a holiday gift for stalwart value investors: On Jan. 1, the longtime value guru Robert L. Rodriguez will reopen his $375 million FPA Capital fund, which has been closed to new investors since 1995.

title: Clinton Sends Mideast Sides Back Home With Deadline
description: The five-day search for common ground between Israeli and Palestinian negotiators on the toughest issues dividing them ended here today without a breakthrough, and President Clinton sent the parties back home, giving them until Wednesday to say whether progress could be made.

title: For Asbury Park, an Unflattering Role
description: AS Bruce Springsteen was predicting the rebirth of his beloved Asbury Park at benefit concerts he gave here last week, the cast and crew of ''City by the Sea'' -- a movie with Robert De Niro, set in a depressed seaside resort -- were starting to leave Asbury Park after a month and a half of shooting.

title: Wolff Making a Return
description: Hugh Wolff, who preceded Zdenek Macal as the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, plans to start the new year with four concerts around the state -- some of which may be sold out. His program bears more than one reference to newness, beginning with the new ''Overture in Feet and Meters'' by Aaron Jay Kernis, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer.

title: Back to the Drawing Board
description: After expansion plans for its building in the John-Witherspoon neighborhood were rejected, the Arts Council of Princeton is considering other sites for a new arts center. The Princeton Regional Planning Board ruled in a 6-to-5 vote that the new center would be disruptive to the community.

title: Putnam Judge Gives Dreary Court Space Happy-Room Treatment
description: TO be listed clearly in the good-deed-doers column: Judge Thomas Scuccimarra of Putnam County Court, who, despite having to leave office at the end of this year, has turned a dreary family waiting room in the Putnam County Courthouse here into a sunburst of blue skies and rainbows with $150 worth of paint he bought himself.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-24-00; Present Tense
description: They say that this giving season won't be quite as bountiful as it has been in recent years. Shopper confidence has flagged, apparently. But down where the giving gets got, under the Christmas trees and in the counting rooms of favored charities, the anguish will be minimal. Last year, for example, we spent $186 billion on the gift exchange. And in 1997, the most recent year for which we have a figure on the charity exchange, itemized donations came to $109 billion, for a return of $99 billion in tax deductions. We probably can't do worse in 2000.

title: Canadiens Showing Some Tarnish
description: In the glorious 91 years of the Montreal Canadiens, few days were more humbling than last Monday. In the afternoon, the Molson brewery announced in a cryptic news release that it had abandoned its target date of Dec. 31 to sell the hockey team. Molson said it would need ''the time necessary to conclude a deal that is in the best interests of our shareholders and our fans.''

title: New Wireless Network Set for Iona
description: ON a recent Sunday night, Sarah Shinabery, a junior at Iona College in New Rochelle, went to the McSpedon Computer Lab to work on a paper about Al Gore's economic proposals. Like him, she was running out of time. Yet like many facing the finals rush, she had to wait in line for a computer with Internet access.

title: Streetscapes /Lafayette Avenue Presybyterian Church, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; A Shelter for Runaway Slaves, a Bastion of Activism
description: IN the 1860's, the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church sheltered runaway slaves in its basement. More than a century later, the church, at South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, continues its tradition of social activism. Now its leader, the Rev. David Dyson, needs to raise money to cope with the problems of age in his Romanesque-style building, which includes an array of magnificent Tiffany stained-glass windows.

title: DOBBS FERRY: SCHOOL BOND PASSES
description: Dobbs Ferry voters endorsed the school district's revised construction bond proposal by a ratio of more than 2-to-1. The vote on the $4.7 million bond was 627 to 299. The bond is a supplement to a $22 million bond that had been approved in 1998 to add classroom and athletic space to the district's buildings, as well as renovate existing buildings. An $8.7 million bond proposal presented last April was rejected. Construction is expected to start next summer, with the elementary school additions scheduled to be completed by September 2002, and the rest of the project slated to be finished by September 2003. Merri Rosenberg

title: Helen Feingold, Noah Kaplan
description: Helen Anne Feingold, the daughter of Susan Feingold and Dr. Alfred Feingold of Coral Gables, Fla., was married last evening to Noah David Kaplan, a son of Carol Kaplan and Dr. Mark Kaplan of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Mitchell Chefitz officiated at the Great House, a catering business in North Miami, Fla.

title: After an Early Burnout, A Ballerina Ignites Again
description: TO become a principal dancer is the highest achievement for a ballerina in any dance company, but the honor is especially significant at New York City Ballet, a company long known for the prowess of its female dancers. Last season, just one dancer was anointed. On a warm day in May, Jenifer Ringer, the vibrant romantic ballerina, was summoned to the New York State Theater stage, where the ballet master Peter Martins proudly announced her promotion. As everyone on stage applauded, Ms. Ringer, dressed in her bathrobe after a rehearsal, let the news sink in. ''I was pretty shocked, but thrilled,'' she said.

description: The accolades keep pouring in for Cisco Systems, its chief executive, John Chambers, and his management team -- named best employer by Fortune, top technology executive by Forbes, and No. 6 in Upside magazine's Elite 100 digerati. title: A Bahamas Resort For Golf Lovers
description: The newest resort in the Caribbean includes the first new golf course in the Bahamas since 1969. The resort, Our Lucaya, opened on Grand Bahama Island on Dec. 1 with two championship golf courses: the new 6,920-yard Reef Course, designed by Robert Trent Jones Jr., with water on 13 of the 18 holes, and the Lucayan, designed by Dick Wilson and opened in 1962. Golfers can also work on their game at a Butch Harmon School of Golf, which includes video swing analysis.

title: Secrets

Max discussed an important issue for psychologists: the consequences of having to break the confidentiality of talk therapy in order to protect society. And Jane Smiley's picture of Charles Dickens in later life (''A Life of Fiction'') shows the mental and physical cost of our need for privacy.

title: NEW ROCHELLE: TOWARD AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: Westchester will spend almost $5 million to acquire 16 properties in downtown New Rochelle for affordable housing. Existing buildings will be demolished and replaced with 102 rental units that will provide assisted-living areas for the elderly and about 20 individually owned town houses. Fifty-four additional town houses will be built on the same site later. ''When you think of assisted living, you think it's only for the very well-off,'' County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. ''This project will make assisted-living apartments available to seniors with less resources.'' Elsa Brenner

Randolph Weber, a Presbyterian minister, officiated in the Rose Museum. Bella Linden, a Carnegie Hall trustee, also participated in the service, which incorporated Jewish traditions.

title: December 17 - 23; Retail Racial Profiling
description: The bitter joke goes that African-Americans are pulled over for Driving While Black. It seems that Shopping While Black can be a problem, too. The Massachusetts attorney general reached a settlement with The Children's Place, a national chain of clothing stores, over what he called retail racial profiling. Employees said they had been told that to prevent theft, they should follow black customers around and not give them large shopping bags. Testers sent into the stores confirmed the treatment, he said. Though it agreed to the settlement, requiring it to take 22 corrective steps, the company denied the allegations. Carey Goldberg

title: The Pain of Losing a Digit

In the mutual fund industry, the $100 billion level, crossed by two mutual funds last year, was crossed again in November. title: Tuileries Welcome Art As Well as Strollers
description: DESIGNED in the 1660's by the great landscape artist Andre Le Notre, the Tuileries Gardens in Paris are a monument to political power. By opting for rigid symmetry, Le Notre proclaimed that Louis XIV could subjugate even nature's seasonal exuberance. And more than three centuries later, when the gardens were restored, control remained the key word. Today, with their neo-Classical and Baroque statues, geometrically shaped lawns, neat flower beds, reflecting pools and trees lined up like parading soldiers, the Tuileries represent order and predictability in a noisy and bustling city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABADORF, ARLENE E. (NEE BARKAN)
description: LABADORF-Arlene E. (nee Barkan). Cherished and devoted wife for 46 years of Irwin, on Thursday, Dec. 21, 2000. Beloved mother of Alan and Robin, and Michael and Corey. Adoring and adored grandmother of Sammy, Dani, Stevie, Juliet and Mark. Age 73, taken from us far too young. Her radiant smile, winning personality, and boundless energy and enthusiasm enriched all of us who knew her. Services Sunday, December 24th at 12 noon, Temple Israel, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, New York.

title: Mixed Offerings

description: After 35 years as a model train collector, Jim Misewich now considers himself more of an operator.

title: From Afar, Christmas Remembered; A City That Takes Christmas in Stride
description: New York is of course hopelessly exciting at Christmastime, sparkling with promise and all dressed up in a finery that somehow manages to be pervasive but not oppressive. But the reason I love the city on Christmas Day is because it never forgets that it is bigger and better than any holiday, even one as serious as this.

title: S. Hacker, 83, Book Dealer In New York
description: Seymour Hacker, whose 57th Street bookstore, Hacker Art Books, was a well-known fixture of both the art and book worlds for more than 50 years, died on Tuesday in New York. He was 83.

title: December 17 - 23; That's Mr. Volcano to You
description: Popocatepetl, the great volcano outside Mexico City, erupted in what some scientists say was its biggest blast in a millennium. Despite a week of warnings, thousands of people under the volcano did not want to leave. It was an old clash: not only officialdom versus ordinary people, but scientists against shamans.

title: December 17 - 23; Presidential Pardons
description: The final days of a president's term are often a time of special generosity when it comes to pardons. President Clinton has handed out 59 pardons, the most notable to the former congressman Dan Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat who was convicted of abusing his office. Other recipients were an official of an Arkansas company who was a friend of the Clintons and a New Hampshire political operative who was a Clinton delegate to the 1992 convention. More pardons are expected before Jan. 20. Neil A. Lewis

title: Acting L.I.R.R. Chief Gets the Job Full-Time
description: Kenneth J. Bauer, the acting president of the Long Island Rail Road since May, was named president of the commuter line on Tuesday by the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, E. Virgil Conway.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; 'A New Type of Woman'
description: Wonder Woman, the first popular female comic-book character, was considered so representative of feminism that she appeared on the cover of the first issue of Ms. magazine, but she was really more of a twisted sister. According to Les Daniels's WONDER WOMAN: The Life and Times of the Amazon Princess (Chronicle, $29.95), she was created in 1941-42 by a Harvard-trained psychologist named William Moulton Marston as, in his words, ''psychological propaganda for the new type of woman who should, I believe, rule the world.'' The early comics were rife with intimations of lesbianism, bondage and discipline. The all-female Paradise Island bore more than a passing resemblance to Lesbos, and the superheroine's favorite epithet was ''Suffering Sappho!'' She managed to get herself tied up or bound by exotic methods in virtually every installment. In one choice panel, Wonder Woman hogties an Atlantean giantess while exclaiming, ''On Paradise Island where we play many binding games this is considered the safest method of tying a girl's arms!'' ''Women enjoy submission,'' insisted Marston, who lived in a menage trois. Ninety percent of Wonder Woman's fans may have been male (the Nancy Sinatra boots, spangly shorts and Versace bustier didn't hurt). The text by Daniels, who has also given the same super-treatment to Superman and Batman, is unfortunately not as colorful as its subject matter, but there are some wonderful arcana: a photograph of a very young Debra Winger as Wonder Girl standing next to the Junoesque Lynda Carter from the television series, and one of a Wonder-Woman-shaped scissors. We won't touch the Freudian implications of that one. Eric P. Nash

description: Victor Borge, the irrepressible musical humorist, pianist and conductor saluted all over the world as ''the comedian of the keyboard'' and ''the unmelancholy Dane,'' died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 91.

title: Visions of Big-Time Sports
description: IN 26 years as a lawyer, David J. Meiselman says he has won more than $100 million in medical malpractice and personal injury suits and corporate litigation. More quietly, he has also amassed a client roster that reads like the table of contents in People magazine.

description: A Christmas tree fire apparently ignited by a candle roared through an apartment in Washington Heights late Friday night, trapping a family of four between a wall of flames and padlocked window gates over a fire escape. Two small children were killed, and their parents were critically burned.

title: Sweet Sustenance for Winter
description: If Unionville Vineyards has its druthers, its first port, dated 1998, will be the port of choice in Hunterdon County winter storms. Eighty cases of the $25 port are being released, and if forecasts of a tough winter prove accurate, they may not last long. The warming wine offers a dusky-fruity bouquet, a lovely deep garnet color, a concentrated grapey-raisiny flavor with restrained sweetness, a smooth texture and a high-octane 18.5 percent alcohol level. The wine was made from chambourcin grapes, and was fortified with brandy made at Knapp Vineyards in the Finger Lakes region of New York State. Unionville has also released its second ice wine, the '99 Cool Foxy Lady, a sweet white dessert wine in the half-bottle, made wholly from vidal grapes, $17. The grapes, picked ripe, were refrigerated and with t water content nearly solid, were pressed gently, enabling the unfrozen acidity, carrying sugar and flavor, to drip out slowly before fermentation. Pale gold and voluptuous, the wine has an enticing tropical-floral bouquet, spicy and tropical flavors with embryonic layers of complexity, a slight piquancy and a long finish. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

description: Steve Wadsworth, 38, is president of the Walt Disney Internet Group, which manages sites like Go.com, Disney.com, ESPN.com and ABC.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDSAY, JOHN V.
description: LINDSAY-John V. Former Mayor of New York City, died Tuesday, December 19th in Hilton Head, SC. Mr. Lindsay was born in New York City on November 24, 1921 and was the son of the late George Nelson and Eleanor Vliet Lindsay. He attended Buckley and St. Paul's schools and was a graduate of Yale University and Yale Law School. During World War II he served on the USS Swanson as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy. He was a partner in the law firm of Webster & Sheffield and also served as executive assistant to the Attorney General from 1955 to 1957. A member of the United States Congress from 1958 to 1964, he represented New York City's 17th Congressional District. He served two terms as New York City's Mayor from 1965 to 1973. Prior to retirement in 1995, he was a counsel to the law firm Mudge, Rose, Guthrie. After his time in office, Mr. Lindsay served as Chairman of the Board of Lincoln Center Theater for ten years and then retired as Chairman Emeritus and board member emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Lindsay moved to Hilton Head Island, SC, in November of 1999. He is survived by his wife, Mary; a son, John V. Lindsay, Jr.; three daughters, Katharine Lake, Margaret Picotte, and Anne Lindsay; two sons-in-law, Stephen Lake and Michael Picotte; a brother, Robert V. Lindsay; and grandchildren Jessica and Stephanie Lake and Nicole, Joseph, and Michelle Picotte. Memorial services will be held January 26th at 4 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Memorial contributions may be sent to the John V. Lindsay Fund, Lincoln Center Theater, 150 West 65th Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: Sandra Lowenthal, Ronald Bernstein

With vacancies rare in the center of the village, enterprising newcomers have had to look to the fringes for space. And so, across from the Bronx River Parkway and opposite Lawrence Hospital sits Otto's, a welcome bright spot on the edge of a dark stretch.

title: Chinese Pigs Feed a Western Fashion Boom

Stores from Gucci to Wal-Mart are chock-a-block with skins -- and not just bomber jackets. The Limited's Express has pink and gold metallic leather halter tops, and Ralph Lauren has designed a leather five-pocket jean in red.

title: Hartford Feels Science Center Can Fix Its Economic Picture
description: For years, in the hearts and minds of everyone who had ever pondered the best way to breathe some life back into this depressed capital city, the solution was neatly packaged into two words: football stadium. But now, those words seem to have been replaced by others that state officials believe stand for an even better idea: science and technology.

Most major Christian faiths in Jerusalem have called for a negotiated solution adhering to United Nations resolutions that require Israeli withdrawal from territory occupied after the 1967 war.

description: Christophe Croquelois was one Parisian who liked to think he knew the world party circuit. He had danced at the full moon raves in Ko Phangan in Thailand and Goa in India. He had worked the clubs in Montmartre and in Miami.

title: The Dot-Com Bubble Bursts
description: A year ago Americans could hardly run an errand without picking up a stock tip. Day-trading manuals were selling briskly. Neighbors were speaking a foreign tongue, carrying on about B2B's and praising the likes of JDS Uniphase and Qualcomm. Venture capital firms were throwing money at any and all dot-coms to help them build market share, never mind whether they could ever be profitable. It was a brave new era, in which more than a dozen fledgling dot-coms that nobody had ever heard of could pay $2 million of other people's money for a Super Bowl commercial.

title: Fueling China's Growth
description: Oil has not figured prominently in the delicate relationship between the United States and China. But it soon will. China, the world's most populous nation with 1.3 billion people, will become one of the world's top oil importers in just a few years. This growing reliance on imported oil will further anchor China in the global economy and help shape its ties to the United States. Both nations should be thinking about how to manage this new reality and its strategic repercussions not only in East Asia, but also in places like the Middle East.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Julian Schnabel; Three Waves of Guests, Then the Police
description: SO this is how to throw a sitdown dinner party for your 350 closest friends. Be a rich, successful painter-director-Rabelaisian figure, who has spent 49 years collecting famous and talented people (actors like Glenn Close and Al Pacino; moguls like Barry Diller; writers like Oscar Hijuelos; musicians like Lou Reed and Michael Stipe; as well as former fashion models and assorted downtown figures). Add an occasion to celebrate: the new movie you've just made, ''Before Night Falls,'' which won the grand jury prize at the Venice International Film Festival. Hold the party in your spectacular painting studio cum home on West 11th Street. Have Dolce & Gabbana pay for the tropical plants, the Cuban food and mojitos. Bring in a Cuban band, with Paquito D'Rivera on sax. Add amps, your five children, your former wife and your wife, and wait for the police to show up.

title: The Nation; A New Look at Russia
description: VLADIMIR V. PUTIN, the Russian president, has found little to talk to the Clinton administration about of late. And so there he was this month, circling the United States with visits to Cuba and Canada and seeming to say: Please take notice, Russia is still a power.

Devoted mother of Claudia White, Frederic White, Adam White and Jason White. Cherished mother - in - law of Joseph Slomka & Judy Schneier. Dear sister of Alfred Yager. title: December 17 - 23; More Voting Fallout
description: What happened in Florida was every state official's nightmare. The undercounts, the butterfly ballots, the dimpled chads, the poorly trained vote counters and the rest subjected the state to ridicule. Some legal scholars believe the U.S. Supreme Court's decision ending Florida's manual recounts requires balloting procedures to be consistent statewide. So from coast to coast, legislatures, universities and research institutes are planning to review their states' election laws and technology. The states will eventually have to decide whether to spend untold millions on state-of-the-art voting machines and retraining poll workers. David E. Rosenbaum

title: On a Pier in Philadelphia, Luxury Apartments
description: Unlike the waterfronts in historic East Coast cities that developed their harbors as attractions for residents and tourists, Philadelphia's bleak eastern edge is experienced by most people as a blur as they rocket by on Interstate 95.

description: WHEN Sheri H. Kornreich moved from Huntington to Smithtown five years ago, she was stunned to find that the books her young children needed for school were not readily available at the Smithtown Library.

title: Pleasures of a Santa Fe Winter
description: YEARS ago, before I moved to Santa Fe, I remember asking a resident what winters were like there. She said they were wonderful and added with a smile, ''We like to keep that a secret.'' Alas, for locals who might want to keep a good thing to themselves, the secret has long been out, and for at least the last century and a half, trappers and traders, sightseers and skiers have known that Santa Fe winters are pretty special.

title: December 17 - 23; Go Ahead, Do the Math
description: It is one of Wall Street's most famous and beloved statistics. If you had invested $10,000 in Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Corporation in 1965, you would be worth about $60 million today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, SHERMAN, SHIRA
description: PALMER-SHERMAN-Shira. The Horace Mann community is in mourning at the tragic death of Shira Palmer-Sherman, HM'98. An enthusiastic and accomplished scholar, a gifted thespian, singer & dancer, she was a compassionate human being whose compass was set by her strong moral values, her religious faith and her commitment to community service and action. Shira was a remarkable individual whose imprint was everywhere & who touched many. Her death is a tragic loss to all of us. We deeply regret her passing and extend heartfelt condolences to her parents, Joanne Palmer and Dr. Andrew Sherman and to her sister Miriam, HM'02. Dr. Eileen Mullady Head of School Horace Mann Community

title: Yves of Destruction
description: The thing to remember about Yves Saint Laurent, the greatest living couturier, is that he doesn't know when to quit. He is a man of extremes, a champion binger. Give him his favorite brand of cigarettes, Peter Stuyvesant, and he will run through them like a child running through corn. ''He smokes 150 a day,'' says Pierre Berge, who, as the business brains behind Saint Laurent and the person closest to him for the past 42 years, has seen him through far more easily fatal forms of self-abuse. Once in Marrakech, when he was still getting high (mostly on cocaine, Saint Laurent says), his friend and court muse Loulou de la Falaise showed him how instead of smoking hashish he could get the same effect from pinching a little bit off and swallowing it. ''He said, 'You can do that?''' recalls her husband, Thadee Klossowski, a son of the painter Balthus. ''And she said, 'Sure.' Well, that day he had eaten the whole thing.''

title: Reading Rooms
description: The Library Hotel, on Madison Avenue at 41st Street in New York, lends new meaning to the term bedside reading. Each floor in the hotel, which opened in August, is dedicated to a different major category in the Dewey Decimal System (social sciences, literature, history, etc.) and each room contains 50 to 100 books on a topic related to the floor's theme: logic, the occult, economics, and erotic literature. Doubles are $295 to $325, with Continental breakfast. Call (877) 793-7323.

description: Michael J. Broadbent, an eminence grise of Britain's wine trade, is a wine-writing industry. Internationally, he is best known for ''Wine Tasting,'' a slender how-to guide published in 1968 and republished many times.

title: December 17 - 23; 'Organic' Gets a Definition
description: For decades, the Department of Agriculture insisted there was no difference between ''organic'' food and conventionally raised crops. Now, with domestic sales of organic foods reaching $6 billion a year, it has performed an about-face, publishing the first federal organic standards. They ban the use of irradiation, biotechnology, sewer-sludge fertilizer, and synthetic pesticides and fertilizers for any food labeled organic, as well as the use of antibiotics in meat labeled organic. Marian Burros

title: December 17 - 23; The Wallets Stayed Closed

The supposed hot products, like Victoria's Secret seamless satin lingerie in crimson, never caught on. Candy-colored leather pants piled up at the Gap. title: GAS RATE INCREASE
description: New Jersey Natural Gas Company, which serves 409,000 customers in Monmouth, Ocean, Middlesex and Morris Counties, is asking the Board of Public Utilities for permission to raise rates by about 2 percent a month over the next several months on top of a 16 percent increase that went into effect in November as well as additional 2 percent increases approved for December and January. The total 20 percent increase already approved will raise the average home heating bill by $28.30 a month for the winter, said Roseanne Koberle, spokeswoman for New Jersey Resources, the parent company of the gas utility. Karen DeMasters

The Christmas tree -- ablaze in the big picture window -- seems more cheerful, the string of blue lights along the path from the driveway to the doorway more serene, the long, chilly winter nights more hopeful.

title: Ideas & Trends; Have a Very Scary Christmas
description: IT is the time of year when many Americans spend hours making obsequious forays into others' good graces, abstaining from the easy comfort of crankiness and misanthropy, and generally making nice-nice with family and friends -- all as a rather contrived but typically effective means of avoiding Santa's ultimate trump: the lump of coal.

title: The Rat Pack Would Have Loved Them
description: Fashion may be having a full-blown love affair with horses, but it is also enjoying a dirty little fling with rats. Marc Jacobs has introduced short- and long-sleeve men's T-shirts with big rats printed on them (they cost $150 and $180 and come in eight color combinations) for spring 2001. Mr. Jacobs designed the collection, called Stinky Rat Productions, with his friend the photographer Juergen Teller. It was inspired by Mr. Teller's daughter, 3, when she called her father ''a stinky rat'' in front of Mr. Jacobs. Diesel StyleLab, an experimental division of Diesel, used rat logos in its spring-summer men's collection. They scamper across preppy clothes like an army green polo ($65), a khaki camp shirt ($115) and a pale pink bomber jacket ($325). ''Since we are a laboratory for style, the idea was to do a lab rat,'' said Leo Brankovich, a designer for the line. He pointed out that he was born in 1972, the Year of the Rat on the Chinese calendar. ''I've been amazed by people's reactions,'' he added. ''Italians have a bad opinion of rats, but the Japanese like them.''

title: Tenants Suspect a Plot In a Plan to Replace Windows
description: From the windows of his home in Graham Court Apartments, perhaps Harlem's most majestic apartment building, Laconia Smedley has seen 40 years of change.

description: ONE of Winfred Rembert's most striking works of art includes a self-portrait. Like all of his art, it is a massive piece of leather tooled and dyed with such skill that it looks, at a glance, like a painting. On the leather, a group of black men in zebra-striped prison uniforms works in a field, one with his head down.

title: December 17 - 23; Radio Diversity Curtailed
description: The nation's biggest broadcasters succeeded in curtailing a federal program to issue 1,000 or more licenses for low-power FM radio stations to schools, churches and community groups. The Federal Communications Commission had conceived the program as an antidote to the consolidation of the radio industry. But the commercial broadcasters, joined by National Public Radio, prevailed on Congress to cut the program after raising concerns that the start-ups would produce significant signal interference. Stephen Labaton

title: Mount Vernon Jewelry Maker Reduces Its Work Force
description: Michael Anthony Jewelers, a Mount Vernon manufacturer and marketer of gold jewelry, has cut 100 employees from its work force. The company, which had more than 650 employees before the cuts, said the reduction represented more than just a seasonal slowdown, which is normal at this time of year when Christmas orders have been filled. The company is predicting that sales will be affected by a diminishing consumer confidence, rising gasoline prices, a fluctuating stock market and consumer worries about heating bills. ''We're adjusting in advance,'' said Allan Corn, the chief financial officer. Elsa Brenner

title: From the Fonz To 'The Sopranos,' Not Much Evolution
description: MIDWAY through the third episode of the new CBS series ''That's Life,'' the story of an Italian-American bartender who shocks (shocks!) her family by breaking off her engagement and enrolling at a local New Jersey college, a friend poses a key question. The college-bound Lydia DeLucca (Heather Paige Kent) regularly gossips with her pals Jackie and Candy at the beauty shop run by Jackie. Amid light banter and serious hair spray, Lydia teases Candy about a yoga class she is taking. Candy, who sells cars for a living, responds, ''Are you the only one who's allowed to evolve?''

title: BackTalk; A Holiday Season for Youth to Be Served
description: One of the wise men, Mansour Ndiaye, journeyed back to the cradle of his celebrity last week with sage counsel for the children. ''You're just going to have to learn life the hard way,'' he said kindly. ''I know you're not going to listen to me.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about matchmaking beween Russian women and American men gave a misspelled name at some points for the Russian city where much of the activity takes place. It is St. Petersburg, not St. Petersberg.

title: Style; Hark!
description: Romaine Patterson says her very best friend, Matthew Shepard, was ''buff in the brain.'' He would listen to ''It's Raining Men'' in his burgundy Honda Accord. He was a big fan of John Denver. He always had a cream-cheese brownie with his cafe latte. He collected colored glass bottles, and they were all over his house and on every windowsill. He had a new cat and moved back to Laramie, Wyo., to be closer to his little brother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGTON, WILLIAM G.
description: WIGTON-William G. Of Plainfield, NJ, former Senior Partner with Orvis Bros. & Co., on December 23, 2000. Husband of Ann Hayes Wigton. Father of William B. Wigton. Memorial services will be at Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, 716 Watchung Ave., Plainfield, Thursday, December 28 at 11 AM. Memorial donations may be made to the Muhlenberg Foundation, Park Ave. and Randolph Rd., Plainfield, NJ 07061. For further information call Memorial Funeral Home 908-322-4350.

title: Robert Buck, 42, Rock Guitarist
description: Robert Buck, the lead guitarist for the popular alternative-rock band 10,000 Maniacs, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 42.

title: Ideas & Trends; Charity Begins at the Rule Book
description: CHARITY is kind, the Bible says. And in this season of coat drives and food baskets, who would disagree? Not President-elect George W. Bush, who has vowed to ''rally the armies of compassion,'' and met with black ministers last week to promote faith-based charity as the kinder, more cost-effective alternative to government-run help for needy people.

description: MADSEN-Mary. On December 21, 2000. Survived by four children Joseph Madsen, Rose Marie Walsh, Frank Madsen and Theodore Madsen; grandchildren Kenneth Walsh, Kim; five great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Clavin Funeral Home, Brooklyn, New York.

description: To the Editor:

description: MY list of automotive overachievers is short this year: The Chrysler PT Cruiser was the standout of 2000.

title: Crime
description: There's a sickly odor -- of something rich with life that has started to decay -- about Nicolas Freeling's disturbing psychological study of a mild-mannered killer, SOME DAY TOMORROW (St. Martin's Minotaur, $22.95). Like the smell of garden mulch, it is not unclean, or even unpleasant; but it carries overpowering hints of death.

title: Ideas & Trends; Giving Up the Reins
description: GOOD evening. Just moments ago, I spoke with my supporters and informed them that I have given up. It has become clear to Santa that few of you believe in me anymore.

title: December 17 - 23; Pinochet Tightrope
description: The Chilean Supreme Court managed a neat balancing act in the charged issue of whether to prosecute Gen. Augusto Pinochet on kidnapping and murder charges. It threw out an order to put the former dictator under house arrest, ruling that an investigating judge had failed to guarantee his legal rights. But the court also ordered the judge to interrogate General Pinochet, meaning that he could be formally charged soon after the new year. Clifford Krauss

title: Peconic Baykeeper Plans Legal Action
description: Kevin McAllister, the Peconic Baykeeper, said last week that he was planning legal action against the state and the Town of Riverhead in connection with more than 2,000 discharge violations at the town's sewer treatment plant.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: Your Dec. 17 article, ''After Merger's Bumpy Start, North Shore-L.I.J. Is Clicking,'' misstates the situation concerning the departments of surgery at the two medical centers.

title: Bold, Full-Flavored Italian Cooking
description: EXPECT bold, full-flavored Italian grandma-cooking at the new Ciao Baby Restaurant in Commack. Enthusiastic young servers tote almost family-size portions of rigatoni under old-fashioned pork sauce, chicken scarpariello, meat platters and penne alla vodka at this storefront spot in the Mayfair Shopping Center at 204 East Jericho Turnpike (631-543-1400).

title: Living Without the Treasury Market
description: THE pace of the long goodbye to the trusted Treasury market will pick up under the new Bush administration. So next year, investors will really have to learn to live with the rapid shrinkage of this venerable $3.4 trillion market.

title: Dances With Buffaloes
description: ON Christmas Eve at Nambe, a small (population 650) American Indian village and sovereign Indian nation 20 miles north of Santa Fe, the buffalo come out to dance by the light of a great bonfire. They come after evening Mass at the ancient St. Francis of Assisi church, and dance for just a little while before returning to the kiva, the underground ceremonial chamber, center of the pueblo's traditional religious life. With the buffalo come the deer, their horns circled with sprigs of fir, like candles in Advent wreaths, the antelope and a couple of Pueblo Indians dressed up as their old enemies, the Comanches, for comic relief.

title: From Afar, Christmas Remembered; Elegant, Materialistic And Proud of It
description: It's the miracle of unabashed commercialism that I miss most about New York at the holiday season. There is an accreted beauty, built from layer upon layer of tinsel and gold. It transforms a grimy, wintry New York into its true self: elegance built on money and pleasure built on spending, with the emphasis on showiness and display.

title: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON: DISTRICT WINS CUSTODY OF PAINTING
description: The Hastings school district won custody of a $1 million landscape painting by a native son, Jason Cropsey, that had been the center of a legal dispute among the school district, the Hastings Historical Society and the village of Hastings. The 115-year-old painting, ''A View at Hastings-on-Hudson,'' depicts a pastoral 19th-century landscape. The painting, on loan to the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers since 1971, will be returned under a ruling by Justice John P. DiBlasi of State Supreme Court in White Plains. ''We felt that the ownership of the painting was clear all along,'' said the Hastings schools superintendent, Dr. John J. Russell. The painting was bought by a former village resident, Sherman Thursby, who gave it to the school district in 1947. The school district had lent it to the Hudson River Museum, and it wasn't until the school district tried to sell the painting last year that a lawsuit challenging its ownership was filed. Merri Rosenberg

description: The Giants are still a little confused over Fred Taylor's words.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-24-00: On Language; Carpe Diem
description: Justifying his plans for transition planning during the vote-counting turmoil, Gov. George W. Bush said that it was important ''to show the American people that this administration will be ready to seize the moment.'' Two weeks later, in his first speech as president-elect, he told the nation, ''We must seize the moment and deliver.''

title: Design and the Guitar At Boston Museum
description: The guitar may be ubiquitous in contemporary music, but for the next two months, visitors to Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, can see guitars they have never seen before. ''Dangerous Curves: Art of the Guitar,'' an exhibit running through Feb. 25, studies the history of guitar design -- the instrument as a work of art -- with a display of 129 guitars of almost every type except the air guitar.

title: PATH FARE HEARINGS
description: As the next step in considering increasing tolls for the bridges, tunnels and PATH trains connecting New Jersey and New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will hold public hearings in each state the week of Jan. 16. The increases would include discounts for off-peak use of the George Washington, Goethels and Bayonne Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels. Regular fares would increase from $4 to $7, with a discount for using E-Z Pass. Prices for PATH trains would increase from $2 for a round trip to $3. The increases would be the first for the toll crossings since 1991 and first for the PATH trains since 1987. Karen DeMasters

description: Poor little Hillary.

title: For Migrants, a Christmas of Hardship and Hope
description: In a clean but heavily used kitchen where the window was labeled ''window'' and the lamp was labeled ''lamp,'' five men from the state of Hidalgo, Mexico, planned their Christmas party. One, a former police officer, was wondering how it would feel to spend the holidays away from his children, ages 1 and 4, while others argued the merits of tostadas de tinga (fried tortillas with beans, lettuce and chicken) versus tostadas morelianas, avocado and beans for their holiday meal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOHE, THOMAS G.
description: YOHE-Thomas G. Resident of Norwalk, CT, died on December 20, 2000. Mr. Yohe was born April 26, 1937 to Robert C. and Berdene Walker Yohe in Flushing, NY. Mr. Yohe graduated from Baldwin High School in 1955 and attended Syracuse University where he majored in fine arts. An advertising executive and animation designer, Mr. Yohe won five EMMYs as a creator, designer and executive producer of ''Schoolhouse Rock'', a series of educational programs broadcast by the ABC Television Network for 25 years. Mr. Yohe's animated characters for films like ''I'm Just a Bill'' and ''Conjunction Junction'' became icons for the young viewers of the '70's now known as Generation X. The ''tiny scrap of paper'' depicted in ''I'm Just a Bill'' and the switchman from ''Conjunction Junction'' became more memorable images to children than most that they encountered in the traditional environment of the classroom. As Generation X has moved on to adulthood, its fascination with the concept and characters of ''Schoolhouse Rock'' has led to numerous books, articles and educational seminars. Mr. Yohe began a career in advertising as an art director at Young & Rubicam. In 1964 he moved to McCaffrey & McCall where he rose to co-creative director. In 1986 Mr. Yohe moved to Grey Advertising where he served in a senior creative position until taken ill in November 2000. Mr. Yohe was married to the former Cynthia Doen in 1960. They had four children: Thomas, James, Lauren and Suzanne. In 1980 Mr. Yohe married his second wife, Diane Sanden Seely. Ms. Seely had two children, Colin and Darren. The couple has resided in Norwalk, CT since their marriage. Mr. Yohe will be remembered as a warm, sensitive, irrepressibly creative man whose cartoon characters were loved by millions and who was a devoted father to an adoring family and beloved by a wide circle of friends. Mr. Yohe is survived by his wife Diane, brother Robert L. Yohe of Bonita Springs, FL, sons Thomas of Brooklyn, NY and James of Munster, Germany, daughter Lauren of Tarrytown, NY, daughter Suzanne Tessitore of Manhattan, step-son Colin Seely of Darien, CT, step-son Darren Seely of Grafton, MA and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 28 at 11 AM at St. Bartholemew's Church on Park Ave. and 51 St. in NYC. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers donations be made in the name of Thomas G. Yohe to the American Cancer Society or Syracuse University, 820 Comstock Ave., Syracuse, NY 13244, to the attention of Angela La France.

description: The riders have spoken. When it comes to litter and swirling grime, the Roosevelt Avenue and 74th Street station is the tops of the major subway stops in the city.

title: AT&T to Job Seekers: Take My Cards, Please
description: When it comes to handing out pink slips, few big American companies can measure up to AT&T, which has engaged in various forms of mass downsizings that have eliminated 25,600 jobs over the last four years. But in what has become a sort of ritualistic annual gesture to the unemployed, AT&T is again giving out free calling cards so job hunters can line up interviews.

title: For Giants, All Roads in N.F.C. Lead to Home
description: Jason Sehorn grabbed the onside kick and began striding toward the end zone, a football and the dreamy promise of a memorable Giants postseason under his arm. Each stride, ever wider, became like the steps in a Giants season that has been a cavalcade of ever broadening accomplishments.

title: This de Sade Favors Pen Over Pain
description: WHEN Geoffrey Rush, playing the Marquis de Sade in ''Quills,'' rips off his wig and costume in a moment of exasperation, he displays a presentable, even dashing, figure. Alas, reality fell short in every way, as the notorious pornographer's latest biographer, Neil Schaeffer, tells us in ''The Marquis de Sade, A Life'' (Knopf). Yet the movie gives us a man who rises head and shoulders above his tormentors.

title: Accorsi Has a Knack For Fixing Problems
description: General Manager Ernie Accorsi of the Giants is always thinking two steps ahead, and he hears everything. Accorsi was informed recently of a rumor that had running back Tiki Barber -- arguably one of the team's most valuable players this season -- irritated that the Giants had not begun talks about extending his contract.

title: Angola's Goal: Stepping Back From the Abyss
description: The morning wind whistles through the bullet holes in the tiny house on Teofilo-Braga Street. The electricity is out again. And Agostinho Capitango shuffles through the dark, his wooden leg dragging, as he considers his rusting faucets. ''We used to take showers when there was water,'' he said. ''That was in 1992.''

title: Ebola's Shadow
description: Grief in Africa is often allayed by a belief in the good that the newly dead can do for the living. In traditions that endure among Christians and Muslims alike, the recently deceased, if properly buried, are believed to be able to watch out for their kinfolk and guard them from catastrophe.

title: Papers, Please; Europe's Love-Hate Affair With Foreigners
description: SEVERAL European nation-states including Germany, Austria and Italy -- emerged about a century ago from the vast multinational, polyglot empires that dominated 19th-century Europe. Their roots are not deep, their reality one of mingled blood. Yet, as the advance of the European Union encroaches on national sovereignty and the wealth of Europe draws the world's dispossessed migrants, a nationalist reaction has set in, marked by jingoistic hymns to national cultures, anti-immigrant tirades and the scapegoating of foreigners for everything from rising crime to rotten schools. It is no longer Communism that haunts Europe: it is the outsider.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Do Not Go Gentle My Search for Miracles in a Cynical Time. By Ann Hood. Picador USA, $23.

title: Striking Strengths, Glaring Failures
description: For eight years, Bill Clinton has been the bright sun and the bleak moon of American politics, embodying much of the best and the worst of his times. Even as he prepares to leave office after two tumultuous terms, he remains near the center of the collective consciousness.

title: Corrections
description: An entry last Sunday in the critics' choices for top 10 pop and jazz albums of the year misspelled the surname of an Elizabethan composer in the collection cited as No. 5 by Neil Strauss. The composer, whose songs have been recorded on the ECM New Series label, was John Dowland, not Downland.

title: A CHANCE TO STAR
description: Dwayne Gordon, 31, a White Plains native and a role player for eight National Football League seasons, has a shot at a starring role today as the Jets try to make the playoffs by winning in Baltimore. He will be starting at strongside linebacker in place of Bryan Cox, who broke his leg last Sunday. ''I'm back to where I need to be,'' said Gordon, who slipped into disuse early in the season. ''A lot of people pinned this season to coming down to the last game several weeks ago. Here we are.'' Chuck Slater

title: Day Care by the Sea to Close, Forcing Parents to Scramble
description: Perhaps because of the place's calliope past, buildings in Coney Island come brushed with their own kind of fantasy. The Sand Castle Child Care Center, wedged into the Surfside Gardens housing project, is no different. Its sign depicts a caring adult with a little aquamarine heart. In its bright interior, children eat snacks in rooms marked Shrimp and Porpoise. The sea gleams in the background.

title: Cold Season, Warm Colors In the Garden
description: AT this darkest time of the garden year, I often wish I had lavender-purple clusters of beautyberries (Callicarpa species) and the bright red fruits of winterberries (Ilex species) on my property.

title: Tinge of Optimism Is Felt in Troubled Kashmir
description: India and Pakistan are not yet talking. They are merely talking about talking. And even if they talk, it is unclear if either has anything new to say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, JEROME
description: KLEIN-Jerome. Age 69 of Waterside Plaza in Manhattan passed away on December 16. Survived by his loving & devoted wife Magda Klein, children Robin, (Gary) Scott (Arlene), Nicole and stepdaughter Joanna, sister Gertrude Benanti, brother Marty Klein, and granddaughters Danielle, Jenna, Julia and Margaux. You will always be in our hearts forever. Contributions in his memory to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital.

title: Dig Gives New View of Colonial Housing
description: AN archaeological dig in Andover has found remains of a medieval-style long house, the first one ever discovered in Connecticut. Until now, no long houses like this one, 15 feet wide and 60 feet long, had been found in New England dating from much past 1650; the Andover house was built in 1705. Historians say this long house challenges assumptions about traditional New England housing.

title: There Will Always Be a 'Trovatore'
description: IN the heart of Africa or the Indies, you will always hear 'Il Trovatore.' '' So said Verdi in a letter in 1862, nine years after the triumphant premiere of this swift-paced, melodically intoxicating Gothic chiller. ''Il Trovatore'' remained until roughly two generations ago the most beloved of his creations. Then it started losing ground. Only last week, Joseph Volpe, the general director of the Metropolitan Opera, volunteered: '' 'Il Trovatore' isn't bread-and-butter like 'Boheme' or 'Butterfly.' '' Times change. Who among his predecessors would have agreed?

title: ENVIRONMENT; Praise the Lord, Pass the Solar Panels
description: Citing pollution statistics as often as Scripture, the Rev. Fletcher Harper spent the better part of his sermon making a pitch for a power company.

title: In San Antonio, a Stetsonful of Surprises
description: INTERSTATE 10 shoots straight from Houston to San Antonio -- a no-sweat 200-mile drive, I figured. I'd been tooling around Houston's city streets for a few days last month, and I'd bonded with my rented cherry-red Grand Am. But, steering into the river of 16-wheel big rigs and S.U.V.'s cruising at 85, I felt as weak-kneed as a flyweight in a ring full of Mike Tysons. So I stuck to the right-hand lane, took deep breaths and didn't rush it.

title: Introduction
description: The mail on our Secrets issue was not all about Chelsea -- but it was close. Some readers speculated on what she'd tell us if she talked. And several suggested that it's the mother, not the daughter, who stayed ''under wraps,'' getting a pass from the press in her Senate race.

title: Who Will Be the Hostess With the Mostest in Bush II?
description: SOCIALLY, a few things in the nation's capital never change, despite the arrival of a new administration. The old guard, or what remains of it, still give and attend intimate dinners in Georgetown and Cleveland Park, where everybody knows that Kay is Katharine Graham, the chairman of the executive committee of The Washington Post; Ann and Vernon are Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Jordan; Andrea and Alan are Andrea Mitchell, the NBC correspondent, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve; and Buffy is Buffy Cafritz, the apricot-haired hostess. And never mind that she is a Republican; she is friends with Hillary and Bill, too.

title: Time and Rust Threaten Island Landmark
description: THE 220-foot spire of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation, Long Island's highest steeple, is clearly visible for miles. What is not so clearly visible is the damage that storms and years of benign neglect have caused. In fact, the top of the spire, the last 20 feet capped by an illuminated copper cross, is ''in pressing danger of falling,'' a survey of the cathedral's stonework has concluded.

title: Reckonings; Bush Looks Backward
description: Optimists expected George W. Bush to take three objectives into account in choosing his secretary of the treasury.

title: In East Hills, Park Is a Peace Dividend
description: EVERY day, many of the 8,000 residents of East Hills pass by the Roslyn Air National Guard base located in the heart of their community. But few had ever been behind the chain-link fence that for six decades separated the public from the operations of an active military base.

title: Guaranteed Prices Draw More Heating-Oil Customers
description: For 15 years, Almeida Oil, based in Scarsdale, has offered customers the chance to lock in prices for heating oil for the season in exchange for a set fee. But with heating costs rising sharply, the program has never been more popular.

title: The New A B C D's of Alphabet City
description: NOT too long ago, the name Alphabet City evoked images of burned-out buildings, rubbish-strewn lots, squatters and drug dealers. These days, the marketers of the high-priced condomiminiums and luxury rentals that are sprouting everywhere in the neighborhood are more likely to refer to it as the East Village, of which it is only a part, or to sweep it into the even-broader domain of the Lower East Side.

Once seated, they are surrounded by tuxedoed waiters bringing good crusty peasant bread, a dish of assorted olives and flavor-packed olive oil bolstered by red-pepper flakes, garlic and rosemary.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel Guarantees the Magic: 'We've Got It'

title: Hitting Full Stride in China; Nanchang looks like a nondescript industrial city, until you put on a pair of running shoes
description: THE pig was slit open, end-to-end, carcass slung across the back of a bicycle. Its snout and hooves dragged behind a slight man in a Mao jacket who pedaled through the gray morning. A second glance revealed just two hooves dragging. Was it just half a pig? Sure enough, from the next block appeared another cyclist, ferrying another half pig, undoubtedly the first one's complement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTERT, WARREN HERBERT
description: ROTERT-Warren Herbert. Died after a long illness on December 19, 2000. Son of the late Herbert and Fannie (Wilson) Rotert, he grew up in Little Falls, NJ, and was a graduate from Passaic Valley High School (1947). He received his undergraduate degree in Civil Engineering from Lafayette College, Easton, PA (1952), his Juris Doctor from George Washington University Law School (1959), and served the United States Armed Forces from 1953-1955. Mr. Rotert was admitted to practice before the Virginia and New York Bars, the United States Supreme Court, the Federal Appellate and District Courts and was a skilled intellectual property trial lawyer. In addition to admission to the Order of the Coif and Phi Delta Phi, Warren was Patent Editor of the Law Review and a Patent Examiner before joining the New York City law firm of Morgan Finnegan in 1960. He was partner, senior partner, and served for 36 years before retiring in 1996. He was a member of the Ramsey Golf and Country Club, Ramsey, NJ, the Tuxedo Club in Tuxedo Park, New York, and Ford's Colony Country Club in Williamsburg, VA. Mr. Rotert leaves behind a family forever inspired by his show of strength, dignity and unending devotion: his loving wife Jean and their son Edward; daughter Lise Thayer and her husband Brian Thayer of Higganum, CT; son Kevin of Linwood, MA; son Todd and his wife Lauren of Ramsey; and brother David of Columbia, PA. His four grandchildren Alison, Jennifer, Ryan and Mary Beth will miss him. Warren was predeceased by his first wife, Mary Jane (Walton) Rotert in 1974. The family will receive friends on Wednesday and Thursday (2-4 PM and 7-9 PM). Funeral services will be Friday, December 29, at 10 AM. For information, contact The Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey, NJ. In lieu of flowers, friends can make donations to The Warren H. Rotert Scholarship Fund to benefit local youth athletes, P.O. Box 81, Ramsey, NJ 07446.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACKERMAN, BARBARA LINTNER
description: ACKERMAN-Barbara Lintner. 95, Hightstown, NJ, Thursday at home. Born in Troy, NY, she resided in South Orange, NJ, before moving to Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, 22 years ago. Graduate of Montclair State Teacher's College, she taught in the Summit public school system. Married Dr. Arthur Ackerman, a Summit pediatrician, in 1939. In 1950, she founded the Union County Association for Mental Health, an organization dedicated to spreading the world about better care for mental health patients. From 1962-1964 served at the state level as the New Jersey Mental Health Association's President, for several years as Chairman of the NJMH Golden Bell Ball. Wife of late Dr. Arthur Ackerman; survived by two sons, Peter Bogert Ackerman of Monterey, CA, & Arthur deWitt Ackerman of Tryon, NC; daughter, Martha A. Achilles of Edgecomb, ME; four grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren. Funeral service will be private.

title: Lives; My Great-Great-Grandmother, the Roundheel
description: The way my mother's family always told it, we descend from a long line of tough pioneer gals who could herd cattle the same day they gave birth. They reared their children on homemade jams and pickles canned over fires of cow pies picked up along the Oregon Trail. Photographs only add to the mystique: in one, sturdy forebears stand outside a log-and-mud lean-to that they crafted with their bare hands. In another, my great-grandfather, clutching an enormous saw, rests a foot on an old-growth tree he chopped down himself. By the next generation, the pictures reveal adventure of another sort, one that seemed out of step with our rugged personas. One shows my grandmother smiling fetchingly outside a dusty rodeo. Skirt inched above her knees, lips a dark red, Nana is embraced by one dashing man as she leans against another. ''Cousins,'' she always says, but the picture leaves another impression.

title: A Hall Where the Sound Is as Good as the Musicians
description: WHEN Londoners talk up their city as the music capital of the world, their pride is justified, because no other town -- not even Berlin or New York -- could claim performances of such persistent quality and quantity. But festering at the heart of this embarrassment of riches is an embarrassment that no one boasts about: London's first-rate music making takes place in distinctly second-rate symphonic halls. The Royal Albert Hall, a barn with a vast dome, swallows the sound from the stage before it reaches the audience. The Royal Festival Hall is dry and unsympathetic to anything that requires atmosphere. And the Barbican Center is acoustically adequate but nothing more. Joyless and drab, it occupies an unlovely part of the financial district, where, after 8 p.m., the streets feel as empty as a plague zone. No place to cherish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, JAMES, JR.
description: O'MALLEY-James, Jr., died on December 20, 2000 after a short illness. Born on August 13, 1910 in New York City. Distinguished by his many achievements in the legal profession and public service, and admired for his integrity, high principles and grace. A graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law School, he was assistant deputy district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey. A Lt. Comdr. in the Navy during WWII, he became the Officer-in-Charge of the Division of the U.S. Army-Navy War Crimes Office with special executive assignments under Maj. Gen. William Donovan in O.S.S. In 1947, he became a member of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, where he practiced utilities and administrative law as well as leading the firm's representation of LLoyd's of London in the U.S. In addition, he was appointed by Governor Rockefeller to serve a three-year term as Waterfront Commissioner of NY Harbor in 1959; and he was named to the Board of Advisors of the Naval War College in 1982. Devoted husband of the late Marcella Butler for 56 years, he is survived by his son, Malcolm Butler O'Malley, and his daughter, Anne Bigelow O'Malley. Contributions may be made in his name to Interfaith Neighbors, 210 E. 86th St., N.Y., NY 10028. A memorial service will be held on Monday, January 22nd at 10:30AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave., N.Y., NY at 66th Street and Lexington Avenue.
