Tim Burton, who is remaking the 1968 science-fiction classic about a future in which evolved apes rule the world and humans struggle for survival, hired two such experts to make sure Helena Bonham Carter, Tim Roth and others authentically mimic the behavior of chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans. Here Terry Notary, the film's movement coach, and John Alexander, a consultant who worked with Notary before filming began, offer some insight into channeling the beast within.

title: Help for the Neediest
description: Christmas Eve comes as a reminder of things done and things undone. Most of what the season requires from us materially has already been fulfilled -- the tree decorated, packages wrapped, cards sent out to friends, family and the people we hear from only once a year. But there is always the question of what the season requires of us ethically. Christmas in America is a feast of profusion, and on its eve, the abundance we share should lead us to contemplate its opposite, a degree of need that is not merely a lack of wealth but a lack of the very necessities that make life tolerable. Need takes every shape imaginable, not only now but all year long. Need grows even as wealth grows, and the distance between them steadily increases.

title: Bookend; Back to the Future

Bellamy does include a love story -- people in the year 2000 do experience the old passions, it seems -- yet the romance is clearly an afterthought, meant to sweeten the social theory.

title: December 17 - 23; U.N. Lowers U.S. Dues

A deal that would reduce American payments from 25 to 22 percent of the U.N. budget, and the share of peacekeeping bills from 30 to about 27 percent, is still short of what Congress demanded, but it may be enough for Democrats on Capitol Hill to persuade their colleagues. The move would clear the deck for a new Republican administration to build a new relationship with the United Nations. Barbara Crossette

title: Newark's Vanishing Skyline
description: AN air horn shrieked out a warning as the countdown hit the one-minute mark before the explosives were timed to go off on a recent early Saturday morning. Charges had been carefully set at strategic structural points in the buildings. The count was picked up again at 10 seconds and could now be heard from the radios of police and demolition workers standing about 500 feet away. When the count ran out, there was momentary pause followed by a flurry of loud cracks. A second later, a plume of smoke and dust bloomed. Another series of cracks rang out along with deeper booms as a second series of explosives detonated. There was a slight pause, and then the whole building seemed to tremble like jelly, before melting down into a cloud of dust.

title: A Hot Kosher Cookbook
description: It's not unusual to find a school's fund-raising cookbook for sale. But it is far from typical to find one for sale at Amazon.com or Barnes & Noble. The Joseph Kushner Hebrew Academy-Yeshiva High School, a modern Orthodox school in Livingston, put out the ''The Kosher Palette'' last March. Now in its third printing, it has sold 15,000 copies. Sandra Blank and Susie Fishbein solicited recipes from other school parents, and sold the resulting book in local stores and through the school. But, Ms. Fishbein said, word spread and within weeks Amazon.com called her, saying it had received many inquiries about the book. She said the book filled a need for a kosher cookbook for everyday use. The book, $26.95, can be still be purchased directly from the school at (973) 597-1115, extension 197, but sales from any source all bring money into the school. One reader-reviewer on Amazon said, ''This is a book to drool over.''

title: The Buckskin Ceiling And Its Discontents
description: THE buckskin ceiling is what some American Indian artists call the invisible barrier that keeps them from rising to the top of their field. Not everyone agrees on its definition, or its origins. Some people even deny that such a barrier exists. But those Indian artists who claim to have bumped their heads against it blame the buckskin ceiling for keeping them out of major museum and gallery shows, and out of positions of power in the art establishment. For them, the buckskin ceiling is an art-world bias that makes space for traditional beadwork, buckskins and trading-post blankets, and ignores almost everything else.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; The Secrets of Taipei
description: ''Ghosts and humans, as everyone is well aware, should not intermingle,'' a wandering spirit tells the narrator in Alvin Lu's first novel, THE HELL SCREENS (Four Walls Eight Windows, $22). But intermingle they do in this entrancing Taiwanese ''Turn of the Screw.'' In Taipei, ghosts, restless spirits, witches and doppelg<diamond=ngers can turn up anywhere and at any time -- they are as wily as foxes, as evanescent as the steam from a cup of tea. The narrator is a Chinese-American, an amateur collector of strange stories, whose command of Chinese is as untrustworthy as his troublesome pair of contact lenses, which afford him ''only passing moments of lucidity.'' The plot, such as it is, concerns his investigations into the identity of the ''Taxi Driver Killer,'' who has been terrorizing young women in Taipei. Lu depicts the city as a disorienting, labyrinthine world where nothing is quite what it seems. Here the boundary between dreams and reality is blurred, landmarks become evasive and a person's identity, even his very size and shape, is mutable. It is a place where ''secrets were whispered through the clenched, oceanic hiss of mah-jongg tiles.'' Lu's prose, at once eerie and meticulous, nicely captures the cool, abstracted voice of his narrator, who becomes increasingly seduced and manipulated by his own imagination. This devilish puzzle of a novel may frustrate the casual reader, but it will appeal to anyone who loves the cat-and-mouse games of Nabokov, the playful elegance of Borges or the rarefied dreamscapes of Calvino. Philip Gambone

title: Essay; Dorothy Dunnett's Excellent Adventures
description: IT is a truism that great novels have seldom been instant successes. Runaway best-selling acclaim tends to settle on the lowlier branches of the literary enterprise, like fantasy, mystery or romance, whose virtue (and defect) is their accessibility. But ''popular'' literature itself, paradoxically, can take years to achieve popularity; consider J. R. R. Tolkien and Patrick O'Brian, who lingered in obscurity for decades before exploding into spectacular cult success.

description: Two reports that reached the United Nations paint a fascinating picture of a shadowy world of diamond and arms traders whose ability to move chameleon-like from country to country -- changing their names, the registration of their aircraft and their bases of operation with speed and stealth -- is undercutting efforts to end the smuggling that fuels vicious wars. Both reports, one on diamonds from Sierra Leone that are sold through President Charles Taylor's Liberia and the other on gem trafficking by the Unita rebel movement in Angola, expose a business built on prolonging the agony of some of the poorest people on earth. Two other moons of Jupiter show similar signs of oceans under ice layers. Mars offers more direct, but still inconclusive signs of water, which scientists regard as one of the essential ingredients for the development of life. Some recent photos show gullies that may have been cut by flowing water within the last few million years. Earth remains the only place in the solar system with liquid water in plain view. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: I HATE it when Santa Claus gets upset. ''Seems we're all so busy,'' he says, in the person of Edmund Gwenn, ''trying to beat the other fellow and making things go faster and look shinier and cost less that Christmas and I are sort of getting lost in the shuffle.'' And that was more than half a century ago, in the original MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET (1947). The film made the big-brown-eyed 9-year-old Natalie Wood a star, playing a young New Yorker who doesn't believe in fairy tales like Santa, toy-making elves and flying reindeer. Maureen O'Hara plays her sensible mother, the Macy's parade executive. John Payne is the handsome Central Park West neighbor who may be able to grant some Christmas wishes of his own. title: December 17 - 23; Anyone Fleeing the Kitchen?
description: Globally, the 10 warmest years in the past century have all been since 1982. But a list of the warmest 10 years in the United States looks quite different: 1998, 1934, 1999, 1921, 1931, 1990, 1953, 1954, 1939, 1987. But that is the way of weather. Not every region follows the global trend. Not every drought is a sign of global warming and not every cold front a refutation. This year was on pace to become the warmest on record for the United States -- until November, which turned out to be the second coldest on record. So 2000 is now expected to fall somewhere between 7th and 12th. Kenneth Chang

title: Weak Links in Latin Democracy

A decade ago, when the number of democratically elected governments had risen from two to 10 in South America and one to six in Central America in only a few years, the future seemed bright. But now political turmoil is an increasing threat.

title: An Option To Buy A Condo

I think the landlord realizes that he can get a better price in today's market. Is there any way to force the landlord to sell me the apartment at the agreed-upon option price? . . . title: Dead Men Talking

Yet, I don't think I'm nave on this subject: I used to edit articles for forensic-science journals. Although Osborne portrayed the University of Tennessee researchers as respectful, committed professionals, which they may well be, these people are nevertheless engaging in something as universally taboo as incest: abusing the dead by not burying them.

title: December 17 - 23; Stopping Smog Belchers
description: Big trucks and buses make up only a small fraction of American vehicles. But in terms of pollution produced, they are by far the worst offenders, which is why a White House decision to close a loophole around them was seen as at least as important as a move a year ago to tighten pollution-control rules for cars and light trucks. The newest standards, which take effect in 2006, will require diesel fuel to become almost sulfur free, and force buses and big rigs to slash emissions of smog-producing material by more than 90 percent. Douglas Jehl

title: Now, Smile!

Families lug trees and wreaths, evergreens trim a hat and bells ring on ears. Children are snugly dolled up. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIFF, FANNIE
description: SHIFF-Fannie, after 93 years during which she selflessly devoted herself to her late husband, Nat, her sons, Larry and Yaacov, her sister Ceil, brother-in-law Nat and nephew Mickey, and to her late sister and brothers Clara, Harry, and Max, Fannie passed away on December 22, 2000. For the last twelve years of her life she was lovingly cared for by Yaacov and his wife Susie on their Kibbutz, Ein Hashofet, Israel, to which she moved from Miami Beach, and by Larry and his mate, Leslie, from New York. True to her ethic, she worked on the Kibbutz almost to the end, to earn her ''keep'' and avoid being a burden. She was never a burden, she was always loved and she will be missed.

title: An Accidental Singer and a Reborn Pianist to Boot
description: DENA DeROSE sings jazz as if she had been at it her whole life long, and then some. She interprets standards in a deliciously laconic, no-nonsense manner, accompanying herself on piano with hard-swinging grace. Yet her slim mezzo voice also sounds a crystalline note of vulnerability. Listening to her plaintive version of ''If I Should Lose You,'' the opening cut on her newly released third album, ''I Can See Clearly Now'' (Sharp Nine Records), you can tell she is no stranger to sorrow. Her style is so self-assured and strongly personal that it is hard to believe her singing career was an accident -- much less an unhappy one.

title: Practicing Surprise, Finding Success
description: ELEVEN years ago, Steven Soderbergh's first film, ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' won the Palme d'Or at Cannes, making him, at 26, the youngest director ever to win that festival's most coveted prize. The title quickly entered the tabloid-headline vernacular (it would gain new relevance during the long melodrama of the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal), but the movie itself was, and remains, refreshingly unsensational. Its spare, mordant comedy of sexual betrayal and romantic confusion seemed to touch obliquely on a widespread sense of unease, though Mr. Soderbergh's script refrained from specifying the causes of this mood (AIDS? economic anxiety? generational exhaustion?) beyond the troubled relationships of its four main characters.

And every year, says Mr. Birchard, owner of Veselka, the venerable Ukrainian restaurant on Second Avenue, he is pressed to bring out the soup a bit earlier. This year, as usual, he pushed up a few days, adding Christmas borscht, listed in red ink, to the menu on the first Monday in December.

''It's not something you'd saddle up to the bar and order,'' said Diane Ghioto, an owner of Isola. ''It's so rich, it goes right to your stomach. title: SUBWAY-CAR REEFS
description: New Jersey has agreed to a proposal to turn 650 old New York City subway cars into three offshore reefs in the hopes that the sunken subway cars will stimulate marine life. It will cost the Metropolitan Transport Authority less to sink the cars a dozen miles offshore than it would to scrap them. While some environmental groups see the proposal as a ''dumping'' measure and not a recycling one, the federal Environmental Protection Agency and the Coast Guard have approved the project. The plan awaits final approval from the Metropolitan Transport Authority. Anne Ruderman

She leaves to cherish her memory, a devoted family: loving husband of 62 years, Dr. Jerome W. title: Fraternal Twin Sets
description: For the ultimate in matchy-matchy, Thomas Pink is offering coordinated shirts and shirtdresses for him and her, respectively. Couples who aspire to be cut from the same cloth can pick from crisp cotton twills in royal blue, black, red and navy (lighter, brighter colors like fuchsia and yellow will be available in the spring 2001 collection). And while the men's version ($125 at all Thomas Pink stores) has classic English shirt tailoring with a cutaway collar, the women's version ($160) borders on -- call it crazy -- chic, with a fitted cut, three-quarter-length sleeves, side slits and a skinny tie belt. For those who stay in wintery climes, the dress is also available in black or camel ''suedette'' for $395. For anyone heading off to a proper Palm Beach-style holiday, however, the cotton twill his-and-her twin set provides ideal preppie attire -- good for going from golf cart to cocktail hour without ever having to change. And everyone knows that when it comes to proper Palm Beach-style holidays, change is anathema. ELLEN TIEN

title: Classifying Florida's Votes
description: The presidential election of 2000 is over. President-elect George W. Bush's transition office is scrambling to take over the White House next month in Washington. But back in the shell-shocked state of Florida, there remains this election's unfinished and untidy business. From 60,000 to as many as 180,000 votes still need to be counted, for the nation's historical and electoral record. Florida's powerful sunshine law allows public access to these ballots, which were not part of the official tally but will now be counted unofficially by news organizations and other interested groups. The results could strengthen the Bush presidency, if Mr. Bush comes out ahead, or could fuel the anger of Democrats, if it looks as though Al Gore should have won the state. But whatever the possible impact, the tally should be completed -- to gain a fuller understanding of what happened in one of the strangest balloting experiences in American history, and to devise reforms that will head off a recurrence.

title: Sometimes The Troubles Include Baldness
description: In 1987 Barry Levinson directed a tart, modest comedy called ''Tin Men,'' about a pair of rival aluminum-siding salesmen (played by Richard Dreyfuss and Danny DeVito) hawking their dubious wares to the insecure middle-class homeowners of early-1960's Baltimore. Over the course of his career, Mr. Levinson has peddled his share of slick, sentimental junk (''The Natural,'' ''Toys,'' ''Liberty Heights''), but he hasn't entirely lost the scrappy wit and the wry sense of human oddness that distinguish work like ''Tin Men,'' ''Wag the Dog'' and the early episodes of the NBC series ''Homicide.''

title: Editorial Notebook; Death of a Dedicated Ugandan Healer
description: The Ebola virus has killed 162 people in Uganda in the last three months. This is the story of death No. 156, that of Dr. Matthew Lukwiya, the medical superintendent of Lacor hospital. He first identified the Ebola outbreak in October, and led the battle against it in Gulu, a city in Uganda's north that has been the center of the epidemic. Dr. Lukwiya, a quiet man in his early 40's who left a wife and five children, died on the battlefield of a successful campaign. Although the infection has sprung up in another district, it is nearly eradicated in Gulu. Dr. Lukwiya's dedication and effectiveness won him admiration in Uganda and among the small band of doctors worldwide concerned with Ebola, and he was widely mourned. His death reminds the world that Africa produces heroism in addition to tragedy, very often both at once.

title: A Cooper's Christmas
description: A few days before Christmas, 1848, the temperature reached 66 degrees in the village of Cooperstown, N.Y. Sheep grazed in the pastures, dandelions stood in full flower, a warm mist hung over the valley. Streams had been low all autumn, but now they were rushing with water, fulfilling the predictions of the farmers, who said ''winter never comes until the streams are full.'' Carts in the bare woods stood loaded with Christmas greens -- pine and hemlock -- and in the poultry yards, ducks and turkeys fattened. But then, hour by hour the weather became more seasonable until, on the 22nd, Susan Fenimore Cooper, daughter of the novelist, could write: ''It is snowing decidedly. We shall doubtless have sleighing for the holidays.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTERT, WARREN HERBERT
description: ROTERT-Warren Herbert. Died after a long illness on December 19, 2000. Son of the late Herbert and Fannie (Wilson) Rotert, he grew up in Little Falls, NJ, and was a graduate from Passaic Valley High School (1947). He received his undergraduate degree in Civil Engineering from Lafayette College, Easton, PA (1952), his Juris Doctor from George Washington University Law School (1959), and served the United States Armed Forces from 1953-1955. Mr. Rotert was admitted to practice before the Virginia and New York Bars, the United States Supreme Court, the Federal Appellate and District Courts and was a skilled intellectual property trial lawyer. In addition to admission to the Order of the Coif and Phi Delta Phi, Warren was Patent Editor of the Law Review and a Patent Examiner before joining the New York City law firm of Morgan Finnegan in 1960. He was partner, senior partner, and served for 36 years before retiring in 1996. He was a member of the Ramsey Golf and Country Club, Ramsey, NJ, the Tuxedo Club in Tuxedo Park, New York, and Ford's Colony Country Club in Williamsburg, VA. Mr. Rotert leaves behind a family forever inspired by his show of strength, dignity and unending devotion: his loving wife Jean and their son Edward; daughter Lise Thayer and her husband Brian Thayer of Higganum, CT; son Kevin of Linwood, MA; son Todd and his wife Lauren of Ramsey; and brother David of Columbia, PA. His four grandchildren Alison, Jennifer, Ryan and Mary Beth will miss him. Warren was predeceased by his first wife, Mary Jane (Walton) Rotert in 1974. The family will receive friends on Wednesday and Thursday (2-4 PM and 7-9 PM). Funeral services will be Friday, December 29, at 10 AM. For information, contact The Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave., Ramsey, NJ. In lieu of flowers, friends can make donations to The Warren H. Rotert Scholarship Fund to benefit local youth athletes, P.O. Box 81, Ramsey, NJ 07446.

Escaping from Denmark in 1940 to freedom in the U.S. just ahead of the Nazi invasion, Mr. Borge continually showed vigorous appreciation for the opportunities provided by both his native country and his adopted land. Among those efforts -Thanks To Scandinavia, a scholarship fund created in 1963 for Scandinavian students and doctors which stands as a perpetual American ''thank you'' to Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden for the protection and rescue heroically offered Scandinavian Jews and others during World War II. This time Victor, this last time, we say thanks to you for your generosity of spirit, your friendship, your legendary humor, your sublime musicianship and your eloquent devotion to the wellbeing of your fellow man. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, EDSON V.
description: MITCHELL-Edson V. Born in Portland, Maine, on May 19, 1953, and grew up in South Portland and Auburn. He attended Edward Little High School, where he met his wife Suzan James. They married on November 11, 1972. Mr. Mitchell graduated from Colby College with distinction in Economics in 1975 and later earned an MBA from Dartmouth's Ames Tuck School. He and his family have resided in Maine, New Hampshire, near Chicago for a short time, and in Northwestern New Jersey and London. Edson Mitchell was head of Global Markets for Deutsche Bank AG, Europe's biggest investment bank, where he directed the powerful global fixed-income business from London and New York. This past June, Mr. Mitchell was one of two Americans ever to be named to the management board of Deutsche Bank AG. Prior to Deutsche Bank AG, he worked for Merrill Lynch and Bank of America's Chicago Branch. Mr. Mitchell served Colby College as an Overseer or Trustee since 1990. He has served on numerous Colby committees, including chairing the Campaign for Colby, the largest capital campaign in the college's history. In 1991, he established a scholarship fund to benefit students from Western Maine. He and his wife Suzan established the Mitchell Family Professorship in Economics and provided one of the three naming gifts for the Anthony-Mitchell-Schupf residence halls. In June, 2000, he was presented with Colby's Distinguished Alumnus Award at his 25th Renunion. Mr. Mitchell was very committed to preserving the natural beauty of Maine while at the same time promoting economic opportunities for the people of the state. He was co-founder of the Rangeley Lakes Heritage Trust, an environmental organization in the Rangeley Lakes region, which has preserved 10,000 acres and is purchasing another 800 acres at Bonney Point. It also offers a summer program for Maine youth called Ecoventure. Each year 250 children have the opportunity to learn about the environment and conservation. Mr. Mitchell was a major shareholder of Keiser Industries, a home manufacturer in Oxford, ME, and Phycogen, a biotech research firm in Falmouth, and was part owner of the Stoneybatter and the Gingerbread House in Oquossoc. He is survived by his wife, Suzan, and five children, Erik, Katie, Becky, Scott and Ellen of Chester, NJ, and Oquossoc, ME, his parents, Edson Jr. and Helen Mitchell of Cape Elizabeth, his brother Glenn of Cumberland, and his sister Karen Villeneuve of Berlin, NH. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, Tuesday, December 26, at Lorimer Chapel, Colby College, Waterville, ME. For information, contact Adams Funeral Home, Main Street, Phillips, Maine. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rangeley Lakes Heritage Trust, PO Box 249, Oquossoc, ME 04964.

Investors reacted to the news by bidding Visx shares down $3.19, or 26 percent, to $9.31. Visx said it now expected operating income of 15 cents to 17 cents a share before an $18 million charge to increase reserves against accounts receivable, indicating that the company would post a small net loss for the quarter. title: The Rural Life; Hard Frost
description: Last week a tree-farmer told me there was only an inch of frost in the ground, which was true when he said it. Now there's more, and I've set aside plans to dig a hole for the blue spruce -- a live Christmas tree -- I was buying. But I was struck by the common expression -- frost in the ground. It sounds so porous somehow, a web of crystals latticing their way down through the snow and the sod, in among the Japanese beetle grubs lying in wait for next summer. After bitter nights and a steady hard wind these past few days, the panes in my office windows have been covered with frost. When the sun strikes those windows, the frost melts instantly and the melt water evaporates almost as quickly, leaving behind dust prints where there had been drops. It all seems so fragile, so 19th-century.

title: Interpreting the Theater Without Speaking a Word

The other night there was another spotlight stage left on a woman standing in the front row facing the audience, acting out the words with her hands and face, reaching up into the darkness, pinching at make-believe cherries and dropping them into her mouth.

I just barely finished high school.''

description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26  Authorities gave tens of thousands of people permission to return to their homes near the base of the Popocatepetl volcano today, but warned them to remain on alert.

description: ''When people think of Peckham, they think of a place that is run down, violent, dangerous,'' said Dennis Tolo, of the London neighborhood where a 10-year-old boy was attacked on Nov. 27. ''But that is not the real picture.''

title: ALUMINUM SMELTER TO REDUCE OUTPUT AND SELL POWER
description: Golden Northwest Aluminum Inc. said it planned to cut production by 83 percent through October 2001 because of power shortages on the West Coast. Smelters in The Dalles, Ore., and Goldendale, Wash., will scale back output and allow the Bonneville Power Administration to resell the electricity they would have used to California, where power prices have quintupled in the last year. Aluminum smelters are among the biggest electricity users in the region. Golden Northwest will use profits from electricity sales to keep all its 1,225 employees on its payroll or to supplement unemployment compensation to match their salaries, a spokesman said.

description: THERE are many good reasons to have a drink, or several, at the holidays. But as much as I am a fan of sipping my way through the endless round of family gatherings and parties, I have never quite been satisfied with holiday drinks as I have known them.

description: POWERFUL public service campaign that has worked to discourage driving after drinking is being freshened to generate new interest in what has become a familiar message.

title: Star Performers, Toasted and Roasted
description: Long ago, boys and girls, back when there were hardly any television channels, people used to watch shows that combined a little pop music, a little serious music, a little dance, a little comedy, even a little drama. They were called variety shows, and in that simpler age, viewers seemed to like them. Nowadays you're apt to find all these elements mixed together only on awards shows. But those are usually marred by the winners' tiresome acceptance speeches.

Loving father of Ellen Piontek of Holliston, MA, and Andy Poland of Milford, Connecticut. Graduate of Columbia Grammar School, attended University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, until joining the army during W.W. II. Was a P.O.W. Worked in the textile business. Volunteered 1000's of hours to the Dad's Club, Boy Scouts, Kiwanas and others. Received numerous awards including Silver Beaver Award and President's Citation for volunteerism. Devoted cousin and friend to so many. Also leaves grandchildren Kelly, Mike, Kenny, Cliff, Tim and Todd. Will be deeply missed in his community and by all those whose life he has touched. title: PORTUGAL TELECOM PICKS SUPPLIERS
description: Portugal Telecom has picked Siemens of Germany, Alcatel of France and Sweden's Ericsson to develop its planned $789.8 million high-speed mobile phone network. Portugal Telecom, the country's leading phone company, made the announcement a week after its TMN mobile unit won one of four licenses for new generation mobile service for which it paid $92.9 million. Siemens is to build the core network and all three companies will supply the handsets for the service, which Portugal Telecom says will be operational before the end of next year. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

title: Where Darwin Mused, Strife Over Ecosystem
description: Here where exotic natural diversity led Charles Darwin to the theory of evolution and the notion of survival of the fittest, a new struggle is raging: fishermen unwilling to accept limits on their catch are openly and violently defying the Ecuadorean government's efforts to preserve a delicate and threatened ecosystem.

title: Philharmonic Broadens Search for A Conductor
description: With just over two years to go until Kurt Masur's contract with the New York Philharmonic comes to an end, and with most conductors of stature booked well beyond that date, Philharmonic officials say that the orchestra is not close to naming Mr. Masur's successor. Moreover, the field of candidates under serious consideration appears to have widened in recent weeks.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WARWICK BANCORP TO EXPAND
description: Warwick Community Bancorp, the parent of Warwick Savings Bank, has agreed to buy the Carmel, N.Y., banking office of Country Bank to expand its financial and banking operations in New York. Terms were not disclosed. The companies said Warwick would assume ''deposit liabilities'' of about $50 million and purchase loans of about $19 million with other assets. Workers in Country Bank's Carmel office will stay on, the companies said in a news release. Country Bank, based in Carmel, has assets of about $150 million and five branch offices in New York City and Westchester and Putnam Counties. Warwick Community Bancorp, based in Warwick, N.Y., has assets of about $650 million.

title: Voters' League To Shut Office In New York
description: After decades of sponsoring local political debates and publishing voter information guides, the League of Women Voters will close its New York office in January because of mounting financial problems, organization officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLERT, PETER JOSEPH
description: GELLERT-Peter Joseph. Died on Dec. 23, 2000 from complications resulting from aplastic anemia. Born on August 6, 1926 to Greta (Petschek) Gellert and Oswald R. Gellert in Prague, Czechoslovakia, he attended The Lawrenceville School, Harvard College, and Yale Law School. He served in the US Army during World War II, including a tour in the Pacific theater. For over 40 years, he was a senior executive at United Continental Corporation, managing the affairs of the Gellert & Petschek families. He was an amateur radio enthusiast, using the call sign W2WSS & published a monthly newsletter. He is survived by his wife, Anna (Monser) Gellert; his children, Alexander G. and Anthony E.; his brothers, Martin F., Michael E., and Hubert J.; his sister, Catherine G. Ross; his grandson, Alexander G.; and numerous nephews, nieces, & cousins. A funeral service will be held January 3, 2001 at 2:00PM, The General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Ave. between 20th and 21st Streets in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to New York-Presbyterian Hospital (Attention: Dr. E. William Davis, Room F-172, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021), or to the Harvard College Music Library (C/O Eda Kuhn Loeb Music Library, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138).

title: New Defibrillators Raise Debate Over Firefighters' Role
description: In mid-December, this city's 19 firehouses began receiving a revolutionary machine that, with a jolt of electricity, can revive people who suffer cardiac arrest. In some cases, victims can walk away unscathed.

While Sauternes is probably the most famous, it is not my favorite. I love the sweet chenin blancs from the Loire, the fabulously honeyed wines from Hungary known as tokay aszu and, especially, the sweet wines of Germany.

title: GENENTECH CITED BY F.D.A. FOR QUALITY CONTROL LAPSES
description: Genentech was cited by the Food and Drug Administration for a series of lapses in quality control, most of them related to Pulmozyme, a drug used by cystic fibrosis patients. Among other problems mentioned in the agency's Dec. 14 warning letter to the company were use of expired raw materials in January and failure to obtain approval before shipping two bulk lots of Pulmozyme that had been contaminated and then refiltered. Filtration issues also prompted a voluntary recall of one lot of Pulmozyne in October. A company spokeswoman said the problems listed in the F.D.A.'s letter had been addressed and that none had caused any safety problems with its drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFLER, RUBELLE
description: SCHAFLER-Rubelle. The Board of Trustees, staff, consumers of YAI/National Institute for people with Disabilities notes with the deepest sorrow the loss of Rubelle Schafler. A distinguished member of our Board of Trustees for over three decades, she was a tireless crusader on behalf of the rights of people with mental retardation and developmental disabilities. Her life long advocacy to promote community inclusion for people with disabilities was instrumental in the establishment of many group homes, including the Rubelle Schafler Residence in Manhattan. Her concern for, and devotion to, young children with special needs was recently recognized through the naming of the Rubelle Schafler Early Childhood Center. Her courage and commitment will continue to serve as an inspiration to all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her son Scott, her daughter Julie, and to her entire family. Marcella Fava, Chairman Dr. Paul H. Levitz, Vice Chairman Board of Trustees Dr. Joel M. Levy, CEO Dr. Philip H. Levy, Pres. and COO YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities

Lee Stanton & Helen LaFetra Stanton & was graduated from the Chapin School. She was a Governor of the Colony Club of New York and a member of the Parent Chapter of the Colonial Dames of America, the Country Club of New Canaan, the New Canaan Garden Club, the Norwalk Yacht Club, and the Yeamans Hall Club of Charleston, SC, and was active with the National Orchestral Association, the Morgan Library and the English Speaking Union. She served as Chairman of the Women's Board of Directors for the Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and as an officer of the Scholarships Foundation, Inc. of New York. description: Before memories fade, let us not forget the television and business highlights and lowlights of 2000:

title: TOBACCO SHARES CANCELED
description: Altadis S.A., the Spanish-French tobacco company, said it had canceled 1.4 percent of its outstanding shares in an effort to stem a slide in its stock price. Since October, Altadis has now canceled a total of 4.9 percent of its shares, which had previously been bought in through repurchase programs, to increase the per-share dividend paid on the remaining shares.

title: For Writers Under the Gun, A Chance to Beat the Odds
description: It may come as a surprise to anyone other than lucky gamblers and people under the federal witness protection program, but Las Vegas is officially a City of Asylum, as designated by the International Parliament of Writers. This means that writers who escape or are exiled from their home countries for political reasons may find sanctuary in Las Vegas, as they also can in Barcelona, Frankfurt, Lausanne, Venice and 25 other cities around the world.

title: Big Investment in Port
description: The Russian government and private companies will invest $105 million to build a new sea terminal for fertilizer and modernize rail and road links to the St. Petersburg port in the next three years, as part of a program to double the port's capacity by 2010, the government said. Russia estimates that it loses $2 billion a year in cargo duties and other fees because lack of port capacity has driven shippers to land their goods in neighboring countries. The terminal is expected to open in November.

title: BHP SAID TO CONSIDER LISTING STOCK IN U.S. OR BRITAIN
description: BHP Ltd., Australia's largest natural resources company, is considering listing its shares on stock exchanges in Britain or the United States out of frustration with the stock's lackluster performance on the Australian Stock Exchange, according to a report in the Australian Financial Review that did not cite sources. The report said the company believed that by listing in London or New York, it would become eligible for inclusion in broad-based index funds and could tap a wider pool of investors, and its share price would rise. BHP shares, which have fallen about 4 percent this year, rose slightly to around 18.8 Australian dollars in early trading Wednesday.

title: LEVI STRAUSS GETS $1.5 BILLION IN BANK CREDIT
description: Levi Strauss got a commitment for $1.5 billion in new bank credit to reduce its borrowing costs and allow it to avoid a $32 million penalty on its existing debt. The new financing commitment, from Bank of America, Citicorp USA and the Bank of Nova Scotia, is split evenly between a term loan and a revolving line of credit. In October, Levi Strauss had to shelve plans to sell $350 million of junk bonds because prevailing market rates had risen too high.

title: Joe Gilliam Is Dead at 49; Pioneer Black Quarterback
description: Joe Gilliam, who was one of the first blacks to be a starting pro quarterback when he played for the Pittsburgh Steelers' 1974 Super Bowl champions but who later slid into drug addiction and homelessness, died Monday in Nashville. He was 49.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCECA, ROBERT K.
description: MARCECA-Robert K., 57, President and owner of RKM Enterprises Real Estate Investments Inc. and Kane Realty Services, Inc., died on December 26, 2000 at NYU Hospital in NYC. Mr. Marceca was a real estate investor, developer and property manager. Mr. Marceca was in the real estate business for over 30 years. He developed, owned and managed his own real estate portfolio, both in the U.S. and abroad. During the 1980s he was extremely active in the cooperative/condominium business, having converted over 100 buildings throughout NYC, Westchester and Long Island. In the 1990s Mr. Marceca began buying unsold cooperative shares and condominium units of rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments at discounted values and more recently, began acquiring residential rental properties. Mr. Marceca was truly a maverick in defining the undervalued market niche for blocks of unsold shares of cooperative and unsold condominium units. Mr. Marceca maintained relationships with dozens of brokers, banks, financial institutions and private lending investment groups who assisted and participated with him in his many ventures. Robert was born on December 1, 1943 in NYC, the son of Alda Marceca and the late Robert P. Marceca. Mr. Marceca, a devoted family man, is survived by his wife, Nini, daughters Cathy Pilkin, Kobi, Kaylie, Riley and Siena, son, Nico, and grandchildren Kaitlin, Sean and Maggie. His contagious enthusiasm for life, his courage, commitment and leadership will be missed by his friends, colleagues, business associates and employees. Mr. Marceca was also a philanthropist, especially interested in organizations which served children. Mr. Marceca was a devoted member of the Steering Committee for Fight Against Childhood Epilepsy and Seizures (FACES), a charity at Mt. SinaiNYU Medical Center whose mission is to promote improved quality of life for children with epilepsy through clinical care, education, and research. Among Mr. Marceca's many generous contributions to the organization was an apartment for families to use while their child has brain surgery or is monitored at the Comprehensive Epilepsy Center at NYU. He was the founder of the Siena New Hope Home, which provides a safe haven to support children and aid them to achieve their maximum psychological, social and economic potential while fully respecting the dignity and worth of each individual. The home presently houses five children at a time. Mr. Marceca was also the founder of the Siena Hostel in Eluru, India, which schools 100 very poor children. He also purchased various supplies for the poor including food for hungry children and vehicles in Brazil, India, Ireland, Albania, Ethiopia and Eritrea. Funeral services will be held for the family on Thursday, December 28, 2000. A memorial serivice wil be held on Wednesday, January 3, 2001, at 10:30AM at the Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, 570 E. 33 St., NY NY. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Robert Marceca's name to the Siena New Hope Home, Box 518, New Monmouth, NJ 07748.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, SUZANNE
description: SNYDER-Suzanne. Adored wife of Ronald Snyder. Dearest mother of Lauren and Richard. Beloved sister of Michael Ullman and Janey Bernstein. Mother-in-law of Miranda Snyder. Sister-in-law of Susan Ullman, Bonnie, Richard and Jeffrey Synder, and Steven Bernstein. Born, New York City to Lucele and Paul Ullman, November 11, 1941. After a long, hard battle that she fought with dignity and fortitude, Suzanne passed away from metastatic breast cancer on December 25, 2000. Loving family and friends surrounded her. Suzanne spent many years giving to others. She had a long career as the Assistant Executive Director of First District Dental Society of New York and was one of the cofounders of the High School for the Humanities. A woman of great accomplishment and a champion for public education, she furthered the quality of learning both professionally and personally. A loving friend, always willing to lend an ear or hand, her advice and love were invaluable to many. Suzanne will be missed by all that she touched and will continue to be an inspiration to all that knew her. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICARD, ANTOINE A.
description: PICARD-Antoine A., 71 of Bean Road in Charlotte, VT. Died Sunday, December 24, 2000 at his son's home in Hinesburg. He was born in Brussels, Belgium on November 8, 1929, the son of Andre and Elizabeth (Boelaers) Picard. He received an M.A. in Law and a B.A. in Economics from the University of Louvain in Belgium. He had been an international insurance broker for Marsh & McLennan for 28 years, retiring in 1995. He continued as a consultant to them until this year. From 1958 to 1966 he developed and managed a Belgian brokerage company, Paul Mortelmans & Co., principally engaged in ocean marine cargo and aviation. He came to the U.S. in 1957 on the Liberte and worked for the Ministry of Foreign Trade at the Belgian Chamber of Commerce. As part of his work he traveled extensively in the Middle East, Far East, South America, Southeast Asia, Europe, and Russia. In addition to his love of travel he enjoyed gourmet food, fine wine, history, photography, and classical music. He lived in the U.S. since 1957 and always considered Brussels, Belgium home. He is survived by his four children and their spouses; Anne P. and Bjorn Ostlund of Calgary, Alberta, Canada, Eric L. Picard and Sally Tappan of Hinesburg, VT, Christina P. and Vanya Yoors of Gloucester, MA, and Nathalie N. Picard of Little Rock, AR; eight grandchildren; one brother, Etienne Picard of Brussels, Belgium. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 29, 2000 at 11 A.M. in the Ready Funeral Home. Burial will be in the Spring in Charlotte, VT. Those who wish may make contributions in his memory to the Nature Conservancy or donate blood to the American Red Cross. Visiting hours will be held on Thursday evening from 7 to 9 PM at the Ready Funderal Home South Chapel, 261 Shelburne Rd., Burlington.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CONRAIL SUES PERTH AMBOY
description: Conrail, a unit of the CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation, is suing to block Perth Amboy, N.J., from condemning a section of its track to build a $30 million municipal complex. The lawsuit, filed last week in a federal court in Newark, alleges that Perth Amboy cannot condemn the track because it is an active part of Conrail's Perth Amboy line, and that only the Surface Transportation Board in Washington can declare an active line abandoned. Conrail's 11,400-mile system was divided in June 1999 between CSX and Norfolk Southern. CSX owns 42 percent of Conrail, and Norfolk Southern owns 58 percent. Conrail said it expects a substantial increase in freight traffic along the Perth Amboy line in the next decade. Conrail said removing part of the Perth Amboy line would eliminate its ability to maintain connections to a local freight yard, and to direct traffic around Amtrak's Northeast Corridor, which connects with the Perth Amboy line.

IBP, whose board is still examining the Tyson offer and a competing $25-a-share bid from Smithfield Foods, the leading pork producer, said in a regulatory filing that shareholders should ''take no action with respect to the Tyson offer at this time.'' An important concern was Tyson's stock price, which has sunk to near the lower end of the ''collar'' provision in Tyson's offer; if it falls any farther, shareholders who accept the offer would risk getting less than $26 worth of Tyson stock for their shares. IBP shares fell 31 cents to $25.75.

title: PHONE RATE WAR IN JAPAN
description: Responding to a plan announced by Japan's dominant telephone company, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, last week to reduce local phone rates for the first time since the 1970's, the Tokyo Telecommunication Network Company, said it would ask regulators to allow it to move forward its own planned rate cuts from May to January. Tokyo Telecommunication is majority-owned by the Tokyo Electric Power Corporation. A deregulation program scheduled to take effect in May would make it much easier for consumers to choose among competing service providers.

Caemi controls production of about 26 million tons of ore a year.

description: Toshiba said it would form a venture with I.B.M. and Taiyo Yuden to control the promotion of the Bluetooth wireless transmission standard in Japan for personal computers, mobile phones and other electronic products. The venture will offer consulting services for companies making electronic products using the technology and will issue certificates to authenticate products meeting the Bluetooth standard, Toshiba said in a statement. Toshiba, the world's largest maker of notebook PC's, is one of the five founders of Bluetooth, an open standard for short-range wireless transmission of digital data between PC's, mobile phones and hand-held devices.

Mr. Lang was the owner of Kenlin Pet Supply in Mahwah, N.J. which was one of the largest wholesale pet supply distributors in the United States. He sold the business when he retired in 1992. Mr. Lang is survived by children Robert (Susan) Lang of Margate, N.J., Carole Lang of Boca Raton, Fla., Dennis (Liz) Lang of New City, N.Y., grandchildren Philip, Steven, Jeffrey, Brian, Lisa and Eric Lang. title: NETCREATIONS ACCEPTS BID
description: SEAT Pagine Gialle, an Italian Internet service provider and telephone directory publisher, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire NetCreations in New York, which offers e-mail data collection, database management and e-mail marketing services. The cash deal, valued at approximately $111 million, comes after DoubleClick dropped out of the bidding for the company. DoubleClick will collect a breakup fee of $8.6 million plus expenses from NetCreations. Plans call for the transaction to close in the first quarter of 2001.

title: THAI UNION TO BUY REMAINDER OF TRI-UNION SEAFOODS
description: Thai Union Frozen Products, a major tuna canner, agreed to buy the other half of Tri-Union Seafoods for $38.5 million in cash from its partner, Tri-Marine International. Tri-Union manufactures and markets Chicken of the Sea tuna, the No. 3 brand in the United States after Star-Kist and Bumble Bee. Thai Union, based in Bangkok, has been diversifying outside its home country for several years; it teamed up with Tri-Marine to acquire the Chicken of the Sea brand in 1997.

title: Colleges Are Moving to Ensure English Fluency in Teaching Assistants
description: At colleges and universities, graduate-student teaching assistants are often the backbone of large lecture classes, especially in the sciences. They guide undergraduates through lab assignments, set up the review sessions and often give out grades. They are sometimes an undergraduate's only hope of understanding incomprehensible course material.

description: Agroup of school leaders and education associations are exploring a new set of technology standards for what school administrators should know about and do with technology.

title: EarthWeb Selling Most of Its Web Sites and News Services

EarthWeb officials said they would continue to operate their business as a recruiting company for technology workers.

title: Hope Is Artists' Medium In a Bronx Neighborhood; Dancers, Painters and Sculptors Head to Hunts Point
description: In the late 1970's, while the Bronx was burning, a small cadre of artists gathered in a storefront gallery on Third Street near the Hub at 149th Street, in the heart of a neighborhood rapidly turning to rubble. They put sculptures in abandoned lots, photographed teenagers dancing on linoleum laid over cracked concrete and painted kaleidoscopic murals on the grayest of walls.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

They were given wrong directions for gaining access to the class Web site. Their passwords did not work. Now their papers have been lost in an electronic netherworld.

Credit Suisse First Boston, J. P. Morgan & Company, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and other banks could have bought the shares at the offering price, 11 euros ($10.25) a share. Moviles stock closed yesterday at 10.4 euros ($9.68).

The Children's Advertising Review unit of the Better Business Bureau informed Oxygen in November that several of its sites for teenagers allowed access to minors without the parental consent or age screeening required under federal law. Oxygen, which denied in the text of the agreement that it sought to attract children, said it would require registering teenagers to give their age and prevent children under 13 from registering for interactive parts of its sites. John Schwartz

title: From the Bridge West, A New TriBeCa
description: ''Fifty-ninth Street is going to be the new hot spot on the East Side,'' said Assemblyman John A. Ravitz, who represents the district. Just how hot? ''It's the new TriBeCa,'' the interior designer Jeffrey Bilhuber said. ''It's the last vestige of Bohemian New York.'' Mr. Bilhuber works in a loft on 59th Street, east of Second Avenue, where funky jewel-box home boutiques are springing up. The Terence Conran Shop on First Avenue in Bridgemarket under the Queensboro Bridge marks the east side of the new strip, Crate & Barrel on Madison Avenue the western boundary. Pottery Barn and Williams-Sonoma opened flagship stores last month just west of Lexington Avenue. Meanwhile, the Transportation Department has installed new carved granite walls that replicate the original architectural detailing on the south side of the bridge roadway. A new bicycle path and walkway on the north side of the bridge, above, is a welcome addition to a neighborhood with everything -- except a parking spot.

To see plasma televisions lined up in an electronics store is like looking at paintings at the Louvre: a connoisseur might explain to you how what's in one rectangular frame might have a special sharpness or clarity, while what's in another might be a little richer in color. But they all look amazing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, HILDA
description: REISS-Hilda. To the sweetest, most lovable wife and mother in the world. For the past 57 years she's been the greatest, most lovable woman that a man could ever have. I didn't deserve her but she was mine. She loved me, took care of myself and my son, was there for me all of the time and was a great friend to me, to my son and to everybody she came in contact with. She listened with a full heart and she gave a full heart for humanity. She gave of herself and she asked for little. She was the best of what humanity has to offer. She was the best mom in the world. For you, I knew that you always loved me more than life itself. I loved you the most, also. I was lucky; I am lucky to have known you. She had the most lovable smile and for me, her husband, she was a pleasure to live with. It's impossible to think that she's not here, but to those who knew her, her spirit touched them and will live on. Alfred Reiss Bart Reiss

description: WARDEN-Ann S. Of New Canaan, CT died Monday, December 25 at her home following a brief illness. She was born in New York City, September 17, 1924 the daughter of the late L. Lee Stanton & Helen LaFetra Stanton & was graduated from the Chapin School. She was a Governor of the Colony Club of New York and a member of the Parent Chapter of the Colonial Dames of America, the Country Club of New Canaan, the New Canaan Garden Club, the Norwalk Yacht Club, and the Yeamans Hall Club of Charleston, SC, and was active with the National Orchestral Association, the Morgan Library and the English Speaking Union. She served as Chairman of the Women's Board of Directors for the Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and as an officer of the Scholarships Foundation, Inc. of New York. The security forces contracted by British Petroleum in Colombia, Shell and Chevron in Nigeria, among other companies, have been accused of similar abuses.

But after he was acquired on Aug. 3 and signed to a seven-year, $93 million contract, Hill played only four regular-season games because of pain in his surgically repaired left ankle. Yesterday, the team announced that Hill would undergo another surgical procedure, ending his season and most likely the Magic's dreams of a run to the top of the Eastern Conference. Hill is expected to need six to eight months of rehabilitation before he can return to the court.

title: NEW PLANT FOR BUILDING V-8 ENGINES IS PLANNED
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is seriously considering building a new plant in the Southern United States to produce 150,000 or more V-8 engines for use in the full-size pickups and sport-utility vehicles it produces in Indiana, a senior Toyota executive said yesterday. The plant, which would be Toyota's second engine plant in the United States, is part of the Japanese auto maker's aggressive push into America's light-truck market, previously the bastion of Detroit's Big Three automakers. Toyota has just introduced two new sport utility vehicles, the Sequoia and the Highlander, and fully redesigned its Rav4 small S.U.V. The senior Toyota executive in the United States, who insisted on anonymity, said the company would probably announce a decision next year.

''There is absolutely no chance that Nintendo will buy Sega,'' Hiroshi Yamauchi, the president of Nintendo, said in a statement. But executives close to the companies say that the companies have held talks, in fits and starts, for months. Sega's shares rose 100 yen (88 cents), their daily limit, to 1,054 yen ($9.28), and were suspended by the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Nintendo's shares closed down 5.4 percent at 17,390 yen ($153.15). title: HUNT OIL OF TEXAS IN BID FOR BERKLEY PETROLEUM
description: The Hunt Oil Company, a closely held company owned by the Hunt family of Dallas, made an unsolicited bid yesterday to buy the natural gas producer Berkley Petroleum Corporation for 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($927 million) in cash and assumed debt to increase its Canadian gas production. Hunt offered to pay 10 Canadian dollars for each Berkley share, a 15 percent premium to Friday's closing price of $8.70, and assume about $379 million of Berkley debt. Berkley rose $2.50, or 29 percent, to $11.20 in late Toronto trading. The share price exceeded the bid, suggesting some investors expect a higher offer. The company, based in Calgary, Alberta, leads a venture that is drilling for gas near Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Survival Instinct Makes Way For a Knight in Shining Armor
description: I HAVE sort of a crush on the woman in Dino Crisis. She has short red hair, intelligent eyes and a level head. (She has to take a lot of guff from the two military types with her.) She looks good whether she's climbing a rope, aiming a shotgun or running down a hallway. She looks good even when she's savaged by a toothy dinosaur. This has been happening to her a lot.

title: SHILOH, AUTO PARTS SUPPLIER, WARNS OF EARNINGS DROP
description: Shiloh Industries Inc., a parts supplier to the three largest United States automakers, said yesterday that earnings this quarter will fall to as low as 5 cents a share as fiscal fourth-quarter profit slid 73 percent on reduced demand. The company anticipates per-share earnings in the quarter ending Jan. 31 of 5 to 10 cents. Shiloh was forecast to earn 19 cents a share, according to an analyst surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Profit from operations at the Cleveland-based company declined to $1.4 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31 from net income of $5.1 million, or 39 cents, in the year-earlier period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELL, MALVINA C.
description: MENDELL-Malvina C. 103, died peacefully on December 26, 2000, in Palm Beach, FL. Wife of the late M. Lester Mendell, to whom she was married for 65 years. Mother of Edward (Renee), Oliver (Shelley), and Olga (Wilbur) Toll. Grandmother of ten, great grandmother of fifteen, great great grandmother of three. Sister of Frances Kaplan, and Mussie Gellis. Mrs. Mendell was a Director of The Jewish Guild for The Blind, and The Honoree at their 1998 Dinner. She will be sorely missed by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, memorials to a charity of your choice in her memory would be appreciated. Services noon Friday, December 29 at Riverside, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon. Respects may be paid at the home of Mrs. Toll on Friday after 4 PM.

description: I LOVE the smell of potatoes in the oven, thin slices of potatoes layered in a cast-iron skillet, doused with butter and cream, bubbling and crispy on top. Everything I love has been taken from me. For the first time in my life, I am on a diet.

title: Fit for a Simulated Versailles on the Terrace
description: Last month, Janus & Cie., a Los Angeles-based showroom of garden furniture and artificial topiary, opened a 4,000-square-foot store at 221 East 59th Street. Chairs, tables and chaise longues from many makers are offered, including garden chairs starting at $150 and a painted mahogany Chelsea seat (above), a bench that costs $14,435. It is from the Chatsworth collection of handcrafted reproduction furniture made in a workshop on the estate of the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, where the originals were made early in the last century. Seven-foot-tall synthetic trees (above) are $2,200 each and can be used in a garden or on a terrace, or even indoors in a lobby or foyer. Four-foot trees are $1,100.

title: Gretzky's Group Gets Extension
description: What tonight's 4-3 loss to the Carolina Hurricanes demonstrated to the Rangers is that they desperately need help. If it is to come from the Phoenix area, however, it is not going to happen soon.

title: Keeping the Show Going in a Circus-Saturated Land
description: Under the Knie Circus's enormous big top, the classic European circus is thriving. Elephants, horses galore, zebras, a giraffe and a huge rhinoceros keep the magic of the center ring alive.

title: Andy Reid, the New King of Philadelphia
description: Andy Reid, the stocky magician who knows how to do more with less than almost any other coach in the National Football League, trekked through the 20-degree chill outside his Veteran Stadium offices earlier this week. There, thousands of Philadelphia fans were standing in winding lines, braving the bone-rattling cold and waiting for a chance to buy tickets to the wild-card playoff game between the Eagles and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Sunday.

title: A Tree Sculptor Revives an Ancient Art
description: PETER THEVENOT, nurseryman and arborphile, calls himself ''a gnarly-bark guy.'' On a Saturday morning last October, he steered his pickup truck toward a lichen-covered river birch near the bank of Big Sewee Creek, which joins the Tennessee River on the edge of his 340-acre farm here. The birch's peeling bark was reddish-brown, tan and white, with the texture of parchment. ''Isn't that cool?'' Mr. Thevenot asked.

title: TALKS SET TO BUY REST OF HAAGEN-DAZS VENTURE
description: Nestle S.A., said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the 50 percent it did not own in a venture that sells Haagen-Dazs ice cream in the United States. Analysts said the transaction might be worth $650 million. Nestle, based in Vevey, Switzerland, had the option to purchase the stake for its agreed value plus $150 million after General Mills Inc. bought Pillsbury, the owner of Haagen-Dazs. Prudential Securities estimates fair value at $500 million. Nestle declined to comment on the price. The Swiss company and Haagen-Dazs merged their United States ice cream businesses last year to become No. 3 in the market, with 1998 sales of $600 million.

title: For All Russia, Biological Clock Is Running Out
description: If Ina Chaikovskaya does not have it all, she has more than most women in this ancient military town: brains and pluck, an apartment and a Zhiguli sedan bought with profits from her own business, a pointed wit.

title: For Classical Music Lovers, the Internet Becomes a Concert Hall
description: MANY people, including music lovers, shy away from live classical music for all kinds of reasons -- distance from the recital hall, objections to dressing up, apprehension in the face of an entire Mahler symphony.

title: Nothing's Too Good For the Super
description: THERE may still be a few New Yorkers who think their building superintendent lives downstairs in a cramped and dark basement apartment suffused with smells from the laundry room and racked by the creaking of the freight elevator. Those people probably don't live in co-ops or condominiums. Or even fancy rentals.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about Thomas Frank, the author of ''One Market, Under God: Extreme Capitalism, Market Populism and the End of Economic Democracy,'' gave an erroneous name in some copies for a debate feature in which he took part in the online magazine Slate. It is ''The Breakfast Table,'' not ''Table Talk.''

title: Into an 80's Time Warp, Complete With Mirror Ball
description: The 1980's weren't over as long as Eikichi Yazawa was onstage at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night. It all came flooding back: the chiseled, raunch-free riffs, the one-handed synthesizer lines, the zooming Van Halen guitar solos, the power ballad with a spotlight hitting a mirror ball. All that was missing from what could have been an early-MTV retrospective was big hair. Not to mention that most of the lyrics were in Japanese.

title: Leading Indicators Fall Again, Signaling Slowdown in Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in November, the seventh month out of eight without an increase, the Conference Board said today. The drop could be an indication that the economy is slowing more than Federal Reserve policy makers had wanted.

title: In America; Fragile Victories
description: In the early 1980's the producers of the made-for-TV movie ''The Day After'' needed a neighborhood suitable for filming scenes of the aftermath of a nuclear attack. No problem. They filmed at the intersection of Linwood and Prospect boulevards in Kansas City, Mo. Over the past several decades, few things have been easier than locating inner-city neighborhoods that had literally been reduced to rubble, destroyed as if by bombing.

title: INTERCONNECTION PACT IN MEXICO
description: Telefonos de Mexico reached an agreement yesterday with the Mexican affiliates of AT&T and WorldCom on debts and interconnection fees. Although the companies provided few details of the accord, it is expected to ease tension over access to Mexico's $12 billion telecommunications market. Telmex reached the accord with Alestra, of which AT&T owns 49 percent, and Avantel, in which WorldCom is a minority partner. Simon Romero

title: The Man Who Watched It Happen
description: Charlie Carter, left, is affectionately known as the mayor of 59th Street because he was the first one on the block and knows everyone in the neighborhood. He has owned Bridge Street Antiques for seven years. The 650-square-foot store, now at 318 East 59th Street, is so full of used furniture and bric-a-brac that he cannot get into his basement. Mr. Carter and other vendors hope to get a city permit to operate a weekend flea market in the spring across the street in Honey Locust Park (now used for trucks). The park, along the south wall of the Queensboro Bridge, will soon be renovated.

title: NRG ENERGY TO BUY 2 COAL-FIRED CONNECTICUT PLANTS
description: NRG Energy Inc., a Minneapolis-based power plant developer, has agreed to buy two coal-fired plants in Connecticut from the Wisconsin Energy Corporation for about $350 million to increase power sales in the Northeast. NRG will pay $325 million for the plants and about $25 million for their inventory and fuel, a Wisconsin Energy spokesman, Michael John, said yesterday. The plants, in Bridgeport and New Haven, together can generate up to 1,000 megawatts, which is enough power to light about one million United States homes. The purchases will help the company's ''strategy of developing and maintaining a top-three position in the Northeast,'' said David H. Peterson, NRG's chairman and chief executive. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter, Mr. John said. It is expected to add to NRG's earnings immediately, Mr. Peterson said. Wisconsin Energy is based in Milwaukee.

title: Browsing the Web for the Ideal Utopia Site
description: THE idealized places and social systems we call utopias, after the imaginary island in Sir Thomas More's 1516 work, have had a bad century. Nazism, Communism, suicide cults, fundamentalist theocracies and other extremisms have led to eye-rolling exasperation at utopias in general and linked the concept of an earthly heaven with a dystopian descent into earthly hell.

It is chockablock with brightly colored products from places Ms. Vinson visits with her husband, Christopher Blackwell, a hotelier with properties in Miami and Jamaica. From Jamaica, she has brought handsome handmade garden fencing (right), which can be custom-ordered ($300 for a 6-foot-by-6-foot panel). Inside, there are 22-inch-square wicker floor cushions ($150) and tablecloths ($150 to $250).

title: Charter School Accountability
description: The New York City schools chancellor, Harold Levy, surprised educators when he announced in the fall that he would consider privatizing a few low-performing schools to see if private enterprise could succeed where the Board of Education had thus far failed. After evaluating proposals from several education management organizations, Mr. Levy has now opened negotiations with Edison Schools Inc., the country's largest for-profit manager of public schools, to run up to five of the city's lowest-performing schools. The privatization experiment should indeed go forward -- but only if the schools placed under private management remain accessible to all children, open to public scrutiny and fully accountable for their performance based on rigorous academic standards. Data from other states show that the only way to guarantee the necessary transparency and rigor is to write them into the contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBARDS, JASON
description: ROBARDS-Jason. The Roundabout Theatre Company profoundly mourns the passing of our beloved friend and board member, Jason Robards. His warmth, generous spirit and extraordinary talent were a source of great inspiration and joy to us all. As an actor, he partnered with his dear friend Christopher Plummer in our production of Harold Pinter's ''No Man's Land''. Later he would spend a full season on our stage when Roundabout opened the Laura Pels Theatre. He was affectionately referred to as our ''artist in residence'' for that very special 1994-95 season. Beyond his work on stage, it was his commitment to the art of theatre and his celebration of the people behind the scenes that made him such a very special member of our company. His impact, as a member of the Roundabout family and the greater theatre community, is profound and we are grateful to have had him in our lives. He will be deeply missed on our stage, in our boardroom and in our lives. We extend our most sincere condolences to his beloved wife, Lois, and his children. Mary Cirillo, Board of Directors Todd Haimes, Artistic Director And Staff Roundabout Theatre Company

For the first time, the Gallup Organization even polled people on which candidate was better-looking. (Mr. Gore beat Mr. Bush, 44 percent to 24 percent.) The question was worth asking because the answer was not obvious. Both candidates were way above average.

title: Remembering Jason Robards
description: When an actor of Jason Robards's stature dies, it is almost as though more than one death were taking place. The characters he played over the years, especially the ones written by Eugene O'Neill, seem to die a little too. At least three O'Neill roles, Hickey in ''The Iceman Cometh'' and James Tyrone Jr. in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' and ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' are indelibly associated with Mr. Robards. He brought them into the special, permanent being that an actor rarely achieves, defining them and himself and the playwright in the process.

title: PUBLISHER OF PENGUIN GETS MARKETWATCH.COM STAKE
description: Pearson P.L.C., publisher of Penguin books and The Financial Times newspaper, bought a stake in MarketWatch.com Inc. from Pearson's Data Broadcasting Corporation unit to cut Data Broadcasting's losses. Pearson, based in London, paid $26.9 million for Data Broadcasting's 34.4 percent stake in MarketWatch.com, owner of the cbs.marketwatch.com financial-news Web site, Data Broadcasting said. Data Broadcasting, a provider of financial market data, will be profitable before taxes, it said, now that it no longer has to shoulder a share of MarketWatch.com's losses. Pearson owns about a 60 percent stake in Data Broadcasting, which is based in Bedford, Mass.

title: A Park Offers Nature, Not Just Hoops

Hawkins Natural Park -- a park the neighborhood helped design to include bits of wildness -- these were some things it was impossible to do in South Central Los Angeles. With irresistible symbols that include hills made from recycled Malibu mudslides, residents of one of the city's densest and poorest neighborhoods finally have a park, with an around-the-clock ranger in a Smokey Bear hat and an arroyo with rocks from the Los Angeles River.

description: GELLERT-Peter Joseph. Died on Dec. 23, 2000 from complications resulting from aplastic anemia. Born on August 6, 1926 to Greta (Petschek) Gellert and Oswald R. Gellert in Prague, Czechoslovakia, he attended The Lawrenceville School, Harvard College, and Yale Law School. He served in the US Army during World War II, including a tour in the Pacific theater. For over 40 years, he was a senior executive at United Continental Corporation, managing the affairs of the Gellert & Petschek families. He was an amateur radio enthusiast, using the call sign W2WSS & published a monthly newsletter. He is survived by his wife, Anna (Monser) Gellert; his children, Alexander G. and Anthony E.; his brothers, Martin F., Michael E., and Hubert J.; his sister, Catherine G. title: BANK OF GREECE CUTS RATE
description: The Bank of Greece cut its benchmark interest rate one percentage point, to 4.75 percent, bringing Greek rates in line with those of the euro zone. Starting next month, the drachma, Europe's oldest currency, will be replaced by the newest, as Greece becomes the 12th nation to adopt the euro -- the unified European currency. The drachma will enter at an exchange rate of 340.75 a euro. The cut in the interest rate was the ninth this year and the fourth this month. It was left until the 11th hour because of concern that lower rates would encourage consumer spending and inflation.

title: Still a Long Way From Checkmate

title: CORDIANT COMMUNICATIONS AGREES TO BUY MICROARTS
description: The Cordiant Communications Group has agreed to buy the MicroArts Corporation, an Internet brand consultant, for as much as $88.1 million in stock to expand its United States marketing business. Cordiant will pay $47.4 million to $88.1 million in stock for the agency, based in Portsmouth, N.H., with the price depending on MicroArts' financial performance to December 2003, Cordiant said yesterday. MicroArts had $5.2 million in 1999 sales and expects to have $13.1 million in revenue in 2000. Closely held MicroArts helps develop online brands and designs Web sites.

title: A Shirt With Such Power That It Just Might Knock 'em Dead
description: To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned by only the most courageous: those who met the enemy in battle or sneaked into enemy camps to steal horses. And those rewarded had to live up to the shirts, observing a strict code of conduct. Many warriors who did became the political and spiritual leaders of their tribes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Montgomery Ward to Close Its Doors
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, once the greatest American retailer and the pioneer of many sales practices that became widely accepted, said yesterday that it would go out of business after 128 years.

title: Broncos' Understudy Now Has Lead Role
description: An almost clairvoyant power ribbons through Denver Coach Mike Shanahan as he annually plunders the garage sale of talent left over in the National Football League draft and routinely comes up with a lost van Gogh.

title: Rio Journal; For Brazil's College-Bound, a Brutal Test of Mettle
description: It is a dreaded rite of passage, known to generations of Brazilian high school students as ''the funnel.'' Every December, just as the rest of the country is starting to ease into the relaxed rhythms of summer vacation, graduates who want to go on to college are forced to prove themselves in a series of exhausting, ferociously competitive and all-important college entrance exams.

title: Sports of The Times; Lemieux's Comeback Is Irresistible
description: YOU did not have to admire Richard Nixon, Elvis Presley or Muhammad Ali to admit that all three staged successful comebacks. As President of the United States, king of rock 'n' roll and heavyweight champion of the world, they enjoyed impressive second acts in their American lives. But each man's denouement -- one politically scandalous, another self-destructive and the third evoking sympathy -- lingers large in the mind.

title: Static Screens of Czech TV Mirror Deep Political Problem
description: A dispute over a new director blacked out state television briefly this week and has brought thousands of demonstrators into the streets, dragged in the president and raised serious questions about the Czech Republic's politics as it pushes to join the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, JOAN
description: MARKS-Joan. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted mother of Susan and Donald Hirsch and Ruth Levenson. Caring stepmother of Howard and Nancy Marks. Dear sister of Richard and Fran Wolff and Barbara and Louis Eisenpresser. Cherished grandmother of Julia. Services Friday 11:30AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to NY Chapter of The Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

title: Another 2000 Record: The Most Recalls Yet
description: CAR buyers want more: more safety technology, more horsepower, more cup holders. What they don't want are more recall notices.

title: TAIWAN TRIMS INTEREST RATE
description: In an unexpected move meant to stave off an economic slowdown, the Taiwan central bank cut a benchmark interest rate known as the rediscount rate by an eighth of a percentage point, effective today. The rate cut is the country's first in two years. The central bank also reduced its forecast for economic growth next year to 5.88 percent from 6 percent.

title: Clinton Scraps North Korea Trip, Saying Time's Short for Deal
description: President Clinton said today that he had decided not to visit North Korea before the end of his term because he lacked the time to put together a deal ending its nuclear missile program.

title: One of Seattle's Newspaper Strikes Is Settled
description: After 38 days on strike, workers at The Seattle Post-Intelligencer announced tonight that they had voted to accept a contract offer and return to work. But strikers at The Seattle Times, locked in a battle with management over the terms of possible layoffs, were still discussing a separate proposal and were not expected to complete a vote until Friday at the earliest.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and a front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's foreign policy misattributed the signing of a trade agreement with China. It was the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, not the president, who signed the agreement in 1999. (This year Mr. Clinton signed the legislation that granted permanent normal trading status to China.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWBERGER, ARNOLD

title: Lots of Style, No First Lady
description: Washington is buzzing with opinions about how the new president should decorate the White House. A few history lessons may be in order, and they can be found in a new book, ''The White House: Its Historical Furnishings and First Families'' (Abbeville Press), by Betty C. Monkman, the White House curator. Ms Monkman, who has been working in the White House since 1967, presents a thorough overview of the decorating and antiques that came and went (and then came back) over 200 years.

title: When Magic Goes Awry
description: Tina is a little girl who says she sometimes feels ''like a fish out of water.'' In short order, she actually becomes one -- well, not a fish exactly, but a certain finned mammal.

title: Judge Upholds Policy on Arresting the Homeless Who Sleep in Boxes
description: A federal judge has upheld a Giuliani administration policy that allows police officers to arrest homeless people for sleeping in cardboard boxes in public. Judge John S. Martin Jr. ruled on Tuesday that a 1969 Sanitation Department regulation barring people from abandoning cars or boxes on city streets could be applied to homeless people sleeping in boxes.
