title: As Bush Ponders Choice of Intelligence Chief, Some Suggest That No Change Is Needed
description: Ever since George Bush served as director of central intelligence in the final year of the Ford administration, he has strongly believed that the post should be above elective politics and not subject to change just because a different president takes office.

title: A Good Deal on U.N. Dues
description: The United States is the United Nations' biggest deadbeat. Conservatives in Congress, led by Senator Jesse Helms, stopped Washington from paying its dues until the U.N. reduced its assessment and made other changes. Now, thanks to the hard work of Richard Holbrooke, America's U.N. representative, and his staff, the U.N. has agreed to trim the nation's share of the financial burdens for both the U.N.'s general budget and for peacekeeping. Senator Helms, who has praised the deal, should release the dues he has been holding hostage -- $582 million of the $1.3 billion the U.N. says it is owed.

Mother of Edward (Renee), Oliver (Shelley), and Olga (Wilbur) Toll. Grandmother of ten, great grandmother of fifteen, great great grandmother of three. Sister of Frances Kaplan, and Mussie Gellis. The gallery is on Third Avenue, near 149th Street, not on Third Street. The artist-activist group known as the Guerrilla Girls was not involved with it.

title: Pataki Says U.S. Is Delaying A Health Insurance Expansion
description: Gov. George E. Pataki voiced an unusually harsh criticism of the Clinton administration today, saying it has delayed approving an important waiver that would allow New York to begin providing coverage to low-income residents without medical insurance.

title: Sega Looks at World Beyond Hardware
description: It was not so long ago that Sega dominated the video game market. Its Genesis game system, released in 1989, broke ground with its dazzling graphics and mind-boggling speed, beating competitors' best efforts by leaps and bounds. But today the game for Sega, at least as a maker of hardware, may be over.

title: AT AUCTION, AES BUYS 61% OF CHILEAN POWER COMPANY
description: Ending a drawn-out takeover effort, the AES Corporation paid $841.2 million for a 61.57 percent stake in Gener, a major power generator in Chile, in an auction yesterday morning. Naveed Ismail, president of AES's Andean unit, said the company expected to buy 25 percent more for about $450 million when the company's American depository receipts are auctioned in the United States today. AES is based in Arlington, Va.

title: DEAL FOR GERMAN COURIER
description: La Poste, the state postal service of France, plans to take control of Deutscher Paket Dienst, raising its stake to 85 percent from 50.6 percent by paying about $390 million for stock held by Frankfurter Kreis. La Poste operates Europe's third-largest parcel delivery service, behind Deutsche Post and the TNT Post Group of the Netherlands.

description: It is a rent fight for the ages.

title: LTV SAYS IT MAY FILE FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: The LTV Corporation said yesterday that it was close to a decision to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because it had nearly run out of money. The company told officials in Ohio, where it has several plants, that falling steel prices and eight consecutive quarters of losses had pushed it to the brink of insolvency, despite cost-cutting moves like the 500 layoffs announced Dec. 6. The company, once a conglomerate stretching from aerospace to meatpacking, was winnowed down to predominantly a steel maker in the 1980's. It went through a Chapter 11 reorganization in the early 1990's. It is considering filing again today in federal court in Youngstown, Ohio. Trading in LTV shares was halted at midday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: After Standing Up to Be Counted, Americans Number 281,421,906
description: The Census Bureau today officially set the population of the United States at 281,421,906 people, a 13.2 percent increase in the last 10 years and more than 6 million above what demographers at the bureau had estimated a little less than three months ago.

title: Tickets Remain For Game In Miami
description: The Dolphins have not exactly generated a groundswell of support this week in South Florida. Their first-round playoff game with Indianapolis on Saturday may not even sell out in time to have it televised in the area. As of this afternoon, just under 12,000 tickets were still available. If the game is not sold out by Friday at 12:30 p.m., it will not be shown in the local television market.

title: Fulton Agrees to Buy Drovers Bancshares
description: The Fulton Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the Drovers Bancshares Corporation for about $144.4 million in stock to gain 17 Drovers and Mechanics Bank branches in southern Pennsylvania.

title: Clintons Said to Have Chosen a New Home
description: Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton has picked her new home in Washington, an elegant, if understated, house at 3067 Whitehaven Street in Northwest Washington, two people who have been involved in the search said last night.

description: Government officials announced plans today to spend $20 billion on public works programs, to jump-start an economy that has been slumping for two years.

title: Return Engagement at Defense
description: Donald Rumsfeld, named by President-elect George W. Bush yesterday as his choice for secretary of defense, is an experienced manager who successfully led the Pentagon once before, under the very different international circumstances of the cold war. But Mr. Rumsfeld's recent close identification with the campaign for early construction of a national missile defense system raises concern that Mr. Bush may try to move too hastily on this front. The emphasis Mr. Bush placed on the issue yesterday only intensifies the impression that he intends to make missile defense the centerpiece of his national security policy.

title: NEW ASIA CHIEF FOR LAZARD
description: Oh Hogen, who oversaw the revamping of South Korea's corporate sector after the 1997 economic collapse, has been named the chairman of Asian operations for Lazard Freres, the French investment bank. The South Korean government forced Mr. Oh to step down as head of the Daewoo Restructuring Committee on Oct. 10, one day before his contract expired, because a deal for the Ford Motor Company to buy the bankrupt Daewoo Motors fell apart.

title: Van Gundy Still Sees Disaster Lurking
description: The Knicks were on their best roll of the season a few weeks ago, having won five of six games, including victories over the highly regarded Minnesota Timberwolves and San Antonio Spurs. The defense was as staunch as ever. The offense moved the ball with crispness and made shots with consistency. And the big backcourt of Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston was being praised.

title: A. H. BELO WILL DO AWAY WITH ITS INITIALS ON MONDAY
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation said yesterday that it would change its name on Jan. 1 to remove the initials of its founder, Alfred Horatio Belo. The company, which publishes The Dallas Morning News and several other newspapers and owns television stations, will become the Belo Corporation on Monday by merging with a new subsidiary of that name. In doing so, the company will not have to wait for shareholder approval. The company traces its roots to the 1842 start-up of The Galveston Daily News, and was acquired by Alfred Belo, then an employee, in 1876. The company was named for him in 1926, when a protege, George Bannerman Dealey, bought it from Mr. Belo's heirs.

title: W. V. Quine, Philosopher Who Analyzed Language and Reality, Dies at 92
description: W. V. Quine, a logician and Harvard philosophy professor whose analysis of language and its relation to reality made him one of the most influential philosophers of the 20th century, died on Monday at a hospital in Boston, where he lived. He was 92.

title: HUMANA AGREES TO SELL PARTS OF ITS H.M.O. BUSINESS
description: Humana Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell parts of its Medicaid health maintenance organization business in Wisconsin and Texas. A subsidiary of the Centene Corporation will take over coverage of 40,000 customers in Milwaukee, Waukesha, Kenosha, Racine and Rock Counties in Wisconsin, while a joint venture of Centene and a Texas association of community clinics will take over coverage of 30,000 customers in Austin and San Antonio. Terms were not disclosed. Regulatory approval in each state is required.

title: CHINA TELECOM NAMES UNDERWRITERS
description: China Telecommunications, the state-run phone service provider in Beijing, chose Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Merrill Lynch as the lead underwriters for an initial stock offering that would be the biggest by a Chinese company and could raise $8 billion. The offering, expected next year, would generate more than $200 million in underwriting fees. The decision is a victory for Merrill Lynch, which has not been a major contender for stock underwriting in China, and a blow for Goldman, Sachs, which has. Morgan Stanley, which has built its presence in China through a joint venture with the China Construction Bank, managed the biggest Chinese offering so far, a $5.7 billion sale by the wireless phone operator China Unicom. China Telecommunications controls about 95 percent of China's fixed-line phone service. Its stock is expected to trade in Hong Kong and New York. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: 3 Generations Partnering in Three-Quarter Time
description: ''Cat's-Paw,'' a play by Mac Wellman from 1995 now at the SoHo Rep, nearly finds coherence as a conventional narrative, which doesn't mean it fails to. Mr. Wellman is an ardent teaser, a writer who always delights in glancing off literal meaning and often in linguistic deconstruction, employing words, parts of words, their sounds, their denotations and connotations in jazzy cacophony. His work is purposely fragmented; his intentions are purposely oblique. That this story of four women representing three contemporary generations has a recognizably linear structure, identifiable themes and characters who speak largely in complete, diagrammable sentences -- it's almost Dickensian by Mr. Wellman's standards -- in some ways makes it all the more tantalizing.

title: Metro Business Briefing; POWER COMPANY LICENSED
description: Green Mountain Energy Company, a seller of electricity generated from windmills and solar panels, said yesterday that it had received a license to become an electricity supplier in Connecticut. Green Mountain, based in Austin, Tex., said it planned to bring energy to Connecticut customers starting next month. The company was a unit of Green Mountain Power Corporation, a Vermont utility, until August 1997. The Connecticut Public Utility Commission approved the license. The company said in October that it would receive as much as $53.5 million from Nuon NV, the Netherlands' largest utility, to help finance its expansion in deregulated energy markets in the United States.

Neals, on Saturday, December 23, 2000, from the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, in Jersey City, New Jersey. Dr. Neals who ran a medical practice for the indigent and others in Jersey City for nearly a half centry, died on December 17th, at home in Jersey City, New Jersey. title: LUCENT OPTIONS 'UNDERWATER'
description: Lucent Technologies said in a regulatory filing that at least 74 percent of the stock options issued to employees as of Sept. 30 had exercise prices higher than its current share price, rendering them ''underwater'' or effectively worthless. The underwater options are complicating Lucent Technologies' efforts to retain employees at a time when the giant communications equipment maker is restructuring its operations after losing market share to competitors. In an attempt to keep employees, Lucent recently changed the way it handles options, allowing recipients to vest each year in a four-year period instead of waiting three years, a Lucent spokeswoman said. Shares in Lucent fell 56 cents yesterday, to $13.13, their lowest level in more than three years.

title: DENTSPLY IS BUYING ONE BUSINESS AND SELLING ANOTHER

It said that it had agreed to buy Friadent G.m.b.H. of Germany for about $100 million in cash to re-enter the dental implant market, and separately that it had agreed to sell InfoSoft, its dental practice software unit, to InfoCure of Atlanta for $32 million in stock. Dentsply, which also makes dental X-ray equipment, dental instruments and a bone substitute, is based in York, Pa., and reported about $830.9 million in sales last year.

title: What the Census Means
description: In establishing the population of the United States at 281,421,906, the Census Bureau discharged an obligation yesterday that it has met every 10 years since 1790. But the bureau's numbers are almost certain to inspire some political battles. The 2000 Census reconfirmed the longstanding population shift from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West, with Republicans in Congress the likely beneficiaries. Now there will be fights in the states over Congressional redistricting. title: WEBMD AND DUPONT END ALLIANCE
description: WebMD, the biggest Internet company linking insurers, doctors and patients, said it had ended a partnership with DuPont in which the chemical maker provided online information and shared WebMD's revenue. The collaboration began in March 1999 and was to expire in March 2004. Under the agreement, DuPont was to provide health care content for WebMD's consumer and physician Web sites and create programs for the drug industry. Earlier this month, DuPont said it would split off its drug unit. WebMD is scaling back its consumer health Web site and focusing on providing software and electronic processing of health insurance claims as it aims to become profitable.

title: WEB DRAWS LAST-MINUTE SHOPPERS
description: Retail Web sites attracted 31.8 million visitors in the last week before Christmas, according to Media Metrix in New York, an Internet and digital media measurement company. That was nearly 11 percent below the peak week of the holiday season for online shopping, which ended on Dec. 3, when there were 35.6 million visitors to the 400 retail sites it tracks, Media Metrix said. Compared with a year earlier, however, the Media Metrix online shopping index for the week before Christmas was up 28.4 percent. Despite declines in traffic to almost all retail sites last week, shopping increased on sites offering last-minute gift alternatives like online cards and online gift currency, Media Metrix said. Among those with the largest traffic increases were Flooz.com, whose site and advertisements feature Whoopi Goldberg; Americangreetings.com; and Hallmark.com. Allison Fass (NYT)

description: TAYLOR-Helen Strauss. On Wednesday, December 27, 2000 of Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late James S. Taylor. Mother of Nicholas C. Taylor and the late Alexandra Taylor Coburn, sister of Elliott B. Strauss; also survived by five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Service and interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The Washington Home, 3720 Upton St., N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016. For information Joseph Gawlers Sons, Washington, D.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, FRED
description: MICHAEL-Fred. We mourn the passing of Fred. Loving husband of Regina. Loving father of Stuart and Bernard. Loving, caring grandfather of Rose, Sara and Shuli. Donations may be made in his memory to Congregation Ahavat Shalom, 315 Madison St, PO Box 220918, Hollywood, FL, 33022. 954-922-4544, or Westchester Day School, 856 Orienta Ave, Mamaroneck, NY, 10543 914-698-8900.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Japan Struggles to Bolster Stocks and Perhaps Banks, Too
description: On the day that major banks announced a rescue for one of Japan's most troubled construction companies, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party floated a plan to prop up stocks that looks a lot like a bank bailout in disguise.

title: Pay Politicians More
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEYAB, BEATRICE (SABBEY)
description: DEYAB-Beatrice (Sabbey), age 79, of Cambridge, MA on December 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles Deyab. Devoted mother of Lawrence, John and George Deyab. Beatrice was an artist and friend of many artists throughout NYC. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Shaping Stories, Shaping Herself
description: HERE'S a deeply impractical resolution for the New Year: suppose we try to become artists in our spare time. Few of us would be any good at it, but so what? It would be a positive move for our psyches, a frivolous act toward no reasonable end except perhaps a personal satisfaction that not even money or power can match.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD TO CUT 1,200 JOBS AND CLOSE A PLANT
description: The American Standard Companies, a manufacturer of automotive and building products, said yesterday that it would cut costs by eliminating 1,200 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force, and by closing one of its plants, though it had not decided which one. The moves stem from a yearlong re-evaluation of the company's operations by its chief executive of 14 months, Frederic M. Poses, the company said. It will take a charge of $82 million to cover costs related to the revamping, partly offset by a $60 million gain from the sale of its Calorex water-heater business. Shares of American Standard, based in Piscataway, N.J., rose $2.13, to $47.50.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend, including New Year's Eve celebrations. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Primedia is allocating millions of dollars to promote its online business operations.
description: PRIMEDIA has begun a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to promote its latest online foray, a redesign of the business-to-business Web sites operated by its Internet subsidiary, IndustryClick.

title: Nicorette Wins Sydney-Hobart Race
description: After pounding through gale-force southerly winds that forced the retirement of 18 boats from a fleet of 83 starters, the Swedish maxi Nicorette won line honors yesterday for the fastest elapsed time in the 630-mile Sydney-Hobart yacht race.

title: Making It On a First Effort
description: Life is sweet for Mike Rich, a lanky 41-year-old Oregonian whose first screenplay has just been made into a major movie with a major star: ''Finding Forrester,'' an inspirational drama that casts Sean Connery as a reclusive writer who befriends a South Bronx teenager.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a plan by the Metropolitan Water District in Southern California to buy privately owned water misstated the amount it expects to buy from Cadiz Inc., a farming company. It is 47 billion gallons each year, not trillion.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It looks like a bar, and that's half right. The chalkboard on the sidewalk suggests a mussels and fries sort of place, and that's dead wrong. Papillon, a place of many contradictions, is an ambitious restaurant grafted onto a boisterous bar, with an Irish chef who spent most of his career in London cooking French food.

title: Haiti's President-Elect Pledges Reforms in a Letter to Clinton
description: Seeking to mend tattered relations with his opposition and the international community, Haiti's president-elect, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has assured President Clinton that he is committed to a broad range of governmental and political reforms, including a runoff for 10 contested Senate seats that had caused an electoral crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, JUDGE LOUIS
description: BLAU-Judge Louis. Beloved husband of Gertrude and devoted father to Yosef, Norman and Andrea passed away on December 22, 2000, the first night of Chanukah, at age 93. He will be missed by his five grandchildren and five great grandchildren as well.

title: Clinton's Trade-Offs: Ancestral Lands and Sacred Sites
description: President Clinton's proposals to the Israelis and the Palestinians outline broad principles for a peace agreement to be negotiated in detail later.

title: Son of 'Nosferatu,' With a Real-Life Monster
description: F. W. Murnau's 1922 silent film ''Nosferatu'' was the first great vampire movie, and it remains, after generations of copies, remakes and rip-offs, among the scariest. In composing his ''symphony of horrors,'' Murnau tapped into the murky depths of European folklore and the reservoir of superstition beneath the cool, rational surface of modern life. The film's images -- a desolate castle, a rat-infested ghost ship and above all the hollow visage of Max Schreck in the title role -- emerge from a commonplace book of nightmares. As the film critic Roger Ebert has written, ''This movie seems to really believe in vampires.''

title: After Dispute Over Ballots, Texas Senate Picks a Leader
description: The events had a familiar ring: a dispute over ballots, an eleventh-hour Supreme Court ruling and a top executive post hanging in the balance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, LOUISE
description: Levin-Louise. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School Community extends our heartfelt sympathies to our devoted board member Susan Levin Schlechter on the loss of her dear mother. We also send our condolences to Bruce Schlechter and the entire family. Shira Nadich Levin, President Roanna Shorofsky, Director

title: Levi Jackson, a Pioneer at Yale, Is Dead at 74
description: Levi Jackson, a star running back whose selection as Yale's first black football captain in November 1948 drew national attention as a symbol of racial progress in American life, died on Dec. 7 at his home in Detroit. He was 74.

title: From the Past, a Way to Save Our Farms
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Reported To Plan Lending
description: The Japanese government's development bank plans to introduce a system to lend money to buyers of financially troubled companies that are being restructured, the Japanese financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported in its Friday issue.

title: Mayor, With Legacy in Mind, Wants to Seal It in the Charter
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would name a commission to propose changes in the City Charter to ''institutionalize'' the work of his administration after he leaves office at the end of next year.

title: Think Simple
description: SOMETIMES gardening is like being lost in the woods. You move from bed to bed and project to project, without ever finding the route to a really pleasing garden. Winter, with its absence of routine outdoor chores, is a great time to stop wandering in circles and think about ways to achieve the goal of making sense of your garden.

title: Variations Make Oven-Cooked Fish Succulent and Exciting
description: THICK fillets of fish are easy to cook in the oven. They can be seared in a nonstick pan or poached in olive oil in a baking dish. Cod, halibut, turbot, bass or salmon are good prepared this way, and emerge juicy and moist. You can use all manner of herbs including parsley, thyme, rosemary and oregano to flavor the fish. Slices of lemon can be cooked underneath it. The lemon loses its harshness and comes out soft and sweet.

title: Ports of Call In Chelsea
description: BONGO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, PETER J.
description: PAPPAS-Peter J. On Friday, December 29, 2000 of New York, NY. Beloved partner of Robert J. Murphy, Jr., loving son of Anne Gleason, brother of Deborah Cambra and Michael Paul and John Pappas, also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Friends may call at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street, Manhattan from 7 to 9 PM Tuesday, and 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered 11 AM Thursday at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 213 West 82nd Street. Interment Private. Memorial contributions may be made to Networth/Positive Action, Inc., 387 Main Street, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601 or Abraham House, 342 Willis Avenue, Bronx, NY 10454.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Pursuit of the Nut Lady
description: With its engrossing story of a small-town murder with big repercussions, G. K. Wuori's first novel, AN AMERICAN OUTRAGE: A Novel of Quillifarkeag, Maine (Algonquin, $22.95), immediately calls to mind ''Twin Peaks.'' But in this case, the victim is more like the town crazy than Laura Palmer. What's more, the local police aren't trying to solve the murder: they committed it. After Ellen DeLay's otherwise loving husband of 26 years accidentally locks her in a large toolbox in the back of his truck for three days, she decides that it's time for a major change. She leaves him, moves into a lonely cabin in the woods and begins dressing game for hunters. Although her business is soon booming, her reputation suffers, and she becomes, in the eyes of the townsfolk, the nutty lady of the woods. When she accidentally shoots off the pinkie of a local man who's on a drinking spree, she ignites the suspicions of the authorities, and four female law enforcement officers descend on Ellen's home, killing her in a panicky hailstorm of bullets. Wilma Doll, one of Ellen's closest friends, witnesses the shooting and determines to settle the score with the official in charge. All this is related by Wilma's father, who gives us context and background and weaves the details of the story into ''a package small enough to be held with horror or embraced with wisdom.'' The appeal of Wuori's offbeat novel is that it shortchanges neither the horror these people visit on one another nor the lessons they learn in order to cope with it. Michael Porter

title: Sports of The Times; Another Leader Heads for Bridge
description: WHAT is there about the Jets that makes coaches so eager to leave them? Is it the Long Island traffic? Is there something in the ground water? Or is there some inherent virus in the Jets' organization that makes men scurry west toward the mainland?

title: Predicting An Upswing In Emerging Markets
description: THEY may not know it, but investors in emerging markets have a lot in common with Brooklyn Dodger fans. Both groups keep waiting for next year.

title: Globalization Grows Up and Gets Political
description: George W. Bush's appointments of Colin Powell, Condoleezza Rice and Donald Rumsfeld as secretary of state, national security adviser and defense secretary, respectively, have been met with general acclaim. But some commentators have wondered how this new team, which is better versed in political and military affairs than in economics (though Mr. Rumsfeld has an impressive background in business) will be able to manage American foreign policy in the age of globalization.

title: Exploratory Oil Drilling From S to X and Back
description: Brazil's state-controlled oil company has always been known as Petrobras. But for a short time last week, Petrobras renamed itself Petrobrax, helping investors tongue-tied from words that end in s or laboring under the misimpression that the company sells women's lingerie.

title: As U.S. Military Settles In, Some in Ecuador Have Doubts
description: United States Navy P-3 reconnaissance planes are parked at the airfield on the outskirts of town, the Pentagon is spending $62 million to expand and improve runways and hangars, and American military personnel are already mingling easily with their local counterparts. But Jorge Zambrano, mayor of this port city of 250,000 residents, would rather not call the project that promises to transform his city an American ''base.''

title: December 24 - 30; Aristide's New Promises
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was elected to the presidency along with a thousands of legislators and local officials of his Lavalas Party, is seeking the one thing that escaped him: international political legitimacy. After meeting with an American diplomatic team, he affirmed his commitment to democratic rule by announcing a series of political and governmental reforms, including a decision to hold a runoff election to determine the true winners of 10 contested Senate seats. He has also vowed to include the opposition in his new administration, introduce economic reforms and work closely with the United States to fight the island's booming drug traffic. David Gonzalez

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Tuckahoe; Village With Strong Sense of Community
description: SINCE its beginnings as a farming community, the Westchester village of Tuckahoe, in the town of Eastchester, has always provided a wealth of opportunities for those who live there. When marble was discovered in 1822, it was sought after nationwide by architects and builders because of its quality and quantity for use in Greek Revival structures like the Capitol and the Washington Monument. Many Irish stonecutters who fled the famine of their homeland for Tuckahoe and, later, Italian workers enjoyed prosperity working in the quarries.

title: Out of Place -- A Virtual Space Odyssey; This Time, the Future Is Closer Than You Think
description: NOW that the new millennium is really about to begin, the futurists' obligatory New Year's Eve forecasts are bound to have a dully repetitive ring. Their predictive powers came out in full force for the dawning of 2000, the false millennium. What is there left to say?

title: Happy (and Healthy) On New Year's Eve
description: For the sixth consecutive year, ''Say Happy New Year,'' an alcohol-free party on New Year's Eve, will be held tonight at the County Center in White Plains.

title: December 24 - 30; Who's the Man? Shaft, John Shaft
description: Each year since 1988, the Library of Congress has selected 25 films it regards as culturally, historically or aesthetically significant and preserved them as part of the National Film Registry. This year, along with classics like the 1931 ''Dracula,'' starring Bela Lugosi, and ''Apocalypse Now,'' the Registry has inducted Gordon Parks' 1971 black detective film, ''Shaft.'' While the original ''Shaft'' is pretty great, this has to be seen as a nod toward the entire, unfairly maligned genre of blaxploitation cinema.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDMARK, MILTON
description: BRANDMARK - Milton. Passed away December 28, 2000. Devoted and caring husband, father, brother and friend. We will all miss him. Services Tuesday, January 2, 2001. 10 AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho, Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: For Whom the Bell Tolls: Exchange Rings Out '00
description: To celebrate the end of the millennium in the final weeks of 1999, the New York Stock Exchange invited a list of celebrities to ring the bell to open or close trading, culminating with the great boxer Muhammad Ali.

title: Bye-Bye 'Blues'
description: When ''Ain't Nothin But the Blues'' left New Jersey two years ago, the revue about the birth, evolution and everlasting life of a musical form was itself evolving. Eric Krebs, the theatrical entrepeneur, who lives in Highland Park, saw ''Blues'' at Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick and rallied other producers and transported the show to Broadway, just in time for Tony Award eligibility. It received four nominations last year. Even though Crossroads won the outstanding regional theater Tony that year, the theater went dark the next season. But ''Blues'' goes on. After more than a year in Manhattan, the show is back in the state for a festive send-off at New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. The last performance is today, at 2 p.m. Alvin Klein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, CLIFFORD
description: JOHNSON-Clifford. Age 79, died on December 17 in his Manhattan home. He will be deeply missed by his wife, Gayle. An admired oil painter who explored themes of light, movement and organic form, his work is represented in many private and corporate collections. Memorial service at the Brick Church, Park Ave. and 91st St., at 4 PM, Monday, January 8.

title: 3 Police Commanders in Bronx Are Replaced as Crime Rises
description: Saying he was concerned that increases in reported crime in three Bronx precincts were not being addressed, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has replaced the precincts' commanders.

title: Worth Preserving
description: To the Editor:

title: Partial to Balanchine, and a Lot of Built-In Down Time
description: THIS year, choreographers visibly looked for new ways of moving. The rhythms of pop music were translated into fragmentary bursts of dancing. At the other extreme, tai chi exercises were turned into a fluid dance idiom. In the West, experimental dance from Asia and Africa has increasing appeal.

title: Residents Are Rankled by Water-Main Construction
description: A year and a half after work began on replacing water mains in their neighborhood, Carroll Gardens residents say problems with noise, vibrations and traffic have gotten worse recently.

title: She Teaches Survival, Learned the Hard Way
description: MARY TAYLOR PREVITE spent five years of her young life at a Japanese concentration camp in China during World War II. Today, she passes on the survival skills she learned to troubled youths in South Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, STEPHEN A.
description: MITCHELL-Stephen A. The faculty, graduates and candidates of the Institute for the Psychoanalytic Study of Subjectivity grieve the devastating loss of the incomparable Steve Mitchell. Those graced by his brilliance as teacher and generous colleague experienced first hand his intellectual elegance, indefatigable curiosity, personal vitality, warmth and irrepressible good humor. For all of us, he changed forever how we think about psychoanalysis. We join the psychoanalytic community in mourning the tragic loss of the leader of the relational psychoanalysis movement and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Margaret Black and his daughters Caitlin and Samantha.

title: FLORIO'S SOFTWARE VENTURE
description: Former Gov. Jim Florio has helped start a company that markets computer software to help municipalities collect back taxes and organize financial files. The creation of Xspand Inc., based in Morristown, was announced earlier this month by Mr. Florio, who is chairman and chief executive officer, and Paul Z. Scura, president and chief operating officer. Karen DeMasters

title: RESTORING STREAMS AND WETLANDS
description: A $5,000 grant from the United States Environmental Protection Agency is financing the county's installation of signs describing the restoration process and ecology of environmentally damaged streams and wetlands in the Long Island Sound watershed. The signs will be installed by this summer at Five Islands Park, New Rochelle High School and Paine Lake in New Rochelle; Flint Park in Larchmont; Edith Read Natural Park and Wildlife Sanctuary, Rye City Middle/High School and Rye Golf Club in Rye; Beaver Swamp Brook in Harrison; and Town Park in Pound Ridge. Elsa Brenner

title: South Africa Looks West for Some Economic Muscle
description: South Africa, long dependent on Europe and the United States for most of its trade, is casting its eyes elsewhere -- and not simply in search of new markets.

title: Aboard the B67 in Brooklyn: Red Alert in a White Tableau
description: At 9:35 a.m. yesterday, the B67 bus had been stuck on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, stretched across an intersection, for 15 minutes when a woman with a rolling suitcase knocked on the door.

title: Word for Word / Measuring a Century; America Then and Now: It's All in the Numbers
description: WITH only 365 days left to fulfill their 32-year-old vision of a space odyssey, the makers of the film ''2001'' already seem to have proved that predicting the future remains infinitely more challenging than dissecting the past. Recently, though, three social scientists pounced on a single 100-year period to quantify American trends that emerged during what they declare to be ''the first measured century'' -- the 20th, which by official measures ends tonight.

title: What's the Best Defense? Start Slow and Hit Hard
description: What do the masterminds of attacking play prefer when they are conducting the black pieces and are not given the chance to make the initial move?

title: . . . Thanks to Mr. Dickens . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Lia Levenson, Evan Oppenheimer
description: Lia Levenson, a daughter of Jeanette and Froim Levenson of Chicago, is to be married today to Evan Lee Oppenheimer, a son of State Senator Suzi Oppenheimer and Martin J. Oppenheimer of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi David Wirtschafter is to officiate at Vincigliata Castle in Fiesole, Italy.

title: Out of Place; The Price of Peace Will Be Paid in Dreams
description: THEY are no longer just refugees, but the children and grandchildren of refugees. Still, in the narrow, muddy streets of Ein Hilweh in Lebanon, Balata on the West Bank and the 57 other camps, where cinder block homes are painted with Palestinian flags and images of rifles, they treasure keys to homes in the Galilee, where they once lived. Old, tattered land deeds with the tax stamps of the British mandate are passed down the generations with equal reverence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: ROUTE 80 SIGNS
description: Drivers on a 34-mile stretch at the western end of Route 80 will begin to see new guardrails and road signs along the highway between now and fall 2002. The overhead and roadside signs and rails between Parsippany and the Delaware Water Gap, in place since the road was built in the late 1960's and early 1970's, are being replaced with $9.5 million in federal financing. Many of the signs are faded or have lost reflectivity and the guardrails have been damaged in accidents. Karen DeMasters

title: How Did So Many Get It So Wrong?
description: OF all the rude awakenings that the bear market in stocks has brought to investors, perhaps the most jarring has been the realization of how woefully wrong Wall Street's research analysts have been this year on the stocks they follow. While the market sank to its worst performance in more than a decade, many of those analysts kept right on smiling and saying ''buy.''

title: The Financial Doctor Is Not In
description: Looking for financial and investment advice at work? Good luck.

title: The Way We Live Now: 12-31-00; The Great Divide
description: American presidential transitions are always beautiful tableaux of near regal courtesy. The loser concedes, saying something like, ''The majesty of the American people has spoken.'' Later the outgoing president spends his last few minutes of power swearing in a man whom, more often than not, he despises. As hypocritical pageantry goes, great stuff.

title: Some Ideas Are Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: People in Blankets, Pups in Boots
description: Temperatures dipped so low last week even the dogs wore boots on their Fifth Avenue walks. Women sheltered their youngsters and pets in voluminous sable and mink. Tourists, many unaccustomed to the biting cold, wrapped their heads in street vendors' hats and scarves. Blankets were popular, and a visitor from Paris wore a patchwork wrap from his native Africa. The deluge of fur included an extravagant ivory-colored mink, near right. A coat seen on several corners was a Victorian-doll navy velvet, edged in white fur, far right. But the crowd pleaser was a strawberry-colored shearling with a deep ring collar.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Living Outside the Law
description: AS students at Harvard Law School, we knew that we would have many options when we graduated. That was the reason that most of us went to school there. But when the big-name firms recruited on campus during our second year, we were dazzled -- or rather blinded -- by the prestige factor.

title: Giant Burts of Green
description: Billing itself as the messiest few minutes on television, ''Slimetime Live'' begins a new season of goo-breaks on Nickelodeon this week, appearing bnetween 4 and 6:30 p.m. during regular Monday to Friday programming. The host of ''Slimetime Live,'' Dave Aizer, matches up an at-home player with a studio audience member, who must face-off against the ''Slime-U-Lator.''

title: Snowy Thrills, With Few Frills
description: I BEGAN checking the Mount Baker Ski Area Web site compulsively about a week before my family's long-planned mid-January ski trip. The daily proliferation of exclamation points made me tingle with anticipation: ''Two hundred inches and counting!'' ''You like it deep? Try three feet of new!!'' And, best of all, the day before our departure: ''Two hundred two inches on top: Largest base in the world!!!!''

title: Do Not Ask What Is It
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Tonight's The Night
description: ONE hundred years ago tonight, the editors of The New York Times positioned an unequivocal headline on the next morning's front page: ''Twentieth Century's Triumphant Entry.'' The lead article began: ''The Century is dead; long live the Century!''

title: NEW CAMPUS IN OSSINING
description: Westchester Community College's latest off-campus location in the Arcadian Shopping Center in Ossining will offer biotechnology, health care, English as a second language and other courses beginning in late January. The college will have two open-house sessions, Jan. 16 and 24, 5:30 to 7:30 p.m., at the new site at 22 Rockledge Avenue. Elsa Brenner

title: Company's New Data Center Allows for Added Services
description: Xand, a managed Internet infrastructure provider in Hawthorne, opened a new 30,000-square-foot data center this month. The center allows the company to offer increased technical resources and security to its customers.

title: A Fit City Offers Russia a Self-Help Model
description: In a nation where the average person barely lives to 66, Nina Nikolayevna Semenovskaya is a most notable exception: 93 years old, and still strong enough to bat out love songs on an equally aged upright piano.

title: Exploring the Affinities Among Painting, Music and Dance
description: MUCH has been written about sisterhood among the arts. It's claimed, for instance, that rhythm in music can be compared with the rhythm of a sinuous line in an abstract painting. But there's also plenty of proof that the arts are entirely different breeds. Whatever side of the argument one takes, it's obvious that there's real difficulty in trying to capture the essence of one art in another. This is borne out by ''Lyrical Visions: Music and Dance in American Art'' at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: Killings Exceed 1999 Toll
description: A man found stabbed to death yesterday in his Chelsea apartment was the city's 668th homicide victim this year, pushing the toll of killings over 1999's count and marking the second straight year in which the city's murder rate climbed. Hours later, the toll rose to 669.

title: For Poor, Health Benefits Are Easier to Have Than to Hold
description: New York State's poor are eligible for some of the most generous health benefits in the country, but the annual process required to renew them inadvertently leaves thousands uninsured for months or longer, say insurance executives, policy experts and state legislators.

title: Jennifer Johnson, Paul Sober
description: Jennifer Love Johnson, a daughter of Mary Ann Johnson and M. Davis Johnson of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married on Friday to Paul Martin Sober, the son of Ingeborg Sober and Dr. Daniel Sober of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Douglas Phillips, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Waybury Inn in East Middlebury, Vt.

title: From the Quiet of a Bedroom, Raw Songs of America
description: I WANTED to let the listener hear the characters think, to get inside their heads, so you could hear and feel their thoughts, their choices,'' Bruce Springsteen has written about his 1982 album ''Nebraska,'' a chilling portrait of an America that has spun off its moral compass. ''I wanted the music to feel like a waking dream and the record to move like poetry. I wanted the blood on it to feel destined and fateful.''

title: Sweet Checkmate For a Team That Faced An Uphill Climb
description: As he peered at the chessboard, Christian Nunez moved the pieces in a series of lightning-fast maneuvers. Less than three minutes into the game, he had trapped his opponent's king.

title: The Neediest Cases; Young Men Learn Life Lessons on a Basketball Court
description: In the week between Christmas and New Year's Day, Intermediate School 90 in Washington Heights was largely vacant during the day as students got a break from their classes. But a third-floor gymnasium at the school was home to the boundless energy of 10 teenagers who were at basketball practice, working on a variety of drills.

title: Judging the Gentlewoman From New York
description: Even if the Senate were not entering the interesting and potentially history-making territory of a 50-50 Republican-Democratic split, it would find itself receiving new, intense attention in the session that begins on Wednesday, simply because Hillary Clinton will be taking office. The other senators will be bombarded with questions about her: what she's doing, how she's doing -- and later, how she has progressed. Some of what's asked will be those all-too-familiar delicate questions for background use only.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: December 24 - 30; Separate Mass Killings In Boston and Philadelphia
description: In one of the country's worst workplace rampages, seven people were killed at an Internet consulting firm in Wakefield, Mass. Prosecutors say that Michael McDermott, a 42-year-old software tester, methodically killed all seven with multiple shots from a semi-automatic rifle and a shotgun, then sat passively in the lobby and let police arrest him. They speculate that Mr. McDermott snapped because the company planned to attach his wages to pay back income taxes he owed.

title: A Cold Eye
description: WHAT was I, a Conservative rabbi, doing in common cause with those with whom I had clashed on many religious, moral and ethical issues -- with the Catholic bishops of New Jersey on the matter of abortion; with the Green Party over their torpedoing of the candidacy of Joseph I. Lieberman; with Amnesty International, which too often employs a disproportionately large microscope to human rights violations of Israel against the Palestinians; and with Ethical Culture on the whole necessity of God as grounding for a moral and ethical life?

title: Across Washington, the Inaugural Rush Is On
description: The protracted vote-counting for the 2000 election delayed the planning for the inauguration of the next president on Jan. 20, but the Texans of Washington, with more reasons than most to celebrate, are well prepared.

title: Shaping Characters
description: ''Sesame Street'' rings in the New Year with a focus on music and art, beginning tomorrow at 7 a.m. on Channel 13. The 32nd-season curriculum emphasizes the importance of the creative process in child development through hands-on projects like the one above, in which Zoe and a friend make their own drawing. Tomorrow afternoon, ''Zoom,'' the on-air laboratory created by kids for kids, begins its third season with a ''Zoom Marathon'' at 4 p.m. on Channel 13. Zoomers old and new, including (back row, from left) Rachel, Kaleigh, Eric and Caroline and (front row, from left) Buzz, Frances and Kenny will participate in two hours of games, arts and crafts, and experiments that demonstrate the importance of lending a helping hand.

title: After a Year, Millennium Dome Calls It a Day
description: If in this season of annual achievement awards there were one for the biggest New Year's bang and sorriest year-ending whimper, the winner would be Britain's entrant, the Millennium Dome.

title: Dude, Where's My Script Doctor?
description: AS revealed in documents recently declassified from the Screenwriters Guild Retirement Spa and Ranch in Oxnard, Calif., the new film ''Dude, Where's My Car?'' was 54 years in the making. And remaking. ''Dude's'' transformation from somber World War I epic to stoner buddy flick traces an enlightening arc of artistic evolution. The subtle changes -- a detail here, a nuance there -- become profound in their totality. The result, in cineplexes now, is genius, a kind of reverse take on death by 1,000 paper cuts.

Next came a dad with two kids on their sleds. The three of them pushed with all their might. Then an ambulance offered a final nudge forward with the gentletap of its bumper.

Set in a quarantined English port during a cholera epidemic in 1831, this well-researched novel uses the crisscrossing experiences of a 15-year-old prostitute, a surgeon and a journalist to explore the underside of 19th-century medicine and the Industrial Revolution. Earlier this year in the Book Review, Annette Kobak praised the author's ''outstandingly generous and fertile imagination'' and her ''limber and vivid'' prose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRITT, FRANCIS SUMNER
description: MERRITT-Francis Sumner, 87. Died Dec. 27, 2000. An innovative educator and visual artist, who as founding director of the Haystack Mountain School of Crafts, Deer Isle, ME, from 1951-1977, created an international community of craftmakers. A painter and print maker, his work was exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern Art and The Corcoran Gallery. Among his many honors he was a fellow of the American Craft Council and The Royal Society of Art. Survived by his wife Priscilla of Belfast, ME, his brother, The Reverend Richard A. Merritt of Nagoya, Japan, two sons, Dr. Alfred M. Merritt of Gainesville, FL, and Steven H. Merritt of St. Isadore, Ontario, Canada, six grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. A celebration of his life will take place at the Haystack in Deer Isle, ME, next summer. Memorial contributions may be sent to Haystack, P.O. Box 518, Deer Isle, ME. 04627.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEARHART, ROBERT PAUL, M.D.
description: GEARHART-Robert Paul, M.D. An attending physician at Lenox Hill Hospital for forty-five years, he died on December 27th, 2000 at the Piedmont Retirement Center in Thomasville, N.C. He was 88 years old. Golda, his wife of 60 years, was at his side. Born in Montoursville, PA., he received a degree in Business Administration from the University of Pittsburgh, before graduating from Temple Medical School in 1939. He interned at Saint Vincent's Hospital in Erie, PA. He then served as Chief Resident at newly opened Triboro Hospital in New York City, before joining the staff at Lenox Hill in 1943. In 1948, he was appointed to the teaching faculty and was named Chief of Pulmonary Medicine in 1964. He served for many years as Chief of the Nursing Health Service and Chief of the Employee Health Service, which were ultimately combined under his direction. With little interest in hospital politics and business, Dr. Gearhart turned down several high-profile opportunities during his career. He much preferred to lead rounds with residents, to brighten the hospital with his spirit and humor, and to dedicate himself to his patients and practice. He retired in 1988. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Susan, and her children Shane and Erin; son Robert, Jr. and his daughter Erin; and son Reid. A memorial service will be held January 13 at the Piedmont Retirement Center (336-474-3804). Donations to the Alzheimer's Association or charity of choice.

title: December 24 - 30; Counting's Not So Hard
description: There are officially 281,421,906 people living in the United States and serving overseas in the military and the diplomatic corps. The Census Bureau's much-awaited decennial count showed a 13.2 percent increase during the 1990's. The state-by-state figures, which will be used to allocate seats in the House of Representatives, show a continuation of the movement of people and political power from the Northeast and Midwest to the South and West. title: An Avoidable Cause Of Breast Cancer
description: In ''Breast Cancer Groups Question New Study,'' [Dec. 3], a number of groups expressed disappointment in recent studies finding no correlation between various environmental factors on Long Island and our relatively high rate of breast cancer. While mention was made of certain factors related to breast cancer, like genetic makeup, age and lifestyle, the article was silent about the one identifiable factor related to breast cancer that is most avoidable. Studies in 1994 and 1996, which included pro-choice and pro-life scientists, have shown that women who aborted their pregnancies substantially increased their risk of breast cancer. Conversely, and this is widely recognized, women who have children reduce their lifetime risk of breast cancer.

For months it was rumored that Riccardo Muti, musical director of La Scala Opera, would come to the Philharmonic -- for months, that is, until last July when Mr. Muti publicly declined the job. title: An Old Highway Wends Its Way Onto the Historic Register

This was part of King's Highway, which connected the two cities. A 10-mile stretch of the old highway that is now Route 27 and Route 206 has been placed on the New Jersey Register of Historic Places and is expected to be named to the National Register. Before the game was over, Lemieux had one more assist and a goal of his own in a 5-0 victory over Toronto. The grateful cheering echoed from coast to coast across a 30-team National Hockey League. description: KAMINSKY-Wallace. Architect. Collector. Life long and passionate New Yorker. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Columbia University School of Architecture, Wally practiced in Manhattan for forty years. He specialized in projects for educational institutions and for organizations serving low income, mentally challenged and homeless people. Loving father of Michael, Alex and Jenifer. Proud grandfather of Allison, Zack and Calla. Long time partner of Susan Lushing. Caring brother of Muriel (Miki) Crespi and Hank. Passed away on December 28. A memorial service will be arranged at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to an arts organization of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLEBACH, PRISCILLA WARDWELL
description: CARLEBACH-Priscilla Wardwell of Mystic, Connecticut, formerly of Bedford, New York. Beloved wife of William, Mother of Michael Lloyd Carlebach and Stevenson Wardwell Carlebach, Grandmother of Adam, Joshua, Katy and Matthew Carlebach and of Priscilla Smith Rathbone, beloved sister of Alice Wardwell Tripp and Augustine Kelly. Born in Chappaqua, New York in 1924, Priscilla left college in her freshman year to marry William Carlebach in 1942. Many years later she graduated from Manhattanville in her 50's and went on to get her Masters Degree, also from Manhattanville. A non-stop reader and a fine gardener later in life she also became a fine watercolorist. She had a generous spirit and a wonderful sense of humor. For these, and for her many other attributes, she will be missed by all who knew her. There will be a memorial service at St. Marks's Episcopal Church on Main Street in Mount Kisco, New York at 2 P.M. on Saturday, January 6, 2001. The Dinito Funeral Home, 17 Pearl Street, Mystic, Connecticut. Memorial contribution may be made to: St. Mark's Church, Main St., Mt. Kisco. National Audubon Society. National Resources Defense Council.

title: Making Like a Mogul
description: Hollywood is a town where lots of people will go to extremes, so it should be no surprise that the W Los Angeles in Westwood offers an Extreme Weekend package. The aim is to make guests feel like Hollywood moguls (at a mogul's price: $1,295 a night per double room). It includes a 1,000-square-foot suite with two bedrooms and two bathrooms, use of a luxury-class convertible (such as a Volvo, Mercedes SLK or Porsche Boxter), four one-hour spa treatments and an hour with a personal trainer. Guests also receive a round of martinis and a book of color photographs of Los Angeles. Call (877) 940-8357.

The moment calls for forthright introspection, so we'll pause here to present a few of the more piquant observations we've received over the past 12 months.

description: SOUTH AFRICAN bulbs are a great way to get through the winter, and more and more of them are available in America. They are easy to care for indoors once you have their rhythm, which in North America is to flower in winter and go dormant in summer.

Yet analysts at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco have figured how much portfolio wealth has vanished because of once highflying initial public offerings.

title: Livingston Journal; Town Sees Blight, but Mall Owners See Promise
description: As far as strip malls go, the Livingston Manor Shopping Plaza is a fairly unremarkable conglomeration of commercial architectural styles: there is a quaint clapboard section abutting a faintly Art Deco addition, its turquoise bricks more evocative of South Beach than North Jersey. Built in the 1920's, the plaza, a trapezoidal collection of stores, occupies the heart of this sprawling, self-confident town, where schools are stellar, crime is rare and many houses fetch well over a million dollars.

title: December 24 - 30; Hark! That's No Herald Angel
description: Just because all the presents have been opened and the deliriously discarded mountains of wrapping removed doesn't mean parents have heard the last of Christmas. Their children's toys will likely be talking -- or squawking, chirping, barking or belching -- around the house for months to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOERFLINGER, WILLIAM M.
description: DOERFLINGER-William M. Died on Saturday, December 23, 2000, at Fellowship Village in Basking Ridge, NJ. He was 90. Born in New York City, he was a longtime resident of Convent Station before moving to Fellowship Village in 1999. In World War II he served in North Africa and Italy in the Office of War Information. During a long career as an editor at MacMillan and E.P. Dutton, he edited hundreds of books, including works by Woody Guthrie, Francois Sagan and Sir Edmund Hillary. A graduate of Princeton and Harvard, Mr. Doerflinger wrote Shantymen and Shantyboys: Songs of the Sailor and Lumberman (1951), an important compilation of folk songs collected mainly on the New York waterfront and in Nova Scotia. He was a member of the Princeton Club and the International Brotherhood of Magicians, both in New York City, as well as the Morristown Unitarian Fellowship. His wife, the late Anne (Homer), died in 1995. Survivors include his five children: Jonathan Warner of Pelham Manor, NY, William Warner of Santa Barbara, CA, Anne Bishop of Sausalito, CA, Katherine Doerflinger of New York City, NY, Thomas Doerflinger of Summit, NJ, ten grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on January 20, 2001, at the Morristown Unitarian Fellowship at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations are being accepted to the Morristown Unitarian Fellowship, 21 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown, NJ 07960. For information, contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, Basking Ridge, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about changes in the Washington social scene foreseeable under the new presidential administration misstated the name of the hotel that houses the Jockey Club restaurant, site of a traditional preinaugural party. It is the Westin Fairfax, no longer the Ritz-Carlton. The article also misidentified the president whose commerce secretary was Robert Mosbacher, the former husband of a prominent Republican fund-raiser, Georgette Mosbacher. It was George Bush, not Ronald Reagan.

title: Where bin Laden Has Roots, His Mystique Grows
description: Hemmed in by 2,000-foot rock massifs, this village seems, by measure of its beauty and mystery, altogether more like a place to stay than to leave. Yet Al-Ribat's villagers, driven by poverty, have migrated for centuries -- in recent decades, mostly northward, out of Yemen and across the vast desert known as the Empty Quarter that forms a barrier between here and Saudi Arabia.

title: Things Are What They Used to Be
description: I have been trying to remember the night I first saw Jane Monheit, but a synaptic gremlin keeps switching on my childhood memory of watching the Beatles on ''The Ed Sullivan Show.'' The reason, surely, is their hair, so startling in both cases that it distracted me from the music. Monheit was about 20, and she was sitting in with a small jazz combo at an Upper Manhattan nightclub called Augie's. Dressed for comfort like the undergraduate she was, casual at the microphone, she sang a romantic Tin Pan Alley ballad in a voice I can scarcely recall. Her face and most of the top half of her body were covered by a fishing trawl of curly brown hair. Nothing occurred to indicate that I might be watching anyone but another of the countless talented young women serving their apprenticeships in New York's clubs, cabarets and piano bars every night. Besides, I already knew who the Next Thing in jazz singing would be: Dominique Eade.

title: Homebuyers Slowly Warm to the Net
description: WHEN it comes to shopping for a mortgage, many homebuyers find the Internet the best source for researching a loan, comparing interest rates and evaluating lenders. But when they're ready to finalize a deal, homebuyers usually turn off their computers and head to a nearby bank or broker.

title: Corrections

He is Mark Siegel, not Spiegel. The report also misstated the hours of the telephone counseling. They were 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Eastern time, not 8 to 4.

title: Reckonings; Real Reality's Revenge
description: At this time last year a share in WebMD -- formerly Healtheon, the ''new new thing'' of Michael Lewis's best-selling book about Silicon Valley -- was worth about as much as 1.5 megawatt-hours of wholesale California electricity. But since then tech stocks have plunged, while power shortages have driven prices in California's electricity market into the stratosphere. WebMD has actually weathered the dot-com crash better than many other companies, but right now you would need to sell about 75 shares to buy a megawatt-hour.

Is there a way to get the erudite and benighted alike to spell aesthetic the same way? To distinguish between that and which or lie and lay or who and whom?

description: Revelers in Times Square tonight will witness the fruits of determined snow removal that cleared the way for hundreds of thousands to crowd into the streets north of 42nd Street to watch the ball drop at midnight.

So, asked to write about the new business book ''Now, Discover Your Strengths,'' I approached the book's centerpiece -- the Gallup Organization's online personality test -- with trepidation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESKONONTS, MORRIS (MURRAY)
description: ESKONONTS-Morris (Murray). Beloved husband of Rose. Devoted father of Laurie and Mark Serwetz & Mordecai. Adored grandfather of Robbie and Rachel Serwetz. Cherished uncle and dear friend. Services were held on Friday, December 29, at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ANGELS walk among us, at least in Wim Wender's satisfyingly existential drama WINGS OF DESIRE (1987). They can hear our thoughts, and sometimes they put a hand on a human shoulder and we feel new strength and hope (thinking we dredged it up ourselves). And as we lie dying, they come to put beautiful thoughts in our heads (''the old houses of Charlottenburg, Albert Camus, the morning light''). Bruno Ganz plays one such angel, assigned to Berlin, who tires of his purely spiritual existence, falls in love with a trapeze artist (Solveig Donmartin) and gives human existence a try. The great Henri Alekan did the gorgeous black-and-white cinematography. This is a real original, even if it's sometimes a little too taken with itself - Tuesday at noon and 5:45 p.m., Wednesday at 9:30 a.m. on IFC.

title: For Rosa Parks, a Place of Honor
description: A museum and library have opened in Montgomery, Ala., in honor of Rosa Parks, whose refusal to move to the back of the bus 45 years ago started a boycott that unfolded into the civil rights struggle. The Rosa Parks Library and Museum is on the corner where Mrs. Parks, a seamstress, told the driver on Dec. 1, 1955, that he could have her arrested, but she was not leaving her seat because a white man was standing. The arrest led to a long boycott of the bus system and a Supreme Court decision that forced racial integration of the city transportation system.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOSEPH A. CALIFANO Jr.; Lessons From the Battle To End Workplace Violence
description: TWO years ago, deeply embarrassed and concerned about the catch phrase ''going postal'' and all it implied, the United States Postal Service commissioned a major study of on-the-job violence. The panelists surveyed about 15,000 postal and private-sector employees and closely reviewed 29 workplace rampage killings, seeking trends and possible remedies.

Moreover, I have used Greyhound and other bus lines on numerous occasions and have never witnessed any acts of violence en route. People ride buses not because they are immoral but because they cannot afford plane fare, or perhaps because they are tired of cramped seats and delays.

description: Edward H. Braun is chief executive and chairman of Veeco Instruments Inc., a maker of fiber optic and disk-drive technology equipment, in Plainview, N.Y.

title: Hellos, Goodbyes
description: Dec. 18: Two hundred guests attended a retirement party for Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center for 17 years. The party was held in the center's Kaplan penthouse.

title: ABUSE BY RABBI FOUND
description: The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations issued a report last week confirming allegations that a prominent New Jersey rabbi had abused numerous teenagers under his supervision. Although Rabbi Baruch Lanner of Paramus has not been formally charged with any crime, a commission appointed by the organization found widespread instances in which young men and women were sexually, physically and emotionally abused during the three decades he oversaw the organization's youth division and a yeshiva. Prosecutors from Monmouth and Bergen counties are investigating the allegations. Rabbi Lanner, 50, who resigned from the organization last summer, has denied the charges. Andrew Jacobs

What we normally perceive as life as usual suddenly becomes a vision of heaven or hell, of a redeeming future or a yawning abyss. Viewed along these lines, the year 2000 was a sad one for the theater, most notable for losses that signaled the ends of creatively fertile eras. But, if you looked hard, there were heartening signs of new life stirring and a couple of spectacular acts of resurrection.

description: Tucked away among the boutiques of SoHo is a shop quite different from the others. title: POSTINGS: All Stars Project Heading to 42nd Street; Performance Center Planned
description: The All Stars Project Inc., a 19-year-old nonprofit theatrical production company with headquarters in a 9,000-square-foot loft in SoHo, signed a contract on Dec. 20 to buy a 30,000-square-foot performing arts center in Midtown. The center, at 529 West 42nd Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues, will occupy the ground floor and basement of the building. The All Stars Project plans to construct rehearsal and performance spaces as well as three theaters: two of 99 seats for experimental plays and a 250-seat off-Broadway theater.

description: WILD THING has calmed down. Deborah Copaken Kogan, working as a photojournalist in 1989, was eager to sleep in Afghan caves and bed men from Maryland to Romania. She writes in detail about both in her memoir, ''Shutterbabe: Adventures in Love and War,'' out next week from Villard: ''Men are like books, to be read -- or skimmed, studied or forgotten, enjoyed for the moment or digested in a forever kind of way . . . they can't all be 'Anna Karenina,' but that doesn't mean I can't enjoy them just the same.'' title: Mega-Cats Compete In Race Around World

The only real certainty is that a gun will sound and the boats will go. But what happens afterward is anyone's guess, for in the 30-year history of globe-circling sailboat racing, no one has seen anything quite so audacious or ambitious as The Race.

description: WHEN Thabo Mbeki, president of South Africa, visited Brazil early in December, his hosts made a point of bringing him here in hopes he would be dazzled, as so many other guests have been, by this country's growing technological and military capabilities. Brazil's space program was born in this trim and tranquil city of 500,000 people, as were companies specializing in the production of armored vehicles, rockets and munitions.

The pass, which was introduced last month, is a package of 3 to 10 coupons; passengers must choose their destinations and pay in advance, but they do not have to select their travel dates beforehand. The coupons are good for three months.

On the other hand, he could be celebrating the fact that his company's stock had declined only 15 percent in value, not 50.

title: A Scholar-Statesman Retires
description: The retirement of Daniel Patrick Moynihan from the United States Senate deprives the nation's upper house of a grand thinker whose trenchant views have not always been fashionable, even among his political allies. Now untethered from daily politics and unleashed from the Senate's ruthlessly partisan atmosphere, Mr. Moynihan can range even more freely, giving voice to the nuances and rhetorical adventures that are increasingly unwelcome in American politics. After this year, his 24th in the Senate, Mr. Moynihan will join the faculty at Syracuse University. What politics loses with the departure of this daring and unpredictable intellectual, academia now gains in a political visionary.

title: Two Disparate Works Are Brothers Under the Skin
description: THE Swiss composer Frank Martin is best remembered in the concert hall for his sprightly ''Petite Symphonie Concertante.'' But in the early 1940's, as war raged around neutral Switzerland's well-defended borders, he wrote two large-scale death-haunted vocal pieces that occupy a singular niche within his canon: ''Der Cornet'' (''The Standard Bearer''), for contralto and chamber orchestra; and ''Sechs Monologe aus Jedermann'' (''Six Monologues From Everyman''), originally for baritone and piano, subsequently arranged for full symphony orchestra. Without so much as an anniversary to account for the coincidence (Martin was born in 1890 and died in 1974), New York audiences this season are hearing both. Last month, the Finnish mezzo-soprano Monica Groop joined Robert Spano and the Brooklyn Philharmonic for the New York premiere of ''Der Cornet.'' Beginning on Thursday, as prelude to the ''German Requiem'' of Brahms, Kurt Masur conducts the first New York Philharmonic performances of the ''Jedermann'' Monologues, with the German bass-baritone Thomas Quast hoff as soloist.

I had been told that one of those rescued, the skipper of the Squalus, Oliver F. Naquin, was subsequently involved in another monumental Navy disaster -- the tragic loss of the heavy cruiser Indianapolis in 1945, during the last days of the war. ''Abandon Ship!'' dealt with that disaster. First published in 1958, it was on the New York Times best-seller list for more than three months. And, as I had been told, Naquin did play a pivotal role in the loss of the Indianapolis.

title: FILM: THE YEAR IN REVIEW; A Year That Was Very Good. Or Very Bad.

By year's end, a story in USA Today reported that some critics and industry-watchers were declaring 2000 the worst year for movies since the advent of sound, and there has been widespread pining for the vanished golden age -- 1999, to be precise. Where, wondered critics and moviegoers, was this year's ''American Beauty'' or ''Being John Malkovich''? To make matters worse, several large theater chains, after a period of precipitous expansion, teetered on the edge of bankruptcy. A potential actors' strike threatens to bring production of new movies to a halt next spring. Nobody wants to see serious movies; fewer and fewer foreign films make it into American theaters. The big studios are content to make hundreds of millions of dollars on overhyped, mediocre pictures -- ''M:I-2,'' ''Gladiator,'' ''The Grinch'' -- that people see more out of habit and desperation than enthusiasm. The sky is falling!

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Pictures in Large Type
description: Everything in Art Shay's background qualified him to be a member of that slightly off-center species, the news photographer. As he relates in ALBUM FOR AN AGE: Unconventional Words and Pictures From the 20th Century (Ivan R. Dee, $29.95), he came out of the East Bronx, learned how to do a job under pressure while engaged in bombing missions during World War II, and trained in the rough-and-tumble school of Chicago daily newspapers in a time when you were fired if your pictures weren't gorier, funnier or more schmaltzy than those of the always-tough competition. Shay's strength, as with all top-of-the-line photojournalists, is not just in Tri-X film and luck, but with his eye for the incongruous -- the Senate crimebuster Estes Kefauver raising his hands in mock surrender to a small boy brandishing a cap pistol or Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago fondling a harp, his facial expression suggesting he is thinking of it for a grandchild and not a political rival. But Shay also had a sense of the macabre, as shown in his picture of the corpses of two Chicago nurses, victims of the mass murderer Richard Speck, waiting their turn on hospital autopsy tables. And he could capture poignancy, as in an image of a shop window filled with bridal-gowned mannequins, reflecting a very pregnant young woman walking by and an older one reading a newspaper. Shay's running commentary to his half-century of shooting pictures is crisp, erudite and at times hilarious. David Murray

''We're not looking to limit news racks in terms of organizations being able to sell,'' Mayor Christine Korff said. ''We just don't want racks to be chained to decorative light poles, or in places where they impede pedestrian traffic or block handicapped access areas.'' The dog was being walked at the Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla when it dashed onto the pond's thin ice and fell through. Police and fire officials could not reach the dog, so the county police department's aviation unit went into action. Barry Silverman, a police pilot, flew a helicopter to the scene, where a county police officer, Carl Eberle, hopped on the landing gear and grabbed the dog as the helicopter hovered inches above the ice. ''We don't cut corners just because it's a dog,'' said Detective William Rehm, a spokesman for the county police. ''We treat it just like we would a human in distress.'' Corey Kilgannon

title: Ideas & Trends; A League Of Its Own
description: NO less an observer than Alexis de Tocqueville noted that America is, to paraphrase, a nation of joiners (does anyone remember the home organ club craze?). But today, clubs that call meetings seem so old-fashioned. Venerated institutions with a broad focus on civic good -- the Rotary Club, the N.A.A.C.P., the Kiwanis -- have been losing market share roughly since the mid-60's, overtaken by niche-market groups like the Sierra Club, the AARP and even Greenpeace, in which membership is a matter of opening a checkbook. Last week, the 81-year-old League of Women Voters stumbled, announcing that its financially strapped New York office would close.

title: Triple Crown Performance
description: If for some reason you still haven't had enough of the holiday season, there is more celebrating to come next weekend. The Fiesta de los Tres Reyes Magos, marking the star-steered visit of the three kings of the Orient to the newborn Jesus, is marked Jan. 6 throughout Latin America. It will also be celebrated at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, with music, dance and giant puppets. ''Los Tres Reyes: The Three Kings'' will be put on by the Hudson Vagabond Puppets, with dancers and students of New Jersey Performing Arts Center's Arts Academy Residency Program taking part. The story is told in English and Spanish narration. Performances are next Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m.

title: There Stays the Hotel and the Neighborhood

Trump made plans in the early 1990's for three cozy, slightly threadbare buildings opposite the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City: New Jersey's casino development authority would use eminent domain power to condemn them and turn over the property to the Trump Organization, which would expand its hotel.

title: Drawing a Line In Tenafly
description: For Chaim Book, an Orthodox Jew, an eruv is simply a symbolic enclosure consisting primarily of existing utility poles and wires to delineate an area where observant Jews can push baby strollers and wheelchairs and carry objects outside their homes on the Sabbath.

title: The Persistent Nets Cannot Beat the Snow
description: The Northeast snowstorm buried the Nets' travel plans to Chicago for this afternoon's game against the Bulls, frustrating the coaches and players who awoke at 6 a.m. yesterday and traveled for seven hours only to go almost nowhere, slowly.

title: Food With the Powerful Tastes of Brazil
description: EATERS, rather than diners, make up the happy throng devouring Brazilian bargains to the music of a bossa nova beat at the new Videira Restaurant in Huntington Station. They care not that the lusty Brazilian home cooking that draws them to this 32-seat storefront, at 1803 New York Avenue (631-424-1915), is served on plastic plates and cardboard cups accompanied by plastic utensils (a soon-to-be installed dishwasher will result in regular china). Of more importance to them are the powerful Brazilian stews, steaks, chops, chicken and fish dishes that come with wonderfully smoky black beans, fastidiously cooked rice and a too vinegary house salad. Most entrees cost only $7.95 at dinner and $4.95 at lunch (four daily specials are priced at $8.95 and $9.95).

title: A White-Hot Housing Market Finally Cools
description: THE region's ultimate adult toy, the million-dollar-and-up home, is suddenly losing its frenzied appeal and languishing longer on the real estate market shelf.

title: Check the Tires? Few Remember
description: MOST consumers seem to have decided that their tires are maintenance-free, according to a telephone survey by the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

title: Recognizing Alsace
description: As speculation about an economic slowdown in 2001 mounts and thrifty buying strategies become important, Europe's most undervalued region of affordable premium wines springs to mind: Alsace.

title: Brookhaven Swears In A New Supervisor
description: Edging out two fellow council members and a county legislator, Councilman John Jay LaValle, 33, was sworn in last week as the 67th supervisor of the Town of Brookhaven, the biggest and most populous of Suffolk County's 10 towns.
