title: Broncos' Offense Meets Ravens' Defense, and Something Has to Give
description: The Denver Broncos sank from being back-to-back Super Bowl champions to having a 6-10 record last season. Two seasons ago the Broncos were the toast of the National Football League and the king and savior of the American Football Conference. The A.F.C. had dropped 13 consecutive Super Bowls to the National Football Conference and was being denigrated as the league's weak link.

title: Bush's Task: Deciding How He'll Spend A Big Surplus
description: WHEN Bill Clinton moved into the White House eight years ago, the economy was starting to gather strength but the federal budget deficit was getting bigger, leaving the new president handcuffed when it came to fiscal policy.

title: A Healthy Sprewell Invigorates the Knicks
description: Five games ago, Latrell Sprewell pronounced himself healed. The back spasms that had dogged him for most of the season were no longer causing him pain, he said, and a return to the explosive, high-rising Sprewell of old was soon to follow.

title: Wall Street Bids Farewell to a Bad Year
description: Following recent wild swings, the stock market steadied last week. But a final sag in the Nasdaq composite index on Friday made it certain that the technology-laden index would finish the year with the worst annual performance in its 29-year history. A 39 percent slide followed a record 86 percent Nasdaq leap in 1999.

title: Streetscapes/'There's Nothing Wrong With White-Glazed Brick Buildings'; For an Architect of the 60's, Simplicity Works Best
description: THE white-brick apartment house of the 1960's seems to be at the nadir of fashion, as lobbies, sometimes even whole facades, are being revamped to look decades older. But like the last Confederate soldier, there is Robert L. Bien, who entered the architectural profession at the knee of his father, Sylvan, designer of the Hotel Carlyle, built in 1930. At 77, the younger Bien is still working, but he has a low opinion of the retro-traditional style: ''It's just a yuppie fad -- there's nothing wrong with white-glazed-brick buildings.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about a Connecticut Supreme Court's refusal to hear Lorna Wendt's appeal of her $20 million divorce settlement from Gary Wendt, a former General Electric executive, referred incorrectly to William J. Lavery, the judge who denied her earlier appeal for a higher amount. He is chief judge of Connecticut's Appellate Court, not its Supreme Court.

The Rev. Alfredo Balinong officiated at the St. Anthony and St. Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Port Antonio, Jamaica.

title: The War Racketeers
description: He is known in international law enforcement circles as ''Victor B.'' Born Victor Anatolyevich Bout in Tajikistan in 1967, he was trained in the Soviet military as a pilot and navigator in the waning days of the Soviet Union. Today, according to two United Nations reports, he oversees a network of more than 50 planes and multiple cargo charter companies ferrying weapons from Eastern Europe into Africa's war zones. Operating from a base in the United Arab Emirates, Mr. Bout personifies a new generation of weapons and diamond smugglers who prey on the world's most vulnerable regions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BORGE, VICTOR
description: BORGE-Victor. The family of Victor Borge would like to express deep appreciation to all of those whose affection and concern have comforted them in this time of their great loss. Contributions in Mr. Borge's memory may be made to any of the following organizations: The Endowment Fund for Victor Borge Hall at Scandanavia House; Thanks to Scandanavia; World Wildlife Fund.

title: A Haunting New Opera Amid Happy Returns
description: BEST NEW WORK OF THE YEAR -- Nothing is more important to the state of classical music than the introduction of a fine new work. I heard many this year, but the one that keeps coming back to me is Kaija Saariaho's affecting opera ''L'Amour de Loin,'' which was given its premiere in a ravishing production by Peter Sellars at the Salzburg Festival in August. The novelist and poet Amin Maalouf provided the composer with the best libretto written in some time, a mystical tale, loosely based on history, of a 12th-century prince and troubadour who nurtures an idealized love for a beautiful countess from Tripoli of whom he has only heard. The work is not flawless. Ms. Saariaho misses the understated humor in Mr. Maalouf's text. But her haunting and beautifully colored score, while nodding to Debussy and Messiaen, is deeply personal and utterly accomplished.

title: December 24 - 30; More Drug-Resistance Seen
description: Drug-resistant infections are difficult to treat, and sometimes fatal. And such infections are on the rise, an ominous trend that scientists attribute to overuse of antibiotics in people and farm animals. Studies published in the Journal of the American Medical Association and the New England Journal of Medicine showed increases in resistant bacteria in children and adults with pneumonia, meningitis, bloodstream infections and food poisoning. Denise Grady

title: A Pop Music Lover Gets to Belt Them Out
description: CHRISTINE OHLMAN is a dual personality. Relaxing alongside a crackling fire in her North Branford home, she's a mild-mannered, self-taught pop music enthusiast, sharing her views on everything from Randy Newman's 1974 album ''Good Old Boys'' (''so brutally honest,'' she said, ''no one could ever make it today'') and the guitar skills of R.E.M.'s Peter Buck to her carefully organized collection of deep Southern soul 45's from the 1960's and 70's.

title: Lonely Gay Teen Seeking Same
description: Thanks to Jennifer Egan (Dec. 10) for a thoughtful and honest article, and to your staff for the courage to publish it. The Internet has literally become a lifesaving tool for young L.G.B.T. (lesbian/gay/bisexual/transgender) individuals. I know that the impact it had on my life as a young gay man has helped me to become the person I am today. Egan also does not shy away from the dangers of life on the Net, like stalkers, deception and pornography.

title: Their Own Profile
description: A lot has been written and said about the New Jerey State Police lately, little of it by the force's 2,700 troopers themselves. To change that, the troopers' union, the State Troopers Fraternal Association, has started its own web site, www.stfa.org. ''Whatever the perceptions may be,'' said Christopher J. Burgos, first vice president of the troopers union, ''our mission has never changed, our goals are to serve the public.'' The site, which was announced this month, includes a gallery of antique photos and a ''Real Stories,'' section, with accounts unlikely to appear in news reports on racial profiling. Like this one, from ''Troopers, Behind the Badge,'' a book by John Stark, quoting Sgt. First Class Phillip (Gentleman Phil) O'Reilly, who patrolled on a Harley Davidson in the 1940's: ''The patrols were beautiful On a spring day, there was nothing lovelier than riding through the countryside.'' Steve Strunsky

title: New Airport Shortens The Trip to Patagonia
description: Patagonia, a wind-swept region of ancient glaciers and snowcapped mountains, just got a lot closer. Last month the sleepy Argentine town of El Calafate (population 6,000) inaugurated a modern airport that will save outdoor enthusiasts upward of two days round trip in getting to some of the region's most impressive sights. The spacious $25 million airport will provide year-round links to Buenos Aires, about 1,800 miles to the northeast.

title: Caviar and Champagne, Taken Externally
description: New Year's Eve is reaching new depths of decadence and indulgence as consumers of caviar and Champagne are no longer just eating the stuff, but bathing in it. Ginny Ferrara, the spa director at Park Avenue Spa & Fitness at the Swissotel (Park Avenue at 56th Street), has just added a New Year's gimmick to her spa menu: a Champagne and sea salt body scrub ($100 for 45 minutes). ''It's not that Champagne has a specific property that nourishes the skin,'' Ms. Ferrara said. ''But it leaves it feeling tingly and perky.'' By mid-January, the spa will also offer a Champagne bubble bath ($75), a 30-minute soak in a tub of Champagne and warm water. In keeping with the spirit of New Year's, Ms. Ferrara has also developed a facial ($95) using tiny black beluga esque jojoba beads, filled with moisturizing oils and caviar extract that are meant to moisturize dry skin. After the hourlong treatment, a vodka-based cleanser is used as an astringent. For those who have no other plans to ring in 2001, spa appointments are available at midnight tonight. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, CLAIRE C.
description: BAUM-Claire C. Well-known resident of Jupiter, FL, passed away Thursday, December 28, 2000 at her residence. She was a resident for eighteen years moving here from Brookville, LI, NY. Mrs. Baum was a valued member of St. Jude Catholic Church, Turtle Creek Country Club and a former member of Meadow Brook Country Club in NY. Mrs. Baum was an accomplished entertainer, singing in three languages at the Stork Club, the Rainbow Room in NY and the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, DC, among others. A close friend of Irving Berlin's, she was the featured singer on Ed Wynn's Texaco Hour on CBS radio. Survivors include her daughter, Joanne Claire (Bonnie) Baum of Long Beach, CA., and nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her husband, Seymour Baum and her son, Robert Brian Baum. The family suggests contributions in Mrs. Baum's memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Inc, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407. A memorial mass will be celebrated at 10 AM Wednesday at St. Jude Catholic Church, 214 North US Highway #

''I feel that it is now necessary to leave Rage because our decision-making process has completely failed,'' he wrote in a statement issued to the news media. title: December 24 - 30; Clinton Pulls a Fast One
description: Usually the nominations for federal judgeships work this way: a president nominates someone and the Senate decides whether to confirm the choice. But President Clinton made an end run around the Senate in naming Roger Gregory to be the first black judge on the appeals court that sits in Richmond, Va. He did so while the Senate is in recess, saying the reason was that the Republican majority had blocked all his previous efforts to put a black person on that court. Republicans fumed at Mr. Clinton's political poke in the eye, but at the week's end seemed undecided on how to respond. Neil A. Lewis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCHRIDGE, WILSON W.
description: LOCHRIDGE-Wilson W., age 77. Died suddenly Friday, December 1, 2000. in Aptos, California. He was born in Chicago, Illinois and grew up in Evanston, Illinois. Married for 51 years to his wife, Marjorie P. Lochridge, he raised his family in Winnetka, Illinois. He and his wife later moved to Weston, Connecticut and moved to Aptos in 1989. Mr. Lochridge worked in advertising at the New York Times from 1957-1985, in both the Chicago and New York offices. He was a member of the United States Army Air Force and a World War II veteran. He had a keen interest in the First World War. He was at one time a private pilot. He volunteered as a docent at the Henry Cowell State Park Nature Center in Felton, California for several years, where he enjoyed meeting people from all over the world. He was a lifelong jazz enthusiast. He leaves his wife, Marjorie P. Lochridge, of Aptos, California, daughters and sons-inlaw Elizabeth and Ron Ward of Aptos, California, Lisa and Mike Tracy of Marion, Iowa, and three grandchildren, Leslie, Michael and Samuel, and one brother, Ben S. Lochridge of Vero Beach, Florida. His parents, Willard and Florence Lochridge, and brothers W. Fiske Lochridge, William Riley Lochridge, Robert S. Lochridge, and John H. Lochridge, preceded him in death. Services were private. Contributions can be made to one of his favorite organizations, the National World War II Memorial Fund, American Battle Monuments Commission, Attention: GR048, P.O. Box 96074, Washington, D.C., 20090-6074.

title: As the Tate Towered, a Giant Guggenheim Got a Lift
description: BIGGER AND BIGGEST -- A peculiar year. To begin peculiarly, with institutions, there was the colossal popularity of the new Tate in London, a healthy sign, I suppose, never mind whether the installation or the architecture are particularly great. Then, in New York, mayoral approval finally came for an even bigger modern art museum, the Guggenheim downtown near Wall Street, designed by Frank O. Gehry. Is bigger always better? That will be a topic for years to come if the building, a behemoth and sure-fire civic symbol, as the Tate has already become, is not undone by the inevitable deluge of complaints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDSON, ANN PAYNE
description: EDSON-Ann Payne. Beloved daughter of the late Christy Payne Jr. and Katharyn Wilhite Payne, also deceased, passed away on Wednesday, December 13. Ann is survived by daughter Christie Soffel of Washington, DC, and brother Neill Hunter Payne of Fouke, Arkansas. Ann was born May 24, 1934, in New York City. She spent her early years in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and remained until the mid '70's. Ann graduated from Mount Mercy Academy in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and attended the Traphagen School of Design in New York City. Ann divided her time between Sarasota, Florida, and Wainscott, NY. She left Pittsburgh in the mid '70's and relocated to New York City for several years. During her Pittsburgh years Ann worked as a fashion model. Ann also implemented one of Pittsburgh's first drug abuse prevention programs through HUD's Office of Economic Opportunity, working with inner city youth in drug prevention and self-care. Mrs. Edson was a member of Shadyside Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. Known for her outstanding abilities to entertain friends and family in her home, Ann decided while in New York City to turn her talents into a profession and became a well known caterer in New York City and Long Island's Hamptons. Throughout her life, Ann supported the arts. In Sarasota she was an active volunteer for the Florida West Coast Symphony Association for several years. Ann was a recognized artist herself. Most of her painting took place at the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art in Amagansett, NY. Ann painted and worked in several art mediums, including acrylic, watercolor, charcoal, batik and collage. Displays of her artwork can be seen at the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art (summers only) and also at the Payne Mansion in Sarasota, Florida-a home built by her grandfather Christy Payne in 1934, which is now a museum for the Marie Selby Gardens. Ann was also a firm supporter of the conservation and research efforts of Selby Gardens, which is also known worldwide as a major source of reference for tropical plants, in particular orchids and bromeliads. Ann actively volunteered at Selby Gardens, assisting with the many social and cultural events held at the Gardens each year. The Payne Mansion is used for receptions and special events and is often featured as Selby's Holiday House and Designer Showcase. A foundation in memory of Ann Payne Edson to support both the Marie Selby Botanical Gardens in Sarasota, Florida, and the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art in Amagansett, NY, is in the works. Donations to either organization are welcome. Address contributions to Marie Selby Gardens, 811 South Palm Avenue, Sarasota, FL 34236 or to The Victor D'Amico Institute of Art, PO Box 1266, Amagansett, NY 11930. Memorial services will be held in Sarasota, Florida, and Amagansett, NY.

title: Schubert's Poets
description: Considering that Schubert wrote more than 600 songs in his truncated life, many at top speed, he did remarkably well at choosing poems to set. In addition to prolific variations on standard themes of love, God and death, his music immortalized verses about fish, flowers, streams, pigeons, colors, sad journeys and famously, his own love for music itself. Next Sunday afternoon in Princeton, the German baritone Matthias Goerne is to sing a recital of Schubert songs grouped by poet instead of cycle or theme. Instead of often-heard settings of Goethe and Rellstab, the poets on the program at McCarter Theater are Schiller and four others far less known today. Mr. Goerne, a pupil of the renowned baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, is not much older than Schubert was when he died at the age of 31. Staying within the bounds of the non-cutting-edge German repertory, Mr. Goerne successfully chooses to delve rather than span. The pianist for this recital is Eric Schneider. Leslie Kandell

title: A Business Finds New Ways to Feast On Its Young
description: POP GENOME PROJECTS -- Cloning technology was successfully applied to sheep in 1997 and, apparently, to song-and-dance boy bands in 2000. Only a near-pubescent girl could distinguish the Backstreet Boys from 'N Sync, 98 Degrees, O-Town or the parody band 2gether. In 2000, the appearance of innocence was no longer the only selling point for teenypop; looking for longevity, Britney Spears started to bump and grind and 'N Sync sang about cybersex. Meanwhile, top-secret music-business laboratories, or their parental and management equivalents, also brewed girl groups, teenage country singers, even a teenage classical soprano. Like the Social Security system, the record business hopes to rely on the labors of its youngest contingent to stay solvent.

title: Ample Reasons for Keeping Both Hands on Wheel
description: There is one simple fact not mentioned regarding dial-and-drive restrictions [''Hands Off!'' Dec. 24] that even Jerry Della Femina would have a hard time controverting or making light of: If a person took a road test with only one hand on the wheel, let alone with the distraction of being on the phone, he'd legitimately fail the test on the spot. If such action is considered dangerous enough to be grounds for denial of a license, it cannot be considered anything but hypocritical for such action to be regarded as acceptable by someone who's already licensed. For the rule not to prevail in both situations would make the test a farce.
